wine: J. Lohr 2000 Hilltop Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Paso Robles)
appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: Held back nearly five years, this Cab still has some sturdy tannins, but I would drink it now because the fruit's in a precarious position. It's rich and tasty now in black currants and cherries, but too soft to age.

Rubbery, bold and earthy on the nose, then full and sticky in the mouth, with sweet black fruit flavors. Tastes more like a Bordeaux red wine than textbook Pinot Noir courtesy of heavy extraction, darkness and oak. Tastes good but could use a lesson in elegance and restraint.

wine: Quinta do Portal 1999 Quinta do Portal Reserva Red (Douro)
review: Smoky, meaty aromas lead into perfumed fruit flavors. The tannins are soft but dry; the fruit is very aromatic with a touch of violets and some rich, dark tannins underneath. The wine will age well—probably 5–10 years. —R.V.

wine: Tenuta di Ghizzano 2006 Il Ghizzano Red (Toscana)
review: The nose is rather neutral save for distant aromas of cherry fruit, boysenberry and spice. However, the mouthfeel is more interesting thanks to the wine's chewy succulence and fresh, zesty close: An 80-20 blend of Sangiovese and Merlot.

This intriguing blend of Falanghina, Biancolella and Pepella (three relatively unknown indigenous grapes) has a candy- or soda-like quality that recalls butterscotch and caramel. However, those notes are balanced by an elegant mineral tone and the wine has good dimension on the close.

appellation: Livermore Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: This is a hefty Barbera, replete with dark, brooding layers of rich cinnamon and anise, especially aromatically, and a chewy texture. Structured, it's leathery yet juicy, touched by oak, with a suggestion of petrol on the finish. But with Nonna's lasagne? Great.

wine: Krupp Brothers 2007 The Doctor Red (Napa Valley)
review: An ambitious blend of Merlot, Tempranillo, Malbec and Cabernet Sauvignon, grown mainly on Atlas Peak. It's bone dry and locked down in tannins and acidity, offering little relief, but there's a potent core of blackberries and black currants that yearns to bust through. Clearly well grown, it could be an ager, but predictions are risky.

wine: Yvon Mau NV Premius Brut Rosé  (Crémant de Bordeaux)
review: Made in a traditional style, this is a fruity, crisp blend of Cabernet Franc and Merlot. With its freshness allied to the attractive strawberry flavors, the wine has both a ripe character and a buoyant mousse and aftertaste. Drink now.

A big, ripe wine, full of berry fruits and rhubarb, edged with tannins, spice and red plum skins. It has a juicy, rich quality, enhanced by acidity, and rounded with vanilla. Keep for a year. Screwcap.

Founder Clive Paton is a keen conservationist, and proceeds from the sale of this wine go toward Project Crimson, which replants threatened red-flowering trees around New Zealand. The nose is a little reductive, requiring a few minutes to get going in the glass, but when it does, it's quite fragrant, with bright red berry fruit, potpourri, floral, pepper and sap characters. It's medium bodied, and the juicy, slippery fruit is tightly wound with sappy, earthy tannins and slightly bitter oak spice. Drink now–2024.

wine: Merry Edwards 2011 Sauvignon Blanc (Russian River Valley)
appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: Despite a chilly vintage, the winery successfully avoiding the green fruit that plagues so much Sauvignon Blanc from 2011. While the wine is dry, it's rich in citrus, pear, tropical fruit and honey flavors, with a touch of spicy oak.

Brushy aromas of wild herbs along with cherry and plum scents feed into a fresh, fairly full palate. This is generously oaked for basic Malbec, and thus spice and resin notes share the stage with plum and blackberry flavors. A dry, spicy, resiny finish is the close.

wine: Château le Prieuré 2007 Grand Cru Classé  (Saint-Émilion)
review: Situated on the plateau of Saint-Emilion, just east of the city, Château le Prieuré has produced a finely structured 2007, not big, but well balanced. Touches of cocoa and cinnamon spice cap the solid fruit and dry tannins. Age for 3–4 years.

wine: Casa da Passarella 2012 Colheita Tinto Red (Dão)
review: A fresh and fruity, juicy wine that is just touched by the tannins and structure of the Dão region. It is a wine to be consumed young for its berry fruits and perfumed acidity. Drink now.

wine: Leone de Castris 2018 Il Medaglione Primitivo (Salento)
review: Aromas of blood orange, baked plum and cherry are lifted by potpourri spice on the nose. Rounded and juicy on the palate, a succulent red fruit jam flavor is honed by racy acidity and fine-grained tannins.
This semisweet wine has a flowery bouquet of jasmine and citrus blossom. The florality continues to the palate, combining with flavors of pineapple, ginger and apricot before a slightly sweet finish.

wine: Herdade do Rocim 2014 Vale da Mata Reserva Red (Lisboa)
review: From a small vineyard owned by the Vieira family for several generations, this wine is dense, impressive and packed with rich black fruits. Its tannins and smoky, tarry character are now almost mature, and the result is very fine. This major wine will be ready to drink from 2020.

appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: Deep and dark aromas of black currant, elderberry jam, dark chocolate and an elegant layering of herbs show on the nose of this bottling. There's a dense frame of opulent black cherry and purple flowers on the sip, which is framed by upright yet smooth tannins.

wine: Laetitia 1999 La Colline Pinot Noir (Arroyo Grande Valley)
appellation: Arroyo Grande Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: There's a complex mélange of aromas and flavors that one taster felt incorporated too many citrus and vegetal notes, but the rest of the panel enjoyed the cherry, herb, cocoa, cinnamon, citrus and olive notes. Smooth and polished, this combines structure and immediate appeal. Good now, but best after 2004.

wine: Bouchard Père & Fils 2008 Ancienne Cuvée Carnot Caillerets Premier Cru  (Volnay)
designation: Ancienne Cuvée Carnot Caillerets Premier Cru
review: Structured and concentrated, it has a silky richness that is very Volnay, while at the same time giving the bright fruits of the year. The final tastes are smoke and crisp acidity.

wine: Winery of Good Hope 2011 Bush Vine Chenin Blanc (Stellenbosch)
review: This wine shows good balance between the lively acidity and ripe notes of red apple flesh, pear and orange oil. The round mouthfeel of ripe fruit flavors are lifted on the finish by a tangy, green plum and lime zest accent. Drink now.

The enthusiastic use of wood for this wine gives a dark, spicy character that masks any fruit. Less new wood would have helped highlight the natural fruitiness of the wine. Leave it until 2020 and the fruit may fill out. Winemaker Stephan Carrier returned from Napa to take over winemaking after Irish businessman Lochlann Quinn bought the property in 2001.

wine: Testarossa 2015 Tondre Grapefield Pinot Noir (Santa Lucia Highlands)
appellation: Santa Lucia Highlands, Central Coast, California, US
review: Plump mulberry and black plum aromas are generous but reserved enough on the edges to keep it elegant, lifted by spicebox and sweet tobacco touches. Lovely layers of flavors explode on the palate, with a strong spicy character lifting the core of dark red fruit. There's also an earthy flavor, and perfect acidity binding it all together.

wine: A.A. Badenhorst Family Wines 2015 Ramnasgras Cinsault (Swartland)
review: Notes of rosehip, clove, nutmeg, red currant, rhubarb and wild strawberry all abound on the nose and mouth in this fresh, vibrant wine. Fine tannins lend a soft structure to the medium-weight palate, with bright acidity providing freshness and levity. Hints of Dr. Pepper and tart red currant ride out the mouthwatering close. Drink now–2021.

appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: This fine Napa producer has set up a Paso Robles operation and here is the result. This is a soft, hot country Zin, with plummy, raisiny flavors, considerable alcohol, and nonexistent tannins. The wine is dry, with a fruity finish.

appellation: South Eastern Australia, Australia Other, Australia
review: Tight in the nose, with hints of tomato and black plum. The flavors veer toward plum and cherry, as there's quite a lot of fruit here. Furthermore, it's nice and easy on the palate. Some toasty oak appears on the finish, which is buttery and fairly long. —M.S.
This 100% Inzolia has aromas of Bosc pear, white flower and Granny Smith apple. The aromas carry over to the easy-drinking palate accompanied by bright acidity that gives the wine a refreshing close.
A fresh, delicious wine, the natural richness of the botrytis balanced beautifully with acidity. It is ripe but delicate, a style that floats over the sweet fruit.

wine: Melville 2002 Clone 76 - Inox Chardonnay (Sta. Rita Hills)
appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
review: An entirely unoaked wine designed to showcase its terroir, which it does in the tartly crisp acidity and streamlined citrus and apple flavors. The wine drinks severe and steely sharp. The bottle I tasted was also a little fizzy.

wine: Geyser Peak 1999 Reserve Alexandre Meritage Red (Alexander Valley)
review: The quintessential Alexander Valley Cabernet, always dependably soft, fruity and complex. This year is one of the best ever. Plush and velvety, with endless nuances, it's like sipping the essence of black cherries steeped in kirsch. Dry, with just enough oak to add smoke and spice. Editors' Choice. —S.H.

wine: Leonetti Cellar 2018 Holy Roller Red (Walla Walla Valley (WA))
appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Coming from the winery's plantings in the Rocks District, this wine is 83% Cabernet and 17% Sangiovese. The aromas are redolent with notes of dark fruit, dried herbs, moist earth, flowers, cocoa and spice. The black fruit flavors are dense and supple, displaying impressive intensity and more structure than is often associated with this region. The finish shows exceptionally long hang time.

This is one of the sweetest white California dessert wines out there. It's addictively decadent, like an upscale Sauternes. Barrel fermentation in new French oak gives an opulent, palate-flattering honeyed vanilla richness to the apricot, peach, pineapple and crème brûlée flavors that are so rich and refined. Crisp acidity provide clean, vibrant balance. Just gorgeous, and worth the price.

wine: Brokenwood 2008 Cricket Pitch Cabernet Sauvignon-Shiraz-Merlot-Petit Verdot Red (South Eastern Australia)
appellation: South Eastern Australia, Australia Other, Australia
review: Dark hints of charred oak and cola accent bright berry aromas, while the palate is marked by bold berry and black cherry flavors and a whack of vanilla. It's a medium-bodied red that comes across as a bit hard-edged because of its acidity despite having rather soft tannins. Drink now.

appellation: North Coast, North Coast, California, US
review: Jammy aromas, figgy flavors and a very smooth mouthfeel define this medium-bodied and straightforward wine. Without much of the typical tannins, it's easy on the palate.

The color and aromas stir intrigue, but the brutally sharp palate that runs on steam-roller acidity does it no favors. Succulent to the point of sour, and giant to the point of overdone, this wine needs to head back to the garage for a tune-up.

appellation: South Eastern Australia, Australia Other, Australia
review: This may only be a medium-bodied red, but it crackles with the exciting flavors of the northern Rhône, marrying freshly cracked peppercorns with a hint of meatiness and bright blueberry fruit. Drink now.

appellation: Mendocino County, Mendocino County, California, US
review: Well-acidified, the fruit shows a long hangtime character of marvelously intense tropical fruits, spices and flowers. The wine spreads a honeyed richness all around the mouth, but it's dry.

wine: Cellers Unió 2014 Roureda Llicorella Clàssic Red (Priorat)
review: Drilling aromas of graphite and balsamic dark fruits open this intense, pulling blend of 50% Carignan, 25% Garnacha and 15% Merlot. Roaring berry, chocolate and pepper flavors get brushed aside by the tannic roughness of the finish. Give this plenty of air before pouring; drink through 2024.
A shy nose gives only slight glimpses of russet-pear peel and earth. The palate emphasizes a textural, earthy element with lemon crispness and finishes refreshingly dry and bright.

wine: Palivou 2004 Ammos Terra Leone Single Vineyard Selection Agiorgitiko (Nemea)
designation: Ammos Terra Leone Single Vineyard Selection
review: A darker, denser red that offers chocolate, black fruit and spice on the nose and palate. A spin of nutty spice and dried fruit punctuates the cherry and raisin fruit. Slightly Port-like and heavier, this wine will soften with time in the bottle.
Aromas of rose petal, red berry and tobacco lead the way. The juicy palate offers raspberry, white pepper and star anise set against firm tannins. Drink 2021–2029.

wine: Château Pavie 2015 Arômes de Pavie Barrel Sample  (Saint-Émilion)
review: 91–93. Barrel Sample. Spicy and ripe, this wine has a strong structure of brooding tannins. There are also great black plum and blackberry flavors here that are super-ripe.

wine: Wyndham Estate 2007 Bin 333 Pinot Noir (South Eastern Australia)
appellation: South Eastern Australia, Australia Other, Australia
review: Wyndham 333 delivers fabulous Pinot aromas of cherry, raspberry and mineral at a very modest price. The palate is serious, with lovely strawberry flavors but falls a bit flat on the plush finish. Drink up.

A new-wood-dominated wine, this has a heavy toast character, with extracted licorice and dark chocolate flavors as well as a big black-plum note. Rich and weighty, with juicy acidity, this demands many years of aging.

Almost a baby in Colheita Port terms, this is a bright, ripe and fruity wine. It does have some touches of wood aging although they are left behind by the honey and orange marmalade flavors that have a light sprinkling of ginger. Drink now.

wine: Chimney Rock 2005 Elevage Blanc White (Stags Leap District)
appellation: Stags Leap District, Napa, California, US
review: Lots to like in this dry, elegant wine, which is a Graves-style blend of Sauvignon Blanc and Sémillon. The flavors are quite complex, with nectarine, peach, pineapple and flowery buttercup accented with a nutty, cashew-rich oiliness. All that richness is perfectly balanced with crisp acidity.
Fruity aromas of tropical fruit and white peach carry over to the simple palate along with the barest hint of bitter almond. Fresh acidity gives it a bright finish.

This opens with spicy aromas of incense and star anise that mingle with cedar and eucalyptus. The chewy palate offers dried cherry, licorice and tobacco alongside solid, somewhat grainy tannins. Drink through 2027.

wine: Philo Ridge 2009 Unfiltered Pinot Noir (Anderson Valley)
appellation: Anderson Valley, Mendocino County, California, US
review: A light yet concentrated Pinot Noir, this has a cherry flavor and a spicy texture. Give it some air to allow the better side of its earthy aromas time to unravel.

wine: Tertulia 2010 Redd Brand BDX Red (Columbia Valley (WA))
appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: It's the Carmenère (14%) that pops first on this Cabernet Sauvignon and Cabernet Franc-dominant blend. Aromas of braised jalapeno pepper are followed by coffee, vanilla and dark fruit. The coffee and cherry flavors are light, with some grit to the tannins and a warm finish.

wine: Perelada 2017 Stars Reserva Brut Nature Sparkling (Cava)
review: Yeasty aromas of freshly baked white bread are lightly toasted but short on fruit. On the palate, this brut nature is dry, crisp and hints at minerality. Flavors of fresh green herbs and citrus fruits precede a light finish.
Aromas of lemon peel, crushed chalk and Golden Delicious apple lead to the dry chalky palate. The pithy finish offers hints of white pepper and river rock.

wine: House of Nobilo 2007 Icon Sauvignon Blanc (Marlborough)
review: A pleasant step up for Nobilo's top-of-the-line Sauvignon, offering slightly smoky, herbal but balanced aromas and plenty of melon and stone fruit flavors. It's full-bodied and rich, with a long, refreshing, slightly herbal finish.

Pinotage's “love it or leave it” character—bright red fruit, plucky spice, a touch of rubber—is in full force here, meaning the wine will pair well with grilled meats and stews and is both fun and exotic. Flavors are balanced, acidity good, and the finish is dry and clean.

wine: Kracher 2016 Nouvelle Vague Nummer 2 Trockenbeerenauslese Zweigelt (Burgenland)
review: An intense streak of dark mint chocolate immediately hits the nose. This is followed by fruity notions of spirit-soaked plums. The palate concentrates on those plum flavors, with their luscious cinnamon-stoked aromas that are pervaded by a welcome freshness. That ethereal pervasive miny lift that was first encountered on the nose continues to add an extra dimension on this marvel of purity and flavor.

Aromas suggesting toasted nut and a whiff of adhesive bandage form the subdued nose. On the lean and racy palate, brisk acidity accompanies suggestions of medicinal herb, lemon rind and bitter walnut.

From the estate, in the Pritchard Hill area of St. Helena which is worthy of its own appellation, comes this densely structured, impressive but young wine. It's massive in fruity extract and new oak, flooding the mouth with soft, ultrarich flavors of blackberries and dark chocolate and a leathery, peppery, grilled meat quality. This is the kind of wine even a non-red wine drinker will be dazzled by, and connoisseurs will appreciate its power and finesse. Ready now for sheer opulence, and should develop through 2012, at least.

A dark, brooding wine, packed with firm tannins and solid plum-skin and licorice flavors. The wine is dense and complex—a powerful evocation of Malbec—allowing the juicy fruits to merge with the young structure that needs agng for at least 4–5 years.

wine: Domaine Au Pied du Mont Chauve 2014 Le Charmois Premier Cru  (Saint-Aubin)
winery: Domaine Au Pied du Mont Chauve
review: This Picard family wine is still showing wood-aging flavors that contrast with the fresh red-cherry fruit and acidity that is light and perfumed. The wine still needs its balance, which will come in the next months. Drink from 2020.

wine: Companhia das Quintas 2005 Quinta do Cardo Selecção do Enólogo Red (Beira Interior)
designation: Quinta do Cardo Selecção do Enólogo
review: Cool and tight, this is a firmly tannic wine, showing its mineral, primal rock character. The structure is dry, solid, the fruit a layer of cranberry and black fig among all this firmness. It should age, but is ready now.
Off-dry to sweetish, this has honey, orange, apricot, lime and vanilla flavors. It shows Sauvignon's clean, brisk acidity, but that taste of sweetness limits its appeal.
Acidity shows strongly in this wine along with the dry tannins. It has weight, suggesting ripe fruits that need to develop. Drink this wine from 2021.

Sweet spice aromas of cinnamon and vanilla come at the heels of bright berry fruit and cherries. This is a plush, modern Merlot (with 15% Cabernet Sauvignon for extra texture and dimension) that offers well-integrated layers of fruit and oak spice. The mouthfeel is round, soft and long-lasting.

wine: Pear Valley 2013 Pear Valley Vineyard Zinfandel (Paso Robles)
appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: Rather elegant and well integrated aromas of stewed black cherries, clove, gingerbread and vanilla are reminiscent of a rich dessert. The palate is also full and flavorful with similar components as well as brown sugar, Vietnamese coffee, purple flowers and a lifting mint component. It's fruity but nuanced and fairly priced.

Honeysuckle and yellow stone fruit aromas lead the nose of this wine. On the fresh, medium-bodied palate, white almond accents back up ripe peach and apple flavors while a salty mineral note marks the close.

wine: Schramsberg 2008 Blanc de Blancs Sparkling (North Coast)
appellation: North Coast, North Coast, California, US
review: Made from 100% Chardonnay grown mostly in Napa and Sonoma counties, this charming bubbly is one of the best blanc de blancs on the market. It's rich and honeyed and feels so good in the mouth, carrying flavors of oranges, sweet limes, Meyer lemons, vanilla and toasty bread. Drink over the next six years.

Ripe, savory and smoky up front, this is oozing blackberry, cassis, bacon and leather aromas. The palate on this minerally Rioja is as juicy, ripe and fresh as they come. Flavors of plum, berry, herbs and oak are integrated, classy and finish long, with a touch of coconut and raw wood that will likely disappear with more bottle age. Drink through 2025.

A majority varietal, this wine also contains Merlot and Cabernet Sauvignon, combining for a taste of baked blackberry and licorice, the oak subtle in smoke. With a tannic bite on the midpalate, it resolves into smoother, velvety textures on the finish, inviting one in for another try.

appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Very citrusy and lifted, forward, scented with orange and lemon peel, cranberry and orange flesh. Unique and persistent, the orange peel character continues all the way through.
Birillo is a soft but straightforward red wine from southern Tuscany that would pair with roast chicken or stuffed turkey. It shows savory aromas of ripe fruit, cured meat, smoked beef and root beer.

Solid and a touch earthy, with rubbery berry fruit and a bit of herbal essence. Crisp, firm and snappy in the mouth, with berry, cherry and peppery herbal flavors and finish. Nothing but regular; decent for the price.

Aromas of gumdrop, lemon juice and anise create a stylish impression, however, the wine turns more zesty and tangy in the mouth. Flavors of grapefruit, lemon and apple are open yet ultimately rather simple.

appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
review: Lush with aromas of ripe red plums and cherries with a hint of warm, golden toast, this is a charming everyday wine that's easy to drink yet offers a satisfying degree of depth. Bright acidity, tart Morello cherry flavors and soft tannins meld elegantly on the palate, leading to a finish that's rich with mocha and dark, toasted oak.

wine: Apollonis NV Cuvée Authentique Meunier Blanc de Noirs Brut Pinot Meunier (Champagne)
designation: Cuvée Authentique Meunier Blanc de Noirs Brut
review: It is no surprise that this producer situated in the Marne Valley has a predilection for Pinot Meunier. The Champagne with ripe fruits and a generous texture was, according to the producer, “cultivated with music.” The wine's freshness is exemplary and delicious. Drink now.

appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: Deep and dark blueberry aromas are laced with blackberry-balsamic reduction, black tobacco, black sage and a brooding spice character on this blend of 71% Syrah, 24% Grenache and 5% Mourvèdre. It's thick and chewy on the palate, with ripe purple fruits clinging to a dense backbone of bacon fat and fudge.
Aromas of sawdust, coconut and espresso lead the way while the palate offers raw sour cherry and just a hint of cinnamon. However, this completely lacks fruit richness and has an abrupt finish.

Although this wine starts well, with scents of lime, stone fruit, gunmetal and mineral oil, it never really gets going on the palate, where the understated flavors of peach and pear end on a citrusy note. Imported by USA Wine Imports.

wine: Monte del Frà 2009 Tenuta Lena di Mezzo  (Amarone della Valpolicella Classico)
appellation: Amarone della Valpolicella Classico, Veneto, Italy
review: Here's a delicious Amarone, with aromas of spirit-soaked black cherry and spice. The palate is rich but refined, with succulent black cherry, raspberry and plum flavors all layered with nutmeg and white pepper accents.

This Missouri Vignoles offers a nose of orange Muscat, pepper and warming spice, followed by slightly sweet flavors (despite its dry designation) of apricot, pineapple and citrus. Balanced acidity and a pleasant, round mouthfeel. The finish is substantial, with a spicy flair.

appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Viognier is a clear success story for Wilridge. This is not a flashy wine, and it goes down easily. It's deeply concentrated, with a rich core of peach, apricot and lemon drop flavors.

wine: Efeste 2012 Jolie Bouche Boushey Vineyard Syrah (Yakima Valley)
appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: This exuberant wine has aromas of raspberry jam, thyme, orange peel, earth, iron and olive. It's rich and intensely flavorful, with waves of mouthwatering fruit and savory notes that lead to an extended finish.

Earthy, oaky, leathery berry and spice aromas come around nicely with airing. This is a plump Rioja with modern leanings; it has good structure and pretty raspberry and cassis flavors. A round finish hints at raisiny maturity but doesn't overdo the ripeness. Drink through 2015.

wine: Shale Ridge Vineyard 2001 Estate Grown & Bottled Merlot (Monterey County)
appellation: Monterey County, Central Coast, California, US
review: This is an easy-drinking and affordable Merlot of a kind flooding the market now. It has ripe flavors of blackberries and cherries and is dry, with good weight and some complexity. Finishes with a youthful bite of acid.

appellation: Lake County, Lake County, California, US
review: Tasting mature and mellow, this medium-bodied wine has a tinge of amber in the color and offers lean red-cherry and cider flavors.

wine: Domaine Christophe Camu 2007 Beauroy Premier Cru  (Chablis)
review: Still young, closed and tight, this exhibits intense, crisp minerality. At this stage, the wine is all texture, with its green and white fruits suppressed. There is a vivid, vibrant character, which promises aging over the next 4–5 years. Imported by Cellar Door Selections.

appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: Blackberry, sage and thyme flavors are at the core of this wine. It's a bit herbal, but well-balanced nonetheless, showing moderate length on the finish.

wine: Markus Huber 2019 Ried Alte Setzen Grüner Veltliner (Traisental)
review: A streak of bright lemon zest accompanies the ripe, green conference pear note on the nose. The palate then adds slightly bitter but completely pleasant citrus pithiness that seems to evolve into yeasty, salty, savory pepperiness without ever leaving that lemon note behind. This is slender but intense and comes with a wonderfully savory finish.

Aromas suggest crushed blue flower, tilled soil, spice and perfumed berries. The savory palate delivers ripe black cherry and wild raspberry alongside notes of clove. Supple and smooth, it will offer easy drinking enjoyment now through 2016.

wine: Les Vins Bréban 2015 Château Castel des Maures Cuvée Jeanne Rosé (Côtes de Provence)
designation: Château Castel des Maures Cuvée Jeanne
review: From a small vineyard near the coast at Hyères, this wine has the freshest red-berry fruits and lively, bright acidity. Its freshness and lightness make it a fine apéritif style, delicious to drink immediately.

wine: Domaine de la Côte de l'Ange 2018 Red (Châteauneuf-du-Pape)
winery: Domaine de la Côte de l'Ange
review: Whiffs of tar and charred wood lend a smoky tone to plump black cherry and cassis flavors in this producer's “tradition” or standard-label bottling. A blend of 70% Grenache, 15% Syrah and 15% Mourvèdre vinified partially in foudre, it balances a richness of sunny black fruit against savory nuances of leather, earth and fur. Soft in tannins, it's welcoming young but should improve through 2028.

appellation: Santa Maria Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: The nose on this bottling is extremely subtle, with hints of stone fruit and citrus. The palate is extremely crisp and clean, with Asian pear, lime peel and hints of oak smoke. The focus is tightly wound texture more than overt flavors.

wine: Rafael Cambra 2013 El Bon Homme Red (Valencia)
review: Scratchy cherry and raspberry aromas are lightly herbal. This 50-50 blend of Cabernet Franc and Cab Sauvignon is tightly wound, with punchy acidity. Herbal raspberry and red-plum flavors finish dry and lightly oaked, with rawness and herbal notes.

Jammy strawberry aromas are alluring but light, which suggests more of an Old World style compared to most of the beefy, brawny Malbecs out there today. The palate is crisp and agile, with light-framed raspberry flavors. More elegant than hefty, but also a little hollow on the midpalate and finish.

appellation: Côtes du Rhône, Rhône Valley, France
review: In this wine, almost equal proportions of Grenache and Syrah yield a steady balance between plush, easy black fruit and darker notes of peppery herb and granite. Fleshy and full bodied yet bright with acidity, it's an appealing wine marked by delicate touches of dark chocolate, bramble and sweet spice.

wine: Talbott 2005 Kali Hart Vineyard Pinot Noir (Monterey County)
appellation: Monterey County, Central Coast, California, US
review: Smells distinctly Porty, with caramelized fruit scents, and tastes sharp and minty, with wintergreen and bitter cherryskin flavors. The finish is dry.

Crisp white pear and grapefruit tones dazzle from nose to finish in this pert, pristine blend of Grenache Blanc, Clairette, Bourboulenc and Roussanne. Despite being vinified and aged in 50% new French oak, it's a remarkably zippy sip marked by delicate traces of hazelnut and spice on the finish. Lovely now but should hold through 2025.

Fresh, while maintaining a spicy, oaky character, this is an everyday sip that will pair well with creamy, opulent dishes and fresh seafood. On the palate, it's round and subtle with good spice but has a nice lively feel.

wine: Marqués de la Concordia 2014 Federico Paternina Reserva  (Rioja)
review: Up-front aromas of cedary oak, vanilla and spice provide framing for riper berry scents. A full palate with piping acidity is cut by creamy oak, while this tastes of red plum, currant, tobacco, savory spices and vanilla. Although a bit ripe and soupy in structure, this is a classic-style Rioja to drink now.

wine: Erste Neue 2017 Puntay Pinot Bianco (Alto Adige)
review: This has a shy nose that eventually reveals subdued aromas of mature orchard fruit. The palate is also rather subdued but polished, offering ripe apple and creamy pear alongside a hint of hazelnut.

wine: Seabold Cellars 2018 Rodnick Farm Old Vines Pinot Blanc (Chalone)
review: It's always a joy to taste the old vines of Chalone, and this bottling captures their unique qualities, starting with aromas of apple syrup, hazelnut and toasted pecan. The palate offers almond, Meyer lemon and a creamy oak flavor that lingers on the tongue for a long time—all very unique elements.

wine: Buck Shack 2017 Small Batch Sustainably Farmed Cabernet Sauvignon (Lake County)
appellation: Lake County, Lake County, California, US
review: This full-bodied wine has plenty of dark berry and cherry notes, a touch of black olive and a big structure of firm, fine-grained tannins. Deft oak accents spice up the palate and linger on the finish. Best through 2025.

wine: Herdade da Calada 2000 Baron de B Reserva Red (Alentejo)
review: This attempt at a modern, heavily extracted red packs in plenty of bulky blackberry and oak flavors but not much finesse. It's simply a satisfying mouthful of fruit and wood.

wine: Harris 2003 Jake's Creek Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
review: I preferred this to Harris's more expensive Treva's Cab because it's not as tannic, offering more immediate pleasure in an opulent, classy way. Soft and charming, yet with an intense structure, the wine is beautiful in blackberry, cherry, anise, green olive and vanilla oak flavors that finish complex and dry. Best now through 2010 for its lush fruit.

appellation: Monterey County, Central Coast, California, US
review: Everyday Pinot, a one-dimensional wine with pleasant cherry, raspberry and cocoa flavors finished with a touch of smoky oak. At this price, it's a good buy for consumers who are curious about Pinot, but don't want to drop a bundle.

Be careful when you look for thense wines, the labels at Aschieri are a little confusing;  a small white strip label at thumb level distinguishes the Sorano ordinaire from the special Costa Bricco. The wine, itself, is thick and quite poerful, with very ripe dark fruit, roses and earth flavors. It is beginning to show its age, and did not seem quite as fresh as the Sorano, but it proved to be more intense and extracted.

Those notorious mountain tannins have largely melted, making the wine drinkable now, although it will hold for a decade with proper cellaring. Lush and velvety, with a drop of Cabernet Franc, this is voluptuous in cherries, black currants and fine, toasty oak.

wine: Lucienne 2015 Smith Vineyard Pinot Noir (Santa Lucia Highlands)
appellation: Santa Lucia Highlands, Central Coast, California, US
review: There are elegant aromas of potpourri, purple flowers, rose hips, fennel, wild mint, blackberries and plums on the nose of this top-end bottling from the Hahn family. Hearty black plum and elderberry mix with black sage and bay leaf on the palate, where a chalky texture and soft mouthfeel complete the experience.

appellation: Dry Creek Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: An interesting wine with an array of citrus, peach and tart pineapple flavors, very high acidity, and a super-long finish. It tingles on the palate, and is refreshing and ultra-clean. Has some complexity, and is a natural for food.

wine: Ca' del Bosco 2009 Vintage Collection Brut  (Franciacorta)
review: Fragrant and floral, this blend of 55% Chardonnay, 30% Pinot Nero and 15% Pinot Bianco offers aromas of lemon blossom, white flowers and toasted almond. The palate shows an impressive depth of flavors, including yellow apple, lemon cream pie and peach alongside an elegant mousse. The creamy flavors are brightened by lively acidity.

A yellow color and toasty aromas suggesting spent yeast and autolysis lead to a round palate with a shot of acidic freshness. Flavors of brioche, butterscotch, apple and lemon finish rich and toasty at first, then more dry and bitter.

wine: Geh. Rat Dr. von Bassermann-Jordan 2008 Forster Jesuitengarten Grosses Gewächs Riesling (Pfalz)
Williams Selyem 2000 Hirsch Vineyard Chardonnay (Sonoma Coast)
review: Creamy smooth but balanced by firm, tangy acidity, and toasty oak and hazelnut flavors. This complex, elegant and sensual wine coats the palate with ripe melon, pear, fig and apple flavors, all highlighted by fresh lemon, orange and herb notes. Clean and long on the finish, this is top-notch Chardonnay. Editors' Choice. —J.M.

Rich, tropical fruit and flowers intermingle on the nose of this elegant white from Durbanville. On the palate, it's a combination of full and flavorful--white fruits and fragrant flowers--as well as crisp and clean. the overall character is delicate and balanced.

appellation: North Coast, North Coast, California, US
review: This full-bodied and moderately tannic wine boasts bold red- and black-fruit flavors shaded by nuances of bay leaf, toasted oak and nutmeg. It's big and sturdy for pairing with rich proteins.

wine: Midnight 2000 Capriccio Italien Cabernet Sauvignon-Sangiovese (Paso Robles)
appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: This is a blend of Sangiovese, Merlot and Cabernet Sauvignon. It is very dry. There are some rich flavors of berries and herbs. It is a good, somewhat rustic red wine. The tannins are considerable and last through the finish. —S.H.
This is a rich, ripe and well-balanced rosé. Made from Pinot Noir, it has hints of red cherry as well as red currants, with crisp intensity and spice. It's ready to drink now.

A blend from several premier cru vineyards in Pommard, here is a wine that exhibits just the right firm but dusty tannins of the appellation. But because it is 2005, the natural exuberance of the fruit is also there, lively red berries under the dry structure. It needs some aging, but already the richness is there, along with a smoky aftertaste.

Dark-skinned berry and culinary-spice aromas set the tone on this easygoing red. Reflecting the nose, the straightforward palate shows red plum, clove and black pepper alongside pliant tannins. Enjoy through 2021.

wine: Gérard Loriot NV Tradition Brut Pinot Meunier (Champagne)
review: From the heart of the Marne Valley, this 100% Pinot Meunier bottling is ripe and yeasty. It has a rich, soft character and hints of toast from the 30% reserve wine in the blend. Balanced dosage gives a soft, smooth aftertaste. Drink now.

appellation: Lake County, Lake County, California, US
review: The curve on this wine has been going up and up, and this '09 is their best yet. It's bone dry and savory in acids, with ultraclean citrus, mineral and white flower flavors. Just delicious as a cocktail sipper.

appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: Concentrated dark red-fruit and a prominent cigar-box aromas show on the nose of this bottling, named after the tiny coastal town where the winery is headquartered. Cedar-led wood spice dominates the palate.
With aromas of strawberry and blueberry, this wine is tart at first sip, but then opens to rich flavors of slightly savory black cherry, strawberry, thyme and aniseed.

wine: Vignerons des Terres Secrètes 2008 Terra Incognita  (Mâcon-Villages)
review: Artificial candy shop flavors, the fruit textured without freshness. Hard to like.

wine: Eberle 2009 Hidden Valley Vineyard 51%, Wine Bush Vineyard 36%, Filipponi & Thompson Vineyard 13% Sangiovese (Paso Robles)
designation: Hidden Valley Vineyard 51%, Wine Bush Vineyard 36%, Filipponi & Thompson Vineyard 13%
appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: Eberle's Sangioveses are always dry, acidic and cherried. On their own, they're tight, rustic little monsters. Drink them with appropriate fare, and suddenly you're in Tuscany. Get out your Italian cookbook and find something with beef, fettucine, ragu and plenty of cheese.

Made entirely with Pinot Nero, this stunning sparkler opens with aromas of lemon custard, yeast, citrus and apple. The elegant palate has lovely depth, offering crisp apple, citrus zest, pastry cream and mineral alongside an ultrafine perlage. The tangy finish closes on an almond note.

appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: Easy to like this wine for its rich lemon meringue pie, butterscotch, vanilla and toast flavors. It's good, tasty and satisfying in the Chardonnay way, at a fair price.

wine: Buoncristiani 2005 O.P.C. Proprietary Red Wine Red (Napa Valley)
review: Just gorgeous. Floods the mouth with decadent black currant, cherry, chocolate, anise, beef jerky and smoky oak flavors that stun for their addictive deliciousness. Yet it's perfectly dry, and the balance of rich, ripe tannins, acidity and smoky oak is near perfect. The wine is a blend of Bordeaux varieties and Syrah, from esteemed vineyards including Hyde, Stagecoach and Caldwell.

wine: Cramele Recas 2020 Legendary Estate Series Pinot Noir (Romania)
review: Cherry red in the glass, this wine offers aromas of sour cherry, powdered sugar and cotton candy. It is soft on entry, and the mouth conveys flavors of black cherry and red raspberry.

wine: G. H. Mumm 2006 Cuvée Lalou Brut  (Champagne)
review: This luxury cuvée has developed slowly and surely into beautiful maturity. Richness harks back to the full Pinot Noir fruits that are now transformed with age. Now at its peak, this wine is ready to drink.
An odd wine, with juicy blackberry and chocolate flavors side by side with annoyingly vegetal ones. High alcohol and low acidity make the wine hot and flaccid.

appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: A fine, everyday Merlot, although a little rough, but nicely ripe and sweet in raspberry and cherry flavors. It's a country-style wine that will pair well with beef.
Aromas of red berries, cooking spices and underbrush shape the nose. The chewy, savory palate doles out raspberry jam, clove and star anise alongside polished tannins. Drink after 2021.

wine: Jacquesson et Fils NV Cuvée 735 Brut  (Champagne)
review: Just released, this latest non-vintage from Jacquesson is very steely, austere, cool and elegant with apple and citrus acidity. It has freshness and balance. Still young, but very complete.

wine: The Federalist 2010 Dueling Pistols Red (Dry Creek Valley)
appellation: Dry Creek Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: The blend is Zinfandel and Syrah. The wine shows its warm-climate origins in exceptionally ripe fruit and and the briary, brambly character of Dry Creek Zin. The blackberry and cherry flavors have an intense spiciness of nutmeg, cinnamon, white pepper and Chinese five-spice. The tannins are thick. Full-bodied, hot in alcohol and a little heavy, it's ready to drink now.

wine: Lachini 2015 La Bestia Puro Sangue Red (Red Mountain)
appellation: Red Mountain, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Fresh herb, orange zest and spice aromas are followed by somewhat sweet, tangy fruit flavors. It's an uncomfortable mix.

appellation: North Coast, North Coast, California, US
review: This wine has classic rosemary and pine aromas and fresh, lively citrus flavors. Supportive acidity and a concentrated palate helps extend the finish. It's all about savory flavors and a nice tart character.

wine: De Loach 2017 OFS Zinfandel (Russian River Valley)
appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: This hearty red tastes of barbecue meat and char. Rounded and rich, it has a juicy, broad appeal of brambly blackberry jam that contrasts against the meat.
This is a fresh and unfussy white wine, lively in acidity and lengthy in grapefruit, fig and dried herb. It stays light and bright throughout, offering balanced weight and ripeness.

wine: Ojai 2007 Bien Nacido Vineyard Chardonnay (Santa Maria Valley)
appellation: Santa Maria Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: This is an extraordinarily rich Chardonnay, built along Burgundian lines. A deep gold color, it explodes in tangerine-infused butterscotch, honeysuckle, citron, spice and tangy mineral flavors, and finishes with a savory bite of coastal acidity.

wine: Château Roubine 2019 Inspire Rosé (Côtes de Provence)
review: An elegant wine that is still young, this is a style of rosé that can age. Richness comes from the aromatic Tibouren in the blend. Freshness contrasts with the generous red fruits and final mineral texture. Drink from 2021.

appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
review: The wine offers aromas of green apple and pears, with a touch of floral spice. On the palate, the character is lively and crisp, with a minerally backbone. The fresh fruit component is elegant and light. A food-friendly wine with a delicate touch.

wine: Claar 2018 Estate Grown and Bottled White Bluffs Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Columbia Valley (WA))
designation: Estate Grown and Bottled White Bluffs Vineyard
appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Dark raspberry aromas are out front, along with notes of medicine, cherry cordial and grapefruit rind. The palate is wound up tightly, with the tannins bringing grip and astringency. There are good things going on if they settle in. Give an extended decant if drinking in the near term.

wine: X 2003 Eutenier Sylar Vineyard Sauvignon Blanc (Lake County)
appellation: Lake County, Lake County, California, US
review: There are some good lime, fig and melon flavors here, but they're really watered down. Definitely needs more concentration, especially at this price.

wine: Trisaetum 2016 Estates Reserve Dry Riesling (Willamette Valley)
appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: One barrel of each of Trisaetum's three estate vineyards contributed to this reserve bottling. It's the most closed of their dry Rieslings, requiring a hearty decant to show its stuffing: tart apple and citrus fruit, with streaks of vanilla and spice. Or age it a few years longer to allow more nuances to emerge.

A blend of 70% Carricante and 30% Catarratto, this elegant white features aromas of acacia flower, broom, crushed rock and crunchy white fruit. The focused, linear palate delivers juicy green apple, citrus and a mineral vein alongside brisk acidity that gives it a pristine finish.

wine: Château Hostens-Picant 2007 Cuvée des Demoiselles  (Sainte-Foy Bordeaux)
review: A rich, smoky style of wine that revels in its high toast character as well as ripe yellow fruit flavors. It is certainly full in the mouth, a burst of ripeness followed by balancing acidity and a texture of red apple skins. It would be worth aging for another year.

Juicy tangerine, pineapple and apricot flavors abound in this fruity, forward Riesling. Semidry in style, it's an approachable, easy-drinking wine balanced by pert acidity and a clean finish. Drink now.

This is a delicate, dainty Sauvignon that glides onto the scene with lime, red apple peel and blossoms. Texturally, it's a little chalky, with an apple-focused tang, balanced acidity and a mouthwatering finish.

wine: Zolo 2015 Reserve Cabernet Sauvignon (Luján de Cuyo)
appellation: Luján de Cuyo, Mendoza Province, Argentina
review: Black fruit aromas are spicy and hint at raisin the longer this sits. A stout, scratchy palate is rough but not scrubbing. Roasted berry and plum flavors are accented by spicy oak and baked notes on a full finish.

wine: Dutcher Crossing 2012 Maple Vineyard Bill's Block Zinfandel (Dry Creek Valley)
appellation: Dry Creek Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: Dutcher Crossing has been producing some of Dry Creek's most compelling Zins. The Maple Vineyard challenges winemakers to harness the potent alcohol levels almost always found in the wines. This bottling has major alcohol, but it somehow works. The wine is big and warming, but not hot, and contains no overripeness. It's a spicy, fruity, full-bodied wine that will pair magnificently with barbecue.

A lovely touch of orange zest teases the nose and there also is a lovely hint of chervil. The streamlined palate comes in with bundled citrus notes. The tart flesh of tangerine and the zest of lemon are softened and enriched with orange oil and ample concentration. This is pure and racy, linear and bold. There is something salty and energetic, something incredibly fresh and vibrant at the core. The palate and finish are absolutely dry, the echo is long and clean. Blastingly fresh right now, sure to evolve. Drink 2019–2037.

Young and boisterous, but nice and tasty. The color is violet, while the aromas are unchained and saturated. Flavors of black plum, ripe grapes and rubber make for uncommon richness, while the finish is sizable and real. Full tannins and some acidic punch ensure that it won't be taken lightly. Made by the people at La Legua.

While smoky and mineral on the nose, the palate of this semidry Rieslaner, a cross between Riesling and Sylvaner, is boldly fruity. Fresh tangerine and berry notes are a bit candied on the palate but balanced neatly by a racy streak of acidity. This light-bodied sip finishes with sweetness.

Deliciously sweet and perfumed, its powerful plum fruit flavors make this wine already accessible. In the background are the tannins—solid and concentrated—and the acidity, creating a nervous tension that confirms the wine's aging potential. Hold for many years.

wine: Château Haut-Monplaisir 2016 Monplaisir Chardonnay-Viognier (Côtes du Lot)
appellation: Côtes du Lot, Southwest France, France
review: This crisp blend of Chardonnay and Viognier is bright, with lively fruit and a smooth texture behind its crisp facade. It's ready to drink now but will soften over the next few months and be richer from mid-2018.
Is this a table or a dessert wine? Either way, the orange and apricot flavors are watery.

wine: Vinos de Arganza 2012 Palacio de Arganza Tempranillo-Mencia Red (Vino de la Tierra de Castilla y León)
appellation: Vino de la Tierra de Castilla y León, Northern Spain, Spain
review: Dark aromas of asphalt, lead pencil, blackberry, toast and lemony oak lead to a raring, zesty palate with toasty, racy cherry and currant flavors. Spicy oak flavors and tingling acidity make for a lively finish.

wine: Sonsierra 2012 Pagos de la Sonsierra Reserva  (Rioja)
review: Concentrated black-fruit aromas are charred and savory, with notes of grilled beef and black olive. A plush plump layered palate offers earthy saucy savory plum fruit, while the finish is round, wholesome and smooth. Drink through 2023.

wine: Clos du Bois 2007 Calcaire Chardonnay (Russian River Valley)
appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: Made in a leaner, crisper style than many Chards nowadays, this Chardonnay trades power for elegance. It's almost like a Sauvignon Blanc, with citrusy acids framing flavors of limes, pineapples and green apples that have a minerally edge. New French oak adds just the right touch of richness.

93-95 Complex wine, its ripe Merlot character structured with tannins, a solid dark core, ripely balanced and intense. The acidity is already well integrated. With this structure, the wine should have a good future.

wine: Le Petit Cochonnet 2015 Pinot Noir (Pays d'Oc)
review: A light, easy and cheery selection, with direct aromas and flavors of sweet cherry, red raspberry and strawberry. The mouthfeel is soft and approachable, with virtually no tannins and a clean, short finish. Drink up.

wine: Kerloo 2016 Painted Hills Vineyard Grenache Rosé (Columbia Valley (WA))
appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: This wine is a pretty very pale peach, almost bronze color. Light strawberry aromas are followed by bone-dry textured fruit flavors. Pink grapefruit lingers on the finish. Pair it with food to see it at its best.

wine: Pothana Vineyards 2004 Big Mouth Red Shiraz-Viognier (New South Wales)
appellation: New South Wales, New South Wales, Australia
review: From winemaker David Hook, who previously worked for Tyrrell's and Lakes Folly, this is an outstanding bargain. A blend of 95% Shiraz and 5% Viognier, it offers loads of cola, chocolate, plum and blueberry, framed with just enough structuring acid and tannin to give it balance. Try this with grilled steak or lamb over the next few years.

wine: Siegel 2011 Gran Crucero Limited Edition Red (Colchagua Valley)
review: Herbal, briary berry aromas are minty and suggestive of olive. The mouthfeel is plump and juicy, while herbal blackberry and black currant flavors finish with a blast of toast and mint. This blend of Cabernet Sauvignon, Carmenère and Syrah is quintessentially Chilean in aromas, flavors and intensity. Drink through 2020.

wine: Josef Ehmoser 2013 Vom Gelben Löss Riesling (Wagram-Donauland)
review: A gentle, fresh-faced, peachy Riesling with a rounded body, refreshing acidity and just a little spritz.
Full and ripe, this has a pure, fragrant fruitiness. Its structure and freshness add a delicious drinkability to this rich wine. Age for another year.

wine: Château Réal Martin 2011 Perle de Rosé Rosé (Côtes de Provence)
review: A caramel- and lemon-flavored wine that's both fresh and soft. It has an attractive perfumed character and a warm and round texture. This is made from old vines, which lends it extra concentration.

wine: Fournier Père et Fils 2016 Terres Blanches  (Sancerre)
review: An attractively mature wine, this is rich, packed with ripe, creamy fruits and acidity. White fruits mingle with citrus and an almond character adds complexity. The crisp aftertaste is a reminder of the wine's Sauvignon Blanc origins.

wine: Château Mouton Rothschild 2017 L'Aile d'Argent  (Bordeaux Blanc)
review: Crisp and fruity, with some attractive herbal accents, this wine is lightly tangy. It is full of citrus flavors with hints of minerality. Wood aging gives smoothness to the texture. Drink from 2021.

wine: Bouvet-Ladubay NV Rubis Excellence Demi-Sec Sparkling (Vin Mousseux)
review: This is a lightly sweet, red sparkling wine with ripe strawberry fruits, a touch of tannin and soft acidity. A fine partner for a fruit dessert or blue cheese.

wine: Freemark Abbey 2012 Cabernet Bosché Cabernet Sauvignon (Rutherford)
review: Brushy sage meets succulent blackberry, blueberry and tar in this impressive wine, which offers generous structure and complex tannin. Though juicy and decidedly enjoyable now, it will benefit from further cellaring; best 2022 through 2032.

appellation: Ancient Lakes, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: On first pour it is the oak —25% new French—that leads with prominent notes of vanilla, but as it opens up these recede to reveal baked apple, butterscotch and pear. It's creamy and almost unctuous in feel with the sweetness of the fruit giving the suggestion of residual sugar.

wine: Edgebaston 2007 Finlayson Family Vineyards Cabernet Sauvignon (Stellenbosch)
review: Herbs, pepper, cedar and smoked sausage on the nose and palate give this Cabernet a rustic, inviting character. Flavors are delivered in a mouthfilling, layered way on the tongue, with lots of spice and cedar in the finish. Good minerality and balance mean it's not overpowering for food.

Named after the chalk soil, this wine is densely mineral in texture. Its concentration and maturity haven't left its crisp fruitiness behind. The final effect is of a strongly herbal, very intense wine that is ready to drink.

Big aromas of blackberry, leather, turned earth and white mushroom set up a bright, layered palate with fresh acidity at its core. Floral, exotic red-berry flavors are spicy and in sync with each other. A crisp, peppery finish with toasty oak ensures that this single-vineyard Malbec is built to last. Drink through 2025.

wine: Clay Shannon 2018 El Coyote Chardonnay (Red Hills)
appellation: Red Hills, Lake County, California, US
review: This richly textured and subtly spicy wine is full in feel and mouthcoating. It's laced with flavors of nutmeg, vanilla and toasted baguette that are tempting and sophisticated.

wine: Youngberg Hill Vineyards 2006 Jordan Block Pinot Noir (McMinnville)
review: A floral note defines this selection from a specific section of the vineyard; leading into black raspberry, pepper and cola flavors. Some forest floor notes can also be found, the only off-note being a little bitterness that creeps into the tannins.

appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: This is an elegant Syrah, blended with 18% Mourvèdre and topped with a splash of Grenache. Good phenolic ripeness along with substantial sugars lead into flavors that have melded nicely. Berry, truffle, chocolate, leather, pepper and coffee are all in the mix, and the mid-palate is delicious. Only a fairly quick fade keeps the score from climbing even higher.
Aromas of espresso, cedar and tobacco emerge from the glass. The dense palate offers prune, licorice and roasted coffee alongside assertive tannins that create a rather astringent finish.

appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
review: This is fermented and aged in stainless steel with no secondary fermentation. It opens in floral honeysuckle and a hint of fresh grass, with notes of peach and tropical vanilla. Lively acidity boosts its light-bodied frame.

wine: Jason-Stephens 2010 Estate Select Chardonnay (Santa Clara Valley)
appellation: Santa Clara Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: This is the oaked version of Jason-Stephens's estate-grown Chardonnay. It's rich and deep, yet still smooth, with the grape's trademark apple crispness. The finish lingers with an apple pie note.
Simple and harsh in texture, this Pinot has the variety's silky texture, but not much else going for it. The flavors are minty and green, with just the barest suggestion of cherries.
Thick, soft and heavy, this Merlot has medicinal cherry and blackberry flavors.

wine: D'Arenberg 2016 The Stump Jump Grenache-Shiraz-Mourvédre Red (McLaren Vale)
review: Ripe plums and red berries are followed by licorice, flowers and tarmac aromas. The palate is plump and rich, with a vice-like grip of savory, woody, tight-grained tannins, lifted acidity and crunchy red fruit. Still finding its feet, this this could use a few more years in bottle. Drink 2020–2030.

Bottled in 2017, this dessert wine is made entirely from Chardonnay and dazzles in lithe layers of apple, pear and melon. With a medium-bodied feel, it shows density around underlying balance and structure.

wine: Vin du Lac 2011 Les Amis Riesling (Columbia Valley (WA))
appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Though labeled Riesling, it's blended with 16% Muscat and 9% Gewürztraminer. The residual sugar is listed as 2%, but rather than sweetness, the wine carries a sour lemon snap and a palate of tart citrus and orange soda flavors.

Forced woody aromas and flavors are a persistent theme on this Uco Valley Malbec, which smells a bit horsey and stewed. Dense black-fruit flavors are roasted and peppery, while wood and related resin notes rise up on the back palate. Rustic power and fiery heat are loud elements on a fully oaked finish.

This lively, dry white from Hungary starts with aromas of apple, oaky spice and citrus, leading in to balanced fruit flavors with a toasty vanilla edge. Smooth but spunky, the wine ends with a good spicy finish.

A very nice Syrah that shows plenty of upscale character. While it's not as complex as the winery's vineyard-designated Syrahs, it shows a rich tannin structure and ripe blackberry, anise, chocolate and pepper flavors. Will drink well for the next couple years.
Very ripe, with a bite of raisin skin bitterness. But it's a lush wine, filled with chocolate, blueberry, blackberry jam and cedar flavors that go down nice and easy. Drink now.

wine: Cave de Vignerons de Beaumes-de-Venise 2004 Carte Or  (Muscat de Beaumes de Venise)
varietal: Muscat Blanc à Petits Grains, Muscat
appellation: Muscat de Beaumes de Venise, Rhône Valley, France

review: Valpolicella Nanfrè presents an easy but balanced bouquet with defined elements of mature berry fruit, prune, Indian spice and crushed black pepper. You'll love those savory, spicy nuances on the close.

Fern fronds mingle with green pear on the nose. The palate adds zingy but ripe lemon acidity and an impression of ripe and juicy pear despite the slender palate. The wine offers supreme refreshment at a moderate weight.

wine: Sorelle Bronca NV Brut  (Prosecco di Valdobbiadene)
review: Here's a quasi-aromatic Prosecco Brut with floral aromas and loads of pear and Golden Delicious apple. The wine is full, generous and has creamy froth in the mouth that is backed by perky effervescence. Pair it with pastry-based finger foods.

wine: A. Toraño 2020 Kick Ranch Sauvignon Blanc (Sonoma County)
review: Light, floral and earthy, this medium-bodied white offers good midpalate weight and breadth, with a tension of acidity. Pear, vanilla bean and a hint of peach round out the flavor profile, finishing in a kick of lime.

wine: Intipalka 2012 Valle del Sol Reserva Malbec-Merlot (Ica)
review: Earthy plum and blackberry aromas are crisp and raw, with overt wood grain riding heavily on the bouquet. This is 60% Merlot and 40% Malbec; it feels grabby, while toasty, heavily oaked flavors of clove and bitter chocolate smother the wine's fruit before turning charred and roasted on the finish.

Here's a charming blend that has lovely fragrances of jasmine and lily of the valley, with a hint of stone fruit. The delicious palate offers creamy white peach, pear and tropical fruit flavors that are energized by a vein of crisp acidity.

wine: Williams Selyem 2000 Hawk Hill Vineyard Chardonnay (Russian River Valley)
appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: Kicks off with a hint of citrus and butterscotch on the nose. It's a densely structured wine, framed in toasty oak and showing tightly wound hints of lemon, melon, pear and peach flavors. Bright on the finish, this is a powerful wine that should unfold nicely with time. —J.M.

A stony smokiness hovers above the nose, only slowly giving way to pear and lemon. The palate then bursts into fruit with notions of ripe apple and Mirabelle framed and contoured by lemon brightness. It is that citrus freshness that soars towards the finish, mouthwatering, insistent and sustained.

wine: Pride Mountain 2016 Vintner Select Chardonnay (Sonoma County)
review: Oaky vanilla, caramel and lemon curd highlight the full-bodied concentration of rich flavor in this wine, aged in both new and neutral oak. Well made, integrated and structured, it shows grace within a powerful package of intensity.

appellation: Dundee Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: This barrel-fermented wine reflects the modest ripeness that marked the 2010 vintage. Scents of almond paste, orange peel, citrus, melon and pear intertwine, and the wine's flavors carry light suggestions of them all, along with a touch of caramel. It's drinking well right now, so why wait?

appellation: Potter Valley, Mendocino County, California, US
review: Hints of rosemary and thyme meet tempting, ripe melon and pear flavors in this aromatic, full-bodied and richly textured wine from winemaker and former chef Pietro Buttita. It's an unusual—but at the same time very appealing—flavor profile.

appellation: Lake County, Lake County, California, US
review: This makes three knockout vintages in a row from Sol Rouge. The wine has richness, roundness, power and finesse all rolled into a balanced package. It smells gutsy, ripe but also smoky and savory, and tastes deep and layered with cassis, chocolate, and tobacco. A good wrapping of fine tannins pulls everything together.

wine: Testarossa 2002 Garys' Vineyard Pinot Noir (Santa Lucia Highlands)
appellation: Santa Lucia Highlands, Central Coast, California, US
review: Ripe, dry and well made, with complex aromas of cherries, sweet herbs, coffee, menthol and smoky oak. Full-bodied and big, with a voluptuous mouthfeel. Delicious on its own, and a versatile food wine.

wine: Coldisole 2011 Lionello Marchesi Riserva  (Brunello di Montalcino)
review: This opens with aromas of cedar, incense and dark fruit. The medium-bodied palate offers black plum, clove and star anise alongside polished, ripe tannins. Drink through 2025.

wine: Kriter NV Blanc de Blancs Brut  (France)
review: This is a blend of white grapes from various parts of France, and thus ineligible for any appellation contrôlée. Yes, the bead is a little larger than it might be if the wine's second fermentation had been in the bottle, but the costs associated with that would price it well out of the value range. Still, it does ferment for seven months before aging on the lees for an additional nine, acquiring toasty, autolytic notes to complement its ripe fruit flavors. It's a soft, approachable bubbly ideal for large holiday crowds.

This rustic Shiraz starts with a nose of menthol, clove, peppermint and a touch of brett, leading into bright waves of berry fruit and pepper. Friendly and easydrinking overall. Pair with spiced meats, pastas.

wine: Copain Wines 2019 DuPratt Vineyards Chardonnay (Anderson Valley)
appellation: Anderson Valley, Mendocino County, California, US
review: Delicious fruity richness comes with bracing underlying acidity in this full-bodied, generous, creamy but well-balanced wine. Lemon, almond, ripe Bosc pear and toasted baguette flavors give it more than enough to savor.
Savory mint, prune and soy sauce blend nicely with notes of violet and rose. More fruit comes through on the palate, showing a bright cranberry note that livens everything up.

wine: Château Bois de Favereau 2015 Cuvée Jean Jules  (Bordeaux Supérieur)
review: The vineyard for this wine lies in the far east of the Entre-Deux-Mers. It has produced a soft, fruity wine with gentle tannins and open fruitiness. The wine has attractive black-currant flavors and acidity along with a dry core that keeps everything together. Drink now.

This lightly colored, delicately structured Pinot has lots of tart acidity framing flavors of cranberries and strawberries. There's a hint of green, but it's bone dry, and the alcohol is a decidedly moderate.

wine: Quanta Terra 2010 Terra a Terra Branco Reserva White (Douro)
review: Flavors of ripe pear and lime juice make this wine both full in the mouth and crisp. There is an apple skin-like texture to this wine that is ready to drink.
Made in a popularly appealing style, this slightly sweet wine has honeyed flavors of lemons, limes, green apples and white pepper. Very food-friendly, especially with salty foods.
Thanks to its silky mouthfeel and balanced acidity, this renders a sensation of elegance and finesse. There's pulp and dimension on the nose with layers of red currant and underbrush.

The Jaen grape, local to the Dão, has produced a perfumed juicy wine that is ripe and intensely full of acidity at the same time. It has only light tannins and red berry flavors that are right up front. The wine is ready to drink.

Cassis and cherry aromas are raw and scratchy, but they are also pure and racy. This blend of Merlot and Cab Franc is choppy and fresh in feel, with jumpy acids propping up red currant, plum and raspberry flavors that come with oak-based vanilla. An earthy tasting, rough feeling finish is the closing act.

wine: Valentina Cubi 2006 Morar  (Amarone della Valpolicella Classico)
appellation: Amarone della Valpolicella Classico, Veneto, Italy
review: Amarone Morar is a bright, lively red wine that delivers fruit, but that also accommodates a steady flow of smoke, tobacco, drying mineral, cigar and asphalt-like aromas. Its texture is dark, dense and there's a touch of chewy sweetness on the close.

wine: Domaine Schoffit 2006 Rangen Grand Cru Clos Saint Théobald Sélection de Grains Nobles Gewurztraminer (Alsace)
designation: Rangen Grand Cru Clos Saint Théobald Sélection de Grains Nobles
review: A heady and lifted nose suggests healing herbs steeped in honey. The palate is rich and unctuous but fresh with the lemon peel, herb and clear honey notes that were already present on the nose. The balance between luscious and tart is on a knife's edge and all the more thrilling for it. The flavors last and last—not in sweetness but in utter, gloried freshness. Drink 2016–2040.

This wine shows soft lime and stone fruit characters that mingle with snow pea, jalapeño and a little wet stone minerality. On the palate it's focused and texturally interesting, with balanced acidity, lime zest and a salty edge.

appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: A splash of tart cherry introduces this charming Pinot Noir, which resemble a country wine from the nether reaches of Burgundy. The alcohol does not touch 13%, yet the flavors are here, with tart berries, a bit of stem, sharp tannins, and a medium-long finish. A great quaffer.

wine: Café du Midi 2017 Merlot (Vin de France)
appellation: Vin de France, France Other, France
review: A subtle warmth graces the nose of this bottling, lifting the rich black-raspberry and boysenberry characteristics. Earthy scents of peat and pepper unfold in the back, while the medium-weight, satiny palate returns to rich, plush black-fruit flavors dusted in clove.
Aromas of tomato, olive, dried herbs and cherry start this elegant red. On the palate, smoke, savory meats and fresh cherry flavors are both complex and easy to love.

wine: Laurent Combier 2000 Cuvee L Red (Côtes du Rhône)
appellation: Côtes du Rhône, Rhône Valley, France
review: Simple and bone dry, with earthy, berry fruit flavors and some peppery tannins that kick in in the finish. Easy drinking stuff, and will be very nice with a rich fish stew.

wine: Dante Robere 2017 Suky's Syrah Syrah-Petite Sirah (Livermore Valley)
appellation: Livermore Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: This heavily toasted, salt-and-pepper wine spent 28 months aging in new French barrels. It offers plenty of charred oak and meat in the aroma, dark-chocolate and blackberry in the flavors, and moderate tannins for a grippy mouthfeel.
This is a tight, tangy wine, laced with attractive wood flavors. Plenty of crisp citrus and spicy flavors balance each other. It is already delicious, so drink now.

wine: Bayernmoor 2017 Bayernmoor Estate Vineyard Pinot Noir (Puget Sound)
appellation: Puget Sound, Washington Other, Washington, US
review: The aromas bring notes of wintergreen, pine, flower, cigarette ash and strawberry, with the oak out front. Fruit and barrel mix on the light, creamy-feeling palate, tussling at time. There's lovely acidity to it, but it gets lost in the shuffle.

wine: Grape Creek Vineyards 2017 Pinot Noir (Paso Robles Willow Creek District)
appellation: Paso Robles Willow Creek District, Central Coast, California, US
review: Strongly extracted aromas of berry jam, caramel and Bourbon barrel show on the nose of this bottling. The palate is also very rich and extracted, with raisin and scotch flavors.

wine: Babcock 2016 Identity Crisis Grenache (Santa Barbara County)
appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
review: Extremely tight, clean and minerally aromas of chalk, citrus pith and lemongrass make for a very crisp and fresh nose on this white wine bottling of the typically red Grenache grape. The palate is just as zesty, with apple skin, green papaya and underripe mango flavors, showing flashes of tropicality while remaining light and tight.

appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: This is a power-packed blend of 72% Syrah, 15% Grenache, 8% Petite Sirah and 5% Mourvèdre, with smoky aromas of game, bacon fat, pressed blackberry, pepper and baking spices. The palate is oak-driven, with flavors of smoked meats in boysenberry sauce, but the tannins are so strong that this needs until at least 2018 for the components to shine properly.

Tastes like the grapes really struggled to get ripe in this chilly vintage. The wine is bone dry and tantalizing in acidity, with green flavors of chlorophyll and gooseberry that just manage to veer into Meyer lemons. Difficult on its own, but gains a few  points for elegance and a clean, steely minerality.
Smooth and velvety in the mouth, this is a fairly simple wine. It brims with sweet, fruity flavors of cherries, berries and cocoa. Syrah, Cab Franc, Petite Sirah and Zinfandel.
This grapy, fruity Malbec is quite enjoyable. Aromas of boysenberry and blueberry are solid despite some reduction. Plum, boysenberry and creamy oak flavors finish on a note of clove.

wine: Casa Cadaval 2012 Vinha Padre Pedro White (Tejo)
review: With its apricot and ripe pear aromas, this is a full and rounded wine. It has a good balance between acidity and ripe fruit. It is floral, smooth and ready to drink.

wine: Caccia al Piano 1868 2016 Levia Gravia  (Bolgheri Superiore)
review: This blend of Cabernet Sauvignon, Merlot and Cabernet Franc offers aromas of cassis, mocha and graphite. The structured palate presents blackberry jam, star anise and espresso alongside polished tannins. Drink through 2025.

wine: Girasole 2019 Estate Grown Pinot Noir (Mendocino County)
appellation: Mendocino County, Mendocino County, California, US
review: Juicy and fresh-tasting, this wine offers plenty of cherry, plum and strawberry flavors that seem to gush out of the glass. It's full bodied, but fairly soft in texture and easy to gulp.

wine: Malibràn 2020 Rive di Santa Maria di Feletto 5 Grammi Extra Brut  (Valdobbiadene Prosecco Superiore)
designation: Rive di Santa Maria di Feletto 5 Grammi Extra Brut
review: Granny Smith apple and white spring flower aromas follow through to the racy, smoothly sparkling palate together with ripe pear and a hint of white almond. Crisp acidity keeps it bright and refreshing.

wine: Russian Ridge 2011 Cabernet Sauvignon (Santa Cruz Mountains)
appellation: Santa Cruz Mountains, Central Coast, California, US
review: With hard, cutting tannins and watery fruit, this Cab is notable for astringency and acidity. There's very little going on, except it is dry.

wine: Franz Hirtzberger 2013 Honivogl Smaragd Grüner Veltliner (Wachau)
review: Strikingly golden in color this tightly holds very ripe yellow pear fruit and dark honey. With time in glass, fresh and ripe pineapple tantalizes. The palate is concentrated and has a pleasantly bitter phenolic edge, stony definition and a core of freshness. The undeniably ripe fruit is still tightly corseted and will need cellaring to express itself. Drinks as of 2018.

appellation: Sierra Foothills, Sierra Foothills, California, US
review: Jammy red-berry fruit gives this wine the scent of raspberry confiture. Add in a healthy dose of vanilla and the result is a very easily accessible and approachable wine that will probably win friends for Sierra Foothills Syrah. Drink now.

wine: Mayer am Pfarrplatz 2016 Nussberg Pinot Noir (Vienna)
review: A lovely notion of Amarena and dried bitter cherry on the nose promises fruit. The fluid palate obliges with freshness and at times sumptuous folds of that cherry fruit. There is almost a bitter edge that adds to the aromatic allure and the mouthwatering finish.

Subtle aromas of acacia flower, yellow stone fruit and a whiff of honey lead the way. On the round medium-bodied palate, tangy acidity lifts yellow apple, dried apricot and citrus rind while a bitter almond note announces the close.

wine: Alain Jaume et Fils 2017 Réserve Grand Veneur Red (Côtes du Rhône)
appellation: Côtes du Rhône, Rhône Valley, France
review: Bright blackberry and red cherry extend from nose to palate in this very fresh, primary red. Easy drinking in style, it's a juicy, full-bodied wine accented by burnt caramel and fine-grained tannins. A dependable bistro-type wine, it should drink well through 2022.

wine: Casa Agricola Alexandre Relvas 2015 Herdade de São Miguel Colheita Seleccionada Rosé (Alentejano)
designation: Herdade de São Miguel Colheita Seleccionada
review: This blend of Aragonez and Touriga Nacional is particularly crisp and fruity. It has some richness, but it is the bright red berry and red currant fruit that makes it so refreshing. Drink now.

This is a barrel-fermented Viura and thus the nose smells distinctly woody and resiny. Cleansing acidity lends clarity to an otherwise resiny palate, while this tastes of raw oak grain, white pepper and white peach prior to an oaky finish.

Good and meaty stuff, with bold aromas that feature leather, berry and char. Seems saturated and ripe, and gets better the more air it sees. Flavorwise, we're talking about plum, blackberry and a little vanilla. Complete on the finish, with all angles covered. Not complicated or complex; good value.
This wine has aromas of lemon rind, peach blossom and tropical fruits. It is aged for six months in oak barrels and has flavors of pineapple and peach with a soft finish.

wine: Clos des Lunes 2018 Lune Blanche  (Bordeaux Blanc)
review: This rich wine is produced by the winemaking team of Domaine de Chevalier. With a predominance of Sémillon, it is packed with white fruits, accented by hints of honey and toast. A fresh streak goes with the richness and the wine is now ready to drink.
This soft nonvintage from Chanoine is gently textured, with a touch of structure from the 70% Pinot Noir. It is smoothly textured and creamy, the apple fruitiness immediately attractive. Drink now.

wine: Silverado 2015 Mt George Vineyard Estate Grown Merlot (Coombsville)
review: Made from 100% Merlot from the producer's historic site, this wine saw time in French and Hungarian oak. Flavors of currant, orange and dried herb provide a complex landscape, held together by sinewy tannins.
A bit of rhubarb marks the nose of this otherwise cherry-fruited wine. Despite 14.5% alcohol, it's not really full bodied, showing creamy tannins but not much depth. Pleasant, soft and easy-drinking.

wine: Commanderie de la Bargemone 2015 Rosé (Coteaux d'Aix-en-Provence)
review: Created by Knights Templar in the 13th century, the estate now consists of 160 acres of vines. This wine has a strong sense of structure, with a zesty tang as well as tannins that enhance the fruitiness of this intense and juicy wine.

wine: V. Sattui 2009 Preston Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
review: This is a fleshy Cabernet, with meaty, olive notes to the blackberries and black currants. It's nicely dry and tannic, the kind of Cab that needs a rich steak to tame the astringency. Should develop over the next 5–6 years, at least.

wine: Hawk Crest 1997 Reserve Vineyard Selection Chardonnay (California)
review: The second label of Stag's Leap Wine Cellars, produced from Monterey and Napa grapes. Tasty with fairly ripe fruit and lively acidity. Not especially oaky or complex, but gets the job done.

wine: Kestrel NV Lady In Red Holiday Red (Yakima Valley)
appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: This is the second non-vintage holiday edition of Kestrel's popular Marilyn wannabe label. Who can resist a cute girl in a mini-skirted Santa suit? The wine is an all-purpose, sturdy red that could liven up a holiday table and ought to be stellar with turkey.
Seems rather oak-dominated, boasting ample brown sugar, vanilla and dill scents backed my some briary, blackberry fruit. Fills out a bit with air, so decant an hour or so prior to serving. Drink now.
This ripe and flavorful wine finds a good balance between plump black-cherry and baking spice notes, while moderate tannins give the good, firm texture that's expected in a Cabernet.

wine: Midnight 2007 Mare Nectaris Reserve Red (Paso Robles)
appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: This Cabernet-based blend is reminiscent to an old-fashioned Paso style that's soft, ripe and simple. It has candied cherry and blackberry flavors. Drink up.

This is a classy wine, showing a deep core of ripe blackberries, black currants and spices, with a smoked meat richness, like crispy bacon. Beyond the flavors is a fine mouthfeel, composed of smooth tannins and a nice bite of acidity.
92-94 Barrel sample. Like many of the Sauternes in 2008, this is dominated by huge, concentrated botrytis. The fruits are dried, with orange peel coming through as a final, fresh lift.

appellation: Monterey County, Central Coast, California, US
review: Dried beef, lamb flesh and leathery tobacco aromas show on the nose of this bottling. There is a grippy texture to the sip, where dried cherry and raspberry flavors meet with more leather and game.
Fruity and fresh, this easygoing semidry Riesling offers heaps of sweet peach and citrus flavors. It's not complex, but is crisply balanced with a clean, refreshing finish. Drink now.

wine: Quinta da Alorna 2015 Arinto-Chardonnay Reserva White (Tejo)
review: This wood-aged wine is ripe, lightly toasty and definitely spicy. It has a creamy, rounded texture that is rich and zingy, layering acidity with citrus and yellow fruits. Drink this wine from 2017.

appellation: Rattlesnake Hills, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Yellow straw, oxidized, with dull and flat flavors showing hints of banana and dried apple.
