wine: Adega Cooperativa do Cartaxo 2018 Plexus Rose Sparkling (Tejo)
review: A medium-sweet pink wine, this blends Castelão and Tinta Roriz, which has the benefit of at least being clean and fruity. Drink now.
The acidity of this wine is simply refreshing. Distinct honey and lemon peel aromas follow through the palate to the long, herbed finish. —K.F.

wine: Di Giovanna 2013 Gerbino Rosato Nero d'Avola (Terre Siciliane)
review: Made with organically farmed grapes, this simple, rustic rosato conveys aromas of red berry, game and a whiff of cellar must. The palate offers crushed wild cherry alongside zesty acidity.

wine: Gérard Bertrand 2018 Clos du Temple Rosé (Languedoc-Cabrières)
review: This is a lovely, complex, layered and inviting rosé. It opens with a light woody top note that suggests cedar-grilled apple, clove-spiked orange, tangerine peel and peach pit. The palate is silky and seductive, with an initial weight and lushness that's balanced by bright orange-flavored acidity and a lovely texture of delicate tannins and citrus pith through the close. Hints of white florals, like clover and Spanish broom, and garrigue also unfold on the finish.

wine: Rudi Pichler 2004 Terrassen Smaragd Grüner Veltliner (Wachau)
review: This nicely balanced GV features ripe pears and tropical fruit allied to citrus and white pepper, but just lacks that extra intensity and concentration of the best examples. Imported by Vin Divino.

90–92. Barrel Sample. Once owned by the Bernadotte family, rulers of Sweden, this estate is home to an impressive chateau. The wine is darkly concentrated and tightly packed with tannins, suggesting considerable long-term potential. There is a spicy character to the wine, along with notes of black plum skin. Try after 2025.
This Malbec is wide and full, lacking in cut and structure. Its chunky plum and berry aromas are a bit spicy, and its plum and herbal berry flavors finish round, with spice notes and dry tannins.
This plump, easy-drinking wine offers plenty of ripe fruit. Lovely pink grapefruit or gooseberry notes lead the way, buttressed by passion fruit shadings. No doubt it's a crowd-pleaser.

appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: A thrilling wine, this impresses instantly with its detail and definition. Vividly fruity with a mix of melon, apple and stone fruits, this tangy, toasty effort has nuanced notes of herb and mineral as well. Drink now through 2030.

Ripe cassis and berry aromas come with common Rioja side notes of vanilla, cedar and tobacco. This wine feels flush, with plenty of weight but also balance. Flavors of raisin, prune, cassis, chocolate and vanilla finish full, toasty and warm. This is a ripe reserva made in the classic Rioja style; drink through 2025.

Lots of chocolate, carob and nut on the nose, plus raisin, more chocolate and tart blackberry on the palate—think granola bar, or trail mix, and you're in the right ballpark. This is a profile that generally piques my interest precisely because it is a little odd. Chalky, even pasty in the mouth, it closes with the same flavors until a long and bitter—half-metallic, half-Brussels sprouts—note takes over the back end. —D.M.
A delicate nose of citrus and white blossoms moves to the light-bodied palate. This is citrusy and zesty, with grapefruit and orange flavors riding on a tangy current of acidity.

wine: Black Kite 2005 Redwoods' Edge Pinot Noir (Anderson Valley)
appellation: Anderson Valley, Mendocino County, California, US
review: Opens with a burst of red cherry, plum and pomegranate aromas, and a smoky scent of charred meat bone that offers hints of bacon fat. Tastes beautifully ripe and supple, with complex fruit, spice and oak flavors that are supported by an intricate acid-tannin structure. A terrific wine, but I encountered some bottle variation in various tastings.

wine: Thacher 2018 Shell Creek Vineyard Own-Rooted Chenin Blanc (Paso Robles Highlands District)
appellation: Paso Robles Highlands District, Central Coast, California, US
review: Very tight aromas of wet stone, light white flowers and Asian pear flesh show on the always appealing nose of this bottling by Sherman Thacher, one of the white-wine highlights from Paso Robles each vintage. The grippy wine grabs hold of the palate with a chalky texture and very dry white-fruit flavors, proving tense throughout the sip.

appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: This is very nice, crisp and fresh, with pure fresh cut pear fruit flavors, and hints of pear skin and citrus rind. There's good texture, mouthfeel and body, with crisp minerality setting off the ripe fruit. A nice, smooth, unwooded finish.
88-90 This is dry, firm, the botrytis giving richness rather than sweetness. Quite toasty, as well.

appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Off-dry and slightly sugary, this fruity, candied sipper mixes orange blossom, orange candy and baby aspirin flavors into a concentrated midpalate. Moscato is on fire these days, and this wine will surely please those who love the style.

wine: Giancarlo Ceci 2015 Almagia Rosso Biodinamico Red (Castel del Monte)
appellation: Castel del Monte, Southern Italy, Italy
review: This Demeter certified blend of Uva di Troia and Montepulciano carries odd aromas of peanut skins, asparagus and saucy, sour red fruit. The palate offers a bit more enjoyment with its more fruit-forward nature, bracing acidity and abrasive tannins carrying to the finish.
Ripe and juicy, this wine comes mainly from vines in the Mâcon region. Attractive yellow fruit flavors are filled out with spice and almond, accented by refreshing acidity. Drink now.

appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
review: Classic overtones of olive and black pepper lend character to pulpy, ripe black cherry flavor in this bold, full-bodied Syrah. It's rich and yielding on the palate with just a faint fringe of tannins. It finishes on a slightly medicinal note.

Richly oaked aromas of burnt wood, caramel and sawmill compete with jammy blackberry and cassis notes. A rugged, drawing palate is fiercely tannic and dry. Blackberry, burnt oak and coffee flavors dry out quickly on the finish, leaving simmering toasty mint. Drink through 2025.

wine: Zahtila 2008 Mayo Family Vineyards Old Vine Zinfandel (Dry Creek Valley)
appellation: Dry Creek Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: An overripe, high-alcohol wine, this shows bold flavors of raisin, plum, prune, dark chocolate and spice. It almost tastes like Port, although it's dry.

Light but flavorful and fresh, this wine has good varietal character, medium body and good complexity, too. Aromas of red cherry and tea lead to cherry and plum flavors, mild tannins and a bit of fresh acidity for balance.

wine: Kana 2008 Katie Mae White Table Wine Riesling (Columbia Valley (WA))
appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Though labeled simply White Table Wine, this is all Riesling, done in an off-dry (3.1% residual sugar) style. The fruit is a powerful burst of apricot and peach, annotated with honey and caramel apples. It's sweet enough to have a little brown sugar-style graininess as well; could work with some desserts but also with spicy foods if the wine is well chilled.

appellation: Val di Neto, Southern Italy, Italy
review: A blend of 60% Gaglioppo and 40% Cabernet Sauvignon, this polished red conveys aromas of underbrush, cassis, grilled herb and red currant. The juicy palate delivers crushed black cherry, ground pepper, licorice, clove and a coffee note alongside velvety tannins.

wine: L'Ecole No. 41 2005 Seven Hills Vineyard Estate Perigee Red (Walla Walla Valley (WA))
appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: From the oldest vines in the Seven Hills vineyard, this is lush and thick in the mouth. A power-packed, evocative Bordeaux blend, it features tightly knit and layered black fruits, augmented with subtle barrel flavors, earth and herb. The balance is beautifully managed; firm acids balance out the still-chewy tannins, and hints of pepper and herb add just the right spicy highlights.

wine: Old World 2005 Dei Du Rocchi Ranch Fog Line Red (Sonoma Coast)
designation: Dei Du Rocchi Ranch Fog Line
review: This Cabernet-Syrah blend is made in a lighter, more acidic and earthier style than most red wines these days. With only 13.9% alcohol, it shows crisp flavors of dried cherries, tobacco, black pepper and sandalwood. Needs a good decant.

wine: Domaine François Schmitt NV Rosé Sparkling (Crémant d'Alsace)
review: Aromas of red apple have a really tart fresh edge. The palate adds more citrus freshness to these tart red-apple notes and fizzes with frothy bubbles. The palate is slender but lively with all the fizz while the finish is dry and moreish.

wine: Alpha Estate 2016 Ecosystem Reserve Vieilles Vignes Single Block Barba Yannis Unfiltered Xinomavro (Amyndeon)
designation: Ecosystem Reserve Vieilles Vignes Single Block Barba Yannis Unfiltered
review: The nose on this Xinomavro has a fruit, black cherries, anise and blueberry character, followed by velvety flavors of plums, cloves dried herbs and vanilla spice. The wine has some depth but is easy-drinking now. The finish is smoky and lingering.
This easy-drinking Pinot Grigio opens with a crystalline appearance and clean citrus, pear and peach aromas. Fresh acidity and a touch of peachy sweetness characterize the mouthfeel.

wine: Saints Hills 2018 Le Chiffre Chardonnay (Hrvatsko Primorje)
review: Straw colored with a green tint at the rim, this elegant Croatian Chardonnay has aromas of lemon curd, soft white peach and a whiff of vanilla in the bouquet. It is soft upon entry with full-bodied texture. On the palate there are flavors of caramelized pineapple, lemon curd and lemon meringue pie before a crisp, clean finish.

The top wine of Château du Cèdre is beautifully balanced, its chewy tannins given the right perspective by the impressively dark fruits. The wine is brooding, profound, concentrated and complex. Age for at least 6 years.

wine: Pierre and Charles Sparr 2011 Cuvée Tradition Pinot Gris (Alsace)
review: Richly warm wine, spicy and very fruity. Seville orange and citrus combine with tropical fruits to give a wine that is full in the mouth and concentrated while ready to drink. Drink until 2018.

wine: Tenuta Poggio il Castellare 2009  Brunello di Montalcino
review: Roasted coffee bean, underbrush, toast and allspice lead the nose on this big wine. The one-dimensional palate offers dense cherry extract, licorice and the warmth of alcohol. It's already evolved so drink now.

wine: Ampelos 2014 Ampelos Vineyard Lambda Pinot Noir (Sta. Rita Hills)
appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
review: Light in color, this equally light-bodied red has spiky acidity and intense flavors of rose petal, lilac and black tea. Bittersweet on the finish, it leans more savory than fruity, providing intrigue and earth.
Here's a solid Pinot Noir for drinking now with a fine steak or chop. It's dry, tannic and silky in the mouth, with pretty flavors of cherries and cola.

wine: Baglio del Cristo di Campobello 2010 Lu Patri Nero d'Avola (Sicilia)
review: This is a pure expression of Nero d'Avola, with bright cherry and generous milk chocolate notes that are backed by toasted oak tannins and a fresh, spicy finish. The quality of the fruit is lively, rich and chewy.

appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
review: There's a delicate whiff of dried orange peel and apple cider vinegar on the nose of this unique Finger Lakes Riesling, but the palate is chock full of fresh apples accented by a sweet tangerine acidity and hints of clove and spice.

appellation: Dry Creek Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: Very soft to the point of melted, this gentle wine has chocolate, blackberry pie, cherry jam and smoky flavors that are fundamentally dry, but finish with an almost liqueur-like sweetness. Good with everything from a smoky charbroiled steak to vanilla ice cream.

wine: The Grifter 2013 Vintner's Select 05 Red (Napa Valley)
review: This is a blend of 49% Merlot with 19% Cabernet Sauvignon, 8% Zinfandel and 4% Syrah offered at an attractive price point. Puckering tannins soften in the glass to unveil hefty blackberry pie and plenty of dark chocolate with mellowed acidity.

wine: Dr. Pauly Bergweiler 2013 Bernkasteler Badstube Spätlese Riesling (Mosel)
review: Earthy notes of saffron and crushed stone accent sweet orange and honey in this zesty, gossamer-textured wine. It's cutting and spry with acidity, finishing with an aromatic spray of honeysuckle and tangerine.

This ripe wine is beautifully balanced, full of black fruits and acidity with an underlying, sophisticated layer of tannins. A blend of Touriga Nacional and Alicante Bouschet, it's dark in color and powered by structure and fruitiness. Drink now.

Harmony and balance are the hallmarks of this full-bodied and vibrant wine in which everything seems well woven together. It smells like bright cherry, cinnamon and cloves, and tastes brisk and tangy like red cherries. A velvety texture complements the brightness of the fruit flavors.

A dark, dense wine that comes from a parcel of old vines. It's a solid, supremely tannic wine at this young stage, but that black fruitiness will push through over the next few years. Great swathes of juicy acidity, tannins and fruit, all impressive potential. Drink from 2018.

wine: Martin Woods 2016 Motley Rose Vineyard Gamay (Eola-Amity Hills)
appellation: Eola-Amity Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: This is a bright, spicy bowl of red fruits, with penetrating flavors and buoyant acidity. It's clean and sharply etched, with a strong tannic base. Such a young wine should improve over the next couple of years; drink up by 2021.

The official residual sugar reading is .77%, but you don't need a degree in fruit chemistry to know that this is a sweet wine, more appropriate as a dessert sipper than as a dry table wine. It's clean and vibrant in sugared apricot, peach and pineapple flavors.

wine: Le Due Torri 2009 Vigneto le Cocce Pinot Grigio (Friuli Grave)
review: This is a very successful expression of Pinot Grigio that offers just the right level of structure and aromatic intensity against freshness and overall crispness. You'll get aromas of peach, citrus and mature pear.
Citric lightness of touch is already suggested on the nose but fully manifested on the palate where is centers on a linear, taut and fresh palate with real, soaring freshness.

Funky at first and simply not as smooth, pure and clean as Catena's Nicasia and Adrianna Malbecs, which are the components of this wine. Argentino in 2007 is deep and dark like always, with coconut and cassis aromas preceding a sweet, ultrarich palate that's teetering on candied. Quite oaky and chocolaty as well, with brown sugar and depth to the finish. Drink now through 2014.

wine: The Williamsburg Winery 2005 Gabriel Archer Reserve Red (Virginia)
review: Poised and poetic, this wine starts with a lovely floral nose of violet and unfolds in the mouth with smooth but structured elegance. Overall spiced wood and pepper flavors are meaty but soft.

wine: Grgich Hills 2009 Estate Grown Chardonnay (Napa Valley)
review: Dry and somewhat herbaceous, this Chardonnay has some good pear, melon and orange fruit, but otherwise is missing out on opulence, especially at this price. New oak, to the tune of 40%, contributes buttered toast and caramel, but the wine needs more than that.

This smells vibrant and sweet fruited, with aromas of strawberry hull, ripe melon and pineapple. Despite the fruity intensity on the nose, the palate is light and bright in feel, with citrus-driven flavors and ample acidity to keep it fresh and vibrant through the medium-length close.

appellation: North Coast, North Coast, California, US
review: Black-pepper and veggie flavors accompany firm tannins and a full body in this rustic but enjoyable wine.

Nicely concentrated aromas of black currants meet tobacco, bell pepper and pencil lead on the nose. There's great verve and tenison on the medium-bodied palate, with tart blackberries against a backdrop of graphite and cocoa dust.

appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: This appealing Bordeaux blend opens with seductive mocha and milk chocolate aromas, threaded with cedar and toast. The fruit stands up to the wood, with pretty berry and rhubarb flavors. Extra bottle age has smoothed it out.

wine: Domaine Christian Moreau Père et Fils 2015 Valmur Grand Cru  (Chablis)
winery: Domaine Christian Moreau Père et Fils
review: A ripe, rounded wine, this shows the richness of the vintage while not missing out on intense acidity. The mineral texture and the concentration of the ripe yellow fruit come together in a harmonious whole while needing a little more aging. Drink from 2020.

This is a rich jammy wine. Great black fruits and dark tannins are mixed with touches of chocolate and bitter coffee. It is dense, although with the acidity of the year it has a crispness that contrasts with the richness. Drink this ripe wine from 2026.

Aromas of blue flowers, black-skinned berries, baking spice and Mediterranean herb take shape in the glass. A blend of 90% Sangiovese and 10% Cabernet Sauvignon, the approachable palate doles out black cherry, crushed plum, cinnamon and clove while dried mint provides backup. Silky tannins and fresh acidity balance the juicy flavors. Drink through 2018.

wine: Joseph Fritsch 2018 Furstentum Grand Cru Gewurztraminer (Alsace)
review: Fresh, ripe yellow apple hits the nose before notions of peach candy appear. The palate of this wine has appealing ease, a lightness that helps counter the medium-sweet finish full of fruit.

wine: Cavalli Tenuta degli Dei 2009 Le Redini Red (Toscana)
review: From superstar fashion designer Roberto Cavalli and his son Tommaso comes this plush blend of Merlot (90%) and Alicante that is aged 10 months in French oak. Le Redini is a soft, velvety wine that shows food-friendly flavors of exotic spice, black cherry and dried tobacco.

wine: Lepe 2019 Zabala Vineyards Sauvignon Blanc (Arroyo Seco)
appellation: Arroyo Seco, Central Coast, California, US
review: Dried grass, kelp, sea spray and a hint of peach aromas show on the nose of this single-vineyard expression. There's a light grassy tone to the sip, which is clean and pure with faint nectarine and more oceanic flavors.

appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: With an off-putting orange color, this Rhône-style blend seems sweet, with orange, apricot and vanilla flavors.

wine: Falchini 2015 Ab Vinea Doni  (Vernaccia di San Gimignano)
appellation: Vernaccia di San Gimignano, Tuscany, Italy
review: Aromas of yellow pear, Spanish broom and a whiff of honeyed nut float from the glass. The medium-bodied palate shows good weight and depth for the cool wet vintage, offering golden apple, nectarine zest and bitter almond framed in vibrant acidity. It finishes crisp and clean, with an underlying pinning of flint on the close.
Rich and oily wine, with smooth pear and apple purée flavors. That means it lacks acidity, compensating for that with its ripe bursts of flavor. The finish reveals toast and spicy almonds.

wine: Franz Künstler 2001 Hochheimer Holle Spätlese Trocken Riesling (Rheingau)
review: These Trocken Spätlese with their high (12.5%). alcohol are strange. They lack the grace of the lighter wines. But they pack punch and power which lies oddly with freshly ripe grapes. Peppery characters are uncomfortable to drink.

What a treat to find a truly dry, balanced table wine among a sea of sweet and overoaked Zins. Plenty of blackberry, clove, sage and cherry flavors are supported by just firm-enough tannins and medium body. The blend is 79% Zinfandel, 12% Carignane, 8% Petite Sirah and 1% Alicante Bouschet.

The nose offers stewy, jammy fruit and pickling-spice aromas. This is a lighter-sized wine that wants to be a heavyweight, with such dark oak, caramel and black cherry flavors. Finishes with similar flavors.

wine: Cayuse 2005 God Only Knows Grenache (Walla Walla Valley (WA))
appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Dense flavors of deep cherry fruit hold center stage in this intense and concentrated 100% Grenache. The flavors resonate through pure fruit, stone and chocolate, yet maintain a feminine, elegant style. Compared with other Cayuse wines, this has more sweet, deep, berry flavors, without sacrificing minerality and definition. It's a joyful wine, saturated with beautiful fruit, pure and deeply satisfying.
Made from 80% Sangiovese and 20% Merlot, this informal red opens with subtle baking spice and cassis aromas. The simple palate evokes black currant jam and vanilla, with round tannins.

Smells ripe and friendly, sort of like a jelly doughnut. The palate is creamy, dense and balanced, with saturated berry and spice flavors. Very smooth and integrated overall, and while it's definitely dark and ripe it's also popping with freshness. A complete wine at every turn.

wine: D'Arenberg 2004 The Stump Jump G-S-M (McLaren Vale)
review: One heck of a nice GSM for $10, this wine has pretty tree bark and barbecue aromas, followed up by juicy plum and raspberry fruit on the palate. Light vanilla/oak accents add interest, as does a mouthfeel thick with dust/chalk. 15,000 cases produced.
Cherry, raspberry and spicy oak aromas open this chunky, standard Rioja. Roasted plum and currant flavors turn more oaky on the back side, while the finish feels fresh and tastes lightly spicy.

appellation: Dry Creek Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: Kind of sweet and simple, with jammy blackberry, cherry and raspberry flavors in a soft texture. Drink now.

wine: Aranleón 2016 Blés Tinto Organic Wine Red (Valencia)
review: This magenta-colored blend is mostly Bobal, and it smells reduced, with raw raspberry and plum scents. A racy, rubbery and pinching palate holds tart plum and currant flavors. This wine is constrained as a whole, but juicy.

Less jammy than the previous vintage, this is still a beast of a wine, but one with some layers and nuance. The nose is a dense combo of charred oak, golden beet, fleshy plum, licorice root, coffee bean and earthy spices. Muscular tannins on the palate are chalky, while the fruit feels satiny. The oak is in the foreground now but should integrate with time. Don't touch this anytime soon. Drink 2023–2035.

appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
review: Dark oaky aromas of minty black fruits are gritty and concentrated. Following that nose, this is grinding on the palate. Acid-pushed dark-fruit flavors come with an offset of oaky vanilla, while this is clipped and gappy in feel on the finish.

wine: Obsidian Ridge 2015 Half Mile 2640' Cabernet Sauvignon (Red Hills)
appellation: Red Hills, Lake County, California, US
review: A deep and dark color signals the concentrated flavors to come in this very ripe, opulent and ultimately gentle wine. Cinnamon, clove and cedar notes waft up from the glass, with rich blueberry, blackberry and espresso flavors that coat the palate. Grown at 2,640 feet in a vineyard strewn with sharp, black obsidian rocks, the wine is packed with minute threads of tannin that add good grip to the texture without being at all drying. Best after 2023.
Aged in traditional large oak casks, this easy wine offers bright berry tones with touches of toasted almond and spice. It's lean, crisp and informal overall.

appellation: Potter Valley, Mendocino County, California, US
review: Fresh peach and light floral aromas lead to ripe, grapey flavors and a soft, soothing texture in this medium-bodied wine. It is smooth and low in acid, with a charming flowery element that helps it stand out.

This wine has a perceptible tawny tone despite its youth, and the scents also seem to suggest that the wine is slightly oxidized. Whiffs of sherry and apple cider lead into a soft, flat, rather dull palate of nondescript fruit.

appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: A beautiful wine, sharp and clean in acidity and savory, with ripe lemon, lime, pineapple and grapefruit citrus flavors. Finishes dry and honeyed, a paradox.

This is the driest wine in an already-dry range of Champagnes. With no dosage, it is crisp, tight and mineral. The high proportion of Pinot Meunier in the blend brings out the the flavors of white fruits and the crisp texture. The bottling is still young and will be better from 2017.

wine: Signaterra Benziger 2009 Shone Farm Vineyard Sauvignon Blanc (Russian River Valley)
appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: Dry and crisp, with pure citrus flavors of Meyer lemon, lime and pink grapefruit. The acidity is strong and mouthwatering. There's also a potent note of unripe ammonia.

wine: Abacela 2013 South East Block Reserve Tempranillo (Umpqua Valley)
appellation: Umpqua Valley, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
review: Moving up the ladder among Abacela's Tempranillo bottlings, this is packed with juicy, ripe black fruits. There are scent and flavor accents of tanned leather and savory herbs, and the wine is built for staying power. If there is a quibble to be made, it's that the tannins have a rather chalky residual flavor.

A subtly wood aged wine, the white fruit flavor giving an extra dimension with a touch of honey. It has all the direct, delicious fruit of 2007, the wine then rounded out with nutmeg and soft acidity.

Hailing from a very warm vintage, this smells like buttered movie popcorn and baked apple. In the mouth, there's adequate acidity and a touch of minerality. Flavors of tropical fruits run sweet and woody, while the finish drips honey and banana flavors.

appellation: Vermentino di Sardegna, Sicily & Sardinia, Italy
review: This medium-bodied white offers aromas of beeswax, Mediterranean scrub and a whiff of citrus. The tangy palate offers ripe white peach, passion fruit and a hint of grapefruit before a bitter almond close.

wine: Dr. Konstantin Frank 2012 Méthode Champenoise Brut  (Finger Lakes)
appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
review: Saline and mineral tones accent fresh apple, pear and lemon in this zippy, invigorating sparkling wine. Made in a Chardonnay-based traditional-method style, its delicate pétillance and whiffs of caramelized sugar and brioche are enticing.

wine: Finca Torremilanos 2006 Torre Albéniz Reserva  (Ribera del Duero)
appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
review: Slightly roasted on the nose, with aromas of blackberry and a penetrating grassy note. The palate is authentic for RDD, with clipped, herbal flavors accenting soupy berry and bouillon. Finishes earthy, meaning there are leafy notes and dryness.

Crisp, green and friendly, with aromas of celery and fairway grass. The palate also has some green to it, namely celery and edamame, but there's adequate melon and grapefruit to balance things off. The finish is dry and pithy, with a lasting flavor of pink grapefruit. Imported by USA Wine Imports, Inc.

wine: Laurel Glen 2014 Counterpoint Cabernet Sauvignon (Sonoma Mountain)
review: Blended with 10% Merlot, this wine sources grapes both from its famous estate, as well as from nearby Pickberry and Murray vineyards. It delights in luxuriously bright acidity and a jammy explosion of blackberry, chocolate, clove and tobacco, the texture roundly approachable.

Aromas of sun-baked soil, stalky underbrush, crushed herb and toast lead the nose while the ripe full-bodied palate offers fleshy black-skinned berry, coffee and oak-driven spice. Rounded tannins support the juicy fruit. Drink 2018–2024.

Earthy mineral and forest tones meld seductively in this off-dry Riesling. The palate feels juicy and revitalizing, marked by tangerine sweetness and racy acidity. It finishes lean on a cool, evergreen note.

wine: Winzer Krems 2009 Ried Sandgrube Grüner Veltliner (Niederösterreich)
review: Despite its Kabinett (off dry) designation, this tastes bone dry, allowing all the crispness of the fruit to shine. It is full of white fruit, lemon and grapefruit flavors, a great burst of freshness. Screwcap.

appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: Soft and gluey, with sweet, jammy flavors of pineapples and butterscotch. Tastes like cough drops.

wine: Marqués de la Concordia 2007 Federico Paternina Gran Reserva  (Rioja)
review: Plum and raspberry aromas are fresh and jammy, with a mushroom note. On the palate, this aged Rioja is wide but with raw tannins that hammer. Spicy but drawing red-fruit flavors are peppery and lean on a finish that turns tart as it winds down.

appellation: Red Mountain, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Syrah comprises 63% of this wine, with the balance Merlot (25%) and Sangiovese. Vanilla extract, baking spice, green wood and cherry aromas lead to ripe, full-bodied black fruit flavors. The tannins give a dry squeeze. A warm finish caps it off.

wine: Bouchard Père & Fils 2006 Beaune du Château Premier Cru  (Beaune)
review: One of Bouchard's signature wines, this is a selection of fruit from different Beaune vineyards in the company's domaine. It is big, ripe and soft, balancing these elements with rounded cantaloupe fruit and spice. The toast is a major factor at present, and the wine would benefit from 2 years aging.

A warm, generous wine with good, meaty, intense fruit, from the Piedmont region of Italy. It shows the accessibility of Barbera, but also its potential richness and concentration. Layers of soft wood and herbs add complexity. In the local dialect, “fiulot” means “young man,” and Prunotto, which is owned by Antinori, has chosen the name for the most youthful style of wine in its range.

wine: Sherwood House Vineyards 2016 Oregon Road White Merlot Rosé (North Fork of Long Island)
appellation: North Fork of Long Island, Long Island, New York, US
review: Whiffs of watermelon and spring blossoms abound on the nose of this dry Merlot, vinified as a white wine. Crisp yellow-cherry and citrus flavors are a bit more delicate in concentration on the palate but its vibrant acidity is refreshing.

wine: Tenuta Le Querce 2000 Rosso di Costanza  (Aglianico del Vulture)
appellation: Aglianico del Vulture, Southern Italy, Italy
review: Stylish but bold. The nose is bruising but lively, with pepper, plum and overall punch. In the mouth, black cherry and raspberry fruit is both snappy and rich. A wine with personality. And it's not fading.

Simply delicious white wine with lip-smacking freshness, bright peach and apple flavors, and clarity from front to back. It's a little leesy but a lot more crisp and oceanic, with a well-cut body and mild citrus undertones throughout.

This prestige cuvée gets the full barrel treatment, and it shows in its aromas of smoke, cedar, tobacco and molasses. Some plum and earth flavors do poke through on the palate, giving us hope that its evolution will put it into a more balanced place. Hold 4–5 years.

wine: D'Arenberg 2002 The Olive Grove Chardonnay (McLaren Vale)
review: Tastes and smells quite tropical, with pineapple and melon at the fore. The nose shows some butter, but on the palate that plump yellowness is more like honey. Finishes a little tart, but it's still a juicy wine.

wine: Big Basin 2011 Rattlesnake Rock Syrah (Santa Cruz Mountains)
appellation: Santa Cruz Mountains, Central Coast, California, US
review: Prevalent black pepper scents swirl alluringly with leather, air-dried meats, tea and blackberry fruit on the nose. It's light, vibrant and peppery on the palate as well, making it a refreshing wine that also delivers a hefty, satisfying flavor profile.

wine: De Martino 2005 Legado Reserva Carmenère (Maipo Valley)
review: Standard but crisp red-fruit aromas are the greeting, while the main course is centered around bright raspberry and cherry flavors. It shows a touch of varietal character, meaning it's spicy and a touch saucy. But overall it registers well, with medium depth and length.

appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: Black-currant jam, crushed slate and black plum show on the nose of this bottling, which features a rendition of the famed Edvard Munch painting on the label. Candied cherry and blackberry meet with a roasted wood flavor on the palate.

Sweet and full-bodied, this is packed with apple, pear and quince flavors. Initial leesy notes slowly blow off, so decant prior to serving, or age 5–7 years. This is lush rather than classically racy, but still very enjoyable.

wine: J.P. Chenet 2020 Original Sauvignon Blanc (Vin de France)
appellation: Vin de France, France Other, France
review: A shy nose on this wine only lightly suggests citrus and river rocks. The palate is pleasantly lemony, light in concentration but bolstered by zesty acidity with a clean finish. Pair this wine with oysters.

wine: Tenuta Cocci Grifoni 2003 Le Torri  (Rosso Piceno Superiore)
appellation: Rosso Piceno Superiore, Central Italy, Italy
review: Young and spunky, but very good when placed under the microscope. The nose is forward and fruity, with animal cracker and juniper as secondary aromas. The mouthfeel is full and ripe, and that's backed by tasty berry flavors. With tannin and chocolate on the finish you can safely say that's it's a full package in its price range. Imported by Empson (USA) Ltd.

Lively on the nose, with a strong whiff of Pine Sol but also some mulchy leaves. The palate is chunky and solid in terms of feel, with short berry and plum flavors mixed with green, mossy, drying tannins. A bit funky but not out of the realm of what's normal for Carmenère.

The '08 Oro is Cab dominant while the '07 favored Shiraz, a difference that seems to be an improvement. Rich and concentrated with lovely dark plum, cassis and black raspberry components coupled with accents of tree bark, sweet spice and soft cigar tobacco. Fresh and lush all at once; easy to drink now or can hold for a year or two.

appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
review: Bitter lime peel and an elegant steeliness give structure to the sweet, fresh apples that dominate this off-dry style Riesling. Bright lemon-lime acidity leads to a mouthwatering pucker on the finish.

wine: Carl Loewen 2004 Leiwener Klostergarten Kabinett Riesling (Mosel-Saar-Ruwer)
review: In what could prove to be a breakout vintage for Loewen, the Leiwener Klostergarten Kabinett is a star. Heavily mineral on the nose, with some characteristic leesy notes, it then bursts on the palate with concentrated flavors of apple, pear and lime, all underscored by cool minerality. Finishes long and citrusy. Imported by Michael Skurnik Wines.

appellation: Anderson Valley, Mendocino County, California, US
review: A savory, leafy expression lends extra interest and complexity to this well-balanced, trim but flavorful wine. A full body and light, integrated tannins support generous black-cherry and strawberry flavors.

wine: Stag's Leap Wine Cellars 2011 Sauvignon Blanc (Napa Valley)
review: Made in a sugary style that gives it popular appeal. The flavors are of apricot, orange-lime jam, vanilla and white currants, brightened with crisp acidity.

wine: Force Majeure 2011 Collaboration Series V Ciel du Cheval Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Red Mountain)
designation: Collaboration Series V Ciel du Cheval Vineyard
appellation: Red Mountain, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Chris Gorman is the winemaker for this pure, old vine Cabernet Sauvignon. Despite the high alcohol and the use of 100% new French oak, most of the old vine nuances are still there—a wild mix of heather and herb with berry and grain scents that weave together in the mouth. Brambly and tart, with strawberry and cherry fruit, it's a compelling wine that keeps you on your toes.

Crimson in color but also translucent, with a candied, slightly green nose. Overall this is a simple quaffer with no excess weight and reasonably good flavors of berry and plum. Bland on the finish, but for $4 who's caring about finish?

This ripe, dense wine is rich with red berry fruits that are laced with acidity and spice. Its soft tannins and crisp edge are full of fruit that is layered with an attractive, juicy aftertaste. Drink now.

wine: Thomas Fogarty 2017 Damiana Vineyard Chardonnay (Santa Cruz Mountains)
appellation: Santa Cruz Mountains, Central Coast, California, US
review: Soft, creamy aromas of nectarine and apricot meet with warmer touches of butterscotch and crème fraîche on the light yet lush nose of this bottling. There's a chalky, grippy texture to the sip, where a toasty backdrop upholds flavors of baked lemon, macadamia nut and sea salt.

wine: Produttori di Manduria 2015 Elegia Riserva  (Primitivo di Manduria)
appellation: Primitivo di Manduria, Southern Italy, Italy
review: Aromas of baked cherry and blackberry meld with dried hay, anise and orange on the nose. The medium-bodied palate is all about jammy fruit, with accents of spice, orange and earth that add complexity. Bright acidity and drying tannins push through to tighten up the close.

wine: Viña Requingua 2007 Toro de Piedra Reserva Carmenère-Cabernet Sauvignon (Curicó Valley)
review: Fairly generic on the nose, with a floral accent. The mouthfeel is tannic and hard, thus the name Toro de Piedra (Bull of Stone) is appropriate. Rubbery, dark and baked flavors of blackberry and chocolate give this a masculine personality, and the finish is pure nails. This may be one to hold for another year; maybe the tannins will soften.
Made in a popular style, this jammy wine has cherry, blackberry and spiced rum flavors that are ripe and pure, with a pleasantly tannic texture. Easy to like.

wine: Willful 2018 Seven Hills Vineyard Red (Walla Walla Valley (OR))
appellation: Walla Walla Valley (OR), Oregon Other, Oregon, US
review: Half Cabernet Sauvignon, half Merlot and hailing from one of the valley's top sites, this old-vine wine was fermented whole cluster. The aromas intrigue in notes of black tea, flower, raspberry, soil, date and cassis. There's pleasing depth and freshness to the flavors, with the oak pulled way back.
Soft, easy and flavorful, this Merlot has fruity tastes of cherries, black raspberries and latte dusted with cocoa and cinnamon. Drink now.

wine: G. H. Mumm 2014 RSRV Blanc de Blancs Grand Cru Brut Chardonnay (Champagne)
designation: RSRV Blanc de Blancs Grand Cru Brut
review: Bright acidity and tense minerality come together in this taut, beautifully structured wine, bringing out flavors of nuts and citrus. Drink now.

wine: Novelty Hill 2016 Stillwater Creek Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Columbia Valley (WA))
appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Aromas of leafy herbs, kirsch, black cherry jam and spice lead to quite ripe fruit flavors. It's a strange mixture of overripe and underripe elements, wanting a bit more structure to support the ripe fruit.

Exotic aromas of coconut, honey and spice start this unique wine from Sigalas. On the palate, waves of lemon, coconut and vanilla are balanced by acidity and spice. Delicious, and unfolding on the tongue, it has its own distinct personality, with a faraway flair.

wine: Château Certan de May de Certan 2009 Barrel sample  (Pomerol)
winery: Château Certan de May de Certan
review: 94-96 Barrel sample. Wonderful concentration here, the wine has the most powerful wood spice, ripe and mineral tannins. It is impressive in every way, showing the total richness of the vintage.
Dense, rich and smoky in cherry, bark and clove, this wine is full bodied and inviting, with a big streak of forest floor that's unrelentingly earthy.

wine: Domaine Albert Mann 2010 Furstentum Grand Cru Pinot Gris (Alsace)
review: Rich, full bodied and medium dry, it is powered by ripe fruits, lychees and pomegranates. A spicy undertow brings along some acidity to this concentrated wine. Drink from 2016.

A blend of grapes including traditional Corvina and Rondinella undergoes air-drying for extra-rich concentration and intensity. That, with careful oak aging, has shaped a richly textured, dense wine that would pair with game meat or bean soup with smoked bacon. It shows raw, slightly chewy tannins on the close.

wine: Georges Duboeuf 2007 Cuvée Elevé en Fût de Chêne  (Moulin-à-Vent)
designation: Cuvée Elevé en Fût de Chêne
review: Fresh, gushing strawberry and red cherry fruit. There is just a side order of tannin, and a hint of wood, but this wine just shows very fresh fruit and sweet and sour acidity. Drink now.

White wild flower, ripe orchard fruit, toasted nut and bread crust aromas lift out of the glass. The vibrant juicy palate tastes of Golden Delicious apple, candied tangerine zest and crystallized ginger zest alongside bright acidity and a lively perlage.

wine: Domaine Christian Moreau Père et Fils 2012 Blanchot Grand Cru  (Chablis)
winery: Domaine Christian Moreau Père et Fils
review: With its perfect south-facing exposure, the Blanchot Grand Cru produces a warm wine. It is opulent, a power of ripe Chardonnay and spicy wood. Combining rich yellow plums, citrus and apricot, topped with wood, this is a structured wine to age. Drink from 2018.

appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: This is straight-down-the-fairway Syrah, with berry, cocoa and spice aromas and flavors. It's not very complex but enjoyable all the same.

appellation: Horse Heaven Hills, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: This almost pure Carmenère (there is a little Cabernet Sauvignon in the blend also) sneaks up on you. At first herbal and green, it fills in with a few hours of breathing time, lengthens and shows unsuspected complexity. Cranberry, a whiff of smoke, a bite of pepper, and fresh, not dried herbs, nicely blended into a seamless, satisfying whole.

wine: Three Rivers 2007 Champoux Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Horse Heaven Hills)
appellation: Horse Heaven Hills, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: The Champoux vineyard's classic black cherry fruit is here driven deep into a seam of what can only be described as dense rock. Astringent and dark, with a dusty, chalky character, this seam of graphite continues on through the finish. Reminiscent of some mediumripe Bordeaux, this should be drunk with a thick, juicy steak.

Already developing well, this rich wine is balanced by acidity. It offers spice, generous apricot and wildflower-honey flavors and a core of botrytis. This wine from Anne-Laure Dufour is still young and will develop further. Drink from 2021.

Nail polish and other sweet, somewhat artificial aromas lead to raspberry flavors. It's a tight, lean wine with more acidity than flesh. A little bit sour but drinkable. Blends Sangiovese, Uva de Troia, Cabernet and Merlot with modest results.

The nose is very shy: a mere hint of earthiness emanates. The slender palate shows very clean fruit of yellow apple residing on a slender lemony palate. This is fresh and sprightly with a dry finish. Drink soon.

wine: Snake and Herring 2014 Dirty Boots Cabernet Sauvignon (Margaret River)
review: A typical yet classy example of Margaret River, this wine dishes up notes of dark cherry, currant, tobacco, mocha, eucalyptus and dried green herbs. The medium-bodied palate has soft but chewy tannins, with some apparent oak components and a dark-cherry and green-tinged finish. It's elegant and soft enough to drink now but will age well through 2028.

appellation: Mendocino County, Mendocino County, California, US
review: Dry, leathery and tannic, this Syrah isn't offering much relief right now. It has tightly wound flavors of crushed blackberries, black currants, cola, leather and pepper. It's a good mountain wine, but it really needs some time. Give it four or five years.

wine: Michel Rolland Napa Valley 2014 MR Red (Napa Valley)
review: Made in partnership with Alpha Omega Winery's Jean Hoefliger, this famous namesake wine embraces the fullness that is Napa Valley concentration and sunny richness, showing baked plum, cinnamon and generous tannin and oak. The backbone is plush and lush in texture, evolving as it opens in the glass. Enjoy this in good time; should show best 2024–2034.
A chocolaty sweetness pervades this medium-bodied, smooth-textured and oaky wine. It adds grape jam to the chocolate flavors and has a soft mouthfeel.

wine: Casa Santos Lima 2013 Bona Vita Red (Lisboa)
review: This is a soft, bold and rounded wine. Rich black currant and berry fruits dominate the blend of mainly Portuguese grapes, with a touch of Syrah. The wine is balanced, ripe and full in the mouth. Drink now.

appellation: Shenandoah Valley (CA), Sierra Foothills, California, US
review: The flavors are almost moving into late-harvest; raisiny, superripe, hot and tannic. On the plus side is the finish, with sweet, juicy, jammy fruit that is really tasty. From 77-year-old vines.

wine: Barnett 2006 Cyrus Ryan Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
review: Made in the modern, cult Napa style, this Cab, from a vineyard north of St. Helena, is tremendously rich, soft and oaky. It strikes you with effusive flavors of ripe black currants, chocolate, anise and cedar, but most impressive is the smooth quality of the tannins. Youthfully brash now, it should gather forces and mellow out after 2010 and beyond.

wine: Peirano 2016 The Heritage Collection Old Vine Zinfandel (Lodi)
review: This full-bodied wine boasts delicious fruit flavors, a dose of spicy oak, good balance and a wonderful sense of polish. Jammy raspberry and strawberry flavors meet hints of smoke, meat and herbs.

Here's a fantastic expression of Pinot Grigio that opens with enticing scents of spring wildflowers, white stone fruit and an inviting whiff of freshly baked bread. Savory and medium bodied, the rounded palate offers ripe green apple, yellow pear and lemon zest alongside a tangy mineral note.

wine: Tinto Rey 2014 Super Tinto Red (Dunnigan Hills)
appellation: Dunnigan Hills, Central Valley, California, US
review: Deep color, bold fruit aromas and substantial, spicy flavors lend significant power and concentration to this full-bodied wine. It's nearly dry, well structured and balanced, with appealing blackberry, nutmeg and cinnamon flavors.

This is superdark and savory smelling, with aromas of cumin, char, roasted blackberry and licorice. Big tannins and beaming acids structure the palate, which bears toasty, oaky flavors of berries. The finish is spicy and salty.

Often herbal and a bit green in nature, Silvaner is a much maligned grape. Yet at Thörle, it seems to blossom into something perfumed and quite fruity, redolent of peaches and fresh pears. Characteristic herb notes are fresh and nuanced, highlighted against brisk citrus and apple flavors and a silken supple mouthfeel.

wine: Maison Pagnotta 2018 Clos Voyens Premier Cru  (Mercurey)
review: A note of mocha fills and dominates the nose on this wine. Mocha also characterizes the sonorous palate, which is roasted and mellow at the same time. This roasted note broadens out the cherry fruit on the palate, but this is counteracted by freshness.

Aromas of roasted coffee bean, baking spice and a hint of blue flower lead the nose. The medium-bodied palate delivers clove, licorice and red plum alongside close-grained tannins. Drink through 2023.

wine: Clos du Lac 2001 Reserve Blend Zinfandel (Amador County)
appellation: Amador County, Sierra Foothills, California, US
review: Unmistakably California Zin, with its briary, brambly flood of wild berry and peppery spice flavors that finish dry and tannic. It's not a heavy wine, but has a silky lightness that makes it super-drinkable.

appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
review: Lightly honeyed aromas of pineapple and ripe orange are clean on the nose of this bottling. There's just enough grip to the palate, giving depth to the yellow-pear and tangerine-peel flavors.

wine: Ancient Peaks 2009 Oyster Ridge Red (Paso Robles)
appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: A blend of Cabernet Sauvignon, Petite Sirah, Petit Verdot and Malbec, this is bone dry and full bodied, and it strikes the palate with rustic tannins. It has a complexity that's hard to define, and it will pair well with grilled meats or stews.

wine: Billecart-Salmon 2006 Cuvée Elisabeth Salmon Brut Rosé  (Champagne)
review: Produced from Pinot Noir and Chardonnay, this balances ripe red berry and citrus fruits with more mature spice and vanilla. With this development has come depth, concentration and richness. It is a wine to drink with food, ripe and finishing with crisp, dry acidity.

White summer blossoms and ripe green pears make for a fresh scent. The palate lifts these notions with bright lemon acidity. All is buoyed by some residual carbon dioxide. Drink soon while this is at its aromatic height.

wine: Señorío de Sarria 2005 Viñedo N° 7 Graciano (Navarra)
review: Varietal Graciano is something we frequently see, and very rarely does it bowl us over. This wine has jumpy cherry and lemon peel aromas, and the flavors are tight, a touch sour and run toward cherry and red plum. Fruity for certain, but lacking in charm and mouthfeel.

wine: Tenuta San Guido 2018 Le Difese Red (Toscana)
review: Aromas of star anise, dark-skinned berry, wild herb and toasted oak form the nose. A blend of 70% Cabernet and 30% Sangiovese, the wine's bright, linear palate offers red currant, prune and a hint of licorice before a coffee-bean finish. Racy acidity and taut close-grained tannins provide the framework and tension.

appellation: Amador County, Sierra Foothills, California, US
review: The name suggests certain proprietarily named Ports, and it's an apt descriptor for this muscular wine, which has superripe flavors of currants and raisins that veer into an overripe tartness. It's dry, but with very high alcohol.
Smells so nice and pretty, just like a young Merlot should, but that white sugary edge to the cherries really detracts.

wine: Doffo 2016 Motodoffo Royal Tinto Red (Temecula Valley)
appellation: Temecula Valley, South Coast, California, US
review: Caramelized black cherry, baked licorice and potting soil combine on the spicy nose of this balanced bottling that features a motorcycle on the label. The tannins are just firm enough to hold up the ripe cherry and cola flavors, and there are intriguing touches of jasmine and elderflower on the finish.

A touch of smoke plays over crunchy, crisp red cherry and cranberry fruit on the nose. On the palate that same crunchy, tart red fruit expands beautifully, while that smokiness adds a darker allure. Freshness pervades and makes for an elegant Pinot that will benefit from some bottle age. Drink 2021–2028.
The wine is fruity with acidity and just a touch of wood aging. It is bright with red currants and a lively bright character. Drink from 2017.

wine: Quinta do Crasto 2016 LBV Late Bottled Vintage  (Port)
review: Bottled unfiltered, this Port comes from 70-year-old vines. It is deliciously perfumed, softly textured with ripe black fruits and hints of dried fruits. While the wine can be enjoyed now, it will be even better with some aging, waiting until 2022.

wine: Arrowood 2011 Alary Vineyard Chardonnay (Russian River Valley)
appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: The vineyard is in a warmer part of the northern valley, and yet it shows brisk acidity and the cool-climate apricot, lime and white peach flavors of a long hangtime region. It's a fine Chardonnay, oaky and buttery, and provides pleasant drinking now.

A full rich and ripe wine that has toast as well as juicy citrus and yellow fruit flavors. It's a young wine, full of crisp fruitiness that will soften and fill out. With its mineral texture, typical of Douro whites, it is a wine for aging. Drink from 2017.
Melon and honey flavors and aromas are lovely, but I wish those flavors were more concentrated than they are. Finishes with taut yellow-fruit skin and mineral flavors.
Grillo Parlante (“talking cricket”) is a pure expression of Grillo with slightly oxidized aromas of butterscotch and caramel. Fresh fruit comes through as melon, apricot and candied lemon.

appellation: Redwood Valley, Mendocino County, California, US
review: Sweet, with flavors of sugared buttercream, pineapple, vanilla and spice. If you like your Chards basically off-dry, it's for you.

wine: H. Blin NV Blin's Édition Limitée Blanc de Blancs Brut Chardonnay (Champagne)
designation: Blin's Édition Limitée Blanc de Blancs Brut
review: A pure and fruity Chardonnay, this Champagne boasts extra complexity thanks to a tight, mineral character. On the palate, crisp, lemony acidity is striated with a steely texture that adds intensity as well as ageability to this fine wine.

wine: Cecilia Beretta 2011 Terre di Cariano Riserva  (Amarone della Valpolicella Classico)
appellation: Amarone della Valpolicella Classico, Veneto, Italy
review: This opens with aromas of grilled herb, resin, stewed plum and cooking spice. The robust palate delivers raisin, dried black cherry under spirits, licorice, tobacco and dried sage alongside bracing grainy tannins that clench the finish.

Camphor, pressed rose, truffle and wild red-berry aromas are front and center on this full-bodied red. Juicy and delicious, the taut muscular palate has unexpected finesse, delivering juicy Marasca cherry, black raspberry, vanilla and licorice alongside enveloping, velvety tannins and fresh acidity. Thanks to the ripe, delicious fruit, you can't detect the declared abv of 15%. Drink 2024–2036.
Crisp and refreshing, this delivers aromas of white flower and tangy citrus. The crisp palate highlights nectarine and lemon zest alongside yeasty notes of baked bread and toasted almonds.

wine: Willamette Valley Vineyards 2017 Dijon Clone Chardonnay (Willamette Valley)
appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: Immediately drinkable, this opens with pretty accents of toasted coconut around stone fruit and apple. It's spicy and delicious, and 16 months in 20% new French oak adds a swirl of butterscotch trailing the finish.
Subtle aromas of black-skinned fruit, baking spice and a hint of lavender float out of the glass. The round palate offers red cherry jam, vanilla a touch of star anise alongside smooth tannins.

wine: Roger et Didier Raimbault 2011 Vieilles Vignes  (Sancerre)
review: Fragrant currant aromas drive this concentrated and rich wine forward. The old vines give a great depth of flavor and ripeness while keeping the fine herbaceous citrus touch. It's that rare Sancerre for aging, over 3–4 years.

wine: Domaine de Font Sane 2016 Terrasses des Dentelles  (Gigondas)
review: Hints of sweet spice, anise and cacao meld into ripe black cherry and mulberry flavors here. It's voluminous and penetrating yet finessed, freshened by sunny acidity. The finish lingers on ripe, integrated tannins. Enjoy now–2028.

wine: Provam 2008 Varanda do Conde White (Vinho Verde)
review: A blend of Alvarinho and Trajadura, this is relatively full-bodied Vinho Verde. The creamy texture is the most apparent, always freshened with lively citric acidity, a very light prickle on the mouth. The wine is fragrant and crisp. Drink this summer, but also possible to age.

The estate wine of Château du Cèdre is structured, balanced and full of fruit. It has black currant freshness under its solid tannins and dry core, poised between the intensity of the fruit and the firm structure. It will certainly age, and will be best from 2018.

This deep garnet-colored wine has a bouquet of cherry pie with touches of extra baking spice. Black currant and blueberry flavors are most apparent on entry, followed by a cooling sensation and flavors of vanilla and clove. Then enduring tannins take hold on the palate, ebbing toward a fragrant finish. Mevushal.

wine: Duval-Leroy 2005 Clos des Bouveries Blanc de Blancs Brut Chardonnay (Champagne)
designation: Clos des Bouveries Blanc de Blancs Brut
review: Made from grapes sourced from a single vineyard, this is an intensely minerally Champagne. It is dry and austere, with citrus fruits dominant. The wine needs to age to bring out all of the richness and toast flavor, but it will always be a structured Champagne. This is very much a food wine.

Malbec blended with a total of 10% Merlot and Tannat gives a wine that is firmly structured. It comes from the heights above the River Lot, a magnificent chalk-soil vineyard. Rich in tannins and young black fruits, it is just beginning to develop. Drink from 2023.

Grapes from Shea seem always to deliver a hit, no matter which winery is at the plate. The lush texture and rich berry-cherry fruit speak volumes about the quality, and the accents of earth and mineral bump up the texture and overall length. Aged 10 months in neutral barrels, it finished with some astringency, which could pair well with a seared duck breast.

wine: Baron Knyphausen 2011 Hattenheim Ortslage Kabinett Riesling (Rheingau)
review: Fresh herbs and florals brighten the nose of this exceptionally balanced Riesling. It's dry in style, yet intensely fruity, with bursts of pink grapefruit and guava that extend through a lush, creamy palate. Drink now through 2014 for its bright, floral exuberance.

wine: Mannucci Droandi 2008 Ceppeto  (Vin Santo del Chianti Classico)
appellation: Vin Santo del Chianti Classico, Tuscany, Italy
review: Made from organically farmed, dried Trebbiano, Malvasia and San Colombano grapes, this offers walnut, candied nectarine and caramel aromas. The rich but balanced palate delivers mature apricot, toasted almond and fig flavors.
Red cherries and touches of banana are the hallmarks of this fruity wine. Brightly textured and crisp with acidity, it is a light wine that is ready to drink.

An easy-drinking syrah from the northern Rhône, this medium-weight wine boasts aromas of horse sweat, black pepper and roasted cherries, backed by flavors of black cherries and dried spices. It's plump and juicy. with a mouthwatering finish. Drink now–2010.
This opens with aromas of candied ginger, mature yellow peach and toast. Made with dried Garganega grapes, the dense palate delivers dried apricot, acacia honey and a touch of toasted almond.

wine: Edna Valley Vineyard 2007 Paragon Sauvignon Blanc (Edna Valley)
appellation: Edna Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: The combination of a cool vintage and a cool region has resulted in this unripe Sauvignon Blanc. It's strong in green pyrazines alongside the lemons and limes.

appellation: Red Mountain, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: This wine shows vanilla, celery root, mesquite and herb aromas on the nose. Its baking spice flavors are quite sweet, suggesting heavy-handed oak. Vanilla flavors take over on the finish, leaving a disjointed impression.
Aromas of banana and fragrant white spring flower lead the nose. The banana note follows over to the tangy palate along with pineapple and citrus before a crisp finish.

Typical varietal aromas of black-skinned berry, blue flower a spice note waft out of the glass. The straightforward, easygoing palate conveys mature black cherry, raspberry jam and a light note of ground pepper alongside soft, round tannins. Simple but well made, it makes an ideal quaffing wine.

wine: S.A. Prüm 2001 Wehlener Sonnenuhr Vat 10 Riesling Beerenauslese Riesling (Mosel-Saar-Ruwer)
review: Viscous, almost oily in texture, this is several vintages older than most of the recent samples, yet seems so unevolved that it's not out of place. Honey and dried spices are the predominant themes, with citrusy fruit making up the core. Should evolve glacially through at least 2025.

wine: Vixen NV The Villain Red (Santa Barbara County)
appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
review: This bistro-style red is dry and lusty in cherry, tobacco and spice flavors. The winery has not revealed what varieties are in it, but it tastes like a juicy, old-fashioned field blend, and will go well with a range of fare.
This full-bodied wine has an earthy savory slant and good appley flavors as a base. Aromas of mineral water and broth give way to rich-tasting fruit flavors and a rounded texture.

wine: Duckhorn 2014 Three Palms Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
review: From the site made famous for Merlot, this estate wine shows the other side of the coin, more structured in tight tannins and a wealth of powerful concentration. Leather, baked plum and cocoa powder dominate the further components of blackberry and blueberry compote.

wine: Concha y Toro 2008 Casillero del Diablo Reserve Carmenère (Rapel Valley)
review: Sweet, minty and confected, with marshmallow and candied berry aromas. The mouthfeel is tangy on the surface and hollow down below, while the palate has average size along with vanilla-infused berry flavors. Lean on the finish. More than 300,000 cases produced.

appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: This brings substantial density to the midpalate, mixing fresh flavors of strawberry, cherry cola and malted chocolate. It gains focus and grip as it breathes open. A slim frame of stem and earth sets up the finish.

wine: Royal Muscato NV Pink Sparkling (Vin Mousseux)
review: Muscat's typical sweetness and delicacy give this an attractive balance of crisp acidity and ripe raspberry flavor. It's light, lively and intensely fruity.

This aged mix of Cabernet Sauvignon, Carmenère and Petit Verdot has aromas of minerals, brick dust, asphalt, herbs and red fruits. These set up a hard-driving palate with cola, vanilla, butter, plum and cassis flavors. A long, oaky, slightly hot finish says this has more gas in the tank; drink through 2018.

Lively, fresh and spicy, with deep cassis and berry aromas. The palate is a bit angular and bumpy in feel, but there's no issue with the wine's berry, cassis and lightly herbal flavors. Finishes long, with elegance and balance. Drink now through 2014.

Heady and superripe, this is a huge, mouthfilling wine that fits the ooze monster moniker, yet it finishes with structure and elegance. Camphor and cracked pepper scents accent the blackberry, dark chocolate and mint flavors that finish long, framed by dusty tannins. Drink now–2025.

wine: Sineann 2007 Scorched Earth Vineyard Grenache (Columbia Valley (OR))
appellation: Columbia Valley (OR), Oregon Other, Oregon, US
review: Light and gently spicy, this first-ever varietal Grenache from Sineann offers cranberry, pomegranate and boysenberry fruit, lots of acid and a quick fade.
This is well-made, medium-bodied Chardonnay. Roasted cashews and grilled lemon slices mark the nose, while the flavors reflect more of the same, then draw to a long, crisp finish. Drink now–2020.
This wood-aged wine is ripe and soft, full of black fruits and warm tannins. It is made to drink young, with great fruitiness and a rich, generous texture. Drink from 2019.

wine: Three 2016 Live Oak Zinfandel (Contra Costa County)
appellation: Contra Costa County, Central Coast, California, US
review: Bold and spicy, this high-octane wine starts with salt and pepper aromas, and delivers intense black-pepper and black-cherry flavors on a firm palate bolstered by fine-grained tannins. Winemaker Matt Cline included 11% Petite Sirah, 9% Carignan and 2% Black Malvoisie in the blend.
Aroma of red berry, pressed purple flower and a whiff of tilled earth lead the nose. The refreshing palate offers crushed blackberry and pomegranate alongside tangy acidity.

wine: Patient Cottat 2014 Le Grand Caillou Sauvignon Blanc (Val de Loire)
appellation: Val de Loire, Loire Valley, France
review: Light and bright with plenty of fruit and a lsoft texture, this lemon-flavored wine has crisp acidity and a ready-to-drink freshness. Drink now.

One of the less well-known classed growths from Saint-Emilion, Cadet-Piola produced a 2006 that is now mature, ripe and smooth. Firm tannins keep the truffle and violet flavors together. It is now ready to drink.

wine: Las Positas 2014 Coccineous Estate Red (Livermore Valley)
appellation: Livermore Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: Not showy or oaky, this wine is very dense, concentrated and dry, and needs more time to develop in the bottle. Blend from Tempranillo, Syrah, Petite Sirah and Malbec, it has an inky color, aromas of blackberry and cloves, and mouthfilling flavors backed by firm tannins and good acidity. Best after 2023.

A seductive floral lift on the nose suggests honeysuckle but also reveals zesty citrus. The palate comes in with wonderful lightness, ease and almost weightless flavor. This dry and aromatic white blend is ideally paired with bright sunshine.

wine: Gloria Ferrer NV Blanc de Noirs Sparkling (Carneros)
review: A rich, fruity bubbly for drinking now. It's a little coarse and scoury, but delicious, with candied lime, strawberry and vanilla flavors.
90—92 Barrel sample. Promoted in 2006 to Grand Cru Classé, this is a dense wine, very concentrated, more about tannin than fruit. It's hugely firm, hugely dense.

wine: Boeckel 2013 Zotzenberg Grand Cru Pinot Gris (Alsace)
review: This beautiful wine is already so balanced and ripe. Rich tropical and yellow fruits are lightly spiced and given a lift with the acidity. Along with that, it offers a more complex texture and mineral character. Drink from 2017.

appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
review: Red currant, grapeseed, smoked meat and cracked concrete show on the nose of this blend of 58% Cabernet Sauvignon, 29% Merlot, 7% Cabernet Franc and 6% Petit Verdot. Tart red plum skins, darker boysenberries and coffee elements arise on the palate, where sticky tannins and a very powerful acidity frame the sip.

appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
review: Whispers of lemon zest and orange blossoms lend subtle dimension to this brisk, minerally Chardonnay. Fresh apple and pear are demure on the palate but jolted into action by a kick of zappy lemon-lime. It's a zesty, refreshing wine ideal for youthful enjoyment.

A fine wine at the bottom of the ultrapremium price category. There's some bramble and forest aromas in advance of jammy cherry and blackberry fruit. Fades away smoothly and with good length. Not the most complex Cabernet, but it delivers the goods at all checkpoints.

wine: Obsidian Ridge 2003 Obsidian Ridge Vineyard Syrah (Red Hills)
appellation: Red Hills, Lake County, California, US
review: Seems a bit herbal or grassy at first, then reveals more mixed berries and spice with air. But it turns irretrievably tannic on the finish, with flavors of over steeped berry zinger tea. Probably best consumed young, for its exuberant fruit.

appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
review: Vibrant blackberry and cherry flavors are accented by complexities of rose petal, bramble and savory herb in this elegant, light-footed red. It's not deeply complex or penetrating, but quite charming, marked by sunny cherry acidity and a plush, lingering palate.

wine: Domaine Berthelemot 2017 Abbaye de Morgeot Premier Cru  (Chassagne-Montrachet)
review: This Meursault-based estate also has vines surrounding the old abbey of Chassagne-Montrachet. The wine shows structure and a zesty, mineral texture that dominates at this stage. It needs time to soften and fill out into a wine that has density as well as wonderful fruitiness. Drink from 2023.

wine: Château Mondésir Gazin 2019  Blaye Côtes de Bordeaux
appellation: Blaye Côtes de Bordeaux, Bordeaux, France
review: Crisp, tangy and fresh, this bright, fruity wine has good acidity. Freshly squeezed lemon flavors add a lively, zesty aftertaste. Drink now. Organic.

appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: This is a 100% whole-cluster, barrel-fermented wine from Stoneridge and Scarline Vineyards in the newly approved Royal Slope appellation. The aromas are brooding in notes of dried herbs, stem, spice and black raspberry. Full-bodied, ripe, luxurious flavors follow. There's an impressive seamlessness to it. It's all about hedonism and full-power expression, and it brings both in abundance.

appellation: Lake County, Lake County, California, US
review: A deep color and potent aromas of blackberry and black currant are the first impressions from this full-bodied, firmly structured and well concentrated wine. They lead to a palate full of deep blackberry flavors, a nicely dry balance and mouth-filling texture.

appellation: Fair Play, Sierra Foothills, California, US
review: A rosé of Grenache, grown in Fair Play, Neophyte is golden peach in color and crisp, with a long, spicy finish. Swirls of cucumber, watermelon and Nilla Wafer add depth to the palate. Only 60 cases made.

Attractively poised between softness and crispness, this best-selling Champagne is packed with ripe white fruits that are given a lift by the tight acidity. Its reliability and the increasing dryness and freshness of the wine are exemplary. This bottling is ready to drink.

wine: Domaine du Roucas de St Pierre 2016  Gigondas
winery: Domaine du Roucas de St Pierre
review: Whiffs of dried strawberry and plum introduce this blend of 70% Grenache and 30% Syrah. It's a gorgeously fruity, fleshy wine with opulent body but also nuanced by hints of crushed earth, leather and violet. A supple wine with soft tannins to enjoy now–2023.

appellation: Hunter Valley, New South Wales, Australia
review: Despite the sub-$20 price, don't expect an easy, fruit-driven style. This is more smoky and meaty, with hints of vanilla, cedar and mint making for a complex, medium-bodied Shiraz. The long finish is framed gently by supple tannins, making it ready to drink now–2014.

wine: Trump 2010 SP Blanc de Noir Brut Sparkling (Monticello)
review: This has aromas and flavors of raw almond, citrus zest, bread crust and salt. Small, vigorous bubbles provide the backdrop, while dried apple and button-mushroom flavors marks the finish.

wine: Troublemaker by Austin Hope NV 9 Red (Central Coast)
appellation: Central Coast, Central Coast, California, US
review: This blend of 71% Syrah, 16% Grenache, 8% Zinfandel, 3% Petite Sirah and 2% Mourvèdre stands up to Paso blends three times its price. Broad aromas of plum, olallieberry and dried cherry mix with vanilla, dill and herbes de Provence on the nose. The creamy palate conveys boysenberry and blackberry seasoned by lavender and white pepper.

This is an amazing wine at this price point, fun and easily enjoyable in its mix of soft, velvety red fruit and firm grip of tannin, backed by plenty of acidity. Stock up for larger gatherings and for midweek meals.

Blue flower, sunbaked earth, Mediterranean brush and dark-skinned berry aromas lead the way on this easygoing red. The round, chewy palate offers juicy black cherry, raspberry jam and a white pepper note alongside rounded tannins. It's straightforward but savory and made to be enjoyed young.

wine: Emmerich Knoll 2017 Ried Pfaffenberg Kabinett Riesling (Wachau)
review: This Kabinett-style wine's heady yuzu leaf and lemon blossom aromas persist on the wonderfully light and still slightly spritzy palate. It's sinuous and light, like a fresh citrus breeze. The finish is off dry and zesty.

wine: Viña Bisquertt 2012 La Joya Gran Reserva Gewurztraminer (Colchagua Valley)
review: Soft citrus with exotic spice notes make for a good but flabby bouquet. Things follow suit in the mouth, which is chunky and heavy. Flavors of mild citrus and lychee are oily and lightly spiced, while the finish flattens up and turns bitter. Drink now.
Smoke and baked plum notes provide flavor within this wine's easygoing structure and approachability.

wine: Herdade do Perdigão 2013 Villa Romanu White (Alentejo)
review: Tight and textured, this is a mineral structured wine. Green fruits and acidity keep the wine fresh. The aftertaste is flatter, not bringing out enough fruit.

wine: The Fifth Empire-Abstracto 2017 Gran Vino Estate Grown and Bottled Cabernet Sauvignon (Mendoza)
designation: Gran Vino Estate Grown and Bottled
review: Chunky black-fruit aromas are full and fruity but common. A grabby palate with hard tannins is jagged more than smooth flowing, while earthy plum and prune flavors culminate on a drawing finish anchored by hard rubbery tannins. Drink through 2028.

wine: Bryn Mawr Vineyards 2010 Estate Pinot Noir (Eola-Amity Hills)
appellation: Eola-Amity Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: This is a rather tannic, lightly peppery Pinot Noir, with plenty of balancing acidity. The red fruits are pleasantly backed with a bit of barrel toast.

wine: Cuvaison 2016 Mariafeld Estate Grown Pinot Noir (Los Carneros)
review: Light cranberry and strawberry flavors show impressive depth and breadth in this full-bodied expressive wine. Cola and cinnamon provide spicy seasoning that melds well with the fruit, the entirety textured in layers of velvety softness.

Warm and hearty, this opens with aromas that recall mature dark-skinned fruit, leather, truffle, scorched soil and a menthol note. The big, chewy palate delivers black cherry marinated in spirits, ground pepper and anise alongside a tannic backbone. The heat of evident alcohol dominates the finish and gives it a monolithic quality.

Peppercorn, cedar and powerful oak mark this blend of Cabernet Sauvignon, Merlot and Petit Verdot, priced fairly for the good quality. Full-bodied black fruit and weighty tannin provide concentrated richness that goes the distance.
Exotic and decadent, with violets, spice, anise, clove and vanilla scents making for a complex opening. The palate is accented by tangy orange peel tones that shape the finish. Drink now.

Though labeled varietally, almost a quarter of the blend is Malbec, along with a two percent splash of Syrah. Herbal and showing scents of stem along with peppery black fruits, this tannic and inexpensive red would be a fine match for a pot roast or stew. Black olive and smoke flavors weave into the finish.

There's a touch of almond or hazelnut buried deep within this wine's aromatic profile that contributes to its thick, dense mouthfeel. The wine is creamy and smooth and would make a good match to lightly roasted fish dishes.

Made with organically grown Sangiovese, this has aromas of black-skinned berry, underbrush and leather. The juicy palate offers black cherry, star anise and tobacco alongside polished tannins and firm acidity. Drink 2023–2031.

wine: De Grendel 2019 Cape Winemakers Guild Wooded Sauvignon Blanc (Darling)
review: Winemaker: Charles Hopkins. There's a pronounced green, herbal note right upfront on the nose of this wine, offering some serious pyrazine character. Green plum and lime leaf lead the aromas and carry through to the medium-weight palate. There's nice body to the mouthfeel, with a subtle creaminess to the midpalate that's then refreshed by bright acidity and a pithy, green-plum skin and lime pith character that floods the finish. Fresh fynbos and herbs, like celery root, parsley and mache, linger long on the close.
Full bodied and firmly tannic, this wine is nicely stuffed with blueberry and chocolate flavors and wrapped in a thick, clinging texture.

appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Charred, horsey scents of burnt leather dominate the attack. This is a dark, tannic wine, chewy and mouth-scraping dry; inside is a core of black cherry fruit, but it's overwhelmed by all the tar and smoke.

95–97. Barrel Sample. This wine's ripeness is intense, just hinting at an impressive future. The dry core of botrytis balances the honey and the spice, along with fresh lemon curd. This is likely to be a very fine wine.

wine: Villa Maria 2018 Cellar Selection Sauvignon Blanc (Marlborough)
review: This well-balanced wine bursts with fruit-bowl characteristics of grapefruit, lime and passion fruit with black-currant leaf, grass and jalapeño pepper to boot. It's slippery in texture, tangy fruited and buoyed by crisp acidity. A long passion fruit note lingers on the finish.

The richness of the vintage is very apparent in this full-bodied wine. With weight, structure and dark black fruits, it is textured and showing some vanilla and spice. Smooth, developing well and ready to drink in 2014.

This 44-acre estate in the north of the Haut-Médoc appellation has produced a blend with almost equal quantities of Merlot and Cabernet Sauvignon, spiced with Cabernet Franc. Its rich fruit and warm tannins are already delicious while also having good potential. The wine, ripe and full, should be ready from 2022.

wine: Les Belles Collines 2015 Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)
appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: A light, ethereal quality ignites this wine's compelling high-toned acidity and subtle, integrated oak. Juicy orange and cranberry form its core, as roses permeate the nose. The texture is silky smooth and inviting.

wine: Fullerton 2017 Three Otters Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)
appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: The winery has substantially increased the production of this affordably priced Pinot, which is fresh and aromatic. Scents and flavors of chocolate, strawberry, raspberry and cherry are in play, and fermentation with native yeast in neutral oak adds texture throughout. The finish turns quite tart and lightly herbal.

appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: A pretty good wine, with a firmly tannic, clean structure. Shows jammy or pie-filling cherry, blackberry and cocoa flavors, spiced with anise and pepper.

This well-endowed Cabernet is full bodied and supple, with soft curves suggesting immediate drinkability. It starts off with mint and cassis on the nose, but quickly develops some dried-fruit, almost molasses-like characters on the palate along with a touch of alcoholic warmth.

wine: Viña La Rosa 2009 La Capitana Barrel Reserve Merlot (Cachapoal Valley)
review: A step up from previous years. It's ripe and minty on the nose, with coconutty oak but also offsetting raspberry and plum aromas. Forward and full, with berry and plum flavors that handle ample toast and mint accents. Spicy, dry, peppery and long on the finish.

Made predominantly from Carricante with a drop of Catarratto, this smooth, stunning white offers delicate, enticing scents of Spanish broom, chamomile, ripe white-stone fruit and a whiff of smoke. Savory and loaded with elegance, the medium-bodied, focused palate features juicy Meyer lemon, ripe Bartlett pear, golden apple and tangy, saline mineral notes. Bright acidity lends tension and balance. Drink through 2025.

wine: Château Brethous 2018 Cuvée Prestige  (Cadillac Côtes de Bordeaux)
appellation: Cadillac Côtes de Bordeaux, Bordeaux, France
review: A year of barrel aging and a selection of the estate's best grapes give this wine a distinguished character. With blackberry fruits and rich tannins, it is dense while having a light touch. Drink from 2022. Organic.

wine: Casa de Santar 2001 Castas de Santar Touriga Nacional (Dão)
review: A finely constructed wine which shows rich herbal flavors, dry tannins and also solid, structured fruit. With its black fruits, its dense texture and its dark acidity, this is a wine which will age well, over 4–5 years.

Here is a Cabernet Sauvignon-Merlot blend that borrows on Bordeaux inspiration but delivers an all-Italian personality. Earthy smells are woven seamlessly with notes of forest berry, blackberry and cedar wood; there's also an appealing hint of smoked bacon. The wine appears firm and solid in the mouth.
