Restrained, lean, subtle black-fruit nose. Soft, round, elegant fruit flavors. Very accessible, with nuances of black cherries. True Pinot Noir character. For drinking now and within the next year, perhaps two at most.

wine: Lucienne 2011 Lone Oak Vineyard Pinot Noir (Santa Lucia Highlands)
appellation: Santa Lucia Highlands, Central Coast, California, US
review: This is a joy to drink. It's dry and silky, with savory raspberry, cherry and cola flavors that are accented by earthy notes of sautéed wild mushrooms, balsamic and soy sauce. It should improve even more with a few years in the bottle.

wine: Bowers Harbor 2013 Unwooded Chardonnay (Old Mission Peninsula)
review: Green apple with a squeeze of fresh lemon makes for a basic and easy unoaked Chardonnay. While standard and simple, this is a perfectly enjoyable wine to pair with lighter fare.

As Colheita releases go, this is young. That means that the wine is as much about fruit as about wood aging. Acidity and red fruit flavors contrast with the touches of toffee and the hints of the old wood flavors. Drink now.

appellation: Central Coast, Central Coast, California, US
review: Tastes like it comes from Edna Valley, with its dryness, great burst of juicy acidity and jammy Mandarin orange, lime, kiwi and Meyer lemon flavors. Great with crab cakes dressed in a mango salsa.

appellation: Dundee Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: Dijon clones anchor this young and refreshing wine. Flavors of lemon flesh and rind are matched to immaculate acids, and penetrate deeply into the finish. Fermented in three-year-old French oak puncheons, this is for acid-lovers and would be best over the next three or four years.

Fruity black currant aromas leap out of the glass in this wine, offering flavors that are fresh, young and fruity. It has soft tannins, cherry fruit and lively acidity. Not made for aging so drink now. Screwcap.

wine: Jerzu Antichi Poderi 1998 Marghia  (Cannonau di Sardegna)
appellation: Cannonau di Sardegna, Sicily & Sardinia, Italy
review: Though it has nice white pepper notes that coat maple and black berry fruit aromas, there's lots of wood here from start to finish. Charred oak envelopes mixed berry fruit in the mouth, where the wine's texture falls flat. Residual woodiness on the back end lasts a little longer than we would have liked.

Hints of savory earth mingle with fresh apple notes. The palate has the bright mellow freshness of ripe oranges and the juiciness of ripe pear. A core of bright lemon acidity makes for a clean, bright and refreshing finish.

appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: Pungent, tarry aromas kick off the nose of this bottling, which also shows extracted blackberry and toasted oak on the nose. The palate offers sour blackberry, dried mushroom and dank herb flavors.

appellation: Snipes Mountain, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: This 100% varietal wine brings aromas of plum, green herb, vanilla and barrel spice. The flavors are sappy and full, showing a sense of polish.

A rambunctious young buck of a wine, with untamed aromas and plenty of aggressiveness from front to back. It clamps with firm tannins while delivering dark plum and other black-fruit flavors. Gets better with airing and may improve in the bottle. Now, it needs food to tame the beast.

wine: Corazon del Sol 2017 Reserva Revana Vineyard Single Block 13 Cabernet Franc (Los Chacayes)
review: A whole lot of complexity is presented on the nose of this excellent Cab Franc, including aromas of cured meat, prickly Uco Valley herbs, blackberry, leather and fine oak. A juicy palate expands with airing, while this tastes of spicy blackberry and cassis. A direct finish avoids roughness and heat but is tight and firm. Drink through 2026.

appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: This wine is a mixture of StoneTree Vineyard and Dineen fruit. The aromas pop, with notes of blueberry pie, plum, coffee and spice. Intensely rich, layered blue fruit and coffee flavors follow. It's a hedonistic interpretation of this variety, with fruit and barrel both playing big roles.
A fine, perfumed wine with great fruit. It's ripe, with lovely rich flavors and a backbone of firm tannins. This is a good, solid, classic wine. Imported by Vineyard Brands.
Oak and oak driven spice dominate the nose and carry over to the palate along with butterscotch, coffee and buttered herb. Tightly tannic, it lacks fruit richness and has an astringent finish.

appellation: Amador County, Sierra Foothills, California, US
review: Intricate aromas and spicy, complex flavors make this medium-bodied wine an adventure to drink. It smells like cherries and cloves and wood smoke, tastes nicely ripe but dry, and has an appetizing, tannic grip in the texture.

appellation: Temecula Valley, South Coast, California, US
review: Straight down-the-middle aromas of red cherry, salt and pepper, vanilla and a touch of brioche show on this bottling of a clone that's related to the Brunello region. It's lighter bodied on the palate and quite easy to quaff, with light cherry and strawberry flavors riding a gravelly texture.

wine: I Giusti e Zanza 2010 Perbruno Syrah (Toscana)
review: The quality of fruit in this expression of Syrah is dark, plush, rich and opulent. The bouquet offers notes of black cherry, prune, smoked bacon, tobacco, white pepper and clove. The tannins are luscious and firm, and there's plenty of ripe fruit to keep the wine firmly fixed to the palate for many minutes.

Clean and showing decent varietal character with grapefruit, grass and gooseberry notes on the nose. Herbs, mild citrus and melon on the palate. Decent mouthfeel with good fruit-acid balance. Simple, but correct and enjoyable Sauvignon Blanc.

wine: Europa Village 2017 C'est La Vie Ben Drake Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Temecula Valley)
designation: C'est La Vie Ben Drake Vineyard
appellation: Temecula Valley, South Coast, California, US
review: Aromas of stewed red fruits, oregano and mahogany kick off the nose of this bottling, which offers a complete and dry sipping experience. The palate combines herbs with cocoa, cracked pepper, soy and carob flavors that amplify the rich red-fruit core.

wine: Romililly 2013 Monte Rosso Vineyard Zinfandel (Moon Mountain District Sonoma County)
appellation: Moon Mountain District Sonoma County, Sonoma, California, US
review: From the highly sought-after vineyard high atop the Mayacama Mountain Range, this burly red traffics in smoky leather and big, ripe, juicy black fruit, providing touches of spice and smoke along the way.

wine: Domaine Albert Mann 2011 Rosenberg Pinot Gris (Alsace)
review: A warmly perfumed wine, it has all the aromatic characters of Pinot Gris, rounded and soft with only a few hints of acidity. Off-dry, it is ready to drink.
This easy going Pinot is light and silky in body, with pleasant cherry, cola and cinnamon spice flavors. It's good enough for curious consumers to find out about Pinot Noir without spending a bundle.

You'll find aromas of underbrush, clove, red berry, blue flower and a whiff of toast on this elegant expression of the 2013 vintage. The bright, sleek palate delivers juicy wild cherry, ground pepper and coffee alongside fresh acidity and polished, fine-grained tannins.

wine: Gloria Ferrer 1996 Late Disgorged Brut Carneros Cuvee Sparkling (Carneros)
review: The winery's priciest bubbly is easily its best, finessing the roughness of the lesser blends with a smoothness that glides across the palate like silk. It displays peaches and cream Chard flavor, and a wonderful balance and dryness. Finishes with classic Champagne elegance.

wine: Michel-Schlumberger 2013 Coteaux Sauvages Estate Red (Dry Creek Valley)
appellation: Dry Creek Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: An unusual commingling of 71% Syrah with 25% Zinfandel and 5% Petite Sirah, this offers a richness of dark pepper and baked, jammy blue and black fruit, the melded tannin providing further weight and structure. Cherry and and violet add a high-toned expression to the whole.

wine: Pierre Frick 2002 Cuvée Precieuse Tokay Pinot Gris (Alsace)
review: A fresh style of Pinot Gris, with aromas of toast and chestnuts and flavors of ripe, juicy fruit. There is some acidity, but this is still rich, with some pepper and softness at the end. Imported by Louis Dressner Selections.

wine: Gräflich von Hohenthal'Scher 2005 Erdener Treppchen Kabinett Riesling (Mosel-Saar-Ruwer)
review: At $12 for a single-vineyard kabinett, this is an excellent value, delivering exotic honey, apricot and spice notes. The texture is creamy and silky; the finish is lush and soft. Drink it over the next few years.

wine: Weingut Binz 2017 Nackenheimer Kabinett Trocken Riesling (Rheinhessen)
review: Perfumed and pristine, this dry, pertly balanced Riesling offers layers of lime and grapefruit flavors cut by shards of slate and steel. Its refreshingly tonic style is quaffable but elegant. Enjoy now–2021.

wine: Michael Mondavi Family Estate 2016 Emblem Chardonnay (Sonoma Coast)
review: This is a barrel-fermented white that fully embraces its richness in the form of a baked pear, caramel and crème brûlée. It's full bodied and ample in fruit, with an underlying crispness that brightens the finish.

wine: Domaine du Castel 2017 La Vie Blanc du Castel White (Haut-Judeé)
review: This wine features aromas of green apple and coffee. Notes of almond blossom make their way through flavors of pink grapefruit, lemon and marzipan. A pervading sense of brightness lingers from first sip through the lively finish.

Give this young Cab time in the cellar to come around. Right now, it's fresh and tannic, with primary fruit blackberry and cherry flavors, and the sweet smoky oak hasn't been integrated. Should knit together over the next 4-6 years, at least.
This full-bodied wine tastes especially ripe and jammy, offering almost-sweet plum, strawberry and blueberry flavors on a velvety texture of soft tannins. It's styled like popular red blends.

wine: Haden Fig 2017 Bjornson Vineyard Pinot Noir (Eola-Amity Hills)
appellation: Eola-Amity Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: This light and balanced single-vineyard selection brings a whiff of composted earth along with medium-ripe blackberry fruit. Firmed up with proportionate acidity that adds a lick of minerality, it rolls into a tight finish with polished tannins.
88-90 Barrel sample. A smooth, ripe, dense wine, with well-integrated fruit and noticeable acidity that powers through with intense flavors of dark cocoa.

This wine's black fruit aromas come with road tar, leather and raisin notes. It's intensely tannic, with ripe, savory berry and cassis flavors and integrated oak. Chocolate and baked black fruit notes last on the strong, tannic finish. Drink through 2025.

appellation: Edna Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: A big improvement over the '08 bottling, the winery's '09 is dry and tart in Central Coast acidity, with pure, clean flavors of tangerine, vanilla and buttered toast. It's a lovely Chardonnay; drink now.

appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: An excellent lineup of vineyards, including estate, Red Mountain and Champoux fruit, contribute to this firm, meaty Merlot. It is chewy and substantial, with a core of black cherry and plenty of new oak. It resolves into flavors of mushroom, earth, coffee grounds and grainy baking chocolate. A return to form after the disappointing '02.

appellation: Santa Ynez Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: Bill Foley named this winery after his daughters. This wine shows stark sour grass aromas at first but then reveals riper scents of dried pears, poached apples and a touch of guava. It's very fresh and both soft and striking on the palate, with lime zest and bitter pith balancing more tropical elements.

wine: Château Tanunda 2009 The Château 100 Year Old Vines Shiraz (Barossa)
review: Full bodied and supple, this wine shows an interesting array of sensory notes for Barossa Shiraz, with notes ranging from espresso, tar, mint and green peppercorn to dark chocolate and blueberry. Finishes long and softly dusty, suggesting the ability to age through 2020, although it's very drinkable now.

wine: ZinPhomaniac 2014 Old Vines Reserve Zinfandel (Sonoma County)
review: There's 3% each of Grenache and Petite Sirah in this wine that is quite ripe and straightforward in its fruity waves of blackberry, cherry and oaky chocolate. Firm tannins don't overwhelm, opting instead to support and structure. Black pepper leaves a lasting impression on the finish.

appellation: Santa Lucia Highlands, Central Coast, California, US
review: Aromas of warm brioche, apple scone and cream laced with singed lemon draw the nose deep into this wine. Broad, approachable flavors of apple and pear are leveled by a line of Meyer lemon acidity and chalky minerality throughout. It's very welcoming and bright.

wine: Raymond 2014 District Collection Cabernet Sauvignon (Stags Leap District)
appellation: Stags Leap District, Napa, California, US
review: Richly layered red fruit accents an explosion of firm lengthy tannin, alongside dashes of clove and cinnamon, in this hearty full-bodied red. Robust and concentrated, it shows oaky bursts of vanilla and smoke on the finish.
You could drink this easy Moscato with fish, chicken, even pork, but it's sweet enough to classify as a dessert wine. It shows flavors of honey, apricots, tangerines and limes.

wine: Benton-Lane 1999 Sunnymount Cuvee Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)
appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: Good texture and more flesh than the B-L reserve from the same excellent vintage. This is a beautifully crafted and balanced wine that could pass for a good Gevrey-Chambertin. Flavors of beetroot, herb, leaf, cherry and spicy oak; will certainly improve with further cellar time. Just 100 cases were produced.
Touches of sweet peach and honey open the bouquet of this easygoing, well-priced sparkler. Pair this with barbecued shrimp or tempura vegetable appetizers.
This is a distinctly simple Chardonnay. It's marked by pineapple, pear and peach flavors. Will satisfy America's basic Chardonnay craving.

A touch of yeast still mixes with the clean citrus zest notes on the nose of this wine. On the palate, that leesiness cushions the uncompromising pure lemon freshness. It's concentrated in body and dry, vivid and brisk in its flavors, with a stucture that will keep it delightful until 2030, if not longer. Rejoice in the lip-smacking finish.

A big, ripe, fruity wine, backed up with firm tannins. The structure is impressive, giving smoky flavors and layers of new wood. It is rich and potentially long-lasting. Under the inspired control of Pascal Dalbeck, Belair is fully living up to its classed growth status.

wine: Thirsty Owl Wine Company 2019 Plane Vineyard Pinot Noir Rosé (Finger Lakes)
appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
review: A pretty shade of salmon pink in the glass, this is a brisk, light-bodied rosé that offers tones of pink grapefruit and white cherry. Bright acidity keeps it fresh, while delicate pepper and cherry-skin tones on the finish lend balance.

appellation: Sagrantino di Montefalco, Central Italy, Italy
review: This wine deserves its lofty reputation as one of Italy's premier bottlings. It opens with a gorgeous fragrance of berry, leather, truffle and spice. The palate delivers ripe and delicious black cherry, black berry, white pepper and chocolate notes accompanied by firm but refined tannins. This will age beautifully and develop complexity for decades. Drink 2016–2028.

wine: Winderlea 2016 Winderlea Vineyard Pinot Noir (Dundee Hills)
appellation: Dundee Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: Decanting is strongly recommended, as this old-vine, biodynamically farmed wine is shut tight when first opened. Primary fruit flavors of strawberry and cherry gather weight with airing, and the wonderful purity of the wine begins to shine. The lengthy finish is detailed by herb, berry and citrus—subtle, well-integrated flavors that suggest a long life ahead. Drink now through the late 2020s.

wine: Sainte-Croix 2005 La Bergerie Viognier Viognier (Vin de Pays d'Oc)
appellation: Vin de Pays d'Oc, Languedoc-Roussillon, France
review: This is a fresh, lightly perfumed, crisp wine featuring red apple and kiwi fruit flavors. It is poised, elegant, with just a hint of Viognier weight and richness. Not imported.
With smoky aromas and strict tannins, this is initially an austere wine. The fruit remains firm and tight, very powerful, while the final acidity gives a delicious, more juicy finale.

wine: Scott Paul 2011 La Paulée Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)
appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: Scott Paul's largest production Pinot Noir is a nicely balanced, silky wine, fermented with wild yeasts and structured for elegance. Raspberry, black cherry, a touch of blood orange and a lick of molasses all contribute.

wine: Pasqua 2004 Villa Borghetti  (Amarone della Valpolicella Classico)
appellation: Amarone della Valpolicella Classico, Veneto, Italy
review: This inky Amarone offers dense and inviting aromas of plum, blackberry, freshly crushed black pepper, lead pencil, tar and leather. It delivers most of its intensity to the nose and makes for a food-friendly alternative. Try it with game or pork stuffed with stewed prunes.

Boysenberry, blueberry, graphite and rubbery aromas form a generous bouquet. The mouthfeel is tighter and more structured than the nose, with oaky, baked flavors of blackberry and toast. A dark, toasty, minerally finish has a crisp feel. Drink through 2018.

appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: Pristine aromas of strawberry and herbs are fresh and inviting on the nose of this bottling. There is a fun freshness to the palate, where the cherry tones are enhanced by greener elements of oregano and dill, all wrapped in firm tannins.
This stainless steel fermented Sauvignon Blanc is kind of thin and weedy, with lemon and lime flavors toned up by citrusy acids. Not bad for this price.

Opulence is the winery's reserve Syrah, and it is a robust, tooth-staining wine that takes no prisoners. Dense scents suggest a pig roast on a pile of licorice sticks; the aromas are almost visceral. The fruit has been very well handled and the tannins, though full and powerful, have been polished to a satiny sheen. There's a little chalkiness to the finish, perhaps from acidification, but that may well resolve with a little more bottle age.

Alastro is a food-friendly blend of Grecanico and Chardonnay. Grecanico adds fresh, floral aromas and the Chardonnay gives the wine its creamy, smooth texture. A percentage of the wine is aged in oak and this process lends aromas of spice and vanilla.

wine: Santa Carolina 2016 Reserva de Familia Malbec (Rapel Valley)
review: A lot of black fruit is on the nose of this Malbec, but also a mild sense of vinegar and volatility. A full, rough palate is braced by hard tannins, while this tastes more oaky, blackened and charred than fruity and defined. Coffee, burnt wood and beefy flavors fill out a grating finish.

appellation: Central Coast, Central Coast, California, US
review: Rounded aromas of red cherry and mulberry pie meet with star anise and allspice on the nose of this bottling. There is a spicy core to the sip, where gingerbread flavors play against rich cherry and dried strawberry elements.

Alvarinho and Chardonnay are the chosen grapes for this blend. As its name suggests, a salty taste from the ocean spices up the ripe yellow and green plum fruits. It's soft with a fine balance of acidity and a soft honey touch at the end.
This simple white isn't very expressive, but the palate eventually reveals unripe yellow apple and green pear. It's diluted, with a short finish.

wine: Château d'Ollières 2013 Haut de l'Hermitage Red (Coteaux Varois en Provence)
appellation: Coteaux Varois en Provence, Provence, France
review: From selected parcels of the Ollières estate, this wine is impressive. It has weight but that is balanced by the acidity and the generous black fruits and acidity. This is certainly a wine that has been well aged, although it would pay to wait another year before drinking. So drink this very fine wine from 2018.

This bright Riserva opens with floral, soapy notes of church incense, Spanish cedar, dried orange peel and polished river stone. It's a feminine wine with power and intensity on the close due in part to the immense firmness of the tannins.

appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Now one of three Viogniers produced by Charles Smith, this is from Art den Hoed's Yakima Valley Vineyard, and was barrel fermented in neutral French oak. Clean and pure fruit aromas lead into fresh, natural, tree fruit flavors of peach and apricot. There's a nice kick of citrus in the vibrant acidity.

wine: Markus Altenburger 2014 Jerry & Barry Für Fruchtige Rosé (Weinland Österreich)
review: Muddled notes of ripe berry on the nose come into sharper view on the citrus-focused palate. There is a vestige of tannin and pleasant dryness. Drink soon.

This wine comes from the only Burgundy region to grow Sauvignon Blanc. It's soft in style, more nutty than herbal, with almond and white fruit flavors. Immediately drinkable and refreshing, it's ready to go now.

appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: Dense in the glass, this blend of Syrah, Grenache and Mourvèdre is a lesson in concentration. Aromas of espresso roast, dark fruit, grilled plum and peppery meats lead into a viscous palate with firm tannins. Dark plum, caramel and nutmeg flavors make for a powerful sip.

wine: St. Innocent 2016 Freedom Hill Vineyard Pinot Blanc (Willamette Valley)
appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: This delicious, sexy wine impresses with its leesy, textural mouthfeel, its mountain spring freshness, it's crisp lemon and grapefruit flavors, and its underlying minerality. One-quarter was fermented in neutral French oak, the rest in stainless steel. A dash of minty wintergreen trails the finish.
Very sweet and soft, with mocha notes punctuated by brighter berry flavors that come across as nearly cloying on the finish.

wine: Adorato 2020 Flora Grenache Blanc (Santa Ynez Valley)
appellation: Santa Ynez Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: Tightly woven aromas of melon, plumeria and gardenia are quite floral but balanced on the nose of this bottling. There's a burst of acidity on the palate, leading through green mango and melon bubblegum flavors, with the slightest hint of stone on the finish.

appellation: Anderson Valley, Mendocino County, California, US
review: This dry and extremely flavorful wine offers rose petal and prosciutto aromas on the nose, with vivid grapefruit and luscious pear flavors on the palate. A rather full body and a lingering finish add to the experience.

wine: Quinta da Ribeirinha 2013 Vale de Lobos Grande Escolha Red (Tejo)
review: Dense and spicy, this blend includes Touriga Nacional and Alicante Bouschet.The spice is balanced by generous black fruits and acidity that give great structure and density. Drink this wine from early 2018.

Another Cahors from the stable of Alain-Dominque Perrin, this one is the entry-level wine, made to be more accessible than his flagship wine from Château Lagrezette or the luxury cuvée. There's still plenty of toasty oak, but also some raspberry-cherry fruit and green tobacco on the finish.

This crisp Sauvignon doesn't wow with intensity, weight or complexity. But it is a clean, well-crafted wine at an excellent price. Snappy grapefruit flavors are buttressed by hints of honeyed peach and a refreshing finish. Imported by Golden Kaan USA.

wine: Avignonesi 2006 Riserva Grandi Annate  (Vino Nobile di Montepulciano)
appellation: Vino Nobile di Montepulciano, Tuscany, Italy
review: Avignonesi's Riserva Grandi Annate is designed as an icon wine from Tuscany but doesn't quite deliver the goods. The issue has to do with the aromas that recall sweet pumpkin contrasted against intense blue flower or violet.

appellation: Greco di Tufo, Southern Italy, Italy
review: The nose is quite shy but eventually reveals subtle whiffs suggesting orchard fruit and crushed rock. The medium-bodied palate is straightforward, offering peach and a saline note accompanied by fresh acidity.

Generic from head to toe, this opens with a hint of wood and aromas that suggest cinnamon-spiced applesauce. The palate is plump but flat, while flavors of wood grain and mixed white fruits finish with a vanilla note and then lasting bitterness.

This proprietary and undisclosed blend is tart, astringent and aromatic. Notes of raspberry jam, squeezed lemon and coffee syrup take center stage here. It spent 22 months in half new French oak, and it's ready to go.

appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: Offering a more traditional California Zinfandel style than some of the other 2011s, this takes off with scents of a warm, butter-crusted cherry pie, unfolding on the palate with cranberry jelly. There's a slight herbal character and quite of bit of tannic grip, so expect this one to improve in the years to come.
The palate is drenched in sweet oak and sugarplums. This is not to say that it is a syrupy quaff: there is also cocoa, toast, dried herbs and a note of eucalyptus that pinches at the finish.

Enticing aromas of blackberry, bramble and wet leaves meld on the nose of this elegant, nuanced Spätburgunder. It's concentrated and juicy, with black cherry flavor, but invigorated by a stream of laser-like acidity that carries through the finish. It ends with a pretty violet accent.

Lovely floral scents of black locust flower, orange blossom and a whiff of aromatic herb float out of the glass. The round but elegantly structured palate offers white peach, white currant, sage and mineral. Soft acidity lifts the creamy flavors.

wine: Meerea Park 2003 Alexander Munro Shiraz (Hunter Valley)
appellation: Hunter Valley, New South Wales, Australia
review: A hint of eucalyptus gives this wine's blackberry fruit a slightly medicinal quality, while black-olive notes provide darkness and depth. The tannins impart a texture somewhere between creamy and silky, remaining somewhat firm on the finish. There is considerable sediment, so decant before serving.

Jammy and full of raisin, stewed berries and leather. Calling it ultraripe might be an understatement because it's nearly over the top in its heft, extract and tannin level. A high-production bruiser that has tons of power but very little precision.
This fruity Champagne is full of raspberry flavors. The wine's crispness gives a fine lift of acidity and adds a tangy texture at the end. Drink this attractive bottling now.

Here's an inky colored and deeply concentrated 50-50 blend of Cabernet Sauvignon and Petit Verdot that delivers rock solid structure and intensely dark aromas of blackberry pie, rum cake, plum, prune, clove, leather, cola, and pipe tobacco. You'll need to pair this wine with succulent beef to break up those tight tannins.

This is a fragrant and fresh ripasso with pressed rose petal, ripe fruit, spice and aromas of cherry cola. The wine is smooth and soft with a medium to long finish that would work well with pasta dishes. Imported by International Cellars.

wine: Altamana 2015 Single Vineyard Constanza Malbec (Maule Valley)
review: It has taken Alta Vista a few years to get this Maule Valley Malbec right, but this rendition is on the mark. A saturated black color and jammy aromas of blackberry, minerals, licorice root and raisin lead to a fleshy palate that's a touch loose in structure, with tannic backing. Toasty oak, herbal blackberry and gamy flavors are complex, while ripe berry and oak flavors offset a minty green note on the finish. Drink through 2023.
Honey and dried apricots provide pretty accents to this late-harvest wine. Sweet but surprisingly light in the mouth. The finish is pleasant but short.
While the wine is a touch gamy, it also has a ripe, fruity character. There is a touch of wood, underlining the acidity and juicy red fruits. The finish brings out the richness of the vintage.

wine: River's Edge 2012 Barrel Select Pinot Noir (Elkton Oregon)
appellation: Elkton Oregon, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
review: Offering good value, this high-alcohol barrel selection saw 50% new oak. It's got a whiff of funk, but the main flavors are there—black fruits, coffee grounds, toast, cacao, Dr Pepper—with grainy tannins that finish with generous mocha, caramel and espresso streaks.

appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: This wine offers simple tones of apple and oak on the nose and palate. It is medium in build and straightforward in its appeal.

wine: Leeuwin Estate 2004 Prelude Vineyards Chardonnay (Margaret River)
review: The Prelude Vineyards Chard typically seems a soft-edged, full wine to me—this year it's even more so. Floral and pear aromas lead to more tropical, toasty flavors of nut and plantain. Acid hounds will want more zing, but this will satisfy most everyone else. Imported by Old Bridge Cellars.

wine: Sonoma Coast Vineyards 2003 Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)
review: Made from grapes grown close to the chilly Pacific, this is a wine with bright acidity and elegance. It's got some size, too, but unlike many big, rich Pinots from warmer areas this one toes the line of balance like a pro. The cherry cola, raspberry, tea and gentle spice flavors are satisfying and complex. Best next year and through 2008.

Round, clean and a touch leathery, but not penetrating or dense. For a nice, smooth red wine with some plum and cinnamon spice, look no further. This crianza is easygoing, lightly oaked and good throughout.

wine: Benessere 2016 John's Promise Estate Red (St. Helena)
review: An unusual blend of 84% Cabernet Sauvignon and 16% Aglianico, this wine has big tannin grip and an intensity of dried cherry, strawberry and mocha. Rose-petal aromas permeate beneath.

Tastes overripe and hot, with a raisiny, stewed prune edge to the otherwise pleasant blackcurrant and cherry flavors. Too bad, because the tannic structure is very nice. That cooked taste is not going to age out.
An earthy, farmyard-touched wine, this has juicy red fruits alongside acidity. It is tight, needing the acidity to calm down.

Soft and jammy with seasonings of black pepper, dried herb and clove, this is a well-integrated and powerful blend of 68% Zinfandel and 32% Cabernet Sauvignon. Soft tannins grip lightly and without distraction, as toasted oak weighs in.

This semisweet white blend offers aromas of melon, hazelnuts and hickory smoke. On the palate there is fruit sweetness and flavors of honeydew and cantaloupe. It is smooth and round in the mouth with a soft finish.

There's a distinctive aromatic element to this single-vineyard wine that resembles dried sweet herb or basil followed by generous tones of sweet berry fruit, toasted nuts and vanilla. Made from the hearty Montepulciano grape, the wine sees 11 months of wood aging (in both larger casks and smaller barrique) that help render flavors of exotic spice and cigar box. It's chewy and rich in the mouth and would pair well with grilled meats.

wine: Novy 2013 Carlisle Vineyard Zinfandel (Russian River Valley)
appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: Complex, integrated and soft, this wine from fellow winemaker Mike Officer's historic site is lightly spiced in cinnamon and pepper. Dollops of vanilla and blackberry make themselves felt on the palate amid the zest.

With aromas of cherry cough syrup and expensive oak, this is a big, rich, flashy Shiraz. Fine-grained tannins, balanced acidity and plenty of plush fruit mark the palate, but the oak is a little too much in the fore.

appellation: Seneca Lake, Finger Lakes, New York, US
review: Notes of sweet quince and pommelo add a soft, blossomy character to this dry yet richly textured Riesling. Quite creamy on the palate, the finish is long, ending with a spray of crushed white pepper over tart grapefruit pith.

Cedar, pressed yellow-flower, toasted nut and acacia aromas lift out of the glass. Fermented and aged in large casks and barriques, the palate offers oak, butterscotch, mature yellow apple and lemon drop before a bitter almond close.
Soft, ripe fruit, already accessible. This has a generous feel and flavors of berries and red plums. Not a wine for aging, but very attractive.
The candy-pink color is a precursor to the sweetness of this wine. Strawberries are cut with squeezed-lemon flavors. The wine is bright and ready to drink.

appellation: Tierra de Castilla, Central Spain, Spain
review: Nervy on the bouquet, with forceful, fiery red berry scents. The mouthfeel is fresh and clacky, while flavors of red plum and dry blackberry are solid and clean. Offers a dusting of light oak and spice on the finish.

wine: Villa Vignamaggio 2007 Terre di Prenzano  (Chianti Classico)
review: Terre di Prenzano is an easy, compact wine that makes up for its thin mouthfeel with bright aromas of wild berry, cherry and dried currant.

An easy wine—this is zesty in acidity and slightly sweet in orange jam and pineapple flavors. The sweetness is the dominant feature, making it a good partner for slightly sweet foods, like teriyaki dishes.

wine: Encosta do Sobral 2018 Reserva Branco White (Tejo)
review: This wood-aged wine, produced from grape varieties more commonly found in Douro white wine, is lightly spicy, fruity with mango and white peach flavors and crisply fresh at the end. It is an attractive wine that is ready to drink.

appellation: Lake County, Lake County, California, US
review: An extroverted burst of meaty, minerally and fruity flavors defines this medium-bodied, firm-textured and concentrated wine. Imagine prosciutto wrapped around canteloupe for the flavor, plus vivid acidity and a lingering, almost smoky finish.

wine: Williams Selyem 2003 Hawk Hill Vineyard Chardonnay (Russian River Valley)
appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: It's hard to describe this as Chablisian, given the 15-percent-plus alcohol, but that word captures its minerality. There's a flintiness underlying the oak, citrus and peach flavors of this bone-dry wine. Similar to grand cru Chablis—it's tough in its youth. Hard to tell where it's going.

wine: Marqués de la Concordia 2016 Federico Paternina Banda Azul Crianza  (Rioja)
review: Aromas of compost, stale peanut and berry fruit carry the nose. In the mouth, this is raw and grabby, with tomato-like acidity. Green, earthy flavors of tomato and herbs are low on fruit and finish with a note of compost.

appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
review: There are fascinating aromas of cantaloupe balls, Meyer lemon peel and crushed chalk on the nose of this bottling. It's crisp and flavorful on the palate, loaded with orange sorbet and white flowers, yet sliced through with high acidity and a chalky mouthfeel.

This wine comes from a small estate planted with equal proportions of Merlot and Cabernet Sauvignon. The wine is balanced between fruit and a core of firm tannins. The aftertaste gives a smoother, ripe view of life.
On flinty soil, the vines of this parcel have produced a wine that is smoky, mineral and tight. The fruit is concentrated and structured, demanding further aging. Drink from 2021.

There's a touch of raisiny overripeness in this dry Syrah, not a lot, but just enough to confuse the palate. Other than that, the wine is as smooth as can be, with a chocolate and bitter cherry finish.

The exquisite freshness of tart, red cherry mingles with the perfume of cinnamon-sprinkled blueberries. The palate then presents wonderfully ripe but tart fruits of the forest, again with that lovely cinnamon inflection. The body is sinuous, slender but firm. The finish is gloriously spicy. A very elegant wine.
There's a slight gaminess to this wine that makes it more interesting than your average Zin. Also some black-pepper and licorice notes that add complexity. A solid effort at a fair price. Best Buy.

wine: Von Othegraven 2004 Kanzem Altenberg Eiswein First Growth Riesling (Mosel-Saar-Ruwer)
review: Words hardly do this wine justice. It's unctuous almost beyond the point of being wine—offering a mèlange of dried fruits and honey that ooze over every taste bud, filling the pores of your mouth and then releasing sugar and flavor for minutes afterward. And the aromas aren't too shabby either, giving up intense scents of dried apricots and orange marmalade, tinged with tea-like notes that add a sense of lightness and complexity.

Made from Loin de l'Oeil, the dominant white grape in Gaillac, this has produced a perfumed, stylish wine. With touches of green plums and a tangy and mineral texture, this is a ripe wine. The edge of spice and acidity at the end complete a wine that will be ready from 2022.

Dark berry, vanilla, roasted coffee bean and toast aromas waft out of the glass. The firm palate offers dried black cherry, anise, espresso and oak-driven spice alongside grippy tannins that leave an astringent finish.

wine: Château de Brigue 2010 Signature Red (Côtes de Provence)
review: This is herbal, with some flavors of green bell pepper and wild spice. The wine is light bodied and fruity, with attractive, juicy black-currant flavors and a perfumed aftertaste.

appellation: Rogue Valley, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
review: Close to half Viognier, this is cofermented with Roussanne and Marsanne, then blended with 7% Grenache Blanc. A small portion of the Viognier was fermented in Acacia oak. Deep and rich flavors are packed with sliced pear, then range on through oranges and mixed citrus, adding a touch of vanilla in a fresh tangy lingering finish.

appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: A tasty Zin, rich and elaborately layered, with wild red berry, chocolate, spice, gingerbread cookie, brown sugar and sandalwood flavors. A bit too sweet and soft, though.

wine: Williams Selyem 2003 Ferrington Vineyard Pinot Noir (Anderson Valley)
appellation: Anderson Valley, Mendocino County, California, US
review: Whoa—this is a tough, acidic baby on opening. No way you want to drink it immediately. Give it time, either by decanting or cellaring. It's  big, dry and tart, stuffed with black cherry, cola, coffee and Asian spice flavors. Best after 2007.

wine: Dr. Pauly Bergweiler 2009 Bernkasteler Badstube Spätlese Riesling (Mosel)
review: Medium-bodied and lush, powered by ripe fruit flavors of apple, peach and pineapple. There's a bit of a flinty note on the nose and a slight vinyl-like element on the finish, which add either complexity or detract from the fruit, depending on your perspective.

Ripe plum, black-skinned berry and pressed violet aromas take center stage. The no-frills but savory palate offers fleshy Morello cherry and ground clove set against solid tannins. Drink through 2019.

Not a big, overwhelming blockbuster, this harmonious blend of equal parts Grenache Blanc, Roussanne, Clairette and Bourboulenc features ripe citrus and pineapple flavors, with a hint of melon thrown in for good measure. It's pleasantly medium bodied and creamy in the mouth, with a reasonably long finish. Drink it over the next 12–18 months.

wine: Castello di Monsanto 1995 Chianti Classico Riserva  (Chianti Classico)
review: Medium-bodied with a light tint, this is a warm wine full of red-currant flavor and hefty tannins. The finish is long as can be, with a pronounced touch of interesting wood. Very tangy and lean, this may improve down the line. Now it's a little closed and lean.

appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: Dusty black cherry, baked earth and chaparral spices show on the nose of this bottling. There is decent tension to the palate, where black-cherry flavors compete for attention with dried thyme and savory sagebrush tones.

wine: Chateau Ste. Michelle & Dr. Loosen 2014 Eroica Ice Wine Riesling (Horse Heaven Hills)
appellation: Horse Heaven Hills, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: The aromas pop, with notes of diesel, lychee, dried orange peel, marmalade and peach. The stone-fruit and tropical flavors are rich, sugary and intense, showing an exquisite sense of balance. Skip the rest of dessert. This delivers it all by itself.

Most subtle hazelnut notes envelop smoke and creaminess on the nose. The balanced palate is rounder than expected with a mellow stone fruit juiciness that sits well with the subtle smokiness that speaks of well-handled oak. A lovely texture completes this subtle, rounded and mellow yet fresh wine.

It's all about acidity and long hangtime with this Chard. The acids come from chilly, foggy nights, the ripeness from long, warm, sunny days. What you get is oodles of bright, pure pineapple, Granny Smith apple, Meyer lemon and spicy clove flavor, with a touch of caramelized oak for richness.

Oak runs rampant here, swamping the dark red berry fruit with ashphalt, licorice and toast, toast, toast. The modest fruit is hard to find. Quite dry and not well-balanced, with overtly woody tannins.

Former Cloudy Bay boss Kevin Judd scores big in this challenging vintage. The wine is round, ripe and amply concentrated, with grassy, herbal shadings and pineapple and stone fruit notes that linger on the lush finish.

appellation: Edna Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: From vines grown on a steep, east-facing slope, this bottling begins with aromas of Key lime peel, caviar-lime flesh, green-fleshed kiwi and even some lychee on the nose. There's a great sizzle of acidity to the sip as well as a compelling grip, framing seashore-like flavors of fresh kelp, green citrus peels and cut grass.

Structured and fully developed, this showcases the strong 2009 vintage, the Oppenlander Vineyard and the brilliance that is Baxter. Marked by bright black-cherry fruit and a heady perfume of rose, this carries itself with elegance and a light touch. This is Pinot Noir purposely made to pair with food.

wine: The Infinite Monkey Theorem 2018 Cabernet Franc (Colorado)
review: Raspberry and cherry pop on the nose, with some vanilla, pepper and leather tones adding depth. The tannins offer gentle grip, but the acidity is tart and sunny, keeping this fresh and structured, and giving a solid base to flavors of ripe plum and tart cranberry wrapped in vanilla. It finishes on tart berry, with lingering tannins making this a good match for fatty protein.
Mealy white-fruit aromas are lacking in clarity and freshness, while the flavor profile is based on pineapple. The finish is broad and heavy.

wine: Claude Baron NV Cuvée Perle Rosé Brut  (Champagne)
review: This attractive, crisp wine is full of perfumed, fresh fruits and tangy acidity. It is lively, with a dry character that keeps the fruitiness right up front. Drink now.

Aromas of blue flower, black-skinned berry and a whiff of new leather form the inviting nose. Smooth and juicy, the palate offers blackberry jam, ripe black cherry and a hint of baking spice alongside soft, supple tannins. It's made to be enjoyed young, so drink soon.

The standard cuvée from Château  Bousquette has light, fresh simple fruit, with good flavors of red plums and fruit tannins. It is finished with balancing acidity, and is certainly ready to drink now.

wine: Boeckel 2012 Zotzenberg Grand Cru Pinot Gris (Alsace)
review: A rich and medium sweet wine, full of spice, lychees and ripe fruits. There is a tangy texture, a strong sense of minerality as well as herb, yellow fruits and nutmeg flavors. It is still young and needs time. Drink from 2017.

wine: Olivier Leflaive 2012 Les Pucelles Premier Cru  (Puligny-Montrachet)
review: Intense fruit shines through the toast and youthful acidity of this opulent wine. A generous structure will develop in concentration, bringing out the rich apricot and pear flavors. This is a grand wine, waiting to age. Drink from 2018.
A fat style with good berry fruits and tannins. The fresh acidity is of course present, but fits well with the raspberry and cherry flavors. Screwcap.

wine: Marston Family 2004 Cabernet Sauvignon (Spring Mountain District)
appellation: Spring Mountain District, Napa, California, US
review: The vineyard, on Spring Mountain, has been the source of very good Cabs from both Marston and Beringer, and the '04 continues that tradition. Made in the modern style, this is soft and very ripe to the point of sweetness. But it pulls back at the last minute, allowing the cassis, chocolate and red cherry flavors to finish dry. Best with something simple, like a grilled steak.

wine: Union de Producteurs de Saint-Émilion 2016 Château Tuilerie Plaisance  (Montagne-Saint-Émilion)
review: This wine has structure and the potential for aging. With its dry core surrounded by ripe black-fruit flavors, the wine is generous but does need time. Drink from late 2020.

wine: C. da Silva 2011 Dalva Reserva Branco White (Douro)
review: The wood aging of this wine has given a lightly oxidized character. It is rich and creamy with toasty acidity as well as yellow fruits. Drink now.

wine: Purple Hands 2016 Freedom Hill Vineyard Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)
appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: This reliable vineyard delivers powerful brambly berry flavors in abundance. It's a big, textural, palate-filling wine, smooth and a bit tannic. There's a touch of green tea in those tannins, and it finishes with a hint of heat. Drink now–2025.

This is a harmonious and elegant sparkler that offers well-integrated aromas of citrus blossom, honey and stone fruit. The wine is bright and luminous and ends with vibrant fruit flavors. The wine will open your appetite before dinner.

wine: Weingut Karp-Schreiber 2010 Brauneberger Juffer-Sonnenuhr Spätlese Riesling (Mosel)
review: Textbook fruchtig Riesling—but with the volume turned up to 11. The flavors of honeyed apple, nectarine and lime are sweet and the wine round and plump in the mouth, but then electric acids kick in, providing great balance through the long finish. Exciting to try now, but this wine should age 10-plus years without any trouble at all.

wine: Adega Cooperativa de Borba 2009 Premium Red (Alentejo)
review: This is a top wine from the Borba cooperative. It has all the right richness and fruitiness followed by great concentration, solid texture and dark tannins. The finish shows acidity, with touches of tar and perfume.

wine: Two Vintners 2013 Make Haste Cinsault (Yakima Valley)
appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: This is a rare, 100% varietal Cinsault from Olsen Vineyard that saw only neutral French oak, and it's hard to imagine a more pure representation of the variety. Aromas of tart red fruit and flowers with high-toned stem accents are followed by piercingly pure, elegantly styled fruit and savory flavors that undulate across the palate. The balance is exquisite. It stands up beautifully on its own but will truly sing at the dinner table. Pair it with lamb.

wine: Stift Göttweig 2010 Silberbichl Erste Lage Reserve Riesling (Kremstal)
review: The vineyards of the Benedictine monastery of Göttweig are now run by the Stadt Krems winemaking team. The quality is now impeccable, as this gorgeous, opulent Riesling shows. With weight and a fine balance between fruit and structure, this will age over many years.
From the well-known Zinfandel producer, this floral Chardonnay is high in balanced minerality and marked by darker, riper pear and apple fruit. The finish is swathed in vanilla bean and toast.
Crisp and light, with flavors of fresh cantaloupe and lychees. The aftertaste is soft, and just slightly sweet. Imported by Palm Bay Imports.

wine: Baglio del Cristo di Campobello 2019 Laluci Grillo (Sicilia)
review: Fragrant, refreshing and delicious, this opens with aromas of grapefruit, white spring flower and Mediterranean brush. The aromas carry over to the vibrant, savory palate along with juicy pineapple, peach and wild herb before a tangy saline finish.

Made up of several different parcels scattered across the Margaux appellation, the château now has 24 acres. This 2012 is structured while also full of ripe fruit. The tannins lie behind the juicy red fruitiness and the immediately attractive ripe flavors. It should age, but not for long. Drink from 2017.

On the nose, this Cabernet-led blend deals telltale Chilean aromas of herbs, pepper, spice, berry, tomato and forest floor. Derivative of a cool year, the palate feels tight, with snapping acidity. Hard-hitting acid-driven flavors of spiced berry and black currant finish dark, toasty and oaky, but pulling. Drink through 2025.

A complex wine, brimming with cinnamon and spice flavors and redolent of coffee, chocolate, black cherry, black currant, raspberry, herb and anise flavors. The tannins are firm but ripe, and the finish is quite long. A first release from winemaker Chris Dearden.

wine: Robert Mondavi 2009 To Kalon Vineyard I-Block Fumé Blanc (Oakville)
review: Another fabulous I Block from Mondavi. Exceptionally ripe in grapefruit, lime and gooseberry fruit, it shows the minerality of this vineyard that gives the wine grip and grounding. Bone-dry, with crisp supportive acidity and just the right amount of oak, it's wonderful now. This is not a wine to age, but will hold over the next four years.

As soft and smooth as velvet, with superripe flavors of chocolate, blackberry and cherry pie filling, currants, cassis and sweetly toasted oak. A best blend of vineyards available to the winery, this Cab was aged in 100% new French oak. The alcohol level is high, leading to questions of ageability.

wine: Beni di Batasiolo 2008 Metodo Classico Sparkling (Vino Spumante)
review: Made from Pinot Nero and Chardonnay, this delivers sensations of bread crust, toasted walnut, lemon drop and red apple. Vivacious bubbles and crisp acidity leave an invigorating finish.

appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: Orange marmalade, lemon meringue and warm melon aromas open this wine from the cool Templeton Gap area southeast of Paso Robles. The flavors show off the brighter elements of the grape, with caramelized pear giving way to slate in the midpalate and a nicely bitter finish of orange peel.

wine: Hug 2005 Cedar Lane Vineyard Syrah (Arroyo Seco)
appellation: Arroyo Seco, Central Coast, California, US
review: As ripe as the fruit is, and it's very ripe, with showy blackberry, cassis, plum and mocha flavors, this Syrah is dry and balanced, with the acidity and tannic structure that comes from the terroir of this cool Monterey appellation. It's a very interesting wine, with real class and style.

wine: Joseph Jewell 2011 Appian Way Vineyards Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)
appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: This Pinot is joyous in fresh berry fruit aromas and flavors, from wild strawberry to taut cherry, the fruit buoyed by lush, velvety tannins and generous acidity. Pretty on the nose and tongue, it discloses a trace of vanilla on the clean, distinct finish.

appellation: North Coast, North Coast, California, US
review: Earthy complexity, full body and ample black-fruit flavors make a fine combination in this bold but nicely polished wine. Aromas of wet earth and tobacco lead to generous plum and black-currant notes.

wine: Rios de Chile 2013 Reserva Sauvignon Blanc (Leyda Valley)
review: Vegetal aromas outmuscle the wine's green fruit character. A plump, round mouthfeel offers only mild acidity, while the vegetal essence returns on the palate, with sulfuric bitterness on the finish.

appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
review: Earth, smoke and herb tones accent aromas of red berries and cherries on this tart, delicately-framed Bordeaux-style blend. A high proportion of Cabernet Franc lends an herbal, brambly tone to crisp cranberry and sour cherry flavors. Finishes moderately long.

wine: Albert Bichot 2008 Les Amoureuses Premier Cru  (Chambolle-Musigny)
review: As so often results from this vineyard, this is a lovely wine, the fruit ripe and showing considerable sweetness as well as richness. The structure is soft, open and elegant, surrounding the core of sweet tannins. Not for long-term aging, but worth waiting 4–5 years.

appellation: Central Coast, Central Coast, California, US
review: This ripe Chardonnay is a successful example of its style, with honeysuckle, white peach and marshmallow aromas on the nose. The palate offers apple custard and lemon curd flavors, held together with savory smoke and sea salt aspects.

appellation: Calaveras County, Sierra Foothills, California, US
review: Chunky and tannic in the mouth, with a sandpapery texture housing ripe flavors of blackberries, currants and raisins. The finish is totally dry, which is a good thing, but it's also a little hot in alcohol.

Powdery white fruit aromas are honeyed and come with a note of sea foam. A round palate flattens out pretty quickly, while this tastes of pithy citrus and melon. Apple, almond skin and mild green notes appear on a short finish. Drink immediately.

From estate-grown grapes, this light wine is salmon in color, with herbal, earthy personality. Strawberry, deli meat and a faint metallic twist of flint combine around medium-bodied ripeness and richness.

wine: Kirkland Signature 2014 Signature Series Premier Cru  (Chablis)
review: Made by major Chablis producer Jean-Marc Brocard, this wine is ripe, soft and attractively fruity. It has crisp acidity along with rich yellow fruits and a touch of minerality. The wine comes from a blend of different premier cru vineyards. Delicious and refreshing, it is ready to drink now.

wine: Louis Bernard 2015 Red (Côtes du Rhône Villages)
appellation: Côtes du Rhône Villages, Rhône Valley, France
review: Garrigue-laced notes of cherries and boysenberries offer plenty of complexity in this realistically priced wine. It's medium in body, with some drying, dusty tannins, so drink it alongside rare beef or lamb.

wine: Materra Cunat Family Vineyards 2015 Reserve Cabernet Sauvignon (Diamond Mountain District)
appellation: Diamond Mountain District, Napa, California, US
review: Herbal and dusty, this wine is lean in red fruit and well integrated in tannin. The oak is pronounced, the wine having spent 22 months in wood. The finish is smooth in chocolate.

wine: Château de Belcier 2010 Les Armoiries de Belcier  (Castillon Côtes de Bordeaux)
appellation: Castillon Côtes de Bordeaux, Bordeaux, France
review: From selected parcels, this solid and dark wine has extracted chocolate flavors from an over-enthusiastic use of wood. It's tough, and hard to see how it can really soften sufficiently to allow the fruit to surface.

appellation: Monterey County, Central Coast, California, US
review: Dark-red-fruit and boysenberry aromas meet with wet gravel on the nose of this bottling. The palate is tart with dark-red fruit, and there's a hint of damp earth as well.

All three of Plantagenet's Shirazes were successful in 2008. This, the flagship bottling, offers aromas of coffee grounds, cherry and cracked black pepper, adding vanilla, spice and charred beef flavors on the palate. It's harmonious, savory and complex. Drink now–2020 and possibly beyond.

appellation: Côtes de Gascogne, Southwest France, France
review: Fresh and light with white-currant fruits, this wine celebrates bright, zesty crispness and easy drinking. It is ready now.

A rich nose of cherry, mocha and jam rolls into mouthfilling flavors that offer a spicy but elegant blend in this stylish Pinotage. Smoke, cherry and plum unfold in the mouth. The finish is lingering and spirited. Pair with spicy grilled lamb, steak, or even curry.

Almost translucent, with a mixed-spice nose that doesn't offer much fruit.  It's got some strawberry and rasberry flavors, but it's also slightly sour.  Milk chocolate shows up on the finish, which is otherwise overly oaky.  Lacks polish.

Slight notes of yellow pear appear gently on the nose and become fully-fledged on the soft easy fruit-driven palate. A dollop of residual sweetness helps these fruity flavors along. An edge of bitter zestiness and freshness contains the fruit. This finishes off dry but fresh.

wine: Bodegas Muriel 2014 Pazo Cilleiro Albariño (Rías Baixas)
review: Don't let the gold color fool you, this is quite vital with floral, leesy, almost grassy aromas. Bracing acidity is at the core with clover, grass, quince and sour-apricot flavors. Blasting acidity is a force on the finish.

appellation: Colli Orientali del Friuli, Northeastern Italy, Italy
review: Here is a saturated and bright dessert wine with a deep orange color and aromas of toasted nut, chestnut, honey, yellow rose and mature peach. These tones are rich and dense and the wine exhibits thick, chewy viscosity in the mouth.

This bears little resemblance to previous versions; though listed as a dessert wine, it is only passingly sweet. Perhaps orange wine is a better description, with some 21 grapes in the blend, principally various Muscat clones. It's an odd mix of grainy sugar and astringent phenolics, and will not readily accompany any desserts with the possible exception of bitter chocolate.

wine: Anakena 2011 Tama Vineyard Selection Malbec (Cachapoal Valley)
review: Medicinal cherry aromas are a touch herbal and green, but also floral. This red-tinted Malbec is jammy on the palate, with lightly herbal plum and currant flavors. The zesty finish brings a cool-vintage green character into play.
While it is rich and powerful, this wine also has a great presence of fresh fruits, lifted by red cherries and acidity. The texture offers red apple skins and some tight tannins.

wine: Pence 2010 Uplands Pinot Noir (Santa Barbara County)
appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
review: This darkly colored, tannic, young wine boasts lots of rich black cherry, currant, cola, pie-spice and sandalwood flavors. It also has a rich mushroomy streak. A bit angular and jagged now, give it 5–6 years in the cellar and see what it does.

The nose is very shy but gives the slightest promise of ripe, red fruit. Red cherry appears in full splendor on the palate, edged by racy, exciting freshness and superfine but crunchy tannins. The body remains slender but there is a sensuous, warm core of ripe fruit. Lovely now but will develop over the coming five years. Drink 2018–2025.
Despite a rush of pungent herbaceousness and cat pee, the flavors are sweetly fruity and low in acid. Rich and a bit heavy. —J.C.

wine: Bodegas Escorihuela 2005 Cruz Alta Reserve Malbec (Mendoza)
review: Starts with roasted coffee, berry liqueur and toast, while the palate is pretty dense and loaded with boysenberry and cherry. The feel is solid and juicy, with firm acids and tannins supporting a peppery finish. Saturated and staunch, but ordinary.

wine: Rippey NV The Crossing Red (Napa Valley)
review: There's a puckering dryness to the palate of this wine at first sip. Over time it opens slowly into elements of strawberry-rhubarb and grenadine syrup. The firm tannins in this mix of a majority Merlot with Pinot Noir make their presence felt.
This Chardonnay has vanilla, lemon blossom and peach aromas. Lemon curd and green apple flavors come through on the palate before a pleasantly acidic finish.

Seems very oaky, with in-your-face aromas of vanilla, char and pepper, but the fruit is able to support it. In fact, the underlying flavors are rich and gorgeous. It shows Cabernet's cassis and blackberry aromatics, with the soft tannins and velvety, drink-me-now texture of Merlot.
Light and a bit herbal, like a pleasant St.-Joseph. White pepper and celery-leaf notes accent tart cherries.

wine: Lucas & Lewellen 2005 Goodchild Vineyard Chardonnay (Santa Barbara County)
appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
review: Many wineries have taken fruit from this vineyard, generally with good results. The '05 Lucas & Lewellen shows its terroir, with a cool-climate crispness backing up ripe pineapple tart, nectarine and papaya flavors. But the oak-inspired caramel, char and butterscotch is a bit heavy-handed.
This has aromas evoking graphite, grapefruit and botanical herb. The aromas march on to the racy palate along with a hint of dried pineapple and mature yellow apple skin before a fennel finish.

The nose on this distinctive Syrah is a mélange of beef teriyaki, aniseed, stewed raspberry and cherry aromas. Oak influence is marked, particularly on the palate, where the juicy red fruit notes and star anise are slightly overwhelmed by a dried bark finish. Nevertheless, this is a savory style many will enjoy.

wine: De Loach 1997 Saitone Ranch Zinfandel (Russian River Valley)
appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: One of the best of the single-ranch wines from De Loach, the Saitone's nose exhibits a lot of coffee and smoke aromas. The mouthfeel is fat, meaty and rich. Bright and edgy, with good acids and a long, sharp finish. A well-made and complex wine.

appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Forward and softly fruity in the nose, it blends into a pleasant melange of roses, cherries and chocolate. Flavors mingle leaf and flower, fruit and root, with modest tannins and a good balance.

wine: Friedrich Becker 2018 Becker Family Pinot Gris (Pfalz)
review: Pinot Gris (aka Pinot Grigio) is a pink-hued grape and this pretty, coppery-pink wine tiptoes the line between a white and rosé wine. Macerated on its skins for 12–18 hours, it offers concentrated raspberry and red apple flavors against a backdrop of citrusy acidity and a clean mineral tang. Dry and delightfully refreshing, it's a fantastic year-round accompaniment to everything from fish to game.
This is has classic blackberry, black currant and cedar flavors. The feeling on the palate feels a little rough, though.

wine: Kingston Family 2014 CJ's Barrel Syrah (Casablanca Valley)
review: Ripe, loamy cherry and blackberry aromas are moderately complex. Racy on the palate courtesy of punchy, fresh acidity, this barrel-select Syrah tastes spicy and a touch charred, with a black-fruit base. Smooth on the finish, with mild residual oak, this is elegant as a whole. Drink through 2020.

wine: Château Lagrézette 2015 Le Rosé de Julie Rosé (Côtes du Lot)
appellation: Côtes du Lot, Southwest France, France
review: Produced from Malbec and fashionably pale, this wine is named after Julie Perrin, daughter of owner Alain-Dominique Perrin. It is light and deliciously crisp and refreshing. Bone dry, it is certainly a food rosé, although with its light raspberry flavor it will also be good as an apéritif. Julie Perrin, an artist, worked on the blend and created the château watercolor on the bottle.

wine: Buttonwood Grove 2015 Frances Amelia Riesling (Finger Lakes)
appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
review: Vibrant lemon and tangerine acidity freshens savory tones of pressed apples and nuts in this slightly rustic earthy Riesling. It's dry on the palate and finishes briskly.

wine: Domaine Tariquet 2018 Chardonnay Chardonnay (Côtes de Gascogne)
appellation: Côtes de Gascogne, Southwest France, France
review: This is a light Chardonnay, with an attractive creamy character and touches of butter. A soft texture and light, juicy acidity give the wine a rounded aftertaste. Drink now.

wine: Babcock 1997 Eleven Oaks Sangiovese (Santa Ynez Valley)
appellation: Santa Ynez Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: Dark and brooding, this needs some serious time in the cellar or in a decanter before it opens up and begins to express its Sangiovese character. Generously oaked, it shows good depth and richness of fruit. Tannins are plentiful but soft.

A smooth, wood-matured wine, this shows all of the richness of Braucol and Duras. Named “the spirit,” it is a true evocation of the rugged nature of Gaillac, with a mineral streak and a big black-fruit flavor. Age for 4–5 years.

A hint of gunflint on the nose of this wine accents ripe, intensely sunny flavors of yellow plum, pear and lemon. Moderately full in body but briskly balanced, it's a rich expression of Chablis anchored by a chalky, subtly salty finish. At peak now–2027.

Big and boisterous on the nose, with ripe plum, berry, smoke and meaty aromas. Mouthfilling and edgy feeling, with bold berry and plum flavors that feature an herbal, peppery aftertaste. Earthy and herbal leaning on the lengthy finish.

wine: J. Lohr 2018 Shotwell Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (El Pomar District)
appellation: El Pomar District, Central Coast, California, US
review: Soft aromas of baked cherry meet with rich mahogany and cola on the nose of this bottling. The palate picks up shiitake, pepper and tar flavors, with sticky tannins that carry the ripe red fruit to the finish.

wine: Domaine Chevillon-Chezeaux 2017 Les Crots Premier Cru  (Nuits-St.-Georges)
review: This small-production wine comes from the few rows owned in this vineyard by this estate. It is developing well as a succulent wine with great charm as well as plenty of ripe red fruits. Tannins and acidity are now fully integrated into the wine, which will be ready to drink from 2021.

There's a touch of honeyed sweetness to this wine that gives it a softly appealing taste. The orange, apricot, tropical fruit and vanilla flavors are absolutely delicious, while there's just enough acidity to lift and balance the richness.
It would be nice to report that this affordable Napa Bordeaux blend is as good as wines costing twice as much, but it's not. It's not bad, but quite thin and herbal, with a tannic finish.

appellation: South Eastern Australia, Australia Other, Australia
review: Probably the wine that put Australian Chardonnay on American consumers' maps, the current vintage boasts aromas of creamery butter, tangerine and lime, with a touch of movie-theater popcorn. Soft peach and vanilla flavors finish with spicy oak.

appellation: Anderson Valley, Mendocino County, California, US
review: Wonderful spearmint and cinnamon accents light up this focused, fruit-driven and well-balanced wine. Light tannins and lip-smacking acidity do a great job of lifting the ample red cherry and rhubarb flavors as the complexity of this wine unfolds on the palate and lingering finish. Best through 2029.

This crowd-pleasing Zin is deeply aromatic, with cedar notes, and boasts a palate that's smooth, leathery and layered with tones of earth and black tea. Fairly priced and with a cleverly designed label, it's a great bottle to take to your next biker party or gathering for the Day of the Dead.

Big, oaky and roasted up front, with charred aromas. The palate is full but clacky, with piercing acidity leading to a saucy, sharp set of tangy red berry and herb flavors. There's a chocolaty element to smooth things out on the finish, but it's always snappy and sheer.

wine: De Stefani NV Zero Gran Cuvée Extra Dry  (Prosecco)
review: Very crisp, focused and clean, this easy sparkling wine does a great job of keeping the palate refreshed. It's an Extra Dry expression which means there's just a tiny touch of sweetness in the mouth.

appellation: Carmel Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: Even though this wine is nicely dry and crisp, it's too vegetal, with a green bean taste.

wine: Bernhard Huber 2011 Bienenberg Erste Lage R GG Spätburgunder (Baden)
review: The better (by just a whisker) of Huber's 2011 Pinot Noirs, the Bienenberg is distinctly fragrant of cherry blossoms and rose. Tart red cherry and cranberry flavors are streaked with saltwater and stone, finishing on a lingering mineral tone. It's bold, yet elegantly structured.

Twelve months in wood and rich tannins have combined to give this wine a strong, structured character. A juicy underlay from the black-plum flavors and the acidity will likely continue to give this wine an edge of freshness even as it matures. Drink this stylish wine from 2021.

wine: Buty 2013 62% Semillon 22% Sauvignon Blanc 16% Muscadelle White (Columbia Valley (WA))
appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: A blend of fruit from Boushey, Rosebud Ranch and Lonesome Springs Ranch, this wine was aged in concrete and seasoned French oak. Aromas of fig, apricot, orange peel and lees are followed by creamy flavors that have a light, elegant style.

As a fan of this traditional winery, I was a little disppointed by the Brunate. Less focussed and interesting than the La Serra, the Brunate had a muted nose of dark fruit, and woodsmoke although the fruit seemed a little more pronounced on the palate. A short medium finish.

wine: Diora 2017 La Splendeur du Soleil Chardonnay (Monterey)
review: Bright aromas of lemon candy, sea spray and lime balm meets with a touch of pastry on the nose. Richer flavors of white peach and sea salt ride a light and bright texture on the palate, which grows more oaky toward the finish.

wine: Caprio Cellars 2018 Sanitella Estate Red (Walla Walla Valley (WA))
appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Cabernet Sauvignon (46%) is in the lead, followed by Merlot (27%), Malbec (18%) and Cabernet Franc (9%). The aromas bring notes of dark cherry, plum, cocoa, fresh herbs and fresh black currant. The palate is all about sophistication and detail, with a velvety feel to the fruit flavors. It's pleasantly unadorned by obviously overt new oak and brings the freshness of the vintage.

wine: Jean-Louis & Fabienne Mann 2011 Resonance Sélection de Grains Nobles Riesling (Alsace)
review: Intense notes of fir honey and caramelized peach have heady lift on the nose of this wine, lending an elixir-like urgency. The concentrated palate displays these flavors against a strong backdrop of beeswax and honeycomb. Intense sweetness homes in on a candied lemon core while the luscious finish rings with honey, wax and lemony caramel. Drink through 2050.
This opens with delicate aromas of baking spice, rose petal and leather. The firm straightforward palate offers sour cherry, clove and green peppercorn alongside assertive tannins.
Hints of ripe pear and Mirabelle on the nose of this wine are subtle. The palate is fresh and light, dulling the fruit with a hint of earthiness. The finish is dry and fresh.

wine: Dr. Loosen 2014 Wehlener Sonnenuhr Kabinett Riesling (Mosel)
review: Bold, penetrating yellow-cherry and pink grapefruit flavors are calibrated by streaks of lime, lemon and slate in this invigorating kabinett. Kicks of saffron and spice accentuate its pert, racy style. Enjoy now through 2018 for fresh, fruity refreshment.

appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Roughout is a fun wine, with a burst of sweet cherry fruit opening into a wild side that veers toward bramble and forest flavors. It's not a big red, but highly gulp-able and perfect for a burger night.

wine: Quinta da Romaneira 2009 Late Bottled Vintage  (Port)
review: The wine was fermented in open stone lagars, still the preferred method at many Douro quintas. That gives the color and the soft extraction in this ripe, sweet Port. It has enough tannins to balance the dried raisin and superripe plum flavors. While it has been bottled to drink now, the wine will benefit from aging. Drink from 2016.

wine: Bianchi 2008 Signature Selection Cabernet Franc (Paso Robles)
appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: Soft, sweet and a little hot, this has flavors of chocolate-covered raisin and black cherry jam. It's an easy wine to drink now with a nice grilled steak or juicy burger.

appellation: Sangiovese di Romagna, Central Italy, Italy
review: Packaged in a big, heavy bottle, this Riserva Sangiovese shows elegant tones of wild berry, blue flowers, moist earth and spice. This is a very traditional take on Italy's favorite indigenous variety with a soft, silky close.
Melony aromas are soft and candied. On the palate, this is watery and doesn't offer much sizzle. Pithy citrus flavors are typical of Chilean SB, however this is flat on the finish.

Made from Zinfandel, Carignane, Petite Sirah and Mataro (Mourvèdre), this hearty wine currently is sweet and full in primary cherry, blackberry, plum and cedar flavors, with a touch of raisins in the finish. It should slowly develop over the next 4–6 years before heading inexorably downhill.

wine: Silvano Bolmida 2011 Bussia Vigna dei Fantini  (Barolo)
review: Aromas of toasted oak, menthol, marinated plum and a hint of wet animal fur lead the nose. The palate is still tight and rather closed, offering raw red berry, licorice and oak sensations supported by raspy tannins.

appellation: Red Mountain, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Released more than four years after harvest, this astringent, oaky Merlot remains in a dumb phase. Barrel flavors of bourbon and vanilla quickly take over the nose and the palate, though there is a suggestion of compact power and black fruit lurking in the background. Give it a lot of decanting time.

Already mature, this medium-bodied wine offers scents of dried fruit and leather, then flavors of caramelized, roasted black cherries and more leather. It's a bit coarsely textured, then falls away on the finish. Drink soon.

wine: Emeritus 2017 Hallberg Ranch Wesley's Reserve Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)
appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: This is a juicy, effusive wine, made from several of the vineyard's prized blocks year after year. Pomegranate, rhubarb and dried herb highlight a length of concentrated blackberry and rich robust tannin. Elegant from start to end, the finish is a mix of black pepper and black tea, and is earthy in forest floor.

wine: Stadt Krems 2016 Ried Wachtberg Reserve Grüner Veltliner (Kremstal)
review: A creamy whiff of fresh, juicy yellow pear creates a most appetizing nose in this wine. That pure, friendly fruit dominates the palate, illuminating a background of spice and herb notes that recall dried sage and fennel seed. Lemon freshness frames everything and makes for a lovely, full-flavored mouthful.

wine: Domaine Begude 2007 Sauvignon Blanc (Vin de Pays d'Oc)
appellation: Vin de Pays d'Oc, Languedoc-Roussillon, France
review: Crisp acidity marks this mouthwatering white. Intense aromas of lemon and grass make for an intriguing nose. The palate is a bit dull, although the acidity gives the minerally finish a bit of staying power and makes it a good foil for fresh seafood.

wine: Thomas Fogarty 2007 Michaud Vineyard Pinot Noir (Chalone)
review: Heavy and soft, with cherry and blackberry flavors that could almost be described as Rhône-style. Lacks delicacy and verve, but these mountain-grown wines can be deceptive in youth. Give it 5–6 years in the cellar, and try again.

wine: Starfield 2018 The Miner's Inch Red (El Dorado)
appellation: El Dorado, Sierra Foothills, California, US
review: This agile and complex wine emphasizes good balance and a tempting mélange of red-fruit flavors that are well braced by bright acidity and moderate tannins. The blend is more than half Cinsault plus four other grape varieties.
This is a fat and rather flabby rosé, dark in color and with a heavy feel. It has weighty red fruits and only light acidity.

Aromas suggest blueberry, coffee and orange rind. The nice marriage of cooked and fresh fruit flavors with cool herbal notes includes blueberry, black cherry, anise, eucalyptus, coffee, pencil lead and violet. Tannins come on strong but back off appropriately, and the pleasing finish includes lasting touches of leather and tart cherry.

wine: Daniel 2015 Ferrington Vineyard Pinot Noir (Anderson Valley)
appellation: Anderson Valley, Mendocino County, California, US
review: Savory nuances and a tight, nervy structure distinguish this impressive, potentially long-lived wine. It has all the ripe fruit and full body one could ask for, but also offers accents of sage, black tea and redwood forest in the aromas and meaty accents in the flavors. Great balance from good acidity and firm tannins completes the picture. Best after 2021.

A solid value in dry Riesling (keep in mind that the bottle is one-third larger than standard). The ripe apple scents lead into dry minerally flavors that boast rounded, smooth edges. Purists may gripe that it lacks a certain precision because of this, but others will find it more accessible and easier to drink for precisely the same reason. Imported by Chapin Cellars.

wine: Macari 2007 Reserve Barrel Fermented Chardonnay (North Fork of Long Island)
appellation: North Fork of Long Island, Long Island, New York, US
review: With 12 months in French oak, the Reserve Barrel Fermented Chardonnay is a rounder, more spice-infused Chard than Macari's regular Estate Bottled offering. As big as it is, the nose is somewhat muted with soft notes of pear and yellow flowers and the palate shows more as a result of the oak (spice, toast) than the fruit.

This blend of Sangiovese, Syrah and Cabernet Sauvignon has aromas of black-skinned fruit, baking spice and cedar while the firm palate offers blackberry jam, clove and mocha. Solid tannins provide support.

appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: This limited-production (137 cases) wine is made primarily of Walla Walla Seven Hills Vineyard fruit, which lends a soft, pleasantly fruity cherry pie character. Four other red grapes are blended in, which gives it a generic red, rather than varietal, palate.

wine: The Eyrie Vineyards 2018 Roland Green Pinot Noir (Dundee Hills)
appellation: Dundee Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: Among the half dozen 2018 Pinots from Eyrie this is the tightest and least immediately expressive, which suggests decanting and/or aggressive aeration prior to early drinking. It grudgingly reveals strawberry and black cherry fruit with a spine of iron. The compact flavors and inner rigidity suggest that this should be cellared and could easily improve for a decade or longer. Drink 2026 to 2035.
Ripe peach on the nose has some earthy undertones. The palate is fresh but has the same earthy and slightly muddy aspect. Lemon freshness brightens the flavors and creates subtle balance. Drink soon.

Ripe from the beginning, with big berry aromas matched by sweet molasses and brown sugar aromas. Round, full and jammy in the mouth, with sweet berry flavors and notes of mild spices and vanilla. Long and just a bit oaky on the finish. Nice and approachable; drink now through 2013.

The wine comes from a small strip of a half acre in the center of this famed grand cru, part of the Olivier Leflaive family domaine. It is laden with toast flavors from the wood fermentation as well as intense fruit, green plums and crisp apples which are given extra richness by apricots. Concentrated and densely textured the wine will develop so well. Drink from 2022.

wine: Charles Krug 2013 Estate Grown Merlot (Napa Valley)
review: Thick and chocolatey, this brawny wine is full bodied and richly concentrated. It is a mighty force of blackberry, blueberry and toasted oak.
This wine is aromatically untoward, with notes of green herbs, bell pepper, dried tobacco and black pepper. The flavors are silky in feel and show decent concentration along with tart acids.

wine: Domaine Nathalie & Gilles Fevre 2018 Vieilles Vignes  (Chablis)
review: Pear and lemon appear on the nose of this wine, alongside tantalizing notions suggesting citrus peel, bergamot and bitter orange.
