review: This bottling by Lane Tanner, who used solely clone 667 and employed 50% new Hungarian oak, offers intense cherry on the nose alongside rose petals, carnations, preserved oranges and North African spice. There's bountiful energy to the sip, where bay leaf, thyme and green sage meet with dark red fruit.

Rather reserved in aromas for a dessert wine, this allows blackberry, black pepper and mineral notes to emerge with time. The palate is lightly sweet, with ripe blackberry and blueberry-jam flavors, made interesting with a pencil-lead minerality throughout.

Smells and tastes just great, with all the hallmarks of an important Napa Cabernet. It's rich in blackberries, black currants, cassis and minerals. Near- perfect tannins and a tasteful overlay of sweet oak add textural complexity. For all that, the wine feels young and brusque. It wants 6–7 years of age to begin to strut its stuff. Open after 2012.

wine: Rive Della Chiesa NV Spumante Extra Dry Prosecco (Montello e Colli Asolani)
appellation: Montello e Colli Asolani, Veneto, Italy
review: Austere and minerally on the nose, with hints of yeastiness and citrus. This is much less fruity and floral than most Proseccos, yielding instead flavors of stones and limes. The slightly chalky finish is clean and refreshing.

wine: R. Stuart & Co. NV Bubbly Sparkling (Oregon)
review: Tasted in September 2019, this nonvintage brut is a 50-50 blend of Chardonnay and Pinot Blanc. Made in the Champagne method, it's foamy and tart, with sharp notes of grapefruit and lemon rind. It finishes with residual bitterness.

appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
review: Full, round aromas of berry fruits are oaky and appealing. In the mouth, this wine is ultradry, tannic and raw. Flavors of blackberry, plum and coffee finish hard and abrasive due to scraping tannins.

appellation: Clements Hills, Central Valley, California, US
review: This blend of Barbera, Petite Sirah and other red varieties tastes hearty, fruity, full flavored and full bodied, without being too tannic to enjoy easily. Aromas like blackberry jam and flavors reminiscent of dark plum and spicy, smoky oak make it tempting and delicious. Enough fresh acidity keeps it balanced.

wine: Rally Point Wines 2013 Limited Production Chardonnay (Russian River Valley)
appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: Dark hay in color with a concentration of oak on the nose, the palate retains that richness of nutty almond and apple pie, finding a balance that betrays the heavier implications of the initial aromas. On the finish it offers a lightness of being, as well as a touch of perfume.

wine: Brown Brothers 2000 Patricia Reserve Cabernet Sauvignon (Victoria)
review: Black as black in color, which may or may not have anything to do with the 7% Petit Verdot inside. It's a straight-up plum-and-oak combo, dense in the mouth with tealike tannins that linger on the finish.

wine: Meadow View 2018 Mary Leigh's Vineyard Jon's Vineyard Chardonnay (Lamorinda)
review: Medium bodied and nicely complex, this well-balanced wine offers hints of butter and fig in the aroma, crisp apple and Bosc pear on the palate and a texture livened by a snap of tartness.

wine: Domaine Salmon 2018 Vieilles Vignes Sur Lie  (Muscadet Sèvre et Maine)
appellation: Muscadet Sèvre et Maine, Loire Valley, France
review: This soft, fruity wine produced from organically grown grapes is attractive, with restrained acidity and a tangy texture. The brightness balances with smooth, creamed-apple flavors. Drink now.

wine: Doña Paula 2006 Selección de Bodega Malbec (Mendoza)
review: Deep and juicy Malbec with aromas of violets, blackberry, coconut shavings and mineral. There's also a cedary element to the nose and palate. Otherwise, look for full-force wild berry and cassis flavors and a smooth, clean finish. Nothing awkward or forced; Doña Paula's best Malbec ever. Drink now through 2013.

appellation: Colli Orientali del Friuli, Northeastern Italy, Italy
review: Closed with a wax- top bottle, this elegant Picolit offers pretty aromas of honey-roasted chestnut and dried lavender. The wine has a uniquely floral feel and ends with piquant acidity that makes it persistent and lively in the mouth.

A woody, toasted note speaks to well-integrated yet present oak in this white that maintains medium-bodied texture on the palate. Bright, lemony acidity complements the creaminess, dashing in wet stone and undeniable floral notes of apple and orange blossom.

Summer berry compote and mellow, creamy apple notes combine on the nose of this wine. The palate reprises these notes and adds a smidgeon of phenolic grip. It's a mellow, rounded but fresh and dry wine.

wine: Cline 2015 Estate Grown Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)
review: Dark color and a punch of smoky oak underline this wine's big burly hold of tannin and ripe fruit. Tobacco, tar and baked cherry highlight the flavor wheel.

wine: Cellier des Dauphins 2019 Les Dauphins Cuvée Spéciale Red (Côtes du Rhône)
appellation: Côtes du Rhône, Rhône Valley, France
review: Smoky tones of charred brioche and hazelnut biscotti accent bright, juicy black plum and cassis in this medium-bodied, fresh-fruited blend of 85% Grenache and 15% Syrah. Supple in texture and finishing on fine, furry tannins, this immediately approachable red is best enjoyed young.

Apple, yellow flower and sea breeze aromas lead the way. The bright, elegant palate displays lemon, lime and walnut alongside vibrant acidity. A mineral vein underscores the savory flavors. Drink now or hold another two or three years for more complexity.

wine: Messina Hof NV Dry Style Rosé (Texas)
review: This canned rosé begs for outdoor concerts or poolside sipping. There is enough acidity to cut through the full, viscous palate, loaded with a strawberry daiquiri flavor. While not cloying, it is decidedly sugary and lingers on a ripe strawberry note.

wine: Domaine Monthelie-Douhairet 1999 Clos Le Meix Garnier Monopole  (Monthélie)
review: Firmly structured, with a smooth mouthfeel and a long finish, this wine needs a few years to relax its tightly wound core of black cherries. Right now, what's showing is mostly spicy, briary notes.
This straightforward informal red offers aromas of dark berry and moist soil. The soft palate displays raspberry jam and a hint of dark spice. It's easy drinking, with supple tannins.

wine: Fattoria di San Quintino 2009 Pilerno Red (Toscana)
review: Simple, crisp, bright cherry aromas would make a good companion to lasagna or cheesy pasta. There's a touch of acidity on the close to keep the palate refreshed.

A noble tribute to his Bordeaux training, winemaker Jean Michel Morel's namesake blend is beautifully concentrated with rich, sweet black fruit, with hints of violet, savory mushroom, cured meat and clay. A textured and powerful wine with vibrant acidity, it finishes long, with a swathe of velvety tannins.

Yalumba's mastery of Viognier extends even to this botrytis-affected dessert style, which offers scents and flavors of honey, dried apricots and orange marmalade. It's not overly complex, but wonderfully concentrated yet balanced, with a long, honeyed finish. Drink it over the next few years.

appellation: North Coast, North Coast, California, US
review: Distinctive aromas of toasted nut and wood-smoke give this full-bodied wine an exotic start, while baked apple, browned walnut and crisp cherry flavors continue the theme. Made from 82% Pinot Noir and 18% Chardonnay, it offers layers of spice, smoke and mild, savory mushroom and tea flavors, surrounded by a plush, creamy texture and light acidity to keep it fresh. Best after 2023.

wine: Stephen Ross 2001 Dante Dusi Vineyard Zinfandel (Paso Robles)
appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: Full bodied and firm textured, with layers of black cherry, plum, raspberry, cola, tea, spice and toast flavors. The wine is muscular, yet sleek, showing the elegance of this grape variety as well as its effusiveness.

wine: Barrister 2011 Klipsun Vineyard Sauvignon Blanc (Red Mountain)
appellation: Red Mountain, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: An excellent follow-up to the luscious 2010, this features a generous array of melon, citrus and light tropical fruits. There is noticeable residual sugar—much in the style of the Sancerres from French producer Cotat—but at one-third the cost.

wine: Marques de Griñon 2002 Cabernet Sauvignon (Dominio de Valdepusa)
appellation: Dominio de Valdepusa, Central Spain, Spain
review: Toasty and solid, with wintergreen on the nose. Blackberry, cherry and other typical Cab flavors work well together on the framed, tannic palate. Finishes ripe, with additional tannins, coffee and chocolate. Hard as a rock in terms of feel. Imported by Moët Hennessy USA.
Simple but solid apple and nectarine aromas are straight forward. This feels round and easy, without much acid-based cut. Flavors of melon, mango and nectarine finish short, with a note of apple.

wine: Domaine Comte Georges de Voguë 2000  Chambolle-Musigny
review: Made from the estate's young vines and from a tiny parcel in the premier cru Les Baudes, this is still a wine with great presence. The aromas of new wood and sweet fruit show through as flavors of vanilla and rich, dark plums and raspberry jelly. The finishing acidity leaves a clean, fresh taste.

appellation: Umpqua Valley, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
review: The spritz you see in the glass translates into a tongue-tickling experience in the mouth. Fresh flavors of orange, grapefruit and pineapple are supported with moderate acidity. This is not a sparkling wine, but you'll want to drink this while it retains that refreshing hint of fizz.

wine: Domaine de la Verde 2015 Prélude Red (Vacqueyras)
review: Prélude is this producer's entry-level red. But unadorned by oak, it's a transparent and luminous expression of pristine black fruit and heady floral perfume. Cherry and plum flavors are lusciously concentrated, accented by violet, spice and baked earth. A silky yet briskly balanced wine with fine, integrated tannins that extend on the finish. Enjoy now–2026.

appellation: Vin de France, France Other, France
review: The nose on this wine blends lemon, grapefruit peel and ripe peach. Juicy with pear and Key lime, the palate ends on tart, ripe lemon. Acidity is sharp, with a tugging finish. The wine has a green edge, but the fruit is just ripe enough.

wine: Pedroncelli 2012 Mother Clone Zinfandel (Dry Creek Valley)
appellation: Dry Creek Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: Blended with 8% Petite Sirah and then aged almost a year in American oak, 30% of it new, this is fruity and smoky in equal measure. Its tones of blackberry, leather and black pepper are harmonious. Round and soft, it's easy to drink and will be approachable to a variety of palates.

appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Fresh, lush ripe red fruits are displayed against some barrel flavors of cracker and vanilla wafer. Forward, plump and quite pleasant.
A very old wine which smells medicinal and tastes like sweet cough syrup. It's so concentrated as to be almost undrinkable.

Made from the Domaine's oldest vines, this is a generous concentrated wine. With its ripe black fruits and firm tannins it is also a wine to age. It has perfumed black-cherry flavors that are enhanced and lifted by the acidity. Drink this wine from late 2017.

wine: Jax 2020 Rosé of Pinot Noir (Napa Valley)
review: Citrus-driven and fresh, this tastes of blood orange, tangerine and grapefruit—the wine light and lingering in delicate acidity. It impresses in its balance and length.

wine: Torii Mor 2015 Nysa Vineyard Pinot Noir (Dundee Hills)
appellation: Dundee Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: Though riper than the last vintage tasted (2013), this wine is affected from the sameness that runs through virtually all of the winery's many vineyard selections. Clearly a stylistic choice, it's acidic, bone dry, earthy and stocked with green, leafy flavors over and above the light hints of berry.

A great, complex wine for drinking now with roasts and stews. Smoothly tannic, it's big, yet dry and subtle, showing flavors of blackberries, raspberries and cherries, with a delightful minerality. The sweet finish is long, rich and spicy.

wine: Colinas do Douro 2016 Quinta da Extrema Edicão II Red (Douro)
review: This is a rich, complex wine, with powerful tannins along with equally impressive black plum fruits. It has richness to go with its structure and great fruits to balance the mineral texture. The blend of Touriga Nacional and Touriga Franca will age further. Drink from late 2021.

wine: Tenuta Santavenere 2012  Vino Nobile di Montepulciano
appellation: Vino Nobile di Montepulciano, Tuscany, Italy
review: A blend of Sangiovese, 5% Merlot and 5% Colorino, this opens with subtle aromas of red currant, brown cooking spice and a whiff of sun-baked earth. The straightforward, accessible palate offers wild cherry, coffee, toasted oak and black pepper. Drink through 2018.

wine: Felix Solis 2014 Viña Albali Gran Reserva Tempranillo (Valdepeñas)
review: Leafy aromas are low on fruit and high in grit. This Tempranillo from central Spain feels racy and rough. Plum, currant, cherry and earthy spice notes fill out the flavor profile, while mulled plum and berry notes ride out on a warm finish.

wine: Lionel Osmin & Cie 2017 Villa Grand Cap Gros Manseng (Vin de France)
appellation: Vin de France, France Other, France
review: Slightly round and opulent in style, this opens with attractive scents of yellow apple, honeydew, guava and passion fruit. The medium-weight palate offers a slightly creamy sensation thanks to waves of ripe pear, peach and melon. Ample acidity lends balance and lift to the close.

wine: Le Cadeau 2006 Côte Est Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)
appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: The Côte Est Pinot Noir is more structured and less immediately accessible than the winery's Rocheux bottling, but ultimately may prove to be the better bottle. It offers tightly woven, chewy fruit flavors of black cherry, black raspberry and plum, along with darker streaks of clove, leaf, smoke and earth. As always, the wine is structured with elegant precision.

89–91. Barrel sample. Ripe and smoky in character, this wine is perfumed and lively with acidity. It has potential to be a delicious, fruity, friendly wine but tannins and minerality both add firmer depth.

appellation: Mendocino County, Mendocino County, California, US
review: This is the kind of Zin that goes well with just about anything, from salmon to burgers. It's dry and balanced, with good flavors of berries, coffee and spices.

wine: Domaines Schlumberger 2013 Saering Grand Cru Riesling (Alsace)
review: The nose is subdued at first but then opens up into ripe apple notes with the zesty spice of grapefruit rind. The palate is dry and concentrated and adds a riper notion of juicy yellow plum while a bright lemony citrus streak keeps everything taut and lively. This is joyful, subtle and fresh and finishes on a pure apple note.

Dark ruby in the glass, this wine offers aromas of cassis and toffee. It is round on the palate, with silky tannins and flavors of black cherry, cranberry and butterscotch. A soft note of salinity graces the finish.

This is Markowitsch's flagship wine, from the Rosenberg vineyard. The blend varies from year to year, but always includes at least 50% Zweigelt, along with Merlot and Cabernet Sauvignon. This 2003 is as powerful and intense as is to be expected from a wine of this vintage, but is saved by its structure. It is rich, ripe and very open, with damson, black currants and creamy wood flavors blending well together.

wine: Szigeti NV Brut Grüner Veltliner (Österreichischer Sekt)
review: An enticing apple aroma sets the scene for a fresh, crisp and deliciously refreshing sparkling wine. It preserves the natural acidity of the Grüner Veltliner, while adding a literally bubbly character, breezy, perfect for an apéritif.

wine: Ilsley 2004 Single Vineyard Estate Cabernet Sauvignon (Stags Leap District)
appellation: Stags Leap District, Napa, California, US
review: This is the kind of wine the late, great André Tchelistcheff described as an iron fist in a velvet glove. The glove is the lush, forward blackberry, currant and cocoa flavors, the smooth texture and the seductively sweet new oak. The fist is the sheer power. This is an important addition to the pantheon of Stags Leap Cabernet Sauvignon, and one that needs some time in the cellar.

The winery's Rutherford-grown Sauvignon Blanc needs warm vintages to ripen. The last time that happened was in 2009. The last three years have not been kind, and 2012 was chilliest yet, resulting in a wine that's green and lean.

wine: Maryhill 2014 Kiona Vineyards Cabernet Sauvignon (Red Mountain)
appellation: Red Mountain, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: This wine's bright raspberry jam, pencil lead and barrel spice aromas lead to quite ripe, dried out fruit and barrel flavors. The tannins are a bit drying.

wine: Byron Blatty 2016 Agenda Syrah (Los Angeles County)
appellation: Los Angeles County, South Coast, California, US
review: This newer winery is one of the most promising Los Angeles County wine projects. This bottling, which includes 15% Tannat, shows cassis, black cherry and crushed purple flowers on the nose, while the palate is loaded with Morello cherry, rounded brown sugar and maple and a pleasantly chalky tannic structure.

wine: Mumm Cuvée Napa NV Brut Prestige  (Napa Valley)
review: Nicely balanced with a blend of toasty-yeasty and fresh elements on the nose, this sparkler has good fruit—not too sweet—and a smooth and creamy feel. Straightforward, it offers full but dry apple-pineapple flavors and some green-apple and lime notes on the finish.

This is quite reductive at first, with sweaty, barnyard aromas dominating. With time in the glass and plenty of vigorous swirling, these notes do blow off, offering in their place ripe plum and cherry fruit, chocolate and a little black pepper. The palate is full and juicy with drying, slightly astringent tannins and a finish that feels a little sour fruited.
Has all the elements of a top Chard, from the ripe fruit to the oak. It's just a little more modest, and a lot less expensive.

Aromas of ripe apple and yellow plum are dappled with an inviting dried chamomile accent on the nose. The medium-bodied palate is rounded and creamy in feel, displaying juicy orchard fruit flavors honed by fresh lemon and plum skin accents.

A combination of very ripe fruit and charred oak results in aromas of blackberry, prune, raisin and burnt toast. In the mouth, this is saturated and rich, with structured tannins. Roasted black-fruit flavors are savory and show sweet notes of baking spices, while this finishes with density and lingering grip. Drink from 2019–2028.

appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: This wine's potent grass and grapefruit scents greet you, and similar flavors follow. It would be easy to mistake this for New Zealand Sauvignon Blanc, given its intensity and aroma. In the mouth, it's immaculately fresh and crisp, with steely acidity. Citrus rind flavors continue through its long finish.

wine: J. Lohr 2007 Fog's Reach Vineyard Pinot Noir (Arroyo Seco)
appellation: Arroyo Seco, Central Coast, California, US
review: Very ripe and almost sweet in jammy, pie-filling cherries and raspberries, with a rich seasoning of cinnamon, brown sugar and cocoa. But it's technically dry, and has a crispness from fine Arroyo Seco acidity. Drink now.
An herbal strawberry aroma meets dusty furniture and dried hay on the nose. Light bodied and showing little tannic structure, flavors of watery strawberry and currant race to the finish.

Aromas of Cran-Grape juice, cherry stones and stalkiness lead into a vegetal palate. There are also some nice cedar and baking spice notes. The tannins are grippy in this full-bodied wine, while the finish is long and dry, with green notes on the back.

Soft, layered and reasonably complex, this red blend showcases juicy black cherry, cassis and a wealth of dried herb. A good value for the quality, it'll serve a gathering well, or do its job as a weekday wine.

wine: Penfolds 2007 Thomas Hyland Cabernet Sauvignon (South Australia)
review: Good luck finding a Cabernet for $15 that offers as much as this one does. It's filled with plums and cassis, accented by vanilla, coffee and chocolate notes. Ample weight and density are balanced by supple tannins. Should be fairly long-lived for a wine at this price; drink now–2020.

wine: Dry Creek Vineyard 2003 Dry Chenin Blanc (Clarksburg)
review: Always a benchmark for bone-dry Chenins, this year's release is fragrant with peach, wildflower and vanilla, and a slightly sour flavor of lemondrop. It's so high in acidity, it practically tingles.

Aromas that recall red berry, dark baking spice and grilled Mediterranean herb lift out of the glass. The elegantly structured palate shows black cherry, wild strawberry, licorice, cracked pepper and a hint of sage. It's nicely balanced, with bright acidity and refined tannins. Drink 2019 through 2024.

Cinnamon-clove aromas on the nose. The wine has dry tannins in the mouth, and very solid, taut cherry and plum fruit, with dusty pencil-eraser accents. Would pair well with grilled food, or just about anything in barbecue sauce.

wine: Llopart 2010 Leopardi Brut Nature Gran Reserva Sparkling (Cava)
review: In a small field of excellent Cavas, this bready, leesy, semi-rich bottling stands out for its totality and comfort on the palate. Along the road are aromas of burnt banana and toasted bread along with flavors of arugula, lime and dried apple. An elegant finish with stone-fruit and green-herb notes is sophisticated.

This off-dry, honeyed Tokaj wine has a penetrating minerality that extends from start to finish, with aromas of honeysuckle and fresh tangerine skin. Slightly dusty on the palate, it shows hints of dried herb and crushed stone, and it finishes on a delicate flower tone.

The vineyards surrounding the 12th-century castle have produced this rich and densely structured wine. Powerful tannins give a smoky character to the ripe, black-plum fruits. It definitely needs aging, so drink from 2026.

appellation: Amador County, Sierra Foothills, California, US
review: Renwood's classic, Grandmère, has an inviting blackberry and sassafras nose with great fruit intensity though it's still smooth—maybe the influence of American oak?—and well-structured, monstrously full-bodied and a little moody at the finish.

wine: Domaine Ostertag 2017 Les Vieilles Vignes Sylvaner (Alsace)
review: Touches of earth and straw appear on the nose but lemon also shines through. This wine shows a lovely juxtaposition of textured, ripe juiciness and vivid freshness, presented on a fresh and Mirabelle-scented body. It finishes dry.

appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
review: Bloody meats, squid ink, black raspberry, crushed rocks and char show on the nose of this bottling. The palate is loaded with dried herbs, lavender and black plum flavors, finishing with a pinch of white pepper.

wine: Ciringa 2011 Fosilni Breg Reserve Sauvignon Blanc (Štajerska)
review: This Slovenian Sauvignon Blanc has aromas of lemon grass and freshly mowed lawn. It is sharp on entry with flavors of lime juice, orange zest and grapefruit before the bright acidic finish.

Here's a wine that just cannot overcome the limitations of the vintage. They tried for extract and gave it some pretty oak but nonetheless herbal, bell pepper characteristics overshadow its modest berry fruit.

wine: Klipfel 2009 Clos Zisser Kirchberg de Barr Grand Cru Gewurztraminer (Alsace)
designation: Clos Zisser Kirchberg de Barr Grand Cru
review: Certainly sweet, this is a rich wine that is maturing well. It has weight and spice and a soft, opulent texture. It's sourced from grapes grown on the steep slopes above the city of Barr. Drink now and until 2018.

A spicy hint of maple syrup precedes the vivid red cherry fruit on the nose. The palate then adds a lovely, slightly smoky oakiness to the elegant, fresh and sinuous palate. This has a lovely coolness about it, a slender elegance accentuated by very fine, tulle tannins.

This McLaren Vale-based winery reaches into the neighboring Adelaide Hills for its Chardonnay. This is subtly oaky, hinting at toast and butter, then pulling back to reveal understated apple and citrus flavors that are clean and refreshing on the finish.

wine: Stags' Leap Winery 2000 Estate Grown Reserve Merlot (Napa Valley)
review: A wonderful Merlot. It's very soft in the mouth; the blackberry, cherry and plum flavors are not especially dense, probably because of the vintage. But the tannins are as softly blurry as Renoir colors. This is an early drinker of immense charm.

wine: Beaulieu Vineyard 2006 Beaulieu Reserve Maestro Collection No. 1 Cabernet Sauvignon (Rutherford)
review: With this Bordeaux blend, Beaulieu seems to be striving to create a softer, fruiter wine than their various Cabernets. They have succeeded. The wine is generous in blackberries, cherries and blueberries, with a strong coating of sweet, smoky oak. Plush and lovely now, and should develop bottle complexity through 2012.

The nose on the Tapestry is a little subdued—but that's a good thing, if brett, garlic and meaty gravy aren't what you're looking for in a Shiraz. Medium-weight and a little chewy in the mouth, the palate offers lots of blackberry plus earth, leather and horsey flavors. Finishes medium-long with grape and oak flavors.
True to its name, this blend is tangy in acidity. Flavorwise, it's simple, with pleasant orange, peach, lemon and vanilla flavors that finish a little sweet.

wine: Domaine Alfred 1999 Chamisal Vineyards Califa Pinot Noir (Edna Valley)
appellation: Edna Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: There's nothing not to like about this round, delicious wine. There are classy toast and charcoal aromas on top of red berries and some yeast. The palate offers the right blend of tart, snappy cherry and richer black plum. Healthy tannins help drive the finish. Editors' Choice.

Earthy and baked on the nose, with rubber, black fruits and warm, almost burnt leather notes. The palate has a lively, dense mouthfeel and flavors of earthy berry fruits and raisin. Definitely on the warm and roasted side but still balanced and interesting. Drink now.

wine: Domaine Saint- Germain 2018 Terroir des Grottes Chardonnay  (Bourgogne)
review: This soft wine is rather unfocused, with baked-apple and vanilla flavors. A gentle wine, it has a light touch of acidity at the end. Drink now.

wine: Columbia Crest 2005 Walter Clore Private Reserve Red Wine Red (Columbia Valley (WA))
designation: Walter Clore Private Reserve Red Wine
appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: The finest Walter Clore since the 2001, this Bordeaux-style blend shows considerable muscle and depth. Built upon firm, cherry-berry fruit, it adds nuances of baking spice, pepper, vanilla wafer and a pleasing earthiness to the tannins. It represents the ultimate expression of Columbia Crest, and the 2005 marks a welcome return to excellence.

wine: Core Winery 2005 Elevation Sensation Red (Santa Barbara County)
appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
review: Overripe and hot, with a Porty, brandied fruitcake aroma and semi-sweet cherry and chocolate flavors. Grenache and Mourvèdre.

Aromas of hot pepper flakes, Chinese mustard, leather and red plum are all over the map. The palate is a bit tart and tangy for Malbec, with mid-level berry flavors and a shot of tartness. Not overly ripe or happy, but with touches of quality.

Typically dry and earthy, with aromas of wet leaves, rubber and cherry drink mix. The palate features tart red fruit floating on a wave of aggressive acids. Some spice on the finish is a decent second act. Imported by 57 Main Street Wine Co.

appellation: Lake County, Lake County, California, US
review: This hodgepodge of Zinfandel, Syrah, Tempranillo, Barbera, Cabernet Sauvignon and Grenache, all grown in Lake County, will please many palates. It's a subtle and satisfying red marked by sweet tannins, a soft mouthfeel and rounded notes of cherry, plum and vanilla.

appellation: Monterey County, Central Coast, California, US
review: Simple and off-dry, with all sorts of fruity, flowery and spicy flavors, this wine shows off high, crisp Monterey acidity, which makes it finish clean. The alcohol is a comfortable 13%.

appellation: High Valley, Lake County, California, US
review: Tangy and well-balanced, this fresh-tasting and light-bodied wine offers tempting citrus and herb aromas, light lemon and crisp apple flavors and an appetizing texture.

appellation: Hunter Valley, New South Wales, Australia
review: Dense and blackberryish on the nose, this medium- to full-bodied Shiraz offers plenty of fruit in soft, easy-to-drink package. Hints of dried spices give it more interest than your average $12 Shiraz.

appellation: Ballard Canyon, Central Coast, California, US
review: Mikael Sigouin extracts the rich side of Grenache in most of his bottlings, and this is an excellent example. Deep and stunning aromas of lilac, cola, red cherries, strawberry-balsamic glaze, black cardamom and sharp sandalwood lead into a palate that's lavish with chai spice, dried ginger and cherry-cordial flavors. Tannins pile up toward the finish and the acidity sings through it all.

Pear, melon and stony mineral aromas share space on the nose of this Godello, which feels solid. Short stone-fruit flavors are pleasing but not overly defined, while this feel sound and round on the finish, with a hint of almondy bitterness.
Black plum, tobacco and baking spice aromas come together on this. The ripe and concentrated palate offers dried black cherry, mocha and vanilla alongside assertive tannins. Drink after 2021.

wine: Sur de los Andes 2004 Reserve Malbec (Mendoza)
review: Guillermo Banfi's Sur de los Andes and Alma de los Andes wines are excellent across the board. This reserve-level holdover from 2004 offers mint, chocolate and leather aromas in front of ripe cherry and raspberry flavors. Almost crisp and choppy, but on the other hand precise and zesty. Not unlike a very good Dolcetto from Italy.

appellation: Rogue Valley, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
review: Spicy and detailed, the mix of cranberry, pomegranate and raspberry fruit carries this wine through a firm, medium-bodied finish. Just a hint of pepper adds further interest.

wine: Kay Brothers 2016 Basket Pressed Amery Vineyard Shiraz (McLaren Vale)
review: From this historic winery's home block of vines, this Shiraz is a rich, winter warmer that's still finding its way. It opens with aromas of plump blueberries, plums, chocolate flakes, dried green spices and black pepper, with flecks of licorice and graphite in the background. There's some heat from the alcohol on the palate and the oak is fairly prominent. Spicy, drying tannins back more plush plummy fruit. This should cellar well, but it's a little chunky at the moment. Drink 2020–2029.

Aromas of cherries with orange-peel notes and a touch of funky earthiness that adds depth and interest. Bright berry and tart-cherry flavors with licorice accents engage the palate. Good, full mouthfeel. Medium finish, with Burgundian sour-cherry tones. Elegant; balanced not heavy.

appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: Tightly woven aromas of honeysuckle, gardenia, Asian pear and lychee make for a pleasant nose on this bottling. There is a tight weave to the texture of the palate, where lime pith leads into more generous flavors of plumeria and poached pear.

There's a decadent spray of rose perfume that lingers from start to finish on this soft, pretty Cab Franc. Light in body with sheer black cherry flavors, it's fresh and quaffable with a dusting of fine, furry tannins on the finish.

wine: Va Piano 2005 Syrah (Columbia Valley-Walla Walla Valley)
appellation: Columbia Valley-Walla Walla Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Smooth, luscious, dense and brilliant—the color is saturated and superbright—this silky wine has kept the tannins supple and ripe. It captures the essence of young, fresh, spicy Syrah, unadulterated or modified with other grapes. This is tight, firm, sappy, young and a bit relentless in a tough, confident style. Flavors of cranberry and wild raspberry run rampant, with plenty of acid to keep it clean and penetrating.
Soft and fruity, with cherry flavors. Drinks dry and clean, a pleasant wine that will go with just about everything.

wine: Gunpowder Creek 2015 Caleb Foster The Greatest Hits Conner Lee Vineyard Cabernet Franc (Columbia Valley (WA))
designation: Caleb Foster The Greatest Hits Conner Lee Vineyard
appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: This is a new project from longtime Washington winemaker Caleb Foster. Aromas of fresh herb, sliced green pepper, flower, orange peel and cherry are followed by soft sumptuous pure cherry flavors. The finish carries.

wine: Dane Cellars 2014 Justi Creek Vineyard Grenache (Sonoma Valley)
review: High toned, with deep cherry, strawberry and vanilla notes, this wine is velvety and dense, with powerful tannins and a breadth of earthy flavor.

wine: Torre Rosazza 2014 Pinot Bianco (Friuli Colli Orientali)
appellation: Friuli Colli Orientali, Northeastern Italy, Italy
review: Aromas of fragrant spring blossom, orchard fruit, hazelnut and bread crust lead the nose on this refined white. The elegantly structured palate offers creamy yellow apple, lemon drop and mineral alongside crisp acidity that leaves a tangy finish.

This is absolutely delicious, offering heady waves of orange marmalade, butterscotch candy, crème brûlée and honey that are wildly opulent. This is a go-to bottling for very sweet, unctuous California dessert wines.

wine: Domaine de la Butte 2018 Mi-Pente Cabernet Franc (Bourgueil)
review: One of three wines from the La Butte vineyard, this comes from halfway up the slope. The positioning gives the wine a rich style, expressing the vineyard in its ripe black fruits and fine, dark tannins. It is an ageworthy wine, poised and subtly elegant. Drink from 2022.

wine: San Giuseppe 2003  Amarone della Valpolicella Classico
appellation: Amarone della Valpolicella Classico, Veneto, Italy
review: There's a nice aromatic ensemble here of spice, clove, oak, prune and cherry. But the oak nuances are a bit overpowering. More wood flavors appear in the mouth as well as dried berry flavors.

wine: Château Bianca 2005 Cellar Select Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)
appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: This brings a lot of flavor to the table for its relatively modest price. Round and spicy, it leads with juicy strawberry, cherry and apple pie fruit flavors. Hints of cinnamon wind through the finish, and overall the impression is of a pretty, lively and slightly sweet wine without pretense.

wine: Kitá 2016 Camp 4 Vineyard Sauvignon Blanc (Santa Ynez Valley)
appellation: Santa Ynez Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: Very light in the glass and fresh on the nose, this bottling by Chumash tribe descendant Tara Gomez offers aromas of lemon blossom and honeydew rind. There is good tension to the sip, which is very much focused on texture, with flashes of green apple skins and lime peels, proving quite tight and zesty.

wine: Winzer Krems 2011 Kremser Pfaffenberg Reserve  Riesling (Kremstal)
review: The steep Pfaffenberg vineyard, sloping straight down to the Danube River, is one of the top vineyards in Krems. This rich and complex wine has a fine perfumed character, laced with lemon and pear flavors. It has a touch of minerality in its texture, making a wine that should age over several years.

A perfumed wine full of white fruits balanced by acidity, this is already advanced and ready to drink. The wine's texture, however, will also allow it to age. Drink now for its fruitiness or from 2021.

wine: Balma Venitia 2004 Terres du Trias Red (Beaumes-de-Venise)
review: From the local co-op, the Cave de Vignerons de Beaumes-de-Venise, this is a soft, very ripe wine filled with flavors of licorice and prune, but without any sense of heaviness. Easy to drink.

wine: Domaine Font Sarade 2018 Les Terres Rouges Red (Ventoux)
review: Notes of blackberry and crème de cassis are piercing and pristine in this concentrated blend of 40% Grenache, 40% Syrah and 20% Carignan. Unoaked and translucent in fruit quality, it's a juicy, invigorating wine accented by whispers of smoke, earth and bramble. The finish lingers on fine, slightly sandpapery tannins. Best now–2027.

wine: Wilson 1999 Sydney Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Dry Creek Valley)
appellation: Dry Creek Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: The blackberry and plum flavors ride next to earthier ones of tobacco and dried herbs, with strong, gritty but balanced tannins. Very dry and a bit rugged, but showing integrity. Drink with roasted meats.

Made entirely from Pinot Nero, this Franciacorta rosé has a subdued fragrance that reveals notes of strawberry, grapefruit and nut. The linear, refreshing palate shows bright cherry flavors and closes on a note of toasted almond.

This is an expressive Barossa Shiraz, combining ripe raspberry fruit and a lush, creamy texture with herbal, savory notes and crisp acidity. Turns a bit zingy on the finish, with cranberry overtones. Drink now–2015.

Here's an elegant and fine Barbaresco with silky tannins and drying touches of talc powder and exotic spice. An austere quality shows on the nose, with smoked bacon, tobacco and black currant aromas. It displays beautiful intensity as well.

wine: Viticultori Associati Canicatti 2010 Centuno Nero d'Avola (Sicilia)
review: This offers ripe notes of prune and blackberry, with a nutty nuance. The mouthfeel is round, plush and smooth.

wine: Phillips Hill 2011 Oppenlander Vineyard Pinot Noir (Mendocino)
review: From a great vineyard, this Pinot is earthy and fairly robust in style, dry and balanced in acidity with a thick texture. Cherry and cranberry dominate in flavor and aroma, the wine aged 16 months in French oak, 25% new.

Hints of orange blossom and crushed stone are subtle on the nose but extend to the palate of this medium-bodied, salt-struck expression of Chablis. Briskly composed but intensely mineral in focus, it lingers on streaks of fresh white grapefruit and an oyster-shell finish.

wine: Rui Roboredo Madeira 2015 Beyra Reserva Quartz White (Beira Interior)
review: From vines in the mountains of eastern Portugal, this is a delicate, floral and crisp wine. Refreshing with shots of acidity, orange zest and lemon, it is bright and tight.

wine: Vin du Lac 2005 Savvy! Blanc Sauvignon Blanc (Columbia Valley (WA))
appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Unusually sweet for Sauvignon Blanc at 1.6% residual sugar. It doesn't have enough stuffing to compensate.
With a light caramel taste, this is a fat while still fruity wine. Salmon pink in color, it has acidity that fits behind the ripe red plum flavors. It should be drunk now.

wine: Amador Foothill Winery 2001 Clockspring Vineyard Zinfandel (Shenandoah Valley (CA))
appellation: Shenandoah Valley (CA), Sierra Foothills, California, US
review: Smooth and silky on the palate, the wine serves up a refined blend of black cherry, blackberry, coffee, tea, spice and herb flavors. The tannins are soft yet firm.

wine: Andis 2015 Hawk Creek Vineyard Cabernet Franc (Sierra Foothills)
appellation: Sierra Foothills, Sierra Foothills, California, US
review: Light-bodied for a red wine and a little rustic in flavor, this wine has engaging earth, leather and cedar aromas, good fruit flavors and a roasted, chocolaty aspect that develops on the palate and lingers on the finish. It's moderately tannic and robust in texture.

appellation: Potter Valley, Mendocino County, California, US
review: This is a smooth and gently fruity wine. Aromas are subtle, fresh and slightly floral, while the more-forward flavors resemble peaches and honeydew melons. The texture is smooth rather than tart, and the wine may have a touch of residual sugar to keep it tasting fruity and feeling rounded.

wine: Bründlmayer NV Extra Brut Sparkling (Österreichischer Sekt)
review: A full, yeasty wine, this has gentle acidity, with a touch of smokiness as well as a note of apple It feels full, without the necessary crispness.

With an unusually bright gold color, pineapple and honey aromas, and lively lemon and grapefruit flavors, this wine shows a lot of personality. The effect is refreshing and fruity, but not wimpy. It should pair well with lots of different salads, appetizers and seafood.

Attractive wood-aging flavors and smoothness have polished this wine and given it richness. Blackberry fruits are integrating with the tannins and structure. The wine should develop well and will be ready from 2022.

This wine was fermented in the bottle only, in the old style. Bone dry, the wine has a wonderful nutty character, shot through with acidity that is now calmed down and forms part of the white-fruit element. Elegant and ripe, it is ready to drink now.

appellation: San Benito County, Central Coast, California, US
review: Hailing from the historic Enz Vineyard, this bottling begins with elegant aromas of lavender, plum and dried earth. The tannic tension is immediately apparent on the palate, both leathery and taut, giving long-living structure to the cranberry, sour cherry, crushed cement and tar flavors. Drink 2022–2038.

Le Silve del Parco delivers bright berry fruit and exotic spice over an easy but cheerful mouthfeel. The wine is smooth but firm with sweet cherry flavors that would pair with lamb chops or barbecued chicken.

wine: Castoro Cellars 2015 Oakenshield Vineyard Falanghina (Paso Robles)
appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: Golden-yellow in color, this bottling of a rarely planted grape from Italy's Campania region shows soft chamomile and sliced yellow apples on the pleasant nose. Squeezed lemon, light mandarin juice and a touch of walnut oil show on the sip, where the acid rises late and lasts long.

wine: Forgeron 2016 Anvil Boushey Vineyard Syrah (Yakima Valley)
appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Aromas of dark chocolate, black licorice, blackberry jam, bacon fat and plum lead to full-bodied, sweet, very jammy fruit flavors that finish warm. The ripeness carries it away, with this oft-expressive vineyard seeming hard to find.

wine: Chateau Ste. Michelle 2004 Indian Wells Cabernet Sauvignon (Columbia Valley (WA))
appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Here at last are the flavors that have been missing from Ste. Michelle Cabs for some time. This is crisply structured, varietally spot-on Cabernet. The ripe—but not jammy—fruit flavors of blackberry and black plum are amplified with spicy cinnamon from aging in American oak. There is a hint of chalkiness in the way the acids hit the palate, but otherwise this is picture-perfect, with well-delineated tannins and some delicious Asian spices on the finish.
This wine is dark and extracted, with bitter chocolate flavors as well as hints of black-currant fruit. It does have weight and structure that could develop, but will need time, so wait until 2020.

wine: Ca' de' Rocchi 2015 La Bastia  (Amarone della Valpolicella)
review: Packaged in an extremely heavy bottle, this has a shy nose that eventually reveals subdued aromas of leafy underbrush, prune and oak. The forward one-dimensional palate offers mocha, raisin and a drop of vanilla alongside evolved tannins.

wine: Domaine Loew 2017 Altenberg de Bergbieten Grand Cru Gewurztraminer (Alsace)
review: Subtlety is the name of the game with this wine. Notes of citrus pith display gentle fruitiness on the nose and then intensify on the palate. Gentle, juicy peachiness on the midpalate has a medium-sweet aspect that balanced by aromatic orange freshness. The finish is zesty and lasting.
A fruity rosé, this is full of red-berry flavors lifted even further by a shot of red currants. It is balanced, with fruit contrasting well with the bright texture. Drink the wine now.
Opens with scratchy, dusty aromas of red fruits and herbs. The palate is round but clunky, with sweet, grapy flavors of blackberry and blueberry. Finishes rather oaky and mild, with a grainy feel.

wine: Domaines Barons de Rothschild (Lafite) 2008 Blason d'Aussières Red (Corbières)
review: Berry and bramble mingle with touches of cocoa and tree bark on the nose. The palate shows more bright fruit flavors supported by garrigue herbs and peppery spice. Forward and approachable but tasty and easy to drink.

A passionfruit-dominated wine without much else besides a fresh, almost watery palate feel. This is a one-trick pony that's all passionfruit except for some pineapple juice and mango sorbet. Wet, zesty and tropical but only moderately pleasant.

wine: Pisano 2013 Río de los Pájaros Reserve Torrontés (Progreso)
review: Aromas of Pine-Sol, petrol and juniper bush are not too inviting. An astringent, citric palate makes for a tough palate that's marked with harsh citrus and passion fruit flavors, followed by a pithy, sour finish.

appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: Rich and savory, this Chardonnay displays lots of fruit and oak, balanced with crisp acidity. The flavors of pineapples and pears have an edge of smoke and buttered toast. Ready now.

wine: White Oak 2009 Sauvignon Blanc (Russian River Valley)
appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: If you like those dry, acidic New Zealand Sauvignon Blancs, with their gooseberry aromas and flavors, this wine's for you. It shows enough lemon, lime and white flower ripeness to give it rich interest.

wine: Ortas 2016 Les Viguiers Red (Côtes du Rhône)
appellation: Côtes du Rhône, Rhône Valley, France
review: This is an intensely ripe, juicy wine made from 70% Grenache, 20% Carignan and 10% Cinsault. It's densely fruity and forward, boasting plush black-cherry and plum flavors as well as a warming touch of caramel. The finish is fresh with a hint of granite minerality.

Rustic, smoky and deep on the nose, with a creamy body holding up commendable raspberry and plum flavors. Valenciso deals medium-level acids and tannins, with oak-based mocha and chocolate carrying the finish. This wine is so close to reaching the next level, but it doesn't quite get there.

wine: La Playa 2004 Estate Rose Cabernet Sauvignon (Colchagua Valley)
review: Light fruit, muddled aromas, candied flavors and a heavy aftertaste don't really add up to a lot. Yes, it's acceptable. But it's also aging quickly and won't be improving.

wine: Willamette Valley Vineyards 2007 Estate Vineyard Chardonnay (Willamette Valley)
appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: Soft, buttery, with microwave popcorn flavors, this needs to be well chilled or it will come off a bit flabby. Simple fruit flavors of green grapes and apples are somewhat overwhelmed by the oak.

Decidedly not a powerhouse this vintage, the '98 Colonnello is a pretty, relatively lightweight wine, displaying a range of aromas and flavors from cherries to cigarbox and dried spices. Drink now–2015.

This is hard coated with a creamy plastic note and a milk chocolate scent. Overall it smells heavily oaked and artificial. It feels resiny, with sticky tannins and thickness, tasting of hickory and carob.

wine: Kaena 2016 Kuliouou Cuvée Alamo Creek Ranch Red (San Luis Obispo County)
appellation: San Luis Obispo County, Central Coast, California, US
review: Strong aromas of potpourri, blackberry jam, licorice and sandalwood show on the nose of this blend of 65% Grenache and 35% Syrah from a hidden vineyard north of the Santa Maria Valley. The sip is tense in structure, which frames the exuberant cassis, fig and baked licorice flavors.

wine: Sanguis 2007 The Oracle of Delphi Syrah (California)
review: A brilliant Syrah, showing its cool-climate origins with a burst of white pepper. Much of the fruit comes from the Bien Nacido Vineyard, and the Syrah contains 4% Viognier. Firm tannins and fine acidity give this delicious wine structure, but it's mostly notable for the extraordinary depth and length of its blackberry, currant, teriaki beef, mushroom and cedar flavors. The wine easily stands up to 100% new French oak casks.
A little unripe and green, with minty flavors that veer into that notorious cat zone. Has just enough lemon and lime citrus flavor to bring it back from the brink.

wine: Cave du Marmandais 2015 Château Terrebert Malbec-Cabernet Franc Red (Côtes du Marmandais)
appellation: Côtes du Marmandais, Southwest France, France
review: Structure and perfume go well together in this attractive blend of 30% Cabernet Franc and 70% Malbec. The wine, full of black fruits, plenty of acidity and a firm touch of tannins is balanced, juicy and ready to drink.

wine: De Loach 2014 Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)
appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: Earthy compost and forest vie for attention in this full-bodied, lush wine that's lightly spiced with clove. Cranberry, strawberry and a hint of leather round out the experience.
Inviting in tropical aromas of guava and pineapple, it smells sweet but drinks dry, balanced in melon and high-toned citrus, just a hint of grass on the finish.

wine: Vicente Gandia 2014 Hoya de Cadenas 130 Anniversary Red (Utiel-Requena)
review: Floral plum and horsey aromas comprise the nose on this multigrape blend led by Bobal. A grabby palate exhibits raw, tough tannins, while plum and berry flavors finish rugged.

A bit leafy up front, with aromas of carob, forest floor and standard berry. The palate deals expected cherry and raspberry flavors, while the tight finish leaves a snappy sensation. A standard food wine.
A surprisingly light, crisp Zinfandel, with tomato and herb aromas and flavors only partially offset by berries. But it finishes with Zin's trademark pepperiness.
Aromas of banana, yellow stone fruit and a heady whiff of jasmine jump out of the glass. The rounded palate offers peach, pink grapefruit and an herbal note alongside bright acidity.

wine: Fiuza 2019 Ducado do Infante Reserva Red (Tejo)
review: A rich blend of 50-50 Touriga Nacional and Alicante Bouschet, the wine has a dense color accompanied by dense tannins and dark black fruits. Wood aging has softened the tannins although they do have a ways to go. Drink from 2022.

Heady and well choreographed, with roasted sweet aromas to get things going. Some char and weight appear next, setting up solid cherry and blackberry flavors. Juicy, ripe and structured. An unusual blend that works nicely. Imported by Billington Imports.

Made with organically farmed Sangiovese, this evokes aromas of black-skinned berry, truffle and new leather. The concentrated palate offers dried black cherry, vanilla and nutmeg alongside close-grained tannins. Drink 2023–2029.

wine: Merriam 2000 Windacre Vineyard Merlot (Russian River Valley)
appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: A first-rate wine, with well-ripened flavors of blackberries, espresso, cola, tea, and bitter chocolate, but made more interesting by fresh acidity not often seen in today's better Merlots. This cool-climate wine also has sturdy tannins that suggest mid-term aging.

Standard fare, but nice. The nose offers some burnt sugar in addition to black fruit, while the palate is full of plum, cherry and spice. Chocolate and vanilla are detectable on the medium-length finish, while the feel and balance are proper.

appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: Marked by deep, rich licorice and black cherry flavors, the wine also serves up an array of lovely plum, raspberry, coffee, cola and spice flavors. Tannins are smooth yet firm, and the finish is moderate in length.

This vineyard had lain derelict after the devastating 1956 Bordeaux frosts before it was purchased in 1995. From vines now approaching peak production, this wine is structured, with dense tannins as well as generous blackberry fruits. It has a future and should be drunk from 2022.

wine: Steven Kent 1999 Folkendt Vineyard - Merrillie Chardonnay (Livermore Valley)
appellation: Livermore Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: From a newish winery, this stunning Chard opens with lush, opulent aromas of tropical fruits and peach, lime peel, smoke, butterscotch, mineral and smoky oak. Fabulous depth and complexity in the mouth, with an almost unnatural limpidity and velvety softness.

wine: Carivintas 2007 Hobo Petite Sirah (Santa Barbara County)
appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
review: Lots of blackberry, cherry, smoked meat and pepper spice flavors in this dry, tannic Petite Sirah. It's a little harsh in texture, so drink it with rich barbecue and roasted meat dishes.

wine: Charles Mignon NV Cuvée Comte de Marne Grand Cru Rosé Brut  (Champagne)
designation: Cuvée Comte de Marne Grand Cru Rosé Brut
review: Grapes for this Champagne come from Grand Cru vineyards in the Montagne de Reims for Pinot Noir and the Côte des Blancs for Chardonnay. Texture and richness are balanced by tight minerality and impressive layers of fruit and acidity. The wine is ready to drink.

wine: Loring Wine Company 2012 Parmalee-Hill Vineyard Chardonnay (Sonoma Coast)
review: The vineyard lies in that fuzzy area that also qualifies for a Carneros or Sonoma Valley appellation. The wine is ripe and forward in tangerine, apricot, mango and lime fruit, with fine acidity and a hit of buttery, toasty oak. It defines the ripe, opulent California coastal style of Chardonnay.

Pithy zesty notes rise from the glass. The palate has the same lifted, pithy, and slightly bitter edge but some residual sweetness rounds the pear apparent on the palate into fluid fruitiness. The bitter edge remains and the wine finishes dry.

wine: Felton Road 2019 Cornish Point Pinot Noir (Central Otago)
review: Using grapes from lakeside vines that are now over 20 years old, Cornish Point displays some of the most brambly fruit and secondary notes of the FR Pinots. It's quite young now, but with just a little air it starts to reveal aromas of wild blueberry, cedar, dried flowers, vanilla bean and a slight meaty undertone. The palate is fresher than the broody nose suggests, with a tug of powdery tannins and fleshy fruit, but has a broader shape than Felton's Block 3 or Calvert. Drink now–2031.
Falcor's previous Sangioveses both seemed underripe. This one's just the opposite, a soft, jammy wine with sweetened cherry and raspberry candy flavors.

wine: Barefoot Bubbly NV Extra Dry Sparkling (California)
review: This light, smooth and somewhat sweet bubbly offers crisp apple aromas, a fine bead of carbonation and relatively soft, fruity flavors that fill the palate.
Review unavailable at this time

wine: Crū 2016 Paraiso Vineyard Chardonnay (Santa Lucia Highlands)
appellation: Santa Lucia Highlands, Central Coast, California, US
review: Very light in color in the glass, this single-vineyard expression shows light chalky aromas on the nose alongside lemon peel and candied honeysuckle. Green-apple-flesh flavors pop on the palate with bright citrus flashes.

wine: Domaine Seilly 2009 Rouge d'Obernai Pinot Noir (Alsace)
review: With some wood aging, this is a richer Pinot Noir than some from Alsace. Good color, red berry fruits and an intense juicy line of acidity. Not for aging, but with some weight.
This Rhône red blend is kind of simple and sweet, offering fruit and oak flavors that go down nice and easy. Tastes like raspberry, cherry, roasted almond, honey and vanilla granola.

appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: A blend based on Cabernet Sauvignon and Petit Verdot, this is heavy, soft and fruity, delivering a blackberry flavor and a dry finish.
With a streak stream of acidity and medicinal cherry flavors, this Merlot has a Life Saver-candy taste, with a sweet finish.

wine: Wine with Spirit 2012 Carpe Noctem Voyeur Limited Edition Red (Alentejano)
review: Put aside the bizarre name and label and concentrate on the wine which is fine, structured and densely tannic red fruit. The tannins and firm texture are balanced by black currant flavors and succulent acidity. The wine needs to age, and shouldn't be drunk before 2017.

wine: Campus Oaks 2004 Cum Laude Reserve Petite Sirah (Clarksburg)
review: Big, thick, rich, ripe and basically dry pretty much sums up this Delta-grown Petite Sirah. It bursts with chocolate-infused red and black currant flavors, with an edge of pepper and tobacco. Sturdy enough to hold well for a decade.
Mineral, crisp and full of acidity, this wine offers a tangy texture and fresh acidity. The refreshing style features just a touch of spice and plenty of fruitiness. Drink now.

wine: Vignerons de Bel Air 2014 Grande QV  (Coteaux Bourguignons)
review: Made from selected parcels of Gamay, this structured wine offers both fruit and fresh acidity. It has a dry core, giving a solid wine with some aging potential. Aromatic and fresh red fruits complete a wine that will be better from 2016.

wine: Pedro Romero NV Extra Dry Manzanilla Sherry (Jerez)
review: Perfectly good manzanilla for casual sipping. The nose is light, pure and offers echoes of pear and blanched almonds. Dry and elegant, with apple, salt and minerally flavors, the palate is complete and mouthfilling. Finishes with length.

appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: Black cherry, cocoa and turned loam aromas show on the nose. Bright berry and cherry flavors meet with tobacco and ancho chile dust on the palate.
Fleshy black-cherry notes on the nose signal generosity and ripeness. The palate obliges with an easy juicy flow of generous but balanced fruit. This is light, dry and harmonious.

wine: Columbia Winery 1999 Red Willow Syrah (Yakima Valley)
appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Despite being a bit closed aromatically, a thick, velvety mouthfeel and dense blackberry and vanilla flavors confirm this wine's quality. With airing, burnt caramel and fleshy berry scents emerge. The finish brings a hint of pepper and some drying tannins--enough to suggest cellaring two or three years.

appellation: Ribera del Guadiana, Central Spain, Spain
review: Rosy in color, with simple jammy aromas. Basic strawberry and black cherry flavors are backed by rubbery tannins. Seems cleanly made; just not all that exciting. Imported by Haro Imports.

appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
review: Fresh grapefruit and ripe apple make for a fresh and inviting nose on this blend of 36% Chardonnay, 32% Pinot Blanc and 32% Pinot Gris. Lime-pith and guava-peel flavors make for a briefly botanical twist to the palate before more tropical elements of mango emerge atop the chalky texture.

appellation: Friuli Colli Orientali, Northeastern Italy, Italy
review: Aromas of beeswax, elder flower and white orchard fruit emerge in the glass. On the lively palate, zesty acidity energizes creamy white peach, green pear and citrus while a mineral note backs up the tangy finish.

wine: Château de Bel-Air 2006  Lalande de Pomerol
review: A rich Merlot-driven wine, smoothly polished by new wood. Flavors of mint mingle with sweet tannins and black berry fruits. There is a fine, smoky edge as well to this wine, which would certainly benefit from 3–4 years' aging.

appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: Sliced green pears, honeysuckle, jasmine, cut limes and a touch of apple-flavored bubblegum show on the nose of this bottling. The texture is nicely cut with steely grip, releasing flavors of sour apple, ripe nectarine and honeydew.

wine: Horsepower 2015 The Tribe Vineyard Syrah (Walla Walla Valley (OR))
appellation: Walla Walla Valley (OR), Oregon Other, Oregon, US
review: The aromas are exultant in notes of fire pit, ham hock, green olive, mineral, peat, soot, sea breeze, steak tartare, coffee bean and potpourri. The palate is full of intensely rich yet still vibrant, savory flavors and an abundant peppery tone. The olive and fire-pit finish easily lingers for a minute, if not beyond.

wine: Albert Bichot 2003 Domaine du Pavillon Clos des Maréchaudes  (Corton)
designation: Domaine du Pavillon Clos des Maréchaudes
review: Part of the Les Maréchaudes vineyard is grand cru Corton, while the rest is simply premier cru—go figure. It just means terroir. This wine, from the grand cru portion, is dense and tannic, typical of the wine and the vineyard. There is great juicy fruit under the tannins. An ager. Imported by Eagle Eye Imports.

This blend of grapes from Monterey's Arroyo Seco and Santa Lucia Highlands appellations comes from the family behind Los Angeles' stalwart San Antonio Winery. It offers aromas of roasted apples, toasted oak and light vanilla. Barrel smoke pushes the palate, with charred peach and grilled nectarines, perfect for those who love their oak.

wine: La Follette 2014 Sangiacomo Vineyard Chardonnay (Sonoma Coast)
review: This is a bright and fully textured, creamy white wine, integrated and smooth in its approach, with highlights of apple, pear and piquant nutmeg. It shows a light yet full style, awaiting pairings at the table.

appellation: South Eastern Australia, Australia Other, Australia
review: A red berry-cherry jamball with rhubarb and herb accents. Lighter-styled, it has a slick mouthfeel, although tart, even sharp, acidity comes up on the back end. This easy drinker closes sweet yet tart, with a slight peppery tang. Best Buy.

Simple and delicious, this vibrant, mouthwatering red doles out fleshy black cherry, crushed blueberry, ground pepper and clove alongside polished tannins. An almond note graces the finish. This makes a fantastic everyday wine.

appellation: Hunter Valley, New South Wales, Australia
review: This wine displays plenty of weight and an unctuous texture alongside aromas and flavors of toasted nuts. There's also a strange herbal note, elements that are decidedly egg-like, and a long, honeyed finish. File it under “intriguing,” and drink it over the next several months.

Gamy and mildly concentrated, this Tempranillo from the Hill Country brings to mind pork fat and peppercorns on the nose. The soft palate brings more fruit, with juicy red berries giving lift to additional notes of game and spice.

wine: Beckmen 2018 Cuvee Le Bec Red (Santa Ynez Valley)
appellation: Santa Ynez Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: This blend of 45% Syrah, 39% Grenache, 9% Mourvèdre and 7% Counoise offers lush aromas of violet, lilac, lavender, vanilla and blueberry on the nose. The palate offers plenty of black currant and spice flavors, with sandy tannins and fresh acidity holding it all in check.

It's the Antão Vaz, the Chardonnay of Portugal, that gives this such class. It is full, tasty and complex, with acidity and superripeness, but still elegant white fruits. Additional richness comes from lees-stirring after fermentation, giving a fine depth of flavor.

wine: Saintsbury 2009 Cerise Vineyard Pinot Noir (Anderson Valley)
appellation: Anderson Valley, Mendocino County, California, US
review: A commanding Pinot Noir that wants a little time in the cellar. It combines power with finesse—the mark of a great wine. Dramatically packed with rich, ripe cherry, mocha and pie spice flavors, it's young and sappy now. Give it 5-6 years to knit together.
Complex, with plum, clove, oaky vanilla and grilled meat notes. Drinks very dry, with firm tannins. Shows real style in the overall balance and harmony.

From Costers del Segre, in northeastern Spain, this Cab spends 24 months in American oak. Once you sample it, that fact won't at all surprise you. Plum fruit on the nose and on the palate takes a back seat to the wood; oak is all you get on the finish.

This big, bold and ripe wine is packed both with tannins and concentrated, ripe fruits. It's smooth, opulent, with a burst of black berry flavors that are shaped by the firm structure. The wood aging shows as spice and smokiness, giving further richness to this powerful wine. Drink from 2018.

wine: Giant Steps 2011 Tarraford Vineyard Chardonnay (Yarra Valley)
review: Despite it's modest reported alcohol level, this is a plush, rounded example of Chardonnay, loaded with fruit. A whiff of woodsmoke frames pineapple and mango, adding complexity while still allowing the tropical notes to shine through. Drink now–2017.

Wild berry, dark spice, new leather and truffle aromas take center stage along with a whiff of violet. The linear medium-bodied palate is on the racy side, offering cranberry, star anise and crushed herb alongside tight, close-grained tannins and vibrant acidity. Drink 2019–2026.

Here's a fresh, easygoing and accessible white, with bright aromas and flavors of green plum, orange, peach and pineapple. The palate is light and breezy, with bright acidity that carries the mouthwatering finish.

wine: Trinchero 2011 Haystack Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Atlas Peak)
review: Black and thick, a study in smoky oak and tar, this intense vineyard-designated Cabernet will behave better over time. Brawny tannins surround substantial layers of blackberry and coffee, the feel on the palate weighty and voluptuous. Cellar through 2026.
White blossom and apple aromas open on this vibrant white while the racy palate shows Kaiser pear, tangerine and a hint of mineral. Zesty acidity gives it a clean, crisp finish.

wine: Claiborne & Churchill 2016 Greengate Ranch & Vineyard Pinot Noir (Edna Valley)
appellation: Edna Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: From a vineyard situated amongst ranchettes near the winery, this wine begins with extremely beautiful scents of black cherry, rosewater and sharp nose-tingling cola spice, proving juicy but elegant. The palate is full of brilliant flavors, from snappy black raspberry to more rounded strawberry sorbet, lifted by allspice, clove, vanilla and plenty of fresh acidity.

wine: Kastania 2008 Jaden & Keira's Cuvée Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)
review: There's plenty of ripe raspberry and cherry jam flavor on this wine, highlighted with interesting cola, beef jerky, vanilla and toast notes. Dry and silky on the palate, it's a pretty wine for drinking now.

appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
review: A very nice wine, lush and drinkable, that demonstrates not only the pedigree of its vineyards (Stolpman and Thompson), but also the deft approach of the winemaker. Soft and juicy, it offers layers of crushed cherry, cassis, red currant, licorice, beef jerky and black pepper flavors, wrapped into rich, fine tannins. Drink now through 2010.

wine: Angulo Innocenti 2017 Nonni Estate Grown Cabernet Sauvignon (La Consulta)
review: Earthy berry and plum aromas are a touch savory, like beef soup. This Cabernet Sauvignon feels dry and snappy but also moderately hefty. Spicy plum and berry flavors come with a bell pepper note, while this feels tight and dry on a finish that's spicy and peppery.

This Cab is in a somewhat awkward state now, poised between fresh blackberry and cherry fruit and mature notes of dried fruits and mushrooms. That tension lends it interest. The grapes come from Calistoga and Carneros, which also gives a dynamic play between lushness and acidity. It's a fine, stylish wine for drinking now–2017.

This lightly structured wine has perfumed, juicy red fruits and a more serious line of tannins. It is balanced and still fresh, but with a sense of maturity. The wine is a fine blend of Aragonez, Alfrocheiro and Alicante Bouschet. Drink now. The wine is suitable for vegans.

wine: The Four Graces 2013 Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)
appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: Part of the Foley Family portfolio, this wine reflects some of the challenges of the vintage. Somewhat bitter tannins overtake the fruit, putting the herbal characteristics front and center. Brambly berry and cranberry fruit carries some tartness through the finish.

wine: Concha y Toro 2011 Terrunyo Costa Los Boldos Vineyard Block 5 Sauvignon Blanc (Casablanca Valley)
designation: Terrunyo Costa Los Boldos Vineyard Block 5
review: This is about as racy as Sauvignon Blanc from Chile gets. It's green and melon-like on the nose, with punchy asparagus and lime aromas. It is wide awake on the palate, where citrusy acids push lemon, lime, green herb and lemongrass flavors. It cuts like a razor; drink with shellfish.

wine: Viña Requingua 2016 Toro de Piedra Gran Reserva Cabernet Sauvignon (Colchagua Valley)
review: Berry fruit and hand soap aromas are standard fare. This feels choppy and high in acid, while forced oak is a big part of a flavor profile that includes berry and plum fruits. A tight and rubbery finish is smacking and tastes oaky.

Deeply concentrated in tangy black cherry and berry, this wine is perfumed and approachable, ready to enjoy and priced fairly for its fine quality. Clove, tobacco and vanilla oak round out the lengthy finish.

wine: Graffigna 2008 Grand Reserve Cabernet Sauvignon (San Juan)
review: Every kind of pepper, from green to red to jalapeño, is present on the nose, along with red plum and spice aromas. Feels tight and zesty, with Italian-leaning flavors of tomato, oregano and basil along with cassis and strawberry. Crisp and agile on the finish, but tastes green.

An impressively mature 20-year old tawny, showing great layers of wood acidity, dark figs and well-integrated spirit. In the house style, it is not a big wine, more perfumed and delicate, and elegant.
This is a bright, citrus-laden wine, with a light texture that balances the tangy, nervy, minerally edge. This needs a few months to bring out the full fruit character.

This Cabernet is not providing much pleasure now. Bone dry and hard in tannins and acids, it's aloof to the point of unfriendly. But there are lots of blackberries packed inside. Give it at least 8 years in the cellar.

Rubber, bacon, berry and plum aromas are good overall. The palate is creamy as a whole but has enough acidity to carry cassis and berry flavors past being resiny and herbal. Basic on the finish, with mild oak flavor and resin coming into play.

Although this is a nonvintage wine, it is a blend around 2012, hence the number in the name. Dominated by Pinot Noir, this ripe, full-bodied wine has a tangy texture boosted by acidity that contrasts with rich red apple and crisp pear flavors that give richness. Drink now.

wine: Domaine des Bosquets 2018 Le Lieu Dit  (Gigondas)
review: Sourced from 60-year-old vines planted in sandy soil, this varietal Grenache offers gobsmacking ripeness alongside freshness. It's a big, richly extracted wine but the red-plum and cherry flavors are vibrant, lifted by minerality and pert, upright acidity. Silky tannins accentuate the rippling mouthfeel. Ready to drink now, the wine is solid enough to improve through 2030 and hold longer.

wine: De Loach 2004 OFS Chardonnay (Russian River Valley)
appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: This is a balanced, easy to drink Chardonnay, with citrus, peach and green apple flavors that have been finished with a veneer of smoky oak. It's totally dry. Do not overchill it, as it's a delicate wine that needs some warmth to open up.

wine: Tapeña 2007 Rosé (Vino de la Tierra de Castilla)
appellation: Vino de la Tierra de Castilla, Central Spain, Spain
review: Already in the twilight of its lifespan, this is a friendly rosé with a little wiggle and kick. The palate sits on ripe nectarine and pink grapefruit, while the finish offers pepper and spice. A little pithy but pretty good if you get at it soon.

wine: Kontokosta 2015 Rosé (North Fork of Long Island)
appellation: North Fork of Long Island, Long Island, New York, US
review: This blend of Syrah, Cabernet Franc and Cabernet Sauvignon offers up decadent juicy flavors of sun-kissed red cherries and watermelon. While dry in style, there's a slightly caramelized ripeness on the midpalate that balances out pertly against brisk grapefruit acidity. Enjoy now for its forward fruity exuberance.

A really good and clean white wine with all the tropicality and zest that this Argentine variety can give. The nose is crystalline and pure, with white flower scents of jasmine and citrus blossom, while the palate is round, melony and full of lychee and papaya. Smooth on the finish. Drink soon.

wine: Bouchard Aîné & Fils 2016 Clos du Roi Premier Cru  (Beaune)
review: This smoky wine offers juicy fruits, bitter red-cherry flavors and potential. Acidity is still very present, giving the wine potential to be serious and ageworthy. Drink from 2023.

wine: Castello di Cicognola 2012 Per Papà Nebbiolo (Provincia di Pavia)
review: Made entirely with Nebbiolo, this opens with aromas of tobacco, dark berry and tilled soil. The firm palate offers red-skinned berry, cooking spice and a touch of licorice alongside fine-grained tannins. Drink through 2023.
Creamy and textured, this has strong fruity flavors of lemon peel, lime and stone, the midpalate viscous and broad in its appeal. The finish offers a twist of hazelnut.

Blossomy notes of white flower and yellow apple mingle into anise and vanilla in this full-bodied white. Composed of Grenache Blanc, Roussanne and Clairette, it's plush and juicy, with a lingering mineral finish. Enjoy now–2024.
An elegant wine, it has both fine structure and dense red berry fruits. The ensemble is balanced, rich while not overpowering. Drink this wine from 2016.
A plump Chardonnay with its aromas and flavors of butter, toast and peaches. A long, citrusy finish caps it off.

Vibrant raspberry, blueberry and red cherry aromas leap from the glass of this elegant and refined Syrah, with faint hints of iris petals and thin mint for added depth. The palate is smooth and silky, with fine, well-integrated tannins and lively, saline-inflected freshness that keeps the palate lifted and the finish vibrant and enduring. Pepper and cola-like spice unfolds on the close.

appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Grenache makes up just under three-quarters of this wine, followed by 21% Mourvèdre and 5% Syrah. The aromas intrigue, with notes of raspberry, stem, tobacco, orange peel, flower and white pepper. Light, lithe cherry and raspberry flavors follow, with plentiful smoked meat accents throughout. It's all about elegance.

wine: Potek 2014 Blanc de Blanc Chardonnay (Sta. Rita Hills)
appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
review: Rounded, yeasty aromas of baking bread, sharp apple skins and the slightest hint of petrol show on the nose of this bubbly by Dave Potter. The bubbles are incredibly sharp and the tangy citrus flavors are refreshingly sour, with a dried apple touch rounding out the midpalate.

appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
review: Chard-like, with peach flavors, oak, a creamy texture and good acidity. It's a little broader than Chard, though, with a nutty herbaceousness that makes it earthy.
This dark-colored wine is textured and feels heavy, probably because of the apparent lack of acidity and peppery aftertaste.

appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
review: Very pale in the glass, this rosé pops with lovely aromas of lemon, pink lemonade and bubblegum on the crisp nose. There is tremendous grip to the palate, which unleashes a mix of peach and citrus-pith flavors.

Part of the same family business as Philippe Girard's wines (Benoît is his brother), this is a ripe, pure and clean wine. Perfumed acidity and zesty flavors are integrated into the rich green fruit. Apples and green plums dominate this refreshing wine that will develop. Drink from 2017.

This blend of 49% Grenache, 32% Shiraz and 19% Mataro is full and lush, loaded with brandied cherries and dressed up with touches of cinnamon and cedar. Hints of coffee and vanilla add an exotic tinge to the aromas, while the rich layers of fruit support the elevated (16%) alcohol.

Floral scents of violet and iris lead the nose on this informal red. The straightforward palate offers raw black cherry, cranberry and white pepper alongside firm, drying tannins that leave a raspy finish.

This is fresh and vibrant, with aromas and flavors of apple, melon and orange citrus. Medium weight, with a mouthwatering zip to the finish, pair this with grilled fish, chicken or summer salads. Drink now.

This blend of all five Bordeaux varieties hails from a smaller, high elevation appellation bridging Sonoma County and Napa Valley. It's jammy and spicy in red fruit, berry and cocoa flavors. Drink now.

wine: Ken Wright 2018 Bonnie Jean Vineyard Pinot Noir (Yamhill-Carlton)
review: This wine shows its complexity right off the bat, with mixed threads of rhubarb, lemon verbena, wild strawberry, sweet cherry, tarragon and a hint of wet hay. Subtle and sensual, it has the acidity to age over a decade or more and should develop fascinating aromas as well as deep flavors. Drink 2023–2032.

wine: Patricia Green Cellars 2017 Olenik Vineyard Anklebreaker Block Pinot Noir (Chehalem Mountains)
appellation: Chehalem Mountains, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: Gotta love the name, which the winery notes attribute to its “unusually rocky topsoil.” Spicy and sharp edged, it explodes with pungent cranberry and raspberry fruit. Then, with a little airing out, the flavors broaden across the midpalate, textural and bracing. The mineral-drenched finish lingers for a full minute or longer.

wine: Villa di Corlo NV Corleto  (Lambrusco Grasparossa di Castelvetro)
appellation: Lambrusco Grasparossa di Castelvetro, Central Italy, Italy
review: An alluring fragrance of blue flower and plum leads the nose of this wine while the smooth, vibrant palate delivers ripe blackberry and Marasca cherry flavors. Bright acidity provides the framework.

This wine is smooth, with a cream-chocolate texture that's rich and dense. Velvety tannins opulently balance with the superripe fruit. This is not a shy wine, everything is right out front. Drink from 2026.

wine: Fratelli Berlucchi 2014 Freccianera Rosa Brut Rosé  (Franciacorta)
review: Aromas of bread crust, wild berry and toasted nut waft out of the glass. The aromas carry over to the bright polished palate alongside pomegranate, sour cherry and citrus. Vibrant acidity and a refined perlage provide the backdrop.

Dry and super-crisp, this Sauvignon Blanc will get your tastebuds watering. The zesty acidity brightens flavors of limes, Meyer lemons, white pepper and vanilla. Great restaurant wine, with more than 100,000 cases produced.

Ripe, luminous wild strawberries and black cherry flavors explode from nose to finish in this hedonistic, intensely fruity blend of Grenache, Syrah, Mourvèdre and Cinsault. It's gorgeously primary in youth with a zesty mineral undertone, but is concentrated enough to improve, gaining earthier complexities through 2030 and likely further.

wine: Louis M. Martini 2000 Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
review: Earthy and herbal, with sage, dill and mushroom flavors, and a streak of red cherry that only partly relieves the austerity. The tannins are tough and gritty, and lead to a dry, puckery finish.

wine: Château de la Terrière 2009 Cuvée de la Lure  (Moulin-à-Vent)
