review: A smoothly ripe wine, with swathes of cherry and black currant fruits balanced by lively acidity. The wine, with its richness and the tannic structure, could well age for 3-4 years, although its fruitiness makes it delicious now.

wine: Patz & Hall 2015 Alder Springs Vineyard Pinot Noir (Mendocino County)
appellation: Mendocino County, Mendocino County, California, US
review: This wine, from a unique single-vineyard on steep slopes, has power along with complexity, combining aromas like sun-baked earth and dry leaves with layered cherry, tea and rhubarb flavors and a firm, nicely tannic texture. This will stand up to rich entrées very well, and should improve through at least 2021.

appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
review: Heady floral and spiced peach notes are enticingly aromatic on this well-priced wine. Off-dry in style, it's intensely concentrated on the palate with juicy, sweet stone fruit and lychee flavors. Sprightly lemon acidity drives a long, subtly spiced finish.

wine: Franz Hirtzberger 2003 Honivogl Smaragd Grüner Veltliner (Wachau)
review: Rich and full-bodied, with flamboyant aromas and flavors of honey, melon and spice that cascade across the palate in a powerful wave. Long and intense on the finish. Tastes great now, but with its impeccable balance and concentration it should age wonderfully, too. Imported by Vin Divino.

appellation: Templeton Gap District, Central Coast, California, US
review: A booming but expertly balanced wine, this blend of 54% Syrah, 18% Petite Sirah, 18% Zinfandel and 10% Grenache shows aromas of black currant, black olive, black cherry, sweet woody spice and powdered hot cocoa. Elegant mocha and cappuccino notes thrive on the palate, which is brightened by penetrating acidity. It boasts perfectly polished tannins and ripe fig flavors, with a flash of dark chocolate on the finish.

Floral cherry and plum aromas are inviting. This Carignan is fleshy and wide in body, with high acidity. Plum and berry flavors are clean and presentable, while this hits with a shock of acidity on the finish before quieting down.

wine: Gassier 2016 Elevae Rosé (Côtes de Provence Sainte-Victoire)
appellation: Côtes de Provence Sainte-Victoire, Provence, France
review: Aged for 24 months in wood, this is a new wine from this estate, only likely to be released in selected years. It offers a different view of Provence rosé, one that will need to accompany food. Wood aging has added a slight oxidation, making the wine rich and full bodied. Drink this fascinating wine now.
88-90 Barrel sample. An intensely spicy wine, full of exotic flavors, dried prunes, figs and a powerful layer of cinammon. The wine certainly has character.

A blend of Bordeaux-based grapes, Terra di Monteverro shows youthful aromas of cherry, blackberry and cassis, backed by savory layers of spice, leather and tobacco. This is rich, smooth and powerful, and it will age for 10 years or more.

A hint of juicy pineapple on the nose leads to a fruity palate that suggests tropical largesse as well as juicy yellow pear and plum. This generosity is corseted very softly by gentle citrus freshness. The overall impression is one of juicy drinkability and burgeoning fruit with a lovely lively grapefruit finish.

wine: Sierra Madre 2010 Block 210 Estate Chardonnay (Santa Maria Valley)
appellation: Santa Maria Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: Strong in oak and ripe fruit, this tastes overworked. It's dominated by buttered toast, butterscotch and pineapple jam flavors. It will satisfy legions of Chardonnay lovers who like this popular style.

This easy blend of Primitivo, Negroamaro and Cabernet Sauvignon opens with fruity aromas of dark berry and a whiff of tobacco. The palate offers dried plum, mature blackberry, a hint of clove and bitter almond alongside round tannins.

wine: Elena Walch 2013 Kastelaz Riserva Merlot (Alto Adige)
review: This 100% Merlot opens with delicate aromas of black currant, tilled earth and a whiff of vanilla. The ripe palate offers black-skinned berries, pipe tobacco and hints of toast alongside assertive tannins. Drink through 2020.

appellation: Umpqua Valley, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
review: The winery has staked its reputation on Tempranillo of all things, and consistently over a half dozen vintages it has surprised and delighted me with the results. Good color for this pale grape, and decent varietal character, though the estate bottling is clearly superior.
A lightly perfumed wine, this is soft with warm strawberry flavors. The acidity and texture play a supporting role in this ripe, light-bodied wine.
A clean, correct California Chardonnay, reliable as ever. Pear, peach and citrus flavors go down easily, buffered by graham crackery spice.

wine: François Lurton 2013 Les Fumées Blanches Sauvignon Blanc (Vin de France)
appellation: Vin de France, France Other, France
review: A fresh, herbaceous Sauvignon Blanc, mainly from the French south-west. It has a lively, crisp, totally fruity character with grapefruit, gooseberry and a more tropical fruit hint. Drink now.

Like a Sauvignon Blanc in its herbaceous character, this wine is all cut grass, damp hay and tight green fruits. That makes for an initial raw character, tempered by some hints of apricot. It seems to need a few more months to develop in the bottle.

appellation: Rattlesnake Hills, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: The aromas are quite subdued for the variety, with light notes of flower and spice. The palate is medium bodied, focused down the middle with stone fruit flavors that taper at the edges.

appellation: Red Hills, Lake County, California, US
review: This wine is concentrated, deep and tannic, yet nicely polished around the edges. It shows harmony between the vivid cranberry, black cherry, dark chocolate and smoky oak flavors and the layered, fine tannins that give it a velvety texture. Drink now through 2022.

wine: Scott Paul 2008 D122 Pinot Noir (Ribbon Ridge)
appellation: Ribbon Ridge, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: This D122 is a new addition to the Scott Paul lineup, a selection of four favorite barrels from the Ribbon Ridge vineyard. Don't let its pretty, pale cherry color fool you—this bright and lively young Pinot Noir is structured for the cellar. A mix of fresh cranberry, spicy plum and pie cherry fruit is supported by tart acids and firm, polished tannins. The lingering finish adds licorice and hints of bark. Note that this is sealed with a screwcap, and needs decanting.

Rooty and smoky smelling, with hickory, roasted berry, cherry and red currant aromas. The palate is smartly structured, with cassis, plum and other solid berry flavors. Finishes with composure and length; a likable wine for grilled meats.

In this wine, briny apple and citrus aromas are dusty and yeasty but also a bit stalky in a classic, cool-climate Basque way. A healthy palate lacks depth and complexity, while dry apple and green-melon flavors are salty. The finish is steady. Drink now.

Ripe black cherry, blackberry and black pepper sensations dominate this brooding blend of 86% Sangiovese and 14% Syrah. The spicy, dense palate is forward and warm accompanied by bracing tannins that carry through to the finish. It's shy on fresh acidity so best enjoy this soon.

wine: Davis Family 2008 Soul Patch Estate Grown Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)
appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: A good success for Davis Family, this Pinot is rich in flavor and elegant in structure. With a layering of toasted oak, it features ripe raspberries and cherries, with an earthy touch of herbs, mushrooms and spices. Drink now.

wine: Marqués de Gelida 2013 Gran Reserva Brut Sparkling (Cava)
review: Powdery white-fruit aromas are simple and suggestive of scented soap. This is round, but with pinching acidity. Orange and nectarine flavors finish with citric snap and then smooth length.

wine: La Selva 2013 Colli dell'Uccellina Riserva  (Morellino di Scansano)
review: Made with 85% Sangiovese and 15% Merlot, this has aromas of violet, black-skinned berry and a whiff of baking spice. The round, chewy palate offers ripe morello cherry, red currant, white pepper and a hint of game. Supple tannins and bright acidity give it an easy-drinking vibe.

wine: Domaine de Ménard 2013 Colombard-Sauvignon Blanc (Côtes de Gascogne)
appellation: Côtes de Gascogne, Southwest France, France
review: Intensely fruity, this delicious, ripe wine explodes with fresh acidity and fragrant fruitiness. Apricots, lemon and juicy apples give a fruit salad of flavors. Drink through 2015.
This is fruity, with some structure and pure acidity. It's fragrant and delicious now, bearing raspberry fruit and a light texture.

Nicely balanced, with medium weight, good acidity and tart black cherry flavors sporting dark chocolate accents. Yes, the funky earth, game and menthol oak bouquet will challenge some, but there's a good, tasty wine here. Closes dry with smooth, even tannins.

wine: Feudo di Santa Tresa 2018 Rina Ianca White (Sicilia)
review: Yellow stone fruit and fragrant spring flower aromas lead the nose. Made with organically grown grapes, the tangy palate offers white grapefruit, apricot and tangerine drop candy alongside bright acidity.

wine: Lágrimas de Maria 2017 Viura-Tempranillo Blanco White (Rioja)
review: This blend of Viura and Tempranillo Blanco offers a simple aroma of apple juice. The palate is low on acidity, with a flat tree-fruit flavor.

wine: Columbia Winery 1996 Sagemoor Vyd Cabernet Sauvignon (Columbia Valley (WA))
appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: An unusually dark, ripe Sagemoor, which seems to have benefited from the 1996 freeze that dramatically reduced crop levels. The nose has the intense, concentrated berry aroma of a good Zinfandel; there's just a bit of heat in the finish. Still young and tight, but silky smooth and ripe right through the stylish, tannic finish.
A mint- and spice-flavored wine, this has concentrated tannins that structure the black plum and berry fruits. The flavors are rich, and the dense texture promises several years of aging.

A $6 Chardonnay from California? Yes, but don't expect too much. There's some decent green apple and pear fruit, okay acidity, and it's clean as technology can make it. But it doesn't rise above the level of a country-style wine. They say it was partially barrel-fermented, but it's hard to detect any oak.

wine: Domaine de Pellehaut 2016 Harmonie de Gascogne White (Côtes de Gascogne)
appellation: Côtes de Gascogne, Southwest France, France
review: As with many wines from brothers Martin and Mathieu Béraut, this is a blend of many grapes. The combination produces a typical herbal grassy wine, full of tangy citrus fruit and with a touch of apricot from the Petit Manseng in the blend. Drink this now.

wine: Domaine Alfred 2007 Chamisal Vineyards Chardonnay (Edna Valley)
appellation: Edna Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: Sweet and simple in vanilla custard and buttered popcorn flavors, with a blast of pineapple jam. If you like fruity sweetness, it's for you.
Exhaling honey-vanilla in the glass, it gives off a hint of sweetness on the quick finish. Midpalate, expect fleshy apricot and white peach flavors. Enjoy on a summer's day with spicy peanuts.

appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: The regular DDO has plump, ripe fruit, bright and vivid, and the fresh, simple appeal of Beaujolais. What is missing is the midpalate, which falls off precipitously and never quite recovers.

wine: Mounts 2008 La Loma Zinfandel (Dry Creek Valley)
appellation: Dry Creek Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: Not quite ripe, with some green, vegetal flavors alongside the blackberries and black cherries. The lack of richness accentuates the hard tannins.

Cutting red cassis acidity and firm, finely grained tannins frame this full-bodied but vibrantly balanced red. A blend of Grenache, Mourvèdre and Syrah, it's a juicy, forwardly fruity sip packed with concentrated black cherry and plum flavors. Best enjoyed now–2023.
This wine is fruity and ripe with fresh red-berry fruits and layers of smoky tannins. Those tannins will open up to give a rich, juicy and spicy wine from 2018.

The nose doesn't give much away, yielding hints of dried flowers, lemon peel and crushed stone after time in the glass. The full-bodied palate is oily in texture, with latent acidity perking things up on the midpalate. For all that weight, it ends a bit short, but still shows a mix of body and fruit that many will enjoy.
91–93. Barrel sample. There's a dry character to this wine. It's concentrated in tannins with a bitterness that leads to a new-wood and spice character. The fruit is still in the background here.

wine: Dr. Loosen 2010 Erdener Treppchen Auslese Riesling (Mosel)
review: Lemon cream, spice and lanolin notes add a mysterious veil to this delicate yet intensely concentrated Riesling. It's sweet on the palate with ripe, honeyed citrus, and a delicious mineral oil sheen that lengthens the palate.

wine: Château Grand Boise 2016 Rosé (Côtes de Provence Sainte-Victoire)
appellation: Côtes de Provence Sainte-Victoire, Provence, France
review: Made from organic grapes, this estate wine from the high-altitude property is crisp and tightly fruity. It boasts great acidity and refreshingly bright red-currant fruitiness. This is ready now.

wine: Testarossa 2013 Garys' Vineyard Syrah (Santa Lucia Highlands)
appellation: Santa Lucia Highlands, Central Coast, California, US
review: This lithe and lively Syrah offers Indian spices of black cardamom and chai on the nose alongside boysenberry, elderberry and graphite aromas. The palate is heavy with Christmas spice of pine, juniper and black clove, with camphor and eucalyptus elements playing against the raspberry fruit backdrop.

wine: Barlow 2001 Red Table Wine Red (Napa Valley)
review: One for the cellar. It opens with a swift kick of dusty tannins that numb the palate to the sweet blackcurrant and cherry fruit buried far below. On the finish, tannins and oak dominate. But such is the overall balance, and the core of fruit, that putting it away for 10 years is no gamble at all. Cabernet Sauvignon (80%) and Merlot.

appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: Unlike most Oregon rosés, this is a blended wine, mixing five white grapes (principally Pinot Gris and Chardonnay) with a small addition (3%) of Pinot Noir, which provides a hint of color. Think dry pink wine, with mixed apple and pear fruit, and a dash of lemon and white pepper.

wine: Crosby Roamann 2016 Crosby's Reserve Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
review: Blended with 16% Merlot, this has expansive structure and concentration, with a pleasing opening note of mint. Sage, cedar and dried herb follow, accenting a thick midpalate of dark cherry and dark chocolate. This can stand more time in the bottle; enjoy 2026–2030.

wine: Reichsgraf von Kesselstatt 2014 Brauneberger Juffer-Sonnenuhr Spätlese Grosse Lage Riesling (Mosel)
review: A spray of rose petals perfumes this aromatic spätlese. Its freshness is exhilarating, contrasting lavish layers of honey and marmalade against the sharp bites of pineapple, tangerine and lemon. Cutting and spry, yet deeply penetrating, it finishes on a lingering pollen note.

A whole world of ideas assails the nose: coniferous forests, stone, ash and white pepper all tinge fresh blueberry and red cherry notes. On the palate, this is taut and tightly coiled. Fresh berries and cherries are still packed away beneath a layer of tart freshness, blinking through alluringly beneath the peppery spice. This is intriguing now but will open up like a flower with some bottle age. Its firm structure and innate freshness signal real ageing potential. Drink 2016–2026.

appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Tasted pre-release, this is clearly ready for prime time. It's both compact and generous, with a core of wild berries soaked in minerals. The words lucid and crystalline come to mind—rarely applied to a red wine, let alone Cab Franc.

A great value Cabernet that's earthy and direct, this has just enough flavors of red and black cherry and tobacco, with soft tannins that keep the wine interesting through the long, slightly spicy finish. There are handfuls of estate-grown Petit Verdot, Petite Sirah, Merlot and Malbec in the mix. Pair it with hamburgers.

wine: Simonnet-Febvre 2015 Côte de Lechet Premier Cru  (Chablis)
review: This normally cool Premier Cru has done particularly well in the 2015 vintage. This bottling is ripe and full of white fruit, while keeping a strong line of fine, tight acidity. It will be ready to drink soon, so only wait until 2018.
An appellation wine that impresses with its complexity, this offers earthy tones of bark, cinnamon and wild strawberry within a sultry sleek texture that's spicy and moderately structured.

wine: Benvenuto de la Serna 2014 Malbec (Uco Valley)
review: Challenging aromas of roasted beet, horseradish, herbal blackberry and animal hide lead to a meaty dense palate with rock-hard tannins. Flavors of black plum, blackberry and toasty oak are fiery, intense and carry over to a hot finish.

wine: Lynmar 2005 Vin Gris of Pinot Noir Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)
appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: Pretty expensive for a rosé, but it's a seriously good, crisp wine from a premier Pinot producer. It features elegant strawberry, rose petal, tea and dried herb flavors that change with every sip. A dash of Syrah seems to add body and richness.

This ripe, spicy wine is full of blackberry fruits, generous tannins and touches of wood. Its balance is coming together, promising a complex wine that will also have weight and some concentration. Drink from 2024.

wine: Imagine Moore 2009 Bliss Sauvignon Blanc (Finger Lakes)
appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
review: Grassy and green with tart gooseberries and hints of honeysuckle and pineapple on the nose and palate, this dry wine a little lacking in concentration but refreshing with zippy acidity.

This wine follows the “give the people what they want” formula to a T, and does it very well. It smells like blackberry jam and is moderate in size, with a core of plums and berries. Nut and toast nuances on the finish are the bow on the package. Imported by Aussie Imports.

appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: This widely available wine offers a reliably rich and expressive Cabernet experience. Aromas of blistered red cherry, wet slate, cocoa, pepper and oregano lead into a palate where coffee and black plum dominate.

wine: Benjamin de Rothschild & Vega Sicilia SA 2009 Macán Clásico  (Rioja)
winery: Benjamin de Rothschild & Vega Sicilia SA
review: Lightly baked and charred on the nose, this is a well-oaked wine showing blackberry, cassis and lemon peel aromas. A saturated, layered palate features loamy blackberry and cassis flavors offset by peppery spice and cocoa dust. Licorice and blackened oak revive a sense of char on a broad, full finish. Drink through 2022.

This exotic white starts with aromas of white flowers, lemon and mint, followed by fuller-bodied flavors of peach, apricot and flowers. Balanced with a viscous mouthfeel. The wine is well-suited for robust dishes—think lobster—but also adds depth to simple grilled fish.
90–92. Barrel Sample. This wine is crisp, herbal and full of green and citrus fruits. It is tangy and juicy at the end.

With attractive, juicy fruit, this wine has as much freshness as it does structure. The palate is warm and open with blackberry fruits that are rounded and soft. Spice and some tannins show through on the finish. Drink from 2017.

appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Black raspberry, plum, herb, tart, mesquite and cherry aromas are followed by lightly smoky flavors that seem out of place. It doesn't all come together.

appellation: Vermentino di Sardegna, Sicily & Sardinia, Italy
review: Smooth, rounded and delicious, this dry, tangy white opens with enticing scents of Mediterranean scrub, white stone fruit and a whiff of Spanish broom. On the bright, medium-bodied palate, fresh acidity accompanies ripe pear, apricot and saline before finishing on a note of bitter almond.

Saucy and spicy to the nose, with hints of chocolate, mocha and damp earth. Plum flavors and a smooth, moderately long finish keep this wine's head above water. Nonetheless, it's not real strong in the middle.

wine: Adegas Gran Vinum 2007 Esencia Diviña Albariño (Rías Baixas)
review: With each vintage this estate improves, but at the top of the Albariño price tier it should be at least this good. There are lemon, almond and creamy aromas preceding apple, pear and melon flavors. The finish is clean, a little dusty and shows a hint of cider. Intricate enough, with fine overall balance.

This wine offers jammy blueberry and lavender aromas that are tinged with brett. The palate brings high-octane flavors, supported by racy acidity that both demand more tannic structure and complexity in mouthfeel.

appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Superconcentrated, unctuous and lush, this mixes a note of lemon drop with a hint of ripe tropical fruit. On the palate, this shows terrific concentration, bearing hints of honey and lemon curd, with a crisp, lingering finish.

Invigorating lemon and sage aromas contrast plump pink grapefruit and guava on the palate of this delicately sweet Riesling. It's a rounded yet elegant wine, with soft, sunny acidity and a crystalline mineral finish. Drink now through 2019.

wine: Les Jamelles NV Méthode Traditionnelle Brut Chardonnay-Pinot Noir Sparkling Wine  (France)
designation: Méthode Traditionnelle Brut Chardonnay-Pinot Noir Sparkling Wine
review: Clean and fresh with lively citrus rind and red apple flesh aromas and flavors. It's not overdone and quite drinkable, with a soft toastiness that lingers through the finish. The texture is creamy and the swallow crisp.

A separate label produced by Paul O'Brien winery, this is a stunning value in an Oregon Pinot Noir. In total, 20% of the fruit was sourced from the Willamette Valley, and all was barrel aged for a year in 15% new French oak. The pleasing toasty scents speak of a far pricier wine, and follow up with graceful, immaculate strawberry fruit. It's balanced out against proportionate acids and tannins, and is truly delicious for near term enjoyment.

wine: Tower 15 2018 Star Lane Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Happy Canyon of Santa Barbara)
appellation: Happy Canyon of Santa Barbara, Central Coast, California, US
review: Dark cocoa and elegant wood spice frame the smashed and grilled black-plum aromas on the nose of this bottling. Cedar flavors envelop the sip, where rounded berry and light herb flavors also arise.

appellation: Montepulciano d'Abruzzo Colline Teramane, Central Italy, Italy
review: There's enviable concentration on the nose of this wine, delivering plumes of dark cherry, plum, salt and tobacco. There's power and verve to the thick-skinned berry fruit on the medium-bodied palate, built up by a sturdy frame of tannins and pushed along by a refreshing vein of acidity.

wine: Dutton-Goldfield 2014 Devil's Gulch Vineyard Pinot Noir (Marin County)
appellation: Marin County, North Coast, California, US
review: Dense and concentrated, this wine is ultra smooth in texture, offering an abundance of red and black cherry, dark plum and baking spice aromas. One of the few Pinots grown in Marin County, it has great depth and a memorable flavor profile that lingers long into the finish.

Light in color and aromas. The nose is mostly dried red fruit and spice. The palate is tart yet precise; it's not sour but it's very peppy, with bright acids and plenty of red fruit in the raspberry or pie-cherry vein. A light, airy finish with a modicum of creaminess closes the package.

95–97. Barrel Sample. Now certified biodynamic, this estate is on a roll. This vintage is very fine, rich and well structured. The dry core is contrasted by black fruit flavors. It is going to be generous and concentrated; there is long-term aging potential here.

wine: Toad Hollow 2008 Goldie's Vineyard Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)
appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: The price is right, but the underlying wine is thin in fruit, offering only modest raspberry flavors. Oak has been plastered on rather heavily, perhaps to mask the basic blandness.
Very dark and young now—this wine needs to be cellared. It's powerfully tannic, with a burst of acidity; the mouthfeel is dusty and astringent. Has enough fruit to last beyond 2008.

wine: Marc Kreydenweiss 2004 La Dame Wiebelsberg Grand Cru Riesling (Alsace)
review: This is a serious selection for those who love a little more weight. Chock full of honey, sweet spice and butterscotch, you know what you're getting into from the first whiff. The palate only further complements the nose with the flavor of ripe, red apples elevating the sweeter aromas. Full- bodied and rich with a long, spicy finish.

Rich, open-knit plum and preserved-cherry flavors are shaded by hints of earth, ore and violet in this ripe, creamy Syrah. Aged 15 months in barriques (70% new and 30% one-year-old oak), it's a decadent, oakier expression of Crozes-Hermitage than most but elegantly composed. Best now–2025.

appellation: Edna Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: Bright and fresh aromas of white peach, lightly tropical mango and a kiss of oak make for a compelling entry to this bottling. There is fresh zest to the palate, which offers ripe flavors of pear and apple flesh on a lighter frame.

Dry, woodsy tannins rein in juicy red and black plum fruit on the palate; a wine with both solid fruit and a sense of restraint as this has is a good bet for a meal (and if I were cooking, that meal would be enchiladas). A very good wine that, had it more to the finish, could have been an excellent one. At this price, though, it's a minor complaint.

appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
review: Super-fruity in peaches, citrus and apricots, with a creamy mouthfeel and brisk acidity, this is a fun wine with some real complexity. It's technically dry, but rich in fruity ripeness.

wine: Marc Kreydenweiss 2004 Clos du Val d'Eléon White (Alsace)
review: A 50-50 blend of Pinot Gris and Riesling, this is a large-scale wine with aromas and flavors of nuts, anise and baked apples—maybe even a hint of butterscotch. Yet for all that sweet-sounding stuff, there's nothing soft about the hard, stony finish. A tough wine to really come to grips with.

wine: Edgewood 2000 Estate Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
review: This wine has a good, dark color, rich aromas of currants and toasty oak, blackberry flavors and fine, dry tannins. It merits a high score because of all these qualities, and yet it would score higher except for a certain absence of depth of flavor. Defines the deficiencies of this vintage.

wine: Maximin Grünhäuser 2003 Herrenberg Riesling Spätlese Riesling (Mosel-Saar-Ruwer)
review: Wonderfully blends apple, pear and peach flavors, picking up mixed citrus fruits on the finish. Yet there's also a deep undercurrent of earth and mineral that provides a strong backbone. It's plump and concentrated on the palate, yet light on its feet. Great spätlese.

wine: Adobe Road 2006 Bavarian Lion Vineyard Petite Sirah (Knights Valley)
review: Too ripe, with a raisiny edge to the currants and blackberries. Hot, too, with 15.5% of alcohol. It's the poster child for what can go wrong with red wines in California.
A wine with overly pronounced smoky, oaky and toasted bacon aromas and flavors that block out most of the lush dark fruit so wanting in a Tempranillo; more tobacco than black cherry or plum.

From benchland vineyards, the winemaker's perennial beauty of a wine is structured, evolved, graceful and complex, with powerful floral aromatics of rose and violet. Earthy and herbal, it tastes of rock and iron, with bright underlying invitations of cassis, tangy cherry and plum. This will do well in the cellar; enjoy best from 2027 through 2030.

The nose gives little away apart from a hint of green-pear peel. The palate is equally subdued, giving clean but almost neutral and slightly dilute notes of green pear. This is very fresh but provides little apart from some lemon and gentle pear fruit. Drink soon.

Leafy raspberry aromas are offset by cured-meat notes of sausage or ballpark hot dogs. This has a creamy yet flabby mouthfeel with barely detectable acidity. Baked cherry and raspberry flavors show touches of cinnamon and chocolate, while the finish is dull.

wine: Ancient Peaks 2012 Margarita Vineyard Petit Verdot (Paso Robles)
appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: Aromas of pure black fruit, slightly burned toast, concentrated plum, black cherries and a touch of espresso show on this study of a rarely standalone grape. The palate is firm with chewy tannins yet approachable in flavors, offering dried elderberries, coffee beans, burned caramel flavors.

Regolo is a pure expression of Corvina, a grape native to northern Italy, that opens with bright aromas of white cherry and cranberry, followed by a crisp mouthfeel and medium build. There's a subtle touch of sour berry on the close.

wine: Les Vignerons Réunis de Monségur 2012 La Tour du Gouverneur  (Bordeaux)
review: The 15th-century tower of the governor of Monségur gives its name to this wine from the local cooperative. It's a solid wine that has firm tannins along with jammy plum fruits and a ripe character. Blackberries dominate allowing some room, maybe not enough, for the acidity at the end. Drink now.

wine: Lindemans 2005 Bin 80 Cabernet Sauvignon-Merlot (South Eastern Australia)
appellation: South Eastern Australia, Australia Other, Australia
review: Simple and grapy, with touches of confected fruit and just a hint of chocolate on the slightly angular finish.

appellation: Livermore Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: Oak and lees give rich, yeasty, butterscotchy complexities, and a creamy texture, to this fine young Chardonnay. Fortunately, the underlying varietal flavors are strong in pineapple, apple, honeydew and papaya. Only 500 cases were produced.

wine: Branchini 2006 D'Or Luce Sillaro  (Albana di Romagna)
appellation: Albana di Romagna, Central Italy, Italy
review: Honey, roasted chestnut, dried apricot, lychee syrup and passion fruit shape a beautiful sweet botrytis wine that would pair with desserts or aged cheeses. It is seamless and elegant in the mouth and offers accents of orange zest and marzipan.

wine: Caves Velhas 2013 Cabeça de Toiro Reserva Red (Tejo)
review: A blend of 50/50 Touriga Nacional an Castelão, this is a firm, structured wine. It has plenty of ripe blackberry fruits that are beginning to fill out and mature. It has a juicy character: ripe and full of sun. Drink now, although the wine will be better from 2017.

This 100% Sangiovese has sharp berry, leather and chocolate aromas, raspberry and strawberry flavors, and a lean, oaky yet fresh finish. Modest tannins work to spread the wine out, and the fruit, while thin and fading, seems ripe and not green.

wine: Vecchia Cantina di Montepulciano 2009  Vino Nobile di Montepulciano
appellation: Vino Nobile di Montepulciano, Tuscany, Italy
review: There's a sweet note of bright cherry or blueberry that opens the nose of this food-friendly Vino Nobile. Medium structure and bright acidity makes this a great choice to pair with lasagna or cheesy pasta.

Faded black cherry in the glass, this wine offers an aroma of pomegranate and brambles. Flavors of tart cranberry, green pepper and eucalyptus are pleasant enough, but this wine is a bit past its prime.

appellation: Central Coast, Central Coast, California, US
review: Concentrated and ripe aromas of cherry and blackberry are enhanced by a pinch of dried herbs on the nose of this bottling. The palate is very extracted and ripe, with balsamic- laced red-fruit flavors and a hint of gamy meat.

wine: Eight Bells 2014 Red Willow Vineyard Sangiovese (Yakima Valley)
appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: The aromas of cherry, herb and raspberry are light but show a pleasing sense of purity. The palate is tart and elegant, with the oak dialed way back and the bright acidity pulling together the finish. Pair it with food to see it at its best.

appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Here is a tart and tangy take on Sangiovese, true to its Italian roots, but incorporating the sharp, vivacious fruit of Washington state. Red apple and plum, lightly dusted with chocolate and showing a trace of earthy barnyard, makes this one of the more interesting and complex versions of this grape to come out of the Columbia Valley.

Aromas of apricot and rose petal prepare the palate for flavors of peach and grapefruit, with a hint of sage. Refreshing acidity on the palate and a splash of pineapple on the finish make this lively and bright.

wine: Domaine Royal de Jarras 2020 Pink Flamingo Gris de Gris Rosé (Sable de Camargue)
review: Hints of guava and kiwi unfold on the nose and dance right through to the light and breezy palate of this easy-drinking rosé. Ample acidity keeps the mouthfeel fresh and the finish crisp. Drink now.

A very deep red color catches the attention. Next, strong, wild aromas like smoke and black rubber lead to a rather fruity but still firm and tannic texture. The flavors are more like blackberries and blueberries, but the overall effect is slightly viscous.
This is a soft wine, with warm red-berry fruits and light acidity. The texture is gentle, rounded and just cut by fresher red-currant flavors. Drink this bright wine now.
A blend of Sangiovese and 10% Merlot, this has aromas of dark-skinned fruit, tilled earth and cooking spice. The easygoing palate offers black plum, sage and star anise alongside pliant tannins.

wine: Fritz Haag 2016 Brauneberger Juffer Feinherb Riesling (Mosel)
review: Intensely dusty, smoky mineral tones introduce this just-off-dry Riesling. It's a bracing, invigorating sip, offering layers of fresh lemon and lime flavors accented by salt and just a glimmer of tannins on the finish. A complex, thirst-quenching wine to enjoy now–2025.

wine: SignoSeis 2014 The Angel Oak Rosé (Uco Valley)
review: This is tan in color, with a flat, murky nose of stone-fruit aromas and chemical harshness. A round, oily textured palate tastes of briny nectarine and pithy bitterness. In many ways, this is like sucking on a peach pit.

appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: It's a big, thick wine with hefty tannins and acidity; very dry and rather austere. It's not likely to improve in the bottle like a big Cabernet, but with the right foods--braised ribs--it could be just the right thing.

wine: The Eyrie Vineyards 2013 Daphne Estate Pinot Noir (Dundee Hills)
appellation: Dundee Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: This selection from a 40-year-old vineyard manages to convey both power and complexity in a transparent, nearly ephemeral style. Like gazing into a clear pool of deep water, you plunge through a surface patina of ripe, crushed raspberries into a textural, evanescent palate framed in dark chocolate. Drink now through 2030 and beyond.

wine: Carhartt Vineyard 2012 Fourplay Red (Santa Ynez Valley)
appellation: Santa Ynez Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: Warm berry-rhubarb pie notes mix with black pepper and an appealing, shy layer of green bell pepper on this blend of 50% Merlot, 28% Cabernet Sauvignon, 20% Cabernet Franc and 2% Petit Verdot from three vineyards. Stewed plums, cherries and strawberries dominate the tasty palate, with a proper acidity and woody bitterness as balance.

wine: Thibert Père et Fils 2008 Vignes Blanches  (Pouilly-Fuissé)
review: On the fresh side, with crisp bright, lively acidity. Green fruits run well alongside apricot juice and lively vivacity. Good and attractive.

Clean lines of bubblegum, strawberry and banana blossom show on the nose of this rosé, which includes 62% Grenache, 12% Mourvèdre, 11% Cinsault, 9% Carignan and 6% Rolle (or Vermentino). Those fruit elements coalesce on the palate, which is crisp and chalky though full of flavor.

wine: Byron Blatty 2017 Proprietary Red (Los Angeles County)
appellation: Los Angeles County, South Coast, California, US
review: Roasted black-plum and boysenberry aromas meet with cola spice on the smoky nose of his bottling. Rich, lush tannins frame flavors of blackberry sauce, butterscotch and fudge on the palate, where acidity keeps the ripeness in check.

wine: Enrico Serafino 2018 del Comune di Gavi Grifo del Quartaro  (Gavi)
designation: del Comune di Gavi Grifo del Quartaro
review: A few swirls of the glass eventually release subtle aromas of spring blossom and Bartlett pear. Crisp and tangy, the refreshing palate offers honeydew and Meyer lemon set against racy acidity.

Shows real Gewürz character in the ripe peach, apricot, pineapple and vanilla flavors and blast of cinnamon-nutmeg spice. High acidity balances the sweetness, making the wine pleasantly clean and refreshing. Very nice as a pre-dinner drink, or with Asian food.

wine: Château La Nerthe 2014 Les Granières de la Nerthe Red (Châteauneuf-du-Pape)
review: For what is essentially a second wine, generally blended from the estate's younger vines, this is a solid effort in a not-so-easy vintage. Vanilla and cinnamon from barrel-aging play a role hedre, but there's also plenty of juicy, plum-tinged fruit. There's ample body and texture, capped off by supple tannins and a lingering finish. Drink now–2022.

wine: Archery Summit 2012 Archer's Edge Estate Pinot Noir (Dundee Hills)
appellation: Dundee Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: The vineyard is one of the youngest at the winery, and the flavors reflect that, with bright, fruity, forward raspberry notes. It's lightly spiked with sweet baking spices, and makes a perfectly delicious choice while waiting for some of the winery's bigger, bolder 2012s to age a bit further.
This wine is soft, indistinct at this stage. It needs to develop more of the fruitiness that is behind the bland exterior. The aftertaste has good freshness.

wine: Nickel & Nickel 2010 John C. Sullenger Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Oakville)
review: A glorious wine, rich, ripe and delicious. It's dry, but lush in blackberries and cherries, tobacco and cola, with the Nickel & Nickel signature of new and one-year-old oak. Very tannic, this is clearly a wine that needs time. Should begin to come into its own after 2018.

appellation: Dunnigan Hills, Central Valley, California, US
review: An easy-sipping white wine, with semisweet fruit flavors and soft acids. Finishes clean and honeyed.
Terrale Oro is a simple, somewhat watered down expression of Nero d'Avola that would pair well with easy pasta dishes or take out pizza. Cherry, blueberry and almond flavors characterize the palate.

Robert and Michel Perroud have teamed up to make wines in Brouilly apart from Robert's own vines. This wine is full of the juicy fruit for which the appellation is best known. Textures are soft and tannins are gentle. Drink from late 2020.

appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: This aromatic wine sends out sweet scents of mint and clover, with fresh green apple and pear flavors following. There is generous acidity to compensate for the residual sugar. Though clearly off dry, it's built to work well with a variety of spicy vegetarian dishes.

Concentrated and rich in flavor and creamy in texture, this wine has a big profile without seeming overtly fruity or oaky. The mouthfeel is lush, broad and quietly powerful, while subtle pear and marzipan flavors coat the palate and linger on the finish. It makes a grand impression and is “meaty” enough to serve with poultry or even beef. Winemaker Tracy Hart used no oak or stainless steel, fermenting and aging the wine in food-grade polyethylene FlexTanks.

Wild berry, fragrant purple flower, new leather and cake-spice aromas come together to create a classic Sangiovese bouquet. On the firm full-bodied palate, white pepper, clove and tobacco accent a juicy black-cherry and raspberry core. Tightly knit polished tannins and fresh acidity provide an age-worthy structure. Drink 2021–2038.

wine: San Pedro 2007 Kankana del Elqui Syrah (Elqui Valley)
review: Sweet and a bit choppy on the nose, with aromas of wood shavings, mocha, fine herbs and spicy black fruits. Flush, lusty and big across the palate, but juicy and clean, with subtle bush berry and spice flavors. Finishes clean and subtle, with floral accents and a touch of heat. Drink now through 2013.

wine: Blackburn Wine Company 2017 Cabernet Sauvignon (Paso Robles)
appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: This is a great choice for an everyday drinker, starting with aromas of clean red cherry, light oregano, a hint of wet slate and a touch of sea salt on the nose. Powdery tannins frame the sip, where slightly sour cherry and more herbs shine through.

wine: Cantina Produttori San Michele Appiano 2010 Sanct Valentin Chardonnay (Alto Adige)
review: Here's an opulent Chardonnay from the far north of Italy that opens with a thick, creamy bouquet of caramel, apricot and honey. Dry mineral notes and crisp acidity balance out those ripe fruit flavors.

From one of the best sites in Barolo, this intense wine opens with a multi-dimensional fragrance of crushed flower, new leather, earth, incense, spice and black cherry. The vibrant, spicy palate delivers red berry accented with notes of black pepper, cinnamon spice, licorice and clove. Bold but noble tannins and brisk acidity promise fantastic aging potential. Drink 2020–2050. Acid Inc Selections, Stefano Miretti Imports.

A strong toasty streak lines the essence of this beautiful Chenin Blanc, adding character to the apple and pear fruit core. The mouthfeel is full and rich without being overdone thanks to the balanced acidity, while nuances of sweet spice, pie crust and wood-grilled Red Delicious all linger well into the long finish.

wine: Eden Road 2015 The Long Road Chardonnay (Tumbarumba)
review: Despite there being a few months less of oak aging on this vintage than the 2016, the oak is more apparent in this wine. This style of Chardy isn't for everyone, but those who do like oaked Chards will appreciate the buttery, toasted nut, pressed yellow-flower and stalk characters on this linear lemony wine.

Smells fairly burnt and dull, with earthy, stemmy aromas that are strained and tough. The palate reflects the nose with heavy, roasted, leathery plum flavors that finish with a meaty thud. Rustic and stemmy, with a low pulse.

wine: Trisaetum 2013 Ribbon Ridge Estate Pinot Noir (Ribbon Ridge)
appellation: Ribbon Ridge, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: This is the vineyard that surrounds the winery on Ribbon Ridge, and it seems always to produce the wines with the greatest concentration and density. The black cherry fruit, with aromatic accents of rose petals and highlights of oregano, digs deep into the midpalate, creating an impression of a bulky, tight, compact wine with miles yet to go. Cellar it for drinking from 2020 through 2030.

wine: Peter Nicolay 2005 Ürziger Würzgarten Spätlese Riesling (Mosel-Saar-Ruwer)
Domaine G. Metz 2016 Melody Pinot Gris (Alsace)
review: Fresh notes of ripe red apple and juicy pear rise from the glass and also swish freely across the palate. The body is slender, pervaded by a friendly invigorating zestiness that stays right through the dry finish.

wine: Marqués de la Concordia 2012 MM Reserva de la Familia Brut Rosé Sparkling (Cava)
designation: MM Reserva de la Familia Brut Rosé
review: This round yet direct Cava offers stone-fruit aromas that are upright and clean. Simple citrus and nectarine flavors hold steady on the finish.
Smells of honey and lychee fruit, but without the bold exuberance of Gewürztraminer. Pear flavors the midpalate, then turns citrusy on the finish.

wine: Saviah 2018 Une Vallée Red (Walla Walla Valley (WA))
appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: This is 69% Cabernet Sauvignon, 20% Merlot and 11% Cabernet Franc. With fruit coming from McClellan, Pepper Bridge, Anna Marie and Eritage vineyards, the aromas bring notes of plum, blue fruit, earth, dried and fresh herbs and flowers. Soft, lighter-styled coffee, cherry and chocolate flavors follow. It's all about grace.

wine: Davis Bynum 2014 Jane's Vineyard Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)
appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: This wine opens with the fresh liveliness of stemmy earth and black tea notes, growing funkier and more herbal on the midpalate. Brightly layered and deeply flavored, it's a full-bodied rendition that remains true to its variety.

Six months of aging in Slavonian oak has imparted a delicate cedary sheen to the juicy black-cherry flavors.  Balancing acidity prevents it from being just another fruit bomb, and it develops some intriguing leather notes with air.  Made of 90% Nero d'Avola, with 10% other mixed indigenous varieties, and from a small (five hectare) estate, this is just one example of why Sicily is a hotbed for bargain hunters.  Modern technology and careful viticulture combined with hot sunny weather and unique grapes are yielding great wines at great prices.
Perfumed notions of green pear lie within a supple, rounded body. The zesty acidity is welcome but not dominating and the core of fruit is firm and inviting.

wine: Jeff Cohn 2016 Zio Tony Ranch Syrah (Russian River Valley)
appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: From a relatively cool-climate site, this wine is dark and inky with fistfuls of earthy forest floor, grilled meat and wild game. Sanguine, it tastes of iron and dried herb, grippy with undeniable underlying brightness and beautiful shocks of white pepper.
This is tartly sweet and jammy, like a cherry and roasted almond candy bar with a chocolate coating. Tasty, but a little one dimensional.

wine: Land of Promise 2016 E Pluribus Unum Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)
review: Light, high-toned and persistently fresh, this is an exotic red wine from Terra de Promissio, shiny and bright in rhubarb, wild strawberry and orange peel. Balanced and well integrated, it brims in Asian spice and herb de Provence.

Fully charred, with a lot of leather and campfire to the nose. More dark and obscure than forward and fruity, with heavy plum flavors and a shot of pepper on the tail end. Smoky and brooding throughout. Imported by Opici Import Company.

A beautiful Dolcetto, defining the state-of-the-art for this grape. Black cherry, violets, roses, and vanilla mark the lovely nose. Robust flavors of cherry, chocolate, and licorice mark the palate. The feel is plush and round, but still substantial, with an admirable seamlessness.
This 100% Syrah has a watermelon-pink color, and it tastes like watermelon, too, with a squeeze of strawberry daiquiri. It finishes with a hint of sweetness.

wine: Villa Mt. Eden 1999 Bien Nacido Vyd Signature Chardonnay (Santa Maria Valley)
appellation: Santa Maria Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: A real crowd-pleaser, this wine has big, bold aromas of citrus fruits, apples and peaches, with a streak of smoky oak and complications from sur lies aging.  It drinks very rich and fine.  Citrus flavors dominate, with a flinty element, and high acidity suggests midterm aging.
This pretty, stylish wine is elegantly silky in the mouth, with hardly any tannins at all, although the acids are fine. Flavors are on the jammy side, with raspberry, tea, cola and spice.

appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Malbec, Cabernet Sauvignon, Sangiovese, Merlot and Syrah make up this wine. Lighter in color, the aromas suggest fresh raspberry, berry and currant. The palate shows an elegant styling, with citrus notes on the finish. There are good things going on but the concentration seems light.

wine: Chateau St. Jean 1997 Durell Vineyard Pinot Noir (Carneros)
review: A full nose of deep and spicy black-cherry, clove, smoke, bacon, and cinnamon aromas open this solidly built wine. Lots of dark fruit, red apples, spice, and even chocolate nuances. Large almost licorice-tinged finish. Very tasty now and should improve.
A dry, rather dark, textured wine, that shows some green pepper character. Not up to the normal standard from Fieuzal.
There's nice harmony here and balance between ripe fruit, cola and spice. The wine is well concentrated and slightly sweet. Pair it with ossobuco or lamb shanks.

appellation: Red Mountain, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: The aromas offer notes of dried and macerated cranberry, raspberry and fruit leather, seeming a bit advanced. Full-bodied, jammy fruit flavors follow, with a nice lick of acidity pulling it all together.

wine: Château La Croix de Queynac 2017  Bordeaux Blanc
review: This perfumed wine from the Fronsac's Gabard family is well balanced, with a warmth that is immediately enticing. The spice and ripe lychee flavors give it richness as well as adding complexity. Drink this well-structured, lightly mineral wine now.

A huge wine, full of soft fruit. The layers of tannins sit gently on the plum and cassis fruits, lifted by acidity. If it wasn't 15.5%, this would be impressive, but the high alcohol makes the wine very Port-like, giving an extra layer of pepper from the alcohol.

wine: Château Haut Prieur 2013  Blaye Côtes de Bordeaux
appellation: Blaye Côtes de Bordeaux, Bordeaux, France
review: This wine is tough, extracted and still very bitter. The fruit is there, well behind the tannic front in this Merlot/Malbec blend. Give the wine until 2017 and decant although it is likely to remain tough. A Châteaux Solidaires wine.

An enticing, heavy-duty blend of 40% Viognier, 40% Petit Manseng and 20% Roussanne, this is rich, round and unctuous, with bold notes of golden stone fruit, orange Creamsicle, lemon tartlet and caramelized nut. The acidity is soft across the midpalate, but it brightens on the warm, medium-length finish. To appreciate the full spectrum of aromas and flavors, don't drink this too cold.

wine: Seven of Hearts 2010 Chatte d'Avignon G-S-M (Columbia Valley (WA))
appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Quite light and a bit diffuse, this southern Rhone-style red has a pretty rose petal accent, along with berry and balsamic flavors.

Pleasing aromas of guava, watermelon rind and a hint of lemon zest set the stage for flavors of Cavaillon melon, peach, marzipan and orange rind. Smooth in the mouth, this wine features a nice interplay of bright and savory notes. A cool finish washes across the side palate, punctuated by a burst of acidity.

wine: Refugio Ranch 2015 Tiradora Sauvignon Blanc (Santa Ynez Valley)
appellation: Santa Ynez Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: This bottling, which includes 20% Sémillon, offers aromas of cut grass, sliced Anjou pear and a lemon-lime freshness on the nose. Sour Granny Smith apple and green lime rinds rule the palate, making for a solid and classic style of Sauv Blanc.

wine: Parras Wines 2019 Casa das Gaeiras Branco White (Obidos)
review: All about the bright fruit and freshly sliced apples, this attractive blend of Arinto, Chardonnay and Fernão Pires is lifted, crisp, still young. It has vibrant acidity and refreshing aftertaste, totally ready to drink.

appellation: Isonzo del Friuli, Northeastern Italy, Italy
review: Soft and penetrating with rich notes of black cherry, spice and tobacco, this is a standout Merlot from Northern Italy. The wine is lively and intense and reveals itself layer after luscious layer. Pair it with meats or oven-roasted pasta.

wine: MacPhail 2012 Mardikian Estate Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)
review: This is the first release of this new vineyard site for the producer, from a cool property planted by the producer with the help of local grower Jim Pratt, who also supplies Pinot Noir under the Pratt Vineyard name. Still working things out, the wine is earthy and intense, a tightly wound expression of tart cherry and pomegranate, with layers of intriguing clove and dried herbs.

wine: Saint-Hilaire 2011 Brut Estate Bottled Sparkling (Blanquette de Limoux)
review: This is a crisp and inviting sparkling wine, with bright notes of citrus and apple that are accented by hints of toast. An approachable and wallet-friendly quaff, perfect for holiday entertaining.

wine: Fritz Haag 2017 Brauneberg Juffer Sonnenuhr Trocken GG Riesling (Mosel)
review: Orange-blossom, tangerine and white-melon notes extend from nose to palate in this effusively fresh dry Riesling. It's medium bodied and silky in texture, bursting with zesty citrus flavors and subtle skeins of honey and candle wax. Enjoyable now for its exuberant  style, it should develop greater complexities through 2030.

wine: Concentric Wine Project 2018 Gamay Noir (Columbia Valley (WA))
appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Examples of this variety are a rarity in the state, with this one made in a Beaujolais Nouveau style—100% whole cluster and all carbonic maceration before aging in neutral oak. The aromas intrigue, with notes of cigar box, tobacco, herb, strawberry and flower, showing clear stem influence. Light, vibrant and pure red-fruit flavors follow. It shows a sense of focus that enchants. Best with a slight chill.

Aromas of scorched earth, underbrush, new leather and grilled herb align with a balsamic whiff of eucalyptus. The tightly packed palate delivers dried black cherry, raspberry jam, cinnamon and tobacco. Fine-grained tannins provide the framework. Drink after 2022.

wine: Poggio il Castellare 2016  Brunello di Montalcino
review: Aromas of cedar, baking spice and menthol form the subdued nose. The chewy, no-frills palate offers ripe black plum, coconut and sage alongside dusty tannins. Drink 2022–2028.

Packaged in an attractive sunflower-adorned screwcap bottle, this Chardonnay made from organic grapes is light, bright and straightforward—tasting of lemon, lime and kiwi—with barely any oak influence.

Almost neutral aromas of cantaloupe and nectarine are dusty on the nose. This Carmenère-based dry rosé is citric, juicy and tight on the palate, with grapefruit and other citrus flavors adding life. Orange and citrus pith notes control the finish.

wine: Penfolds 2002 Koonunga Hill Chardonnay (South Eastern Australia)
appellation: South Eastern Australia, Australia Other, Australia
review: Good for casual circumstances, this is a simple oak-and-yellow fruit Chard, with stone fruit and smoke on the nose, and oaky, malty flavors on the finish.

This is a wood-aged Touriga Nacional that is smooth and rich. It shows some extraction offering dark chocolate flavors that cover the fruit, yet happen to provide a ripe, rounded feel. Drink from 2017.

Inspired by the Bordeaux tradition and made from a blend of Cabs Sauvignon and Franc, Burdese is a rich and perfumed wine with penetrating notes of blackberry, currants, tobacco and exotic spice. It is full bodied and concentrated without being overextracted thanks to its vibrant red fruit flavors, silky tannins and long finish.
Delicately scented, this offers subtle aromas of ripe apple, yellow pear and a hint of almond. The aromas follow on to the light-bodied palate along with a hint of lemon drop.

Although many will find this Chard fancy and worth the price, the oak sticks out too much, giving it outsized butterscotch and toast flavors. Maybe something less than 40% new oak would have let the tropical fruit, citrus and pear flavors express themselves more purely. Excessive oak has marred Patz & Hall Chardonnays in the past.
Candy and fruit drops are the first impression of this young wine. It has some good fruit, more in the honeyed and nut character, but that heavily perfumed candy character doesn't fit well.

Roasted coffee bean and menthol aromas lead the nose while the evolved palate offers dark bitter chocolate, licorice and a toasted note. Showing the heat of the vintage, the fruit has largely dried up while astringent tannins lead to a bracing finish.
Recalling the zesty style from New Zealand, it offers aromas of cantaloupe and crushed tomato vine along with exotic fruit that all carry over to the palate. It has a crisp, refreshing finish.
Dark-berry, pressed violet and tilled earth aromas come together on this. The easygoing enjoyable palate offers ripe blackberry and a hint of clove alongside mellow tannins.

wine: Husch 2001 La Ribera Vineyards Sauvignon Blanc (Mendocino)
review: Lots to like in this simple, flavorful wine, with its pretty citrus and apple flavors and crisp bite of acidity. Could use more concentration and depth, but the wine is versatile and friendly. —S.H.

Camastra is a 60-40 blend of Nero d'Avola and Merlot from Tenuta Regaleali that delivers distinct aromas of blackberry fruit, leafy vegetable, green pepper, cherry and moist earth. The wine is firm and black in concentration with a high quality of tannin.

appellation: Santa Ynez Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: Too hot, with 15.6% alcohol, and it shows in the chile pepper heat. Also too soft, lacking structure. With the glycerine, it tastes like a sweet Starbucks drink with raspberry, mocha, vanilla and cinnamon flavors.

Citrus, Mediterranean herb and cut grass aromas lead the way. The crisp palate offers Bartlett pear, unripe apricot and grapefruit alongside tangy acidity. A saline note backs up the succulent finish.

wine: Bouchard Père & Fils 2003 Beaune Marconnets Premier Cru  (Beaune)
review: This is a big wine, powered by dusty, ripe tannins, and dense black fruit flavors. The power doesn't take away from the wine's freshness and its rich perfumes. Imported by Clicquot Inc.

Waxy and a touch volatile on the nose, this wine offers broad aromas of tropical fruit and barrel. The palate is lithe and medium bodied, bearing kiwi and papaya notes. It finishes with a minerally tang and vital acidity.

appellation: Adelaida District, Central Coast, California, US
review: Very light in the glass, this wine begins with aromas of ripe red plums and hibiscus on the rustic nose. There's a decent tension on the palate, where muddled strawberry and red-plum flavors are lifted by herbs and baking spices.

92–94. Barrel Sample. This is a rich wine that has a generous full-bodied character. At the same time, the acidity is there, offering some beautiful spice and ginger. This is going to develop so well.

wine: Woodenhead 2011 Wet Kiss Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)
appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: A field of mint is found on the nose of this soft, spicy wine with the gimmicky name, around a core of red cherry and touch of oak. Fresh and bright, it has a suggestion of heft on the finish.

A dry, stainless-steel fermented wine, this presents a generous floral bouquet upon entry, followed by a creamy palate, with textural layers of apricot and peach. Medium bodied, it remains refreshing throughout, making it an ideal choice for lighter occasions and lighter fare.
89-91 Barrel sample. Owned by Cos d'Estournel, this is made in a sumptuous style for a Médoc wine. It is plump, ripe, the fruit the sole event here. It is sweet black and rich. For early drinking.

appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: With Zinfandel and Petite Sirah, this is a big, hot, high-alcohol wine with chocolatey, stewed flavors. It's too soft and Porty, and isn't going anywhere.

wine: Eder 2018 Ried Süssenberg Federspiel Grüner Veltliner (Wachau)
review: A very subtle hint of lemon oil signals both richness and freshness on the nose. The palate adds a creamy richness and a zesty texture and that homes in on that lemon oil freshness. It also has a salty, yeasty zip that lifts up the toned, concentrtated body.

appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: This wine's smoke, seaweed, black pepper, orange peel and purple fruit aromas pop. The palate features easy-drinking fruit flavors, with gritty tannins to back them up.
Features a creamy mouthfeel and supple tannins, but also entirely too much brett influence. Smells and tastes like a well-worn Band Aid.

wine: Monte Faustino 2011  Recioto della Valpolicella Classico
appellation: Recioto della Valpolicella Classico, Veneto, Italy
review: Delicately scented, this opens with aromas of dried black cherry and toasted notes. On the concentrated palate, oak-driven spice takes center stage while mature dark-skinned fruit and dried prune provide the background. Pair it with Gorgonzola at the end of the meal.

From grand cru vineyards on the Montagne de Reims, this fine, now mature, Champagne is rich with ripe citrus, pear and peach flavors, generously structured and poised between toastiness and fresh, crisp fruits. Drink this wine now.

Hickinbotham's Bordeaux varieties are made by Napa Winemaker Chris Carpenter. The latest Merlot is up a quality notch from most Down Under. A mélange of cherry, licorice and scrubby Mediterranean herbs and spices is coated in a cola-driven sheen of polished oak. Lighter than others under this label, this is nonetheless a big wine which captures the juicy red fruit via lifted acidity and well-structured, savory tannins. Drink now–2028.

wine: Château la Calisse 2016 Patricia Ortelli Rosé (Coteaux Varois en Provence)
appellation: Coteaux Varois en Provence, Provence, France
review: This small appellation is an enclave in the middle of Côtes de Provence. Its style is very similar and this wine, named after the owner, is a structured blend of Syrah and Grenache. The wine from organic grapes has a pepper and spice edge over the crisp acidity of the red fruits. Drink now.

wine: Château Hermitage Saint-Martin 2014 Ikon Rosé (Côtes de Provence)
review: The heavy bottle signals this is statement rosé. It's certainly rich, full in the mouth with spice, acidity and tangerine flavors mingling well together. The wine is deliciously textured and could do with some more aging. Drink from the end of 2015.
Citrus, floral and nutty aromas form the nose. On the fresh palate, zesty acidity accompanies yellow, peach, pineapple and a bitter almond note.

wine: Caccia al Piano 1868 2011 Levia Gravia  (Bolgheri Superiore)
review: A blend of 70% Cabernet Sauvignon, 22% Merlot and 8% Syrah, this offers aromas of cassis, cedar, leather, black pepper and grilled herb. On the palate, coffee, chocolate, toast and a hint of powdered sage accent the blackberry and dried cherry core. Polished tannins make this already accessible. Drink through 2019.

wine: Bodega Noemía de Patagonia 2011 A Lisa Malbec (Río Negro Valley)
review: his wine is being produced at 57,000 cases, and this vintage shows distinct aromas of green herbs and tomato. In the mouth, it rings with acidity such that raspberry and red-plum flavors taste sour. Tasted twice with similar results.

wine: Schmelz 2007 Pichl Point Smaragd Grüner Veltliner (Wachau)
review: Johann Schmelz has produced a voluptuous wine, full of ripe fruits and a velvet texture. Of course, the acidity is there, giving the wine a crisp edge, but it is the rich structure and flavors of apricots, red apples and spice that blend together in a harmonious, balanced whole. Imported by Blue Danube Wine Co.

This soft, rich wine is a delicious reminder of the great fruit in this vintage. It has broad red fruits with balanced acidity and a crisp edge. This wine that comes from vineyards at the southern end of the Côte de Beaune is ready to drink now.

Savory, minty, foresty and showing its own style and personality. Not a generic Syrah; there's leather, fir tree and berry aromas, and then a large, mouthfilling palate full of savory, herbal berry flavors accented by oak and BBQ notes. Hard to peg as varietal Syrah but definitely a good wine with character.

Close to the Gironde estuary, le Temple's wines are dominated by Cabernet Sauvignon, making for a powerful, complex bottling, with great acidity and black currant flavor. This has potential to age for at least five years.
91-93 A powerful wine, very ripe and rounded. Finely concentrated, with dark plum skins and opulent tannins.

This is a bold, hearty Bordeaux blend of 65% Cabernet Sauvignon, 20% Merlot, 10% Malbec and 5% Cabernet Franc. Substantial in tannin and oak, it has softened edges of earthiness, forest and sage. Nuanced black fruit complements the graphite and savory spice.

wine: La Scolca 2002 Il Valentino  (Gavi di Gavi)
review: Standard tart and refreshing stuff, with added notes that hint at anise and sour cream. Light-bodied, drink as an apéritif.
Beautifully smooth, this ripe wine contrasts its rich peach and pineapple flavors with a squeezed lime note and taut acidity. With its intensely-fruity finish, this is a wine for aging.

appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: This value brand makes a number of West Coast Pinots, with mixed results. Here are very strong, dominating flavors of vanilla and breakfast tea, of the sort often associated with oak additions during the winemaking process. Don't look for any specific Willamette Valley character here. It's a light generic red, tasting mostly of vanilla.

appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Another well-priced offering out of Washington's Columbia Valley, this one offering pretty caramel and coffee scents and raspberry and herb flavors. It's light in body, but creamy-textured, with a decent finish that echoes with coffee, vanilla and ground pepper.

One whiff tells you this rosé of Malbec and 10% Petit Verdot is all about pyrazines. A high level of citric acid drives a palate that tastes of orange extract and gritty bitterness. Beyond tang there's not much to a sharp finish.

wine: Scott Paul 2015 Azana Pinot Noir (Chehalem Mountains)
appellation: Chehalem Mountains, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: Scott Paul's Azana is precise and distinctive, delivering a focused fusion of strawberry, blueberry and spicy cherry flavors. There's a pleasing touch of lightly earthy funk as well, and the overall balance keeps it interesting and on point through the finish.

wine: Fattoria di Lamole 2011 Vigna Grospoli Gran Selezione  (Chianti Classico)
review: Aromas of meat juices, peppercorn, underbrush and game lead the nose. The palate delivers dried cherry, prune, clove, grilled herb and anise. Tightly knit tannins lend support but still need to unwind. Drink 2017–2023.

A blend of 90% Sangiovese, 5% Cabernet Sauvignon and 5% Merlot, this opens with earthy aromas of truffle, scorched earth, violet and a touch of dark spice. The palate offers dried black cherry and ground pepper alongside fine-grained tannins. It also shows the heat of the vintage, so drink soon.

Youthful and bright now, this elegant wine will surely benefit from five to ten more years of cellar aging. At this point, the wine is very focused on oak-driven aromas of spice, cedar, chocolate, old leather and toasted nut but the quality of the fruit comes through. Drink with succulent red meats.
White spring-flower and white stone-fruit aromas form the delicate nose. On the refreshing palate, bright acidity accompanies grapefruit, yellow apple and a drop of saline.

appellation: Central Coast, Central Coast, California, US
review: Puts all the pieces of the puzzle together, combining ripe tropical fruit, ample sweet oak and coastal acidity, but the picture is a little blurry. The wine is decadently ripe and obvious.

wine: Domaine Laporte 2017 Le Bouquet Sauvignon Blanc (Vin de France)
appellation: Vin de France, France Other, France
review: A blend from grapes mainly across the Loire regions, this fruit, crisp and herbal wine is a pleasing homage to Sauvignon Blanc. It has all the citrus and gooseberry flavors as well as hints of tropical fruits. Drink this easy-going wine now.

wine: Domaine Serene 2014 Coeur Blanc Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)
appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: A barrel-fermented white Pinot Noir, this is bursting with broad, creamy flavors of ripe caramel-dipped apples and fresh pear. It might be mistaken for Chardonnay, except for the extra weight that carries through the lengthy finish. Though it's tempting to describe white Pinot Noirs as sparkling wines without the sparkle, this is much more interesting, and one of the rare examples that defines both a style and a standard for the rest.

wine: Barone di Villagrande 2014 Passito  (Malvasia delle Lipari)
appellation: Malvasia delle Lipari, Sicily & Sardinia, Italy
review: This deeply hued, almost amber-colored dessert wine has aromas of toast, apricot and roasted nut. The sweet, honeyed palate evokes offers maple syrup before a bitter walnut finish.

wine: Henry's Drive Vignerons 2006 Dead Letter Office Shiraz (McLaren Vale-Padthaway)
Babcock 2019 Old Vines Estate Grown Sauvignon Blanc (Sta. Rita Hills)
appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
review: These old vines produce a compelling style of Sauvignon Blanc, which begins with honeyed aromas of baked apple and Meyer lemon, with an underlying grass touch. The palate offers hints of toasted nuts and more baked apple, with a pinch of sea salt as well.

appellation: Edna Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: Dried lemon, hints of almond and a brush of sour cream make for a very clean and intriguing nose on this bottling. The palate combines toasted wood, baked lemon and yellow-cake aromas, with pinches of salt and brown spice adding even more warmth.

Here's a super Tuscan blend of Sangiovese and Cabernet Sauvignon that shows its 10 years of age surprising well. There's still loads of fruit here backed by tertiary aromas of licorice, polished stone, dried fruit and old leather.

wine: Pindar Vineyards 2019 Dr. Dan's Signature Collections White (North Fork of Long Island)
appellation: North Fork of Long Island, Long Island, New York, US
review: Bright aromas of white blossoms, candied lemon peels and orchard fruit carry the nose of this blend of Viognier, Pinot Gris, Sauvignon Blanc and Riesling. Juicy citrus and yellow plum flavors are housed on a juicy, easy-to-like palate.
Some firm tannins lie at the back of this dry, solid wine. It has dark plum fruits, juicy acidity and a fresher aftertaste. It's balanced and needs a little aging. Drink from 2017.

appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: Numerous lively aromas kick off this bottling, from black currant and purple flower to savory smoke and black peppercorn. The palate is framed by buoyant acidity and chalky tannins, which hold up rich black cherry, clove, licorice and mocha flavors.

An unusual blend dominated by Cabernet Franc and Merlot, with only ten percent Cabernet Sauvignon. Very dark, rich and fruity, with cassis, blackcurrant, anise and herb flavors that are wrapped in big, sturdy tannins. Too young to drink now, unless it's with an enormous dish like braised short ribs, but best left for four or five years.
A ripe, smoky wood- and black fruit-driven wine. It has richness with structure, a smooth texture and just the right level of acidity. A delicious wine, ready to drink now.

wine: Merry Edwards 2019 Klopp Ranch Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)
appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: Salty and spicy, this full-bodied red from the famous site, long sourced by the producer, is fruity in dark cherry, boysenberry and baked strawberry flavor. The tannins are supportive and well-integrated, as is the toasted oak, which underscores the combination of sweet spice tones.

appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Generous, appealing melon, pear and apple aromas are followed by plump but still elegant while well-balanced fruit flavors. It's a bit one note but it hits that note well.

wine: Nickel & Nickel 2006 State Lane Ranch Cabernet Sauvignon (Yountville)
review: Dark as midnight and very tannic and dry, this 100% Cabernet is somewhat forbidding in its turbulent youth. It's very astringent and chewy, and the palate has to work to bite through to the core of blackberries, black cherries and cassis. Has all the hallmarks of a wine that will benefit from extended aging. Give it at least until 2012 and try again.

wine: Stift Göttweig 2017 Ried Gott Reserve Grüner Veltliner (Kremstal)
review: The merest whiff of gunflint on the nose gives way to subtle pear and lemon zest notes. The palate comes in with the animating juiciness of really ripe lemon and continues in this slender, juicy, refreshing and concentrated fashion. This is full of flow, ease and lemony joy and provides perfect refreshment.

wine: Château de la Terrière 2006 Vieilles Vignes Cuvée Jules du Souzy  (Brouilly)
designation: Vieilles Vignes Cuvée Jules du Souzy
review: Rich, concentrated red and black plum flavor dominate a wine that shows structure as well as intensity. This is powerful stuff, a delicious wine, fruity but with a core of dark tannins. It is just edging into maturity, so drink this year. The name recalls the Counts of Souzy who once governed the region.
Is this wine off-dry or dessert sweet? It straddles the border, with white sugar, peach, orange, vanilla and creamy flavors.

wine: Gypsy Canyon 2004 Pinot Noir (Sta. Rita Hills)
appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
review: This is the second vintage from this tiny winery. This is a bone-dry Pinot, dark and full-bodied. It's not a fruit bomb, but shows a controlled balance of rhubarb pie, cola, cherry and coffee flavors, wrapped in rich, sturdy tannins and a velvety texture. A little rustic now, this fine wine should develop further by 2007 and hold for several years.

wine: Alain Brumont 2009 Château Montus Blanc  (Pacherenc du Vic Bilh)
appellation: Pacherenc du Vic Bilh, Southwest France, France
review: The white wine at Montus is a blend of many of the local grapes, including the rare Petit Courbu. It has a herbaceous character that's broadened with toast and lively acidity. Finely perfumed and rich, it has an apple- and quince-flavored finish.

wine: Foursight 2017 Charles Vineyard Clone 5 Pinot Noir (Anderson Valley)
appellation: Anderson Valley, Mendocino County, California, US
review: Flavors that are light and earthy-savory give this medium-bodied, unfined and unfiltered wine an austere feel. If offers underripe fruit notes, spicy tea accents and a brownish tinge in the color.
Fresh and crisply fruity, this is a balanced, lively wine. A touch of caramel adds to the tannic edge, giving the wine a good structure along with ripe strawberry fruits. The wine is ready to drink.
Not so much sweet as intensely rich, peppery and zesty with orange peel and spiced pear juice flavors. It is concentrated, intense, likely to last for many years.

wine: Hazlitt 1852 Vineyards 2017 Homestead Reserve Riesling (Finger Lakes)
appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
review: Ripe aromas of peach, pineapple and mango carry a bit of a banana undercurrent in this dry-style Riesling. The medium-bodied palate is soft and fruity, with a creamy feel that's honed by balancing acidity.

wine: Château la Prade 2012  Francs Côtes de Bordeaux
appellation: Francs Côtes de Bordeaux, Bordeaux, France
review: Smooth and ripe, 90% Merlot and 10% Cabernet Franc, this is a solid, structured wine. Its juicy acidity is full of potential, giving a ripe character with red berry fruits and a tannic structure to balance. The wine's fruit gives a fresher feel at the end.

wine: Hawk Watch Winery 2017 Sauvignon Blanc (South Coast)
appellation: South Coast, South Coast, California, US
review: Clean aromas of ripe nectarine and Anjou pear skins meet with lime pith, cut grass and cement on the nose of this bottling from the San Diego area. An impressive texture grabs hold of the palate immediately, then gives way to baked apple and dried pear flavors that go down easy.

wine: Wise Villa 2015 Estate Petit Verdot (Sierra Foothills)
appellation: Sierra Foothills, Sierra Foothills, California, US
review: Great fruit flavors and an especially smooth and creamy texture make this full-bodied wine hard to resist. It smells delicious like black cherries and tastes rich, almost jammy, with blackberry-pie notes. Moderate tannins add some good structure for all that fruit.

This offers savory aromas of old spice and Indian market with bright background nuances of tar, cola and dried berry fruit. There isn't much fresh fruit, but there is a touch of sweetness on the finish.

wine: Calicaro 2009 Liberty Bridge Split Rock Vineyard Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)
review: Lots of toasty new oak on this Pinot, which gives it a sweet roasted marshmallow aroma and taste. Mixed in are rich flavors of cherries, raspberries and cola, sprinkled with cinnamon and pepper. An exotic, powerful wine. Too bold and in your face now, but should gain traction over the next eight years.

90-92 Barrel sample. This poised wine has attractive layers of clean, fresh lemon and honey flavors. There are some light wood nuances, lively acidity and dryness from botrytis. A finely balanced wine.

wine: Vignerons de Tutiac 2016 Carrelet d'Estuaire  (Bordeaux Blanc)
review: A pure citrus-flavored wine, this is refreshing and light. Its crispness will soften over the next few months, but drink now for the forward fruitiness.

Aromas of prune, pressed purple flower and powdered sage lift out of the glass along with a suggestion of rubber. The palate is ripe and full bodied, offering raisin, dried black cherry and a hint of exotic spice. Close-grained tannins give it a grippy finish.

wine: Andrew Januik 2017 Stone Cairn Cabernet Sauvignon (Red Mountain)
appellation: Red Mountain, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Brooding aromas of cherry, scorched earth, herb and bittersweet chocolate are followed by plump, ripe cherry flavors backed by tannins that are combed to a fine sheen. Bright acidity accents it all. It's a delicious offering of the variety.

appellation: Sierra Foothills, Sierra Foothills, California, US
review: Very tannic, without the necessary fruit to make it sing, this Sierra Foothills' Cab Franc has some pleasant spiciness to it that veers dangerously close to pepper land.
This simple red leads with baking spice, underbrush and red-skinned berry aromas. The palate delivers orange peel, black cherry and clove flavors, with round tannins. Drink soon.

Hamilton Russell continues to lead the pack in producing consistent, elegant wines. Though pretty, the wine has a South African edge, but it adds character to the soft spice and red and black cherry flavors. Minerality and acidity add balance. Overall, a classic, collectible Pinot.

appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: This wine is a blend of Cabernet Sauvignon (62%), Cabernet Franc (30%) and Petit Verdot. Aromas of coffee, dried herbs, green pepper and smoke are followed by creamy-feeling cherry and café au lait flavors. It brings a whole lot of appeal.
Toasted popcorn kernel is the chief note. Medium in body, it bears simple pomaceous flavors and even-keeled acids.
