From an estate situated close to the vineyards of Pomerol, the 82% Merlot in this blend gives a sumptuous wine that will be ripe and full when it matures. The obtrusive wood flavors need to calm down first, so wait to drink the wine until 2022.
There's a fine balance here between minerality and rich toast. The result is a very pure but ripe wine, dominated by a good mix of ripe white fruits and honey.

wine: Dante Rivetti 2007 Bricco di Neive Riserva  (Barbaresco)
review: Indian spice, cardamom, clove and dried berry aromas open the nose. The palate has a raw, chewy quality, so give this 10 more years of cellar aging.

wine: Proulx 2006 Yellow Label Petite Sirah (Paso Robles)
appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: A simple, awkward Petite Sirah, showing overripe flavors and a soft, melted texture. Tastes syrupy in cola and berries.

wine: Quinta da Plansel 2008 Plansel Selecta Grand Escolha Red (Alentejano)
review: Like its overweight bottle, the wine feels superrich, superpowerful, with few holds barred as its tannins sink into the cushion of luscious fruit. It is given shape by blackberry acidity, and a firm, dry finish.
A ripe, juicy wine, this has swathes of red fruits cut through with acidity. The tannic structure gives weight to this very fresh red wine that is ready to drink now–2018.

wine: Domaine des Géléries 2017 Les Chënes Cabernet Franc (Bourgueil)
review: Smoky aromas and stalky fruit come from some crispness in this textured wine. The smokiness and blackberry fruits are allied to layers of tight acidity. The wine is ready to drink.

wine: Larchago 2014 Val de Oron  (Ribera del Duero)
appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
review: Wiry, withdrawn plum aromas are a touch floral. A jagged palate feel with high acidity and hard tannins frames plum flavors. This is bullish overall and a bit fiery and hot on the finish.

wine: De Bortoli 2016 Deen Vat Series No 5 Botrytis Semillon (Riverina)
review: From a vineyard planted in 2003 specifically for botrytis wines, this is a pure delight. It oozes notes of honeyed nuts, ripe lemons, blossoms and just a touch of mushroom. The palate is rich and viscous, but there's beautifully bright acidity to cut through the creaminess and make the mouth water for another sip. The finish lingers on honey and citrus.

You'll love the powerful richness and natural concentration of this beautiful Barolo. It boasts masculine renderings of cherry liqueur, carob pod, red rose and sassy cinnamon spice. The wine shows great aging potential (10 years or more) thanks to its firm tannins and fresh acidity.

wine: Viña Maipo 2015 Vitral Reserva Carmenère (Central Valley)
review: Lightly spiced aromas of plum and licorice are varietally correct. This wine feels energetic, albeit a touch choppy. Blackened plum and berry flavors end with hint of toasty oak and caramel.

wine: Fattoria La Lecciaia 2012 Vigna Manapetra  (Brunello di Montalcino)
review: Underbrush, dried tobacco leaf, roasted coffee and balsamic notes lead the nose. The tightly wound palate is lean, offering sour cherry, pomegranate, licorice and espresso notes, clenched by close-grained tannins on the finish.

wine: Losi Querciavalle 2011 Millennium Gran Selezione  (Chianti Classico)
review: Underbrush, mature black-skinned fruit, worn leather and scorched earth aromas lead the way. The firm, chewy palate offers mature plum, juicy Morello cherry, clove, anise and tobacco framed in tightly wound tannins. Drink 2019–2028.

wine: Joseph Swan Vineyards 2011 Cuvée de Trois Chardonnay (Russian River Valley)
appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: The oak is strong on this blend of three of the winery's best vineyards. It shows up as buttered toast, with a distinctive, charry-sweet note of toasted marshmallows. The wine is strong in pineapples and oranges. An eccentric Chardonnay for drinking now.

A plump, fleshy Chardonnay that delivers plenty of pear and peach aromas and flavors. It's pleasing, if a bit simple, with just some modest hints of smoke and popcorn on the finish to add complexity. Imported by Broadbent Selections, Inc.

wine: Bellante 2018 Bentrock Vineyard Reserve Pinot Noir (Sta. Rita Hills)
appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
review: A bit dark in color and extracted in aroma, this bottling offers black cherry, boysenberry and peppery spices on the nose. It's big and brawny on the palate, mostly showing tangy boysenberry.

There is a touch of toast to this full, soft wine. That shows that aging for four years after bottling have enhanced this rich mix of Pinot Noir and Chardonnay, emphasizing the ripe apple flavors. Drink this nonvintage cuvée now.

From vines that are at least 70 years old, this wine shows great concentration and density. It is rich with black fruits and bright with acidity, a winning combination of accessibility and structure. Drink the wine now.

wine: Banfi 2010 Poggio all'Oro Riserva  (Brunello di Montalcino)
review: This slowly opens in the glass to reveal aromas of espresso, dark spice, menthol and ripe black-skinned fruit. On the firmly structured palate, integrated, close-grained tannins frame mature black cherry, licorice, clove and grilled herb. Give it time to unwind and fully develop. Drink 2022–2035.

wine: Rodney Strong 1999 Alden Vineyards Cabernet Sauvignon (Alexander Valley)
review: From vineyards quite high up in the eastern mountains, this wine is from stressed, low-yielding grapes. The blackberry and cassis flavors are concentrated and dense, and the tannins are tough and firm. Oak plays a supporting role. Rich foods, such as lamb or gongonzola cheese, will soften and sweeten it, but you're best off cellaring for a few years.

The wine is structured while also juicy. Its red-berry fruits are in the process of coming together with the tannins to give a rich wine. It has plenty of acidity at the end to give a crisp aftertaste.

appellation: Sierra Foothills, Sierra Foothills, California, US
review: The honeyed aroma of this Rhône blend of Marsanne, Roussanne, Rolle and Viognier makes it immediately attractive, but then the flavors kick in, and it turns into a roller coaster ride. Apricot jam, peaches, pears, pineapples, butter-sautéed plaintain, vanilla custard, star anise, lemon crème brûlée, the list goes on and on. The finish is fully dry and the alcohol is refreshingly low. Drink now.

A perfumed wine, this is rich in tannins and generous, ripe black fruits. Aged nine months in wood, it has a hint of caramel as well as spice that adds extra dimension. It is juicy, ripe and needs to age further. Drink from late 2018.

wine: Mark West 2009 Pinot Noir (Santa Lucia Highlands)
appellation: Santa Lucia Highlands, Central Coast, California, US
review: A sweet, jammy Pinot Noir, with raspberry, cherry, licorice and sandalwood flavors, brightened by crisp acidity. Good as an introductory Pinot to explore the variety at a fair price.

appellation: Edna Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: Bright strawberry-rhubarb fruit, toast, orange and pine aromas open this light but flavorful wine. The almost candied cherry fruit wears a black oak veil, but is strong enough to not be completely buried by it. Finishes long, with coffee and cocoa accents.

With its fine aged-wood and fruit character, this is a sweet yet complex wine. Toast, almonds, a hint of spirit and the palate and delicate acidity all combine easily in a harmonious wine whose closest comparison is with a great amontillado.

wine: Encosta do Sobral 2017 Reserva Branco White (Tejo)
review: A ripe, creamy-textured wine, this is full of ripe pear and crisp quince flavors. There is an attractive perfumed character to this wine, freshened by the bright acidity at the end.

Mainly Merlot, this Bordeaux blend is a combination of grapes from Santa Maria Valley and the Santa Cruz Mountains. It's very rich and likeable now for its crisply acidic flavors of black cherries, red currants and spices, coated with sweet, smoky oak. Give it a brief decant before serving.

appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: A very nice Pinot, actually Bearboat's best yet, that shows the dry silkiness of a fine Russian River Pinot, and also some complex layers of flavor. Cherries, rhubarb, pomegranates, orange zest, herb tea, clove and pepper all mingle together, enlivened by crisp acidity.

This is a great wine with its swathes of ripe fruit allied to a very structured character. It is concentrated with complex flavors that bring in wood, tropical fruits, apricots and a dense texture. Combined, these elements give the wine great style and aging potential.
Lively acidity and crisp fruits mark out this attractive wine. It conveys citrus and bright lemon fruitiness, with a fresh aftertaste. Drink this lightly textured wine now.

wine: Wines & Winemakers 2014 Companhia das Lezírias Herdade de Catapereiro Rosé (Tejo)
designation: Companhia das Lezírias Herdade de Catapereiro
review: A strange orange-pink color for a wine that is somewhere between fruity and sweet and acid and bitter. This one hasn't found a balance.

wine: Domaine Bertagna 2018 Les Murgers Premier Cru  (Nuits-St.-Georges)
review: From a densely planted vineyard halfway up the slope, this wood-aged wine has density, powerful tannins and the promise of rich fruitiness. This concentrated wine needs to age many years. Drink from 2025.

So soft and dense in richness, this is easy to enjoy now. But you really want to restrain that impulse and give it some time in the cellar. Blended from roughly equal parts of Cabernet Sauvignon, Cabernet Franc and Merlot, it's dry and tannic, but with a molten core of blackberries, cherries, blueberries, anise and sweet new oak. Very fine, very elaborate and complex. Give it 5–6 years, at least. This wine could still be unfolding in 2020.

wine: Kenneth Volk 2006 Garey Vineyard Pinot Noir (Santa Maria Valley)
appellation: Santa Maria Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: Despite some tasty cherry, cola and sandalwood flavors, this Pinot Noir is too soft. It melts in the mouth, and the imbalance emphasizes the alcohol, which gives the impression of heat. Drink now.

wine: Jean Becker 2016 Schoenenbourg Grand Cru Riesling (Alsace)
review: Juicy, mellow apple, dried apple skin and dried lemon rind make for a rich and mellow nose on this vivid wine. The palate redoubles on creamy, zesty mellowness reminiscent of tart, baked apple flesh. All is made vibrant with lemon acidity and the finish is rounded but bone dry. The wine is intense and rich, but svelte.

wine: Woodenhead 2012 Dolinsek Ranch Syrah (Russian River Valley)
appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: Licorice and leather stand out in this softly layered wine that leans heavy on the palate. Made in a full-bodied, brawny style, it's single-minded more than complex, finishing in toasty oak and black pepper.

This opens with aromas of red berry, underbrush and a whiff of eucalyptus. The firm palate displays red cherry, star anise and white pepper alongside bracing tannins and bright acidity. Drink after 2023.

90–92. Barrel Sample. This small estate, with the same winemaking team as Pichon Baron, reveals a gentler view of Cabernet Sauvignon. The blend with Merlot gives plenty of ripe fruit with smooth tannins and an attractive medium-term potential.

wine: Sean W. McBride 2016 Filigreen Farm The China Block Pinot Noir (Anderson Valley)
appellation: Anderson Valley, Mendocino County, California, US
review: Plush and full-flavored, this ripe and fruity wine tastes like black cherries and red-cherry jam, has a smooth, lightly tannic texture and soft acidity.

The nose hints at ripe fruit but it is on the palate that the wine's textured yeasty fullness becomes apparent. This is edged with the tang of grapefruit peel which encapsulates very ripe rounded fluid pear fruit on a concentrated palate. This is compact and impactful and finishes with pleasant, lip-smacking freshness.

appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
review: Wines like this are good indicators that 2004 is indeed an exceptional vintage in RdD. For a Tempranillo that spent only five months in oak it's fairly settled. The nose is a touch syrupy but you can only love the concentrated berry aromas. The mouth is bulky but satisfying, with huge dark-fruit flavors and balancing tannins and acidity. Jumpy but very likable.

wine: Jean-Luc Baldès 2013 Clos Triguedina Les Selections Parcellaires Les Galets  (Cahors)
designation: Clos Triguedina Les Selections Parcellaires Les Galets
review: This third-terrace parcel in the Baldès terroir Trilogie is clay and limestone with iron and lava deposits. The wine presents a rich medley of black fruits, ripe tannins and a powerful structure. It has concentration, ripe fruit and bright acidity. Drink from 2023.
The wine is subdued and clean on the nose and it doesn't exaggerate or mask the quality of fruit. This is executed in a bright, compact and streamlined style that combines freshness and firmness.

A crisp, fresh and creamy wine, it has grapefruit acidity and a firm sense of mineral structure. The wine is developing well, but to bring out its balance between fruit and texture, it needs until 2015 in bottle.

The subtle nose of this wine shows notions of vine peach and rhubarb. On the palate, the full impact of the fruit comes across, with red apple, lime zest and juicy peach cut with zesty citrus. This wine is lively, full fruited, refreshing and dry. The finish is vivid and lastingly zesty.
A slight note of Golden Delicious apple plays on the nose of this wine. The palate picks up this fruity notion in a juicy, easy flow. The light, smooth palate comes to a dry, slightly bitter finish.

wine: Abbazia Santa Anastasia 1998 Montenero Nero d'Avola (Sicilia)
review: This New Wave wine from Sicily is a blend of 70% Nero d'Avola, 20% Syrah and 10% Merlot. Aromas of vanilla buttercream, cedar, cinnamon and clove make one wonder if the fruit has been oaked into submission, but the bright cherry fruit shines on the palate and lingers through the tart, smooth finish. Soft enough to drink now, but should get better through at least 2005 and drink well until 2010.

wine: Nora 2010 Nora da Neve Albariño (Rías Baixas)
review: Aromas of candle wax, nectarine and lees carry the bouquet on this well-aged Albariño that's round and full in body. Flavors of baked apple, citrus, almond skins and vanilla are briny, while the finish feels and tastes creamy and leesy. Drink now.

Classic Muscat muskiness greets the nose and is followed by grass, citrus, dried flowers and rubber. The dried flower notes are particularly attractive and beg for hazelnut tarts, as producer Andrea Faccio suggests. Imported by Vin Divino.

Liquid smoke and toasted elements of roasted hazelnut and cured meat dominate the nose of this modern Barbera d'Alba. There is power and high alcohol here too, coupled by the wine's naturally high acidity that is a bit strong on the palate. Pair this wine with very cheesey foods.

wine: Falua 2017 Conde Vimioso Colheita Seleccionada Branco White (Tejo)
review: Fernão Pires and Arinto have produced this floral, perfumed wine that also has crisp citrus and green-apple flavors. A refreshing wine, it's lively, bright and ready to drink.

wine: Domaine Zind-Humbrecht 2002 Clos Windsbuhl Hunawihr Gewurztraminer (Alsace)
review: A smooth, rich, unctuous wine from the 13-acre Windsbuhl vineyard. It oozes charm, and hides its power underneath its seductive exterior. There is great fruit here, with some hints of acidity as well as flavors of lychees and pepper.

wine: Chanson Père et Fils 2013 Teurons Premier Cru  (Beaune)
review: Rich in character, this is a dense wine, with smoky tannins and juicy red fruits that are deliciously ripe. The tannins and the fruit concentration result in a weighty yet brightly acidic wine. It will develop quickly, and then remain at a peak for many years. Drink from 2018.

wine: Buttonwood Farm 2007 Sauvignon Blanc (Santa Ynez Valley)
appellation: Santa Ynez Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: Dry and grassy, with high acidity that makes the palate clean and zesty. The lemon, lime, grapefruit and floral flavors finish with a scour of peppery spice.

wine: Small Vines 2010 MK Vineyard Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)
review: Gentle and silky, this Pinot Noir has perfumes of rose petals, ripe red cherries, flat cola and sandalwood, plus a hint of grilled bacon. It tastes as sweetly delicious as it smells, and it feels round, supple and polished. So easy to drink now, but you might miss the complexity if you do.
Just fruit, this young wine shows attractive blackberry flavors and soft tannins. It's ripe and juicy, fresh while also rich. Drink now.

Generic red fruit and milk chocolate aromas precede a tangy palate with a fairly high acid-to-body ratio. This tastes of tart red plum, with a hint of chocolate; it's short, crisp and quaffable. Novo Imports and Aidil Wines & Liquors.

Although the varietal composition isn't typical of Châteauneuf (one-third each Grenache, Syrah, Mourvèdre), the flavors certainly are, combining baked fruit with dusty earth and touches of leather and spice. It's soft and round in the mouth, with a juicy, mouthwatering finish. Drink now-2015.

wine: Naughty Boy 2013 Thornton Ranch Chardonnay (Potter Valley)
appellation: Potter Valley, Mendocino County, California, US
review: A straightforward and light-bodied wine, this has buttery, earthy aromas, and butter and apple flavors on a rather crisp texture. It turns dry and a bit sharp on the finish.
Shows some rather lactic overtones to go with ample citrus and guava flavors. Medium-bodied, with a fresh, lemony finish.

Aromas of exotic spice, red berry, crushed dill, espresso and a whiff of coconut lead the nose. The rounded polished palate offers black raspberry, dark cherry, vanilla, coffee and a hint of anise alongside fine-grained tannins. Drink 2021–2028.

Vineyards in the northern Médoc have produced a wine that while offering some attractive black-currant fruit also has an excess of wood flavors. At this stage, the fruit should be more prominent and the wine possibly will remain toasty and woody.
Hard to like this Pinot. It has flavors of beets, cola and asparagus, but it's drinkable.

wine: William Heritage 2016 Pumpkin Hill Vineyard Chardonnay (Outer Coastal Plain)
appellation: Outer Coastal Plain, New Jersey, US
review: This Chardonnay opens with alluring aromas of vanilla, lemon curd, dried apricot and pie crust. Lemon-lime acidity pulls together flavors of ripe peach and vanilla, with a hint of wood spice. Lime peel and spice linger on the fruity finish.

wine: Santos & Seixo 2015 Rotas de Portugal Tinto Red (Alentejano)
review: The wine is ripe, full of the Alentejo warmth while still having enough smoke and spice flavors to paint a contrast. The acidity and the full aftertaste give a rich finish.

wine: Scotto Family Cellars 2016 Reserve Mohr-Fry Ranch Zinfandel (Lodi)
review: Great balance and subtle complexity give this full-bodied wine an extra level of enjoyment. Vivid black cherry and blackberry mingle with light earth and oak nuances while moderate tannins and mild acidity support the texture. More than just a gulper, this wine has many attributes to savor.

wine: William Grassie NV Millésimes Mélangés Red (Columbia Valley (WA))
appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: This is a blend of wines from their 2011 and 2012 vintages, mostly Cabernet Sauvignon with a bit of Merlot, as well. Spicy cherry fruit combines with herbal notes and a hint of balsamic. It has an earthy undertone, but overall the fruit shines.

wine: Maximin Grünhäuser 2010 Abtsberg Alte Reben Trocken Riesling (Mosel)
review: Hints of peach and clover give this medium-bodied dry Riesling a warm, sunny gloss, although it's still a racy, crisp wine laced with crushed stone and tart fruit notes of passion fruit and quince.

wine: Sanguis 2014 Loner Favonius Bien Nacido Vineyard Chardonnay (Santa Maria Valley)
appellation: Santa Maria Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: There are strong hints of smoke and flint at first on the nose of this bottling, but then comes a tighter mandarin orange pith character and a warming sandalwood spice. It's very fresh, tightly wound and bright on the palate, with pink grapefruit, squeezed lemon and lime skin toward the finish.

89–91. Barrel Sample. This soft wine is comfortably fruity and is already open and accessible. Its attractive white fruits, a shot of citrus and light minerality are integrating with the light wood spice.

Lemon freshness surrounds the pure Damask rose notes on the nose which become more intense with air. Intensity also is the watchword on the concentrated, almost oily palate but this richness is countered by the bone-dry style and the vivid, orange zest freshness. There is a lovely peppery savor on the long, mouthwatering finish.

appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
review: Coming from the dramatic Lindsay's Vineyard, which rises from 500 to 1,000 feet in the Sta. Rita Hills, this highly nuanced wine overdelivers on multiple fronts. The nose mixes floral notes of violet and rose with an herbal tone of dried oregano, alongside fruity sour cherry. On the palate, there's graphite, espresso, purple flowers like lavender and a tad of tobacco, both fresh and smoked.

A solid effort from Barbaresco's local cooperative, which should augur well for its single-vineyard riservas that will be released later this year. The normale is a fairly priced, somewhat herbal and tannic wine that shows enough cherry fruit and minty complexity to anchor it in the Very Good range. Astringent on the finish, so give it some time in the cellar or drink with rare beef. Imported by Vias Imports.
Soft, fruity and ripe, this is deliciously flavored with pear and melon notes. It opens slowly to reveal its wood aging and a hint of spice. Still developing, this needs 2–3 years of aging.

wine: Leyendas de Familia 2011 Cachos de Oro Cabernet Sauvignon-Carmenère (Maule Valley)
review: Woody, grainy aromas of fresh-cut timber relax with airing. in the mouth, this is drawn and a touch rough, with full tannins supporting rugged flavors of oak, wood resin, spice and black fruits. A nicely textured finish with rubbery notes and length is satisfying.
Dark gold in color, this estate-grown wine blends bright, crisp orange, melon and caramel apple flavors with richer toasted oak and vanilla notes.

Subdued aromas of coconut, camphor and toasted notes mingle with underbrush. Firmly structured but lean in terms of fruit richness, the palate shows sour cherry, espresso and powdered sage set against assertive, grainy tannins that clench the finish.

wine: Suhru 2012 Ember Red (North Fork of Long Island)
appellation: North Fork of Long Island, Long Island, New York, US
review: Lavish heaps of blackberries and cherries are accented by nuances of nuts, dried herb and black tea leaves in this composed red wine. Full bodied but balanced in acidity and fruit, it's substantial without overpowering. The finish lingers on velvety tannins.

Made from organically farmed vineyards, with native yeast and old barrels, this wine is a melting pot of bright cranberry and raspberry, smoke, toast, florals and sweet herbs. Medium bodied, with silky tannins, and plenty of terroir expression, it's well priced to boot. A win all around.

wine: William Fèvre 2016 La Misión Reserva Especial Pinot Noir (Maipo Valley)
review: Stale, sweaty aromas suggest old shoes and peanuts. In the mouth, this wine is raw and pulling, with no depth. Dry, leafy red-fruit flavors are lightly bitter and stewy, while an overall lack of ripeness is echoed on the finish.

appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
review: Aromatically restrained, with hints of green herbs, underripe apple and pineapple on the nose. It's semisweet in style, but brisk and approachable with pretty apple blossom and tart, green apple-skin flavors on the palate.

wine: Rudolf Müller 2007 Piesporter Goldtröpfchen Kabinett Riesling (Mosel-Saar-Ruwer)
review: This smells like a typical Mosel kabinett, offering up hints of crushed stone and fresh flower-shop greenery. It's styled appropriately, with modest alcohol and a hint of residual sugar. It just lacks the extra flash of fruit and acidity needed to raise it to the next level, leaving it a good if somewhat commercial effort.
Delicate hints of yellow cherry and apple sweeten this uncomplicated but fresh wine. Off dry in style, it's pleasantly sweet and tart on a zesty lemonade finish. Drink now.

Dry, minerally and acidic, this Chardonnay offers pineapple, lemon and mineral flavors. It's a food-friendly wine that won't compete with what you eat. At this price, it's a good restaurant wine, and easy to find, with 7,500 cases produced.

wine: Château les Mesclances 2016 Faustine Red (Côtes de Provence)
review: This lush wine is full of generous black fruits and rich tannins. Spice, touches of wood and a full-bodied character give the wine warmth and great ripeness. The alcohol shows in the edge of pepper that gives a burnt aftertaste. Drink from 2020.
Tasting fresh and vivid, this light-bodied wine exudes grassy citrusy aromas, followed by grapefruit, celery and scallion flavors that are assertive and refreshing. Good acidity keeps it lively.

wine: Beresan 2006 Viuda Negra Red Red (Walla Walla Valley (WA))
appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: This “Black Widow” blend of equal parts Cabernet Franc and Merlot was only made in 2005 and 2006. It's a fascinating combo—the Merlot giving breadth and flesh; the Cab Franc spotting in coffee and berry flavors.

wine: Clement et Florian Berthier 2018 Le de Pépé Gamay (Coteaux du Giennois)
appellation: Coteaux du Giennois, Loire Valley, France
review: In this smooth, velvety wine, tannins are engulfed by ripe black fruits. Acidity and black-cherry flavors give freshness as well as a rich, open character. Drink from 2021.

This is woodsy, spicy and narrow in its delivery of berry aromas. The palate is lively and shows acidic pick up. Full, generous berry flavors fade quickly then finish with a wave of minty, medicinal wood character.

wine: Domaines Devillard 2015 Domaine de la Garenne  (Pouilly-Fuissé)
review: Citrus aromas reveal this wine's essentially crisp character. Plenty of acidity balances the rich white fruits while the mineral texture adds bite to this well-made wine. It will be ready to drink from 2019.

A racy wine, with a tart streak: Aromas are of pear, green apple and grapefruit. Feels clean in the mouth with citrus and peach fruit, and a hint of herb. Finishes with a peppery sourness. Bring a bottle to the raw bar.

Inky dark concentration and bright cherry fruit open the nose of this nicely balanced Brunello. Leather, tobacco and cola notes give it aromatic momentum, and the wine shows bright acidity capped by firm tannins. Pair it with lamb or pork.

wine: Agustí Torelló 2002 Kripta Gran Reserva Brut Nature Sparkling (Cava)
review: Austere in style, with a smooth nose and dry, short flavors of apple and citrus. Elegant, smooth and well made, although not as exciting and flavorful as Kripta, with its unique oblong bottle and wild labeling, has the potential to be. Recall: 2002 was not a great vintage in Spain.

A finely structured wine, with dusty tannins, delicious fresh, purple fruits and fine acidity. Great perfumes set the scene for a poised, intense wine that is high in alcohol (15%) but does not taste like it. Imported by Simon N Cellars.

wine: L'Antica Quercia 2007 Matiú Brut  (Prosecco di Conegliano)
review: The wine's golden hue tells you this is Prosecco from a warmer climate (Conegliano is a few degrees warmer than Valdobbiadene) as do its aromas of mature peach and honeysuckle. The wine tastes flat and big in the mouth and offers sophisticated notes of white pepper and spice.
Intense lemon and lime flavors are accented by hints of mineral in this off-dry Riesling. Racy acidity is balanced elegantly by a lavish, silky mouthfeel and long, clinging finish. Enjoy now–2021.
The Canti suffers from a lack of acidity, which mars the pleasant minerality and apricot jam flavors of the wine. The low acid gives the wine little presence on the palate, and a short finish.

appellation: Dundee Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: A light and lovely mix of red fruits, this also shows a streak of chicken stock, dried straw and moderate acids. It spent 16 months in 20% new French oak.

wine: Les Parcelles de Stéphane Derenoncourt 2012  Bordeaux
review: Rich and smooth, this solid, ripe wine offers a good sense of structure. It has weight, dense tannins and a creamy texture. Drink from 2015.

Pfalz Gewürztraminer lacks the weight and richness of most Alsace examples, carrying less alcohol. This one shows the characteristic gingery-pepper spice of the variety combined with apple and pineapple fruit and a crisply focused but off-dry finish. It would make a top-notch foil for Indian cuisine.

A blend that includes some Cabernet Sauvignon (11%) and Cab Franc (3%), which add a little muscle to a somewhat soft, forward Merlot vintage. Definitely aging quickly, and probably drinking its best right now. Soft cherry fruit with tomato leaf/herbal notes, and a chocolaty finish.

Earthy and leathery smelling, but very much on the light-bodied side for Malbec. The palate is angular and slightly acidic, with juicy, spicy red-cherry flavors. Racy and lean on the finish, with a final wash of cleansing acids.

wine: Solar de Cambres 2014 Casa de Cambres Colheita Red (Douro)
review: This is a rustic wine with very ripe fruit that gives a red jelly flavor. It is simple, with a dry edge and acidity, ready to drink now.

wine: St. Clement 2010 Oroppas Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
review: Not a bad wine, but not particularly exciting. It has blackberry and cherry flavors, tinged with oak, but also some green, vegetal notes that prohibit aging. The finish is soft and sweet.

appellation: Dry Creek Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: This brawny, intensely ripe wine is dripping in red licorice, blackberry jam and seamless tannin, packing plenty of heat on the palate. Concentrated and soft, it finishes in high-toned acidity and a lasting touch of vanilla oak.

wine: Mailly Grand Cru 2009 Exception Blanche Blanc de Blancs Brut  (Champagne)
designation: Exception Blanche Blanc de Blancs Brut
review: The tight, mineral edge has softened just enough to make this Champagne drinkable now, although it will certainly age. Crisp apple and grapefruit flavors will develop well and the wine will be at its best from 2022.

appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Barbera, Sangiovese and Nebbiolo comprise the wine. Half of the grapes were air dried for three months, which is known as appassimento. The Sangiovese was crushed and fermented conventionally before being added to the blend. The result is a dry, slightly nutty red wine, with tart flavors that are suggestive of fruit leather. It shows good grip and length, and it comes with just a bit of alcoholic heat.

Dating to the 14th century, this estate is now run organically. Dense and richly fruity, this is one of the property's top wines, packed with tannins that complement ripe cherry and black-currant flavors. The wine's still-fresh acidity suggests further aging, so wait until 2020.

appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
review: Plum and berry aromas are a bit jammy, while a grapy mouthfeel features chewy tannins and just enough acidity. Blackberry and prune flavors finish with a note of raisin and a hint of soy sauce. This spent eight months in oak. Drink now.

Melon and grassy aromas waft from the glass. The palate delivers plenty of green melon and crème brûlée flavors. Thefeel is a little oily. Despite its texture, there is still enough acidity to match this with plenty of foods. Imported by Cape Wine Ventures.

wine: College Cellars 2014 Cockburn Ranch Vineyard Chardonnay (Walla Walla Valley (WA))
appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: There's plenty of appeal to the aromas, with notes of toast, spice and peach. The palate offers sweet, lightly creamy-feeling stone and tropical-fruit flavors that convey balance. The barrel influence (new 500L puncheon) is there but doesn't get in the way.

wine: Quinta Nova de Nossa Senhora do Carmo 2013 Mirabilis Grand Reserva White (Douro)
winery: Quinta Nova de Nossa Senhora do Carmo
review: Spicy wood-aging flavors dominate this wine. It is rich, almost too rich and pushy for its own good, seeming to be more opulent than previous vintages. Nutmeg dominates more than the pineapple and apricot fruit flavors. It could settle down, although it will always be larger than life.
With soft tannins framing herb-infused black cherry, cassis, green tea and oak flavors, this is a nice Cabernet to drink now. Give it an hour or so in a decanter to let it breathe.

Moving towards richness, with a smoked meat character, this offers a rounded, ripe texture. The blackberry flavors are layered with some tight tannins, and boosted by spice and vanilla. A definite for food.

Grove Mill has been working hard on getting their Pinot Noir right, and the staff there have finally succeeded, crafting a lush, mouthfilling wine filled with black cherries and cocoa that linger elegantly on the long finish.

appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Almost all the fruit for this wine comes from Olsen Vineyard. Aromas of green herb are out front, followed by notes of violet, plum, dark chocolate, coffee and black currant. Chocolate, cherry and herb flavors follow. A snap of acidity, the hallmark of this vintage, ups the interest. Best after 2024.

Boroli presents yet another ace with its Villero. There's more to chew on here compared to your standard Barolo and the wine boasts roundness and power. It's a modern, luscious interpretation with creamy vanilla and soft spice lavished over aromas of wild berry and plum. It has the tannins to cut through béchamel sauce.

wine: Caven 2015 Sassella La Priora Riserva  (Valtellina Superiore)
review: New leather, Alpine herb, violet and red berry aromas form the nose. Linear and firmly structured, the rather lean palate features pomegranate, sour cherry and star anise set against firm, fine-grained tannins and bright acidity.

wine: Nectar Of The Dogs 2018 Princess Edition Rosé of Pinot Noir (Santa Barbara County)
appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
review: Aromas of bruised watermelon, a hint of kirsch and a touch of muddy earth show on the nose of this bottling. The palate combines tea, dried cherry and clay, with lots of acidity and a firm texture.

Ebullient aromas of blackberry coulis, crushed pepper and violet introduce this hauntingly pretty Syrah sourced from 50-year-old vines. Made from 100% destemmed fruit and aged in 15 months en barrique (10–20% new), it's a glossy, intensely black-fruited sip wrapped in silky tannins. Irresistible in youth but should develop its more earthen, animal side as it matures through 2030.

appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: This wine opens pleasantly with floral scents over tangy citrus fruit, especially lime. It's tart and juicy, but it seems to close down in the back, and there is an impression of light toast, unexpected in a Viognier.

Round and soft, this warm wine from the southern end of the Côte de Beaune feels rich and generous. It has caramel and yellow fruit flavors, and its crisp acidity will ensure that it will remain fresh and fruity.

wine: Rodney Strong 2004 Chalk Hill Chardonnay (Sonoma County)
review: Immediately likeable for its direct, ripe flavors of candied peaches, kiwis, limes and pineapples. It has just the right acidity and a creamy texture.

appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
review: Shy aromas of pink grapefruit and creamy peach start off this blend of Cabernet Sauvignon, Cabernet Franc and Merlot, with a bit of stoniness riding underneath. The palate is soft and creamy in feel, with an easy melon flavor mixing with a slight lift of lemon. It's a soft, approachable pour that has a lingering creamed peach finish.

appellation: Dry Creek Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: Briary and peppery, with fresh, jammy flavors of wild blackberries, blueberries and chocolate, accented with crisp acidity. You'll find some sandpapery tannins and notes of raisins in the finish of this lusty Zin.

wine: Napa Valley Quilt 2018 The Fabric of the Land Red (Napa Valley)
review: Softly structured, this crowd-pleaser combines Petite Sirah, Merlot, Zinfandel and Petite Verdot. Herbal and dotted in black pepper, the jammy fruit is defined in raspberry and blackberry.

wine: Tait Wines 2014 The Wild Ride Red (Barossa Valley)
review: Despite the steep 15.5% alcohol that adds some heat, this blend has a lot to offer. On the nose, ripe red currant and cranberry fruit mingles with more savory, earthy characters of green olive, tobacco and eucalyptus. The palate is grainy in textured, with a strong savory current propelled by soft, supple tannins and bright acidity.
Light in color and lightly textured, this is a toffee and red-fruit flavored wine that is sweet without great definition.

wine: Carmel 2007 Sha'al Single Vineyard Late Harvest Gewürztraminer (Galilee)
review: This late harvest selection boasts ripe apricot, lychee, golden raisin, honeydew and baked apple fruit characters alongside glimmers of sweet spice, candied orange rind and raw honeycomb. It's full and deliciously weighty in the mouth, with a stunning ginger-infused lift to the long close.

Moncalvina is a soapy, creamy expression of Moscato d'Asti that delivers sweet pulses of stone fruit, honey, acacia, melon and pressed flowers. Pair it with fruit-based desserts such as peach pudding, apple pie or custard.
Raisiny smelling and short on freshness. Full in feel but tasting roasted, stemmy and a little bitter. Finishes baked and earthy, with a lasting leafy quality.

This wine comes from the home region of this producer, and features the local Baga grape. Once difficult to control, this grape can now produce richly structured wines, as it does here. This is packed with as much fruit as tannin—ripe fruit giving red-berry flavors that are bursting with juice as well as acidity. Drink this wine from 2018.

wine: Bernardus 2015 Rosella's Vineyard Pinot Noir (Santa Lucia Highlands)
appellation: Santa Lucia Highlands, Central Coast, California, US
review: Broad aromas of black cherry and black-tea spice make for a dark and full nose, which is enhanced by strong soil components of turned loam and gravel. Dark boysenberry and tart plum skins show on the palate along with more tea spice, making for a very full sipping experience.

Enticing scents of white wild flower, yellow stone fruit and a whiff of honeydew melon lead to a vibrant palate loaded with ripe apricot, cantaloupe and citrus. Baking spice and ginger notes add depth to the lingering finish while fresh acidity lends balance. This will continue to age well and evolve for several years or longer.
There's a thick, slightly muddled quality to this wine (made with Manzoni grapes) that recalls peach, yellow rose, almond and honey. The mouthfeel is soft and medium in intensity.

From a biodynamic vineyard owned by a member of the Fetzer family, this is one of the more aromatic '98 Merlots, with lovely black cherry and blackberry in the nose, topped with smoke and vanilla. It's extremely rich, with complex tannins.

Il Velluto is a thin, neutral smelling wine with distant aromas of fruit and spice over mineral and cedar wood. The wine performs nicely in the mouth however with fresh fruit flavors and a tonic, vibrant feel that would work with simple meat, lamb or pork.

appellation: Central Coast, Central Coast, California, US
review: Cola-like in flavor, with earthier notes of tobacco and leather. Drinks pretty lean, and the tannins are strong. Finshes with a bitterness of acids and tannins.

wine: Le Doubblé Troubblé 2019 Dry Hollow Vineyard Merlot (Columbia Valley (OR))
appellation: Columbia Valley (OR), Oregon Other, Oregon, US
review: This is fascinating—an Oregon side of the Columbia Valley Merlot in a Rhône-shaped bottle released extremely early with the oak pulled way back. Aromas of red plum, muscat gummy and pomegranate lead to pleasantly pure, textured, layered fruit flavors. It's a radically different interpretation of this variety. Give it a bit of additional time in bottle or decant to see it at its best.

wine: Château Calon Ségur 2019 Le Marquis de Calon Ségur Barrel Sample  (Saint-Estèphe)
designation: Le Marquis de Calon Ségur Barrel Sample
review: 93–95. Barrel Sample. The second wine of classed growth Calon Ségur, this is becoming impressive in its own right. This vintage shows the structured side of Saint-Estèphe while also showing generous black fruits and bright acidity. It is set to age well.

A creamy, earthy touch hovers on the nose, blending in with apple flesh and lemon. The palate comes in with ripeness, roundness and vigor but also more of that creaminess. Underneath it all there is a wonderful vein of lemon that is the guiding light until the very long finish. Concentration and texture enhance each other here, all homing in on that citrus zestiness.
This wine is very fresh and forward with its acidity and green bell-pepper flavors. The black currant flavors show some potential, but this is not a wine for aging.

Delicate scents of honeydew melon, orchard fruit and a whisper of white spring flower lift from the glass. The savory palate offers white peach, green apple, sage and a hint of toasted almond alongside bright acidity. A light mineral note signals the close.

wine: Seven Hills 2006 Seven Hills Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Walla Walla Valley (WA))
appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: There is something comfortably old-fashioned about this 100% single-vineyard variety; the alcohol is at 13.5%, the fruit is moderately ripe and detailed with light herb and sweet spice. Wild blueberry aromas and flavors come wrapped in a thin layer of bark.

This Syrah is really attractive upfront, with aromas of sweet pastry crust, baked plum, licorice and cracked pepper. The plum and blackberry fruit is balanced by some savory elements on the palate, which doesn't show a lot of weight or length. A pretty wine to drink over the next couple of years.

Rusting in color, but showing some of the positive signs of maturing Rioja. For instance, the bouquet provides spiced raisin, dried plum and cinnamon, and together the nose is as old-fashioned as it comes. Dried cherry and apricot flavors mix with pepper and tobacco on the palate, while the finish is warm and accented by vanilla. Imported by Palm Bay Imports.

A much less dense wine than either '95 or '96, reflecting the vintage. Red berry fruit aromas with dusty tobacco notes. Lighter, juicy mouthfeel with chocolate and leather notes. Mildly drying finish. Well-made but light, with a definite herbaceous quality.

Crisp, minerally cherry aromas come with a complex note of desert herbs. This feels totally fresh and full, basically just right. Nicely oaked, ripe flavors of plum and berry fruits are chocolaty, dry and spicy on the finish.

Still quite closed, this is a firm wine with all its tight tannins still in place. It's dry at this stage, although the fruit is going to develop well. Acidity and a hint of perfumed red-berry flavors promise a good future. Drink from 2020.

appellation: Dundee Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: Here's a big, full-throttle, wide-open style of Chardonnay. It's richly aromatic, deep gold in hue, and loaded with ripe tree fruits. Toasty and flavorful, it's cloaked in a rich dressing of buttered nuts. It was aged for 11 months in one-quarter new French oak, and is drinking beautifully at this relatively young age.

wine: Scarlet of Paris 2015 Rosé (Vin de France)
appellation: Vin de France, France Other, France
review: This is a ripe and fruity rosé, with forward notes of lychee, rose water, peach gummies and tropical fruit salad. The palate is round and plump in similarly rich fruit flavors, with just enough acidity to keep it from feeling completely flat. Drink up.

wine: Andrew Murray 2008 McGinley Vineyard Syrah (Santa Ynez Valley)
appellation: Santa Ynez Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: Give this lush, rich Syrah two or three years to soften and develop in the bottle. It's a very good wine, offering impressive blackberry, blueberry and cherry-pie filling flavors, wrapped into fine acids and tannins. But it's fresh and young and will get better. Better well into 2011.
Vanilla and floral aromas have a suspicious artificiality to them, and in the mouth it's a sweet, sugary ride toward a cloying finish.

wine: Viña Cobos 2012 Bramare Marchiori Vineyard Malbec (Luján de Cuyo)
appellation: Luján de Cuyo, Mendoza Province, Argentina
review: Toasty woodsmoke aromas are matched by wild berry, cassis, cherry and marshmallow scents on the nose of this huge Malbec. Creamy feeling but also inky and fully concentrated, this tastes like black cherry and cough drops. Candied ripeness carries onto the finish along with chocolate and dry spice flavors. Drink through 2022.

wine: Moonbase Cellars 2019 Les Collines Syrah Block 31 Syrah (Walla Walla Valley (WA))
appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: This is an inaugural release from this producer, and it flat-out impresses. Coming from one of the valley's top Syrah sites, it was cofermented with 4% Viognier with two pick dates two weeks apart. The aromas are expressive, with piercingly pure notes of fresh raspberry, blueberry, violet, medicine, orange peel, smoked meat and dried herbs. The fruit flavors show a lot of density while retaining a sense of levity. It's yummy.

Part of a range of wines that showcases the different styles of Portugal's regions, This wine is smooth, creamily textured and with a warm ripe character. It has pineapple and mango as well as crisper lemon flavors to give a rich wine that is still poised and finely balanced. Drink now.

appellation: Yolo County, Central Valley, California, US
review: An abundance of floral and savory flavors drives this full-bodied, dry and mouth-filling wine. It's not fruity per se, but has a good core of white peach along with almond and white-tea notes. This 50-50 blend of Albariño and Verdelho will bring a welcome change of pace to the table.

wine: Pagter Brothers 2013 Pinot Noir (Paso Robles Willow Creek District)
appellation: Paso Robles Willow Creek District, Central Coast, California, US
review: Made by brothers Scott and Gib Pagter, this rich wine is scented with sandalwood, strawberry, incense and chaparral shrub. There is a core of red cherry and ripe cranberry on the palate, where touches of sagebrush, eucalyptus and a strong minty freshness provide lots of energetic verve.

wine: Quivira 2018 Wine Creek Ranch G-S-M (Dry Creek Valley)
appellation: Dry Creek Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: Letting 60% Grenache lead the way with companionship from 20% each of Syrah and Mourvèdre, this well-made wine is fruity in strawberry and nicely savory in cedar, dried herb and lavender. Rounded, juicy and complex, it takes a light touch to the varietal gaminess and intrigue of garrigue and white pepper.

Fragrant, full bodied and boasting great finesse, this delicious Barolo hits all the right buttons. It opens with enticing aromas of woodland berry, rose, camphor, botanical herb and exotic spice while the elegantly structured palate doles out juicy red cherry, crushed raspberry, licorice and cinnamon. Firm, fine-grained tannins and fresh acidity keep it impeccably balanced. It's already tempting but hold for even more complexity. Drink 2024–2046.
Tropical aromas suggest bath soap. A tight, lemony palate has an oily feel, while flavors of melon, lychee and lime are exotic, finishing with an oily essence of white flowers.

wine: Solminer 2015 deLanda Vineyard Blaufränkisch (Santa Ynez Valley)
appellation: Santa Ynez Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: David and Anna deLaski planted this obscure grape on their home vineyard to honor her Austrian roots—the results are fascinating. A dark earthy graphite-driven minerality contrasts with the brighter sweeter strawberry and cherry fruit on the nose, and then the bone-dry sip pops with a candied raspberry flavor, enhanced by fennel and white pepper.

wine: Dion 2016 Winemaker's Reserve Pinot Noir (Chehalem Mountains)
appellation: Chehalem Mountains, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: Chewy and tannic, this young wine is dense and a bit stiff. Black fruits, espresso and cacao combine to accent the dark flavors. It spent 18 months in half new French oak, and should continue to develop nicely over the next few years.

wine: I Veroni 1999  Vin Santo del Chianti Rufina
appellation: Vin Santo del Chianti Rufina, Tuscany, Italy
review: Dark amber in color, this sophisticated vin santo offers aromas of resin, pine nut, caramel candy, molasses, chestnuts, honey and dried apricots. It has some spicy tones in the mouth, buffered around its sweet core, and long nutty flavors on the finish.

appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: This flavorful, herbal Syrah spends its time in one-year-old oak; the reserve is made in 100% new oak. It is a pure, distinctive, cool-climate Syrah with a strong, dark, spicy, gamy streak of pungent flavor. It smells and tastes like ripe, almost raisined grapes, hung meat, boysenberry syrup, smoke, tar and coffee, all infused with wild herbs. Pay attention to the finish; that's where it really shines, as it slides through spice, earth, herb and, ultimately, into chocolate.

wine: Elderton 2015 Neil Ashmead Grand Tourer Shiraz (Barossa Valley)
review: Ripe cassis and blackberries are in the fore here, but they're backed by a meaty, smoky and earthy quality, along with a touch of warming baking spices that make this an instant wine for the wintertime. It's rich and powerful in style but also silky-textured with that intriguing and lingering core of savory smokiness and a spine of grainy tannins. This is just barely ready to drink now, but cellaring for up to 10 years should be pretty rewarding.

This entry-level red from St. Hallett displays ample cedar and cinnamon spice, cassis and plum fruit and judicious touches of mocha and vanilla, all framed by soft tannins and crisp, tangy acids. Drink now.

wine: Longboard 2010 Mavericks Goosechase Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Alexander Valley)
review: This is a seriously good Cabernet. You can stand it against anything in California and it will acquit itself with pride. It shows the soft tannins and herbaceousness of Alexander Valley, but is rich in blackberries, cherries and mocha, with a long, spicy finish. The result is a deliciously complex wine, dry, full-bodied and rich. Drink now–2016.

Aromas of moist earth, Mediterranean scrub and wet stone waft out of the glass. It's racy and lean, offering raw cherry, coconut and a hint of coffee bean alongside brisk acidity and close-grained drying tannins.

Starts off with an interesting bouquet of honey, tapioca, peach, tropical fruit and vanilla, but it's disappointingly thin and hollow in the mouth. Leaves behind a faint fruitiness and lots of acidity.
Here's a good, soft, easy-to-drink red blend. It's dry and ripe, with berry, cherry and currant flavors.

appellation: Santa Ynez Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: The winery's best Hilltops in years, dry and elegantly structured. There's real power to the baked black cherry and currant fruit, with all sorts of meaty, earthy, peppery nuances that linger long into the finish. The alcohol is robust, but in keeping with the wine's volume, giving it a rich, warming headiness. Drink now–2018, as suits your taste.

92–94. Barrel Sample. Rich, structured and with some stylish tannins, this is a wine with a fine future. Its blackberry flavors are ably supported by the structure of the wine and this will continue as it matures.

Red berry, rose petal, white pepper and chopped herb are just some of the aromas you'll find on this. The bright full-bodied palate delivers crushed raspberry, dark cherry, star anise and tobacco alongside firm refined tannins and vibrant acidity. It's already tempting but will be even better with more bottle age. Drink 2021–2033.

appellation: South Eastern Australia, Australia Other, Australia
review: This Chardonnay is fragrant and flavorful, full of easy, bright pineapple and peach flavors. Round and full in the mouth, with a little sweetness. 80,000 cases produced. Imported by Pacific Wine Partners.

wine: Alta Vista 2010 Serenade Single Vineyard Malbec (Mendoza)
review: This single-vineyard Malbec is superripe and borderline syrupy on the nose, with liqueur, leather and other generous aromas. The palate is huge and grabby, with full extraction and immense flavors of blackberry, fig and cassis. This is flavor packed, but a bit soft and hot on the finish. Drink now through 2018.

Riserva Vigna Castellero is an approachable and elegant food wine with focused aromas of wild berry and cassis, backed by mineral, cola and powdered licorice. There's a polished and fine nature to the mouthfeel and the wine would stand up to juicy filet mignon topped with foie gras and mushroom pâté.

The power of this wine is palpable. Great swathes of rich berry fruits roll around the palate with a not-too-sweet juicy acidity. It is, of course, young, powered by tannins, sweet plum juice and an intensely ripe structure. It needs many years, so don't drink before 2030.

An opaque purple color and cooked, stewy aromas of beef soup and raisin are telling. Confirmation of a stewed wine comes on the palate, which is sappy and obese. Baked black fruit flavors are overweight throughout.

appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
review: A touch of hibiscus nectar seems to sweeten this gorgeously floral, fruity Gewürztraminer. It's chock full of characteristic rose petal, lychee and stone fruit flavors, but also bright, lemony and balanced despite its bold alcohol content.

wine: Lowden Hills 2004 Boushey Vineyards Syrah (Columbia Valley (WA))
appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Varietal and showing some of the typical gamy, earthy flavors of Boushey vineyard Syrah, this is a forward, aromatic wine with interesting scents of leather, compost and pepper. Green tea flavors fill in where the very tart, acidic red berry fruit fades out.

wine: Les Vins Skalli 2005 Robert Skalli South of France Chardonnay (Vin de Pays d'Oc)
appellation: Vin de Pays d'Oc, Languedoc-Roussillon, France
review: Very soft, very clean, a little neutral, this wine has apricot and green plum flavors, touches of toast. It is fresh, rounded and soft, neatly finished with acidity and a fruit skin texture.

This lush wine is sourced from an estate vineyard and barrel fermented in neutral French oak. Sappy and sexy, it hits the palate with rich flavors of apple sauce and peach pie, along with accents of toasted hazelnuts. Despite the implied decadence, it's firmly anchored in vivid acids that keep it lively.

wine: Santa Sofia 1995 Gioé  (Amarone della Valpolicella Classico)
appellation: Amarone della Valpolicella Classico, Veneto, Italy
review: The complex nose features tobacco, raisin, rum liqueur and apple peel. The mouthfeel is racy courtesy of healthy acids, and delivers ripe red fruit. Substantial yet fine-grained tannins give the finish a necessary edge. In addition, latent bitter chocolate and coffee flavors add to the overall character.

wine: Leonard Kreusch 2018 Estate Label Beerenauslese Huxelrebe (Rheinhessen)
review: Bright white peach and grapefruit flavors are shaded by hints of earth and smoke in this juicy but slightly savory dessert wine. It's light in body but lusciously textured, a honeyed sip best enjoyed now–2025.

Wet and citrusy smelling, with a touch of toasty oak. Good and medium-bodied on the palate, with decent acidity and balance. Tastes like spiced apple and melon, with vanilla and mild woodspice on the finish. Well done for under $10.

wine: Benhaim Family Winery 2012 Reserve Cabernet Sauvignon (Upper Galilee)
review: Aromas of mixed berry preserves and geranium leaf prepare the palate for flavors of fruits of the wood, dark chocolate, tobacco leaf and orange zest. Strong fruit flavors and acidity compensate for strong tannins. The long, satisfying finish is marked by a final touch of brightness.

wine: Harney Lane 2011 Lizzy James Vineyard Zinfandel (Lodi)
review: This is a Captain America-sized Zin, muscular and strong in walls of huge, dusty dark fruit. Firm in tannins, juicy and swirling in vanilla and cinnamon toast flavors, it spent 22 months swaddled in French oak, an imprint that lets itself be known in the wine. Lay this baby down until 2015 or so, or let it breathe before enjoying with racks of ribs.

wine: Carlisle 2014 Old Vines Zinfandel (Russian River Valley)
appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: This is a blend from several vineyard sites, including Banfield, Saitone, Carlisle, Montafi and Papera, each boasting more than 100-year-old vines. A chocolate cordial note dominates the palate, as bold cherry, rhubarb, cinnamon and citrus flavors wander in. It's a steal for the price, too.

The middle wine in the trilogy of wines from the Molinié family at Ponzac, this is a ripe wine that has density, some firm tannins and rich black-plum fruit flavors. It is concentrated and firm at first and then fills out with the richness. Drink this wine from 2018.

From a trio of vineyards the winery otherwise vineyard-designates, including Spring Hill, Saltonstall and Nobles, this Pinot is rustic in truffled earth and dried herb, the earthiness of the Pommard clone grapes out in full force.
88-90 Barrel sample. Very sweet fruit, deliciously approachable. Chocolate and ripe black fruit. The layer of tannin is important to keep all this opulence together.

appellation: Sangiovese di Romagna, Central Italy, Italy
review: This wine has loads of balsam and menthol-like notes, which I find particularly attractive. Candied cherry almond and a brambly quality add more interesting layers. The wine's impression on the palate is balanced yet lean with spicy crispness and a sour note on the finish.
Soft and full in the mouth, with spice adding an extra dimension to the broad berry fruits. The wine is ready to drink, its acidity melding well into the richness. The final taste is solid and dense.

wine: Domaine de la Terre Rouge 2001 Roussanne (Sierra Foothills)
appellation: Sierra Foothills, Sierra Foothills, California, US
review: Here's a big, fruity puppy of a wine, filled with life and zest and wagging a friendly tail. You'll love the rich lime and peach flavors, with their hint of spearmint and vanilla and long, dry finish.

wine: Malibràn 2012 Ruio Brut  (Conegliano Valdobbiadene Prosecco Superiore)
appellation: Conegliano Valdobbiadene Prosecco Superiore, Veneto, Italy
review: Ruio Brut is a simple and clean Prosecco Superiore that offers peach, citrus and crushed mineral. The effervescence is soft and foamy but the finish is dryer than most Italian sparklers from the general Prosecco category.

Fragrant and refined, this shows enticing aromas of wild herb, rose petal, dark spice, red berry and a whiff of camphor. Luminous and elegant, the vibrant palate has juicy Marasca cherry, cranberry, star anise and white pepper while bright acidity and taut polished tannins provide the framework. It's still young but already possesses terrific poise. Drink 2021–2033.

Tutti-frutti berry aromas are medicinal like cherry cough drops and red licorice sticks. An inexact palate lacks structure, while this tastes of medicinal plum and raspberry prior to a lightweight finish.

wine: De Bortoli NV Emeri Sparkling Pinot Grigio (Australia)
review: De Bortoli's Emeri line of sparkling wines are not conventional Pinot Noir-Chardonnay blends. This one is Pinot Grigio with bubbles, the usually muted aromas of the variety perked up to show grapefruit and fig notes. The wine is soft and fullish in body, with hints of fig coming through on the palate.

A blend of Merlot and Cabernet Sauvignon, this is a powerful, rich wine. The structure has now softened, giving perfumed and ripe black-fruit flavors. Touches of licorice and dark chocolate contrast the bold fruitiness. Drink now.

Pointy, inky aromas are top-heavy and electric. Those characteristics carry over onto a shocked palate, which is jagged in feel due to hard tannins and blazing acidity. Plum and currant flavors are wide awake, while this Malbec blend tastes peppery and herbal on a fiery finish.

White spring flower and citrus aromas lead the way on this juicy, savory wine. On the bright palate, a touch of cake spice accents succulent grapefruit, lemon drop and green apple alongside fresh acidity. A white almond note fills in the finish.
This is a softly textured wine, with flavors of ripe cantaloupe, perfumed acidity and an attractive light touch of texture. Drink now.

wine: Peacock Family Vineyard 2001 Cabernet Sauvignon (Spring Mountain District)
appellation: Spring Mountain District, Napa, California, US
review: Some of the grapes got overripe during this remarkably long, dry, warm vintage, to judge from the raisiny aromas. Then, too, the wine has a hot mouthfeel and finish.

wine: René Muré 2017 Clos St Landelin Pinot Noir (Alsace)
review: A gamy touch hangs over red-currant and tart cherry notes on the nose. The palate comes with subtle depth that brings forth an unexpected intensity of red fruit. Tannins are supple and fine; the body is slender and sinuous. This wine is elegant and lasting.

Ripe and smoky, with attractive nuances to the forward bouquet. This is a nice wine with spunky plum flavors balanced by adequate but not overpowering oak. Cola, wood grain and toast notes help the finish along. Medium in weight and pure; mildly tannic. Imported by Mediterranean Wine Imports.

A wonderful ready-to-drink Barolo with an amiable personality. Dark-cherry fruit is accented by a touch of orangey dryness; the body is amply weighty but not heavy. There's nothing here not to like, and once again, it's drinkable now. Belying the quality, this is a secondary wine from the sensational Bricco Roche vineyard.

appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
review: With dark aromas of prune, black tea and baked earth, this is a ripe, modern wine with sound balance and depth of flavor. It deals a nice mix of fresh berry fruit flavors blended with oak, while the finish rings on with spice, mint and proper acidity.

wine: Pech Merle 2013 Sauvignon Blanc (Dry Creek Valley)
appellation: Dry Creek Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: Made from 100% Sauvignon Blanc fermented and aged in stainless steel tanks, this wine shows why Dry Creek Valley has achieved such a fine reputation with this variety. Totally dry and brisk in acidity, it has savory flavors of lemons and limes, passionfruit, gooseberries and white pepper. Awesome with Vietnamese, Ethiopian and Indian fare calling for white wine.

wine: Fabre en Provence 2017 Rosé (Côtes de Provence)
review: For 17 generations, the Fabre family has been making wine in Provence. The latest vintage to bear their name is ripe and concentrated, a product of the hot, dry year. The rich red fruits have just the right amount of acidity and of tangy, zesty texture. Drink now.

Adequate on the nose, with staid berry aromas. The palate is narrow and tart, with cherry flavors and edgy heat. And the finish doesn't really change the scene much. Too snappy and short on personality; a step down from previous vintages.

wine: Stark-Condé 2005 Twin Peak Vineyard Unfined and Unfiltered Syrah (Jonkershoek Valley)
designation: Twin Peak Vineyard Unfined and Unfiltered
review: A lovely nose of cedar, pepper and berry is followed by flavors of smoke, pepper and energetic fruit in this big red. A touch aggressive on first taste, the wine is rounded by good acidity and elegant spice layers.

A Merlot-based wine from old vines on the plains at the base of the hill of Saint-Emilion. This is soft and fresh, with an element of wood and smoky tannins to give structure and aging potential. The ripe, jammy fruit flavors are balanced by freshness and vibrant acidity.
This soft wine is creamy and smooth thanks to the 35% of Chardonnay in the blend. Viognier and Arinto add perfume and some crispness. Packed with fruit, the wine is ready to drink.

appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: This is three quarters Syrah, sourced from Klipsun, Hedges Bel Villa, and Lewis; with a touch of Merlot from the Meek vineyard. Dark, spicy and lush, its sappy fruit has a lively snap to it, with a hint of licorice and smoke. Not the funky “in the rocks” Walla Walla style of Syrah, this is for those who want the fruit forward, front and center.

wine: Villa Sandi NV Opere Trevigiane Serenissima Metodo Classico Sparkling (Vino Spumante)
review: Aromas of field flower, white stone fruit and a whiff of toasted bread crust lead the way. The vivacious palate offers apple, hazelnut and a hint of candied citrus zest alongside tangy acidity.

appellation: Red Mountain, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: The aromas suggest notes of iron, medicine and earth, along with dark berry. The palate has depth of flavor but with an acidic snap that ups the ante.

wine: Clos du Val 1999 Palisade Vineyard Zinfandel (Stags Leap District)
appellation: Stags Leap District, Napa, California, US
review: A single-vineyard Zin bursting with ripe, jammy red and black rasberry fruit and sweet , vanilla-tinged, smoky aromas from French oak.  Stresses elegance rather than weight or size, with pretty, melted tannins and a soft, velvety mouthfeel.

Made from Nerello Mascalese and Nerello Cappuccio, this shows bright berry aromas of blackberry and cassis, with cola, dried ginger and polished mineral notes. The mouthfeel is clean and bright, with a touch of chopped mint.

wine: Famille Ravoire 2019 Olivier Ravoire Banderet Red (Côtes du Rhône)
appellation: Côtes du Rhône, Rhône Valley, France
review: Dried plums are perfumed by hints of anise and smoked meat in this rich, peppery Grenache-dominant red. Full bodied and plump on the palate, it balances ripe, opulent black fruit flavors with a fresh spine of acidity and plush, cocoapowder tannins. Ready now but should hold through 2024.

wine: Sheldrake Point 2017 Estate Bottled Pinot Gris (Finger Lakes)
appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
review: Aromas of nearly wilted honeysuckle and lemon peel carry the nose. The palate is light in profile, with mild acidity pushing along apple and sharp citrus flavors. It ends a bit bitter on a candlewax note.

appellation: Spring Mountain District, Napa, California, US
review: Here's a textbook Napa Cab. It's concentrated in black currant flavors, with the best tannic structure money can buy. Soft and elegant in the mouth, with a long, elegant finish. Could use some individuality, though, as it's firmly in the international style.

Aromas of Mediterranean brush, cooking spice and dark-skinned berry set the tone. Made with organically farmed Sangiovese, the lithe palate offers cherry, clove and tobacco alongside youthfully austere tannins. Drink 2024–2029.

Aromas of mature white stone fruit, hawthorn and citrus mingle together in the glass. The tangy palate delivers ripe apricot, grapefruit and crushed Mediterranean herb set against crisp acidity. It closes on a hint of brine.

When a wine is as dense, plummy and pretty as this, you're in business. It's somewhat round and fat, but it's rightly balanced by driving cherry fruit and bitter chocolate. An LBV rich enough to top off vanilla ice cream yet vital enough to be drunk by the glass is a good thing to have in the house.

wine: Château la Mascaronne 2020 Rosé (Côtes de Provence)
review: This pale-colored wine is ripe and full of wild strawberry flavors. Textured acidity gives spice and a saline tang that will soften as the wine ages a bit. Drink from late 2021. Organic.

appellation: Friuli Colli Orientali, Northeastern Italy, Italy
review: Aromas of chamomile flower, yellow peach and candied citrus zest lead the nose on this bright dessert wine. On the palate, notes of acacia honey, fig and sweet almond accent a core of mature apricot. Fresh acidity keeps it from being cloyingly sweet.

Notes of ripe pear and dry hay appear on the open nose. The palate is light and fresh with lemon but also rounded by ripe pear juiciness. Purity, vividness and that lovely hay perfume are chief characteristics. The finish is off dry but balanced.

wine: Smith-Madrone 2010 Estate Bottled Chardonnay (Spring Mountain District)
appellation: Spring Mountain District, Napa, California, US
review: This Chardonnay has plenty of ripe pineapple, pear and tropical fruit flavors. Having aged in 100% new French oak barrels, it offers rich notes of vanilla and buttered toast. Like all of Smith-Madrone's wines, this has great acidity and minerality, and even some tannins. Give this some time, and see how it is after 2017.

wine: Rasa 2009 Plus One Cabernet Sauvignon (Red Mountain)
appellation: Red Mountain, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Crisp and penetrating, with great fruit purity, the wine's core bears cassis and black cherry flavors. The tannins are supple, even silky, and the finish is smooth, with dark accents.

wine: Kendall-Jackson 1997 Buckeye Vyd Cabernet Sauvignon (Sonoma County)
review: Big mountain fruit here throws powerful aromas of ripe plum, thyme and bacon, while full-scale oaking yields maple aromas, vanilla flavors, and coffee on the finish. The wood element is a little weighty at this point, but there's solid fruit to support it.

wine: Koehler 2007 Oak Savanna Vineyard Sangiovese (Santa Ynez Valley)
appellation: Santa Ynez Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: One of the better Sangioveses out there, because it avoids the pitfalls of unbalanced flavors and textures. It's a dry, crisply acidic wine that's ripe enough in cherries and cola to satisfy. Good job. The next step is to build in complexity.

Really good and interesting Syrah, with chocolate, campfire, menthol and prune on the nose. With airing the wine quickly settles into a deep, smooth berry and chocolate groove, while the finish deals pure tannins and comfort. Ripe but not raisiny; a really nice example of Jumilla Syrah, with 4% Viognier blended in for lightness (and it still weighs in at 14.9%).

wine: Cameron Hughes 2006 Lot 58 Chardonnay (Santa Barbara County)
appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
review: With its crisp spine of acidity, this wine clearly comes from a cool climate. The flavors show long hang-time notes of ripe pineapples and pears. There's too much oak for balance, given the dominating blast of caramel, but the wine will appeal to many for the price.

wine: J Wrigley 2016 828 Single Clone Estate Pinot Noir (McMinnville)
review: Firm and precise, this pushes tart cranberry/raspberry fruit up front, with a seam of citrus oil and rind. Grapefruit highlights and lemony acidity flow into a lingering finish, with a comet's tail of chocolate.
Aromas of iris, tobacco and underbrush lead the way. The savory medium-bodied palate offers raspberry jam, clove and white pepper alongside firm, fine-grained tannins. Drink 2023–2032.

wine: Terroir 2009 by Ant Moore Sauvignon Blanc (Marlborough)
review: Crisp and brisk on the palate, with hints of grapefruit, melon and fig accented by herbal, leafy notes. The flavors fade quickly on the finish, but the wine makes for a pleasant apéritif.
Light to medium in body, this red-fruited Shiraz is a bit simple, but offers extremely fruity, cherry-berry flavors. It verges on confected, then turns crisp on the finish.

Named after a Roman city that existed in the Douro region, this wine is impressively balanced, rich with both tannins and vanilla flavors. They go with the perfumed blackberry fruits and the wine's sophistication. Drink from 2022.

One of Australia's most expensive and sought-after Cabernet blends, Mount Mary's Quintet has failed to impress more than one American critic. It's an appealing, well-crafted wine that combines leather, cherry and dried herbs in a somewhat lean, crisp style that delivers a long, mineral-and-cedar finish.

appellation: Red Mountain, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: This wine is predominantly Cabernet Sauvignon (85%) with the remainder Cabernet Franc, Merlot and Syrah. Reserved aromas of toast, high-toned herbs, coffee and blue and black fruit lead to dense, rich, structured dark fruit flavors that show depth along with vibrant acidity and a long finish. This wine is built for the long haul and will be best from 2021–2028.

Zesty and light footed, this dry varietal Marsanne offers a fresher expression of this typically lavishly textural grape. There's a delicacy to the palate marked by slightly creamy tones of fresh yellow apple, Asian pear and peach. The finish is rimmed by a pleasantly salty tone. Enjoy now–2022.
Green apple, citrus and spring blossom aromas waft out of the glass. Crisp and linear, the palate offers green melon, Meyer lemon and white almond alongside vibrant acidity.

wine: Tenuta di Sesta 2014  Brunello di Montalcino
review: Underbrush, toasted nut, exotic spice and plum aromas lead the way. On the rounded palate, you'll find dried cherry, crushed clove and a hint of coffee bean set against fine-grained tannins and bright acidity. Drink 2021–2026.

wine: Stuart Cellars 2004 Limited Estate Reserve Tatria Meritage Red Table Wine Red (Temecula)
designation: Limited Estate Reserve Tatria Meritage Red Table Wine
review: The grapes had no problem getting ripe, to judge by the flood of red cherry marmalade, cola and milk chocolate flavors. With its dryness and softness, the wine is delicious, if a little one-dimensional.

Sourced from the cool Awatere Valley, this wine displays some of that region's characteristic leafiness. It also shows hints of cruciferous and root vegetables, medium body and crisp, red-fruit flavors on the finish.

appellation: Cayuga Lake, Finger Lakes, New York, US
review: This bouyant red starts with red berry and spice aromas, leading into a balanced, pleasant array of red berry, black cherry and cedar on the palate. Friendly and expressive, it's a quaffable wine for myriad occasions.

Just a hint of horsey leather over dense, cherry liqueur flavors. The wine is earthy but carries it well, and the super-saturated fruit offers substantial flavors that carry the authority and taste of old vines.

This fruity Pinot is packed with plush red berries quietly backed by savory spice. Although the palate has a softness and roundness, the astringency of both tannins and fruit is difficult to get past. It's a light- to medium-weight wine for everyday drinking.

Aromas of black cherry and summer farm stand pave the way for flavors of blackberry, pomegranate, roasted tomato and green pepper. It is bright in the mouth, with barely-there tannins and a splash of cranberry on the finish.

Forceful on the nose, with red berry aromas leading to an angular, high-acid palate with zesty, almost sour flavors of raspberry and red currant. Tastes herbal as well, as the wine's scouring acidity makes for a long but not very flavorful finish.

Silky layers of sweet cream and honey seem to edge this full-bodied white sourced from Marsanne vines averaging 50 years old. While vinified in oak (30% new) and voluptuous in mouthfeel, it's a breathtaking, sunny sip balanced by pert Meyer lemon and tangerine acidity along with that classic salty finish. Ready now but should drink beautifully through 2030.

wine: Henri Bourgeois 2009 Le M.D. de Bourgeois  (Sancerre)
review: This is great Sancerre from the Monts Damnés vineyard. It shows all the right varietal character, stylized by initial austerity, flint and a dense texture. Gradually it opens up to show a balance of acidity and richness.

A hint of vanilla appears amid notes of crushed black cherry and blackberry. The palate burgeons with fleshy black cherry fruit that could do with a little more precision, but the fruit, texture and grip are out in combined force. Lovely freshness on the finish.

wine: Château de la Rivière 2017 Barrel Sample  (Fronsac)
review: 89–91. Barrel Sample. Big, firm tannins add structure to rich fruit, this is dark and concentrated with hints of bitter chocolate and juicy acidity. This wine will age well, drink from 2022.

wine: Auguste Bonhomme 2016 La Forcine Sauvignon Blanc (Vin de France)
appellation: Vin de France, France Other, France
review: This cool-climate wine is crisp, steely and full of fruit. Its acidity and touch of saltiness add to its refreshing nature.

wine: Rusack 2014 Solomon Hills Vineyard Pinot Noir (Santa Maria Valley)
appellation: Santa Maria Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: This excellent bottling blends power with finesse, showing fresh red and black cherries, a smoky earthiness and pretty hints of red rose petals and hibiscus on the nose. The flavors are very cohesive and expertly woven on the palate, where bright red fruit is lifted by star anise spice and framed by a taut texture and uplifting acid. Stunning depth.
A rich and sophisticated wine, with loads of dark fruit and exotic spice. It's bright ruby-garnet appearance, with bright acidity and a fresh, lively finish.

From the northern end of the Haut-Médoc region, close to Saint-Estèphe, this dark-hued wine is still very structured. Smoky wood-aging flavors give complexity that balances the ripe black currant fruitiness. It's still developing, so don't drink before 2018.

A gorgeous array of mineral tones anchor this vivacious medium-bodied white wine. Ripe juicy tangerine and grapefruit flavors are accented by hints of pollen and dusty earth. While creamy and textured, it finishes lean with a bracing hit of lime acidity. Drink now through 2023.

appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: After an initial clarified butter aroma invites one in, this fleshy, full-bodied white is smooth and delicate, taking on body and weight as it develops in the glass. Anise, green apple and pineapple flavors meet a coterie of toasted oak and smoke.

A standard but well-done red blend. The nose deals lively plum and blackberry aromas, but also a slight hint of pickle. It's juicy and ripe-feeling on the palate, where red-fruit flavors of plum, cherry and raspberry are dominant. Solid and warm on the finish, and healthy and honest overall. It's 75% Malbec with 15% Syrah and 10% Bonarda.

appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: This opens with a strong scent of herb and bud; it's sharp and aggressively leafy. The wine follows with similar flavors. The light fruit flavors of plum and berry are quickly suffocated with leaf, herb, earth, spice and tannin. Time may be the answer.

wine: Royal Tokaji 2016 Betsek Single Vineyard 6 Puttonyos Aszú First Growth  (Tokaji)
designation: Betsek Single Vineyard 6 Puttonyos Aszú First Growth
