review: This Tokaji Aszu is golden in color, with ethereal aromas of honeysuckle, acacia, fresh peach and canned apricots. Flavors come to life in the mouth, with honeycomb, pear and canned apricot. Well-balanced acidity is an excellent foil for the delightful sweetness.

Aromas of ripe dark-skinned fruit, forest floor, rose and wild mint shape the enticing nose. Elegantly structured and full of flavor, the linear, focused palate delivers mature Marasca cherry, blood orange, licorice and tobacco set against a backbone of refined tannins. Drink 2023 though 2035.
Smooth and fat in texture, this wine has pear and butterscotch aromas, candied apple and butter flavors, and an almost sweet finish. It's a big, soft wine with low acidity and a short finish.

For a large-scale offering at this price, this wine hits it out of the park. It honors the winery's early days with the variety and shows off a great vintage. Grapefruit, peach and tangerine spark atop a subtle minerality and crisp mouthfeel.
Typical Sauvignon, well executed. Struck flint aromas add an intriguing aspect to this wine, which otherwise delivers melon and fig notes on the midpalate and a zesty, citrusy finish.

wine: Michel Torino 2012 Don David Finca la Primavera #3 Torrontés (Cafayate)
review: Musky lime aromas and tropical perfume notes steal the bouquet. The palate is full, driving and demanding, with sheer acids and crisp flavors of lemon and passion fruit. A touch of sweet mango and offsetting bitterness work the finish. Drink this intense Torrontés as soon as possible.

Another crowd-pleaser for its ripely sweet fruit and smooth, polished mouthfeel. Lots of black cherries, currants and anise, in addition to smoke and vanilla. Really dry, balanced and elegant. Finishes clean and vibrant in youthful acids.

wine: Joleté 2017 Cuvée Select Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)
appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: A sensational value, this sends up an aromatic mix of rose lotion, cherry blossom and fresh herbs. The wine is smooth and balanced, with plenty of pretty cherry fruit loading up the center palate. Tannins are moderate, ripe and proportionate. At this price, it's virtually peerless.

wine: Phelps Creek 2007 Celilo Vineyard Chardonnay (Columbia Gorge (OR))
appellation: Columbia Gorge (OR), Oregon Other, Oregon, US
review: Rich Cushman made this wine; it nicely expresses the minerality and tight fruit that characterizes this excellent vineyard. This is at first a rather austere, compact wine, but it is dense with layers of flavor and representative of one of the most unique terroirs in the Pacific Northwest.

appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Clean, fresh and simple, this does not claim to be “unoaked” but it carries that style in its flavors, a snappy mix of green apple, pineapple and grapefruit. Good everyday drinking.

appellation: Santa Ynez Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: Here's a refreshingly crisp Riesling whose high acidity makes it a natural for friendly fare. It has subtle flavors of citrus fruits and minerally chalk, while a bit of residual sugar gives it a mellow roundness.
Earthy and leathery, with aromas and flavors of black olives and dried cherries. It's medium-bodied, with a chewy tannic structure that calls for rare beef at this stage of its development.

wine: Paul Jaboulet Aîné 1998 Les Traverses Red (Côtes-du-Ventoux)
review: There's a youthful and dominant smashed-berry element to the bouquet. A little bit of citrus rind and nutmeg add nuance to an otherwise full-blast and friendly southern Rhône quaffer. Has balance, style and a woody finish. Best Buy.

wine: San Quirico 2014  Vernaccia di San Gimignano
appellation: Vernaccia di San Gimignano, Tuscany, Italy
review: Fragrant and luminous, this vibrant wine opens with aromas of stone fruit and freshly chopped mint. The linear palate offers citrus zest, aromatic herb and bitter almond while mouthwatering acidity provides balance. It boasts a clean, crisp finish.

With its elegant structure and a layer of firm tannins, this wine has density, a dry core and the black-currant freshness that comes with the vintage. The tannins will allow this wine to age well. Drink from 2023.

Brawny in cherry, cola and baking spice, this has a soft, approachable midpalate of balanced weight and ripeness. Integrated acidity boosts layers of strawberry, mint and citrus that complement one another well. This is a great value for the quality.

Now owned by Bollinger, Ayala's Champagnes have seen great improvement in recent years. This nonvintage Brut is complex, with its dry character given weight by a hint of toast, almonds and a taut aftertaste.

appellation: Livermore Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: Steven Kent Mirassou is practically single-handedly reviving Livemore Valley's historic reputation for Cabernet Sauvignon. The wine shows a wonderfully lush structure and impeccable tannins, framing slightly herbal, dusty flavors of blackberries, blueberries, cherries and cedar. Really fine, and a superb accompaniment for rich meats and cheeses.

appellation: Anderson Valley, Mendocino County, California, US
review: Dry Gewürztraminer like this makes a great pairing with appetizers and seafood, and especially with white meats and grilled sausages. Here is a classic example, with rose petal aromas, piney-appley flavors, a rich texture and lingering, aromatic finish.

wine: De Bortoli 2002 Noble One Botrytis Semillon (New South Wales)
appellation: New South Wales, New South Wales, Australia
review: This is a safe bet for people who aren't big on sweeties: It's balanced and round, and not too cloying. Tastes of apricot and a sweet hint of citrus, like lemon sorbet, and smells like dried pineapple fruit and lemon pudding.

appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: Earthy with streaks of mint and sage, this is a light-bodied, soft and perfumed wine, brightly highlighted in red cherry and pomegranate. It finishes crisp and juicy.

wine: Fullerton 2017 Bella Vida Vineyard Pinot Noir (Dundee Hills)
appellation: Dundee Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: Another fine vintage for this single-vineyard cuvée, it opens with a whiff of minty spice, truffle and red fruits. On the palate it mingles raspberry, red plum and Bing cherry, with svelte tannins buoyed by hints of citrus. Just one-quarter of the barrels were new French oak.

appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: This twist-top bottling is always a playful and immediately likable take on Grenache, boosted with 11% Petite Sirah. Rich red-cherry, roasted strawberry and caramel aromas lead into a palate that's loaded with clean red-fruit, nutmeg and gingerbread flavors.

wine: Quinta Nova de Nossa Senhora do Carmo 2017 Pomares Red (Douro)
winery: Quinta Nova de Nossa Senhora do Carmo
review: Structured and rich, this blend of classic Douro grapes was wood aged for six months, adding to the spice and highlighting the minerality and fruitiness of the wine's structure. Drink from 2020.

appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: Like its vintage predecessors, this seems to have some residual sugar, which gives a honeyed sweetness to the peach, pear, fig and honeysuckle flavors. But it has a very crisp, pleasant acidity that keeps the wine lively.

wine: De Loach 2000 Barbieri Ranch Zinfandel (Russian River Valley)
appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: How ripe these grapes got. You can taste sunny sugar in every sip: black raspberries, black cherries and blueberries, with all kinds of wonderful crushed brown spices. As sweet as it sounds, the wine is bone-dry, an impression heightened by sticky tannins and excellent acids. This is Zin, pure and simple.

wine: A Blooming Hill Vineyard 2012 Pinot Noir (Chehalem Mountains)
appellation: Chehalem Mountains, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: This young Pinot opens hard and tight and remains so, even after many hours. The raspberry fruit is somewhat hidden, and some off scents creep into a finish that has a bitter edge.
The 2006 vintage strikes again, causing particularly strong feline aromas and taste.

Streaks of honey and white melon introduce this creamy, fruit-forward Chablis. A decadently textured, almost lactic, sip, it is bolstered by sunny lemon and lime acidity and a cool tang of steel on the finish. This hedonistic yet pure-fruited white is ready to drink now but will likely hold through 2027.

wine: Navarro 2011 Cluster Select Late Harvest Muscat Blanc (Anderson Valley)
appellation: Anderson Valley, Mendocino County, California, US
review: Smooth, balanced and lingering, this is sippable by itself after a big meal, and it can also pair well with strong cheeses, dark chocolates or stone-fruit-based desserts that are layered with crème Anglaise. This selection also comes in 375-ml bottles.

wine: Joyce 2014 River Road Chardonnay (Santa Lucia Highlands)
appellation: Santa Lucia Highlands, Central Coast, California, US
review: Underripe lemons, yellow roses, cut apples and white lilies are bolstered by an intriguing, light cinnamon spice on the nose of this bottling. It's a bit like sipping on honeysuckle tea, as the palate is sizzling with acidity and packed with flavors of lemon oil, green apple skins and tangerine rinds.

wine: Porta 1999 Grand Reserve Pinot Noir (Bío Bío Valley)
review: This Pinot, from a vineyard region not commonly seen in the U.S., boasts aromas of root beer and sour malt backed up by blackberries, black cherries and licorice. The black cherries persist all the way through the dry, toasty, slightly bitter finish.

wine: Murgo 2018 Brut Rosé Metodo Classico Nerello Mascalese (Terre Siciliane)
review: Red berry, bread crust and Mediterranean herb aromas come to the forefront on this tangy, savory sparkler. On the crisp, dry palate, vibrant acidity and a continuous perlage accompany sour cherry, strawberry compote, citrus and saline before a star anise finish.

Exotic fruit, citrus zest and crushed tomato vine aromas combine with whiffs oak. It's structured and linear, offering ripe pineapple, grapefruit, coconut and a hint of butterscotch alongside bright acidity.

This is a lean, focused and earthy white, offered at great value, with bright layers of green apple, honeysuckle and vanilla bean. Balanced in approach, it is a wine of wide appeal and approachability that overdelivers on many levels.

LTU is superconcentrated, black as night, minerally, rich and wonderfully balanced. The palate is wide but well structured, while flavors of toasty oak, peppercorn and stirring black fruit are delicious. Toasty, chocolaty and macho to the last drop. Drink now–2016.

This beautiful quinta, high above the Douro, has produced a generous, raisin and black fig-flavored Port. It is ripe, plummy and sweet in style, although the tannins at the end show good structure. Imported by Broadbent Selections, Inc.

wine: Gundlach Bundschu 2011 Estate Vineyard Gewürztraminer (Sonoma Coast)
review: This shows the variety's delicious spiciness, as well as ripened pear and honeysuckle flavors. Treading that fine line between dry and off-dry, it's an exotic accompaniment to Vietnamese, Ethiopean and Indian foods.

A hot-pink color and punchy aromas of citrus and red fruits make for a bright opening. In its current youthful state, this feels healthy and medium in body. Primary citrus flavors come with a spicy note of cactus prior to a foxy, lightly green finish.

wine: Balletto 2010 Estate Bottled Pinot Gris (Russian River Valley)
appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: A very nice Pinot Gris, with excellent acidity and rich flavors of citrus and honey. With steely minerality, it tastes clean and tangy.

appellation: Santa Maria Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: Tasters all praised this wine's clean, polished black cherry, beet and vanilla flavors and polished, supple mouthfeel. Could use more strength mid-palate, but the cherry and raspberry finish turns rich with charcoal and vanilla.

Dusty red-fruit aromas come with earthy, leathery tones. It feels tight, drawn and resiny, with hard spice and oak flavor. There's not much fruit to ponder, and the finish is dried out, with a woody note.

wine: Dutton-Goldfield 2004 Dutton Ranch Chardonnay (Russian River Valley)
appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: Made mainly from vineyards in Green Valley, the wine was barrel fermented and underwent complete malolactic fermentation. The French oak barrels were 50% new. This level of intervention was appropriate to the underlying wine, which is massive in tropical fruit, pear, fig and melon flavors. The result is complex and lush.

appellation: Temecula Valley, South Coast, California, US
review: Relatively light in the glass, this blend offers lots of strawberry fruit and leather on the nose along with strong aromas of toasted oak. There is crispy red fruit on the sip, overlaid with powerful oak tones that prove toasty and inviting.

appellation: El Dorado, Sierra Foothills, California, US
review: This is a terrific wine from a classic estate which sits at 2,700 in the Sierra Foothills. It offers rich vanilla and cream aromas, with abundant pear and nutmeg flavor balanced by subtle acidity.

wine: Wild & Wilder 2017 The Unforgettable G-S-M (South Australia)
review: A label made by the talented crew at Thistledown, this rose petal-hued red blend walks on the lighter side of the tracks. It bursts with fragrances of blueberries, plums, red currants, baking spices, white pepper and florals. It's light to medium in weight with a silky texture, a savory line of soft yet structured tannins, lifted acidity that makes the fruit feel crunchy, and an herb-flecked finish.

wine: Concha y Toro 2003 Marques de Casa Concha Chardonnay (Pirque)
review: Lots of popcorn and butter on the nose, with more butter along with lemon and apple on the palate. This is a soft, rich wine without a lot of driving acids to spunk things up. Turns increasingly creamy on the finish. Imported by Banfi Vintners.
Robust and flavorful, Nobilo's top Pinot Noir is undeniably toasty, but it also features burly cola and plum flavors to match the oak. Big-boned and firmly structured, drink 2008–09.

Vinified in the soft, opulent style of Chambolle, this is ripe and round. With its dry edge and rich fruit, the structure of the apparent is apparent. The acidity cuts through to give a juicy element. Already delicious to drink, but it's worth aging over 2–3 years.

wine: Martin Ray 2009 Reserve Cabernet Sauvignon (Stags Leap District)
appellation: Stags Leap District, Napa, California, US
review: Who wouldn't love this Cabernet? It defines the famous description of wines from this district as an iron fist in a velvet glove. Shows a firmly tannic structure, with good acidity and a firm minerality. That's the iron. The velvet is the ripe, rich black currant and cherry fruit. Glamorous and delicious, it gives its best over the next six years.

You can usually count Don Antonio as one of Sicily's very best Nero d'Avolas. But the 2003 heat seems to have left a slight jammy quality that butts awkwardly against the blackberry and crunchy toasted almond. The tannic structure is firm, which bodes well for its evolution over time. Imported by Winebow.

This is one unusual wine. It's a blend of Cabernet Sauvignon with Tempranillo and Garnacha, but it smells like a root-based perfume mixed with herbs and tobacco. It's over the hill in feel and green and herbal in flavor, with a raisiny aftertaste.

Chunky and full, but not totally pure. The palate holds form, showing sharp flavors of strawberry and cherry. Some light oak and vanilla works the finish, while some leftover acidity creates a tangy overall impression. Imported by Global Wine Imports LLC.

wine: Cave de Hunawihr 2019 Rosacker Grand Cru Riesling (Alsace)
review: Beautifully pure notions of lime and lemon zest create aromatic, heightened freshness on the nose of this wine. Vivid citrus juiciness on a dry, svelte but sinuous body reverberates with lemon and tangerine. The blend of ripeness and ethereal coolness makes this wine compelling.

wine: Martin Ranch 2017 Therese Vineyards Victoria Denice Vineyard Petite Sirah (Santa Clara Valley)
appellation: Santa Clara Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: Thick aromas of black currant meet with savory streaks of dried meat and strong scents of crushed cloves on the nose of this bottling. The palate is overloaded with barrel spices, as mace, clove and star anise rise above the fruit and herb flavors.

Red-apple notes on the nose of this wine have the merest edge of tangerine-peel spice. Immensely juicy, easy and rounded, the palate offers great clarity, with bright, ripe citrus at the core. The finish is dry and totally refreshing.

Produced from the estate's oldest vines, this is a ripe, generous wine. Wood aging and concentrated fruit have given a wine that is rich with blackberries, with spice and some firm tannins. This dense wine needs to age further, so drink from 2019.

There's a strong funkiness to this wine, which can be called barnyard or even bordering on Band-Aid, that almost overwhelms the nose and mouth. Black plum and berry flavors struggle for dominance, while spicy oak controls the close.

Made entirely with Sangiovese and without any added chemical sulfites, this wine leads off with earthy aromas of wet soil, leather, fragrant blue flower and red berries. The one-dimensional palate opens with sour cherry accented with a hint of cinnamon-spice alongside chewy but fleeting tannins. It's a bit diluted and finishes abruptly.

The fruit has become the main attraction here—layers of ripeness, tempered with an elegant smoothness. The tannins are certainly present in this powerful wine, but they are here to lend support, not dominate. With herbs and very clean black fruits, this is a wine to follow.

wine: Eagle Eye 2013 Proprietary Estate AlphaWolf Vineyard Reserve Meritage (Napa Valley)
review: Huge puckering tannins make it hard to decipher the fruit imparted by this blend of 81% Cabernet Sauvignon with 14% Cabernet Franc and 5% Petit Verdot. Oak, cedar and pencil shavings make it through the hearty ripeness.

This Ribolla Gialla sparkling Brut is perfumed and thick on the nose with aromatic highlights that recall white mineral, peach, citrus and pear. It offers creamy foam in the mouth and a strong twist of citrus zest on the finish.

A nice Chardonnay that feels pedigreed and well-made, with crisp acidity and a creamy texture framing very ripe tropical fruit and citrus flavors. The oak dominates, however, making the wine heavy in sweet, caramelized toast.

wine: Simonsig 2018 Cape Winemakers Guild Heirloom Shiraz (Stellenbosch)
review: Winemaker: Johan Malan. A bit shy and reserved at first, this opens up with some time and air to reveal brooding sensations of black plum, cherry, forest floor, wood spice and a touch of mentholated herb. It's bold, dense and powerful on the palate, with gripping tannins and black fruit-skin flavors that fill the mouth and carry through to the lightly charred, spicy finish. Give this some more time in the cellar to truly shine; drink 2026–2029.

appellation: Mendocino County, Mendocino County, California, US
review: Fruity and savory flavors mingle well in this full-bodied, smooth-textured wine. It offers ample black-cherry and black-plum notes along with hints of tasty mushroom and beef jus.

This is like drinking liquid black currants and blackberries. The wine has great intensity and richness from the superbly generous Merlot. The wood aging shows as a hint in the background, with the bold black fruit and ample acidity dominating. Drink from 2026.

A typical production from this fruity grape, this is an easy-drinking, juicy style of wine, full of red berry flavors, just a touch of wood, and gentle but dry tannins. Imported by Aidil Wines & Liquor Inc.
Scents of roasted nuts and apples gain levity on the palate with flavors of lemons and delicate white flowers. Richly textured, this has a slightly-viscous but refreshingly-fruity profile.
This bright, fruity wine is crisp with acidity from the red-currant flavors. A blend of Aragones and Touriga Nacional, it is light with just a touch of tannin. Drink now.

Up there in the Chalone hills they have a lot of limestone, and you can taste the flint and chalk in this wine even through the lavish tropical fruit and spice. It's a really interesting Chardonnay that's quite fancy and elegantly structured, and it will hold for a good six years.

Produced from old vines and aged for two years in wood, this wine is still not quite ready to drink. Black fruits shine through the firm tannins and vanilla and spice flavors, but still need time. Licorice and dusty tannins give a perfumed character. Drink this rich wine from 2022.

Yes, this blend of Chenin Blanc, Chardonnay, French Colombard and Muscat Canelli is quite sweet, with sugary flavors of oranges, peaches, vanilla and toast. And yes, some people will turn their noses up at it. Too bad for them—it's an ideal wine for drinking at the beach or picnics, or celebrating just about anything.

Green plum skins, bitter lime pith, hay and pepper all dominate the nose with barely a hint of ripe fruit to be found. The mouth, however, offers a bit more ripeness to the lime and plum flavors, fleshing out the medium-weight mouth and adding depth to the wine.

wine: Rex Hill 2006 Sims Vineyard Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)
appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: A full, fleshy, lushly fruited Pinot Noir, streaked with espresso and caramel from barrel aging. The fruit and overall structure are up to the challenge of the wood; lots of black cherry and even hints of cassis running through the core. A finish with some noticeable heat supports the 15.4% alcohol reading, but it's a tasty bottle of wine.

Heavily toasty, this wine seems to rely on the wood aging rather than fruit. It does have weight and hints of juicy black currants in the background, but too much wood has not done the wine any favors.

A softly fruity wine that is just strengthened by tannins with attractive red fruits as well as a more herbal character. Smooth texture leads to final acidity. The light structure promises aging until 2018.

wine: Northwest Totem Cellars 2007 Low Man Red (Columbia Valley (WA))
appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Aggressively tannic, this is an earthy red wine with a lot of barrel influence. The fruit vanishes into a mélange of pepper, clove, coffee and tannin.

wine: Rocca delle Macìe 2008 Riserva Famiglia Zingarelli  (Chianti Classico)
review: Sangiovese is enhanced with tiny percentages of Cabernet Sauvignon and Merlot to create a fresh, balanced wine, with aromas of red fruit and savory spice. The mouthfeel is soft and rich with good structure and fullness.

wine: Cuneo 2001 Del Rio Vineyard Syrah (Rogue Valley)
appellation: Rogue Valley, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
review: Rich and extracted, with a purple color and nutty, maple-based aromas. There's no denying the power here, and with flavors of sugar beets, smoked meats and kirsch, it's quite the bruiser. Despite that heft, the finish is balanced, with chocolate and dried herb flavors. Some hard tannins make it a bit tough now; maybe time will tame it.

Oak-derived vanilla, brown sugar and menthol aromas open yet another wine that's tasty, but doesn't show real vinous depth and intensity. Cherry fruit is hidden behind a powerful oak veneer, so a caramel quality prevails. Finishes tart and dry, with coffee flavors.

wine: Vollereaux NV Brut Rosé de Saignée Pinot Noir (Champagne)
review: Most rosé Champagnes get their color by the addition of red wine. This wine gets its hue from the skins of red grapes macerating before fermentation. It has a deep pink color and a lightly tannic character, making for a rich wine flavored with red currants and finished with acidity.

Get after this one soon, for it seems to be fading. It's already quite gold in color, indicating maturity. What it lacks in vivacity, however, is made up for in the bright lemon, pineapple and melon flavors. It's a mixed bag of fruit, yet nothing really stands out.

wine: Croix 2019 Eastside Ritchie Vineyard Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)
appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: This bold, brawny wine is earthy with a wealth of forest and black tea. Tannic and concentrated in rich berry fruit, it is made in an unctuous, richly rewarding style from the famous site.

From ex-Penfolds winemaker John Duval and made in part from vines over 150 years old, this Grenache offers a complexity and depth. This favors dark fruit on the nose and is chock full of intriguing aromas of cumin, clove, chocolate, sandalwood and mint. The palate offers more of the same multifariousness, with added minerality reminiscent of hot stones and graphite. Drink now–2027.
Okay everyday Chard, with toned-down peach, pear and oak flavors and a creaminess to the texture. Finishes dry, crisp and short.

This is a rich style of Chardonnay that shows pear and apple aromas, with vanilla and butter flavors. The palate offers a good balance of ripeness and natural acidity. It's medium in body and smoothly textured without feeling too soft.

wine: Quinta do Regueiro 2018 Reserva Alvarinho (Vinho Verde)
review: From the sub-region of Monção and Melgaço, this wine has perfumed fragrant fruitiness with hints of a creamy texture. It is rich and full in the mouth, touched by spice and pepper and likely to age for a while. It will be ready to drink from early 2020.

While it has weight and richness, this is also seriously structured, a wine packed with dry tannins. The potential is all there—the sweet fruit of the vintage along with a solid texture and final acidity.

appellation: Eola-Amity Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: This big-boned wine spent two years in barrel, 40% new. The ripe black fruits run all the way into cassis, with aromatics and flavor highlights that suggest wet hay. There's a heavy dose of vanilla, though the winery indicates that the barrels were French rather than American oak. At such high alcohol, this wine shows some back palate burn, and is best drunk soon.

appellation: Mendocino County, Mendocino County, California, US
review: This is a snappy, well-balanced and also concentrated wine that's compelling to drink. Engaging complexity in the aromas leads to equally intriguing and spicy flavors that are well supported by good acidity and firm tannins.

wine: Quinta do Portal NV 10 Year Old Aged White  (Port)
review: This fruity style is also concentrated. Poised between the rich lemon and orange fruitiness and the touches of wood aging, the wine is balanced and medium sweet.

appellation: Applegate Valley, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
review: The 2003 version of the estate Zinfandel clocks in at just 15.5% alcohol, but carries a fair amount of volatile nail polish aromas. It is marinated in new oak—French, American, Hungarian—so that whisky barrel scents and flavors cover up any taste of the varietal fruit.
86–88. Barrel Sample. This wine has an extracted character, leading to bitterness. Its fruit, buried under the tannins, could come through, although it is likely to always remain firm and structured.

Organically grown Sangiovese Grosso is the base of this bright and buoyant Rosso di Montalcino. There are mineral and campfire notes that play a supporting role to black cherry, currant and cola. The mouthfeel is compact and informal.

appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Though quite dark, spicy, smoky, fragrant and seductive, this is a very flavorful wine. Citrusy acids underscore flavors of grapefruit and orange, but the core of the wine is straightforward, pure and ripe berry. It's nice not to fight the fruit with oak; the aromatics are beautiful.

appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: It's rare to find a straight Cinsault bottling, which is reason enough to seek this out. But the flavors are muted compared to other rosés. It leads with burnt orange, peach and pineapple aromas, and then delivers faint tropical flavors on the palate, reminiscent of papaya and coconut, lacking acidic zing.

wine: Adair Bachman 2014 Rose & Thistle Rosé (Napa Valley)
review: This is made from 92% Cabernet Sauvignon and 8% Pinot Noir, an interesting and fulfilling combination thats robust on the palate. Pinkish-orange in color, it's both tangy and weighty, finishing dry in orange zest.

wine: Antiquum Farm 2015 Aurosa Pinot Gris (Willamette Valley)
appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: This unusual rosé is all Pinot Gris, picked for thick skins, chewy tannins, high acidity, and given a 36-hour cold soak prior to fermentation. It's a pale salmon/copper shade, full-bodied and juicy, with fruit flavors of peach and citrus. Highlights of hibiscus tea and floral aromatics contribute further complexity.

Pretty straightforward stuff, with green apple and citrus aromas and just hints of honey and petrol. It's medium-bodied, with a touch of residual sugar, but ends with mouthwatering acids. Drink now–2010.

appellation: El Dorado, Sierra Foothills, California, US
review: This smooth and rich-textured wine offers a creamy mouthfeel, light apple and Bosc pear flavors and a noticeable streak of earth, almond and flint.

An intense, mineral-driven wine, this is tight and very textured. Its dryness is mitigated by hints of riper mango and apricot that fill out the palate. The structure and the tense acidity show this wine is still young. Drink from 2017.

wine: Rijk's 2018 Cape Winemakers Guild CWG Chenin Blanc (Tulbagh)
review: Winemaker: Pierre Wahl. This is quite toasty and oaky upfront right now, with pronounced aromas of wood-grilled apple, orange oil, custard and yellow melon. The palate is full and weighty, but not fat, with plush, mouth-filling toasted-fruit flavors that have a decadent, grilled edge and lingering impressions of sweet spice and toast on the finish. Impressions of yellow apple, musk melon, sweet braised fennel, straw and pie crust carry through on the close, with a kiss of honey on the way back as well as the lingering warmth of toasty baking-spice characteristics.

appellation: Vino Nobile di Montepulciano, Tuscany, Italy
review: Forest floor, truffle, new leather and woodland berry scents mingle in the glass. The palate is linear, taut and austere, offering sour cherry, licorice and sage notes, framed by firm acidity and assertive, close-grained tannins that grip the finish. Drink after 2019.

appellation: Red Mountain, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: This barrel-fermented Sauvignon Blanc is from Klipsun vineyard. There is a clean and lightly grassy nose, with added highlights of citrus, lime rind, lemon drop, honeysuckle and light toast.

appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: A flinty wine, with toasty oak nuances.  Bright acidity supports a core of citrus and pear flavors that finish quite clean.

wine: Brick House 2011 Les Dijonnais Pinot Noir (Ribbon Ridge)
appellation: Ribbon Ridge, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: Certified organic and Biodynamic, this estate-grown gem offers seductive scents of rose petals and orange blossoms, dried figs and a hint of pastry. The lush aromatics lead into a delicate yet profound wine, with a core of raspberry/cherry fruit, and lingering minerality.

wine: Marc Kreydenweiss 2004 Perrières Red (Costières de Nîmes)
appellation: Costières de Nîmes, Rhône Valley, France
review: Alsatian Marc Kreydenweiss has acquired a vineyard in the Rhône Valley, where he practices the same biodynamic techniques as in Alsace. This lively, vividly fruity wine is full of red currant, fresh plum and lightly juicy fruit. Tannins lend some dryness to the aftertaste.

wine: K Vintners 2007 Pheasant Vineyard Syrah (Wahluke Slope)
appellation: Wahluke Slope, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: This is also a Milbrandt vineyard, but quite different flavors emerge from the other Milbrandt wines. Plenty of black cherry fruit, with a minerality that suggests iron ore. Penetrating, ripe and potent (15% alcohol), yet well balanced and complex, with wild herbs lurking in the background.

A great waft of ripe fruits, wood spice and tense acidity. A Valmur is a model for great Chablis, a taut wine, like a spring of green fruits waiting to burst out. This impressive wine needs aging, give it at least five years.
88-90. Barrel sample. Firmly tannic on the initial taste, this wine shows bell pepper and juicy black-fruit flavors. It is light and fruity, and finishes with dry tannins.

wine: Cambridge California 2013 Cold Creek Vineyard Chardonnay (Carneros)
review: Thick and sour, this wine has a waxy fruit component to it that is off-putting and out of sync with the crisp fruit that is trying to compete on the palate.

Great Southern is an underrated source for Cabernet Sauvignon, amply demonstrated by this wine. Expansive notes of cedar, brown sugar, vanilla and baking spices enrobe tart berries, while the wine's firm structure carries through to a crisp, tannic finish. Try in 2020.
A bright, soft, user-friendly wine in the Gallo style. Delicate and pretty. Few complexities, but it's supple, balanced and very drinkable. Best Buy.

Compelling and sweet-smelling, Archimede offers pretty tones of spice, black cherry, molasses, espresso and cola. The ruby-colored wine is zippy and fresh with soft tannins and medium length in the mouth.

appellation: Mendocino County, Mendocino County, California, US
review: This crisp and appetizing wine offers herb and apricot aromas, lip-smacking acidity and tempting flavors of dried herbs, apricots and mineral water. It is medium bodied, shows no signs of oak and will be very versatile with food.

appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
review: Scents of smoke and sweet roasted chestnuts add a warm, rustic tone to this medium-dry Riesling. Deeply concentrated, with ripe yellow peach and apricot flavors, it's brightened by a shower of lemonade acidity and a snappy lemon-rind finish.

On the nose, dried apples and yeast notes are drenched in the rich aromas of clarified butter and malt; in the mouth, expect tons of mousse and a full mouthfeel, plus concentrated, dry fruit flavors (especially pear).  Finishes long, with smoldering toast and vanilla flavors.  "Very solid stuff," wrote one taster.  Worthy of a very special occasion.

wine: Von Strasser 2007 Grüner Veltliner (Diamond Mountain District)
appellation: Diamond Mountain District, Napa, California, US
review: This unoaked wine, made from the red-hot Austrian variety, is very dry and high in acidity. It has a grassy, gooseberry tang reminiscent of New Zealand Sauvignon Blanc, with some richer, chewier notes of figs and green apples. There's a spritziness that may calm down over the coming months.

Very ripe pear notes on the nose have an earthy tinge and a hint of bruised apple. The palate reverts to ample, ripe pear notes that brim with easy, juicy flair, boosted by a hint of residual sweetness. It's an easy, just off-dry wine with attractive balance.

Outstanding. Ultra-ripe and lush, but very dry, showing powerful, long hangtime flavors of black and red sour cherries, currants, violets and cedar, wrapped into dense, melted tannins. Almost Porty, but stops short of overripeness to finish with dramatic richness. The vineyard is adjacent to Rubicon's, in the heart of the Rutherford bench.

A tropical whiff of mango plays about the smoky reduction on the nose. The palate carries on in fruity abundance with that same mango and passion fruit combo and a bright note of lemony ripeness. The body is concentrated and zesty, and the finish is mouthwatering, dry and still wholly tropical.

One of the wave of Beaujolais wines bottled without added sulfur, this wine is all about black fruits and good acidity. It has a light structure along with ripe berry flavors and a juicy aftertaste. Drink now.

wine: Kokomo 2012 Pauline's Vineyard Winemaker's Reserve Zinfandel (Dry Creek Valley)
appellation: Dry Creek Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: Smoky aromas give this wine allure, its layers of flavor soft and flowery, accented by red berry fruit. On the elegant spectrum of the variety, the wine is fairly subtle, with an evolving cinnamon spiciness to the finish.

Brisk tangs of lime and pineapple lend zest to this light-footed dry Riesling. Intently mineral on the palate, it's a subtle yet thirst-quenching white that's ideal as an aperitif or party wine. Best now–2022. This cuvée is also labeled under the Hooked brand.

Fresh, ripe notes of Meyer lemon are joined by hints of rose. It is on the slender palate that the rose aromas become stronger, countered by lovely lemon freshness. The finish is dry, perfumed and refreshing.

This has toasted oak, espresso and mature dark-skinned berry aromas. The palate dense and packed with prune, blackberry extract and roasted coffee flavors. Raspy tannins leave an abrupt, astringent finish.

From vineyards above the grand chateau of Moncontour close to the Loire, this medium-dry wine offers acidity and crisp white fruits. Its freshness is as important as the perfumed fruitiness, giving the wine the potential to age. Drink from 2020.

Abacela has made great strides with its Merlots, and here the fruit has ripened past the “green” stage while retaining plenty of tannic, earthy mineral flavors. Dense and minerally, this has a core of sweet fruit and a pretty finish.

wine: The Big Five Collection 2004 Rhino Sauvignon Blanc (Western Cape)
review: Opens with a soft mineral-herb bouquet. The rounder style continues on the palate, but ample citrus and white pepper notes keep it from being flaccid or mushy. Closes fairly long with a nice reprise of the early mineral notes. An appealing, well-done mainstream white.

This is produced from 25-year-old vines in the Chambertin Grand Cru vineyard. It is a smoky, structured wine with layers of dark fruits and ripe tannins, with the fresh acidity of the year. Lots of attractive fruit is surrounded by the firm tannins and dry aftertaste. It should not be drunk before 2020.

appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Leesy and nicely textured, this has lime and green apple notes that rest on a bed of bracing acidity. It has length, focus and detail, all without intrusive new oak—just a small percentage of the wine was barrel-fermented.

Blended with 3% Viognier, the Snitch is within the Prisoner Wine Company portfolio of illustrative, creative label design. Intensely full-bodied, it tastes of caramel, brioche and baked apple, sure to please fans of a rich, concentrated style.

A luscious, amber-hued sticky from the spiritual home of dessert wines down under, Rutherglen, this wine oozes chocolate, caramel, mint, coffee and that old library smell that emanates from so many fortifieds. The palate is ultrarich and satin-textured with molassesy sweetness. The alcohol feels a little hot and it could use a bit more acidity, but this is nevertheless an affordable and indulgent drop.

wine: Sobon Estate 2013 Cougar Hill Zinfandel (Amador County)
appellation: Amador County, Sierra Foothills, California, US
review: Smoothness and richness describe this full-bodied wine. It smells plummy and raisiny, tastes ripe like dried fruit, and has a firm texture.

A solid, dark wine, this is structured and firmly tannic, deliciously perfumed. The black currant fruit is balanced with acidity and a dense, tarry character. The wine exudes dark power, very firm and certainly ageworthy.

wine: The Naked Grape NV Harvest Red (California)
review: This red blend is nicely dry, with abundant of dark plum and pomegranate flavors and a full-bodied, moderately tannic mouthfeel. It's easy to drink but bold enough to pair with hearty proteins.
Largely Chardonnay and Riesling, this wine offers aromas that include peach, pear, melon and almond. It's full in feel, lightly sweet with citrus and stone-fruit flavors that linger.

appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Zippy flavors of melon and new-mowed grass, nicely integrated and loaded with the sort of spicy herbs that might have come fresh from the garden. Note the relatively low alcohol, making this a perfect summer sipping wine.

This Virginia Cab Franc starts soft and ripe with loads of juicy black currant and berry flavors flecked with sweet, warm baking spices and cedar notes. A zesty kick of acidity on the midpalate and a flash of fresh, green herbs on the finish add elegance and balance.

wine: Rieflé 1996 Selection de Grains Nobles Tokay Pinot Gris (Alsace)
review: Features honeyed, overripe melons that carry only a hint of botrytis. Quite sweet and rich, it's forward, showing plenty of charm while lacking the depth and backbone to improve. Drink now.

appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: This blend of 33% Cabernet Sauvignon, 23% Malbec, 20% Petit Verdot, 12% Cabernet Franc and 12% Merlot is very approachable on the nose with blackberry and black-pepper aromas. The palate also offers the black fruit with a touch of purple flowers, but it is somewhat simple and weak, especially compared to this winery's other bottlings.

wine: Januik 2006 Cold Creek Vineyard Chardonnay (Columbia Valley (WA))
appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: More new oak shows here; it's packed with butterscotch and toasted, caramel-coated, apple-flavored fruit. It's tighter, spicier and oakier than the Elerding Vineyard Chardonnay from Januik, though at the moment it seems less complex in the finish.

A solid, ripe and tannic wine that is full of firm fruits, ripe berries and a strongly mineral character. It has some concentration and certainly dense tannins while also showing a fresher, licorice and black currant side. Drink now, but best wait until 2015.

appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: This is a fresh, immaculate wine, low in alcohol but complex with mixed fruit flavors of jicama, melon and Honeygold apples. Acids provide the right underpinning without turning sour, and the lingering finish is spot-on.
Vaguely floral aromas precede a sweet, cloying palate that tastes candied.

appellation: Central Coast, Central Coast, California, US
review: Very ripe aromas of blackberry jam and sweet cedar show on the nose of this bottling. The palate is candied with black-cherry juice and maple-syrup flavors.

wine: Domaine des Crets 2016 Climat En Bout  (Mâcon-Chardonnay)
review: Lightly toasty, this wine is both crisp and fruity It has acidity, touches of apples and a nutty minerality at the end. Drink now.

Extreme reflects a level of oaking that may prove controversial. Raw cedary notes mark the nose, while some dark fruit sneaks through on the palate, reflecting the blend of Cabernet Sauvignon, Merlot and Syrah. More wood shows up again on the finish, partially balanced by tart berries.

appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: I don't know if there's technical residual sugar in this wine, but it sure tastes like it. Brings to mind sweetened cherry cough medicine, with a flat, syrupy finish.

The initial wood flavors dominate this still-young wine. With its tight mineral character and black currant fruits, it is very focused despite its power and intensity. The flavors open slowly over many hours, emphasizing the need for 4–5 years' aging.
Herbal and earthy, this white tastes of pea shoots, peach and flowers. It's textured and showing just a hint of oak. Rounded in richness, it finishes lush and tropical.
87-89 A rather lean wine, which has the acidity, but not the full botrytis effect. Quite delicate and rather austere.

wine: Kendall-Jackson 2017 Jackson Estate Pinot Noir (Anderson Valley)
appellation: Anderson Valley, Mendocino County, California, US
review: Light oak spices shade lots of fresh red-fruit flavors in this medium-bodied, generous and nicely balanced wine. It is well rounded and smooth on the palate, getting better with each sip.

This is not an ageable Cab, but it is balanced and complex, and has more than $20 worth of elegance. Dry and softly tannic, the Provençal herb, black cherry and oak flavors make you reach for a second glass.

wine: Rütz 2017 Maison Grand Cru Chardonnay (Russian River Valley)
appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: This wine is tart and cloudy, with strong flavors of baked pineapple and anise. The acidity takes on a persistent sour character that won't appeal to all.

appellation: Mendocino County, Mendocino County, California, US
review: Light but enticing jasmine and honeydew melon flavors give this full-bodied, dry wine a lot of personality, and the mouthfeel is just rich enough to coat the palate and help the finish linger. It's crafted from 70% Viognier and 30% Roussanne.

This wine feels big and burly, its tannins powering through the fruit. It has a strong structure, firm black plums, the acidity giving a lift to the weight of dark fruits. It needs aging, over the next 4–5 years.

wine: Molnar Family 2007 Poseidon's Vineyard Pinot Noir (Carneros-Napa Valley)
review: A bit more concentrated than the '06, but similar in lush, appealing flavors of cherries, raspberries, cedar, cola, vanilla and spices. With a silky texture, it should develop through 2013.

A gorgeous wine, its richness fuelled by the concentration that comes from old vines. The wine rolls opulently around the mouth, showing apricot flavors over almonds and spice. A final burst of freshness gives it a delicious lift.

wine: Silverado 2005 Miller Ranch Vineyard Sauvignon Blanc (Napa Valley)
review: This wine is so high-toned in wildflowers you might think it was Alsatian, maybe Pinot Gris, a suspicion the high acidity also supports. But it's Sauvignon Blanc, with a rich core of yellow citrus fruit and papaya and an elegant minerality. This is a classy white wine at a good price.

Based in the village of Bué, this producer is a top name. A blend from different vineyards, this well-balanced wine moves easily between herbal and ripe tropical flavors. After two years, it is very ready to drink.

wine: Umberto Cesari 2005 Colle del Re  (Albana di Romagna)
appellation: Albana di Romagna, Central Italy, Italy
review: This is a nice, refreshing wine, but it does have certain elements that need to be tucked back into place. One example is the sour note on the finish that distracts from the wine's pleasant flavors of stone fruit, melon and cut grass.

Mid-gold in color, this has a pronounced classic Gewürztraminer nose of lychee, rose petals, spice and ripe stone fruit with notes of earthy minerality. Sweet and richly textured, round mouthfeel with moderately intense flavors similar to nose with an added note of stem ginger and smoky spice on the finish.

From a single parcel in the estate, this is a full and rich wine with impressive intensity and concentration. It has spice, pepper and warm black cherry fruits, with a layer of tannins. Ripe and full in the mouth, this can be enjoyed now.

appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Cocoa, vanilla and baking spice aromas intertwine with cranberry, black licorice, herb and dark fruit on a wine with a very distinctive aromatic profile. The cranberry and cherry flavors are quite soft for the variety, seeming a touch dried out at times but showing a pleasing sense of balance.

wine: K Vintners 2007 El Jefe En Chamberlin Tempranillo-Cabernet Sauvignon (Walla Walla Valley (WA))
appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: This is 75% Tempranillo and 25% Cabernet Sauvignon. It's got an unusual structure, and dramatically displays this biodynamic vineyard's funky, herbal, earthy character, with plenty of acidity from the Tempranillo, and a little bit of the tomato leaf character also. A complex, unique, distinctive wine that does not show fruit so much as earth and terroir. It keeps going, adding weight and depth through the midpalate, with a strong tomato component.

appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Cabernet Sauvignon (65%) takes the lead on this wine followed by Merlot (15%) and equal parts Cabernet Franc and Petit Verdot. Aromas of high-toned dried herbs, flowers, black currant, coffee and barrel spices lead to densely packed black fruit flavors that need time to strut their stuff. Drink after 2021.
Medium bodied and just a touch sweet, this wine overflows with ripe apple and melon aromas, and broad rich appley and floral flavors.

This is a crisp, dry wine that exibits delicious acidity, along with fresh citrus and green-apple flavors. It's bright and fruity, but has a textured undertow that promises good bottle aging. Ready to drink now, but could also benefit by cellaring for a year.

One of the most succulent and drinkable Napa Cabernets of the '08 vintage. With Merlot added to the blend, it's rich in blackberries, cherries, currants and cedar, with firm but pliant tannins that give a beautiful structure.
This textured wine brings something of a cool northern character to the ripeness for a taste that is attractively crisp and fresh. The wine is ready to drink.

Aromas of truffle, smoke, leather and wild berry take center stage. Boasting an earthy elegance, the medium-bodied palate offers dried cherry, cranberry, star anise and a hint of game set against grainy tannins that leave a firm drying finish. It's still rather austere and needs a few more years to unwind. Drink 2021–2027.

appellation: Santa Ynez Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: Cherry and berry aromas are lifted by cola, incense and Dr Pepper elements on the nose of this blend of 56% Cabernet Sauvignon, 25% Cabernet Franc and 19% Petit Verdot. Fennel-bulb and mint flavors meet with backed black currant and elderflower on the palate, where firm tannins hold up the midpalate.

appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: The aromas start out reticent for the variety, with pear, white peach and green apple notes. The palate is sleek but flavorful, with pleasant balance. It lacks only a bit more expression; perhaps additional time in bottle will bring it out.

wine: Château Palmer 2014 Alter Ego de Château Pamer Barrel Sample  (Margaux)
designation: Alter Ego de Château Pamer Barrel Sample
review: 91–93. Barrel Sample. This wine boasts great structure, with a dark color and vibrant aromatics from the high proportion of Petit Verdot. It offers dusty tannins partnered with ample acidity, providing great freshness through the finish.

Full-bodied, rich and chewy, this is a big, bold wine. Ample oak frames black cherry and cassis fruit, adding hints of vanilla and dark chocolate to the fudge-like impression. Warmth suffuses the palate, but doesn't quite progress to full-blown high-alcohol heat. There's no doubting its impressive intensity and ripeness. Drink now–2025.

Here's a strongly mineral-driven expression of Chardonnay with a polished, linear appeal in its clean aromas and crisp mouthfeel. The wine is luminous and light and would pair with seafood or a fresh Caesar salad.

wine: Quinta da Romeira 2014 Prova Régia Arinto (Lisboa)
review: Arinto is the real local grape of the small city of Bucelas where this quinta is located. This fresh wine shows its light mineral and citrus character very well. It also brings out riper fruit flavors that fill it out and give it a rich character. The wine is ready to drink now.

wine: Castello di Borghese 2002 Hargrave Vineyard Reserve Pinot Noir (North Fork of Long Island)
appellation: North Fork of Long Island, Long Island, New York, US
review: Woody on the nose, but with decent red berry and a touch of rhubarb, this wine has a drier, heavier feel and tannins than most Pinots but still delivers modest red berry and cola flavors. Finishes chalky.

Stewed cherry, spice and leather aromas set up a dense palate with feisty tannins. Earthy, foresty flavors of meaty black plum and spice finish ripe and chewy. This gets better the more air it sees; drink through 2019.

wine: Volker Eisele Family Estate 2007 Gemini White (Napa Valley)
review: A mighty fine white wine. Fills the much-needed niche of extreme dryness, acidity and restraint, which are the hallmarks of elegance. Call it the anti-Chardonnay. A Semillon-Sauvignon Blanc blend with some barrel and sur lie influence, it's rich and crisp in Meyer lemon, pear, fig, vanilla and smoky butter flavors.

wine: La Folia Winery 2013 The Madness Red (Sierra Foothills)
appellation: Sierra Foothills, Sierra Foothills, California, US
review: Abundant dark-fruit flavors and a smooth mouth-coating texture make a good combo in this deep-colored, full-bodied but not overly tannic wine. Light touches of cinnamon and vanilla add extra interest, and linger on the finish.

wine: Tangent 2011 Paragon Vineyard Sauvignon Blanc (Edna Valley)
appellation: Edna Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: Clean and sleek on the palate, this wine has brisk Central Coast acidity, which highlights the complex flavors of green melon, lemon, lime, Asian pear and white pepper. Made without oak, it shows the wonderful terroir of its vineyard.

wine: Château de Santenay 2017 La Comme Premier Cru  (Santenay)
review: This vineyard, on the edge of Santenay and next to Chassagne-Montrachet, produces both white and red wines. This red is juicy, structured and has a good future. A core of dry tannins gives it weight as well as potential richness. Drink from 2021.

Made by the folks at Longview, this Sem-Sauv is cottony-soft around the edges, with a clean feel overall. Smells like green grass, pea and flowers. A good Saturday afternoon wine: Easy, uncomplicated and fresh.
Minty, herbal and stemmy, this big red wine is crisp and fresh up front, opting for a more robustly powerful midpalate of plummy concentration and thick tannin.
Dull and cidery, with mealy apple aromas and similar flavors. Offers almost nothing besides a pale straw color, generic white fruit and corny side notes.

wine: Porterhouse Winery 2018 Black Label Reserve Red (Santa Ynez Valley)
appellation: Santa Ynez Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: Stewed red-fruit, vanilla, star anise and milk-chocolate aromas align on the nose of this bottling. Clove makes a showing on the sip, spicing up the dried red-fruit flavors at the core.

wine: Cleto Chiarli NV Rosé Brut de Noir Sparkling (Vino Spumante)
review: A blend of 85% Grasparossa and 15% Pinot Noir, this lovely sparkler offers aromas of apple, berry and bread crust. The aromas carry over to the tangy palate together with red cherry and a hint of pastry cream alongside bright acidity and small continuous bubbles.

appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: A dry, medium-bodied Pinot that shows very ripe fruit, easy tannins and a crisp bite of acidity. The flavors are delicious, all black cherries, sweet rhubarb tea, cola, vanilla and cinnamon. It's a wine you'll find yourself reaching for a second and a third time.

wine: Zuccardi 2016 Poligonos del Valle de Uco Malbec (Tupungato)
review: A saturated dark-purple color and aromas of pure grape juice and stout berry fruits amount to an impressive opening. Blackberry, cassis and natural peppery flavors fill out this cement-fermented-and-aged Malbec from the highest part of Tupungato. A steady, focused finish is clean and powerful, and overall this is a racy muscular wine to drink through 2024.
A bit muted and shy on the nose, with faint accents of fresh grass, sweet citrus and just-ripe gooseberry. The palate offers a pithy-citrus flavor, adding a touch of bitterness to the clean close.

wine: Walla Walla 2003 Cabernet Sauvignon (Walla Walla Valley (WA))
appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Scents and flavors of cranberry and raspberry are followed with layers of caramel, brown sugar, espresso and dark chocolate. Very smooth, very seductive, very creamy, it leads into a long, smooth finish.

wine: Nigl 2014 Privat Senftenberger Pellingen Reserve Grüner Veltliner (Kremstal)
review: A very restrained nose hints at citrus zest which comes into full, exciting force on the concentrated, taut and slender palate. This is so fine, so clean, that it suggests a cool, Alpine stream. Zesty freshness conquers all—just a few peppery, yeasty notes are glimpsed at the edges. A racy memento of the 2014 vintage.

wine: Hanna 2010 Bismark Mountain Vineyard Zinfandel (Sonoma Valley)
review: This high altitude vineyard reliably produces enormously ripe fruit with correspondingly giant alcohol and tannin levels. The palate is full of chocolate-covered raisin and blackberry jam flavors, but it's a little over the top.

appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: This brand is undergoing a significant transformation, including a name change (Ascent is new) and a deft touch in the cellar. This pleasing effort has a spicy nose, a soft heart and a lightly toasty finish. Banana and peach, cream and vanilla notes thread through the finish.

wine: Il Conventino 2014  Vino Nobile di Montepulciano
appellation: Vino Nobile di Montepulciano, Tuscany, Italy
review: Truffle, new leather, violet and moist-earth aromas delicately lift out of the glass. The ethereal palate shows sour cherry, pomegranate and a hint of dark culinary spice alongside bright acidity. Lithe tannins offer light, polished support. Drink through 2020.

An interesting wine, with a rich tobacco and clove streak that's distinctive. There are underlying flavors of blackberries and chocolate, and the acidity is just right. It has depth and substance, which are rare at this price. Try pulling this one out and serving it to your wine snob neighbor, blind.

Made from 80% Merlot, this wine is smooth and generously textured. The tannins are already embedded in the black fruits and juicy acidity. Spice from wood aging adds complexity. This is a wine for the medium-term. Drink from 2022.

Earthy aromas of truffle, pressed rose and new leather shape the nose. The structured palate offers licorice, dried black cherry and tobacco alongside fine-grained tannins and fresh acidity. Drink 2022–2031.

wine: Churchill's 2013 Churchill's Estates Grande Reserva Red (Douro)
review: Old vines in a field blend are the basis of this dense and concentrated wine. It is powered both by its tannins and by dark black fruits. This is solid, dark and powerful but still young needing plenty of time for the rich fruits to broaden out and mature. Drink starting from 2019.

wine: Jardin 2015 The Real McCoy Riesling (Western Cape)
review: Forward notes of lanolin, lemon oil and citrus peel lead the nose of this pure and direct Riesling. The palate offers a bit more weight of stone-fruit flavor, though in an incredibly fresh, clean and mouthwatering package. Drink now–2020.

Tannic yet balanced wine with a great swathe of perfumed fruit as well as dense black flavors. There is a herbal character as well as dark plum and sweet fruit flavors. Age for 2–3 years, the wine will always be firm.

Poised and focused Mencía with lush, bold aromas that are powerful and alluring. The palate is healthy and stout, with tannic grip that props up black fruit, toast and charcoal flavors. Black pepper, spice and licorice are the finishing notes.

This Napa-based company has acquired some Oregon Pinot from a top vineyard, and made a tasty, nicely detailed wine with it. Scents and flavors conjure up plum, candied orange peel and baking spices, guaranteed to tickle the taste buds. It's a little bumpy in the finish, perhaps as a result of the long ride south taken by the grapes. Drink now while it's at its best.

appellation: Rogue Valley, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
review: Overall, Rogue Valley Syrahs get better every year, as the vineyards age and when vintage conditions allow for full ripening. This new release brings some green herb and savory flavors to tart fruit flavors of rhubarb and raspberry. There are gentle hints of the cured meat and umami flavors that the better Oregon Syrahs can reveal. This does not taste as ripe as in past vintages. The new oak (40%) barrel flavors are still prominent, with toasted cashew and hazelnut dominating the finish.

wine: Arrocal 2019 Rosa de Arrocal Rosé (Ribera del Duero)
appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
review: An orange color and prickly pyrazine aromas lead to a citric palate that breaks up quickly. Light citrus flavors are noncommittal, while this tastes yeasty and slightly bitter on a raw finish.

Aromas of plum, pipe tobacco, leather and menthol lead the nose along with a whiff of damp soil. The taut medium-bodied palate offers crushed cranberry, wild cherry and baking spice alongside firm, close-grained tannins. Drink 2021–2028.

The potential for a juicy, fruity wine lurks here beneath the youthful, extracted tannins. The wine certainly has density, with its rich structure coming through strongly. However, it needs aging over at least 10 years.

Enticing aromas of balsamic, leather, menthol, crushed herb, blue flower and dark culinary spice unfold on the nose. The focused palate boasts wonderful, nervy energy, showing red cherry, cranberry, white pepper, cinnamon and clove flavors framed by firm, elegant tannins and vibrant acidity. Drink 2022–2032.

Made in a dry, earthy style, this wine chooses elegance and structure over dazzling opulence. And that's just fine. It has a good core of blackberry and currant fruit, and the balance suggests some time in the cellar. Give it 3–4 years.

wine: Feudi di San Gregorio 2015 Studi Fraedane  (Greco di Tufo)
appellation: Greco di Tufo, Southern Italy, Italy
review: Intriguing scents of underbrush, grilled Mediterranean herb, honey and lemon zest carry over to the palate along with ripe yellow pear and almond. A tangy saline note closes the finish. Fresh acidity provides support throughout and gives it an elegant, age-worthy structure. Drink through 2025.

appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: Inviting aromas of Bing cherries, star anise, mace, tobacco and wood spice show on the nose of this blend. There's a strong herbal kick on the earthy palate, where turned loam and red-cherry flavors arise.

Soft, sweet, baked aromas of spice cake and raisin announce a very ripe wine that's almost over the top. Heavy and wide on the palate, with a soft, chunky foundation, this blend of Tempranillo and Merlot tastes of raisin, vanilla, tobacco and cherry liqueur. Oaky mocha flavors control a soft, pudgy finish. Drink now.

wine: Stefano Accordini 2006 Acinatico  (Amarone della Valpolicella Classico)
appellation: Amarone della Valpolicella Classico, Veneto, Italy
review: Amarone Acinatico opens with jammy, ripe fruit aromas and candied fruit followed by cured meat, moist pipe tobacco and beef jerky. It's a big, bold, meaty wine with sweet spice flavors and loads of plump, dense fruit flavors and overall richness.

wine: Ca'Na 2005 Celebration Rose Rosé (Contra Costa County)
appellation: Contra Costa County, Central Coast, California, US
review: Made from Cabernet Sauvignon, this is a full-bodied and rather rustic pink-hued wine, with earthy peach and spice flavors. If you tasted it blind, you might even think it was Chardonnay.

Cloudy's Bay's Chardonnay is a polished and ripe number that feels a touch sweaty on the nose, with ripe melon and stone fruit, honey, flint, florals and a lick of vanillin oak. The palate is thick and creamy but there's a citrusy lift on the midpalate that brightens things, and a wreath of spicy oak adding sophistication.

appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: This wine smells like a bowl of fresh fruit. Aromas of huckleberries and raspberries mix with dried flowers, orange peel and milk chocolate. It's rich and hedonistic in style, with a velvety texture and a finish that won't quit.

wine: Reichsgraf von Kesselstatt 2019 Graach Josephshöfer Grosse Lage Kabinett Feinherb Riesling (Mosel)
designation: Graach Josephshöfer Grosse Lage Kabinett Feinherb
review: Tropical notes of guava and pineapple are struck by crushes of salt and smoke in this intensely fruity, juicy Riesling kabinett. Just a shade sweet and profoundly ripe in fruit, it's an opulent expression of the Mosel but maintains a zingy, steely edge and fine, filigreed finish. Ready now but should maintain peak through 2030 and hold further.

wine: Wrath 2008 Noble Wrath Late Harvest Sauvignon Blanc (Monterey)
review: A fantastically sweet wine, with very high residual sugar. Dazzles with honey, tangerine, apricot and vanilla flavors, but could use extra concentration to earn a higher score.

This mountain-grown wine has a mineral, stone-like flavor that adds lift to the rich, concentrated texture. It unfurls layers of toasted oak, vanilla and baking spice, finding balance from underlying acidity.
Cedar, pencil and tobacco characteristics give this wine an herbaceous earthiness that persists through a full-bodied core of concentrated currant and toasted oak.

wine: DENO 2008 Paso Rouge Alto Pomar Vineyard Estate G-S-M (Paso Robles)
designation: Paso Rouge Alto Pomar Vineyard Estate
appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: Tons of candied grape and lilac aromas show on the nose of this rather aged blend of 60% Grenache, 30% Syrah and 10% Mourvèdre, with root beer and blueberry-sorbet notes. The palate offers a similar array of sweet dark fruit, but the tannic structure and acidity clean it up nicely.

wine: Lomas del Valle 2016 Coastal Cool Climate Wine Single Vineyard Sauvignon Blanc (Casablanca Valley)
designation: Coastal Cool Climate Wine Single Vineyard
review: Lime and green-apple aromas are tight and stony. Bright, juicy and chiseled on the palate, this tastes of wet stones, lime and bell pepper. Citrusy residual flavors along with a note of bitter citrus pith make for an honest finish.

wine: Baglio del Cristo di Campobello 2015 Adènzia White (Sicilia)
review: Enticing scents of spring flower, beeswax and orchard fruit come together in the glass. The elegant, linear palate shows juicy lemon, nectarine, hazelnut and a saline note framed in firm acidity. It closes crisp and clean.

appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
review: Whiffs of savory spice and terra-cotta pots lend rusticity to this unusually earthy Chardonnay. Partial fermentation on grape skins gives the palate grip, accentuating softer tones of bruised apple and pear. Brisk acidity lengthens the finish.

wine: José Maria da Fonseca 2017 Periquita Reserva Red (Península de Setúbal)
review: It is a combination of fruit selection, a longer time in wood and the extra bottle aging that gives this wine its reserva label. With a dense texture and spice and richness from the wood and the juicy black fruits, the wine is developing well and will be ready from late 2020.

Made with 80% Sangiovese, 10% Syrah and 10% Cabernet Sauvignon, this opens with aromas evoking dark berry, underbrush and cedar. The savory, concentrated palate offers blackberry jam, mocha, licorice and a tobacco note set against fine-grained tannins. Drink through 2026.

Tangy and tart in high acidity, this red offers lithe, crisp layers of currant, cranberry and cassis, the fruit from the Immaculate Vineyard. Lengthy, with well-integrated tannin and oak, it has a touch of reduction that adds earthiness and complexity.

wine: Chateau Ste. Michelle 2004 Cold Creek Chardonnay (Columbia Valley (WA))
appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Big, oaky and extremely bright, with refreshing acids and crisply defined fruit. As is usually the case with this spectacular vineyard, the flavors carry extra intensity; they seem to drill down into the heart of the palate. Though released young, this is a wine that could certainly benefit from another 6–12 months in the bottle.

Comes across like a straightforward warm-climate Viognier, meaning it's full and waxy, with peach and nectarine aromas and flavors, a touch of searing heat, and pithiness to the back palate and finish. It's also juicy and zesty due to plenty of acids.

wine: McFadden 2020 Blue Quail Organic Grapes Estate Grown Pinot Gris (Potter Valley)
designation: Blue Quail Organic Grapes Estate Grown
appellation: Potter Valley, Mendocino County, California, US
review: Light floral and apple aromas lead to crisp fruit flavors in this medium-bodied and refreshing wine. It is tangy and appetizing in texture.

wine: Les Frères Couillaud 2014 Château de la Ragotière Vallet  (Muscadet Sèvre et Maine)
appellation: Muscadet Sèvre et Maine, Loire Valley, France
review: This is a beautifully fruity wine with great acidity and citrus flavors contrasting with ripe apple and melon fruitiness. The wine is cool, crisp, full of juicy acidity, and ready to drink now.

wine: Flanagan 2017 Gap's View Vineyard Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)
review: From a new site for the producer, acquired in 2015, this is made in tiny amounts and shows savory character throughout. Floral and earthy, with a note of clove and flint, it's tightly wound in grippy tannin and tart cranberry, cassis and raspberry, with a lasting trace of black tea.

appellation: Monterey County, Central Coast, California, US
review: Smells fragrant and inviting, with aromas of peach, vanilla, smoke and a pretty wildflower streak. In the mouth, the wine seems dominated by high acidity and lees, making it rather tart and sour despite the fruity flavors.
This is a ripe, perfumed wine, smooth from light oak aging and fruity with the black currant flavors. It has attractive acidity and a juicy, spicy finish. The wine is ready to drink.

appellation: Santa Ynez Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: Loads of purple-flower aromas meet with black-plum juice and a hint of roasted meat on the nose of this bottling. A firm range of purple fruits and flowers expands across the palate, while a pinch of baking spice completes the experience.

The wine opens with thick, purple concentration and segues to earthy aromas of asphalt, tar and mineral backed by dark fruit, prune and berry. It's a strange wine with too much emphasis on those heavy resin and tar notes but it would pair well with Mexican chocolate mole sauce.

wine: The Gentleman's Match Wine Co 2015 Madame X Red (Napa Valley)
review: Tight-grained tannins underscore high tones of plum, cherry and coconut shavings in this full-bodied red which blends a majority of Merlot with Cabernet Sauvignon and Malbec. It has brawn and soft approachability.

wine: Château Haut Rozier 2018  Francs Côtes de Bordeaux
appellation: Francs Côtes de Bordeaux, Bordeaux, France
review: Spicy and smoky, this firmly structured wine has rich tannins as well as black fruits, shot through with licorice and acidity. Ripe and well textured, the wine will be ready from 2022.

wine: White Rose 2018 White Rose Vineyard Pinot Noir (Dundee Hills)
appellation: Dundee Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: As with the winery's other Pinots, there's a gentle hand at work, using just 10% new French oak, though this is the top wine from the estate. The low alcohol suggests it was picked early, and the flavors offer a subtle mix of blood orange, plum, blueberry and blackberry fruit. Though delicate, it's not lacking for depth or complexity, and shows medium concentration through a long finish.
An easy, everyday Chard, with apricot and peach flavors and a little oak. Finishes creamy and dry.

wine: Mumm Napa 2010 Blanc de Blancs Sparkling (Napa Valley)
review: This majority Chardonnay-based sparkler is yeasty and dry, offering a refreshingly crisp, firm mousse and subtle core of green apple and ginger. It retains plenty of acidity on the palate and is equally delicious as a solo sipper or with creamy, rich foods.

Tannins and structure bring out the character of the 2010 vintage in this open, generally soft wine. It is already attractive, drinkable and fresh. Black currants dominate the natural fruitiness. Drink now.

With almost four years aging, this wine has developed a softer, nutty quality, while retaining good freshness. It is relatively light in character, a fine mix of green fruits, a more mature almond paste flavor and a fine, tangy edge.

appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
review: An odd wine, at once raw and green, then turning semi-sweet. Too bad, because the tannins are really lush and smooth.

wine: Sangenís I Vaqué 2001 Vall Por Red (Priorat)
review: Cherry, earth and leather are nice opening notes, while some charred oak adds masculinity and depth. Almost syrupy in the mouth, with plenty of black cherry and chocolate to satisfy those with a sweet tooth. Exhibits nice core qualities. Imported by Five Star Imports.

Subdued aromas of espresso, scorched earth and baking spice eventually emerge from the glass. The tightly wound palate offers unripe cherry, orange zest and roasted coffee bean alongside grainy, rather fleeting tannins.

appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: This moderately aromatic wine offers notes of pear, citrus and apricot. It drinks medium sweet with stone-fruit and citrus flavors along with spritely acidity, bringing a whole lot of appeal.

wine: Bodegas y Vinedos Santa Sofia 2002 Urban Oak Red (Uco Valley)
review: Smooth and burly, with meaty, berry aromas preceding a friendly, hefty palate that's chock full of black plum, chocolate and vanilla. With its open-knit finish, this has most of what the average wine lover seeks. This Tempranillo-Malbec blend is solid.

appellation: Rogue Valley, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
review: Sourced from the Folin vineyard, this is quite light and herbal. The flavors move into a tannic midpalate, with tobacco and tea rather than ripe fruit. It spent almost two years in 100% new French oak, which seems to have sent the fruit packing, at least for the time being.

appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: TF stands for Tocai Friulano, a perfectly legitimate grape name that has been outlawed in Oregon and will soon be illegal in its own home of Friuli. It's a fresh, herbal grape, which mixes light grassy flavors, citrus, pineapple and honeydew, with a pleasing mineral undercurrent.

wine: Bernardus 2011 Soberanes Vineyard Chardonnay (Santa Lucia Highlands)
appellation: Santa Lucia Highlands, Central Coast, California, US
review: This is a fine Chardonnay marked by rich, ripe pear, peach and tropical fruit flavors, but also a bright acidity that highlights all the fruit. Notes of buttered toast add richness. It's delicious on its own, but would also be an ideal accompaniment for tapas.

wine: Oakville Ranch 2001 Estate Robert's Blend Red (Oakville)
review: Shows true Cabernet character in the dry, smooth tannins, rich, full-bodied mouthfeel and harmonious flavors of black currants, coffee and oak. It all comes together to make a polished, soft wine. Drink now through 2008.

wine: Damien et Romain Bouchard 2010 Vaillon Premier Cru  (Chablis)
review: With the typical intense acidity of 2010, this is a taut, fruit- and mineral-driven Chablis. Its fruitiness is balanced by judicious toast and vanilla flavors. Age for 2–3 years.

wine: Kir-Yianni 2016 Kali Riza Vieilles Vignes Xinomavro (Amyndeon)
review: Fig, olive and red cherry aromas give this wine an enticing start. On the palate, tomato paste, olive and black cherry flavors are luscious but bright.

Like so many Drouhin wines, this is beautifully balanced. The wood, green fruit, spice and acidity already in fine harmony. There is a richness coming from the deep soils of the vineyard. Can it age? Probably, because of the firm structure.

wine: Flora Springs 2015 Wild Boar Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
review: This comes from a site in Pope Valley on the eastern edge of the appellation, where the grapes are grown at 1,200-feet in elevation. Red currant, clove and turned earth top a layer of grippy reduction and sizable oak, with secondary elements of tar and leather.

wine: Three Rivers 2014 Bacchus Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Columbia Valley (WA))
appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Bacchus Vineyard is home to some of the state's oldest Cabernet vines. There's no mistaking the variety, with its aromas of fresh herb, black currant, blackberry and barrel spice. The palate is lighter on fruit yet heavy in structure, with the tannins giving a firm grip.

Citrus and light herb aromas turn to slightly more buttery, spicy flavors in this medium-bodied well-balanced wine. It has a good sense of richness in the mouthfeel along with hints of vanilla, cream and almond flavors to complement the fruit notes.

appellation: Dry Creek Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: Quivira's basic '05 Zin is a polished, attractive wine, dry and rich in cherries, raspberries, vanilla and dusty spices. It has a silky texture, and will go well with grilled meats and poultry and hard cheeses.

wine: Marston Family 1999 Cabernet Sauvignon (Spring Mountain District)
appellation: Spring Mountain District, Napa, California, US
review: Opens with aromas of black currants, chocolate and olives, then adds toasty oak. The mouthfeel is smooth and velvety, and the wine is fully dry. There's an edge of rough earthiness that keeps it from getting a higher score, but it's still a very good wine. —S.H.

wine: Falcone 2010 Mia's Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Paso Robles)
appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: Akin to a reseve, this barrel selection of the best wines of the vintage is pretty close in quality to Falcone's regular 2010 Cab, although a shade richer. Drink soon with char-broiled steak.

Very pale in color, this Chardonnay doesn't lack in structure or flavor. Lean and crisp, it has aromas of hay and minerals, spicy apple and pear flavors, and a tangy mouthfeel. Angular and engaging, and not just another butterball. Best Buy.

wine: Mumm Napa NV Blanc de Noirs Sparkling (Napa Valley)
review: A little rough in texture, but delicious, with a rich mélange of strawberry parfait, brioche, lime juice, peaches and cream and toast flavors that finish long and dry. Contains 85% Pinot Noir, with the balance Chardonnay, and is easy to find, with 95,000 cases.

appellation: El Dorado, Sierra Foothills, California, US
review: This is a gorgeous Viognier that opens with gentle aromatics of subtle notes of flower and stone fruit—mostly apricot and golden plum. Clear and focused, with a crisp backbone, this contains enough weight to pair with a range of foods, especially anything roasted with apples.

wine: The Calling 2018 Sullivan Vineyard Dutton Ranch Chardonnay (Russian River Valley)
appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: With a rich, dense and fruity nose of baked pear and tropical crème brûlée, this wine is broadly fleshy and lush, with underlying crispness that contrasts and keeps it effortlessly fresh. The bottle is incredibly heavy, but the wine is nicely light.
Smoky and teeth staining with savory blackberry fruit, this Petite is balanced, with a long finish, and will get better with 3–7 years of bottling age. Think grilled meats when pairing.
