A mid-weight Zin, with a tannic backbone and a soft mouthfeel plus, rich and interesting blackberry and coffee. Encrust some ribs, chops or tenderloin in coffee grounds to pair with this wine for explosive results.
Shows lean red berry and herb aromas. Mild tea and currant flavors play on the tongue, but the desired weight and texture of Shiraz aren't there. Finishes short, with a tea note.

wine: Bird in Hand 2001 Sparkling Pinot Noir Pinot Noir (Adelaide Hills)
review: This rose-colored sparkler boasts alluring aromas of baking bread and strawberry jam on toast. The palate is fresh and lively, laced with strawberries and cream. Refreshing and satisfying.

Sharp, tightly wound raspberry fruit on a clean but dry frame. A little lean and leathery; the tannins grab hold and don't let go. Simple, straight-ahead California red wine blended from grapes grown in Napa, El Dorado and San Joaquin counties.

There is good balance between citrus and tropical-fruit flavors in this wine. Wood aging gives an extra dimension of richness to the wine, which comes from a chateau close to Smith Haut Lafitte. Drink from 2022.

This is black and tarry on first take, but complex aromas of pine, baked plum and wood smoke emerge. It has a nice full body and a few levels of texture, while the wine's dark plum and berry flavors are generously spiced. This is composed, full and grabby on the finish. Drink now through 2018.

wine: Dorigo NV Dosaggio Zero Metodo Classico Pinot Nero (Vino Spumante)
review: Field-flower, chamomile and orchard-fruit aromas lead the way on this savory sparkler. On the dry palate, tangy acidity balances white cherry, white peach and ginger while a citrusy note lifts the finish.
This opens with ripe black-fruit, toasted oak and cooking-spice aromas. The brawny palate offers prune, roasted coffee bean and vanilla packed in assertive tannins.

wine: Cathedral Ridge 2013 Dampier Vineyard Pinot Noir (Columbia Gorge (OR))
appellation: Columbia Gorge (OR), Oregon Other, Oregon, US
review: This is a pleasant bottle, with delicate fruit flavors that suggest watermelon and strawberry—nothing riper. There's a distinct impression of white balsamic vinegar, adding a high-toned lift that's just on the edge of too much, at least for some tasters.

This friendly wine offers fresh, jammy berry and cherry aromas. The palate has a bit of grit and stickiness to it, while blackberry, black cherry and boysenberry flavors are ripe, sweet, not pushy and ultimately satisfying.

A big, dark wine that is full of black plums, figs and spice. Firm, dry tannins support the intense fruit flavors. Aging in French oak gives the wine a richness, a touch of vanilla and smooths the edges. Imported by Aidil Wines & Liquor Inc.

appellation: Southern Oregon, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
review: Nothing stands out here, but it's a perfectly sound and drinkable wine, with round, clean fruity flavors. Apple and pear notes come together, with a touch of pineapple and citrus zest.

Intense blackberry, vanilla and violet aromas start this stylish red from Nemea. Flavors of cherry, tobacco and mocha are balanced by a pert acidity. The finish is long and fruity. The wine has structure and complexity, and while very good now, will benefit from aging.

wine: Cooper-Garrod 2009 Lone Oak Vineyard Estate Cabernet Sauvignon (Santa Cruz Mountains)
appellation: Santa Cruz Mountains, Central Coast, California, US
review: Lightly toasted tobacco, blueberry pie and cedar scents lead the way on this single-vineyard Cab. Fresh blueberry on the palate combines with a great arc of flavors that ends in a chewed cigar finish.

From a 66-acre vineyard in the heart of Pauillac, this wine has powerful Cabernet Sauvignon as an important part of the blend, bringing out juicy black-currant fruits along with rich tannins. Weighty and concentrated, the wine needs to age. Drink from 2023.
Fresh and fruity, laced with citrus, crisp apricot and a delicious layer of lime juice. Drink now, but the wine will age a year.

Excellent due to the sheer fabulosity of its flavors, which are rich and opulent in black currant, blackberry and roast coffee. But this is a young wine, with sharp acids, and the tannins leave a drying sensation after you swallow. It hasn't all knit together yet.

The 18 months in wood has enhanced the already succulent, exuberant black fruits of this wine. Black-coffee flavors combine with dense tannins and black-plum flavors to produce a superrich, big-hearted wine. Drink from 2024.

wine: Château Petit Boyer 2018 Unique Terroir Premium Lieu-Dit Merigot  (Blaye Côtes de Bordeaux)
appellation: Blaye Côtes de Bordeaux, Bordeaux, France
review: This powerful wine relishes its weight and richness. Dense tannins speak of extraction as well as ripe black fruits. The wine has power, but it is saved from excess by acidity and the core of juicy black currants. Drink from 2022.

Truly delicious, with bright mineral tones that are wrapped tight around aromas of citrus, peach and Golden Delicious apple. There's soft creaminess in the mouth and loads of bright intensity that makes it easy to love and easy to drink.

wine: Giuseppe Lonardi 2008  Valpolicella Classico Superiore Ripasso
appellation: Valpolicella Classico Superiore Ripasso, Veneto, Italy
review: Wood shop aromas make a big first impression and add a tight, bitter sensation to the nose. Beyond those obvious wood tones are layers of dark fruit and spice that give the wine a bold, chewy personality.

wine: Famille Perrin 2014 Red (Côtes du Rhône Villages)
appellation: Côtes du Rhône Villages, Rhône Valley, France
review: There's a subdued elegance to the crisp black plum and cherry flavors in this full-bodied red. While brisk in concentration, it refreshes with whiffs of garrigue and granite. The finish is marked by fine, firm tannins.

wine: Domaine Jessiaume 2018 Les Brouillards Premier Cru  (Volnay)
review: A note of cinnamon on dark fruit emanates from the glass, suggesting sumptuousness. The palate of this wine follows up with concentrated, ripe fruit that is reminiscent of blackberry with its freshness and darkness. Ripe tannins that brush slightly lend a firm frame to this juicy, concentrated ripeness.

wine: Curtis 2007 Vogelzang Vineyard Syrah (Santa Ynez Valley)
appellation: Santa Ynez Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: Grill a nice steak and wash it down with this richly textured, gentle Syrah. Dry and smoky, it has black pepper-infused flavors of blackberries, currants and singed bacon. Gives lots of elegant pleasure for the price.

wine: Brassfield 2016 Volcano Ridge Vineyard Mourvèdre (High Valley)
appellation: High Valley, Lake County, California, US
review: This wine tastes powerful and has a robust mouthfeel. A dark-ruby color leads to slightly smoky, peppery aromas and concentrated tight flavors like cranberry and smoked cherries. The texture is firmed up by fine-grained tannins that may need time to mellow. Best after 2021.
White spring flower and tropical fruit aromas waft out of the glass. On the crisp palate, racy acidity accompanies grapefruit and pineapple before an almond close.

wine: Borgoluce 2016 Rive di Collalto  (Valdobbiadene Prosecco Superiore)
review: Delicate scents of wisteria, acacia, herb and beeswax lift out of the glass. It's both lively and ethereal, offering yellow apple, Bartlett pear and a citrus note framed in crisp acidity and silky perlage.

wine: Domaine Aegerter 2018 Les Petites Corvées  (Bourgogne Hautes Côtes de Nuits)
appellation: Bourgogne Hautes Côtes de Nuits, Burgundy, France
review: There is a good balance between ripe red fruits and tannins in this wine from the hills behind Nuits Saint-Georges. It has a fresh feel that is filled out with the wine's structure. Drink from 2022.

Made from organically farmed grapes, this evokes mature black-skinned fruit, leather and forest floor aromas. It's warm and densely concentrated on the palate; fleshy black plum, tobacco and aniseed flavors leave it feeling one-dimensional. Drink 2018–2022.
A soft, creamy wine, with bright yellow fruits and just the right amount of acidity. Green apple skins give texture to go with a citrus aftertaste. Screw cap.

Earthen tones of struck flint and smoke need time and aeration to allow prettier notes of grapefruit and honeysuckle to appear. A powerful, full-bodied dry Riesling, it penetrates with tart tangerine flavor and a zesty cutting mouthfeel. This tight mineral-dense Riesling needs time to meld. Hold till 2023.

L'Eremita is a spicy Recioto della Valpolicella (a red dessert wine made from the same blend of grapes as Amarone) that boasts savory tones of cigar box, barbecue smoke, brown sugar and teriyaki. The wine shows some tannins with an otherwise smooth and creamy mouthfeel.

The faintest gleams of flint, smoke and mango try to escape from this still tightly closed wine. A bouncy, toned, totally ripe core displays pineapple, mandarin and hints of mango, all framed by zesty lemon with satisfying length.

wine: Futura 14 2013 Il Rosso di Vespa Primitivo (Salento)
review: This warm, brawny wine opens with aromas of tilled soil, underbrush, plum and ripe, dark berry. The dense, spicy palate delivers prune, raisin, licorice and ground black pepper alongside velvety tannins. The heat of evident alcohol dominates the finish.

wine: Quinta das Carvalhas NV 20 Year Old Tawny  (Port)
review: At the perfect moment of aging, this 20-year-old Port is smoothly textured and rich in dried fruits that are balanced by wood and spice flavors. This is a very fine wine, ready to drink now.

Bogle blends grapes from 30-year-old Amador vines, 60-year-old Lodi vines, and 80-year-old Oakley vineyards to produce a truly great wine for the price. A briary, raisiny nose leads into succulent flavors of plum, allspice, cocoa and   coffee. It's a brawny, rustic wine that is immensely likeable despite some rough tannins.

wine: Domaine Jean Grivot 2004 Les Boudots Premier Cru  (Nuits-St.-Georges)
review: Right at the northern end of Nuits-St.-Georges, this premier cru vineyard combines the elegance of neighboring Vosne-Romanée with the more savage character of Nuits. There is a wild, rustic element, plus rounded black fruits and delicious freshness under the rich tannins.

This tart and tasty wine, one of three new Chardonnays from Trisaetum, offers fresh flavors of cucumber, lime and pineapple. It's solidly built and firmly structured, moving across the palate with precision and polish. A touch of toasted almonds leaves a final impression.

Underbrush, cassis and star anise aroma follow over to the firm palate together with dried Morello cherry, espresso, powdered sage and a hint of tobacco. Tightly stretched, close-grained tannins leave an assertive, slightly astringent finish. Give the tannins a few years to unclench then drink up.
A nose of grapefruit and lemon with a hint of thyme sets the stage for flavors of lemon-lime, pineapple, vanilla and white flowers. This wine is bright from first sip until lingering citrus finish.

appellation: Carmel Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: Long on flavor, this is a classy wine meant for white tablecloths. The pleasant aromas are of green olives, smoke, white chocolate and berries, and a hint of bacon fat. Drinks soft and plush, striking a nice balance between herbs and fruit. Some sharpness from acids is okay, and suggests short-term ageworthiness.

Blueberry and raspberry on the nose of this impressive, well-priced Shiraz entice, and on the palate, a balance of lively fruit, bright flavors and spice make this an attractive everyday sip. A touch of smoke and blackberry add to its appeal.

wine: Kokomo 2013 Timber Crest Vineyard Zinfandel (Dry Creek Valley)
appellation: Dry Creek Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: Smoky red and black berry wrap themselves around a full-bodied expression of fruit and introverted oak, managing to provide texture and body through a foundation of well-managed acidity. With a grippiness on the finish, the wine offers velvety power and finesse.

88–90. Barrel Sample. This wine has richness and concentration, with tense acidity. It has a rustic edge to the ripe blackberry fruit and spice. It is rich, with generous tannins, perfect for mid-term enjoyment.
Very mineral in character, this is an elegant and crisp wine. The perfumes are a vivid balance to the fresh green fruits, with a light layer of acidity. Screwcap.

wine: Longoria 2000 Santa Rita Hills Chardonnay (Santa Barbara County)
appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
review: Longtime vintner Rich Longoria has crafted an intensely flavored wine whose tastes are exotic, even eccentric. Bosc pears dominate, with their spicy, nutty flavors,   augmented by rich oak and the creamy mouth-  feel from lees. It's a big, thick wine with good acidity. —S.H.
Very spicy from wood aging, this is a toasty, solid, dark hued wine. It has a dense, dry texture, that doesn't allow much space for the fruit. It's always likely to be austere.

appellation: Dundee Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: This unoaked wine is made entierly from estate-grown fruit. It offers green apple, green melon, kiwi and lime flavors that build to a pleasing midpalate. It hangs there before trailing off into a lightly grassy finish.

wine: Doyenne 2013 Grand Ciel Grand Ciel Vineyard Syrah (Red Mountain)
appellation: Red Mountain, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: The aromas are brooding, with notes of orange peel, mineral, raspberry and cranberry. The palate is flavorful yet reserved with a lingering fruit-filled finish.

wine: Living Roots 2017 Coastal Wattle Cabernet Sauvignon (McLaren Vale)
review: An austere, savory expression of South Aussie Cab from an Aussie/American ex-pat couple living full time in Rochester, New York, this wine opens with aromas of sage, mint, mocha and peppery oak spice amidst blueberry and currant fruit, licorice and streaks of dusty earth. The palate is austere and linear, with the acidity and tightly wound, chalky tannins taking center stage. But the silky fruit is present too, along with a savory finish. Give this time in bottle and then sip with protein at hand. Drink now through 2027.

wine: Chatter Creek 2002 Alder Ridge Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Columbia Valley (WA))
appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: With its medium body and supple tannins, this seems destined to be consumed young. Vanilla and pastry-crust notes accent raspberry fruit on the nose, while on the palate, chocolate and caramel shadings frame tart red berries, turning cedary on the finish.

wine: Château Léoville Las Cases 2014 Le Petit Lion Barrel Sample  (Saint-Julien)
review: 92–94. Barrel Sample. Smooth Merlot has given this wine power and a sense of weight. The freshness and ripe black-fruit flavors come from the Cabernet. It's structured while still boasting fresh fruit and ample acidity on the finish.

appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
review: Funky and gassy at first, but with time leather and wild berries emerge on the nose. The mouth offers red plum and blackberry, while the lean, starchy finish is tight, tannic and oaky. Very zippy and alive, with raisin and chocolate nuances.

appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Bright aromas of melted butter, vanilla, candlewax and peach lead to broad feeling stone fruit flavors, with a bitter note on the finish. The oak seems a bit intense for the fruit.

appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: Made in a rather austere style, with minimal time in oak, this wine offers crisp texture and body complemented by a tartness of Golden Delicious apple that finishes with creamy lushness.

wine: Brys 2013 Estate Grown Pinot Noir (Old Mission Peninsula)
review: While the nose seems dominated by oak, with charred bacon and cola aromas, the palate shows plenty of fruit, offering velvety dark cherry in the lead. Savory spice notes streak across the plush, structured palate, giving way to a mocha finish. There's enough acidity and tannic structure to explore how this will develop in the years to come. Give it another year or two for the oak to integrate further.

Aromas of road tar, blackberry and rubber are a touch chemical but not bad. A raw palate with rubbery tannins is home to generic plum and berry flavors. A dry rubbery-feeling finish is appropriate for this everyday Tempranillo.

wine: Montemar 2014 Thompson Vineyard Syrah (Santa Barbara County)
appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
review: Zesty aromas of cranberry and slight purple fruits meet with purple flowers and wet soil on the shy nose of this bottling. The palate is lighter in expression, offering white-pepper spices alongside crisp black-raspberry flavors.

wine: Elyse 1999 Morisoli Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
review: Sweet oak and ripe fruit lead off. The follow-up features bright blackberry, currant, sage, thyme and toast flavors. Tannins are firm and fairly ripe, though slightly drying on the finish. —J.M.

This simple red has a shy nose that eventually shows suggestions of iron, violet and menthol while the extremely evolved palate offers the merest suggestions of prune and rusty nail. Fleeting, dusty tannins give it an abrupt, astringent close.

wine: Pavona 2001 Coastal Selection Pinot Noir (Monterey County)
appellation: Monterey County, Central Coast, California, US
review: Delicate all around in body, texture and flavor. Shows cola, cherry, tobacco and spice, with silky tannins and those crisp Central Coast acids.

The Jackson and Hartford families established this vineyard on the far Sonoma Coast in hopes of crafting Pinot Noir at the limits of its ability to ripen. The magnificent 2007 vintage has resulted in a wine of unusual tension. It's very ripe in black and red cherry pie filling and sweet oak flavors, but retains the acidity of its cool-climate origins, and even offers a feral taste of bloody meat. Drink this impressive, complex wine now and through 2015.

wine: Domaine Pierre Luneau-Papin 2007 Clos des Allées Vieilles Vignes  (Muscadet Sèvre et Maine)
appellation: Muscadet Sèvre et Maine, Loire Valley, France
review: Super-fresh, this is tight, full of green fruit and crisp apple flavors. It has some concentration under all this freshness, a structure coming from the cool year. This is classic, but very superior, seafood-friendly Muscadet.

wine: Dr. Loosen 2016 Wehlener Sonnenuhr Spätlese Riesling (Mosel)
review: Luxurious guava, grapefruit and red berry aromas perfum this intensely fruity, sun-kissed spätlese. It's wispy and spry on the palate but penetrating acidity guides a long brambly finish. Approachable already but structured enough to stay pristine well through 2025.

appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: Delicate, herbal, ultra light. Clean, correct, but dilute.
Packaged in a fun screwcap bottle, this easy Primitivo opens with bitter almond and cherry flavors, followed by crisp fruit and citrus freshness. It would pair with grilled pork chops.

Luminous blackberry and raspberry flavors are edged by shards of stone and smoke in this deeply fruity but intensely mineral Syrah. It's fresher and brighter in fruit than the producer's other 2016 Hermitage, full bodied but taut and bracing in feel. Rigid tannins should meld as the wine opens and gains complexity. Best enjoyed from 2022, it should reward cellaring well through 2040.

wine: Marco Abella 2015 Roca Grisa Single Vineyard Carignan (Priorat)
review: A warm vintage resulted in a ripe varietal Carignan that offers black fruit, raisin and vanilla aromas. A fleshy, pulpy palate is in balance but hefty, while this tastes of ripe black fruits, prune and cassis. A steady and deep finish offers a blueberry essence and long echoes of ripeness. Drink through 2026.

wine: Leonard Kreusch 2017 Piesporter Michelsberg Auslese Riesling (Mosel)
review: Pristine grapefruit, yellow peach and fresh apricot flavors abound in this honeyed, intensely fruity Riesling. It's sweet on the palate but balanced by spine tingling acidity and a touch of saffron on the finish. An excellent value Auslese to enjoy now–2025.

wine: Papapietro Perry 2003 Leras Family Vineyards Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)
appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: There's good acidity in this wine, with fruit that seems too extracted and sweet, like a baked, granulated sugar-infused cherry pie. If you're a fruit freak, this will do it for you.

This crisp, tangy and refreshing wine has lemon and green-apple aromas, bright citrus flavors, medium body and a lean texture, due mostly to the generous acidity. Raw oysters on the half shell, garlic shrimp and goat-cheese toasts come to mind as good pairings.

appellation: Yorkville Highlands, North Coast, California, US
review: This excellent wine from a steep terraced vineyard offers beautiful aromas of lavender and violet that segue to a palate replete with black fruit, black pepper and anise tones. Each flavor seems especially well defined and they layer together harmoniously on a velvety texture that provides good support for all that concentration. Best after 2020.
High-altitude vineyards in central Sicily yield a finely concentrated wine, with fruit aromas and crisp, green fruit.

wine: Monte da Ravasqueira 2018 Ravasqueria Touriga Franca (Alentejano)
review: This grape, normally found in the Douro, makes a perfumed appearance in the Alentejo. The wine's ripe tannins give density while bringing out red fruits and a fresh edge. Sourced from two parcels, the wine will be ready from 2023.

appellation: Monterey County, Central Coast, California, US
review: A brilliant shade of pink, this bottling offers plenty of melon, rose and chalk aromas on the nose. The palate grabs hold with just enough texture, leading into lemon and cantaloupe flavors.

wine: Full Pull & Friends 2007 CVBDX Red (Columbia Valley (WA))
appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: This well-aged wine announces itself with aromas of leather, cherry cordial, dried fruit, mushroom and medicine, showing its age in a pleasing way. The palate brings a seamless feel to the cranberry and cherry flavors, supported by the impressive acidity of the vintage. It's in a sweet spot and an outrageous value for a wine of this age.

This is Yangarra's foray into this very Australian preservative-free category of wines, and the result is delicious. Brambly fruit, baking spices, coffee, vanilla and ground peppercorn aromas lead to a palate that is plush but firm, deftly woven with stony, mineral tannins, an earthy core and a long savory, herbal finish. This is a clean-cut, warming wine that makes you want to eat a gamy casserole on a cold day in winter.

Candied and simple, with candied flavors of pineapple, lemon, lime and vanilla, this pleasant wine finishes a little sweet, but is balanced by crisp, citrusy acids. It's notable for the clean, richly fruity finish.

Spicy, mushroomy and earthy, full of forest floor character, what the French would call sous bois. It's nicely textured as well, supple and round, just don't expect a fruit explosion. Imported by Station Imports Inc.

wine: Domaine Jacques Prieur 2001 Clos de la Feguine Premier Cru  (Beaune)
designation: Clos de la Feguine Premier Cru
review: The aromas aren't too different from what you might find in a New World Chardonnay: toast, butter, cinnamon and apples, but the mouthfeel is hard and unyielding, and there's a firm spine of lemony acidity. Needs some time; try from 2005–2010.

wine: Domaine des Remizières 2000 Cuvée Emilie White (Hermitage)
review: A wine that is dominated by ripe exotic fruits, plums and a hint of green figs. There is wood, but it is not at all obvious, while the ripeness is balanced with a touch of acidity and some attractive bitter-almond flavors.

wine: Le Vigne 2018 Di Domenico Petite Sirah (Paso Robles)
appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: Focused aromas of blackberry, black currant, cocoa and warm toast invite the nose into this bottling. It's very dark and big-boned on the classically formed palate, where the mouthfilling dark-berry flavors are lifted by a pinch of mint.

Dry and nicely oaked, with hints of fine aged cheese, campfire, dried fruits and leather. The palate is a little more fruity than the nose, but still it's dry and tight, with raspberry and cherry flavors. While some acidity sits on the surface, overall this gran reserva is tasty, fresh and more than likable. Drink now through 2013.

appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: Most of the estate vines used for this blend date back to the mid-1970s. It emphasizes bright citrus flavors, like lemon and lime, with lemon verbena, cilantro and other fresh herb notes that add detail to the finish. A very fine value, it can also age for a decade or longer.

Dusty, oaky aromas of papaya, corn and green banana precede a full, buttery palate with matching flavors of buttery oak, papaya, creamy vanilla and green banana. Brine and popcorn notes protrude from an otherwise mild finish.

Superstar Egon Müller has at least kept his basic Riesling at an affordable level. At first, it's almost odorless, but give it a chance to develop in the glass and delicate apple, fern and lime notes emerge. A hint of CO2 adds to the impression of lightness, and the wine finishes crisp, racy and clean. A finesse-filled wine likely best in its youth.

wine: Ozwell Vintners 2008 Flying Piano Hand Select Chardonnay (South Eastern Australia)
appellation: South Eastern Australia, Australia Other, Australia
review: Bursting with bold, fully ripe fruit notes of pear and peach, followed up with tropical notes, this is a lush fruit bomb of a Chardonnay to drink over the near term (3–4 months).
This is a dense wine that has plenty of fresh fruit to support its weight. It's quite tannic though, so enjoy with food. It could also do with time, so wait two years.
This Chard is bit thin and soft, with straightforward fruit-cocktail flavors. But it's clean and crisp, and at this price, it's just fine for parties.

wine: Domaine Viticole de la Ville de Colmar NV Brut Chardonnay (Crémant d'Alsace)
winery: Domaine Viticole de la Ville de Colmar
review: Gentle notes of Golden Delicious apple on the nose continue with equal mellowness on the palate. Hints of grapefruit add a note of bitter pith while frothy bubbles liven things up. The dry finish is zesty, generously fruity and fresh.

wine: Anne Amie 2002 Hawks View Vineyard Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)
appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: Forward, engaging and nicely fruited wine, with a tart, dry body and pretty, dried spices. Elegant.

Showing slightly better than it did a year ago when last reviewed, the 2000 boasts sweet plum fruit, ample earthiness and refined spice flavors. As vintage Ports go, it's not the biggest or most concentrated, but shows a fine sense of harmony and balance.

Ripe in cherries and blackberries, generously oaked, with firmer tannins and acids than most anything you'd get from Napa, which is the inevitable comparison. A minor quibble is the taste of raisins, the result of overripeness in the grapes.
Smoke, chocolate, toffee, spice and caramel. It's ripe, very open, full-bodied, with a rich Merlot character.

wine: Panther Creek 2000 Youngberg Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)
appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: Like every Panther Creek Pinot we tasted, there is lots of oak—too much for one of our panelists. But there's also a bounty of pristine black fruit aromas and smoky bacon. In the mouth, it's lush, still with ample barrel char, but with even more lip-smacking plum fruit.

wine: Monte da Ravasqueira 2018 Ravasqueira Premium Branco White (Alentejano)
review: A year in wood has enriched this fine blend of Viognier, Alvarinho, Arinto and Marsanne. Richly textured, showing great white fruits, citrus and hints of tropical flavors, the wine will need a few more months to reach its peak. Drink from late 2021.

A wiry, minty nose with aromas of herbs, compost and strawberry is pushy and direct. In the mouth, this feels grabby and tight, with driving tannins. Flavors of baked berry, carob and herbs finish with a prune-driven character, heat and choppy tannins.
This opens with subdued aromas of baking spice and red plum. The straightforward palate delivers vanilla, espresso, licorice and a hint of dried cherry alongside assertive tannins.

appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: A Rhône blend of Syrah, Mourvèdre, Zinfandel and Grenache, this is a soft, dry wine, with dusty tannins framing cherry, coffee and herb flavors. Shows some real class. Drink now.

wine: Domaine Carneros 2010 Le Rêve Estate Grown Blanc de Blancs Chardonnay (Carneros)
designation: Le Rêve Estate Grown Blanc de Blancs
review: This gorgeous wine is floral and doughy, made entirely from Chardonnay and given time to mellow and mature over many years. The patience is rewarded in intensely complex layers of apple, pear and lemon—a caramelized backdrop providing appropriate richness and accents of gingerbread and doughy brioche.

wine: Duca di Salaparuta 2008 Calanìca Nero d'Avola-Merlot Red (Sicilia)
review: There are several versions of Calanìca made from various blends of red grapes. This version combines Nero d'Avola and Merlot, and opens with ripe aromas of black cherry and dried raspberry. The mouthfeel is soft, simple and chewy.

This is a big, slightly rustic Pinot that marches to a decidedly unfruity beat. Coffee and mushroom aromas set the stage, then add cola and earth notes on the palate. Finishes long, but with some rough edges; give it 2–3 years in the cellar.

wine: Côté Mas NV Brut Rosé Sparkling (Crémant de Limoux)
review: The aromas of this pretty, refreshing rosé are delicate and subtle at first. Faint scents of white cherry, raspberry and red-apple skin build strength and concentration on the medium-weight palate. The mouthfeel is bright, juicy and mouthwatering, while a toasty, spicy accent unfolds on the finish. Drink now.

This is a spicy and gritty expression of Aglianico with aromas of blackberry jam, mineral and Indian spice all backed by long-lasting succulence. You'll enjoy the wine's firm texture and bright fruit flavors.

The wine, from one of the top vineyard areas of Morgon, has great richness along with spice from wood aging. The texture gives a dry core, although the wood has smoothed the wine out, enhancing juicy black-cherry flavors. Drink the wine from 2021.

wine: Spot-On 2007 Bells Echo Vineyard Syrah (Mendocino County)
appellation: Mendocino County, Mendocino County, California, US
review: Dry, tannic and peppery, a Northern Rhône-style Syrah that will pair well with game. It has flavors of ripe, wild forest blackberries, blueberries and grilled mushrooms, accented with smoky oak. Best now-2011.

wine: Maximin Grünhäuser 2016 Abtsberg GG Grosse Lage Riesling (Mosel)
review: Pretty blossom, guava and pink grapefruit notes abound in this gorgeously perfumed, dry Riesling. It's lively and fresh, but maintains a creamy lusciousness on the palate. Concentrated and zingy, it lingers through a long finish marked by murmurs of astringency. Drinks beautifully already but should improve through 2030 and hold further.

wine: Von Siebenthal 2010 Tatay de Cristóbal Carmenère (Aconcagua Valley)
review: Forgetting about the crazy price, this is a rustic wine with graphite, green herb, tobacco and marzipan aromas. The mouthfeel is hard and resiny, while flavors of blue fruits, graphite and oak finish green, candied and sweet. Overall, this is a particular wine that requires patience and digging.

Tilled soil, forest floor, mature black-skinned fruit, leather and a truffle note come together in the glass. The firmly structured palate presents juicy black cherry, crushed raspberry, cinnamon, vanilla and an earthy hint of game while assertive, close-grained tannins provide support. Give it a few years for the tannins to relax then enjoy. Drink 2019–2023.
Fruity aromas of ripe red berry and mature plum are accompanied by whiffs of baking spice and fennel. The palate offers oak, espresso, licorice and toast framed by astringent, woody tannins.

wine: M. Chapoutier 2018 Belleruche Red (Côtes du Rhône)
appellation: Côtes du Rhône, Rhône Valley, France
review: In this wine, hints of toasted caramel and licorice lend spice to intensely ripe blackberry and cassis. Voluptuous and creamy on the palate, it's balanced by fresh acidity and a peppery fringe of tannins on the finish. Best now–2023.

appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Peaches, melon and the unmistakable scent of fresh cream cheese comprise the nose, which is backed up by a good mix of tangerine, melon, pear and apple. The mouthfeel is round and satisfying, while the finish is broad and substantive. Not a bad domestic Chenin.

wine: E16 2012 Trenton 1880 Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)
appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: This wine has a soft, earthy dullness, despite decent raspberry, cola and oak flavors. It's not an ager, so drink up.

wine: Troon 2006 Steelhead Run Vineyard Viognier (Applegate Valley)
appellation: Applegate Valley, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
review: This aromatic wine has a strong floral scent that opens into more typical notes of tart lime skin and pineapple. It continues with similar palate impressions, then leaves a somewhat oily aftertaste, like a swallow of perfume.

This alluring blend of Roditis and Moschofilero offers elegant aromas of white flowers and melon, followed by honeyed waves of citrus, flowers and white fruit. Curvy and lush, the wine still finishes clean and easy. A fun white for everyday enjoyment.

An interesting, complex wine with the peppery aroma of a fine Northern Rhône. But the softness and forward fruit are all California. Tastes like blackberry tea with a shot of cassis followed by a shot of cocoa. Sweet oak is there, too.

wine: Ninquén 2007 Antu Mountain Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon-Carmenère (Colchagua Valley)
review: Dark, powerful and minty, with a strong blast of sawdust, black fruit marmalade and perfume on the bouquet. The palate shows potent acidity and bracing tannins, while the flavors are dark and feature a fair share of vanilla, butter and creamy accents. Cola and cassis cover the finish. Drinkable now but better from late 2010 through 2012.

This opens with aromas of dark berry, underbrush and chewing tobacco. The structured savory palate offers Morello cherry, star anise and a note of white pepper alongside fine-grained tannins. Drink 2022–2029.

wine: Lion Ranch 2017 Three Lions Red (Santa Clara Valley)
appellation: Santa Clara Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: Dried cherry, damp forest-floor and light mushroom-tea aromas show on the nose of this blend of 74% Grenache, 13% Cinsault and 13% Counoise. The wine starts with a peppery kick, then weaves through flavors of hibiscus and cinnamon that linger across the light but textural structure.

wine: Château La Mothe du Barry 2010 Vieilles Vignes  (Bordeaux Supérieur)
review: A solid and dense wine, this is full of firm tannins, plus black currant and berry flavors. It is well structured and concentrated, a benefit from using fruit sourced from low-yield old vines. With its dark, dense texture, it will age for several years.

This estate, run by the same family for five generations, has produces a structured wine. Its firm tannins and generous black-plum fruits suggest aging potential. Full bodied and rich, the wine should be drunk from 2019.

This wine has aromas like toasted bread and black pepper, followed by ripe blackberry flavors and a firm structure of grippy tannins and mild acidity. It is medium to full bodied and offers plenty of character, so don't let the screwcap be a negative.
Aromas of pomegranate and chocolate set the scene for flavors of strawberry, raspberry, white chocolate and anisette. Medium-weight tannins and a good mouthfeel lead into a licorice-tinged finish.
Dominated by Pinot Noir, this Champagne is rich, full and creamy. With some bottle age, it has become lightly toasty while still retaining a fruity citrus and apple character.
This is a rich, plush wine that's soft and simple at its core, heady in licorice aromas. On the palate, expect an exuberance of leather, coconut and dark chocolate flavors.

This wine from the Trambusti company features a nose of pepper, leather and mint. The palate runs sharp, with berry fruit, black pepper and some pronounced bell pepper. Ripeness is in doubt here; the back end is extremely green and peppery, and just doesn't have the fruit flavors of a well-ripened Sangiovese. But structure seems right.

wine: Evergreen Vineyards 2008 Spruce Goose Riesling (Willamette Valley)
appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: Laurent Montalieu is the winemaker behind the Spruce Goose wines. This young Riesling is a snappy, palate-awakening wine with lemon-lime fruit, a hint of mint, fine length and a persistent, fresh finish.

This is a screaming deal for a wine of this quality: a light, delicate and earthy expression of the grape that's stemmy and spicy. Forest floor, bark and dark brooding fruit meet a tangle of tight-woven acidity dipped in orange zest.

appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
review: An interesting wine that belies its price. Rich blackberry flavors ride side-by-side with earthy, herbal notes of dark coffee and tobacco. A good percentage of new French oak shows up, especially in the vanilla and toast accents of the aroma. This full-bodied, bone-dry wine has a lot of richness.

wine: Alma Rosa 2004 Pinot Noir (Sta. Rita Hills)
appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
review: Here's a heavy, dense, slightly sweet Pinot that may not be at its best now. It's young and jammy, in the way of a wine that hasn't had time to settle down. But the fruit is huge, and the tannins and acids are all there. Cellar until at least 2007.

wine: Gainey 2005 Limited Selection Sauvignon Blanc (Santa Ynez Valley)
appellation: Santa Ynez Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: Another beautiful wine from Gainey, a great producer whose Sauvignon Blanc comes from one of the best terroirs for that variety in California. The aroma is so invitingly rich in lemongrass, pineapple zest, Key lime pie and coconut macaroon that you almost fear it won't follow up in the mouth, but it does. Bone dry, rich, zesty and clean, it seems to have benefited from the coolness of the vintage, in the way the beautifully ripe fruit is accented by crisp, flinty acidity. This is gorgeous, world-class Sauvignon Blanc.

This fragrant, softly herbal wine has a creamy texture. Its orange-zest tang is balanced by ripe apple fruits and lifted by acidity. The balance between richness and freshness is just right. Drink from 2020.
Pure fruits and black currant juice flavor are just lightly layered with some tannins making this wine easy, fresh and refreshing. Enjoy now.

A 50-50 California Cab Franc-Oregon Pinot Noir blend, this works better than most attempts to blend Pinot Noir with anything. It's aromatically focused, scented with exotic incense that's soft, sultry and smooth. The fruit suggests cherry and plum, with streaks of stem, leaf and rather stiff tannins. It's the barrel flavors that help to pull it all together.

wine: Le Mas de l'Ecriture 2005 Emotion Occitane Red (Coteaux du Languedoc)
review: Enjoyable and approachable now with straightforward red cherry, berry and game notes spiced up by glimmers of mocha and nutmeg. Linear in the mouth with soft tannins and a clean finish.

appellation: Central Coast, Central Coast, California, US
review: A vibrantly tropical nose of guava and ripe pear meets with a touch of hard vanilla candy on this affordably priced wine from the pioneer winery of Paso Robles. It's a powerfully flavorful, cocktail-style Chardonnay, with prominent papaya and mango fruit, followed by a blast of acidity and kiwi grassiness on the finish.

wine: Viña Pérez Cruz 2005 Reserva Cabernet Sauvignon (Maipo Valley)
review: Here's a full-force Maipo red that's ready to run. The black cherry aromas and flavors are dark and chocolaty, while the feel is solid and the finish long and minty warm. Big but not plush; loaded but not opulent. A commendable large-production wine (45,000 cases).

wine: Salentein 2019 Portillo Estate Bottled Pinot Noir (Uco Valley)
review: Dusty red plum and currant aromas are easy to peg as Pinot Noir. A grainy-feeling palate with chewy tannins deals flavors of spiced cherry and raspberry, while this displays mild burn and a vague note of buttery oak on the finish.

Heady aromas of blackberry, dried cherries and anise extend from nose to finish in this intensely pink wine. A blend of both red grapes (Grenache, Cinsault and Syrah) and white grapes (Clairette and Picpoul) fermented together, it's a juicy, intensely berry-flavored wine peppered by spice and dried herb notes. Structured, mineral and delicately tannic on the finish, it's a year-round rosé that can accompany even hearty meals of lamb or game.

wine: Hindsight 2013 Bella Vetta Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Howell Mountain)
review: Juicy plum, raspberry and pencil lead lead the way in this vineyard designate, a site that's 2,000 feet high. Tobacco and cedar meet a full-bodied hit of oak and puckering tannin, the wine still youthfully wrapped in its full-bodied boldness.

wine: Asuncion Ridge 2016 Rosé (San Luis Obispo County)
appellation: San Luis Obispo County, Central Coast, California, US
review: A darker shade of blood orange in the glass, this bottling of Cabernet Sauvignon shows cranberry and orange on the nose. It's quite flat on the sip, with sour orange, strawberry and plum notes, and that makes it seem more like an afterthought than a focused rosé, which is such a competitive category now.

wine: Ca' del Bosco 1994 Cuvée Annamaria Clementi  (Franciacorta)
review: Very fine wine, showing all of the complexity you expect from a great sparkler combined with delicacy and elegance. Toasted almonds, pears and dried spices on the nose, with tangerine and apple notes chiming in on the palate. The mouthfeel is creamy and rich; the finish lingering and citrusy.

The mellowness of ripe yellow apples is apparent immediately, as is the creamy yeasty depth of autolysis. The palate brims with notes of wet chalk and baked apple and a combination of freshness and richness that is compelling. This is a demi-sec and with its subtle sweet-sour balance, this finds its place with fruity desserts, cheese and Asian, hot spice. These flavors will benefit most from this wine's inherent off-dry balance.

This wine ultrarich—perhaps too much so. With intense apricot and spice flavors, it's a dense powerhouse of bitter botrytis that lacks elegance. Although it will soften with time, the superripe character will remain.

wine: Villa San Juliette 2015 Reserve Cabernet Franc (Paso Robles)
appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: Appropriately herbaceous aromas meet with fresh red fruit on the nose of this bottling, which also shows rustic hints of tar. The palate offers black plum, peppercorns and more herbs, framed by sticky tannins.

wine: Fischer 2005 Premium Pinot Noir Pinot Noir (Thermenregion)
review: Caramel and soft berry fruits characterize this pleasant and fresh wine. It has flavors of red berries along with vanilla  to round it out. Easy Pinot, drink now.

wine: Château de Saint-Cosme 2018 Les Deux Albion White (Vin de Pays de la Principauté d’Orange)
appellation: Vin de Pays de la Principauté d’Orange, Rhône Valley, France
review: Sourced from limestone soils outside Gigondas by the famed red-wine producer, this plump, sunny sip offers juicy pineapple and tangerine flavors edged by layers of stony minerals and salt. It's a thirst-quenching, fresh-fruited wine but elegant too, lingering on murmurs of lime zest and salt. Enjoy now–2023.

wine: Quinta da Pacheca 2015 Grande Reserva Touriga Nacional (Douro)
review: This fine, ripe and perfumed wine comes from a selection of grapes at harvest. This has produced a richly structured, impressive wine full of both tannins and great black currant fruits. The wine has density, juicy acidity and aging potential. It would have been just as good without the heavy bottle. Drink from 2021.

wine: Finca Río Negro 2016 Cogolludo-Guadalajara Gewürztraminer (Vino de la Tierra de Castilla)
appellation: Vino de la Tierra de Castilla, Central Spain, Spain
review: Highly aromatic on the nose, notes of flowers and soap carry the lead. In the mouth, this is oily in feel yet with a strong vein of acidity. A quick blast of lychee flavor finishes short and bitter.
Lemon and green apple are the chief flavors of this easy Riesling that provides honest and uncomplicated refreshment. It finishes dry, with a fresh, lemony aftertaste.

wine: Treasure 2012 Joseph Proprietary Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
review: This is a blend of two barrels and it contains a strong lingering notion of cured meat and Italian delicatessen. Thick green tannins spark ongoing flavors of cedar and tobacco within a full-bodied concentrated package.

wine: Château Paveil de Luze 2009 Barrel sample  (Margaux)
review: 87-89 Barrel sample. Solid, foursquare, chunky wine that packs a punch of tannin, the fruit rather reticent.

Wild berry, rose, toasted notes and the barest whiff of new leather form the nose on this savory young red. The lithe, linear palate shows juicy Marasca cherry, red plum and baking spice alongside polished tannins. Bright acidity keeps it fresh. Drink through 2023.

wine: Vignerons de Bel Air 2012 Bel Air Nouveau  (Beaujolais-Villages)
review: Firm and tight, this is a wine that is still shaking off its baby tannins. Open this a few minutes before drinking, and its fruitiness will pair well with food. The finish is bright with acidity.

wine: Schola Sarmenti di Terrulenta 2010 Masserei Rosé (Nardò)
review: Presented in clean and modern packaging, this bright rosé from the Nardò area of Puglia in Southern Italy offers bright aromas of cranberry, pink rose, peach blossom and drying brimstone. Made with the native Negroamaro grape, there's a playful touch of sweetness on the close.

Light buttery notes complement fruit and salted oak in this dry, tannic and full-bodied white. The texture is grainy and lengthy, with flavors of ginger and lemongrass that work well against the riper, bolder aspects.

As befits a wine from the Médoc, this blend holds a goodly proportion of Cabernet Sauvignon. That translates into black-currant fruits, stylish tannins and a structure that will allow the wine to age. Drink from 2022.

A tangy wine from a Despagne property with an illustrious history, this is packed with perfumed fruits that enhance the wine's fruitiness. The freshness is augmented by the tangy acidity and density that come through at the end. Drink now.

This is the first vintage of this estate under the ownership of the Bouey family, which has a Bordeaux negociant business. The wine is dry, anchored in tannins at this stage although the juicy black fruits will come through over time. Wait for this wine until 2022.

wine: Casas del Bosque 2014 Pequeñas Producciones Pinot Noir (Casablanca Valley)
review: Saucy tomato paste aromas suggest pizza, while this full-bodied Pinot feels sticky, soupy and heavy. Savory oak, tomatoey red fruit and herbal green flavors result in a disjointed flavor profile, while this remains saucy and jumbled on the finish.

wine: Cà Vittoria NV Costa dei Peschi Brut  (Prosecco di Conegliano e Valdobbiadene)
appellation: Prosecco di Conegliano e Valdobbiadene, Veneto, Italy
review: A sweet, candy-like note appears at first and is followed by slight tones of yellow fruit and butterscotch. Yet this is a compact and linear sparkler that is pulled tightly together by the mineral notes that define it. It ends on a fruity but acidic note.

A slightly muted nose of dark cherry and toast offers hints of rose and tar. Similar flavors play on the palate with a touch of chocolate and a smooth mouthfeel. Long and dry, the espresso-tinged finish is elegant. The depth of fruit can be sensed and this should open up with short-term cellaring, displaying more depth and richness in a year's time.

Band-Aid and black fruit aromas amount to a mild and innocuous nose. This feels collapsed, but it's not without a pulse. Spicy, herbal flavors of plum and berry are a bit green, while this is narrow and hollow on the finish.

Vibrant fruit, red apple and blue flowers appear with intensity on the nose to create a racy, clean red wine. The acidity is good, as is the structure, but the 15% alcohol does hit the palate hard. Pair it with cream-based pasta (to counter the alcohol), white meat and roasted winter vegetables.

wine: J. Portugal Ramos 2010 Loios Branco White (Alentejano)
review: Attractive, softly fruity wine, with some citrus character as well as pear and apple juice. It is crisp, fresh, ready to drink. Winebow.

wine: Brotte 2019 Les Hauts de Barville Red (Châteauneuf-du-Pape)
review: Deep, ruminating layers of black plum and cherry confiture are lifted by tangs of crushed salt and stone in this bright, fresh-fruited blend of Grenache and Syrah. It's mouthfilling and rich but maintains a thrilling zestiness, too. Fringed by fine-grained, lingering tannins, it's at peak now but should maintain vibrantly through 2027 at least.

wine: Donelan 2016 Tripp's Block Perli Vineyard Pinot Noir (Mendocino Ridge)
appellation: Mendocino Ridge, Mendocino County, California, US
review: Delicate and floral on the nose, this wine picks up intensity as it develops in the glass, coming from a 2,000-foot-elevation site surrounded by wilderness. Textured and layered in strawberry and rich cola, it has a woody finish of forest and oak.

appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: This appealing Chardonnay is the same wine that carried a reserve designation in prior vintages. It's lushly woven and has aromas and flavors of pear, pineapple and peach. The fruit is rich but not overly sweet, and sports accents of cinnamon and allspice. This balanced, medium-weight wine finishes long and easy with a nice nuttiness. Top Value.

wine: LaVelle 2008 Matthew's Reserve Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)
appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: The winery notes that this is their first reserve quality Pinot Noir since 1998—a remarkable statement. It reaches for that extra something without blowing itself out of proportion, retaining the varietal elegance so nicely displayed in the regular 2008 bottling. This is bigger, tighter and harder—with more tannic weight—than that wine, and should be cellared while you drink up its stable mate.

appellation: Wahluke Slope, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: All coming from Rosebud Vineyard and having a whopping 27.2 g/L of residual sugar, this slightly browned wine offers aromas of brown sugar and crème brûlée. It's intensely rich on the palate, with dried pineapple and honey flavors. A long finish ups the interest.

appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: Thick and intensely ripe, this appellation red is hearty and substantial on the palate, a richly interwoven mix of dried herb, strawberry and cola.

Underbrush, leather and a whiff of dark-skinned berry come together on this. Reflecting the cool, wet vintage, this is rather light-bodied and loose knit for Brunello and already extremely approachable, offering Morello cherry and hints of coffee and a clove note alongside dusty, loose-knit tannins and bright acidity. Drink through 2021.

wine: Dry Creek Vineyard 2003 Heritage Zinfandel (Sonoma County)
review: Dry Creek Vineyard knows Zin, and it shows in this dry, balanced and attractive wine. It has Zin's briary, brambly berry richness, with smooth tannins and a complex mouthfeel. As good as it is, it would be even better with greater intensity of fruit.

Aromas suggesting rose, iris and red berry are front and center. The linear medium-bodied palate offers sour cherry, cranberry, white pepper and star anise alongside close-grained tannins and fresh acidity. It has a firm drying finish. Drink 2021–2028.

wine: Château Bertinerie 2012 Réserve  (Blaye Côtes de Bordeaux)
appellation: Blaye Côtes de Bordeaux, Bordeaux, France
review: From selected parcels on the Bertinerie vineyard, this is still a young, firmly structured wine. Red berry fruits offer a contrast to the solid tannins and rich texture. The wood aging still shows, giving a spicy character that will integrate as the wine matures. Drink from 2017.

Alluring scents of perfumed berry, underbrush, pipe tobacco and leather come together on this firmly structured wine. The palate delivers mature black cherry, crushed raspberry, sage, rosemary, clove and a hint of cured meat. It's extremely well balanced thanks to assertive, fine-grained tannins and bright acidity.

appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: A dark, peppery wine that contains just enough Zinfandel to quality for a varietal label, plus Petite Sirah, Carignane and Alicante Bouschet. In other words, an old-fashioned field blend. It is a well-made wine, and the minor varietals seem to add earth and tannins.

Made from 100% Chardonnay, this shows lemon, apple and nectarine on the nose with hints of croisant. Spritely bubbles quickly fade, leaving honeydew, green apple, nectarine and a hint of pastry. The finish is fresh with lemon juice and tart apple.

wine: Chelan Wine Company 2006 LEHM Estate Pinot Gris (Chelan County)
appellation: Chelan County, Washington Other, Washington, US
review: I believe this is the first vintage for the LEHM estate Pinot Gris; the young vines need a few more years to pull the flavors out. But this is a good start, very crisp and clean and well-defined, with intriguing hints of apple and pear and light herb. The finish continues gracefully, adding notes of rock and pepper to the mix.

Dusty floral plum flavors are fresh, not over-extracted. Solid but regular on the palate, this tastes of oaky spicy dried cherry and plum along with tobacco. Latent acidity and grabby tannins make the finish abrasive.

wine: García Figuero 2003 Tinto Figuero 12  (Ribera del Duero)
appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
review: Young and jumpy at first, with early lactic notes. Airing allows this wine to show ripe berry aromas and flavors with ample shadings of oak-based vanilla and chocolate. Saturated and full; this wine gets it right. Drink through 2008.

Raspingly dry and fierce in tannins, this Merlot is quite different from other Bordeaux-style red wines from Oakville that are ripe and lush. Doesn't offer much reward now due to the astringency, but has a solid core of blackberries. Hard to know if the fruit will outlast the tannins.

wine: Latah Creek 2012 Monarch Reserve Zephyr Ridge Vineyards Petite Sirah (Horse Heaven Hills)
appellation: Horse Heaven Hills, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Brooding aromas of dill, purple fruit, vanilla and wood spice are followed by full dark cherry flavors backed by a wall of firm yet still accessible tannins.

Fresh apple, pear and lemon flavors have a crystalline edge in this just-off-dry example of Elbling, an unusual white variety grown in the Mosel. It's zesty and spry, finishing with a delicious murmur of lime-pith bitterness. Drink now.

wine: Foxen 1997 Morehouse Vineyard Syrah (Santa Ynez Valley)
appellation: Santa Ynez Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: Shows plum, chocolate, smoke, coffee and tobacco notes. Very rich and fruity, with pretty tannins. Soft but rich. Balanced and harmonious, and very dry.

The wood is a bit forced, and overall this wine has a heavy, full-fruited personality. But the depth and ripeness are pretty nice and the blackberry, dark plum and cassis flavors are earnest. A bit tannic and not all that varietal.

This wine has a touch of weight on the nose and palate—a result of the Viognier and Roditis in the blend. Fresh flowers and citrus on the nose lead into minerals, spice and exotic fruit on the palate. The wine is medium-bodied but maintains acidity.

wine: Franck Bonville 2012 Pur Mesnil Grand Cru Brut Chardonnay (Champagne)
review: This wine comes from Le Mesnil, one of the top villages in the Côte des Blancs, and is produced from only Grand Cru vineyards. It is as textured and mineral as a young wine like this should be. White fruit shows through the concentrated texture and will become more dominant as the wine matures. Drink from 2020.

Aromas of underbrush, tilled soil, tobacco, wild berry and a balsamic note take shape in the glass. The elegantly structured palate offers black cherry, cranberry, white pepper, clove and grilled herb that lead into a mineral-driven finish. It's young but well balanced, with austere but fine-grained tannins and bright acidity. Drink 2016–2028.

wine: Rieflé 2011 Zinnkoepflé Grand Cru Vendanges Tardives Pinot Gris (Alsace)
review: Gold in color and unctuously sweet, this is a dense wine. The sweetness is cut with a dry edge and some fresh acidity. It tastes delicious now with flavors of wild honey and apricot skins, but it will certainly age well. Drink until 2024.

appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: Zesty, clean and fruity, with ripe grapefruit juice, fig and melon flavors. This SB finishes with a slightly sweet flourish of honey. From the beach to the patio, it'll be just fine.

wine: Helix by Reininger 2015 Phinny Hill Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Horse Heaven Hills)
appellation: Horse Heaven Hills, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: The aromas bring heaping amounts of dried green pepper, along with raspberry, herb and pencil eraser. Plush, full-bodied cherry flavors follow. The tannins bring a dry grip. Give it time in the cellar to see if it comes around.

appellation: El Dorado, Sierra Foothills, California, US
review: This wine is super dark in hue and packed full of blackberry, wood smoke and black pepper flavors. It brings a relatively light (for the varietal) mouthfeel considering that it does have a wealth of fine-grained tannins and elevated alcohol. Drink now with a steak or chop, or cellar until 2025 for more maturity and nuance.
Kicks off with enticing aromas redolent of lychee and peach. On the palate if falters a bit, however, with a sugary quality that masks the fruit. The finish serves up pretty spice notes. Kosher.

Zesty, lemony purity is evident from the start. The nose brims with lemon and the palate makes it shine even more. This freshness has a counterpoint in tangy concentration that shimmers with tropical hints of passion fruit. The finish is pure, crystalline and lasting.

appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: This has some real strength to the fruit, which shows depth, nerve and muscle. There's a nice high note suggesting citrus, even grapefruit; below that some racy berry fruit flavors; then comes the impact of tannin and espresso. It all adds up to some real excitement in the mouth. A powerful wine that zings the palate and leaves you wanting more.

appellation: El Dorado, Sierra Foothills, California, US
review: There is a gentle side to this medium-bodied wine, as it offers aromatic complexity with slightly restrained fruit flavors. Light aromas like cedar shavings and black pepper give way to a smooth texture supported by moderate tannins, and pretty plum and pomegranate flavors.
Marred by aggressively hard tannins and acids, this Syrah's berry-cherry flavors finish thin and bitter, with a green edge. The chilly vintage took its toll. Drink up.

wine: I Giusti e Zanza 2006 Perbruno Syrah (Toscana)
review: Tobacco, spice, black pepper corn, clove and cured meats create a powerful and inviting wine that would pair well with the heartiest of meat dishes. This excellent expression is very representative of Syrah from sun-drenched Tuscany and it offers a smooth texture and polished tannins with a blast of espresso on the close. Drink after 2012.

Hints of ripe yellow pears with just a suspicion of passionfruit dominate the nose. The palate is intense and balanced, the lushness of the fruit brightened by a tight streak of refreshing acidity. Racy and versatile.

wine: Pondera 2012 Stillwater Creek Vineyard Syrah (Columbia Valley (WA))
appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Aromas of raspberry, coffee, herbs, smoke and baking spices are austere on the nose. The fruit and barrel flavors are bright and tart, showing a lot of polish, detail and length.

wine: BiancaVigna 2017 Rive di Ogliano Brut Nature  (Conegliano Valdobbiadene Prosecco Superiore)
appellation: Conegliano Valdobbiadene Prosecco Superiore, Veneto, Italy
review: Loaded with finesse, this radiant sparkler has delicate, enticing aromas of fragrant spring blossom, white stone fruit and citrus. The vibrant palate delivers green apple, peach and tangerine before a tangy, bone-dry finish. It's balanced and elegant, with bright acidity and a silky mousse.

wine: Left Coast Cellars 2013 Cali's Cuvée Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)
appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: Production has climbed on this entry-level Pinot. Light fruit flavors mix plums and strawberries, with a subtext of clean earth and chocolate. The finish turns a bit chalky.

appellation: Vin de France, France Other, France
review: Initial whiffs of smoke and flint take some time to dissipate here but eventually open to prettier raspberry and plum notes. It's a savory rosé, with slightly muted red cherry and berry flavors edged by exotic spice, bramble and delicate tannins. With its firm structure, it's best served with dinner.

Too young to drink now, this blend of Sangiovese and Cabernet Sauvignon shows all the requisites to be an age-worthy wine. The quality of the fruit is rich, the acidity is bright, and the tannins will carry the wine forward during its slow evolution.
Opens with a burst of smoky new oak, cherry and menthol notes, then reveals additional layers of currant and mocha. A little soft, plush in the mouth, almost fat. Certainly an accessible wine.

wine: Grandes Serres 2019 Les Portes du Castelas White (Côtes du Rhône)
appellation: Côtes du Rhône, Rhône Valley, France
review: Waxy lemon peels and strikes of salt lend refreshment to this supple blend of Grenache Blanc and Marsanne. Matured in 15% new oak, it balances fresh, primary grapefruit and white-pear flavors against lingering hints of smoke and cashew. Easy drinking and crisp on the finish, it's at peak now but should hold through 2023.

wine: Central Coast Group Project 2013 Blood Orange White (Santa Barbara County)
appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
review: A numeric score on this wine is almost silly, as it's about as bizarre as wine gets. A shade of yellowish orange in the glass, this bottling shows aromas of vermouth, wood varnish, cherry and, yes, blood orange on the nose. The palate combines iron, sour peach, walnut oil and pine much like a Sherry. Fascinating, though not for the mainstream.

wine: La Casa Dell'Orco 2010  Fiano di Avellino
appellation: Fiano di Avellino, Southern Italy, Italy
review: A popular choice in Rome and southern Italy, Fiano di Avellino is a perfect seafood and shellfish white wine. There's crispness and brightness here, all backed by easy pear, peach and citrus aromas.

Firm and closed, this is a wine with so much power and concentration. It also has beautiful fruit, smooth and opulent, that merges into the complex tannins and brooding, dark structure. It will take many years for this wine to open up.
A blend of Sangiovese and Alicante, this plush wine shows simple tones of black fruit, worn leather and cherry. The nose is a bit muddled, and there's a subtle touch of sweet soda on the close.

wine: Château Roquevieille 2010  Castillon Côtes de Bordeaux
appellation: Castillon Côtes de Bordeaux, Bordeaux, France
review: Firm and structured, this powerful wine has considerable aging potential. Black plum skins, dark tannins and ripe, juicy fruitiness are all piled into the solid structure. Drink from 2016.

wine: Le Cadeau 2010 Côte Est Pinot Noir (Oregon)
review: An elegant version of the Côte Est, this is an Oregon Pinot sourced from the winery's vineyard in the Chehalem Mountains that's bursting with juicy goodness. It's a wine with finesse, full of tart fruit flavors like cranberry and cherry, tight and well-suited for 10 or more years in the cellar.

wine: Rudolf Fürst 2016 Pur Mineral Weisser Burgunder (Franken)
review: The name “Pur Mineral” is an apt descriptor for this intensely mineral wine full of dusty slate and river rock complexities. It's luminously fruity too offering pristine Muscat grape and pear accented by a hint of exotic spice. It is dry in style yet rich and expansive in mouthfeel.

Ripe, heady, slightly malty aromas of blackberry and plum set this on its way. In the mouth, there are scratchy, unresolved tannins and acidity to deal with along with salty flavors of oak, plum and cassis. A lasting, oaky finish with vanilla and butter notes provides for a good close out. Drink through 2020.
Very structured, dense and powerful, this wine is finely shaped, with acidity balancing the solid fruit.

Gritty black-fruit aromas come with notes of bell pepper and green herbs as well as coffee grounds. A snappy, tough, drawing palate delivers peppery, blackened spice and herbal berry flavors prior to a crisp, tight finish with fresh acidity.

appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Sourced from five excellent Walla Walla vineyards, this wine spent about 15 months in barrel, one quarter new. It has dried cherry fruit, almost like an Amarone in style, though with no sweetness. Tannins are drying and finish with a slight bitterness. Tasted twice from different bottles.

wine: Muhr-Van der Niepoort 2013 Samt & Seide Blaufränkisch (Carnuntum)
review: There is nothing obvious about this wine: everything is subtle and elegant. The nose holds back and the taut palate only unfurls slowly to show a floral, fruity wine that reminds one of crimson peony petals as much as of dark, juicy cherries. Yet there is nothing facile about this. It is the silky-smooth texture, however, that delivers the killer blow. A most sensuous, intriguing wine of great elegance. Little wonder: its name means silk and velvet

wine: Trinchero 2010 Central Park West Vineyard Cabernet Franc (St. Helena)
review: With cherry, green herb and mint flavors, this Cab Franc is elegantly structured, but lacks the richness you want in a California Bordeaux-style wine.

wine: La Chablisienne 2011 Les Clos Grand Cru  (Chablis)
review: The most serious of the Chablis Grand Crus has produced here a wine that combines that firmer nature with generous yellow fruits, toast and tender acidity. A strong sense of structure partners with a steely core and mineral texture that firms up the fruit and promises aging. Drink from 2017.

This is smooth and full, and has got the requisite black cherry fruit, some lemon rind and pineapple peeking through the acids. In the finish are suggestions, just a lick, of tobacco, wild cherry, maybe sweet ham. Gets interesting in the end, though it remains very tart and acidic.

Heathcote Shiraz often has an earthy tinge to it, and this offering is no exception. There's loam and a touch of molasses on the nose, then lightly roasted berries, earth and a hint of mushroom in the mouth. It's large in scale (15% alcohol), but framed by some firm tannins that should soften in 2–3 years.

appellation: Calaveras County, Sierra Foothills, California, US
review: Ultrasmooth and mouthfilling, this full-bodied wine boasts ripe plummy jammy aromas and flavors, a rather soft mouthfeel and relaxed tannins.

There's considerable richness in this broad, generous, velvet-  textured wine that brings out the red fruit and ripeness. The 18-months barrel aging have not dampened the fruit, but have certainly contributed to the power of this impressive wine.

appellation: Monterey County, Central Coast, California, US
review: Salted grapefruit skins, browned butter and a toasted-nut element arise on the nose of this wine from a vineyard near the tiny Salinas Valley town of San Ardo. It offers acidic energy and tight minerality on the palate, with ripe aromatic apples showing midway through the sip.

Hints of smoke frame this very traditional, authentic Pinot made in time-honoured Austrian fashion. The balance and freshness of red fruit is borne in a very graceful structure and just cries out for food. Light bodied but with lovely depth.

wine: HKG 2011 North Bridge Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)
appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: Made in a fruit-forward style, this brims with rich, ripe flavors of raspberries and strawberries. It has a touch of sautéed wild mushrooms that brings a pleasant earthiness. It's a good wine to drink now, and should evolve nicely over the next six years.

wine: King Estate 2019 Inscription Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)
appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: A classy package adorns this affordable wine. Cranberry and black cherry fruit come to a solid, focused core, with stiff acidity backing substantial yet smooth tannins.

wine: Hightower 2006 Pepper Bridge Vineyard Red Wine Red (Walla Walla Valley (WA))
appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: The blend is 88% Merlot and 12% Cabernet Sauvignon. From the first sniff to the last give-me-more swallow, this broadly delicious wine is going to win a lot of friends. The pretty strawberry and cherry fruit is generously endowed with mocha and chocolate, but the barrel flavors are not overbearing. Not one for the cellar; enjoy this wine in the fullness of its youth.

wine: Windemere 1997 Cathy MacGregor Vyd Signature Chardonnay (Edna Valley)
appellation: Edna Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: Intensely smoky and earthy aromas, with a deeply toasted, almost burnt-match quality. There are pear, lemon and nutty flavors on the palate. Long finish with earthy, nutty, spicy elements. Large-scaled and refreshingly unique, if not uniformly liked. A challenging and controversial wine for our panel.
Rather herbal and spicy, bursting with anise, Asian spicebox aromas. Cherries and sweet herbs in  the mouth, with a spicy finish. The soft tannins make it instantly drinkable.

Seyfried always seems to do well with aromatic varieties, perhaps because of the family's Germanic roots. This Riesling includes a hint of honey on the nose, plus melon and pear fruit and a lingering hint of gingery spice on the finish.

wine: Château le Bon Pasteur 2009 Barrel sample  (Pomerol)
review: 92-94 Barrel sample. Dense, with impressive solid tannins and powerful fruit. The wine is smooth at first, then structure comes through with a final dry core.
This simple white offers delicate hints of pear and citrus while vibrant acidity gives it a crisp, short finish. It's a quaffing wine to pour at picnics and other informal get-togethers.

wine: Adega Cooperativa do Cartaxo 2013 Private Collection Red (Tejo)
review: A blend of Touriga Nacional and Castelão, this is a wine that is almost too rich, too intense. Its dense texture and background of tannins are balanced with black currant acidity; however, the high alcohol does show with pepper and tongue-burning spice. That won't go away, although the texture will soften. Drink from 2017.

Here's a smoky, earthy Brunello that shows sophisticated use of oak to render aromas of toast, spice and leather. There are fresh fruit nuances here as well— mainly cherry and blackberry—and the wine is bright, tonic, crisp and relatively lean on the close.

wine: Bocopa 2015 Conde de Alicante Selección Rosé (Alicante)
review: Cherry and plum aromas are light, generic and clean. This feels mostly right, with moderate acidity creating a solid mouthfeel. Plum, citrus and herbal flavors finish round and balanced.

Dusty berry fruit aromas blend with milk chocolate and lactic notes on what amounts to a mildly oaky nose. The mouthfeel, meanwhile, is juicy and just right. Flavors of berry fruits, licorice and raisin finish full, minty and ripe, with lasting freshness.

Very rich and opulent, in the Heidi Barrett style, this Cabernet is sweetly jammy but somewhat direct in blackberries, cherries and raspberries. The finish is extraordinarily long and spicy, an indication that it's a wine for the cellar. Firm tannins and fine acidity confirm its ageability. Hold this flashy, decadent wine until 2016 and then try it again.

Cabernet Franc takes the lead in this blend, giving spiciness and richness. It is a shame that the wine also has high alcohol that adds a pepper edge to the weight. The wine is more for food and is ready to drink.

wine: Volker Eisele Family Estate 2004 Family Estate Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
review: This is just a little too soft, sweet and ripe, although it retains the classic structure and elegance you demand from the venerable name Eisele. The flavor of sugared crushed blackberries, cherries and caramelly vanilla suggest drinking now.
Rich and ripe, this is a full-bodied wine that has great plum and sweet blackberry flavors and good concentration. Firm in texture, the dusty tannins giving further density. For aging over 5–6 years.
Saucy berry and tea aromas are herbal, earthy and stewed. This feels full but syrupy. Flavors of cooked berry, molasses and mocha finish sweet and soupy, with only a touch of acidic offset.

wine: Albert Bichot 2016 Domaine Adélie en Pierre Milley  (Mercurey)
review: Still full of youthful tannins, this wine has both richness and structure. The potential is there, with the dense character of the tannins that are about to soften. Wild-berry flavors and a juicy aftertaste add to the promise. Drink from 2022.

Packed with ripe, honeyed Sémillon, this wine has richness while also keeping plenty of freshness. Acidity and a crisp edge are balanced with the intense orange marmalade and spice flavors that will make this wine develop well. Drink from 2022.

A rich blend of the three main Bordeaux grapes, this generous wine offers spice, tannins and plenty of black-currant fruits. It has the potential to be well balanced, fruity and structured. Drink from mid-2021.

wine: Flora Springs 2014 Rennie Reserve Cabernet Sauvignon (St. Helena)
review: Big-boned and soft, this reserve-tier wine is savory and serene, with forest flavors of wild mushroom. Soy, dried herb, sage and black currant notes pepper the scene.
Sweet-tart red cherry and berry flavors are plump and juicy in this fresh, easy drinking Dornfelder. It's not a complicated wine but balanced in sweetness and acidity. Drink now.
Lightly perfumed earthy aromas carry a hint of cinnamon. Dull cherry and pungent earth flavors finish with a sharp edge.

wine: Morgan 2003 Rosella's Vineyard Chardonnay (Santa Lucia Highlands)
appellation: Santa Lucia Highlands, Central Coast, California, US
review: You can smell the minerals in this tight, compelling wine. It has an aroma suggesting cold metal, even a touch of diesel, floating above the guava, pineapple, nectarine and peach flavors. Smoky oak and zesty acidity help make this Chard very complex and satisfying.
This blend of Gamay and Pinot Noir is soft, with cherry flavors and gentle tannins. Its ripeness and fresh aftertaste give a perfumed wine that is ready to drink.
Dominated by Merlot, this wine is rich and luscious. Bold tannins and ripe blackberry flavors make it both structured and fruity. It is set to develop well, so drink from mid-2021.

A nose of herbs, kiwi, smoke and minerals gives this white an intriguing start. On the palate, it's crisp and clean, with flavors of tropical fruit, herbs and spice unfolding over a minerally backbone. Ageable and terroir driven.

appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: Made from 48% Grenache, 37% Syrah and 15% Mourvèdre, this is an earthy wine, full of mushroomy herbal notes that lean into a trove of eucalyptus. Leather rides along a smooth texture of baked and dried cherry.

wine: Vincent Wine Company 2015 Pinot Noir (Ribbon Ridge)
appellation: Ribbon Ridge, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: Vincent's Pinot Noirs are fermented with native yeasts in a mix of once-used and older barrels. This bottling opens with fresh strawberry and raspberry flavors, lemony acids, and an underpinning of wet stone. It's on the lighter side and was made (and priced) for everyday enjoyment.
This wine's dry tannins still dominate the fruit, giving a tough dimension. It needs to soften and release the pent-up black fruits. Drink from late 2021.

wine: Bethel Heights 2015 The High Wire Chardonnay (Eola-Amity Hills)
appellation: Eola-Amity Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: This is from an old-vines Wente clone, planted in 1977. You'll notice the texture first, layers of well-proportioned citrus, lemon zest, wet stone and hints of barrel toast. The length and detail are superb, and though drinking well already, this is a wine that will reward cellaring. Drink now through the 2020s.

appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
review: Riper and deeper than some in this class, but arguably overoaked and roasted, such that the finish tastes like burnt coffee and the bouquet smells of peeled tire rubber. In between look for plum, blackberry, cumin and black pepper.

wine: Domaine Serene 2012 Yamhill Cuvée Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)
appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: This cuvée offers the pleasures of sweet, sappy red fruits, soft tannins and broad swaths of caramel, toasted hazelnuts and mocha. It coats the tongue with flavor and has a sort of insistence that the next sip will be even better.

In a league with Italy's best dessert wines, San Petrolo is a superrich and concentrated wine that almost has a hard time pouring out of the bottle. The wine does indeed have the consistency of maple syrup, with a deep brown color and gorgeous aromas of toasted almond, chestnut honey, crème caramel and crème brûlée.

wine: Cave de Gan 2012 Grains de Béarn Rosé (Béarn)
review: Full and rounded, this warm rosé has some weight. A food-friendly selection, it has a dry, tangy character, textured red-currant flavor and tight final acidity.

wine: Anselmo Mendes 2016 Parcela Unica Alvarinho (Vinho Verde)
review: As its name suggests, this wine comes from a single parcel of Alvarinho. Its richness and concentration is impressive. So are the apple, pear and citrus fruits that are now maturing into a ripe, spicy and nutty wine. At the end, the wine has a fine mature balance that makes it ready to drink.

wine: Buena Vista 2013 The Count's Selection Pinot Gris (Sonoma Valley)
review: White pepper and matchstick come to the fore aromatically in this crisp white that's fuller bodied on the palate than one would expect given the aromatics. Apple and pear give a complex, autumnal fruit presence that leads up to a ripe, creamy finish.

The back label posits this as a “dry” style, but there's plenty of fruit sweetness nonetheless. Peach and citrus rind flavors come with a sprinkling of powdered sugar. It's a fairly significant change from the aromatic and detailed 2016 version.
