Savory and delicious, this opens with alluring aromas of yellow spring wildflowers and ripe white stone fruit. Made with Garganega, Fernanda, Trebbiano Toscana and Trebbianello, it's delicious and loaded with finesse, delivering creamy white peach, Bartlett pear and lemon drop candy before closing on an almond note. While it's great now, it will also age and develop even more depth. Drink through 2027.

wine: Charter Oak 2010 Monte Rosso Vineyard Zinfandel (Sonoma Valley)
review: High alcohol and exceptionally ripe fruit are the hallmarks of this mountain vineyard. In this Zinfandel, they express themselves as blackberries, cherries and mocha that have a roasted edge, and a Port-like heat that is by no means unpleasant. But you do want to drink this Zin with dishes rich in beef, cheese and olive oil.

wine: Domaine Sauvat 2016 Coquines Pinot Noir (Puy de Dôme)
appellation: Puy de Dôme, Loire Valley, France
review: This is a young tannic wine. It needs time to show up the red fruits that are underneath the dryness. There is potential for a fine juicy softly textured future. Drink from 2018.

wine: Dutton-Goldfield 2014 Dutton Ranch Walker Hill Vineyard Chardonnay (Green Valley)
review: This resplendent white offers a wealth of wet stone minerality and crisp, lemony acidity, with just a subtle hint of oak. From old vines, it boasts tangerine and anise flavors on the palate, with tropical notes of guava and mango and a jolt of nuttiness.

This well-built wine shows just the barest hint of barrel from fermentation and aging in neutral oak which seems to have rounded out the fruit and put some polish on the mouthfeel. Flavors are a tasty mix of lemon curd, honeysuckle, apple and peach, lightly spiced.

wine: Dry Creek Vineyard 2018 Fumé Blanc (Sonoma County)
review: This wine was given no time in oak and made entirely from grapes grown in Dry Creek and Russian River Valleys. It is lively, tart and fresh. Balanced flavors of lemon peel, lime and peach mingle around an earthy tease of fresh-cut grass.

wine: Las Estelas 2017 Finca Mangato Alto de las Piedras Malbec (Tupungato)
designation: Finca Mangato Alto de las Piedras
review: Plum and berry aromas are accented by a whiff of desert brush and hefty lemony oak. A powerfully built palate has a resiny feel to it, while oaky blackberry flavors show a strong barrel influence backed by herbal hints and smacking tannins. This is excellent for an inaugural wine, with room to improve in subsequent years.

This blend of Cabernet Franc and Montelpulciano opens with earthy aromas of tilled soil, blackberry and evident oak. The palate offers up plum, red berry and roasted coffee-bean flavors. It's soft and ready to drink.

wine: Zeitgeist 2017 Fanucchi Wood Road Vineyard Trousseau Gris (Russian River Valley)
appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: Made to be fresh, fruity and enjoyed frequently, this wine is oily in lemon and apricot, with a refreshing, spritzy acidity that's both bright and complex. The vineyard is one of very few in the state to grow the variety and this producer has made it its mission to honor both the site and the grape. She does.
Solid Chilean Cab, with herbal notes and chewy cassis and chocolate flavors. Fine with burgers and the like.

appellation: Dry Creek Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: Nice and peppery-spicy, this Zin shows how well the variety performs in Dry Creek Valley, one of its natural homes. There's a rich coating of new oak that adds vanilla and smoky chocolate flavor, but the wild blackberry, raspberry and blueberry fruit shines through.
Lightly scented, this has subtle aromas of yellow stone fruit and a floral note. On the fresh palate, bright acidity underscores ripe peach and a citrusy note. It closes on a hint of almond.

wine: Pearl and Stone 2016 Resolution Peaks Red (Columbia Valley (WA))
appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Sourced from the Two Blondes and Dionysus vineyards, this is principally Cabernet Sauvignon, with the last 15% a blend of Cabernet Franc and Merlot. Flavors of sweet tomato, pretty strawberry and a hint of cherries account for the fruit, alongside an earthy, herbal component and a streak of coffee. The overall balance is good and the acids bring a note of orange citrus.

wine: Stadt Krems 2009 Wachtberg Reserve Grüner Veltliner (Kremstal)
review: This is powerful, rich Grüner, one that brings out the pepper character as well as apricot and honey. There is a dense texture in this concentrated and well-balanced wine. It needs to age for 3–4 years.

This delicious wine is rosé by virtue of the pink color of the Pinot Gris skin, taking the concept of blush to the extreme of paleness. Attractive and fruity, it has the lightest texture and the typical floral perfumes of Pinot Gris. Drink this wine now.
Tough, dry and weedy, with astringent tannins. Clean, but not going anywhere.

This is a petite-sized Sem with some plumpness in the mouth. Flavors are of citrus and straw, but aren't as concentrated as I'd like. Aromas are peachy and musky. Imported by Australian Wine Connection.

Based in Chamery on the northern slopes of the Montagne de Reims, this producer has made an immediately attractive nonvintage wine. Fruity and with crisp acidity it hits a good point between dry and sweeter in the Brut range, making it very drinkable, with a crisp aftertaste.

wine: Encore 2002 San Bernabe Vineyard White Medley White (Monterey)
review: From Monterra, a delicious blend of Sauvignon Blanc, Pinot Blanc, Muscat Canelli and Viognier. Each variety contributes a different fruity flavor. Smooth and a little sweet, with a nice cut of acidity.

wine: Whitehall Lane 2003 Leonardini Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
review: A very good Cab, a little young and in need of cellaring, but such is the fruit that you can drink it now. It's plush in black currant, crème de cassis and new oaky flavors wrapped in soft, velvety tannins, with a chocolaty, licorice finish. Should hold for a good ten years.
A ripe and plumy expression, this wine is rich and velvety with loads of ripe cherry, blackberry and natural spice. The mouthfeel is soft, chewy and powerful.

This wine has attractive light tannins as well as layers of berry fruits and acidity. It has structure still, giving a core of dryness to what is otherwise a straightforward, fruity wine. Drink from late 2019.

This inky garnet-colored wine has a nose of blackberry and roast fennel bulb. It has flavors of freshly picked cherries and strawberries with touches of violet and orange blossom. Potent tannins are not entirely insurmountable thanks to vibrant acidity that really does its job on the surprisingly bright finish. Mevushal.

wine: Domaine de la Renjarde 2007 Massif d'Uchaux Red (Côtes du Rhône Villages)
appellation: Côtes du Rhône Villages, Rhône Valley, France
review: Fresh in style, especially for the hot, dry 2007 vintage, reflecting the slightly higher elevation of the Massif d'Uchaux, this medium-bodied wine offers oodles of cherry-berry fruit. It's nothing too serious or complex, just good, quaffable pleasure to consume over the next 2–3 years.

wine: Feudi di San Gregorio 2015 Serpico Aglianico (Irpinia)
review: Taut and linear, this opens with aromas of red berry, pipe tobacco and eucalyptus. The firm, elegantly structured palate delivers sour cherry, cassis, star anise and a hint of smoke before finishing on an accent of coffee. Taut, fine-grained tannins provide the framework. Drink 2023–2035.

wine: Franz Keller 2016 Franz Anton Schwarzer Adler Pinot Noir (Baden)
review: Pristine, pure fruit abounds in this exceptionally fresh, invigorating red. Crisp red-cherry and -plum flavors are accented by crushed minerals, blossoms and tobacco. Full bodied and plump in mouthfeel, it's balanced by fresh acidity and a hint of ash reminiscent of the Kaiserstuhl's volcanic origins. Lovely already, it should gain depth and complexity through 2030.

wine: Clos du Lac 2004 R Reserve Red (Amador County)
appellation: Amador County, Sierra Foothills, California, US
review: Black pepper aromas and flavors star in this dry Rhône-style blend. It's a little soft in structure, with fine silky tannins that frame attractive blackberry, cherry, cassis and tangerine zest flavors.

A hint of peardrop appears first on the fresh nose before green pear and lemon take over. On the palate, there is a whole world of pepper and lemon pith, held in a taut, tight and concentrated fashion that makes this variety such a joy.

wine: Otazu 2011 Premium Cuvée Señorío de Otazu Red (Navarra)
review: This Navarran blend of Cabernet Sauvignon, Merlot and Tempranillo opens with mulchy aromas of compost, tomato and herbs as well as currant and plum. The palate is thick and syrupy in feel, with a mix of baked, stewy berry flavors offset by green notes. Herbal berry and chocolaty flavors control a rooty, sweet-tasting finish.

This wine is blended with 10% Cabernet Franc and 3% Malbec. Spicy leather and sweet tobacco combine around bright red fruit and supple tannin. It offers a balanced approach to richness and concentration.

appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Apex has just released this 2002, which makes it, as far as we know, the last of that vintage to see daylight. Dark and smoky, it is already heading into more mature, secondary fruit flavors, and has a pleasing softness throughout. Time has sanded away the rough edges of the tannins, and rounded out the herbal components as well. This is drinking very nicely, and gives you a cellared wine at a new wine price.

wine: Roux Père et Fils 2006 Les Macherelles Premier Cru  (Chassagne-Montrachet)
review: While there are plenty of toast, butter and ginger spice flavors here, this wine also shows the tight, more mineral side of Chassagne-Montrachet. It comes from the acidity and the dry edge of red apple skins. This powerful wine needs 2–3 years for the wood to calm down.
This wine shows Pinot Grigio's bright, ripe lemongrass and peach flavors, touched with a kiss of honey. But it's balanced and crisp in acidity.

wine: Château Certan de May de Certan 2010 Barrel sample  (Pomerol)
winery: Château Certan de May de Certan
review: 92-94 With huge tannins, very dark fruits, powerful and concentrated. The wine is ripe, juicy and firmly tannic.

appellation: Anderson Valley, Mendocino County, California, US
review: Off-dry to semi-sweet, this wine's honeysuckle, apricot, pineapple and Meyer lemon richness are balanced by zesty acidity.

appellation: Central Coast, Central Coast, California, US
review: A solid wine for the price, this shows lush aromas of baked red cherries, vanilla, caramel and clove. The palate is more restrained with tart, somewhat rigid tannins that will allow more fruit and spice flavors to emerge with patience.

wine: Beringer 2001 Bancroft Ranch Cabernet Sauvignon (Howell Mountain)
review: Like all of Beringer's 2001 gold letter single-vineyard Cabs, this one is a cellar laydown. It's hard in tannins now, a dry wine that leaves the palate rasping because it's so astringent. Yet the fruit is gigantically ripe, flooding the mouth with blackberries and cherries that are the essence of those fruits. With all that ripeness, the acidity is crisp and fine. Drink 2008–2020.

appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Has dense, heavy aromas of jasmine, cinnamon, rose petal, chocolate and citrus. Fruity and fairly sweet, with flavors of ripe peaches, nectarines and orange sherbet. Acidity is okay, but there's a heaviness, a thickness to the wine that makes it a bit awkward on the palate.

wine: Kawarau Estate 2006 Reserve Pinot Noir (Central Otago)
review: This seems tight and unyielding right now, making it hard to evaluate. Enough cola, plum and licorice is showing to think this will be better in 2010. For now, it's a bit crisp and monolithic.

wine: Atwater 2017 Dry Rosé of Cabernet Franc (Finger Lakes)
appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
review: A bit closed at first, this reveals tart strawberry, watermelon and pepper notes as it opens. While there is roundness to the feel, sharp acidity drives the midpalate, eventually smoothing out on the finish.

The superb palate boasts richness, with honey and orange zest notes. It shows fine balance between the flavors of orange jelly and the intense botrytis-driven notes. It has a light, delicate texture and acidity.

wine: Trinchero 2003 Family Selection Sauvignon Blanc (Napa Valley)
review: Here's a good value in a fruit-forward wine that has some real complexity and depth. You'll find flavors of apples, peaches, melons and figs. Finish is crisp, ripe and spicy.

wine: Cantine Barbera 2007 La Vota Cabernet Sauvignon (Menfi)
review: La Vota is a Cabernet Sauvignon from a hot climate that surprises the palate with its crisp, green aromas. There's a touch of soya, wasabi, bramble and forest floor. But you'll also recognize wild berry and toasted almond.
87–89. Barrel sample. With remarkable density and solid tannins, this is a firm wine that's dry and solid. It's likely to age well.

Hints of smoked nut, licorice and wild herb accent sumptuously ripe black plum and wild strawberry flavors here. The midpalate is fleshy and forward, cushioned by delicate acidity and fine, velvet tannins. Its open-knit demeanor is welcoming now but should drink well through 2026.

appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: Minty and sharp in acidity, and not offering much richness now, especially at this price, although it does feel stylishly dry and elegant. Shows proper cherry, cola and sandalwood flavors.
This late harvest wine is straw in color, with aromas of yellow peaches, white flowers and apricots. It's well balanced, with a pleasing level of acidity to offset the ripe, fruit-driven palate.

wine: Arachon 2016 Evolution T FX T Red (Burgenland)
review: Cinnamon, plum and blueberry send aromatic waves from the glass. The palate is rich and smooth but also shows inherent freshness and a crunchy, fine tannin structure. A juiciness starts to seep through these fine strictures and fills the senses with joy. Density, fruit, tannin—all is there in a very elegant, fresh fashion. The finish is long with juicy blueberry. Lovely now but will develop. Drink now–2030.

Velvety on the palate, this wine initially conveys a sense of restraint. A shy line of cool-climate raspberry and strawberry are made brighter on the palate by zesty acidity. Begging for grilled meats, it becomes more substantial over time, offering leather and savory spice.

wine: Domaine de la Rochette 2020 Pineau d'Aunis Rosé (Touraine)
review: Produced from a local Loire grape that is just right for rosé wines, this is fruity, with a touch of pepper as well as acidity. The lightness and crisp red-currant flavors are a fine foil for the wine's texture at the end. Drink now.

appellation: San Martino della Battaglia, Veneto, Italy
review: Made entirely with Friulano (formerly called Tocai Italico), this vibrant white conveys aromas of white flower, citrus and nut that carry over to the palate along with a slight metallic note. Bitter walnut marks the close.

wine: Margerum 2010 Alamo Creek Vineyard Grenache (San Luis Obispo County)
appellation: San Luis Obispo County, Central Coast, California, US
review: This is a soft, gently sweet Grenache, with raspberry jam, toast and cinnamon spice flavors. Drink up.

wine: Château La Carelle 2014  Blaye Côtes de Bordeaux
appellation: Blaye Côtes de Bordeaux, Bordeaux, France
review: Owned by the Bayle-Carreau family since the late 19th century, this estate produces an elegant style of black-currant and tannin-structured wine. With acidity and the perfume from Cabernet Franc, the wine has a good future. Drink from 2022.

wine: Legado del Moncayo 2019 Garnacha Rosé (Campo de Borja)
appellation: Campo de Borja, Northern Spain, Spain
review: A bold orange color and aromas of cherry, plum and vanilla open this citrusy rosé of Garnacha. Yeast, tangerine and slight bitterness comprise the flavors, while a crisp finish deals notes of orange, brine and salt.

Ripe red berry, truffle, new leather and tobacco aromas fill the glass. It's juicy and full bodied, doling out ripe raspberry, sour cherry, star anise and crushed herb framed in chewy tannins. You'll also detect the warmth of alcohol but the fruit richness keeps it in check.
Made in small quantities, this wine opens in a decadence of gingerbread and graham cracker aromas before a medium-bodied texture supports a supple ripeness of green apple, melon and pear.

wine: Buena Vista 2012 Jovita's Selection Chardonnay (Sonoma Coast)
review: This is a hearty, medium-bodied Chardonnay with ripe caramelized apple on the front palate that delves into toasty oak.

wine: José Maria da Fonseca 2005 Domingos Red (Terras do Sado)
review: Blending Touriga Nacional and Syrah, this personal blend is named after Domingos Soares Franco, the head winemaker at J.M. da Fonseca. The wine is big, fruity and perfumed, with black, ripe fruit flavors and a solid edge, finishing with dark chocolate.

wine: Northwest Ridge 2016 8 Barrel Whole Cluster Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)
appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: Sharply focused flavors bring cranberry and cherry fruit front and center. There's a stiffening frame of black licorice, suggesting some time in new wood. The wine seems to sit on the palate without any further development, and then just stops. A bit more bottle age is recommended; drink after 2020.

The famous blend combines Zinfandel, Cabernet Sauvignon, Petite Sirah, Syrah and Charbono from throughout the Napa Valley, combining the grapes into a robust, flavorful explosion of soft, richly rounded fruit and body. It's undeniably appealing.

appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: Simple, with fruit punch-sweet pineapple and lemon flavors. High acidity makes it a little sour.
96–98. Barrel Sample. This wine has great tension, with an almost mineral character. The ripe black fruits are complemented by ample acidity, with a stylish structure and enormous aging potential.

appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: This is barely Merlot—just 75%—and the rest is filled in with Cab Sauvignon, Cab Franc, Petit Verdot and Syrah. This definitely bumps up the tannins and brightens the natural berry flavors. Tart fruit and creamy vanilla finish with softly astringent tannins. Nothing spectacular, but very smooth drinking.

wine: Veuve Clicquot Ponsardin NV Brut Rosé  (Champagne)
review: This is a soft rosé, smoothly textured and approachable. It has layers of rich strawberries as well as touches of red currant attractively wrapped in ripe acidity. The bottling is ready to drink.

wine: Alma de los Andes 2007 Malbec-Cabernet Sauvignon (Mendoza)
review: Tight on the nose, with hints of resin, lemon peel and black fruit that smell inviting when all added up. The palate is juicy, arguably a bit acidic, and runs fresh with red cherry and plum flavors. Spunky and properly tannic.

wine: Santa Rita 2016 120 Reserva Especial Hero's Red (Central Valley)
review: Aromas of black olive and black fruits show an almost grilled element. This wine offers energy and balance, with a touch of oak. Plum, berry and cherry flavors end powerfully on a tightly wound finish.

appellation: Rogue Valley, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
review: Pure varietal, and aged 15 months in neutral or once-filled oak, this shows brambly and tart red fruits, with sharp acidity.

Bone dry, with crisp, mouth-cleansing acidity and flavors of citrus fruits, minerals and vanilla. There's a touch of gooseberry and muscat. Turns almost sour toward the finish, but it's zesty and alive.

This vibrant, delicious rosato delivers fruity aromas of woodland berry and cooking spice. On the spicy palate, notes of white pepper and clove accent a juicy core of crushed raspberry. Crisp acidity gives it a clean, lingering finish.

appellation: Rogue Valley, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
review: This classic G-S-M blend, here done as a dry rosé, absolutely rocks. The balance of fruit and acidity strikes a perfect chord, and the harmonious flavors bring a mix of raspberry, cherry, orange and a hint of chocolate. The blend is 63% Grenache, 26% Syrah and 11% Mourvèdre, all specifically farmed for this rosé.

wine: Covenant 2019 Red C Sauvignon Blanc (Lake County)
appellation: Lake County, Lake County, California, US
review: This well-balanced medium-bodied wine fermented in steel barrels with native yeast is alive with tangy citrus aromas and flavors that are shaded by hints of riper melon and cream notes. It is crisp, clean and refreshing.
Citrus, spring blossom and apple aromas follow over to the straightforward easygoing palate along with peach and a candied note. Lively acidity provides the backdrop.

appellation: Sierra Foothills, Sierra Foothills, California, US
review: Tastes distinctly sweet in pineapple juice, lemonade, peppermint candy and vanilla custard flavors, but balanced with crisp acidity.

appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
review: This is a new winery for me, but one to watch. The grapes are from Santa Maria Valley, and the wine shows the ripe balance of this fine vintage, with a tremendous depth of tropical fruit, apricot jam and oak-inspired butterscotch flavors. Brisk acidity provides needed balance to the wealth of fruit.

This blend of Aglianico and Montelpulciano opens with slightly funky aromas that include nail polish remover, stewed prune and oak. The palate offers toasted oak, vanilla, sweetened coffee and sugar plum alongside astringent wood tannins.

Rose, red-berry and dried herb aromas lead the nose on this entry-level offering. The palate is rather light on its feet for Barolo, offering suggestions of spiced cranberry and orange zest alongside brisk acidity and loosely knit, dusty tannins.

wine: Sbragia 2017 Nonno's Reserve Zinfandel (Dry Creek Valley)
appellation: Dry Creek Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: This is a hearty, abundantly ripe wine, broadly thick and concentrated in syrupy black fruit. The oak is appropriately matched, adding weight and woody elements alongside hints of tobacco and brush.

wine: RhonéA 2017 Domaine du Paparotier  (Muscat de Beaumes de Venise)
varietal: Muscat Blanc à Petits Grains, Muscat
appellation: Muscat de Beaumes de Venise, Rhône Valley, France
review: Gorgeous orange blossom, honeysuckle and white-peach aromas perfume this pretty vin doux naturel. It's bold in apricot and stone-fruit flavors and lip-smackingly sweet, but maintains a mineral elegance and freshness from nose to finish. Balanced in alcohol, its finish lingers sweetly and with uncloying purity. Enjoy now–2022.
This wine struggles in its overripe, nearly sweet confections of vanilla and marshmallow.

wine: Nikolaihof 2010 Im Weingebirge Federspiel Grüner Veltliner (Wachau)
review: Earthy, juicy ripeness of Russet pear is evoked vividly on the nose, while white pepper and ground stone shimmer in the background. The palate is juicy at first, but soon the salty, yeasty, almost cheesy core spreads its savory magic, not without adding vivid apple notes. A very complex and deeply satisfying wine. The finish belongs to zesty, clean lemon.

This is Judith Beck's flagship wine, a single vineyard Blaufränkisch, firmly tannic, solid, chunky, but still keeping a wonderfully perfumed character. The fruit is very pure, black berry juice dominant, along with acidity. Impressive and worth aging.

Pale in color, this 100% Grenache has arresting, complex aromas of candied strawberries, pomegranate, herbs, plum and orange peel. The red fruit and savory flavors are sweet and generous, showing an exquisite sense of purity and richness. It's a knee-buckler but all about delicacy and restraint.

wine: Michelle NV Extra Dry Sparkling (Columbia Valley (WA))
appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Using the all-too-confusing “extra dry” designation for a rather sweet sparkling wine seems unnecessary for this re-named wine with spiffy new packaging. The blend is 63% Chardonnay, 19% Pinot Noir and 18% Pinot Gris; the flavors are a mix of citrus rind and crystalized sugar. The finish, despite the sweetness, is slightly bitter.

wine: Establecimiento Juanico 2018 Don Pascual Coastal Tannat (Uruguay)
review: Berry, dark plum and a hint of raisin fill out the nose of this tightly wound Tannat. The full palate is cut by bright acidity, while plum and berry flavors finish with a complex saline note.

Organic and biodynamic Punset offers Nebbiolo-based wines that are very difficult to assess. Try them too young (as in this case) and the wines often lack clarity and balance. Wait ten years or more and they blossom into something very special indeed. The 2008 Campo Quadro illustrates this point exactly.
An open wine with a good balance between sweet honey and acidity, this is made to drink young. With apricot and spice flavors, the wine is both perfumed and fresh. Drink now.

appellation: North Coast, North Coast, California, US
review: This handsome, full-bodied wine shows the sturdy, muscular aspect of Cabernet Franc in its structure of firm tannins while holding its complex graphite, tobacco, blackberry and singed herb flavors slightly in check. It opens and ripens beautifully in the glass, and will be best after 2023.

appellation: Vino Nobile di Montepulciano, Tuscany, Italy
review: Aromas of blue flower, plum, scorched earth and allspice come together in the glass. The soft, rich palate offers layers of black cherry, white pepper and savory herb alongside round tannins. Drink through 2018.

appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Plump, soft and appealing with cherry tobacco scents and fruit flavors mixing berry, black cherry, plum and fig. Smoke, hints of herb and green tea-flavored tannins lead into a substantial finish with buttery cocoa, coffee and spice.

appellation: Clairette de Bellegarde, Rhône Valley, France
review: It should be easy to stump your wine-geek buddies with this one. At once honeyed and rich, exotic and tropical, this is a rarity they're unlikely to even know exists. A mere hint of bitterness on the finish of this medium-bodied wine nicely balances the ripe tropical flavors. Drink now.

appellation: Santa Ynez Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: Sweeter-leaning aromas of lime and lemon syrup meet with crushed white rocks and light orange blossom on the nose of this bottling. The palate proves more dry than expected, with flavors of lime rind, orange-blossom candies and fresh herbs.

wine: Domaine de Granajolo 2009 Blanc Vermentino (Corse Porto Vecchio)
review: Spices, a hint of honey, a texture of pears and white plums—this is a rich, soft wine with a good intensity of taste and ripeness.

wine: Flora Springs 2005 Rennie Reserve Cabernet Sauvignon (St. Helena)
review: An extraordinary wine, among the greatest Cabs in Flora Springs' long history. One hundred percent varietal, and made from a single clone, it shows fabulous density and serious weight, with dramatically rich blackberry, currant and cedar flavors anchored by a firm minerality. For all its power, the wine is balanced and elegant. An ager, it will drink well for at least a decade.

appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: Soft and gentle, with earthy, herb-infused cherry and currant flavors, this is a nice wine to drink now. It's dry and balanced, with a tannic, peppery tug that grounds the fruit.

Aromas like black pepper and red cherries, and flavors like lightly sweet strawberries give this medium-bodied wine a lot to like, besides the very affordable price. It has just a touch of tannin to add some good texture.

wine: Johanneshof Reinisch 2017 Ried Holzspur St. Laurent (Thermenregion)
review: Hints of cedar and cinnamon swing alongside the toasty but subdued notes of oak on the nose. The palate comes in with absolute freshness that showcases dark, luscious fruit reminiscent of both black cherry and elderberry. Hints of licorice and smoke add aromatic allure while supple tannins already reveal much of the juiciness at the core of this elegant, concentrated wine. Drink 2025–2040.

A dance between tangy acidity and a creamy texture plays out wonderfully in this medium- to full-bodied wine. It offers fresh citrus aromas and generous apple and honeydew melon flavors while the mouthfeel is broad and smooth.

This is a nice, cheerful blush wine, but you should chill it well to stun the slight sweetness, which makes it a little insipid. Icy cold, it's refreshing, with strawberry, raspberry and vanilla flavors.

wine: C. von Nell-Breuning 2013 Kaseler Dominikanerberg Kabinett Halbtrocken Riesling (Mosel)
review: Robustly citrusy notes of orange peel and tangerine show brightly in this brisk, off-dry wine. It is approachably fresh and fruity, but nuanced by a touch of crushed stone and whiffs of rose petal on the finish. Drink now through 2018.
Oak, peach and nutty aromas ride on the nose. Dense, creamy and reasonably balanced on the palate, this chunky number offers full melon and peach flavors prior to a briny, long finish.

wine: Domaine Sainte-Marie 2013 Paparazzi Rosé (Côtes de Provence)
review: As fresh and fruity as possible, this is a lively wine. Coming in a darkened bottle it looks stylish on a table, although its fragrant red fruits make it even better as an apéritif.

wine: Bella 2001 Belle Canyon Estate Zinfandel (Dry Creek Valley)
appellation: Dry Creek Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: Smooth and silky, with an elegant mix of coffee, chocolate, plum, black cherry and spice flavors. The tannins are ripe, with moderate body and a good finish.

wine: The Eyrie Vineyards 2010 Estate Pinot Gris (Dundee Hills)
appellation: Dundee Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: The grapes used for this wine are from the original vines, planted almost 50 years ago by David Lett. Rich, sleek and textural, this thrilling effort sets a new standard for Oregon Pinot Gris. Grassy notes are married to lush citrus and apple fruit. The flavors go deep and long, the finish is immaculate and brings a palate-refreshing minerality.

wine: Bailiwick 2011 Londer Vineyard Pinot Noir (Anderson Valley)
appellation: Anderson Valley, Mendocino County, California, US
review: Wonderfully aromatic in Bing cherry, this is a soft, supple Pinot with an oaky, tannic backbone that's otherwise light in color and body. With just the right hint of rose petal happening, it's pretty, too.

wine: Comte Stanislas NV Cuvée Sélection Brut  (Champagne)
review: The style of this brand, with its high proportion of Meunier, gives a soft Champagne that is very accessible and immediately delicious. Its fruitiness and floral character are totally ready to drink.

wine: Clos Pegase 1999 Palisades Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
review: From this Calistoga vineyard, a first rate Cabernet, sumptuous and elegant. The fruit straddles an interesting line between herbaceous, green olive notes and riper ones of blackberries. Feels just great in the mouth, plush and sensual. Unquestionably an ager.
This dry, barrique-aged Malvasia opens with aromas of honey and beeswax with the merest hint of petrol. The aromas carry over to the palate along with vanilla and rosemary.

This is a 100% expression of Cabernet,  with ripe, jammy fruit and lingering tones of spice, leather, rum cake, strawberry rollup and blackberry pie. The wine is round and ripe but it also adopts an elegant, direct style that is enhanced by a nice touch of acidity on the close.

A full dark-cherry, herb and toast nose. A slight funky note may put off some people, but there's very good depth of fruit here; concentrated and rich. The fruit shines with a classic tartness nicely framed by oak.
95-97 Barrel sample. Very gold in color, this is a wine that seems initially closed, tight, only slowly showing its full panoply of richness, density and sweet final acidity.

This is a medium-bodied, fruit-driven Syrah that seems built for immediate consumption. Black cherry fruit is in the lead, with hints of chocolate and lavender to spice things up. Eminently quaffable, with bright fruit and a lingering finish.

appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: This light colored red offers cranberry fruit leather, strawberry, rose hip and red cherry aromas. The flavors are elegant and enjoyable yet lack concentration. Herbal notes linger on the finish.

wine: Boheme 2013 Taylor Ridge Vineyard Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)
review: This is a spicy, vibrantly realized wine from a coastal ridge five miles from the Pacific Ocean dusted in sandy, loam soils. It's planted entirely to the Swan clone, which can contribute an undeniable wildness to the variety. Baked cherry meets spearmint and clove, the acidity light and bright with plenty of texture atop the medium-sized body.

Oodles of enticing fruit flavors and deft oak spices give this full-bodied wine plenty to enjoy. It has a buttery, creamy richness both in flavor and texture, excellent concentration and a lingering finish.
This is a full-bodied wine with a rich texture. It has a creamy character, along with flavors of almond, toast and ripe green plum. Worth aging a year.

This indigo-colored wine has a cacophony of aromas ranging from barnyard and leather to eucalyptus and dark berry. The flavor profile is nearly identical, the eucalyptus taking on more of a balsam note and additional dashes of forest floor and spice. The gritty tannins may soften, but the acidity will always be high. This wine has a lot going on, but after four years it still doesn't mesh.

wine: Domaines Schlumberger 2011 Les Princes Abbés Riesling (Alsace)
review: This perfumed wine is very dry but has delicious and fragrant fruitiness. A slight steely character adds complexity and structure. Made from biodynamically farmed grapes, it is ready to drink.

appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: This excellent blend of 70% Cabernet Franc, 25% Merlot and 5% Cabernet Sauvignon shows caramelized black cherry, mint chocolate chip and a bit of smoke on the dense nose. The palate's soft mouthfeel is held up by firm tannins that last deep into the finish, presenting rich cherry juice flavors, along with caramel, milk chocolate and pleasant oak character.

wine: Craggy Range 2013 Aroha Te Muna Pinot Noir (Martinborough)
review: A barrel selection off Craggy Range's estate vineyard in the Te Muna Road area of Martinborough, this isn't a huge blockbuster style, but one that favors elegance. The aromas and flavors are ripe, oozing with hints of plum, black cherry, cola and licorice, but what makes the wine special are its subtle spice shadings and silky texture. Drink now–2025.

wine: Hajszan Neumann 2017 Ried Weisleiten White (Wiener Gemischter Satz)
review: A touch of dried hay flowers and notions of ripe, red apple combine on the appetizing nose. The palate comes in with precise slenderness that highlights white apple and pear flesh and juiciness. There is something deeply zesty at the core that makes this utterly moreish and so fresh.

Ripeness is conveyed through mild raisin and prune aromas. While this is firm on the palate, there's just enough cushion to provide depth. Earthy berry and raisin flavors reflect a warm year, while this is sappy on a fruity finish with just enough edge to it.

wine: Siduri 2006 Parsons' Vineyard Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)
appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: Spicy and very ripe, this polished Pinot bursts with pie-filling cherry and currant flavors, with interesting notes of tangerine rind, clove and orange pekoe tea. Could develop additional nuances with bottle age, but basically ready now.

wine: Castiglion del Bosco 2007 Prima Pietra Red (Toscana)
review: Prima Pietra is a stand-alone super Tuscan blend from the Castiglion del Bosco estate (owned by fashion's Ferragamo family), which is already well known for its excellent Brunello di Montalcino. This is a plump, modern and well-extracted wine with soft tannins and beautiful length.

Opening with a crisp, stony nose of mineral and brine, this wine is also floral and earthy, with demure fruit. From the famous vineyard, it offers classic flavors of apple, pear and nutmeg, wrapped within complementary oak.

appellation: El Dorado, Sierra Foothills, California, US
review: This is a big red wine that packs a whallop. It has the majestic rusticity of Petite Sirah, yet with a Bordeauxesque nobility that makes it elegant. With a briary taste of blackberries, black currants, mocha, pepper and violets, it might gain a little complexity with a few years in the cellar.

wine: Barone di Villagrande 2015 Salina Bianco White (Terre Siciliane)
review: A blend of native grapes Rucignola, Catarratto and Malvasia, this has aromas suggesting pressed yellow flower and dried herb. The palate is somewhat lean, offering citrus, dried Mediterranean herb and a hint of nut.

Stony minerality blends with raisin, leather and leafy berry aromas. This offers cheek-stanching citric acidity but not enough body to absorb it. Flavors of herbal red plum are choppy and turn gritty and fiery on the finish.
Gaseous aromas settle on saline, chlorine and gritty citrus. This is round and not overly acidic in feel, with pickled, briny, green-leaning flavors of lime, cucumber and bell pepper.

wine: Rowen Wine Co. 2016 Rowen Red (Sonoma County)
review: Juicy in soft layers of cherry, cola and vanilla, this balanced wine is approachable and memorable. It shows a richness of fruit on the midpalate and a lasting hint of toasted oak.

Very sweet in fruit and refined in texture, a softly gentle wine to enjoy now and over the next six years. Shows lots of blackberry, cherry, orange zest, licorice and sandalwood flavors, wrapped into rich, silky tannins.

Seems a bit too big and bulky in the mouth, with a touch of warmth on the finish, but has plenty of pluses as well, showing more minerality and complexity than many wines in this price range. Hints of honey, petrol and smoke intertwine with melon and pineapple fruit. Imported by Magellan Wine Imports.

Rarely seen as a varietal wine, this Pinot Meunier is reminiscent of a sturdy, earthy Pinot Noir. The same pie-cherry and chocolate flavors are there, nicely scented with new oak, but the acids are a bit higher, and the finish tightens up. A great wine for salmon.

wine: Rocca delle Macìe 2010 Riserva di Fizzano  (Chianti Classico)
review: Underbrush, spice and plum aromas lead the nose on this blend of 85% Sangiovese, 10% Cabernet Sauvignon and 5% Merlot. The smooth palate delivers a core of juicy black cherry accented with licorice and espresso. Polished and round, this is already drinking well, but can age at least a few more years.

wine: William Knuttel 2008 Basor Terrace Vineyard Pinot Gris (Sonoma County)
review: A rich, elaborate Pinot Gris, with strong, ripe tangerine, white peach, honey and sweet, oaky vanilla flavors. There's good acidity, but the finish is so sweet, it's almost like a dessert wine.

appellation: Fiano di Avellino, Southern Italy, Italy
review: This bright wine reveals fragrances of white flower, pear, citrus and slate. The juicy palate offers grapefruit, lemon-lime and mineral. A succulent finish closes on a note of white almond.

appellation: Mendocino County, Mendocino County, California, US
review: There are structural similarities here with Napa Cabernet. The wine is dry, lush in tannins, balanced in acidity, with ripe but controlled black currant and cherry flavors. Yes, there's a certain briary, wild character, but this is really one heck of a good wine. Drink now through 2009 for its youthful fruit.

wine: Quinta do Vale Meão 2017 Monte Meão Casa das Máquinas Red (Douro)
review: This single-vineyard wine is one of a series from this major estate. It is a blend of Touriga Franca and Tinta Barocca. It's rich and spicy from wood aging, while also impressively balanced. The still-young black fruits are set to allow it to age comfortably. Drink from 2023.

Aromas of toast, coffee, ripe plum and caramel lead the nose of this Sangiovese-based wine. On the palate, espresso and dark chocolate notes back up dried black cherry while firm tannins provide the framework. It's a bit shy on fruit richness so drink soon.

The most accessible of Paul Jaboulet Aîné's Crozes cuvées, the 2005 Les Jalets offers smoky, herbal, peppery aromatics, crisp pomegranate fruit and silky   tannins on the finish. It's a solid introduction to Crozes-Hermitage in an early-maturing style.

Richly fruited and tropical, this is a medium-bodied, slightly creamy-textured Marlborough Savvy. Flavors hint at pineapple, honey and stone fruit, yet remain zesty and clean, with a refreshing citrus zing to the finish. Stock up for the summer.

wine: Testarossa 2012 Dos Rubios Vineyard Pinot Noir (Santa Lucia Highlands)
appellation: Santa Lucia Highlands, Central Coast, California, US
review: Rich blackberry fruit gets aromatic lift from violet and sagebrush in this wine from a relatively new vineyard, planted in 2008. That spice and fruit tension works well on the palate too, with ripe pluot and wild berries accompanied by black licorice, black olive and roast beef.
Smells basic and clean, with touches of apple and green veggies. The palate has a thick grab to it, while the flavors seem both sugary and green, with grapefruit and pithy bitterness on the finish.
This easygoing white conveys delicate aromas of white flower and citrus. The simple palate offers lemon drop and a hint of Mediterranean herb alongside zesty acidity.

Fresh hazelnut, ginger and crushed chervil notions come wrapped in an intense, smooth creaminess on the nose. The palate continues in the same creamy fashion but adds juicy Mirabelle and ripe lemon that edges all these notions with ripeness and clarity. Yes, this is generous and rounded, but its contours are defined and there is not an ounce of fat. Drink 2025–2040.

wine: Roederer Estate 2003 L'Ermitage Brut Rosé Sparkling (Anderson Valley)
appellation: Anderson Valley, Mendocino County, California, US
review: This is as fine a rosé sparkling wine as has ever been produced in California. Almost 50-50 Chardonnay and Pinot Noir, it has rich flavors of cherries, raspberries, vanilla, toast and creamy lees, in the style of Champagne, and is completely dry and very crisp in acidity. Fabulously drinkable now, it should develop well over the next 6–8 years.
Aromas of butterscotch, vanilla and melony fruits rest comfortably in front of a smooth palate. Melon, honey and floral flavors finish full but healthy courtesy of just-enough acidity.
This soft, ripe and fruity wine offers a bright blend of acidity and black-currant flavors. With its light structure and forward fruitiness, the wine should be ready from 2022.

appellation: Horse Heaven Hills, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Like many wines from this vintage, this one packs a fruit-filled wallop. Toast, coffee and blueberry aromas give way to ripe, plush plum flavors that bring a sense of seamlessness. It's a whole lot of wine for the money.

This is a supple, medium-bodied Pinot Noir that exemplifies much of what is coming out of Marlborough. Hints of mushroom and soy sauce accent bright cherry fruit, finishing on a silky note. Drink now.

wine: Davies 2016 JD Estate Cabernet Sauvignon (Diamond Mountain District)
appellation: Diamond Mountain District, Napa, California, US
review: This elegant, classically styled wine is earthy in tobacco, mushroom and fig, a lovely wine from the mountain appellation. A soft understated richness of plum and black cherry wrap around a texture of grippy dust and dark chocolate, finishing as gracefully as it starts.

wine: El Pensador 2009 Verdejo (Vino de la Tierra de Castilla y León)
appellation: Vino de la Tierra de Castilla y León, Northern Spain, Spain
review: A solid rendition of Verdejo with apple and pear aromas along with basic minerality. The palate is standard and firm, with good acidity pushing apple and citrus flavors. Perfectly competent but not showing the nuances and higher qualities that would justify a $17 outlay.

wine: Quinta de la Rosa 2011 DouRosa Red (Douro)
review: A spicy, ripe wine that is part of the second line from Quinta de la Rosa. With its rich tannins, fine layers of acidity and sweet berry fruit, it is already drinkable. Give it 2–3 years and it will develop beyond its just fruity stage.

appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: There's lots of fresh, savory raspberry and cherry jam fruit in this Zin. Marked by good acids and tannins, with a dry finish, it's a fine wine to drink now

Scents of mature tropical fruit, walnut and bread crust segue over to the dry savory palate together with yellow apple and lemon zest. Tangy acidity brightens the rich flavors while an elegant perlage lends finesse.
This fresh expression of Sangiovese Grosso offers tight berry aromas, with shades of spice and toasted almond in the background. Bright acidity brings up the rear.

This Sangiovese-based red has a light, ruby color and offers fresh aromas of violet, wet earth, wild mushroom and leather. Delicate and streamlined, it has fresh acidity that would pair well with simple pasta and Parmigiano.

Savory aromas of baked raspberry, cranberry and vanilla are somewhat foxy. Flavors of raspberry and pomegranate are nearing overripe, with layers of pepper and grippy tannins that offer some much needed structure. The finish is all tannin and spice.

wine: Sanchez Romate NV NPU Amontillado Sherry (Jerez)
review: Pure and nutty, with aromas of dried apricot and sea air. In the mouth you get lots of almond and butter, while the A-rate finish is buttery but also quite complex. A classic, refined wine that dances across your tongue like a ballerina. Imported by Shaw-Ross International Importers.

wine: Il Conventino 2011  Vino Nobile di Montepulciano
appellation: Vino Nobile di Montepulciano, Tuscany, Italy
review: Anisette, steeped plum, tar and espresso aromas take shape in the glass. The concentrated palate offers fleshy wild cherry, dark berry, graphite, coffee and allspice alongside chewy tannins.

This 100% Cabernet was blended by Kirk Venge from vineyards in Oakville, Calistoga, Mount Veeder, Spring Mountain and Coombsville. It makes you wonder why we obsess with single-vineyard bottlings. Unfined and unfiltered, it's rich and pure in blackberries, currants, mocha, anise and new French oak, with superb tannins. Will age effortlessly through at least 2021.
Simple and jammy, with sweet flavors of cherries, currants, licorice and spices.

wine: Golan Heights Winery 2002 Yarden Katzrin Chardonnay (Galilee)
review: Yarden's top Chardonnay is top-heavy with buttered popcorn flavors, buttressed by layers of peach and vanilla. Full-bodied, and seems a bit warm on the finish. Imported by Yarden.
Fruity and soft, this wine has ripe citrus and red-apple flavors, with a light texture. Drink now.

This wine awakes with just a little air as notions of ripe mandarin and clemetine appear, along with a pleasantly bitter, zesty tang. The palate introduces bright lemon vigor that cuts right through to hit all the pleasure centers of the brain with freshness. This is alive and shimmers with tangerine and lemon. Inherent acidic drive makes for a thrilling, dry finish.
This wine balances its acidity, light texture and softness with ripe red fruits. It has a touch of bitterness, although this is enveloped by the ripe fruit of the vintage.

wine: Cave de Ribeauvillé 2010 Clos du Zahnacker White (Alsace)
review: From a parcel in the Osterberg Grand Cru vineyard, this is a blend of Riesling, Pinot Gris and Gewurztraminer. The spice dominates although it is cut through by Riesling acidity. It's not quite integrated, showing youthful exuberance that needs to settle down. Drink from 2016.
Big, grapey and whole on the nose, and then lound, large and ripe in the mouth, with ringing acidity, bold berry flavors and a warm, oily, earthy finish. A solid wine that gets it mostly right.

A sexy wine with lush black cherry and licorice on the nose; a full, round mouthfeel to the black-cherry flavored palate. Tarry notes add interest, and the finish is long and ripe with dusty tannins. Luscious.

wine: Producta Vignobles 2014 Château Léo de Prades  (Saint-Estèphe)
review: Produced by the fine Saint-Estèphe cooperative, this wine still shows tannins aplenty. If it does have the fresh black currant characteristic of the vintage, it is possible that it is verging on drying out. The wine should be drunk now.

wine: Carol Shelton 2015 Coquille Blanc White (Paso Robles)
appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: Dried apple, pear and fresh honeysuckle scents show on the floral and fruity nose of this blend of Grenache Blanc, Roussanne, Marsanne and Viognier. The palate overflows with fruit, from pineapple guava to banana and cherimoya, while lemony acidity holds it all together.

Makes an interesting contrast to the spice-driven flavors of Felsner's Vordernberg bottling, by offering honeyed stones and peaches in a medium-bodied format. Finishes with bright notes of citrus zest.
The aromas are fruitful, with notes of black currant and plum, along with accents of tar and smoke. The palate is direct in the appeal of its fleshy fruit flavors, straight down the fairway.

wine: One Woman 2010 Chardonnay (North Fork of Long Island)
appellation: North Fork of Long Island, Long Island, New York, US
review: Touches of vanilla accent flavors of freshly pressed apples and pears in this bold, full-bodied wine. Piercing lemon acidity adds freshness to the palate, but the finish is a bit warming overall.

Like many Mornington producers, Kooyong has a relatively short track record (founded 1996). For much of that time, winemaking was under the guidance of Sandro Mosele, including this stunning 2012. It shows Burgundian levels of complexity in its array of smoke, leather, root vegetable and black cherry notes, then backs that all up with a firm-yet-supple texture and tremendous length. Drink now through 2022.

wine: Maysara 2002 Estate Cuvée Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)
appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: From a blend of very low-cropped pinot clones, this expressively fruity wine jumps with strawberry, raspberry, cherry and plum fruits, hints of mineral and a tight streak of tannic beetroot. Complex, youthful and engaging effort.

wine: Villa Diamante 2015 Vigna della Congregazione  (Fiano di Avellino)
appellation: Fiano di Avellino, Southern Italy, Italy
review: Scents of yellow flower, ripe orchard fruit and aromatic herb lead the way on this round, medium-bodied white. On the savory palate, an underlying mineral note reminiscent of oyster shell underscores mature pear, yellow apple, fennel and a hint of honey. A hazelnut note marks the close.

Stewed aromas of berry fruit and leather with green notes get this Tannat-Merlot blend going. Lively acidity and tannins create an aggressive mouthfeel, while flavors of vanilla and baked berry fruit finish round.

Incredibly candied and sweet smelling, much like cotton candy or pink marshmallows. The palate has a cloying, sticky mouthfeel and flavors of raisin, milk chocolate and herbal, tart berry fruits. Creamy and carob-like on the finish. Tastes and smells affected.

wine: Fitz-Ritter NV Fitz Extra Trocken Sekt Riesling (Pfalz)
review: Invigorating acidity and crisp citrus and apple flavors shine in this sparkling Riesling. The mousse is elegant and smooth, brightened by tiny, persistent bubbles that seem to disseminate pops of caramel and honey sweetness.

wine: Corinne et Pierre Grossot 2018 Les Fourneaux Premier Cru  (Chablis)
review: Subtle but insistent lemon zest is all that the shy nose on this wine reveals. Creamy fullness and softness on the palate counterbalances the lemony brightness and sits well with the rounded generosity of the vintage. The concentrated body has enough freshness to come out balanced and supple.

wine: Segura Viudas NV Brut Reserva Heredad Sparkling (Cava)
review: Lime and apple candy aromas are approachable and likable, while the palate is solid and structured, but a touch foamy. Flavors of apple, pear, green melon and lime are dry, crisp and pithy, while the wine's freshness and spunk are admirable.

wine: Coelho 2018 Coelho Vineyard Chardonnay (Van Duzer Corridor)
appellation: Van Duzer Corridor, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: Made using the black Chardonnay method that is intentionally hyper-oxidized prior to fermenting, this wine is crisp in snappy apple and persimmon fruit. It was aged 14 months in half new French oak, softening the mouthfeel and adding pleasant notes of toast and butter.

Light, bright and fruity, this is a delicious glass of wine. It's fresh and crisp with fragrant white fruits layered with zesty citrus. It has a cool feel, with bright acidity adding lift to the finish.

wine: J. Lohr 2017 Hilltop Cabernet Sauvignon (Paso Robles)
appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: This reliable bottling offers fudge, caramel, black cherry and oak on the ripe nose. Cola and sarsparilla meet with black-cherry foam on the palate, where creamy tannins and just enough acidity carry into the finish.

appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: Soft and luscious, with a sweet peppermint patty taste firming up the blackberries, currants, pepper and cedar flavors. Shows real discernment and class. Drink in the next five years.
Red-berry, tilled soil and leather aromas shape the nose. The linear palate offers red cherry, cinnamon and a licorice note alongside firm, polished tannins. Drink 2021–2029.
Black currant and blackberry are plush on the palate with aromas and flavors of anise, vanilla bean and pepper. Firm tannin and long spicy finish are smooth and food friendly.

wine: Nicolas Feuillatte NV Brut Kosher Mevushal  (Champagne)
review: Bizarre is the best way to describe this kosher offering: The nose is fragrant, with bright ripe fruit backed by cotton-candy and algae-ish notes.  Apple, charcoal and pear are tinged with a slight greenness on the palate; mouthful is medium-full, but a bit too effervescent and frothy. Finishes long.

wine: Maison Champy 2015 Les Folatières Premier Cru  (Puligny-Montrachet)
review: Packed with mature fruit, this is a ripe wine from one of the top premier cru vineyards in Puligny-Montrachet. It has a delicious, full and creamy texture that's cut with lemony acidity. Toast from oak aging is still present and will soften as the wine ages further. With its mineral aftertaste, it will need time. Drink from 2021.

Now almost mature, this richly textured wine is powered by dark tannins that sit comfortably with the black plum and berry fruits. The majority Merlot in the blend gives the wine weight and ripeness that are happily balanced by final juicy acidity. Drink from 2021.

wine: Thirsty Owl Wine Company 2015 Pinot Noir (Finger Lakes)
appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
review: Lavish violet perfume introduces this demure yet luminous Pinot Noir. Crisp black cherry and berry flavors are full of tartness and vibe, yet edged by soft tones of toast and earth, along with a fine frame of tannins. The finish meanders beautifully. It's ready to drink now but should continue to drink well until at least 2023.

wine: Jean Becker 2012 Froehn Grand Cru Riesling (Alsace)
review: A steely, crisp and mineral Riesling from the Froehn vineyard in Zellenberg. Great potential awaits in its tight aromatic fruits and zesty acidity. It offers structure, flavors of citrus and white currants from the organic grapes and a texture that demands aging. Drink from 2017.

wine: Chapel Hill 2014 The Parson Shiraz (McLaren Vale)
review: Blackberry (or perhaps mulberry) leads the way in this plush wine. Hints of black licorice and cracked pepper add nuance to the palate, while the finish is warm and supple.

Underbrush, moist earth, toasted nut and a whiff of violet form the nose. Light bodied and linear, the palate offers cranberry, Marasca cherry and star anise alongside bright acidity and dusty, not very persistent tannins.

wine: Hugl-Wimmer 2019 Gemischter Satz by Martin White (Niederösterreich)
review: Lemon and lemon balm send aromatic freshness from the glass. The palate also shimmers with green notes reminiscent of moss, boxwood and blossom, all surrounded by lightness, slight spritz and lemony freshness. This is easy but oh so fresh and makes a cracking, light summer wine.

Unusually lush, even for this vintage, it starts with pronounced aromas of limes and lemons, fresh green apples, and juniper berries, and turns luscious in the mouth. Partial barrel fermentation and lees aging create a creamy, smoky mouthfeel, while the fruity flavors are volcanic. But it's dry and elegant. Virtually flawness Sauvignon Blanc.

wine: Domaine Santa Duc 2019 Les Quatres Terres Red (Côtes du Rhône)
appellation: Côtes du Rhône, Rhône Valley, France
review: This wine incorporates grapes from the elite Cru appellations of Vacqueyras and Rasteau as well as Côtes-du-Rhône Villages sites in Roaix and Séguret. A piercing blackberry and bramble-scented blend of Grenache and Syrah sourced from limestone soils, it's an approachably fruity introduction to Santa Duc's majestic (and more expensive wines) but maintains a trademark vitality and finesse. Highlighting juicy cassis and plum flavors along with a zippy mineral finish, it's a delicately tannic red that should drink well through 2026.

appellation: Dundee Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: A difficult wine to analyze, this at first seems dilute. With ample breathing, it fills in and spreads out, showing mineral notes and raspberry and pomegranate fruit. The astringent, tongue-drying finish calls for pairing with a hearty, meaty entrée.

Still very firm and dry, this is a structured wood-aged wine with a good aging potential. As it opens up, juicy black plum flavors show strongly alongside the dark tannins and perfumed acidity. It's a powerful, dense wine that needs to age. Drink from 2017.

Black fruit aromas dominate the dark nose and carry to the tightly packed palate. Flavors of spiced berries and toast are the main focus for this blend of Monastrell and Cabernet, enjoyable for those who seek out riper, oaked offerings.

Tough and gritty, with hard tannins, this is definitely astringent and dry, but it does show classic Napa character. Blended with Cabernet Franc and Merlot, it's rich in blackberry, black cherry, currant and dark chocolate flavors that finish long. It would be a mistake to drink this wine too young. Cellar it until 2018, and it should provide mature beauty well beyond.

wine: Caruso & Minini 2006 Terre di Giumara Syrah (Sicilia)
review: Here's a Syrah with bursting aromas of mature blueberry, cherry, spice and smoked bacon. The wine is full, round and generous with a supple feel and soft concentration. Pair it with lamb or roasted pork.

wine: Lynmar 2012 Quail Hill Vineyard Block 10 Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)
appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: Block 10 was made with 25% whole cluster fermentation, the result bold and impressive in cola cherry and soft baking spices, an intriguing floral note akin to geranium or gardenia highlighting the palate. Midway, expect an expansive opening of the wine, before notes of cocoa and espresso delve in.

wine: Viña Arnáiz 2010 Gran Reserva  (Ribera del Duero)
appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
review: While this isn't terrible, for a gran reserva from a vaunted vintage it leaves much to be desired. A stalky nose is briary at best and mulchy at worst. A tannic, raw and rubbing palate deals herbal berry and oak flavors, while the finish is woody and not fruity.

wine: Emmerich Knoll 2006 Ried Kreutles Smaragd Grüner Veltliner (Wachau)
review: A rich wine, touched by tropical fruit, pepper and light acidity. Although there is crispness, this wine is more about roundness, allied with weight, but finishing with fresh spiced pear flavors.

wine: Chateau Lafayette Reneau 2013 Proprietor's Reserve Barrel Fermented Chardonnay (Finger Lakes)
appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
review: Orange blossom and acacia perfume this very pretty, spry wine. Tart green apple and pear flavors are straightforward yet refreshing on the palate, finishing briskly on a zesty lemon-lime note.

wine: Château de Gaudou NV Gaudou Exception Brut Malbec (Vin Mousseux)
review: A Blanc de Noirs from Malbec, this aromatic wine has just a hint of tannins from the grape skins along with attractive acidity. It's a surprisingly fresh and fruity wine in the context of Malbec. Drink now.

wine: Jaume Serra 2015 Brut Nature Reserva Método Tradicional Sparkling (Cava)
review: White fruit and pineapple aromas are a touch briny. On the palate, this is round and pulpy without much bubble action or scour. Dry, salty lemon-lime flavors finish well. Known for its value Cristalino label, this is a step up for Jaume Serra.

appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: Tastes unevenly ripened, with blackberry and vegetal flavors side by side, and seems to have residual sugar. The sweetness is compounded with high alcohol.

This is a wine that feels old-fashioned but still not ready to drink. It smells nutty and dusty, with black pepper and anise accents. Its plum fruit core is wound very tightly, and encased in a fair amount of good-quality oak. Tannins are thick and wooly, so much so that I'd forget that I even had this in the cellar until Bush is out of office, then drink through 2014 or so. Imported by Broadbent Selections, Inc.

There's a pleasing depth to the aromas of brandy-soaked cherry, allspice and tobacco on the nose. It's rounded in feel, with soft tannins and juicy fruit flavors that show a delicate accent of warm spices.

Starts with dusty cherry, plum and green herb aromas before turning more smoky and saucy. Warm and solid, with flavors of plum, vanilla and spice. Well constructed and balanced, if not overly exciting. Imported by Quality Wines of Spain.

This is a dark, dense and brooding Bordeaux-style blend, comprised of 57% Cabernet Sauvignon, 28% Merlot, 5% Petit Verdot, 5% Malbec and 5% Cabernet Franc. Notes of cocoa, cigar tobacco and leather jazz up the black-fruit core of cassis, black plum and berry. The palate is full and gripping, with firm tannins that hang on tightly through the long and slightly smoky finish. Drink after decanting now, or enjoy through 2018.

wine: Château de Santenay 2015 Les Brunettes et Planchots  (Aloxe-Corton)
review: Vines at the base of the famed Corton grand cru hill produce this rich attractively fruity wine. Bold and with warm tannins and light wood-aging flavors, the wine is generous and full of red-berry fruits. It also has a more serious side as witnessed by the tannins. Drink from 2019.

wine: Quinta Vale Dona Maria 2013 Late Bottled Vintage  (Port)
review: Bottled unfiltered, this wine has definite aging potential. It is perfumed and structured with ripe tannins as well as red fruits. It is a dry style of Port, bringing out fruit as well as structure and acidity. The tannins will allow the wine to age. Drink now, but better from 2021.

A very perfumed wine, almost heady, with its herbal and wild flower aromas. The wine is still closed up, darkly tannic and very firm. At the same time, black fruits show the same perfumed character. This is very flavorful and structured. Drink this unusual wine from 2014.
Tight and herbaceous, this is a very Sauvignon-oriented wine. It has the classic, intensely grassy feel, a tangy lemon texture and green acidity. It is very intense and concentrated.

There's a strong chemical and plastic aroma on the nose of this wine, which eventually blows off to reveal more classic Pecorino aromas of chamomile and melon. It has a waxy texture that carries rich fruit and floral flavors, with proper acidity to match.

Black cherry, chocolate and menthol accents color the nose of this ripe and plump Barbera d'Alba. The wine is firm and generous in the mouth with a chewy, slightly sweet finish. It sees one year of oak for extra spice on the close.

Packaged in an extremely heavy bottle, this offers subtle aromas of banana, pineapple, wild herb and a whiff of toast. The aromas follow over to the rounded palate along with a hint of bitter almond while a saline note marks the finish.

A burnished gold color and rich honeyed aromas open this dessert Torontel with Old World shadings. A balanced palate suggests lateharvest Pinot Gris from Alsace, while flavors of honey, caramel and toffee finish with a pecan note. Drink through 2028.

wine: Bodegas Escorihuela 2003 High Altitude Cabernet Sauvignon-Malbec (Agrelo)
review: Purple in color, with potent berry aromas. The blend is 65% in favor of Malbec, and the wine boasts black raspberry and plum flavors. Finishes hefty and warm, with notes of cola.

wine: Martin Ranch 2018 Therese Vineyards Grenache Blanc (Arroyo Seco)
appellation: Arroyo Seco, Central Coast, California, US
review: A bright splash of lemon and crisp pear flesh kick off the nose on this fresh bottling. There's a hit of wax at the tip of the sip, which then offers zesty citrus flavors and plenty of palate-cleansing acidity.

wine: Viña Andrico 2014 Gran Reserva Malbec (Uco Valley)
review: A pitch-black color and ripe aromas of cassis, raisin, vanilla and cocoa set up a lush palate that's made less jammy by tartaric acidity. Vanilla, mocha and blackberry flavors finish with more of the same before settling on prune, cassis and creamy oak.

wine: Kirkland Signature 2007 Grandmère Old Vine Zinfandel (Amador County)
appellation: Amador County, Sierra Foothills, California, US
review: A bit overripe and hot in alcohol. That's the price of getting such rich fruit flavors. Dark chocolate, blackberry preserves, red currants, black raspberries and spicy satsuma flood the mouth, leading to a super-spicy finish.

wine: Varner 2001 Home Vineyard Chardonnay (Santa Cruz Mountains)
appellation: Santa Cruz Mountains, Central Coast, California, US
review: Oakier, leesier and riper than Varner's two other Chards, but not superior, because the wine loses balance. Charry, smoky oak dominates the fruit from entry to finish.

Austrians Paul and Anna Kretzel co-own this winery with the Stephan family from Germany. The best fruit from their 600-ton production launches a fleet of proprietary wines. This flagship white is barrel- fermented in French oak, which produces a strong whiff of buttered wheat toast at the start. The flavors of dried pineapple, sweet basil and white pepper are supported by good acidity. Try this with a summery fruit salad.

wine: Aresti 2009 Estate Selection Sauvignon Blanc (Curicó Valley)
review: Tropical on the nose, with aromas of pineapple, mango and lychee. The palate is plump and highly regular, and the flavors of green banana and pithy orange and citrus are not much to ponder. Perfectly drinkable if well chilled, but it's not bringing a lot to the table.

wine: Viña Cobos 2015 Bramare Marchiori Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Perdriel)
review: Ultraripe aromas of raisin, oud wood and musky men's cologne are attractive and complex for a young Cabernet that's putting out at max level in terms of lushness and extraction. Deep oaky blackberry and chocolate flavors hold onto a café-mocha note on a full finish. Drink through 2024.
Primary black-cherry and berry aromas abound in this approachably fruit-forward wine. Appreciate this uncomplicated but juicy sip for its buoyant fruit character.

Initial notes of dried herbs and earth freshen with aeration, exposing pristine notes of apricot and pear. The palate is silky and supple, anchored by a grip of grapefruit pith on the finish. This rich, voluminous wine is ready now but should hold through 2021.
Oak dominates this wine, giving it toast and vanilla caramel aromas and flavors. The underlying wine is soft and fruity, with blackberries and cherries. Drink now. Production was 24,146 cases.

Soapy, floral aromas are more like those of a scented candle than most Malbecs. Next is an astringent, raw palate with sketchy plum flavors and bitterness to the finish. This doesn't taste convincingly natural.

This Romanian white blend is straw colored with aromas of hickory smoke, lemon and grapefruit zest. The well balanced palate offers flavors of grapefruit and lemon zest before the crisp, clean finish.
A very sweet style, with flavors of Hershey bars, figs, vanilla and caramel. Rather out of balance.

Always rock-solid and fairly priced, Geyser Peak's Cab this year is well-structured and firm, with sturdy tannins and bright acidity. It will need a year or so for the blackcurrant and plum flavors to emerge. There's a rich earthy streak that makes this a fine companion with food.

wine: Matuba 2006 Premium Select Sauvignon Blanc (Western Cape)
review: Soft and subtle tropical fruit aromas are anchored by some spice on the nose of this pleasing but straightforward wine from Matuba. There's pineapple, lemon and grapefruit on the palate, and the finish is clean and refreshing. Imported by American Wine Distributors, Inc.

wine: Quinta do Carneiro 2008 Pactus Touriga Nacional (Lisboa)
review: Earthy wine that has rich, chewy fruit, its tannins a serious element. There is weight as well, the wine ripe, full, with juicy plum flavors.

wine: Pievalta 2017  Verdicchio dei Castelli di Jesi Classico Superiore
appellation: Verdicchio dei Castelli di Jesi Classico Superiore, Central Italy, Italy
review: Made with grapes grown according to the principles of biodynamic farming, this fragrant white opens with heady scents of yellow flower, tropical fruit and a whiff of acacia honey. Round and savory, the polished, delicious palate delivers ripe yellow peach, citrus, almond and white almond.

wine: Mahoney 2009 Las Brisas Vineyard Pinot Noir (Carneros)
review: A tight, dry and somewhat one-dimensional Pinot Noir. It offers cherry, cola and spice flavors, and is elegantly structured. Grows more interesting as it warms in the glass, but it's ready for drinking now.

wine: Doudet Naudin NV Brut  (Crémant de Bourgogne)
review: A refreshing, crisp blend of Chardonnay, Pinot Noir and bright, tight Aligoté, this wine is light and fruity. Bursting with apple flavor, it is ready to drink now.

Anise, blackberry, black pepper and savory spice aromas lead this ripe red from Pavlidis. The palate is laced with a vanilla note, and the red berry flavors are rich and easy to like. With its good spice and complex fruit, this should pair well with grilled meats and tomato pastas.

wine: Tenuta Cavalier Pepe 2016 Bianco di Bellona Coda di Volpe (Irpinia)
review: Linear and bright, this has delicate aromas of pineapple and yellow stone fruit that follow over to the palate. Fresh acidity gives it a clean finish.

Failla's 2011 Syrah is strikingly brisk with acidity, but has a tannic smoothness that makes it velvety in the mouth. Complex flavors of blackberry, blueberry, roasted meat, mushroom, black pepper, balsam and cedar are layered and bright. It's harder and leaner in style than Failla's best vintages, but nonetheless elegant. Drink now–2014.

appellation: Arroyo Seco, Central Coast, California, US
review: Opulent aromas of ripe pear, gardenia, apple and coconut show on the nose of this bottling. It's racy with acidity on the sip, where a tart lemon flavor leads into apple blossom, poached pear and pineapple, with a slight butter tone on the finish.

appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: Strawberry and cherry fruit combines here with a pie-filling consistency. A mix of grapes from six different vineyards, it comes into focus as a seamless and complete fruit-forward wine. Tannins are moderate but provide enough back-end texture to boost the overall power.

A fairly dark shade of rusty gold in the glass, this bottling starts with aromas of toasted nuts and baked bread. The palate comes across more fresh, showing tangy lemon rind, unsweetened iced tea and more nutty qualities.

appellation: Sierra Foothills, Sierra Foothills, California, US
review: Soft in the mouth, with a somewhat simple structure, this Syrah's main virtue is flavor. It's enormously rich in ripe blackberry- and cherry-pie filling, cola, licorice, mint, chocolate, bacon and pepper flavors, and is fully dry.

Simple peach and melon aromas are chunky. Strong acidity cuts through an otherwise plump and melony palate. Short, basic green melon and white pepper flavors lose fruit but not their appeal on the finish.

wine: Nicholas Cole Cellars 2005 Michele Red Wine Red (Walla Walla Valley (WA))
appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Very ripe flavors of berries and figs dominate this Cab-centric Bordeaux blend, along with intriguing side notes suggesting melon and cassis, smoke and mocha. It's a big, sexy wine, its fruit flavors backed with thick, ripe, but chalky tannins. If there is a downside, it is that it comes off as a bit monolithic.

appellation: Mendocino County, Mendocino County, California, US
review: Bold aromas and generous but sophisticated flavors shape a rich tasting experience in this full-bodied, buttery wine. Aromas resemble nutmeg and ripe pear, while the flavors are like lively green apple. The texture is both smooth and crisp at the same time, and the long finish denotes quality.

wine: Good Earth Wine 2008 Concerto Collection Basso Reserve Cabernet Sauvignon (Nashik)
review: Charred wood and smoke dominate the nose and palate of this Indian Cab, smoldering over a core of plush black fruit that hides within. It's a pleasantly textured wine with soft, fine-grained tannins, but overwhelmed by smoke and a stalky, green finish.

wine: Lanciola 2009 Le Masse di Greve Riserva  (Chianti Classico)
review: This wine opens with slightly rustic, leafy aromas that blow off in the glass to reveal mature black fruit and spice. The soft palate offers up ripe black cherry, blackberry and cinnamon. It's round and ready so enjoy soon.

appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: This is the last of Amity's '99s to be released; no '99 reserve was made because the juice went into three single-vineyard releases. With the extra time the wine has smoothed out a bit, but it is still tight and reticent upon first being opened. Good structure, some spicy highlights, and a concentrated, tarry finish.

Aromas that recall underbrush, oak, espresso, truffle and mocha unfold on this bracing red. The firm palate offers dried dark berry, sawdust, espresso, anise and ground pepper alongside assertive tannins.

A blend of Sangiovese, Cabernet Sauvignon and Merlot, this is a compelling and exciting expression of territory. The Tassinaia hill produces a balanced wine with black fruit and some herbal notes backed by spice, toast and a long satisfying finish.

wine: Prinz Salm 2012 Scharlachberg Bingen Trocken GG Riesling (Rheinhessen)
review: Smoke tones blow off revealing layers of tropical fruit encased in wax and lanolin on this bold, nuanced wine. It's dry in style with a luscious, creamy texture cut with shards of acid and lime-zest astringency. Finishes long and lean.

The light cherry aromas and flavors with herb accents show a slight candied quality. Decent structure, but overall the wine is a bit narrow and closes with sharp, quite tart cherry fruit. It's youthful, for sure, and perhaps will even out with six to nine months in the bottle.

Purple as they come, with extracted aromas of boysenberry, blackberry, maple and bacon. It's a wide, flush wine with bulk, 14.5% alcohol and savage flavors of blackberry and smoky BBQ. Definitely for fans of big, modern Spanish wines; Old World enthusiasts will probably call it “too modern” and overdone.

wine: Feudi di San Gregorio 2005  Fiano di Avellino
appellation: Fiano di Avellino, Southern Italy, Italy
review: Peach, cantaloupe, pear and a touch of citric zest characterize this expertly made white wine from southern Italy. Beyond the fruit aromas, you'll also pick up notes of white flower and mineral-flint that add dimension and complexity. Drink it well-chilled with seafood or white meat.

wine: Trapiche 2011 Terroir Series Orellana Single Vineyard Malbec (La Consulta)
review: Smoky blackberry aromas hint at raw charcoal and hickory. A deep, lush mouthfeel is mildly tannic, while toasty flavors of chocolate, herbs and menthol brush shoulders with blackberry and spice. This is big, deep, fruity and oaky on the finish. More time will only help it out; drink from 2016–2023.

wine: Bodegas Bilbainas 2010 Viña Pomal Gran Reserva  (Rioja)
review: Balsamic berry aromas are heady and include tones of tobacco, cigar box and maple. This gran reserva from a fabulous vintage is solid and chewy, with ripe tannins that are firm but not too harsh. Baked berry flavors are augmented by chocolate and spice notes. It's dense and chewy on the finish, with just enough acidity to ensure balance and longevity. Drink through 2035.

wine: Yalumba 2012 The Octavius Old Vine Shiraz (Barossa)
review: Named for the special format of small oak barrel it's aged in, this has soaked up the oak impressively. Hints of vanilla and graham crackers accent mixed berry fruit, while the finish is long and mouthwatering. There's ample concentration, yet the wine never seems heavy. Drinkable now, but why rush things? Drink 2020–2030.

This 50/50 blend brings a bowl full of sweet cherry fruit to the nose; it's hard to resist after the first sniff. There's plenty of glycerin and a lushness to the mouthfeel, and the fruit flavors pile on sweet streaks of cherry, plum and raisin. Much of the pleasure is right up front, and the wine turns a bit stiff and stemmy as it heads down the back stretch.

Graves-like aromas of earth and tobacco laced with cassis are an instant hit; even the palate is Bordeaux-like, featuring a lean, chalky mouthfeel and drying tannins that demand cellaring. Age it one or two years and drink it over the next 3–5.

wine: Anselmo Vineyards 2007 St. Pé de Bigorre Blanc White (California)
review: This blend of Gewürztraminer and Sauvignon Blanc is sweet and sour, like sugary cough lozenges, with pineapple and other citrus flavors.

wine: Dutton Estate 2004 Jewell Block Vineyard Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)
appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: You'd never expect such nice flavor from such a lightly colored wine. Nonetheless, this single-vineyard Pinot is fresh and dry in rosehip tea, strawberry and cinnamon spice, with a bracing coat of toasty oak. It's not a blockbuster, but defines elegance.
Smells and tastes like a combination of sun-warmed stones and white peaches. It's round and ripe, showing just a touch of alcoholic warmth on the finish. Imported by Grape Expectations (CA).

This wine displays ample concentration in its inky color and potent aromas of dark berry fruit. There's a hint of raisining as well. In the mouth, it's mouthfilling but lacks a bit of texture; the flavors include dark plums, vanilla and hints of dried fruits, like figs and dates. With a finish that calls to mind chocolate fudge (minus the sugar), opt for drinking this wine over the relatively near term, now to 2020.

wine: SignoSeis 2014 The Angel Oak Reserva Malbec (Uco Valley)
