review: Intensity and purity of fruit are virtues on an otherwise smoky nose with full ripeness. This wine is strong on the palate, with enlivening acidity. Peppery, chocolaty berry and cassis flavors finish dark, toasty and spicy, with some heat. Drink this bold Malbec through 2026.

Red berry, underbrush, baking spice and leather aromas lead the nose. This is pretty straightforward by Barolo standards, offering morello cherry and light cinnamon flavors framed in firm tannins. Drink 2019–2025.

This dark-hued blend of Syrah and Grenache shows ample length and suppleness to go along with aromas of fresh herbs, black cherries, espresso and black olives. It'd be a fine casual pairing for burgers or pizza.

Earthy, gritty berry aromas announce a jammy palate with modest acidic bounce. Following the nose, this Malbec tastes earthy, jammy and a touch herbal. A lively finish with solid fruit flavors and juicy acidity provides for a nice close.

appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: This lively wine has an electricity about it, with lip-smackingly delicious and crisp green apples. It's blended from McMinnville and Van Duzer Corridor grapes, with highlights of fresh green herbs and a finishing lick of buttery caramel.

wine: Wine by Joe 2015 Pinot Blanc (Willamette Valley)
appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: Almost indistinguishable from an all-stainless Chardonnay, this nonetheless offers fine value and clean crisp flavors. The basics of simple white wine are here—green apple and tart lemon, served up fresh and immediately drinkable.

wine: Domaine Clavel 2018 Clair de Lune Saint Gervais White (Côtes du Rhône Villages)
appellation: Côtes du Rhône Villages, Rhône Valley, France
review: In this wine hints of anise and marshmallow lend a sweet, spicy tone to zesty pear and quince aromas. A juicy, full-bodied white, it boasts concentrated yellow-apple flavor and fresh grapefruit acidity, with a lingering apple finish. Enjoy this easy-drinking but elegant wine now through 2023.

This is a very interesting and ultimately very likeable Soave with ripe aromas of banana, pineapple and loads of almond marzipan. The wine is light and short on the palate but those aromatic aftertastes stay etched in your memory.

appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: At first this wine seems quite astringent, closed and tight. It shows dark streaks of cassis and dried leaf, and it only reluctantly opens up to expand the black fruit flavor with a wash of Bourbon barrel.

Touches of toast from the wood aging give a spicy character. The toast brings out acidity at this stage rather than sweetness, with lemon and lime flavors dominant over the honey and botrytis in the background. Drink from 2018.

wine: Cooperativa Agricola de Santo Isidro de Pegoes 2012 Adega de Pegões Aragonez (Península de Setúbal)
winery: Cooperativa Agricola de Santo Isidro de Pegoes
review: Aragonez, or Tempranillo, is grown more widely in Alentejo than in Setúbal where this wine comes from. The move gives the wine a softer character, with fresh blackberry acidity and a smooth, ripe fruitiness. It has some gentle tannins to balance the fruit. Drink now.

wine: Wellington 2003 100 Year Old Vines Zinfandel (Sonoma Valley)
review: Fully dry, at the cost of 15.8% alcohol, this enormous Zin wears its size well. There's a Port-like, raisiny note, but it's more of a subtle seasoning than a takeover, and the wine is balanced in its own distinctively Zinny way.

appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: The aromas bring appealing notes of fig, herb and whole lemon. Sleek, tart, citrus and tropical fruit flavors follow. It's tasty.

appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: Exceptionally concentrated, unctuous and oily, this reveals the floral/spicy character of the grape in all its glory. It's a complex wine that just keeps on going, with jasmine, lemon polish, citrus and more fleshing out the flavors. The moderate alcohol and dry style keep it perfect for a range of foods, especially smoked salmon or spicy Thai.

wine: Roar 2019 Soberanes Vineyard Chardonnay (Santa Lucia Highlands)
appellation: Santa Lucia Highlands, Central Coast, California, US
review: Very clean and suave aromas of chalk, lemon balm, lychee and a hint of salted nuts show on the nose of this bottling. The palate is a showcase of restrained opulence, offering peach and apricot flavors that are encapsulated in a chalky texture, all blasted by focused, driven notes of citrus zest.

wine: Bruno Paillard 2004 Blanc de Blancs Brut Chardonnay (Champagne)
review: This mature wine shows its toasty side. A mineral texture is now integrated with the almond, yeast and bread flavors to give a wine that's crisp while no longer bringing out its fruit. This wine is elegant with poise and great style. Drink now.

wine: Rockpile Winery 2018 Rockpile Ridge Vineyard Zinfandel (Rockpile)
review: This estate wine is among the last picked by the producer due to the high-elevation vineyard. It tastes of blackberry, cherry, nutmeg and cola, with underlying notes of dried herb and crushed rock. The texture is velvety, with a lasting chewiness.
Rose petal, raspberry and Mediterranean brush aromas mingle together in the glass. On the tangy palate, brisk acidity accompanies pomegranate, strawberry and a note of botanical herbs.
Simple and watery, it has oaky flavors of citrus fruits and peaches. There's not much going on, but it is dry and crisp in acidity.

Obvious wood aging gives this wine a smoky character. At the same time, black-currant fruits are developing and promising a richly textured wine in the future. The wine, under the same winemaking team as Château Smith Haut Lafitte, is likely to be ready from 2024.

wine: Peter Nicolay 2009 Bernkasteler Badstube Kabinett Riesling (Mosel)
review: Nicely balanced and nicely priced, this is a medium-bodied kabinett that would make delicious summertime drinking. It shows hints of wet stone, but also layers of sweet apple, pear and lemon fruit, which ease into a long, harmoniously crisp and clean finish.
Very forward in jammy fruit, with waves of blackberries, cherries, raspberries, red currants, mocha and caramelized new oak. Feels too soft and melted to do much in the cellar, so drink up.

Mature dark-skinned berry, sunbaked earth and pressed blue flower aromas come together on this charming red. The easy-drinking palate doles out ripe black cherry, raspberry and clove while supple tannins provide the relaxed framework.

Despite some grit and tar on the nose, this Rioja opens well with spicy cherry and plum aromas. A standard, mild palate is satisfactory, while lightly roasted slightly briny plum and berry flavors end with a hint of saltiness.
This coastal Tuscan Vermentino delivers aromas of citrus, peach and white flower that give the wine a bright and beautiful bouquet. Touches of sweet honey and almond appear on the close.

wine: Domaine Poulleau Père et Fils 2012 Les Mondes Rondes  (Côte de Beaune)
review: Côte de Beaune is a small strip of land at the south end of the Beaune vineyards, not often seen as a stand-alone appellation. This gently structured wine is full of fresh fruits and attractive acidity. With its dry core, it could develop but is drinkable now.

wine: Dr. Loosen 2003 Ürziger Würzgarten Spätlese Riesling (Mosel-Saar-Ruwer)
review: Starts with some lime and grapefruity notes, but seems to get softer as it moves toward the finish, ending with ripe flavors of apples, pears and even some stone fruit. Light in body, a tough trick in this sunbaked vintage. Imported by Loosen Bros. USA.

wine: Paradise Ridge 2003 Hoenselaars Vineyard Zinfandel (Russian River Valley)
appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: Too soft and syrupy for my tastes, with a viscous texture framing blackberry and coffee flavors. Just lacks life and zest.

appellation: Lake County, Lake County, California, US
review: This is a vineyard selection from the winery's estate, and it's a nicely drinkable Sauvignon Blanc, showing how well the variety does in Lake County. Fresh and juicy, the pineapple and fig flavors finish with a honeyed richness.
87–89. Barrel Sample. Tight and tannic, this is a weighty and concentrated wine. Its rich berry fruits are integrated with the structure already, supplying fine fruitiness and crisp acidity.

wine: Cristom 2018 Marjorie vineyard Pinot Noir (Eola-Amity Hills)
appellation: Eola-Amity Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: Sourced from the estate's oldest vines, this lovely wine is a complex mix of red and blue berries, with pretty highlights of chocolate and mocha from aging 17 months in two-thirds new French oak. Though not labeled as a reserve, it brings an extra dollop of detail and depth.

wine: Achaia Clauss NV Demestica White White (Greece)
review: This blend of Savatiano and Roditis is very popular in Greece and perhaps a bit too exotic for mainstream palates, but it's easy drinking and priced well. Aromas of citrus and melon are followed by peach and honeydew melon flavors. Simple but friendly.

Ethereally light in texture, this intriguing Auslese calibrates pristine tangerine and peach flavors against savory notes of pollen and earth. It's spry and spine-tingling, with a long, floral finish. It drinks well now, but should meld and improve from 2021–2030.

appellation: Nevada County, Sierra Foothills, California, US
review: From the Sierra Foothills, it shows pretty citrus and tropical fruit aromas. Very fruity, with a strong chocolate note, which California Viognier often has.

wine: Januik 2012 Champoux Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Horse Heaven Hills)
appellation: Horse Heaven Hills, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Almost all varietal (with 2% Malbec) from one of the state's premier sites, this wine draws you into the glass with aromas of coffee, scorched earth, herb, spice and dark fruit. The palate shows a beguiling sense of restraint and detail, with the tannins combed to a fine sheen, perfectly framed acidity and a lengthy finish. It's an exquisite example of the variety that should have a long life ahead of it. It will be best after 2020.

A bouquet of baked apples, pear and burnt brown sugar kicks it off. Next comes a soft palate of pineapple, papaya and lemon, and then a finish of apples and white pepper. Lovely flavors and plenty of depth push it forward. However, the bead is so light that the wine goes flat in the glass.

The bouquet is a bit oily and heavy as it dishes primary orange aromas and also cured ham notes. The palate is bulky and a touch oily in feel, with flat-edged papaya and melon flavors that dry out on a chunky finish.

appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
review: One of the better Roussannes out there, this is dry with balanced acidity, showing a creamy mouthfeel, plus complex citrus, butterscotch, mineral and spice flavors. It has many food-pairing possibilities.

wine: Casa da Passarella 2012 O Oenólgo Encruzado (Dão)
review: A ripe and fruity wine that boasts yellow fruits and fresh citrus characteristics. It's lush and ripe, with just a touch of minerality to give the wine structure. There's a delicious tangy aftertaste to this full, impressive wine.

wine: St. Francis 2010 Petite Sirah (Dry Creek Valley)
appellation: Dry Creek Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: This is great Petite Sirah, and classically Dry Creek Valley in style. It has the weight and texture of a fine Cabernet, with gorgeously smooth tannins, but it's the flavors that really make you reach for another glass. Offers blackberries, black currants, bacon, charred meat bone, pepper and anise flavors that go on and on into a long finish. Will age for a long time, but you can drink it at any point in its journey.

Shows off some of Scheurebe's exotic personality, delivering banana notes alongside pink grapefruit and dried apricot aromas and flavors. It's oily in texture and very sweet, but balanced by those grapefruity acids. Drink young for the flamboyance of the grape variety.

appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: Fresh boysenberry aromas are cut by peppery spices, roasted coffee and lavender on the dynamic nose of this bottling. The palate begins softly with a wide array of floral flavors, from wisteria to elderflower, and then settles into fine-grained tannins toward the finish.

wine: Browne Family Vineyards 2017 Skull & Chain Cabernet Sauvignon (Red Mountain)
appellation: Red Mountain, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Fresh green herb aromas are out front along with satsuma notes. The flavors are light and direct. Decant for best effect.

A barrel-fermented Chardonnay with creamy texture, this opens with bright, prominent Meyer lemon notes before delving into softer flavors of pear and vanilla on the midpalate. The acidity holds through to the finish, accented by a touch of honey.

wine: Fenestra NV True Red Lot 26 Red (California)
review: This is an easy-drinking blend of many red varieties from a Livermore-based producer who loves both Rhône and Portuguese reds. This is soft and lightly spiced, with cola and cherry notes on the finish. A very good wine for a barbecue or a tailgate.

wine: Casa da Passarella 2013 Colheita Branco White (Dão)
review: This intensely fruity wine is full of crisp acidity, lemon and lime flavors and a tangy, tight, steely texture. The wine is mineral and structured, while remaining fresh and attractively juicy. It's tempting to drink it now because of the freshness, but better wait until 2016.

wine: Delta Vineyard 2005 Hatter's Hill Pinot Noir (Marlborough)
review: This is a full-bodied, supple rendition of Marlborough Pinot Noir, boasting smoky, slightly herbal-peppery scents and bold cherry and plum fruit. There's a suggestion of sassafras or cola as well, which gives this wine an almost Californian flavor. Long and velvety on the finish.
Smoke and toast aromas are accented by butter and spicy vanilla notes. Full and round, it's a big yet graceful Chardonnay, reminiscent of the ballerina hippo in Disney's Fantasia.

Predominantly Sauvignon Blanc, and you get those varietal grassy, citric aromas and flavors as the main package. Chardonnay and Viognier at 15% each add roundness and riper flavors, particularly peach and apple. And it's minimally oak-aged, which adds to the mouthfeel. An interesting Chilean blend.

wine: Ashan 2018 Conner Lee Vineyard Chardonnay (Columbia Valley (WA))
appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Barrel fermented and aged in 100% new French oak, this Chardonnay offers aromas of toast, lees, apple and spice leading to sweet-seeming, center-focused, creamy flavors. The lees influence is primary at present. It runs hot on the finish.

This is a typical blend of Sauvignon Blanc and Sémillon, but one that has been produced by a family famed for its white wines. This is warm with yellow fruits as well as citrus, showing a rounded texture as well as herbal minerality. Drink this wine now.

appellation: Mendocino County, Mendocino County, California, US
review: Gets the job done with a burst of jammy Lifesaver aromas and flavors. Lightly structured. There are some less ripe, green, stalky flavors that lead to a tart finish in this dry wine.

appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: Light-to-medium-bodied, but hardly weak.  An elegant Pinot that amply reflects what people mean when they say “Russian River Pinot Noir.”  Cinnamon spice, brambly raspberry, and stylish sweet oak throughout.  An intriguing and impressive first-ever M-G Pinot from Olivet Lane and Home Vineyards.

Soft and smooth, this is a wine that is still developing its full potential. The fruit is subdued but should burst into richness in the next six months with apricot and spice flavors that show strongly.

wine: Bodega José Quattrocchi 2002 Nino Franco Torrontés (Mendoza)
review: The dark hue and thick, sweet aromas announce that, just like the label says, this wine was oaked. What emerges from the glass is a cloying honey and orange-laden confection. It's pretty aggressive stuff with too many odd and out of place flavors, i.e. creamed corn. Acceptable, but just. –M.S.

wine: Ego Bodegas 2017 Goru El Blanco White (Jumilla)
review: Floral aromas include whiffs of jasmine and peach blossom, scents you can attribute to the Moscatel in this blend that also includes Chardonnay. In the mouth, this is a touch oily in feel but also acidic. Flowery, tropical flavors of lychee and pineapple finish full and healthy.

wine: Antonopoulos 2003 Collection White Dry Table Wine White (Greece)
review: Shows some toasty, caramel-popcorm scents, but also pleasant enough peach, pineapple and lemon flavors. Finishes intensely citrusy, with mouthpuckering acids that scream for food.

wine: Viña San Esteban 2003 Reserva Shiraz (Aconcagua Valley)
review: Raisiny, with aromas of stewed fruit and sweet almond candy. Basic but blunted on the palate, with a dull feel and nonexistent tannins. Adequate on a good day; a bit weedy. Imported by Joseph Victori Wines.

wine: Clovis Point 2013 Vintner's Select Merlot (North Fork of Long Island)
appellation: North Fork of Long Island, Long Island, New York, US
review: A bit firmer and more powerful than the producer's regular bottling, the Vintner's Select boasts a core of black cherry and cassis accented by shades of bramble and forest floor. Rich, rounded and full bodied, it's balanced by a streak of cranberry acidity and lingering notes of anise.
Front-loaded with gooseberry and feline aromas and flavors, this Sauvignon Blanc will appeal to those who like those New Zealand-like notes. It also has richer flavors of Meyer lemons and limes.

This producer's nonvintage cuvée is just right. It is balanced, the ripe apple and pear flavors are laced with acidity and citrus are, giving minerality as well as structure from the 65% Pinot Noir in the blend. This Champagne is perfectly ready to drink.

appellation: Anderson Valley, Mendocino County, California, US
review: Distinct aromas of cola, cedar and Bing cherry, as well as flavors of mocha and blackcurrants, weave fascinating complexity into this supple, full-bodied wine. The texture feels broad and relaxed, while the acidity and tannins are moderate. A nice viscosity carries its plump appeal through the finish.

A mere suspicion of black cherry can be discerned on the nose of this Zweigelt-Pinot Noir blend. On the palate, ripe but tart cherry fruit is on full display, made precise by ample freshness. It conveys a touch of white pepper amid soft, pliable tannins, with an edge of crunchy freshness.

wine: Quinta Seara d'Ordens 2013 Reserva Vinhas Velhas Red (Douro)
review: This wine has tannins, a dense structure and concentration. Still firm, it offers wood-aging flavors as well as big black fruits. Drink this wine from 2018.

wine: Jeff Carrel 2017 Lilac Wine Red (Côtes du Roussillon Villages)
appellation: Côtes du Roussillon Villages, Languedoc-Roussillon, France
review: A blend of 45% Syrah, 30% Carignan and 25% Grenache, this young wine smells fresh and lovely, yet with ample richness and concentration thanks to waves of lush blackberry, cherry and boysenberry that are all hit by earthy, floral accents of violets and singed sage leaf. The palate is smooth and silky, with fine but spicy tannins and bright, juicy black-fruit flavors that carry through to the medium-length close.

This salmon-colored wine offers a bouquet of strawberry and white peach. Flavors of pomegranate, clementine, passion fruit and vanilla are set amid moderate tannins that afford rich mouthfeel before fading into a bright tangerine finish.

appellation: El Dorado, Sierra Foothills, California, US
review: This powerful, full-bodied and tannic wine shows mint, clove and cedar in the aroma and quite ripe fruity-spicy flavors resembling red vermouth.

Ripe and soft on the nose, this blend of Monastrell, Garnacha and Syrah is so easygoing that it lacks pop up front. Plump and fruity on the palate, this is low on structure and acidity. Jammy raspberry and strawberry flavors end in friendly fashion, but with low definition. Drink now.

wine: Domaine des Tilleuls 2011 Haute Sélection Sur Lie  (Muscadet Sèvre et Maine)
appellation: Muscadet Sèvre et Maine, Loire Valley, France
review: Taut, light and crisp, this Muscadet boasts fresh citrus flavor and apple-skin structure. There is a youthful, yeasty fell to the wine at this stage and it needs a few more months to settle together.

This is a benchmark rendition of Pinot Gris. The flavors are fruit driven, with lime, apple and pear notes combining on the smooth, relatively soft midpalate. This is a consistent wine, even with its production level of 100,000 cases.

wine: Beringer 2003 Alluvium Blanc Sauvignon Blanc-Semillon (Knights Valley)
review: Seems a bit overwrought, with too much oak framing too little fruit. But it's a pleasant, dry wine, with citrus and buttercream flavors and enough acidity for balance.

One of the most balanced and impressive Barolos from the hot 2011 vintage, this opens with alluring aromas of mature black cherry, tobacco and spice. The smooth, full-bodied palate abounds with ripe raspberry, juicy strawberry, chopped herb, clove and cinnamon alongside firm but polished tannins that give the wine a silky mouthfeel. Drink 2018–2031.
Specs of dusty mineral lend some depth to this honeyed, off-dry Riesling. The palate is straightforward but brisk, marked by pressed apple, pear and a tart lemon-lime finish. Drink now.

wine: Barber 2014 Mr Beast Topolos Vineyard Zinfandel (Sonoma Mountain)
review: This organically farmed field blend includes some Petite Sirah and Alicante Bouschet. It has soft acidity and a simple structure, the flavors a mix of red and black cherry and berry.

wine: Lynmar 1999 Reserve Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)
appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Amarone della Valpolicella Classico, Veneto, Italy
review: Chocolate chip cookie, Graham cracker, plum cake and cinnamon snaps are some of the offbeat aromas that emerge from this wonderful Amarone. You'll love the intensity and overall richness of this special wine.

wine: Notre Vin 2006 Cabernet Sauvignon Rosé (Howell Mountain)
review: A very rich blush wine made from the same Cabernet grapes that go into the winery's expensive dry table wine. It's silky and wonderfully crisp, with deep flavors of raspberries, rose petals and vanilla spice. Wonderful with mushroom risotto, or with little puff pastry appetizers.

wine: Quinta do Covão 2016 Reserva Touriga Nacional (Dão)
review: Vineyards located between 1,200 and 1,500 feet have given richly textured fruit and finely perfumed tannins. Fermented and then aged in new wood for 12 months, this is splendid, ripe, full of fruit and still worthy of aging. Drink from 2021.

wine: Domaine de la Soufrandise 2008 Clos Marie  (Pouilly-Fuissé)
review: The aromas are spicy, toasty,and on the palate the wine is fresher, with attractive crispness, giving bright apple skin flavors.

The notes of crushed yuzu leaf on the nose have a lifted intensity. The palate is the counterpart to these soaring aromatics with its lovely, concentrated depth. It shows an enduring lemon note alongside ripe Mirabelle plum. This has an enlivening, vivid energy that will evolve well.

wine: Cottonwood Canyon 2008 Estate Dessert Syrah (Santa Maria Valley)
appellation: Santa Maria Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: This dessert bottling kicks off with the boozy aromas of port, but also shows lively fresh fruit reminiscent of concentrated blackberry syrup with hints of cola spice. It hits the palate with undeniable sweetness, but then come strong sandalwood and cedar flavors and a rush of vanilla and clove. It is soft while penetrating, like a dagger under silk lace.

wine: Endrizzi 2011 Pian Castello Brut Metodo Classico Riserva Sparkling (Trento)
designation: Pian Castello Brut Metodo Classico Riserva
review: Made with Chardonnay and Pinot Nero, this offers subtle aromas of toasted nut, citrus and orchard fruit. The smooth palate offers mature yellow apple, lemon zest and bread crust alongside a fine perlage.

wine: Gadais Père et Fils 2013 Vieilles Vignes Sur Lie  (Muscadet Sèvre et Maine)
appellation: Muscadet Sèvre et Maine, Loire Valley, France
review: Still young, this wine promises great potential. It has a rich character, full of white fruits that are laced with orange zest and spice. Fresh and crisp while full in the mouth, it will be better in a few months. Drink from 2016.

Wild berry, crushed herb, new leather and truffle aromas emerge from the glass. The juicy, savory palate offers red cherry, crushed raspberry, licorice and a hint of grilled porcini framed in taut, polished tannins. Tangy acidity keeps it bright. It's already almost accessible but will age well for several years or more. Drink 2023–2028.

Dominated by rich Pinot Noir, this is still impressively youthful. It has a sense of power and concentration, with intense white fruit, yeast and just a hint of honey. It could age, but is ready to drink.

appellation: Umpqua Valley, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
review: This is a light, spritzy wine; it could almost qualify as frizzante. The light citrus flavors start out fine, then become rough and vegetal.

wine: Gagliole 2003 Pecchia Red (Colli della Toscana Centrale)
appellation: Colli della Toscana Centrale, Tuscany, Italy
review: Very tense and tight is the nose: It contains precise fruit, baking spice, toasted oak and mint. Wonderfully structured on the palate, which shows bright berry flavors and grainy, grabby tannins. Finishes on the chocolaty side, with length and power. A big boy for sure.

wine: Rui Roboredo Madeira 2018 Beyra Superior Red (Beira Interior)
review: This rich and powerful wine with its layers of black plum and berry fruits is showing the enriching effects of wood aging. Spice, solid tannins and the fruits are all there, coming together well. Drink this fine wine from 2023.

appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: Ponzi makes very little Riesling, which is a shame, because this is a big, full-bodied, leesy, mineral-soaked mouthful of fresh, zesty flavor. Whole cluster pressed, stainless steel fermentation, and 13% alcohol, it's a wine to gulp down by the glass. Pure pleasure.

appellation: Edna Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: Ripe and flavorful, in a direct sort of way, this Pinot offers a mouthful of cherry-pie filling, black raspberry, cola, pomegranate and spicy oak flavors. It's fully dry, with a nice, silky texture, and is best now.

wine: Château Bertinerie 2011 Grande Cuvée  (Blaye Côtes de Bordeaux)
appellation: Blaye Côtes de Bordeaux, Bordeaux, France
review: Attractive and smooth, this is a ripe, broad wine with its soft, juicy red berry fruits and supporting firm tannins. Balanced and fruity, it is ready to drink, finishing with a crisp texture of acidity.

One of the most exciting names in Barolo, with fruit from one of the most celebrated vineyard crus, this vintage of Cannubi Boschis is a real treasure. Cellar the wine 10 years or more to achieve balance between its firm tannins and bright acidity. The wine already shows incredibly complex aromas of wild berry fruit, truffle and cola and those tones will surely become more elegant with time.

wine: Raphael 2014 First Label Merlot (North Fork of Long Island)
appellation: North Fork of Long Island, Long Island, New York, US
review: Striking tones of roasted coffee, cocoa and toasty oak ride over a dense core of ripe dark cherry and plum. The palate is silken in feel, with a plush, round texture supported by grainy tannins and bright acidity. More oak shows in the flavors, yet it's integrated among bright cherry, dark currant and granite tones which lead to a lingering dark cocoa finish.

wine: Château Cantelaudette 2015 Grand Vin  (Graves de Vayres)
review: In this wine, dusty tannins are richly integrated into the mature fruits and acidity. Produced from selected parcels, the wine is concentrated, ripe and generous with black cherries and dark spice. Drink the wine now.

wine: Gruber Röschitz 2019 Ried Hundspoint Grüner Veltliner (Weinviertel)
review: Crushed yarrow and ripe lemon peel feature subtly on the nose. It is on the palate that the herbal hit strikes fully. There is more of that crushed yarrow, boxwood, white pepper and salty miso. The plate is slender and taut but packed with flavor. Lovely now, it's certain to evolve. Drink by 2030.
Despite 18 months in wood, the oak isn't that obvious. Instead, there's honey and pineapple, good richness for the Mâcon, and a long, crisp finish. Imported by Kermit Lynch.

Soft and rounded, this is touched by a note of vanilla that adds extra openness. With its apple and pear flavors, this is an attractive, fruity wine; it's very forward, but it shows a note of Chablis steel in the background.

wine: Ca'Maíöl 2018 Valtenesi Chiaretto Rosato (Riviera del Garda Bresciano)
appellation: Riviera del Garda Bresciano, Lombardy, Italy
review: Acacia, wild-berry and almond aromas carry on the bright palate along with sour cherry and orange zest. Crisp acidity gives it a tangy refreshing finish.

wine: Sagemoor 2018 Without Rehearsal Limited Release Sauvignon Blanc-Semillon (Columbia Valley (WA))
appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Made from 88% Sauvignon Blanc and 12% Semillon, this wine is a blend of old-vine fruit from Dionysus, Gamache and Bacchus Vineyards. The aromas charm in notes of fresh and dried herbs, flowers, nut oil and lemon pith. Full-bodied, mouthwatering flavors follow. A lingering finish caps it off.

Hints of honey and crushed dandelion appear tenderly on the nose. The palate then swishes in with intense sweetness, cut by wonderfully sharp freshness to leave a balanced, bright and pure body that is mouthwatering and elegant.

wine: Tishbi Estate 2000 Tishbi Vineyards Cabernet Sauvignon (Judean Hills)
review: Wild mushrooms, herbal, earthy aromas lead to green olives on the palate with black pepper, spice and tobacco, and ripe berries on the long finish.

wine: Le Salette 1999 La Marega  (Amarone della Valpolicella Classico)
appellation: Amarone della Valpolicella Classico, Veneto, Italy
review: Deep and full; a thoroughbred with firm tannins and ample acidity. The nose of cherries, mint and licorice draws you in. Next comes brandied cherry flavors touched up by hints of black pepper, herbs and chocolate. The finish is lengthy and layered, and overall this is one complete, smooth wine.

wine: Adega Cooperativa Ponte de Lima 2014 Ponte Loureiro (Vinho Verde)
review: Lightly sparkling, this is a crisp, almost dry wine that offers fresh sliced apples and citrus flavors. Made from the Louriero grape which is widely planted in the Lima valley, this is a fruity sip for the summer.

One of a half-dozen chess-themed Chardonnays from this exciting new winery, this was fermented in both barrel and concrete egg. Peach, melon, lemon oil and pineapple flavors combine, then lead into an interesting finish with vanilla wafer (from one-third new oak) and a dash of sea salt.

wine: Bodegas Tobía 2016 Alma Tobía Blanco Fermentado en Barrica White (Rioja)
designation: Alma Tobía Blanco Fermentado en Barrica
review: Oak and more oak is the greeting on this not so subtle barrel-fermented white Rioja. A full palate is lively under a resiny surface, with kicking acidity. A peppery spice flavor tops apple and stone fruit notes, while this is long, toasty, creamy and intense on the finish. Drink through 2030.

Pride continues to struggle with this variety, as does everyone else in California who tries their hand at it. The '05 is semisweet and simple, with candied cherry-blackberry flavors that finish more like a dessert wine than a dry table wine.

wine: Ashes & Diamonds 2017 Mountain Peak Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Atlas Peak)
review: With Diana Snowden Seysses as winemaker, this structured, focused and complex wine is both age-worthy and immediately impressive. Earthy dried herb, clove and spice ride along a wave of firm, integrated tannin and mineral-tinged crushed rock, with nuanced red berry bubbling beneath. This will do well to cellar; enjoy best from 2025 through 2030.

wine: Terrazas de Los Andes 2013 Single Vineyard Las Compuertas Malbec (Mendoza)
review: A bullish nose is charred, minty and delivers heavy blackberry aromas. This is a massive Malbec with weight issues: It's rather flabby, but with biting tannins. Stewed blackberry and chocolate flavors finish with notes of fig and raisin.

Bold and flashy, with layers of smoke and toast wrapped around a core of mixed citrus and riper stone fruits. It's a tasty mouthful of Chard that picks up some mineral notes along the way to complement its brash flavors.

This base Barolo from Bric Cenciurio offers everything you should look for in an excellent Nebbiolo from the Langhe, Piedmont. The wine is delicate and layered with soft shadings of berry fruit and spice. The mouthfeel is supple but determined with a blast of berry freshness on the close.

wine: Domaine de Ménard 2017 Sauvignon Blanc (Côtes de Gascogne)
appellation: Côtes de Gascogne, Southwest France, France
review: Totally herbal, this crisp wine is all about richly flavored Sauvignon Blanc. It has weight despite its low alcohol, and is full of green and citrus fruits. The cut-grass aroma sings of a summer's day and this makes a great aperitif to drink right then.

wine: Marco Felluga 2006 Ronco dei Moreri Refosco (Venezia Giulia)
review: Here's a dark and well-extracted Refosco with deep layers of black fruit and spice. The wine is brambly and slight sour on the close but also offers soothing softness as it moves across the palate.

wine: Two Wives 2006 Pink Red Table Wine Rosé (Napa Valley)
review: This is certainly full-bodied for a rosé. It's a soft, thick wine, with cherry and blackberry Lifesaver flavors and something stewed and caramelly, like licorice. Finishes a little off-dry. Mostly Merlot, with a drop of Syrah.

Like the 2007, the winery's '08 is a tasty, fruity wine that's ready to drink now. Grown on Atlas Peak, it offers soft, spicy flavors of cherries, raspberries and cola, with a rich coating of smoky sandalwood.

wine: Bowe Joubert Vineyard & Winery 2001 Cuvée Emmerentia Chardonnay (Stellenbosch)
review: Clarified butter and toasty fruit aromas and flavors follow through to the palate, where there's thin lemon fruit. The finish is layered in butter and lemon zest. —K.F.
Pressed violet, crushed herb and camphor aromas shape the nose. The chewy palate delivers crushed raspberry, black cherry and a hint of star anise alongside firm tannins. Drink 2021–2027.
A dark, ripe and fruity wine that is full of dense red-fruit aromas and spicy tannins. The palate offers ample freshness, with crisp, juicy red berry fruit up front. Drink now and until 2017.

wine: Domaine Valéry Renaudat 2017 Le P'tit Renaudat Sauvignon Blanc (Val de Loire)
appellation: Val de Loire, Loire Valley, France
review: A soft, creamy wine, this is full of crisp apple fruit that is lightly touched by a squeeze of lemon. Acidity is muted by the ripe fruits to give a rounded wine that is ready to drink.

A ripe, fragrant wine that also manages to retain fine crispness. There is some Grüner pepper and spice, but the freshness of the wine allows it to show grapefruit and other citrus characters as well as tense acidity.

appellation: Dry Creek Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: Soft and vegetal, with herb and asparagus flavors alongside cherry candy ones.

wine: Columbia Winery 2014 Limited Release Grenache Rosé (Horse Heaven Hills)
appellation: Horse Heaven Hills, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: A medium cherry-red color, this wine offer fruit-filled aromas of strawberry bubble gum, pomegranate and cherry. It drinks a hair off dry, with broad, fleshy fruit flavors that linger.

Filled with black and red berries and stone fruits that have a smoky, grilled edge, this dramatic Cabernet-based Bordeaux blend hails from several great vineyards, mainly Stagecoach, which is up on Atlas Peak. It drinks well now at the age of four-plus years, showing lush fruit that's just beginning to dry out and achieve bottle bouquet. Feels sweet and soft in the mouth. A compelling, complex and nuanced wine of great elegance and allure.

Few wineries have a more consistent track record with this rare Rhône white than Kunde. This year, as usual, the wine is brilliant in tropical fruit, apple, peach, honeysuckle and buttery-vanilla flavors. It's well-balanced with acids and just a touch of oak.
Acidic and clean, a slightly sweet Sauvignon Blanc to drink as a cocktail sipper with hors d'oeuvres. Has flavors of lemons, limes, grapefruits and vanilla.

wine: Seppeltsfield 1999 Vintage Para Tawny Red (South Australia)
review: With over two decades under its belt, this Tawny fortified defies its age. It's radiant burnt orange in hue, with an equally sunny disposition. High-toned aromas of candied citrus, flan, roasted nuts and a damp woodsy underbelly lead to a mouthfeel that's rich but not unctuous, sweet but not cloying. There's some heat from the alcohol but a wealth of primary citrus flavors that hint at many more years to come. A delicious tribute to Australia's most traditional winemaking style from one of its oldest wineries.
This is a generous and ripe version of the variety, reflective of warmer Napa Valley sites, and a wine that's completely delicious in its abundance of apple and caramel.

wine: Companhia das Quintas 2009 Quinta da Fronteira Selecção do Enólogo Red (Douro)
designation: Quinta da Fronteira Selecção do Enólogo
review: Huge and rich, this offers ripe black fruits and a concentrated structure. It's packed with a seemingly sweet blackberry flavor that serves as a counterpoint to the firm texture. With both density and a dark edge, this will age over several years.

wine: Grassini Family Vineyards 2018 Merlot (Happy Canyon of Santa Barbara)
appellation: Happy Canyon of Santa Barbara, Central Coast, California, US
review: Black-cherry and light clove aromas meet with a delicately layered wood-spice array on the nose of this bottling, which is immediately appealing and accessible. There's a tightness to the tannins on the palate and yet it remains a generous wine, offering bright red fruits, sandalwood and spiced toast amidst fresh and fun acidity.

wine: TH Estate 2017 5 Blocks Reserve Red (Paso Robles Willow Creek District)
appellation: Paso Robles Willow Creek District, Central Coast, California, US
review: Very subdued on the nose at first, this blend of 39% Syrah, 36% Mourvedre, 17% Grenache and 8% Graciano opens up to aromas of macerated black plums and violet. There's a subdued richness to the palate, where roasted boysenberry, savory grilled pork and charred fennel flavors meet with an earthy touch of potting soil.

wine: Monte Seis Reis 2009 Private Selection Red (Alentejano)
review: This is very ripe, rounded and rich, with its black fruit dominating the tarry, tannic character. Chocolate and mint notes surface from the wood aging. With its dark toast element, this could age another two years.

Blackberry and rubber aromas are friendly and forward, with spice added in for good measure. Feels full, lush and cushioned, with integrated tannins, good acidity and bright red berry flavors dusted by herbs and spice. Finishes smooth and true. A winning wine from a difficult vintage.

wine: Domìni Veneti 2005 La Casetta  (Valpolicella Classico Superiore Ripasso)
appellation: Valpolicella Classico Superiore Ripasso, Veneto, Italy
review: The soft and enduring texture of this wine is what sets it apart. Sweet and plush, you'll get flavors of peppercorn, spice, black fruit, prune and liquid smoke. This is a bold a modern interpretation of Ripasso with long staying power. —M.L.

wine: Dumas Station 2005 Estate Merlot (Walla Walla Valley (WA))
appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: This is the winery's first Merlot. It's a simple, pleasant effort, fruit forward and lightly oaky. The usual flavors of berry are there, and the balance is fine; it just could use more concentration through the finish.

wine: Holus Bolus 2016 Franc De Pied Syrah (Sta. Rita Hills)
appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
review: Cola, blueberry and red fruits meet with sweet tobacco and peppercorn-crusted beef on the nose of this foot-stomped bottling. Though young, it's very accessible now, with smashed berries, tar and savory flavors of black, white and green peppercorn riding a strong acidity.

Aromas of underbrush, camphor, fragrant pipe tobacco and a whiff of scorched earth form the nose on this captivating red. Firmly structured and boasting finesse, the youthful palate already shows great depth and precision, delivering raspberry compote, juicy black cherry, licorice and a hint of hazelnut set against firm fine-grained tannins and fresh acidity. Give it time to fully develop. Drink 2025–2040.

appellation: Shenandoah Valley (CA), Sierra Foothills, California, US
review: Aromas like iron, earth and cherries lead to good rich fruit flavors in this well-balanced and medium-bodied wine. Energized by firm tannins and lively acidity, it matches them with ripe cherry and raspberry flavors and a tantalizing spiciness that lasts through the finish.

Planted on a former river bed of the Loire, this vineyard profits from the deep gravel soils. This adds minerality to the black-currant fruits with their crisp acidity and spicy aftertaste. Drink the wine from 2020.

wine: Golan Heights Winery 2013 Yarden Cabernet Sauvignon (Galilee)
review: This deep red violet colored wine features aromas of plum, black cherry and violet. Velvety tannins provide a backdrop for a good mix of fruit and spice flavors that include black cherry, raspberry, vanilla and licorice. The long spicy finish wraps up with a burst of cranberry flavor.

wine: Les Domaines Auriol Claude Vialade 2016 Le Jardins de Vignes Rares de Ciceron Le Cabernet Franc (Pays d'Oc)
designation: Le Jardins de Vignes Rares de Ciceron Le
review: There's a slightly gamy, meaty character upfront on the nose of this wine, with bold, black fruit tones to add support. Touches of green pepper, tobacco and tea add interest, as well as a hint of fresh coffee grinds. Plush and velvety in feel, it shows good structure and tannins, with lush black-fruit tones that ground the palate and ride through to the medium-length finish.

wine: Maryhill 2014 Proprietor's Reserve Gunkel Vineyards Barbera (Columbia Valley (WA))
appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Bright aromas of raspberry, macerated cranberry, nougat, vanilla and pencil shavings lead to tart puckering fruit flavors that show intensity and length. There is much to enjoy.

While there are few varietal Tempranillos made in Chile, this one is mostly positive. On the nose, this is dark, with a chocolaty crust along with patented Los Lingues aromas of olive and herbs. A choppy palate is high in acidity, while flavors of heavy oak, vanilla and herbal plum finish peppery, spicy and scratchy in feel.

There's brightness here, though the wine's flavors are a little strange. The nose is a mix of wet soil, caramel and clarified butter; the palate offers the same wet-soil flavor, plus plum and wood. Not nuanced; closes with herb and metal.

Initially, this big-time Tempranillo from Bodegas San Román smells lactic and chocolaty, with a hint of marshmallow to go with black cherry and blackberry fruit. On the palate, this is rugged and tough, something you can embrace but can't avoid. Black cherry, cassis and dark plum flavors finish with cocoa notes, and the more air this sees the better it will perform. Drink through 2030.

wine: Vincent d'Astrée 2009 Novae Brut Pinot Meunier (Champagne)
review: This mature vintage Champagne is rich in nutty flavors along with the acidity and crisp fruitiness. It is a dry wine, poised and with a clear, clean balance. Drink now.

One of the markers for Vinho Verde, this brand gets better and better. The 2005 is a new blend, with 10% of Alvarinho from the Aveleda estate. It is ripe and rich, with great solid full fruits in the mouth, tropical but with some citrus character. It's bone dry, with fine finishing acidity. Imported by Aveleda Imports.

wine: Vega Sindoa 2008 El Chaparral de Vega Sindoa Old Vines Garnacha (Navarra)
designation: El Chaparral de Vega Sindoa Old Vines
review: Smells like bath soap, then turns grassy and burnt. Tannic and medicinal in the mouth, although better as it airs out. Tastes and feels overdone and super sweet.

appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
review: Cedar, bold berry and cassis aromas come with an exotic note of sandalwood. In the mouth, this feels alert, bright and grabby, with a full load of muscular tannins and acidity. Flavors of spiced blackberry, coffee and chocolate are toasty and a touch burnt in character on the finish. Drink through 2023.

A suave Sangiovese-Cabernet Sauvignon blend with dark, minty, cola aromas that mix with serious red-fruit notes to create a character-packed bouquet. The palate is as ripe and aggressive as you want, but with good balance. Throughout the oak is present but integrated. Can hold through 2010 without much effort.

wine: Siduri 2016 Soberanes Vineyard Pinot Noir (Santa Lucia Highlands)
appellation: Santa Lucia Highlands, Central Coast, California, US
review: Sultry and elegantly integrated aromas of purple flower and black raspberry decorate the nose of this single-vineyard expression by veteran Adam Lee. Pungent fruit shows on the palate, where baked black cherry and boysenberry are lifted by wild thyme and chaparral spice.

appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: Lighter in body and color, yet full of exotic plum, mulberry, sumac and cinnamon aromas, this is a very fresh and taut Pinot Noir from Paso Robles. It's full in body despite its light color, with brilliant acidity and snappy mouthfilling flavors of raspberry, cranberry, fennel pollen and soy.
A wine that combines richness with sweet cherry flavors and a firm tannic edge. Acidity and ripeness have produced a structured, food-friendly wine.

wine: Les Frères Couillaud 2015 Château de la Ragotière Vallet  (Muscadet Sèvre et Maine)
appellation: Muscadet Sèvre et Maine, Loire Valley, France
review: This wine from Vallet, one of the new crus of Muscadet, has been aged for three years. That gives its richness a boost and introduces minerality, spice and intensity. The wine is packed with fruit and tightly textured. Drink now.

wine: Le Casematte 2015 Peloro Bianco White (Terre Siciliane)
review: A blend of 65% Grillo and 35% Carricante, this offers subtle aromas of ripe orchard fruit, wild flower and a whiff of almond. The vibrant, savory palate boasts green apple, creamy white peach, citrus and aromatic herb alongside an energizing mineral vein. It finishes crisp and clean.

wine: The Winery At Holy Cross Abbey 2016 Reserve Merlot (Colorado)
winery: The Winery At Holy Cross Abbey
review: Earthy aromas of nutmeg and fallen leaves mingle with pink peppercorn, goji berry and black currant notes on the nose of this Merlot that's blended with small amounts of Cabernet Sauvignon and Cabernet Franc. This is fresh in feel from a strong core of acidity and wrapped in papery tannins. Flavors of juicy cherry and cranberry meld with earthy tones of underbrush and dried sage. Peppercorns and red plums emerge on the finish.
A bold Grüner Veltliner, with spice and minerality to go with the rich fruit. There is a steely edge that suggests the wine needs a year's aging, to bring on greater richness. Big and impressive.
From a single parcel in Chorey-lès-Beaune, this fruity wine has crisp red berry flavors and light tannins. It's ripe and will develop easily and quickly into a soft, rounded wine. Drink from 2018.

This simple wine blends the typical Dão grapes of Alfrocheiro, Tinta Roriz and Touriga Nacional into a spicy fruity whole. Young and fruity with black currant and spice, it's finished with toast. This is ready to drink.

wine: Cristom 2018 Louise Vineyard Pinot Noir (Eola-Amity Hills)
appellation: Eola-Amity Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: This young, bright wine bursts open with raspberry and cherry fruit. The concentration and length are excellent, and it should benefit from additional bottle age. Drink from 2022–2030.

From the producer's Cohn Estate Vineyard, planted in 1970, this is Zin from a Pinot Noir perspective, given gentle treatment and cooperage in French oak (34% new). Juicy, thick and robust in tannin, it settles into a softness of floral aromas and high-toned red and black cherry and berry laced in nutmeg.

wine: Lingua Franca 2017 Estate Pinot Noir (Eola-Amity Hills)
appellation: Eola-Amity Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: A delicious mix of blueberry and cherry fruit, ripe and firm, this estate-grown wine nicely reflects the AVA with a dusting of dried herbs. Those savory notes are perfectly integrated. The wine was finished in 25% new French barriques.

Green peppers and a stemmy quality mar the nose, which is otherwise closed. Fruit then creeps into the picture, but never quite gets its foot through the door. Dry and tannic. Not bad but not all that welcoming.

wine: Domaine des Peirecèdes 2020 Le Fil d'Ariane Rosé (Côtes de Provence)
review: Soft and ripe, this wine is generous with its fruits and perfumed acidity. Red-berry flavors are freshened further by the crisp texture and given spice by the pepper aftertaste. Drink the wine now. Organic.

Saturated purple in color, with vanilla, mint and tobacco aromas. The fruit is a bit herbal, but there's still enough blackberry and coffee character to keep things balanced. Some poke-through acidity creates a piqued mouthfeel.

This Tempranillo Blanco offers candied melon and lime aromas. On the palate, it has the consistency of apple juice and tastes of Bartlett pear with a hint of salt. Ultimately, it's a good but average wine little character and a dilute finish.

Fresh brioche and roasted honey aromas are as rich and intense as the apple and anise flavors. The mouthfeel is creamy yet crisp and vibrant. The favorite of Page Six celebrities—you know, the ones who are usually drinking it from the bottle.
Delicate aromas of red berry and spring wildflowers waft out of the glass. Simple but well-made, the bright palate offers raspberry and strawberry alongside crisp acidity.

wine: Soos Creek 2008 Palisade Red Wine Red (Columbia Valley (WA))
appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Pure Merlot, though not labeled as such, this is broadly fruity with a play of strawberry, hard cherry candy, and citrus. The grape sources—Champoux, Klipsun and Bacchus vineyards— are impeccable. Tannins are stiff enough to put a stop to the finish, and to suggest that some further bottle age is called for.

appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: This Sangiovese was as usual co-fermented with Syrah (13%), and sourced from a mix of estate vineyards. Smooth and supple, it's a sweetly appealing wine, loaded with strawberry preserves, but also detailed with impressive notes of Italian herbs and a whiff of tomato paste. As befits the variety, the underpinning of natural acidity lifts the finish beautifully, and suggests aging it through 2020.

With its dark color and intense tannins, this is a big wine in all senses. The fruit is packed into a box of firm dry structure, with acidity keeping a lid on its potential exuberance. It certainly needs time for the richness to fully come through.

Wonderful sweet fruit, velvet in texture, with concentrated ripe fruits and red berries. This is a wine that rolls sumptuously around the mouth, the tannins certainly dense but full of the same sweetness as the fruit. The final flavor is perfumed and fresh. Deceptively attractive, it will profit from many years' aging.

Toasty oak, rounded vanilla and ripe lemon immediately show on the nose of this wine. These flavors continue on the fresh but smooth palate, with the oak rounding out and and the vanilla providing perfume. This wine is concentrated but has lovely freshness.

Tettineive Barbaresco shows nice integration of wood and fruit. The wine offers elegance over intensity and although all the aromas are clean and correct, there is a slight point of dried dill or chopped herb in the background.

wine: Companhia das Quintas 2016 Quinta do Cardo Red (Beira Interior)
review: This wine hails from an organic vineyard that sits at 2,400 feet above sea level. That seems to give it an herbal character with touches of bell pepper as well as ripe black fruits. The structure suggests the wine should age, so drink from 2019.
84–86. Barrel Sample. A strangely flavored wine with hard tannins. The oak seems to overpower the fruit at this stage in its life.

Scala Dei seems to have managed 2003's tough conditions, and this is endowed with sweet Garnacha-driven aromas that touch up against raisiny but don't cross the line. The palate is plump and loaded with strawberry and vanilla flavors, then chocolate shows up on the finish. The blend is 41% Garnacha, 41% Syrah and 18% Cab Sauvignon.

This blend of this wine is popular in Alentejo with Syrah now part of the repertoire. The wine is warm, with a ripe character and a sunny feel. Its structure and acidity keep the wine balanced. Drink now.

wine: Osprey's Dominion 2016 Dry Rosé (North Fork of Long Island)
appellation: North Fork of Long Island, Long Island, New York, US
review: A touch of Riesling accentuates the fresh citrusy backbone on this Cabernet Sauvignon rosé. Dry in style with a sprightly light-footed tone, it offers loads of concentrated cherry and berry flavors. The finish is brisk and clean.

wine: Columbia Crest 2011 Grand Estates Syrah (Columbia Valley (WA))
appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: This budget Syrah brings good flavor as well as good value. Black tea, cherry tobacco and cherry candy flavors mix well across a full, generous palate. The cooler vintage kept the alcohol down and acids up.

wine: Caves Velhas 2013 D. Fuas Reserva Red (Terras do Dão)
review: This is a herbal, earthy wine with as many tannins as fruit at this stage. That gives it a dense, dusty texture that seeps into the ripe, sweet plum flavors. With the wood giving an extra push of richness as well as spice, it needs to age. Drink from 2017.

Aromas of radiator dust, melon, apple cider and minerals are intriguing and suggest good quality. A minerally, citric, chiseled palate offers flavors of crushed vitamins, tart persimmon and salty sea brine. Saltiness comes back on a minerally finish.

appellation: Arroyo Seco, Central Coast, California, US
review: There's pleasing smoke on the nose of this wine, with roasting chicken, grilled apples and seared pears. The palate picks up more familiar stone fruit and cherimoya, with some slightly bitter lemongrass verve, but the smoke returns for a complicated finish.

Shows something of a Graves-like flavor profile, with dark coffee, earth and tobacco notes arrayed alongside cedar, cola and black cherry. It's a complex, medium-weight wine with enough soft tannin to stand up to rare beef or lamb, but enough elegance to please. Drink now–2010.

wine: Stottle 2011 Elephant Mountain Vineyard Merlot (Yakima Valley)
appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: This Merlot, which includes a small amount of Syrah, at first feels a little disjointed, though some breathing time helps pull it together. Raspberry fruit enters softly and lingers nicely, though without much depth or further development.

wine: Chronic Cellars 2015 Purple Paradise Red (Paso Robles)
appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: Another accessible, complex and tasty wine from the Beckett brothers, this blend of 68% Zinfandel, 18% Petite Sirah, 8% Grenache and 6% Syrah offers baked and fresh blackberry notes on the nose, alongside slate, lilacs and clove. The layered palate shows blackened berries, espresso and a touch of caramel that ride a decent acidity deep into the finish.

wine: Graffigna 2007 Centenario Reserve Cabernet Sauvignon (San Juan)
review: Floral but dilute, with mild red fruit scents mixed with herbal fern and juniper aromas. The palate has a good but innocuous mouthfeel, and overall it's fresh but simple, with herbal, generic red fruit and dried oregano flavors.

Smoky cinnamon and nutmeg pierce the entry of this wine, a dense, full-bodied expression of place. Layers of rich cherry and strawberry lie over classic varietal earthiness, finishing medium in length.

appellation: Temecula Valley, South Coast, California, US
review: Rusty red-fruit aromas meet with bloody earth tones on the nose of this bottling. The palate shows dried berry, smoke, oak and a vanilla finish.

appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: Quite a pretty shade of pink, this rosé blend of 70% Grenache, 27% Syrah and 3% Viognier offers generous aromas of watermelon, strawberry and rose petals. This is not a shy rosé, as the palate is loaded with cherry flavors, yet there is an underlying wet stone quality and strong acidity that add elegance.

appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
review: From a variety that's difficult to ripen in California comes this plush, sleek wine, with cola, berry, leather, and currant aromas, and rich, dry flavors. What a nice mouthfeel, velvety smooth, and a slightly bitter, almond-skin finish.

wine: Calyptra 2011 Inédito Limited Edition Cabernet Sauvignon-Merlot (Cachapoal Valley)
review: On first take, this blend of Cabernet and Merlot is like diving headfirst into a juniper bush, that's how herbal and green the nose is. A wiry, tight palate has no give to it, while this tastes of plum, wild berry, tobacco and fresh herb. While lively and prodding, the finish offers nothing new or complex. Drink through 2026.

appellation: Rogue Valley, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
review: A solidly fruity wine, it's loaded with pear flesh and texture, balanced against fresh and proportionate acids. Not a complex wine, but clean and quite flavorful.

wine: Corte Rugolin 2012 Monte Danieli Riserva  (Amarone della Valpolicella Classico)
appellation: Amarone della Valpolicella Classico, Veneto, Italy
review: This opens with aromas of ripe black-skinned fruit, resin and roasted coffee bean. The warm, dense palate delivers espresso, dried black cherry, clove and vanilla alongside close-grained tannins.

Don Paolo is a blend of Nero d'Avola and Syrah that offers generous, yet decidedly feminine, aromas of cherry, forest berry, exotic spice and dried flowers. The wine has depth and personality and ends with very good freshness and concentration.

The nose is slightly feral, bearing fragrances of brambly boysenberry and wild blueberry. There is a nice play between fruit and savory notes, with flavors of raspberry, strawberry, smoked meat and summer farm stand. Mellow tannins offer an ample preface to a citrus-zest finish amped up by a touch of salted caramel.

appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: The winery is in eastern Oregon, near the Idaho border, but the grapes were sourced from an unnamed Willamette Valley vineyard. A bit high-toned, with sharply defined strawberry and cherry fruit, this finishes with a burst of caramel and mocha.

This isn't overly expressive but reveals nuances of blue flower, black cherry and chocolate that carry over to the palate along with prune and roasted coffee bean. Drying wood tannins give it a mouthpuckering close.

appellation: Santa Clara Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: Tightly woven aromas of citrus peel, green plums and struck flint show on the nose of this bottling. The palate is also brisk and somewhat austere, with slightly sour fruit flavors.

wine: Quinta do Vallado 2016 Vallado Touriga Nacional Rosé (Douro)
review: This crisp wine is as light as a feather—fruity and perfumed. The fruit came from the highest altitude of the quinta, resulting in the wine's cool character and considerable acidity. Drink now.
This broad, ripe wine has plenty of ripe red fruits but the minimum of structure. It is soft, generous and ready to drink. Much of the hand-picked production is from old vines on a 45-degree slope.

wine: King Estate 2014 Croft Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)
appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: Tart cranberry and pomegranate fruit is front and center in this wine, streaked with an herbed butter accent. Barrel aged for a year in 30% new French oak, it's smooth and silky in feel. The tannins are somewhat astringent but should soften in time.
This zippy, fresh Savvy wakes up the palate like a citrus sorbet after a big meal. It's refreshing with bright acidity and flavors of limes, smoke and just the barest hint of green pepper.

This affordable wine is smooth and deeply fruity, rather full bodied, and quite enjoyable for the ripe blackberry and boysenberry flavors. Not as tannic as some, it still has a moderately gripping texture that will be perfect with grilled meat.
The orange, lemon, honey and vanilla flavors are a little thin, but crisp acidity and a sweet finish make the wine likeable, perhaps nice on a summer night.

A soft, floral-talc note coats earth and juicy red fruit on the comforting, almost sexy, nose. On the palate, flat blackberry and strawberry notes take on a bit of tanginess, thanks to the oak. It's medium to light in weight—this is no heavy-hitter—and finishes a little thin, the floral-talc note returning. The nose is the best part; the wine lightens up considerably after that. —D.M.

wine: Caliza 2013 Syrah (Paso Robles Willow Creek District)
appellation: Paso Robles Willow Creek District, Central Coast, California, US
review: Dark in the glass, this wine by Carl Bowker offers fragrant vanilla, baked blueberry, a touch of pepper and coffee-cocoa foam on the rich and inviting nose. Hearty blueberry and blackberry fruit flavors are lifted by baking spice, bound to a tart, tannic, black-plum-skin-like structure.
91–93. Barrel Sample. Full of ripe fruit, this is a fine and rich wine. It has a good balance between fresh acidity and sweet berry fruit. With its bold structure, this is a wine for aging.
Confident saline and citrus aromas are a good entry to this clean, fairly lean brut. Lime and tangerine flavors are racy and not too sweet, while this is fresh and well made on the finish.

wine: Patient Cottat 2019 Le Grand Caillou Pinot Noir (Vin de France)
appellation: Vin de France, France Other, France
review: Ripe, spicy and warm, this wine has a light structure that supports the blackberry fruits. A crisp edge contrasts with the full, fruity aftertaste.
While this wine is initially juicy, its structure shows later, coming from behind to give tannins and weight to the black-fruit flavors. It is now fully balanced, rich and fruity.

Fine tannins and attractive acidity set the scene for a wine that is structured and rich in perfumed berry fruits, with a dry, dark core. It is an impressive, ripe wine, still developing and filling out. Drink from 2018.

wine: Acorn 2003 Alegria Vineyards Sangiovese (Russian River Valley)
appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: This is a pretty good Sangiovese and Acorn has worked hard on the variety for years. It's dry and elegant, with silky, Pinot-like tannins and crisp acids. It's also very ripe in cherry and cocoa flavors.

wine: DFJ Vinhos 2009 Point West Touriga Nacional (Lisboa)
review: This wine emphasizes the fruit of Touriga Nacional rather than its structure. Ripe red-plum fruits dominate, cushioning acidity and tannins with fruity richness. It's for drinking now or aging until 2015.

wine: Dona Maria-Júlio Bastos 2009 Dona Maria Amantis Reserva Red (Alentejano)
review: The wine tastes old before its years. It has a leathery character and prominent acidity rather than fruit. It has interest, with its dried fruits and tannins that are just on the point of drying out. Drink now.

wine: Canoe Ridge 2002 Oak Ridge Vineyard Gewürztraminer (Washington)
review: The winery always does well with this tricky grape, somehow walking the line between floral and oily, sweet and dry, and coming up with intensity that doesn't tire out the palate. Complex and lingering, it's perfect for southeast Asian cuisine.

This is a good wine from a less-than-successful vintage. The blackberry flavors have a raw, unfinished edge that liberal oak cannot sweeten. There's also a streak of tart acidity that leads to a dry, puckery finish.

Lovely top notes of peony and baby's breath grace the bouquet of this rosé, with supporting notes of ripe melon, white cherry and strawberry at the core. The palate is medium in weight but well balanced, with a sweet orange flavor and bright acidic thread that keeps the momentum moving from the fruit-fueled palate to the vibrant, refreshing finish.

wine: Jean Laurent 2006 La Griffe de l'Ource Blanc de Blancs Brut  (Champagne)
designation: La Griffe de l'Ource Blanc de Blancs Brut
review: One of a pair of 100% varietal wines produced from vines in Celles-sur-Ource, this Chardonnay is taut and structured while having the extra richness of the Aube. Acidity and crisp texture give this ripe wine a good balance. Drink now.

Native Italian grape Garganega and Sauvignon Blanc are blended to produce a layered white wine with fresh tones of stone fruit, kiwi, melon and lemon zest. This interesting combination offers good, fresh acidity and vibrant fruit flavors.

A weighty yet balanced nose offers bold berry aromas matched by oaky notes of mocha, vanilla and marshmallow. Racy acidity and firm tannins lend brightness and grit to the palate, while this Cabernet Sauvignon-led blend tastes of blackberry, cassis and supporting spice notes. A smooth and mellow finish is a fine conclusion to this fruit-forward blend of Cabernet Sauvignon, Malbec, Carmenère and Syrah. Drink through 2024.
Informal and refreshing, this light-bodied rosé has flavors suggesting tart sour cherry, unripe strawberry and a hint of saline. It's simple but well-made, with a crisp finish.

A dry white with a smooth mouthfeel and some typical Sémillon waxiness to boot. Still, a strong, unyielding bell pepper quality detracts throughout. Closes clean with a slight grainy feel, but it's just too green and lean.

A classic Bordeaux-style blend with Merlot dominant, this wine has an attractively luscious texture full of rich berry flavors. The tannins are there, but they are light, emphasizing the wine's fruitiness. It is developing quickly and will be ready to drink from 2019

wine: Barton & Guestier 2002 Chardonnay (Vin de Pays d'Oc)
appellation: Vin de Pays d'Oc, Languedoc-Roussillon, France
review: There are sweet vanilla aromas, along with aromas of green plums. This is a soft, creamy wine, with just a touch of greeness, and a full, creamy texture.

wine: Carpe Diem 2005 Firepeak Vineyard Pinot Noir (Edna Valley)
appellation: Edna Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: The '05, as befits the cool vintage, is very dry and crisply elegant, with crushed cherry, raspberry and root beer flavors boosted by a squirt of lime juice, enriched by sweet vanilla and oak. Best now–2008.
Subdued aromas of toasted oak, baking spice and graphite guide the nose. The dense palate delivers raw sour cherry, clove and vanilla while assertive tannins give it an astringent finish.

Odd stuff, with vegetal notes appearing in place of the ripe floral aromas expected of Viognier. Corn, lime and green tomatoes all show up on the nose or in the mouth, along with a slightly oily mouthfeel.

Hints of sweet spice and smoke seep into sunny apricot and honeysuckle in this lavishly rounded Viognier. It's a classically fleshy, weighty wine with a delightfully clingy finish, but cutting mineral tones and crisp tangerine acidity lend lift and vitality, too. Excellent in youth but concentrated enough to mature well through 2040.

Raw and rugged at first. The mouth offers a bit more, although even here the raspberry and plum flavors are spread thin. Has its merits but also some faults, primarily a finish that's not far enough removed from cough syrup.

appellation: Temecula Valley, South Coast, California, US
review: Rustic but pleasant aromas of blistered berries, plums, oak and licorice invite the nose into this bottling. Chalky tannins frame the sip, where roasted black fruit and an array of brown spices lead into a vanilla-kissed finish.

wine: Laetitia 2006 Estate Pinot Noir (Arroyo Grande Valley)
appellation: Arroyo Grande Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: A lovely, crisp wine that shows many of the excellent characteristics of Laetitia's more expensive vineyard block bottlings, without the complexity. You'll find the same fine acidity, rich tannins and cherry and cola flavors, compromised only by some green mint dilution.

wine: Ruggeri & C. NV Frizzante Gentile  (Prosecco di Conegliano e Valdobbiadene)
appellation: Prosecco di Conegliano e Valdobbiadene, Veneto, Italy
review: This is a very sweet-smelling frizzante with intense aromas of peach, exotic fruit and kiwi. The mouthfeel is lean and somewhat watery but the wine cleans the palate thanks to its natural crispness.

Under the same family ownership as Château Mont-Redon in Châteauneuf-du-Pape, this is soft, ripe and rich. Hints of caramel, a light sprinkling of toast flavors and spice. Full-bodied wine that works best with food.

wine: Domaine Ansen 2015 Struch Brut Nature Auxerrois (Crémant d'Alsace)
review: Rounded, creamy notes of ripe and mellow apple stream from the glass. The palate is equally mellow and creamy, with an inherent bright freshness and a wonderfully creamy midpalate. Notions of freshly baked shortbread pastry join the apple notes and make for a very balanced, textured and rounded palate, vivid with apple freshness. This is lovely now, but sure to evolve in bottle. The finish is dry and creamy. Drink now through 2025.
From a vineyard that was once a cherry orchard, this wine is vibrant with red-berry flavors and juicy fruitiness. While it is lightly textured, it is really a wine to drink young, from late 2021.

wine: Brick & Mortar 2018 Manchester Ridge Vineyard Chardonnay (Mendocino Ridge)
appellation: Mendocino Ridge, Mendocino County, California, US
review: Deep but lively fruit flavors energize this medium-bodied wine with tangy apples and vibrant lemons while light mineral tones add complexity. Grown at relatively high elevation, it is absolutely clean and fresh, showing little oak influence.

wine: Quickfire 2007 Top Chef Selection Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
review: A full-bodied, spicy Cabernet, with lots of jammy blackberry and cherry fruit. Drink this robust young wine now.

Delicate aromas of lemon blossom, pear, Spanish broom and brimstone lead the nose on this vibrant white. The bright palate offers citrus, apple and mineral along with a touch of light oak that adds depth, while crisp acidity imparts energy.

wine: La Jota Vineyard 2007 Cabernet Franc (Howell Mountain)
review: A big, vital, dramatic wine, one of the finest Cab Francs of the vintage. Dazzles with blackberry, black cherry, mocha and spice flavors, wrapped into thick but finely ground tannins, and enriched with smoky oak. Beautiful now and for the next 4–5 years.
Aromas of leafy underbrush, roasted coffee bean and dried black cherry open this robust wine. The palate offers prune, fig, oak, blueberry extract, vanilla and espresso framed in firm tannins.

appellation: Eola-Amity Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: Keeler is doing some interesting experimentation with fermentation methods, and here they deliver a stunning amphora-fermented, off-dry Riesling. The wine offers a fine mix of apricot, peach and nectarine tones that display a sweet and sour tension. It finishes with a lick of butterscotch.

wine: Château Eugénie 2009 Cuvée Pierre le Grand  (Cahors)
review: Perfumed aromas give this wine a smooth, polished feel. Hints of mint go with the well integrated tannins that firm up the sweet blackberry flavors. A great ripe swathe of fruit is laced with acidity on the finish.

wine: Peachy Canyon 2001 Mr. Wilson's Vineyard Zinfandel (Paso Robles)
appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: A smooth-textured wine that sports a pretty core of cherry, plum, coffee and chocolate flavors. The tannins are firm and ripe and offer a good framework to support the flavors.

Sweet and slightly viscous in texture, this wine lacks some aromatic flourishes, sacrificing complexity for purity of its pineapple, apple and citrus flavors. Yet because of its balanced, crisp acidity, the wine still sings, finishing long and mouthwatering. Drink now–2030.

Viognier and Vermentino spend some time in both stainless steel and oak, which gives this blend fresh aromas and a creamy palate. Stone fruit, apricot, honey and white flower notes are accompanied by mildly spicy overtones.

wine: Williams Selyem 2018 Vista Verde Vineyard Pinot Noir (San Benito County)
appellation: San Benito County, Central Coast, California, US
review: This wine begins with zesty aromas of black raspberry, poached cherry and hibiscus accented by mace and clove. Flavors of roasted cranberry and black raspberry converge with star anise and black licorice on the delicious palate.

Not such a rarity these days, Albariño is turning heads in California and Oregon. This tart, juicy, and deliciously fresh effort is loaded with tangy citrus and green apple fruit. It's leesy and textural, tasting of wet stones: in sum, a wonderfully refreshing summer white.

wine: Hugh Hamilton 2020 The Scally Wag Chardonnay (McLaren Vale)
review: There's a lot of winemaking here. The nose is fruity, with peach and strawberry notes backed by ginger, cream and some oak influence. There's also what seems like a good lick of sulfur. In the mouth, acidity is angular and feels forced. The wine has a slippery texture and plenty of zippy fruit but again, the sulfur shows and the finish is a touch sour.

wine: Gabriel Meffre 2005 La Chasse du Pape Prestige Red (Côtes du Rhône)
appellation: Côtes du Rhône, Rhône Valley, France
review: A quaffable if somewhat innocuous Côtes-du-Rhône with modest cherry fruit. The blend of 60% Grenache, 30% Syrah and the remainder Cinsault and Mourvèdre is medium-bodied, then thins out a bit on the finish.

Lightly wood-aged Alvarinho has an inspired balance between freshness and a rich, open spicy character. The carefully judged wood brings out the natural creaminess of the variety, while keeping plenty of freshness and citrus flavors. Drink now.

Shingleback's 2009 displays the hallmarks of South Australian Cabernet: cassis, chocolate and mint notes and plenty of weight on the palate. The tannins are a little coarse, but that will only help the wine in the context of a steak dinner.

wine: Tenuta di Fessina 2014 Laeneo Nerello Cappuccio (Sicilia)
review: Made entirely with Nerello Cappuccio, this reveals aromas of raspberry compote, tilled earth, ripe berry and grilled herb. The juicy palate delivers fleshy black cherry, licorice, white pepper and a hint of sage alongside bright acidity and smooth tannins. It's already accessible. Drink through 2019.

wine: Charles Smith 2014 Broncho Stoneridge Vineyard Malbec (Washington)
review: The aromas erupt from the glass, with notes of potpourri, orange peel, moist earth, stem and garden herb. The palate shows a pleasing mix of earth and savory flavors that deliver a lot of elegance and intertwine effortlessly through the finish. The variety seems a bit hard to find but the expression is quite intriguing.

appellation: Santa Ynez Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: Crisp aromas of red apple, light raspberry, rose petal and a hint of chalk make for an intriguing nose on this Grenache-based rosé. The palate is tense and acid driven, offering flavors of cherry and light cola spice.

wine: Bouchaine 2009 Bacchus Collection Estate Vineyard Pinot Meunier (Carneros)
review: A tough wine to like. It's bone dry, hard in tannins and tartly acidic, and not very fruity, with flavors just barely suggesting sour cherries. On the plus side is elegant construction.

appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
review: A little peppery and lean, but time unleashes more heft, char and fruit than what's initially evident. In the mouth, it's full of plump berry and cherry notes, and maybe a touch of raisin (2003 was a hot year). Not the most agile, finesse-based red but still very good.

wine: Albert Bichot 2007 Domaine du Clos Frantin Clos de Vougeot  (Clos de Vougeot)
designation: Domaine du Clos Frantin Clos de Vougeot
review: There is power here, but it is hidden behind an exterior of sweet fruit. The black plum juice freshness fronts dark, dry tannins, a core of steel. The ripe fruit is already delicious, but those tannins shows this dense wine's aging potential.

wine: Haka by Labyrinth 2010 Freebird Red (Paso Robles)
appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: This blend of Merlot and Tempranillo, with touches of Petit Verdot and Cabernet Sauvignon, opens with notes of warm cherry pie, black tobacco and cedar. Fresh boysenberry starts the palate, with mouthwatering spice in the midpalate and mocha on the finish.
This dry, mature wine tastes older than a 10-Year-Old, with complex wood aging, spirit and acidity that have taken over from the fruitiness. It is serious and structured.

appellation: Southern Oregon, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
review: Chewy, earthy and tannic, this rather awkward wine matches cranberry and black cherry hard candy fruit to a rough, stemmy underbelly. There is some leather and barnyard in the middle; all in all it's a bit of a rough ride.
Ripe and smooth, this is rich with red berries. A touch of pepper accompanies a zesty texture that backs up the fruitiness. Drink now.

wine: Carol Shelton 2019 Wild Thing Rendezvous Rosé (Mendocino County)
appellation: Mendocino County, Mendocino County, California, US
review: A bright, deep-pink color and intense candied fruit aromas make this medium-bodied wine dramatic to sip. An edgy raspberry vein takes over the finish.

Generous ripeness is already apparent on the juicy, almost tropically inflected notes of pear on the nose of this wine. Juicy, mellow and fresh, the palate comes with creaminess that accentuates the richness. The finish is off dry and mellow.

wine: Spy Valley 2016 Hand Picked Single Estate Chardonnay (Marlborough)
review: Aromas of onion mask prettier nuances of citrus, grapefruit and toast on the nose. It's slippery with tingly acidity on the palate, but the fruit seems somewhat sour and the toasty oak flavors at the finish throw off the wine's balance a little.

wine: Chateau Faire Le Pont 2004 Provence Red (Washington)
review: Despite excellent vineyard sources, this is overripe for my palate, with flavors that are pruney and soft, and lacking definition and authority. It's soft and mysteriously weightless, with figgy fruit and a quick finish.

wine: Rideau 2003 Iris' Estate Bon Temps Vineyard Syrah (Santa Ynez Valley)
appellation: Santa Ynez Valley, Central Coast, California, US
