review: Combines an intensely pepery note with dense plum-cake fruit and elevated (16.4%) alcohol, yet remains appealing thanks to a full, rich mouthfeel and supple tannins. The plum, dried spice and pepper flavors mostly obscure the high alcohol, leading to a long, spicy finish.

appellation: Amarone della Valpolicella Classico, Veneto, Italy
review: Earthy aromas of tilled soil, meat juices and blackberry are accompanied by flavors of black cherry and nutmeg. The palate is already evolved and shows tertiary aromas, with a slight warmth throughout, so drink over the next few years.

appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
review: Equal proportions of Cabernet Franc and Merlot yield this penetrating sour-cherry palate touched with nuts, smoke, bramble and herb. It's refreshingly light bodied, marked by a crush of cranberry acidity and finely grained tannins.
Aromatically subtle but ripe notes of yellow pear match the creamy mouthfeel, which has a pleasantly pebbly undertone and soft, almost cushioned acidity.
This elegant red is earthy, with highlights of clove, currant and cedar. The midpalate is thick, concentrated and intense, built by a bold tannic grip that eases as it sits in the glass.

Earthen notes of honeycomb, pollen and stone accent pristine lemon and lime in this dry, slightly savory Riesling. It's a zesty, peppery wine that's invigorating and spry on the palate. Enjoy now through 2021.

wine: Saints Hills 2010 Sv Roko Plavac Mali (Neretvansko Vinogorje)
review: Bright red cherry and plum flavors are cloaked in layers of chocolate, leather and dried herbs on this lush, luxurious Plavac Mali. The palate is deeply penetrating with ripe black fruit, and a tannic structure that builds in density towards the finish. Soft floral notes add a feminine flair.

Enticingly delicate scents of peach blossom, white stone fruit and wild herb mingle with whiffs of almond on this vibrant white. The bright savory palate shows Granny Smith apple, grapefruit, pineapple and a saline mineral note alongside crisp acidity.

wine: Swiftwater Cellars 2013 Black Diamond Red (Columbia Valley (WA))
appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: This wine is a blend of Merlot, Cabernet Sauvignon, Malbec, Cabernet Franc and Petit Verdot. Aromas of wood spice, herbs, black fruit and flowers lead to a full bodied palate with dark chocolate and cherry flavors, showing a lovely sense of balance.

wine: Quinta do Passadouro 2008 Passadouro Reserva Red (Douro)
review: From Passadouro's old vines, this is serious, complex wine. Its fruit is an integral part of the dark tannic structure, adding to the gentle power. It has spice as well as juicy fruit, wood and, on the finish, sweet fruit flavors.

wine: Chateau La Tour Carnet 2005  Bordeaux Blanc
review: A spicy, nutty wine, with fresh white fruits and some richness. A high proportion of the rare Sauvignon Gris gives this wine an attractive aromatic quince element, supported by judicious new wood.

wine: Domaine Jessiaume 2014 Les Cent Vignes Premier Cru  (Beaune)
review: This rich wine has spice and red fruits backed by a dry texture. The smoky wood is still right up front, giving the wine a firm character. Wait for the fruit to develop further and drink from 2020.

Notes of crushed berries on polished mahogany come to mind. This is elegant and classic, its strucure is firm but not imposing, the tone is one of subtlety and elegance. This stands straight and presents honest, dark fruit and leaves with a long, velvety train of spiced berry, more mahogany and a touch of forest floor Very alluring.

This small estate, dedicated to white wines only, is part of the same stable as Château Haut-Brion itself. This superb wine is packed with ripe, sweet fruit, but equally importantly, shows intensity, layers of wood, a great citrus character and the acidity so typical of 2002. This is a long-term wine: drink in 10–15 years.
A hugely rich wine, from a biodynamic vineyard; it will be immensely long-lived. Its sweet fruit contrasts with brooding tannins and intense herbal essences. Drink this in 10 years.

Blended with 14% Cabernet Franc, this succeeds in its light-bodied palate of red currant, cranberry and plum, with secondary characteristics of pencil shavings and graphite. The midpalate is thick and concentrated, finishing with elegance.

wine: Strange Family Vineyards 2015 Pinot Noir (Sta. Rita Hills)
appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
review: Dried cherry, stewed mulberry, orange peel and Christmas spices play on the nose of this bottling. Extracted flavors of dried red plums, fig and a hint of raisin are lifted by bay leaf and eucalyptus on the tangy palate.

wine: Korbel 2009 Made with Organically Grown Grapes Brut Sparkling (California)
designation: Made with Organically Grown Grapes Brut
review: A sweetly delicious bubbly, with fine bubbles and a rich yeastiness to the citrus, cherry and vanilla flavors. The blend is of French Colombard, Chardonnay and Sangiovese.

Entirely stainless-steel fermented and oak aged—the oak neutral—this is a formidably memorable wine, fulsome and balanced in anise and juicy Gravenstein apple and peach. On the palate it's lush and creamy, with supportive acidity maintaining welcome, lasting freshness.

Spicy in honeyed oak, this full-bodied wine is bright in acidity and strong flavors of lime and lemon verbena. Balanced and integrated despite its complete embrace of ripeness, it allows for a brightness of acidity beneath grainy texture and grip.

wine: Ulrich Langguth 2014 Piesporter Günterslay Kabinett Riesling (Mosel)
review: While rich and almost nectar like in ripeness, this vibrantly peachy, floral wine is kept in check by an exhilarating strike of lime acidity. Off dry in style, it's concentrated and penetrating, yet bracingly sheer. It would be a showstopper apéritif at the most elegant cocktail party.

Solid and textured, this is a firm wine with a bright future. It has weight from its tannins as well as ripe berry fruits that shine through. Delicate acidity lightens the load. It does need to age, so drink from 2016.

wine: Montresor 2006 Castelliere delle Guaite  (Valpolicella Ripasso Classico)
review: This is a very intense and compelling Ripasso with bright tones of currant berry and blackberry that rise above a spicy base of cinnamon, chocolate and dried tobacco. The wine is smooth and soft although it finishes with power and determination.

A full, rich nose of blackberry, cinnamon and black pepper introduces this impressive Shiraz from mover and shaker Marc Kent. Balanced and elegant with a restrained minerality, this is a food-friendly and structured without being rugged.

wine: Lava Vine 2016 Mangels Vineyard Grenache (Suisun Valley)
appellation: Suisun Valley, North Coast, California, US
review: Warm, generous plum flavors meet subtle spices, a full body and soft tannins in this rich and inviting wine. Plums, mulled cherries and a hint of strawberries are accented lightly with cinnamon and vanilla.

Made from organic grapes, this is a seductively perfumed Syrah shaded by savory tones of smoked meat, cacao and sun-dried herbs. Pristine black-fruit flavors are powerfully concentrated yet briskly balanced, framed by a grip of raspy tannins and vibrant acidity. It's a lovely wine to enjoy now through 2030.

Jadot is one of about 80 owners of tiny parcels in this walled, five-acre vineyard. This wine is as much about rich, generous opulence as about structure. An ethereal fragrance moves into the powerful black fruits and velvet tannins. The wine will develop slowly and surely, ready to drink from 2027.

wine: Bucci 2012  Verdicchio dei Castelli di Jesi Classico Superiore
appellation: Verdicchio dei Castelli di Jesi Classico Superiore, Central Italy, Italy
review: This classic bottling opens with enticing floral aromas of Spanish broom, acacia and a whiff of flint. The palate delivers succulent yellow peach, citrus and almond along with mineral notes. It boasts impeccable balance and nice length.

A big, powerful, fruity wine, this is laden with dry tannins as well as blackberry flavor. Dark and concentrated, it has a solid, dense feel with fruits layered with intense wood notes. It needs at least five years to soften and round out.
Spicy aromas give this wine a contrast between fruit and nutty flavors. The texture is balanced by hints of tropical fruits at the end. Drink from 2020.

appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
review: This wine falls short of its rather lofty ambitions with lavish new French oak treatment resulting in a diminished fruit profile. Sawdust notes dominate the nose while the faintest hint of cherry can be detected on the palate. Finishes a bit tart. A good choice for those hankering for a vanilla milkshake.
This is fragrant and varietally-correct on the nose. Quince, lemon-lime and lychee flavors show their best right away before turning decidedly sweet on the finish.
Attractively perfumed and also with firm, young tannins, this wine has density and signs of wood aging. It is still young and coming together. Drink from 2022.

appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Rich and smoky, this Sauvignon Blanc-Sémillon blend delivers a nose suggesting golden raisins, ripe figs, white peaches and light streaks of butter, honey and caramel. The fruit and wood are balanced and the alcohol is a moderate 13.5%. Everything here is in proportion, layered, smooth and seductive. More than past vintages, this is a Chaleur blanc that seems destined to age and develop over the next decade or more.

A firm and tannic wine, it is still developing. The dry structure and the smoky wood aging are dominant, giving a hard feel. It does have a juicy hint underneath, so the fruit will develop although tannins are going to remain prominent.

wine: Château Belles Eaux 2015 Les Coteaux White (Languedoc)
review: Pretty, light aromas of green melon rind, lime leaf, thyme, clover and just-dried grass dance on the nose of this white blend. The palate offers even less intensity, with a faint green-melon flavor and a thin yet clean mouthfeel. Drink now.

appellation: El Dorado, Sierra Foothills, California, US
review: Ripe and fruity, this full-bodied wine brims with melon and tangerine aromas and almost-sweet peach and melon flavors. It wraps them in a soothing, rich texture that encourages a long finish.

appellation: Ribera del Júcar, Central Spain, Spain
review: Ripe blueberry, black plum and violet aromas are sweet and ripe. This is a chunky, flat feeling Tempranillo with candied, soft blackberry and other black-fruit flavors. A short, simple finish fits this heavy wine's overall profile.

wine: Fall Creek 2012 Salt Lick Vineyards Tempranillo (Texas)
review: Smoky and savory on the nose, stewed blueberries mix with sweet barbecue sauce aromas. The palate shows fresher black fruit supported by grainy tannins.

appellation: Dry Creek Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: Sometimes you just need a tasty, inexpensive Sauvignon Blanc to wash down almost anything, and here you go. It's dryish and zesty in acidity, with white currant, green grass and tropical fruit flavors that are rich enough to accompany grilled salmon. Grows more interesting as you sip.

wine: Bodega San Pedro Regalado 2008 Embocadero  (Ribera del Duero)
appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
review: Broad, dark and meaty, with aromas of leather and beef broth. The palate comes on as bulky and tannic, but the flavors are full and deep even if they are also a touch soupy and meaty. Good for a 2008 midlevel RDD, but nothing to get excited over.

appellation: Eola-Amity Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: This hits the palate with full force—a stylish effort that coats the tongue with lush stone fruit flavors, elevated with citrus-tinged acidity. A light touch of barrel toast frames the lovely fruit. Drink now through the mid-2020s.

Jammy and lush smelling, yet more racy, acidic and flashy in the mouth. Flavors of cherry and raspberry are saturated and dense, but the feel is kind of hard and narrow. Minty and a little warm on the finish. 70% Malbec and 30% Petit Verdot.

wine: Clos de la Coulée de Serrant 2002 Clos de la Coulée de Serrant  (Savennières-Coulée de Serrant)
winery: Clos de la Coulée de Serrant
designation: Clos de la Coulée de Serrant
appellation: Savennières-Coulée de Serrant, Loire Valley, France
review: Nicolas Joly and his mother are possessors of the smallest appellation in France: Coulée de Serrant. This almost vertical vineyard, dropping down to the Loire, facing due south, makes a mythical wine that is powerful and laden with exotic fruit flavors: oranges, lemon, apricots, accented with spices and the tannins of a youthful white wine. This will last for decades. Imported by Vintus.

wine: Vinadeis 2016 Le Val Sauvignon Blanc (Vin de France)
appellation: Vin de France, France Other, France
review: This warm style of Sauvignon Blanc has easygoing acidity and gooseberry fruit flavors. It's lightly tangy, with a bright, crisp texture.

appellation: Ribbon Ridge, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: The slightly tawny straw color suggests incipient oxidation, and the wine's flatness in the mouth confirms it. The vivid, peppery quality for which the grape is known is nowhere evident. The flavors are autumnal, like apples just past the point of optimal ripeness, so this wine should be consumed as soon as possible.

wine: Arista 2013 Toboni Vineyard Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)
appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: From a longtime vineyard source, this wine opens with dried herb and menthol aromas. It's exotic on the palate too, with seductive, silky-smooth texture and a tightness of acidity. Black cherry meets black tea and pomegranate, with just the slightest remembrance of cola. Drink now through 2023.

wine: Di Lenardo 2007 Vigneto Vigne da Lis Maris Chardonnay (Friuli Grave)
review: This luminous wine has a smooth, creamy quality that is reinforced by generous aromas of pineapple, citrus, peach and a dot of vanilla. It tastes fruity and fresh, but doesn't lack in structure, and would pair well with mushroom risotto.

wine: Margarida Cabaco 2001 Monte dos Cabacos Red (Alentejano)
review: Like many of the Alentejano wines, this one is a blend of several grape varieties. In this case, it's Syrah, Cabernet Sauvignon, Touriga Nacional and Alicante Bouschet. The result is a broad, mouthfilling wine but one that lacks depth or richness. Black cherry and leather flavors are pleasant enough for washing down weeknight burgers. Imported by Vinum International.
There's an explosion of rich, intense fruit here: dried prunes, black plums and even some licorice. The wine is attractively edged with wood, giving a fine, ripe finish.

Fruit-forward, with green apple and lime aromas that are rounded out on the palate by a bit of peach. Light to medium in body, this fresh, crisp Chardonnay picks up citrusy notes on the finish. Imported by Total Beverage Solution.
91–93. Barrel Sample. Structured and firm, this wine has dark, concentrated tannins counterbalanced with plenty of freshest acidity. This composition shows promise for good aging.

wine: Ojai 2005 Thompson Vineyard Syrah (Santa Barbara County)
appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
review: So lush and soft, so delicious, you have to drink it right now. Shows impeccably dry, complex flavors of blackberries, cherries and cedar, with roasted meat, sassafras, spice and dried herb notes. Great with lamb.

This rich and dense wine shines with ripe Merlot, a product of the warm vintage. Dusty tannins, licorice and black-fruit flavors and plenty of spice from wood aging all contribute to the generally ripe effect of this generous wine. Drink from 2023.

wine: Mirabeau en Provence 2020 Belle Année Rosé (Vin de France)
appellation: Vin de France, France Other, France
review: This wine is all fruit, with bright red-berry and red-currant flavors. It is crisp while also warm and juicily fresh. Drink the wine now. Suitable for vegans.

wine: Two Sisters 2016 Lindsay's Vineyard Pinot Noir (Sta. Rita Hills)
appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
review: Aromas of rose petal, mulberry and violet make for an intriguing entry to this bottling. It's a smooth style of Pinot Noir, with soft tannins and a rich mouthfeel that carries flavors of violet and boysenberry.

wine: Besserat de Bellefon NV BB Blanc de Noirs Grand Cru Brut Pinot Noir (Champagne)
designation: BB Blanc de Noirs Grand Cru Brut
review: With its 100% Pinot Noir from grand cru vineyards, this Champagne has great richness and good structure. Freshness balances with the strong mineral texture that gives the wine a tight edge. Drink the bottling from late 2021.

wine: J. Lohr 2018 Pure Paso Proprietary Red (Paso Robles)
appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: This blend of 69% Cabernet Sauvignon, 27% Petite Sirah, 2% Syrah and 2% Malbec offers aromas of black-cherry pie, toasty brioche and fresh mint on the nose. That minty element carries to the palate, where more black cherry and fudge flavors are wrapped in ample acidity and chalky tannins.

Full bodied and lushly textured, this is not a typical Marlborough Sauvignon. On the nose, there's a restrained smoky character and some grapefruit, while the plate bursts with lovely pink grapefruit and some understated leafiness. It's all brought together by a balanced, harmonious finish.

wine: Sarah's Vineyard 2015 Estate Pinot Noir (Santa Clara Valley)
appellation: Santa Clara Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: Red cherry, rust, cinnamon, vanilla and wet herbs make for a crisp and compelling nose on this bottling by winemaker Tim Slater, who manages to elicit cooler climate properties from a warmer region. A wide array of herbs, including thyme, oregano, marjoram and sage, decorate the firmly structured hibiscus, red currant and cranberry backdrop. The acid goes deep into the finish.

wine: Cono Sur 2008 Organically Grown Grapes Cabernet Sauvignon-Carmenère (Colchagua Valley)
review: Hard and inky on first blush, with aromas of shoe polish and wild, aggressive fruit. A far more narrow and acidic wine than we expected to find, with racy, short, blue fruit flavors. Bright and choppy, with a short finish. Seems underdeveloped.

wine: Vallformosa 2000 Mas La Roca Selección Especial Syrah (Penedès)
review: Dark and smoky, almost like a burnt wooden match on top of plum purée. Runs a bit tart in the mouth for Syrah, with red raspberry and cherry flavors. Firm and lean in the mouth.

wine: Brick House NV House Red Made with Biodynamic Grapes Pinot Noir (Ribbon Ridge)
designation: House Red Made with Biodynamic Grapes
appellation: Ribbon Ridge, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: The fire-impacted 2020 vintage led founder Doug Tunnell to declassify all the fruit and create this blend, which includes a significant portion of 2019 juice. The winner here is you, the consumer. Delicious blackberry fruit, hints of coffee and chocolate, smooth tannins and a lush mouthfeel make this immediately enjoyable.

wine: Kevin White 2015 DuBrul Vineyard Red (Yakima Valley)
appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Coming from one of the state's top vineyards, this wine is a blend of Merlot (52%) and Cabernet Sauvignon. The aromas pop, with achingly pure notes of raspberry, assorted dried herb, pie cherry, blueberry and spice. The palate shows finesse and grace, with silky fruit flavors and velvety tannins, with savory notes on a finish that won't quit. It's a flat-out gorgeous, exquisitely understated interpretation of this vineyard.

wine: Henri de Villamont 2015 Sous le Puits Premier Cru  (Puligny-Montrachet)
review: This naturally cool vineyard fared well in warm 2015, giving wine that has retained minerality and a crisp texture. It is fruity, while having a tight edge as well as layers of acidity. Drink from 2020.

wine: Villa Monteleone 2009 Campo Santa Lena  (Valpolicella Classico)
review: Easy on the nose and mouth, offering simple aromas of cherry, blueberry and white almond. In the mouth, it delivers an informal, lean approach.

wine: Carol Shelton 2019 Coquille Rouge Red (Central Coast)
appellation: Central Coast, Central Coast, California, US
review: Living legend Carol Shelton sources from the town of Oakley in the San Joaquin Delta region for this blend of Carignan, Grenache, Mourvèdre, Alicante Bouschet and Petite Sirah. Oaky aromas of vanilla, dark berry and violet lead into a palate of cola, sarsaparilla, cinnamon and baked strawberry flavors.

appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
review: A little earthy and rough at first, with rubbery aromas. After time it evolves to deliver a weighty palate full of black fruit, oak and medicinality. Dry, toasty and a bit hot and scratchy on the finish. Nice for $11 Ribera del Duero.
Like the label suggests, it's sugary in tangerine, vanilla cookie and butterscotch flavors, with crisp acidity and fine, scoury bubbles. A nice sparkling wine for those who like a sweeter style.
This smells like a melted Luden's cough drop sprinkled with coffee grounds and spices. Medium bodied, it has a jumbled herbal flavor, finishing with warmth and notes of dark chocolate and coffee.

wine: Bailly-Lapierre 2013 Vive-la-Joie Rosé Brut  (Crémant de Bourgogne)
review: Strawberry shortcake notes abound on the fresh nose of this wine, which conveys the fresh fruit, creaminess and richness of the pastry. The palate puts these all in a tight, fresh corset, vivid with liveliness. Fine foam makes everything exuberant and bright. The finish is alluring and dry.

wine: Château Clairac 2013  Blaye Côtes de Bordeaux
appellation: Blaye Côtes de Bordeaux, Bordeaux, France
review: This lightly oaked wine is already balanced with some attractive dusty tannins and red currant fruit flavors. It is bright with acidity and with a fresh, fruity aftertaste. Drink from 2016. This is a Carreau family estate.

wine: Maison Bleue 2007 La Vallée du Soleil Roussanne (Yakima Valley)
appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: This reverses the blend of the Viognier; it's 85% Roussanne and 15% Viognier and finishes in a rather surprisingly sweet, off-dry style with 1.4% residual sugar. White peach and spicy pear fruit flavors are bright and fleshy, while the sweetness is offset by moderate acids. For those who prefer some sweetness in their white wines, this is an excellent choice.

Earthen notes of crushed mineral and bramble juxtapose lip-smacking lemon, lime and white grapefruit here. It's a spine-tingling, piercing wine edged by delicate hints of sweetness and a pleasantly savory, salty finish. It needs more time to open but is structured enough to improve through 2035.

wine: Tres Palacios 2012 Family Vintage Cabernet Sauvignon (Maipo Valley)
review: Leafy, herbal aromas of plum and raspberry show a touch of tomato, with a dash of oregano. This is soft on the palate, without a lot of spine or structure. Earthy, herbal flavors of stewed berries, tomato and green herbs finish minty and leafy, but with good feel.

wine: La Forge Estate 2008 Unfiltered Merlot (Vin de Pays d'Oc)
appellation: Vin de Pays d'Oc, Languedoc-Roussillon, France
review: The bright and inviting nose is loaded with lively red fruit, including raspberries and cherries, along with a soft hint of vanilla. Incredibly lightweight with soft fruit flavors; easy to drink.

Just a hint of sweet mesquite lends spice on the nose of this juicy, bright-fruited Chardonnay. Medium bodied and plump in yellow apple, pear and Mirabelle flavors, it's a fruit-forward, elegant sip best enjoyed young.

appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: A rich and smooth vintage for Abbinare, once again a Bordeaux-style blend that is half Merlot, and roughly 20% each Cabernet Sauvignon and Cabernet Franc. Purple fruits are swathed in milk-chocolaty tannins. It's full, firm, dense and immediately appealing, with aftertastes suggesting graphite and vanilla.

wine: Château Pertignas 2016 Cuvée de Copains  (Bordeaux Supérieur)
review: This wine holds fruit that was too ripe, giving a clumsy character. It has structure as well as bright acidity, but the wine is spoiled by the jamminess.

wine: Sanfeletto NV Brut  (Conegliano Valdobbiadene Prosecco Superiore)
appellation: Conegliano Valdobbiadene Prosecco Superiore, Veneto, Italy
review: Delicate aromas of Spanish broom and pear come with a hint of nuts on the nose. The palate offers yellow peach, green apple and a mineral note alongside vibrant acidity and small, persistent bubbles.

wine: Golan Heights Winery 2014 Yarden Sauvignon Blanc (Galilee)
review: Light straw to the eye, this wine offers aromas of pineapple, grapefruit and cut grass. There is a nice balance of citrus and herbal notes on the taste buds, with flavors of pear, peach, lemon and chopped parsley and basil. It has a bright, fresh finish.
Heavy and flat, with dull apple aromas. The palate delivers simple yellow fruit, while the finish is soft and devoid of spunk. There isn't a whole lot more to say about this wine; it's a cipher.

wine: Walt 2017 Gap's Crown Vineyard Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)
review: Fresh in cherry and pomegranate, this is a full-bodied, robustly ripe and tannic wine, that is also oaky and powerful. Bold fistfuls of Asian spice give it complexity and balance.

wine: Sartarelli 2008 Balciana  (Verdicchio dei Castelli di Jesi Classico Superiore)
appellation: Verdicchio dei Castelli di Jesi Classico Superiore, Central Italy, Italy
review: Light golden in color, this has ripe aromas of stone fruit, apricot, honey, grapefruit and dried herb. It has freshness and structure, and the finish lasts for many long minutes.

appellation: El Dorado, Sierra Foothills, California, US
review: This handsomely oaked wine sprinkles ginger, cinnamon and clove over ripe and vibrant black-cherry flavors that are wrapped in moderate tannins for a grippy mouthfeel. Tempting now for its warm spices and deep fruit, it will be best from 2024.

wine: Frei Brothers 2009 Reserve Cabernet Sauvignon (Alexander Valley)
review: This treads the line between simple and complex, showing ripe flavors of blackberries and cherries that seem sweet, although the finish is dry. Softly tannic, this is made for drinking now.

wine: Chandon 2003 L'étoile Tête de Cuvée Sparkling (Napa County-Sonoma County)
appellation: Napa County-Sonoma County, Napa-Sonoma, California, US
review: L'Etoile is Chandon's highest expression of brut-style sparkling wine, and with this bottling, they've exceeded their reputation. The wine is as smooth as silk, like honey gliding over the palate, carrying lime, grapefuit, peach and raspberry flavors. A certain softness may limit ageability, so drink now.

wine: Errazuriz 2005 Don Maximiano Founder's Reserva Red (Aconcagua Valley)
review: The best Don Max in quite some time. After too many herbal-green vintages, the 2005 is ripe, rich and well woven. The bouquet shows hickory, roasted plum, chocolate, vanilla and peanut. The palate, meanwhile, is all about pure cassis, blackberry, mocha and spice. Finishes with a dash of caramel and earthy fruit leftovers. Honest, rugged and ready, but ageable for at least another 3–4 years.

This is a gem, with lots of up-front toast. A typical  structured year for Champagne, this has clean, round fruit, but retains good acid, providing firm support and longer-term aging potential than the '95. It floats into a pleasing, vanilla cream and toast finish.

appellation: Central Coast, Central Coast, California, US
review: Dust and earth aromas cover underlying apple flavors in this simple, rather sweet wine. Excessively soft acidity makes it drink syrupy. Still, it has basic Chard features and will satisfy most big crowds. —S.H.

This blend of 80% Merlot and 20% Cabernet Franc has a satisfyingly rich and perfumed character. It is dense both with tannins and black fruits, ripe and with enough concentration to promise good aging. Drink from 2023.

wine: Simon Gilbert 2004 Central Ranges Semillon-Sauvignon Blanc (New South Wales)
appellation: New South Wales, New South Wales, Australia
review: What we get of this Semillon-Sauvignon Blanc is nice, but there's just not enough of it to go around. Mineral and green grape flavors fade into fresh herbs on the palate, but the flavors are less than intense. Peach skin and grass aromas are joined by some rubber on the nose. Has potential; just wants to be dialed up a little louder.

wine: Hayward by Folin Cellars 2012 Utopia Vineyard Pinot Noir (Ribbon Ridge)
appellation: Ribbon Ridge, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: This is winemaker Rob Folin's side project, sourcing grapes from the excellent Utopia Vineyard in the heart of the Willamette Valley. It captures the elegance, precision and depth of that specific location. Toasty, spicy and focused, it's structured around bright, deep raspberry and Bing cherry fruit. The lush baking spices are the perfect frame.

Dark and tough, this shows considerable wood at this early stage. Like many Faiveley wines, it is tough and tannic when young, with a dry core. But I also taste red fruits, fresh acidity and a lively, fresh aftertaste. Just be patient.

wine: Domaine Castel Oualou 2016 Fût de Chêne Red (Lirac)
review: Oak aging lends a savory, earthen quality to fleshy black-cherry and plum flavors in this wine. Medium bodied and restrained in style, the black-fruit flavors are intensely ripe and concentrated but also muted and smoky. Approachable now the wine should hold through 2023.

This perfumed wine is now approaching maturity. Aged in wood, the wine has spice backing up elegant tannins that are fully integrated into the ripe black fruits. Acidity keeps everything fresh. Drink from 2021.

A plush, fairly flashy style, this wine starts with ripe, bright red fruit, licorice, raspberry leaf and some savory undertones. The palate bumps the style up a notch, with powerful tannins and plenty of acidity. Perhaps the more intriguing element to this Pinot is the finish: Tart cranberry and floral tones are long and lingering.

appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: The aromas explore Cabernet's greener side, with overt notes of bell pepper along with vanilla and other barrel spices. The black-fruit flavors show richness, with grainy tannins backing them up. This wine is best for those who enjoy the variety's savory aspects.

Ripe plum and berry aromas are supported by a full dose of smoky, savory oak. The palate is round yet jagged, while flavors of toasty, chocolaty berry fruits are also lightly herbal and heavily oaked.

An effusively fruity, unoaked style of Chardonnay, with bold flavors of pear, apple and citrus and maybe even a touch of mango. Its charms are upfront for all to see, as it loses a bit of intensity and lacks length on the finish.

Brandy soaked plum and plenty of sweet and savory spices grace the nose of this lush red. The palate is soft and supple, yet properly lifted by enough tangy red fruit to balance out the sweet spice flavors.

appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: This is made from 90% Pinot Noir and 10% Carignan, the grapes both bled and direct-pressed to make the wine. Light, crisp and meaty on the palate, it is weighty yet balanced, a celebration of cranberry, strawberry and rhubarb flavors.

Made of 50% Cabernet Sauvignon, 40% Syrah and 10% Teroldego, this boasts alluring ripe black currant and white pepper aromas, with a whiff of graphite. The firm palate offers juicy blackberry, black plum and tobacco notes, held together by polished tannins. Enjoy now–2025.

wine: Maison L'Envoyé 2014 Two Messengers Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)
appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: Young, bright raspberry fruit brings fresh, forward flavors front and center. There's a touch of cherry Popsicle also. It's an undeniably pretty wine, ready to drink, though don't look for much in the way of either depth or concentration.
This is a light, soft and creamy wine, with an apricot aroma and flavor, fresh acidity and an attractive fruity aftertaste. It is crisp in green apple and grapefruit notes on the finish.
Montepulciano grapes are aged six months in oak to render sweet nuances of cinnamon and toasted almond that rest over a dense core of jammy fruit. The wine is lush, soft and velvety on the finish.

wine: Companhia das Quintas 2005 Quinta da Pancas Reserva Cabernet Sauvignon Cabernet Sauvignon (Estremadura)
designation: Quinta da Pancas Reserva Cabernet Sauvignon
review: Even Cabernet Sauvignon, that defiantly international variety, takes on a Portuguese character. This has that dark chocolate, high acidity and dry, but juicy character that marks so many Portuguese reds. It also has a more unfortunate volatility that is just too prominent.

Here's a nice and dark Cab with black licorice, clove, pepper and blackberry aromas. The palate is ripe and sweet, with roundness and serious depth. Finishes with chocolate and mint as well as some lushness.

A big, rich wine, candy-sweet in fruit and toasted oak. Shows the blackberry, cherry, nougat, roasted almond and chocolate flavors of a delicious granola bar. The tannins are a work of art, soft, intricate and refined.

wine: Atwater 2013 North Block Six Cabernet Franc (Seneca Lake)
appellation: Seneca Lake, Finger Lakes, New York, US
review: This wine is a fine showcase of Cabernet Franc's seemingly contradictory juxtaposition of ripe fruit flavors against its herbaceous green elements. Black cherry and berry flavors are succulent and mouthwatering, yet show a savory restraint anchored by swathes of ripe bramble and dusty herbs. It's an elegant yet easing drinking wine marked by fine, penetrating tannins.
Aromas of green bean and citrus peel struggle to impress. This feels raw and pinching, with pulling, dry tannins. Herbal red-plum flavors finish green and with an oaky note of carob.

Crafted from a range of vineyards, including Gap's Crown and some new sites in this vintage, this lovely, well-made and balanced wine is made in larger quantities than the producer's vineyard-designates and is enjoyable young. Creamy and full bodied at first, it evolves into cohesive flavors of baked pear, toasted almond and lemon-lime.

wine: Melini 2007 Le Grillaie  (Vernaccia di San Gimignano)
appellation: Vernaccia di San Gimignano, Tuscany, Italy
review: A simple, no-fuss Vernaccia with clean aromas of stone fruit and passion fruit, this Tuscan white would make a good companion to pasta salad or a lunchtime sandwich. The wine doesn't have big intensity, but offers clean freshness instead.

appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: Pretty strawberry and milk chocolate scents introduce a new wine from a company that says its offerings are based on algorithms. This one, algorithmic or not, is a fairly ordinary bottle of Oregon Pinot, tightly wound and earthy, with some bitter phenolics.

wine: K Vintners 2006 Morrison Lane Syrah (Walla Walla Valley (WA))
appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Black cherry and berry fruits are front and center, tannins are ripe but carry an herbal edge, and the time in barrels adds a chocolaty underpinning. The finish goes dark, with mocha, espresso, black olive and smoke, and the alcohol rests at a sensible 14.5%.
Prickly and generic, with flat, cushy citrus flavors that don't hold court for long. Finishes mealy and pithy, with the essence of lemon juice.

wine: Armida 2004 check price Sauvignon Blanc (Russian River Valley)
appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: Herbal and bulky, with sweet apple, pear and pineapple flavors. Quite heavy on the tongue, with soft acids. Seems a bit gummy and candied, and just not that precise, despite delivering some rich flavors.

wine: Domaine des Bouzons 2018 La Félicité Red (Côtes du Rhône)
appellation: Côtes du Rhône, Rhône Valley, France
review: This piquant Syrah-dominant blend is augmented by 20% Grenache. The palate is packed with black cherry and boysenberry flavors edged by sun-scorched garrigue and hits of black pepper and clove. Primary and fruit forward yet angular and fresh, the wine is ready to drink now through 2025.

Here's a rich and layered blend of Barbera and Cabernet Sauvignon from Piedmont, Italy with deep layers of black fruit, spice, mesquite wood and chocolate. The wine is modern and very likeable with rich density and long-lasting flavors. The mouthfeel is smooth, round and there's a slightly sweet vanilla note on the close.

wine: Ruby Hill Winery 2015 Jewel Collection Series Estate Reserve Malbec (Livermore Valley)
appellation: Livermore Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: Powerful and earthy, this rich and concentrated wine is full bodied, broad in texture and has envelope-pushing spice and leather aromas backed by well-concentrated wild-berry and plum-compote flavors of significant depth. It's seductive and lavish in character.

wine: XYZin 2009 100 Year Old Vines Zinfandel (Dry Creek Valley)
appellation: Dry Creek Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: A big, full-bodied, rich Zinfandel, bone dry and spicy, with impressive flavors of wild berries, herbs, balsam and smoke. Needs equally big fare to stand up to, like barbecue slathered in sauce.

Citric lift emerges from creaminess on the nose of this wine, promising freshness. The broad, round palate is still raw with yeasty notions. but a vein of lemony brightness awaits underneath. With time, the generous, creamy wine will coalesce around it. Drink 2022–2030.

wine: Boas Quintas 2019 Herdade de Gâmbia Reserva Red (Península de Setúbal)
review: This estate, in a nature reserve, has produced a deliciously fruity wine with ripe berry fruits and smooth tannins. The blend of Touriga Nacional and Syrah is rich and very ready to drink.

This smooth rich wine, dominated by Touriga Nacional, is full of both crisp fruit and bright acidity. It has a good depth of flavor, red fruits and good weight behind the attractive final acidity. Drink now.

wine: Uptick Vineyards NV Sparkling Brut Sparkling (North Coast)
appellation: North Coast, North Coast, California, US
review: Made from 60% Chardonnay and 40% Pinot Noir, this is a young, light sparkler with developed flavors of honey, lychee and apple. The body is crisp and medium in weight, and it finishes tart in lemon.

Foxy berry aromas mixed with forced-oak scents of clove create a jumpy sum of disparate parts. A tight, drawing palate is basic at best, while this tastes tart, woody and limited, with herbal plum and berry flavors on the finish.
Crisp, lively and elegant, with peaches, pears, apricots, orange and spice flavors all beautifully integrated.  Long and bright to the very end.

Aromas suggesting toasted nut, bread dough, chamomile and stone fruit waft out of the glass. The shy, straightforward palate suggests yellow apple skin, lemon zest and a hint of bitter almond alongside crisp acidity.

wine: Ravoire et Fils 2019 Jas Du Lauzon White (Luberon)
review: Fresh lime and tangerine from 10% each of Ugni Blanc and Clairette accent this pineapple-scented Grenache-Blanc blend. An ample, rounded wine marked by soft lemon acidity and easy yellow apple and pear flavors, it's a wine at peak now but likely to hold through 2024.

appellation: Guenoc Valley, Lake County, California, US
review: Very rich and opulent, a Chardonnay that can stand on its own alongside most anything from the Russian River. Crisp in acidity, and fueled with oak, it shows complex flavors of pineapples, Asian pears, buttered cinnamon toast, vanilla custard and smoke.
This pure expression of Primitivo is partially aged in oak for added extra structure and concentration. The bouquet here is characterized by jammy strawberry and bitter almond notes.

wine: Bailly-Lapierre NV Réserve Brut  (Crémant de Bourgogne)
review: Bright and fruity, this is an apple and crisp green-fruit-flavored wine. There is a hint of the maturity to come, giving a light toastiness while the fruit remains crisp and refreshing. Drink now.

appellation: Anderson Valley, Mendocino County, California, US
review: This is a well-balanced medium-bodied wine that has everything in good proportion. The aromas are lightly fruity, like green apples, the tangy apple flavors are touched with of fresh herbs, and the texture is fresh and crisp.

Like much from this ruggedly dry appellation, this bottling is tightly wound and should stand the test of time. Dark aromas of black currant, crisp blackberry, violet, game and graphite lead into a tense, chalky palate with dark fruit and black pepper flavors. Drink 2022–2037.

appellation: Central Coast, Central Coast, California, US
review: The winery's 2012 dry whites offer plenty of value-driven quality, as usual. This Pinot Gris is crisp, clean and minerally, like cold snowmelt in the mouth. The citrus, honeysuckle, vanilla and white pepper flavors are a delight.

Chardonnay is not Argentina's calling card, but this basic version issues apple, butter cup and mineral aromas backed by zesty, sheer citrus and pineapple flavors. Expect no heft or oak on this. It's straightforward warm-climate Chard, nothing more or less.

A bouquet of cherry, white chocolate and juniper berry sets the stage for flavors of raspberry, blackberry, blueberry pie and baking spices. It is smooth in the mouth, with a sense of soft sweetness that is neither overpowering nor cloying, bolstered by a pervasive backbone of acidity.
Yet another fine effort from this Marlborough winery, the 2002 Sauvignon Blanc is a big, rich, mouthfilling wine. Hints of honey and smoke accent gooseberries and nectarines. Drink now.

Melon, yellow apple, yeast and celery swirl on nose and palate, creating a savory, spicy vortex. Nuances of watercress and something even more savory, like lovage, lurk in fruity ripeness. Take time over this lovely, original wine and it will reveal almost all its secrets. The length is wonderful and apple-scented.

appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: Slightly tart aromas of black fruit meet with turned earth, campfire and incense on the savory nose of this bottling from the Riboli family. Cooked black-currant and olive flavors combine with roasted beef and cocoa on the thick palate.

This mellow and minerally wine brings savory elements to the aromas and flavors rather than overt fruity ones, giving it an unusual and interesting complexity. Earthy tones meet subtle fennel and lemon flavors on the palate, and good concentration leads to a lingering finish.

wine: Thomas Fogarty 2018 Mindego Ridge Vineyard Pinot Noir (Santa Cruz Mountains)
appellation: Santa Cruz Mountains, Central Coast, California, US
review: Intriguing aromas of tar, nori and juniper float above the core of blistered plums on the nose of this bottling. The bay leaf and green-sansho-pepper elements are prominent on the sip, spicing up the underripe currant and cranberry flavors, leaving the palate with a menthol sensation.

wine: Domaine du Haut Bourg 2020 La Désirée de Haut Bourg Sur Lie  (Muscadet Côtes de Grandlieu)
designation: La Désirée de Haut Bourg Sur Lie
appellation: Muscadet Côtes de Grandlieu, Loire Valley, France
review: A selection from different parcels, this wine is full of fresh apple flavors that are lifted by acidity and smoothed by a creamy texture. This Muscadet has the potential for some aging. Drink from 2022.

This medium-bodied wine is graceful and well balanced, offering crisp lemon and green-apple flavors on a rather lean, tangy texture. It is nuanced and complex, and has a nice tension from tantalizing acidity.

appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: In this warm, ripe, lush and forward vintage, winemaker John Abbott has outdone himself. This is immediately appealing, sending a rush of black cherry and cassis fruit backed with darker notes of coffee, smoke and licorice. The flavors are dense and supple, and the wine combines grace and power, unfolding with additional layers of tar, green tea and smoky herb.

wine: D'Arenberg 2012 The Laughing Magpie Shiraz-Viognier (McLaren Vale)
review: There's only 7% Viognier in this blend but it shows, lifting the aromas of green veg, orange rind and plum sauce with some welcome floral tones. It's got the d'Arenberg stamp of approachability: appealing tangy fruit and plenty of interesting secondary characters, but it's lacking the label's usual softness and, for the moment anyway, the oak is on the chunky side and the tannins a little chewy.

appellation: Applegate Valley, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
review: From the cool 2011 vintage, this wine brings notes of black tea, dark raspberries and herbs. It's tangy with lip-smacking plum and cranberry flavors backed by firm tannins.

wine: Jean-Luc and Paul Aegerter 2017 Les Beaumonts  (Chorey-lès-Beaune)
review: The small village next to Beaune produces ripe wines with generous tannins and the ability to age relatively quickly. This wine with cherry flavors and acidity has a light structure and great fruitiness. Drink from 2020.

A dry, spicy wine, with some good dense tannins. There is some power here, the dark fruits hinting at sweetness, but this is followed by the high acidity typical of the vintage. It should all come together in a year to 18 months.

wine: J. Lohr 2017 Los Osos Merlot (Paso Robles)
appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: This is a solid choice for midweek enjoyment. Generous aromas of ripe fresh red fruits meet with crushed slate, gravel and a kiss of sweet oak on the nose. It's lively on the palate, where juicy red cherry and oak framed by a spicy acidity.

appellation: Amador County, Sierra Foothills, California, US
review: A really great mountain Zinfandel that shows luscious power and fruit at a fair price. The flavors of blackberries, cherries, currants, oranges, cloves and white pepper flood the palate and are just wonderful to experience. At this price, buy this Zin by the case.

wine: Cave de Ribeauvillé 2013 Rodern Pinot Noir (Alsace)
review: Red plum and strawberry compote rise faintly from the glass. The palate is fruity but dilute, easy and clean. Drink soon and possibly chilled a little to accentuate the freshness.

Reductive on the nose, this bold mountain red is brimming in plum, cranberry and currant, with underlying earthiness that complements in savory cedar and tobacco. High-toned acidity and lifted aromatics provide a balance and brightness that surprises and lengthens the impressive palate.

wine: Vinyes dels Aspres 2008 Blanc dels Aspres Garnacha Blanca (Empordà)
review: Almondy and smoky on the nose, which is a textbook combo for this variety. The wine was 50% barrel-fermented, but it's not a woody, toasty product. Instead, it's focused and fruity, with a pretty mix of tropical flavors, banana and melon. Decidedly not bitter, with honey and light notes of vanilla on the finish.

appellation: Anderson Valley, Mendocino County, California, US
review: Husch is one of the original Anderson Valley wineries and has not been a particular Pinot Noir star, but this fantastic 2014 may start a trend. Fresh and alive, the wine is medium bodied but packs lots of tangy cherry and almost jammy plum flavors into a smooth but lightly tannic texture that provides great structure. Simply delicious, it's balanced well enough to enjoy time after time.

Smells of raspberries, but tastes meaty, chalky and a hint metallic, though the metallic edge isn't too much of a bother. Thick, dusty, very dry tannins complete the picture. Imported by Clos Du Val Wine.

appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
review: Smells ripe and fruity, then provides a letdown once it hits the mouth. The promise of currant and cherry turns herbal, with a hint of blackberry. This dry wine finishes with astringent tannins.

Here's a wine that caused some debate among our editors. It's weighty in the mouth, with flavors that approach a cordial-filled white chocolate candy, finishing with passion fruit and more white chocolate. Your thoughts on the wine will hinge on whether you think it's lush and hedonistic, and practically fit for dessert, or just too heavy and low acid for its own good.

Opens with berry fruit aromas, density and slightly medicinal notes. Feels bright and lively, with ample acidity pushing toasty, lightly herbal flavors of blackberry and plum. Shows mild spice, licorice and barrel notes on the finish, along with herbal notes. Seems like a very good everyday or value-driven choice.

wine: Jeaunaux-Robin NV Le Talus de Saint Prix Extra Brut  (Champagne)
designation: Le Talus de Saint Prix Extra Brut
review: With the high percentage of Pinot Meunier typical of the producer, this Champagne is already ripe and smooth. The acidity and dry edge that come from its low dosage are finely integrated, framing its ripe white and citrus fruit. Drink now.

wine: Chapillon NV Secret Reserva Brut Nature Sparkling (Cava)
review: Dusty, briny citrus and apple aromas lead to a palate that's calm and only mildly bubbly and active. Lightly pickled lime and tangerine flavors finish dry, slightly bitter and briny, with a coarse but crisp feel of seltzer.

Scents of mixed forest berries, red plum, fresh thyme and bay laurel lead the bouquet of this wine, and carry though to the juicy palate. Approachable and enjoyable now, with ripe fruit flavors and a hint of chocolate that stays through the medium-length finish. 60% Cabernet Sauvignon, 20% Merlot, 10% Syrah and 10% Petit Verdot. Mevushal.

wine: Foxen 7200 2017 Vogelzang Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Happy Canyon of Santa Barbara)
appellation: Happy Canyon of Santa Barbara, Central Coast, California, US
review: Dark-blackberry aromas meet with crushed rock, turned soil, espresso bean and a light minty tone on the nose of this bottling. The palate snaps with fresh blackberry, orange-peel, black-pepper and wild sage flavors, framed in a firm structure.

wine: Chateau Ste. Michelle 2016 Pinot Gris (Columbia Valley (WA))
appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Aromas of melon, pear and candied apple lead to medium-bodied fleshy-feeling fruit flavors. It brings a pleasing sense of acidity—a delightful white.

On the eastern end of the Bordeaux appellation, this Gazaniol property reserves 10 of 161 acres for its white blend. This is a ripe, soft wine that is rounded with peach and red-apple fruit flavors. Crisp acidity gives it some tightness to balance the full, fruity character of the wine. Drink now.

wine: Chacewater 2016 Windrem Vineyard Sauvignon Blanc (Lake County)
appellation: Lake County, Lake County, California, US
review: This is a nicely dry, fresh and restrained wine. Its best attributes are lightly fruity aromas, white-pepper and wet-stone flavors and a tangy mouthfeel, with a good snap of astringency.

appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: Good concentration and noticeable density, with intriguing, briary flavors that mix candied fruit with dusty herbs, cinnamon and cocoa.

appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: This feels a bit stripped, though the bottle says the alcohol hits almost 15%. There is a chocolaty coating over sharp, herbal, rather thin fruit flavors. The wine shows pleasant strawberry and watermelon fruit flavors, though the tannins and chocolaty barrel flavors quickly take over.

wine: Boeger 2016 Pinot Grande White Pinot Noir (El Dorado)
appellation: El Dorado, Sierra Foothills, California, US
review: Made as a white wine from dark Pinot Noir grapes, this medium-bodied wine has earthy aromas and savory herbal flavors that give it a rustic character. It has a tartness like grapefruit on the finish.

wine: Sleight of Hand 2006 The Spellbinder Red Red (Columbia Valley (WA))
appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: This affordable red blend includes 60% Cabernet Sauvignon, 20% Cab Franc, 10% Malbec and 10% Sangiovese. The wine is surpassingly soft, as if the tannins had miraculously, spellbindingly vanished. The fruit tastes of berries and plums, with some coffee mocha streaks in the finish.

Lightly off dry, this rich, smooth wine has acidity to balance the honey and ripe pineapple flavors. With some aging, it will show a delicious, ripe balance of fruit and creamy texture, with some zest to add liveliness. Drink from 2017.

A young, very fruity wine produced by Christian Moueix. It is structured, firm and juicy, layered with dry tannins, probably needing 6–12 months of aging. A touch of pepper, red currants, toast and acidity complete this good, very Bordeaux, wine.

wine: Domaine du Père Caboche 2018 Rosé (Vin de Pays de Vaucluse)
appellation: Vin de Pays de Vaucluse, Rhône Valley, France
review: Initial notes of smoke and mineral open into blossom and raspberry in this wine. Dry and medium bodied in style, it is a refreshingly straightforward summer sip with easy white-peach and red-cherry flavors. The finish is brisk but accented by a touch of caramel. Drink now.

Underbrush, ripe plum and baking spice aromas waft out of the glass. On the palate, vanilla, licorice, dark chocolate and espresso accent the black cherry core while polished tannins provide the framework. Drink through 2017.
Starts off with promising tropical fruit overtones, but loses steam on the palate, where the fruit is slightly stewed, some of the wine's alcohol shows through and a trace of bitterness emerges.

Solid and well-rounded, this very tasty wine has lively spice and apple aromas. The juice has nice texture on the tongue, well defined apple and peach flavors, and again the spice, which may be characteristic of the Nonnenberg vineyard. The long, even finish shows the tangy spice elements well. Will drink well for the next five years, maybe more.

wine: Château d'Ollières 2016 Prestige Red (Coteaux Varois en Provence)
appellation: Coteaux Varois en Provence, Provence, France
review: This is a richly ripe blend of Grenache and Syrah. Perfumed from wood aging and full of powerful tannins, the black-fruit flavors bring a core of density to the wine. Drink now.

wine: Winery of Good Hope 2011 Bush Vine Pinotage (Stellenbosch)
review: Here's a bright Pinotage that offers aromas of blackberry and plum, as well as faint hints of dried herb and cured meat. The palate is light and easy drinking, with approachable tannins and a short but clean finish.
Freshly cut pear is exuberant on nose. Rich but toned, the soft palate has a cheeky seam of acidity that delivers both mellow pleasure and refreshment.

Ready for immediate enjoyment, this offers a lifted nose of rose petals and cherry blossoms, carrying a slight whiff of milk chocolate. The fruit has a tart, cranberry character, moving up into Bing cherry flavors with plenty of crisp acidity.

wine: Pindar Vineyards 1999 Ice Wine Johannisberg Riesling (Long Island)
appellation: Long Island, Long Island, New York, US
review: Sure, it's made “artificially” in a commercial freezer, but so what? It tastes good. Dried apricots and honey are imbued with layers of flavor and richness. Enough acidity to avoid being cloying, but not so much that you'll want to age it. Drink now.

“Old vines” here means more than 20 years. But the wine owes its concentration to the selection of parcels and fruit as much as the vines' age. For there certainly is a rich intensity in this impressive, rounded wine. The spice and pear flavors are lifted by sweet green fruits and white berries. Imported by Frederick Wildman & Sons, Ltd.

wine: Les Dauphins 2018 Réserve Rosé (Côtes du Rhône)
appellation: Côtes du Rhône, Rhône Valley, France
review: Hints of crunchy nectarine, raspberry and fresh thyme extend from nose to palate on this light-bodied, lively rosé. A zesty thirst quencher it finishes on a brisk mineral note. Enjoy now.

Blatant aromas of milk chocolate and candied-berry fruits amount to a soupy, heavy, jammy nose. This Monastrell feels choppy and broken. Saucy berry flavors are loaded with oak and clove notes, while this wine tastes like chocolate and feels hot on the finish.
Made entirely with Malvasia Nera, this opens with aromas of black cherry, ground pepper and cocoa that carry over to the straightforward palate. Close-grained tannins grip the finish.

wine: Michel Torino 2007 Cuma Organic Cabernet Sauvignon (Cafayate)
review: Bubble gum on the nose makes you wonder about carbonic maceration, but that technique wasn't used to make this fruity, simple and generally nice little Cabernet. Don't expect complexity from it, or much varietal character; this is your basic red wine with adequate sweetness and some chocolate.

wine: J. Portugal Ramos 2012 Loios Branco White (Alentejano)
review: This is a light and fruity wine from J. Portugal Ramos. It's crisp, with lemon and citrus flavor, and bright with grapefruit acidity. Drink now and over the next year.

Starts out sort of jumbled, with heavy aromas, deep fruit scents and a shot of leather or animal hide. The palate is healthy, however, with proper acidity pushing earthy plum and berry flavors. Shows good structure and ample size and mouthfeel. The blend is 75% Garnacha and 25% Graciano.

wine: Edio 2018 Chene Vineyard Pinot Noir (Edna Valley)
appellation: Edna Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: Dried rose petals, a flash of violet and dried red-currant aromas show on the nose of this single-vineyard expression from a special and small site. The palate is dry in texture, offering rose petals and pomegranate flavors in a subtle and elegant display.

wine: Feudi del Pisciotto 2008 Missoni Cabernet Sauvignon (Sicilia)
review: Here's an inky black and densely concentrated Cabernet Sauvignon that would pair with grilled sausage or barbecued steak. The wine is soft, round and slightly sweet on the finish.

wine: Prospice 2017 Phinny Hill Vineyard Cabernet Franc (Horse Heaven Hills)
appellation: Horse Heaven Hills, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: We know what a special vineyard this is for Cabernet Sauvignon, but this wine shows that the grape's progenitor can excel there, too. Its 100% varietal, alluring aromas of raspberry, earth, herbs and flowers focus the attention. The palate is dense and textured, full of dark-fruit flavors with a firm sense of tannic structure. The balance is impressive. Best after 2024.

wine: Montes 2007 Classic Series Cabernet Sauvignon (Colchagua Valley)
review: Good but common as Chilean Cabs go. It's a jumbled mass of bulky fruit, raw power, sweet oak and spice. The mouthfeel is tannic, grabby and big, while the flavors of black cherry and raspberry are nice but generic. Finishes with spice and a hint of hickory. 20,000 cases produced.

Reduction on the nose creates aromas of tire rubber and black olive. On the palate, this is thick and rather sticky. Chocolaty oak dominates the palate, which also includes minty berry flavors and green notes.

wine: JM Cellars 2009 Boushey Vineyard Syrah (Yakima Valley)
appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: An elegant showcase for the Boushey fruit, this new JM Cellars release displays refined raspberry fruit, coated in silky cocoa and almond butter. Firmly acidic, sleek and racy, it gains complexity and texture through a lingering, tobacco-laden finish.

Soft and melted in tannins and acids, this dry red wine, which is the same as Grenache, has intense flavors of perfectly ripened cherries, with a rich coat of oak. There's a peppery tingly feeling that suggests a nice barbecued steak.

Massolino delivers a beautifully compact and elegant Nebbiolo with soft layers of spice and red fruit enhanced by bright intensity, menthol layers, licorice and cherry cola. Thanks to the wine's structure and persistency, you could try a pairing with crispy roast pork.

For lovers of Syrah, Cornas is the purest expression, with its dark, brooding tannins and heady fruit. This wine, from the Tain cooperative, is a classic Cornas, which just misses the intensity of some examples, but still has fine, dry tannins and long-lasting acidity.

wine: Real Companhia Velha 2015 Porca de Murça Reserva Branco White (Douro)
review: This fruity, unoaked wine is bright with citrus and crisp apple flavors, lightly perfumed from the Verdelho and Cerceal grapes in the blend. It's a refreshing wine that is ready now.

wine: Château Haut Caillou 2018  Lalande de Pomerol
review: The estate emphasizes the environmental balance of its vineyards. This dense wine is dominated by 80% Merlot. The wood aging shows but will integrate as the black-plum fruits develop, resulting in a balanced, ageworthy wine. Drink from 2022.

Gritty, muscular aromas of charred, smoky black fruits and asphalt give way to a medium-full palate with good acidity. Saucy, savory berry and plum flavors finish with notes of herbs and tobacco. For Rioja crianza, this is more than satisfying.

Here's a find for lovers of big, buttery wine. Dripping with cream and butter, Tarara's darkly toasted, full-bodied Chardonnay screams new French oak. Rich and viscous, there's just a hint of fresh lemon and apple flavors hiding behind all of the oak.

wine: Alpha Omega 2016 Drew Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Mount Veeder)
review: Woody and earthy in cedar and dried herb, this wine speaks of the appellation's wild qualities, showing a juicy center of black currant, blueberry and cocoa powder. The acidity is fresh and persistent, adding length and breadth as well as age-worthy structure. Enjoy this wine best from 2026–2031.

wine: Martin Ray 2010 Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)
appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: There's something subtlely unripe about this Pinot Noir. It show up in the aroma, with a trace of stewed asparagus. Still, it's dry and elegant, and the flavors of sour cherry candy and sandalwood make it all right.

An excellent Syrah. It's opulent almost to a fault, the fruit thick as a brick and ripe to the point of raisiny. It's buoyed with firm acidity and loads of black pepper and pencil lead. The wine is still a bit of a monster at 15.5% alcohol, but it's a loveable monster for sure.

The second wine of Château Haut-Brion is firm, mirroring its grand vin. It is dark, brooding and dense, rounded by ripe fruits. There is also an edge of bitter chocolate that offers an intriguing counterpoint to the elegance of the fruit.

wine: Grgich Hills 2003 Yountville Selection Red (Napa Valley)
review: Grgich has struggled with this uneven bottling over the years, and the 2003 shows the problems that have plagued the wine. It combines sharpness with sugary cherry-berry flavors, making for a sweet and sour taste. There are tannins aplenty, but it doesn't seem like an ager.

Here's a smooth, creamy Chard with flavors of apples, peaches, buttered toast, vanilla and plenty of oriental spices. The rich flavors last through a long finish. Has enough complexity to stand up to cracked crab, with a sourdough baguette.

From a parcel within the La Moussière estate, this is a luscious wine. Its wood is still present but will be absorbed by the generous black fruits and tannins. The wine has profited from the fine vintage and shows impressive richness. Drink from 2020.

wine: Elizabeth Chambers 2016 Temperance Hill Vineyard Pinot Noir (Eola-Amity Hills)
appellation: Eola-Amity Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: Juicy raspberry, plum and black cherry fruit flavors align here, along with citrus flavors from balancing acids. Details of fresh ground herbs come up also, and the melding of fruit, acid and tannin suggests medium-term aging potential. Drink now–2026.

Lemon peel, wet clay, sandalwood and nutmeg aromas are inviting. In the mouth, it's tight and tannic, but lively, with leather and roasted berry flavors. Finishes firm, tight and a bit clipped and choppy. A reflection of 2008's tough conditions.

Tomato leaf, raspberry and earth aromas lead into a sharp, acidic palate that turns the cherry and raspberry flavors toward jagged and pointy. The finish is mildly lemony and on the sharp side, with a hint of carob flavor. Registers as green and lean.

wine: Domaine la Rouillère 2017 Rosé (Côtes de Provence)
review: With its ripe blend of five grapes including Mourvèdre and Cabernet Sauvignon, this wine has spice, perfume and tannins. Its acidity and flavors of almonds as well as red fruits are deliciously balanced. This estate's vineyard is in the hills at the heart of the Saint-Tropez peninsula. Drink the wine now.

wine: Spann Vineyards 2014 Mayacamas Range Cabernet Sauvignon (Sonoma County)
review: With additions of 12% Malbec, 7% Cabernet Franc and 6% Petit Verdot, this red is spicy and full of heat, with an astringent note of dried herb. The tannins are substantial and fruit dull.

wine: Graf Hardegg 2005 Vom Schloss Grüner Veltliner (Niederösterreich)
review: A crisp, austere wine; it is a little lean, but does show fine varietal character. Treat this as a good food wine, rather than as an apéritif.

Whiffs of burnt sugar, smoke and toast mingle into pristine white grapefruit and red apple on the nose of this delightfully easy-drinking Chardonnay. It's light bodied and fresh in composure, with a lingering silky touch. Drink now–2024.

Here's a very ripe Cabernet Franc whose plummy flavors veer into dried prunes. It's dry, and a little hot, but there's something nice about it. It's honest and forthright, and will support food without overwhelming it.

Smoky notes of graphite and incense accent crisp blackberry and plum in this light-footed, spice-inflected Lemberger. It's a brisk, fresh, concentrated red backed by pert red currant acidity and very fine, feathery tannins. Ready now but should drink at peak through 2027.
Pear drop candy freshness on the nose suggests ease and lightness. The palate duly delivers with fine spritz and a slender but fresh body, which has hints of green pear and white pepper. Drink soon.
Mature plum, underbrush and baking spice aromas lead the nose while the forward palate offers blackberry extract, licorice and a hint of hazelnut. Drink soon.

wine: Château Rayne Vigneau 2018 Le Sec de Rayne Vigneau  (Bordeaux Blanc)
review: This Sauternes estate also produces a dry white wine. Ripe and with just a hint of honey, it is full and rich, almost too dense. There is enough acidity to keep the wine's freshness in place and it could certainly age for a few more months. Drink from 2021.

wine: André Kientzler 2013 Cuvée MIllésimée Non Dosée Sparkling (Crémant d'Alsace)
review: Brisk lemon freshness sets the tone on the nose. The very frothy mousse on the palate continues in this fruity, exuberant and fresh vein. The finish is superclean, brisk and dry, creating an ideal and invigorating apéritif-style for summer days.

wine: Domaine Schoffit 2018 Lieu-dit Harth Tradition Cuvée Caroline Gewurztraminer (Alsace)
review: Jasmine and narcissus cast a perfumed spell on the intense nose of this wine. Focused on peach compote, the palate presents sweetness shot through with freshness. This wine is sweet but also balanced, with a long, perfumed echo.

appellation: Vin Santo di Montepulciano, Tuscany, Italy
review: Made with dried Malvasia and Trebbiano grapes, this meditation wine offers aromas of chestnut honey, caramel and nutmeg. The spicy, balanced palate offers candied tangerine, dried fig and toasted almond alongside fresh acidity and a lingering finish.

appellation: Cole Ranch, Mendocino County, California, US
review: Try this as an alternative to Sauvignon Blanc. It's bone dry and tart, with lime rind flavors and just a hint of mineral. The crisp acidity pulls it all together. Finishes clean and swift.

This isn't a very complex Merlot, but it is textbook if you're looking for soft fruitiness. It has oak-influenced cherry and blackberry flavors, with hints of violets and fruit tea, and is dry and dusty in tannins. Give it more concentration and it would be a star.

Vines with an average age of 35 years have produced a concentrated wine. It is rich and full, while also having restraint and elegance. That makes for a fine balancing act of generous tannins and opulent black fruits. Drink the wine from 2021.

wine: Krupp Brothers 2016 Black Bart Stagecoach Vineyard Syrah (Napa Valley)
review: This is a big, reduced and mighty wine from a mighty site, richly interwoven in tannin and smoky oak. The flavors are varietally underlined in black pepper, grilled meat and lavender, with blueberry and blackberry fruit flirting into jam.

wine: Pellegrini 2005 Olivet Lane Vineyard Chardonnay (Russian River Valley)
appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: Nice and oaky and rich, from a vineyard in the heart of the cool-climate southern part of Russian River Valley. Acidity stars, giving zesty balance to the ripe pineapple, green apple, Key lime pie and pear flavors. New oak, to the tune of 40%, adds an opulent touch.

wine: Rex Hill 2018 Seven Soils Chardonnay (Willamette Valley)
appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: This enters with a soft, slightly soapy mouthfeel, showing quince and gooseberry fruit as it tightens up in the mouth. There's a streak of celery, green apple and a hint of toasted hazelnut. At least at this stage of life it's a bit disjointed, so aggressive aeration is recommended.
A blend of 50% Merlot and 50% Cabernet, this delivers sassy aromas of leather and cinnamon, with ripe, pulpy fruit. There's a touch of cherry that gives the wine a soft, velvety finish.

appellation: Amador County, Sierra Foothills, California, US
review: Soft and silky, with moderate alcohol that seems to have been achieved at the cost of some sweetness. The cherry flavors taste like they were dusted with white sugar.

Despite the smooth tannins, delicious blackberry and cherry fruit and good acidity, this wine finishes just a little too sweet for comfort, although some wine aficienadoes will enjoy that burst of sugar.

wine: Adelaida 2011 Anna's Estate Vineyard Syrah (Paso Robles)
appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: This 100% Syrah is rich and ripe in blackberry jam and new oak flavors. It's dry, with a fruity sweetness, and the tannins are strong but yielding. High alcohol gives it a hot feeling. Barbecue is your best bet.

appellation: High Valley, Lake County, California, US
review: Shows its aspirations to the northern Rhône in the 100% varietal that's wrapped in dense young tannins now, but deep down below brims with finely ripe fruit. Black currants, licorice, mu shu pork plum sauce, sweet worn leather and Asian spice flavors mingle into a long, complex finish. This is a wine to watch.

wine: Barton & Guestier 2006 Bistro Wine Cabernet Sauvignon (Vin de Pays d'Oc)
appellation: Vin de Pays d'Oc, Languedoc-Roussillon, France
review: With grapes from the Limoux region, the coolest in Languedoc, this wine goes for structure, with stalky, dry tannins. Those flavors, and the black currant fruits, are offset by considerable soft finishing sweetness.

wine: Loberger 2015 Sélection de Grains Nobles Riesling (Alsace)
review: Apricot compote and lifted citrus make for a heady, almost ethereal opening on the nose of this wine. Hints of mint tisane and blossom honey come into play with more air. The palate is richly and decadently sweet, but this is countered by the Riesling's focused acidity, lending drama and drive. The concentrated palate finishes with whistle-clean, mouthwatering richness.

wine: Torres 2005 Mas La Plana Cabernet Sauvignon (Penedès)
review: Heavily roasted and loaded up with coffee, mocha and other huge oak-based aromas. Frankly, there's so much new-barrel influence on this youngster that it's hard to assess. Once you're past the oak, there's deep fruit in the blackberry and cassis realm, and then fierce tannins that dry out the palate. Needs time.
This Merlot has aromas of tilled soil, toasted oak and mocha. The tightly knit palate offers baked plum, sage and roasted coffee bean alongside assertive, rather astringent tannins.

Equal parts Malbec and Merlot add to the whole of this wine, which is thick and extracted in black fruit and firm tannins. With a floral undercurrent and spicy rocky tones, it combines blackberry and currant with a rich addition of caramel.

What you see is what you get, an inexpensive wine from the Delta. It's dark, dry and jammy, and as cleanly made as American winemaking allows. Hamburgers or, better still, cheeseburgers come to  mind.

wine: Pewsey Vale 2017 Single Vineyard Estate 1961 Block Riesling (Eden Valley)
review: A new release from Pewsey Vale's oldest vineyards and fermented on native yeasts, there is a long life ahead of this wine. Right now, it's young, eking out notes of apple skins, blossoms, grapefruit and talc. The balance is spot on, and while this would be delicious now with shellfish, it'd be even better with some time in the cellar. Drink now–2032.
Tobacco and spice aromas lead into flavors of jammy fruit and vanilla. A touch smoky on the finish, with pretty aromatics typical of the grape. Pair with lamb or grilled meats.

This is a wine that will change your perception of Howell Mountain Cabs as wines that you have to cellar to enjoy. Yes, it's tannic enough for the long haul, but so good now, it's hard not to drink it. Packed with ripe, rich currant, cherry and sweet tobacco fruit, with vanilla and cocoa seasonings, it's absolutely delicious. Drink now through 2012.

wine: Foundry 2013 Lindsay's Vineyard Pinot Noir (Sta. Rita Hills)
appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
review: Dense but not overpowering aromas of iron, cherry jelly, dried cranberries and black rocks show on this wine, a combo of the Pommard and 2A clones. It's fairly lush at the tip of the sip, with smoked-meat flavors, but then stays reserved down the middle, with pencil lead, cranberry fruit and sanguine notes into the finish.

The estate wine of Jean-Luc Baldès is often overshadowed by the limited production wines. In itself, though, it is a firm, solid, well balanced wine, rich and expressing the minerality of Malbec in Cahors. This vintage should be aged, drink from 2016.
Bright, crisp and packed with fruit, this is a refreshing, simple wine. Its lively acidity has a fresh character that shows well against the apple flavors. Drink now.

wine: Wombat Gully 2000 Cabernet Sauvignon (South Eastern Australia)
appellation: South Eastern Australia, Australia Other, Australia
review: Very light, with spicy green aromas and much more tomato than fruit. The flavors are sugary and sweet. It should not be hard to find better Cabs than this.

wine: Vixen 2006 Vivant Syrah Rosé Syrah (Santa Barbara County)
appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
review: Starts with a harsh smell of burnt jam, then turns simple, soft and slightly sweet in jellied cherry flavors.

Structured and aromatic, this is an immediately attractive wine. It has a ripe, juicy character, balanced by firm, dry tannins. At this stage, although drinkable, it will certainly benefit from 3–4 years of aging.

appellation: El Dorado, Sierra Foothills, California, US
review: This wine's prominent buttery aromas grab one's attention right away, and that same buttery element runs through the flavors and lingers on the finish. The fruit components are mild and melon-like, the body is medium and the texture reveals good acidity.

wine: Louis Bernard 2009 Château Noël Saint-Laurent White (Côtes du Rhône)
appellation: Côtes du Rhône, Rhône Valley, France
review: Unusually full bodied and lush for a white Côtes du Rhône, with smoky, intense aromas of grilled peaches and crushed stone and a lingering finish. Drink now.
This wine has simple aromas of fresh herbs and banana pith. The acidity is a likeable counterpart to one-dimensional tropical fruit flavors. Finishes with another dose of fresh herbs.

This is a heavily oaked Tannat that opens with mint gumdrop, milk chocolate and wood grain aromas. A fully extracted palate is plodding, while overriding bitter oak dominates the wine's black fruit flavors. On the finish, this is fiery and overtly chocolaty.
Green pear on the nose has a hint of zestiness. The palate is light but mellow, features more of that fresh pear fruit and is dry and fresh. There is a juicy core and a clean finish.

wine: Casa Setaro 2008 Don Vincenzo Piedirosso (Lacryma Christi del Vesuvio)
appellation: Lacryma Christi del Vesuvio, Southern Italy, Italy
review: Don Vincenzo is a sharp, brambly red wine from the blackened slopes of the dangerous Vesuvius volcano. It offers bright aromas of wild berry, cassis, currant and mocha. With its crisp acidity, this wine should pair well with pizza or cheesy pasta.

wine: Feudi di San Gregorio 2005 Campanaro  (Fiano di Avellino)
appellation: Fiano di Avellino, Southern Italy, Italy
review: This Fiano-based wine offers the generous pear and peach aromas often associated with this native grape from Campania plus its trademark structure and caressing consistency (it is oak aged for six months). But what sets it apart is the elegant manner in which these elements are brought together.

wine: Marqués de la Concordia 2013 MM Reserva de la Familia Brut Nature Sparkling (Cava)
designation: MM Reserva de la Familia Brut Nature
review: Dusty apple aromas are yeasty and come with a notable vanilla scent. Flatness is an issue on the palate, which is low on fizz and kick. Bready white-fruit flavors finish yeasty and dry, with a hint of white pepper.

A straightforward example of Chilean SB, meaning there's citrus and mineral on the nose, juicy acidity and lime, grapefruit and tangerine flavors. It's clean and solid, with slight pithiness. Delivers a lot for $9; drink now.

Bright and richly expansive, this wine is floral and gritty, a beautiful exploration of rose petal, forest floor and strawberry-rhubarb. Lightly spiced, it has a full-bodied figure of ripeness within polished tannin and structured acidity.

wine: Dr. Loosen 2010 Erdener Prälat Alte Reben GG Trocken Riesling (Mosel)
designation: Erdener Prälat Alte Reben GG Trocken
review: Lush flavors of preserved peach are touched with notes of savory herb, lanolin and blossom on this dry, but deeply penetrating Riesling. Bright lemon acidity shines through a textured, glycerine sheen on the palate, lingering long with a murmur of crushed slate and stone.

wine: Alexandria Nicole 2008 Destiny Ridge Vineyard Block 20 Malbec (Horse Heaven Hills)
appellation: Horse Heaven Hills, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: This opens with a fertile, fecund nose mixing together layered scents of forest floor, dried leaf, moist loam, ripe plum and sandalwood. A good, sharp acid base puts a frame around the complex mix of flavors. It finishes tart and still tight; give it some breathing time.

Aromas of wild flower, baked yellow apple and citrus slowly take shape in the glass while the medium-bodied palate offers toasted hazelnut, mature pear and a note of lemon zest. It finishes on a slightly bitter note reminiscent of powdered sage.

appellation: Shenandoah Valley (CA), Sierra Foothills, California, US
review: This roasted and rustically pleasing Montepulciano, which is hard to find in California, has dry tannins, a layer of boysenberry and a leathery mouthfeel. Pair it with roasted chicken or rich risotto.
Light in body and lean in flavor, this nervy, tangy wine is refreshing and simple.
