wine: Georges Vigouroux 2016 Chenin de Mercuès Chenin Blanc (Côtes du Lot)
appellation: Côtes du Lot, Southwest France, France
review: Growing Chenin Blanc has a long tradition in the Cahors region. Along with its nutty character and red-apple flavors, this wine has a mineral texture that gives tension to balance the ripe fruitiness. It is ready to drink.

This is a big, tannic and dry Syrah that seems built for the cellar, but an unripe note of green peppercorn verging on bell pepper rules that out. So drink now and appreciate the blackberries and oak.

Fresh cassis and blackberry flood this gorgeously plummy blend of Grenache, Syrah, Mourvèdre and Counoise. Sourced from high-altitude, limestone soils, it's voluptuous but briskly balanced. The long finish is marked by fine-tipped tannins and lingering hints of bramble, dried mint and garrigue. It's at peak now through 2027.

Undefined black fruit aromas are average at best, while the cherry fruit is decent but citric. This wine shows too little to warrant much attention; it's brittle but persisent, with thin, cleansing acids throughout.
There's an abundance of ripe berry-cherry and spice fruit in this dry, full-bodied wine, which also has silky tannins and a liberal dose of smoky oak. It's robust and satisfying, in a rustic way.

wine: Chehalem 2010 Stoller Vineyards Pinot Noir (Dundee Hills)
appellation: Dundee Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: Medium bodied, this fruity vineyard-designate has a peppery spice note. A touch of dried herb and a hint of earth carry onto the finish.

wine: Murray Street 2005 The Barossa Red (Barossa Valley)
review: This venture is only about five years old, but already turning out some pretty smart wines. This blend of Shiraz (49%), Grenache (34%), Cinsaut (10%) and Mataro (7%) features a medium- to full-bodied blend of savory, meaty, spicy aromas and flavors that emphasizes dark fruit and earth. Relatively open knit and ready to drink.

From a spectacular Douro quinta, this wine is structured with dark tannins and rich with black-currant and berry fruits. The acidity, dry core and firm texture testify to the wine's aging ability. Drink this wine from 2021.

Carob, blackberry and camphor aromas shape the nose on this young, vibrant red. It's smooth and silky, delivering raspberry compote, eucalyptus and hazelnut set against polished tannins and bright acidity. A saline note caps off the close.

Shy at first on the nose, this wine develops to reveal a voluptuous style of fleshy, rounded grapefruit, pineapple, cantaloupe and Meyer lemon. It remains complex and exotic through a lengthy midpalate and textured finish, with persistent acidity.

appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: Smashed plums, drying lilacs and a hint of soy show on the nose of this bottling. The palate is layered with flavors of sour blackberry, dried violets and lavender, marjoram and other roasting herbs and a more savory soy touches.

Overt oak aromas outweigh generic white fruit notes prior to a plump and creamy palate that's fairly resiny. Wood-based flavors of vanilla and spice work well with salt and melony fruit notes, while this Chardonnay performs a slow fade on a salty tasting but balanced finish.

wine: D'Arenberg 2014 The Galvo Garage Red (McLaren Vale-Adelaide Hills)
appellation: McLaren Vale-Adelaide Hills, South Australia, Australia
review: This Bordeaux-style blend of Cabernet Sauvignon, Petit Verdot and Merlot shows plenty of d'Arenberg character while also walking to its own beat. It needs a bit of swirling in glass or decanter to come together but when it does it reveals notes of soy sauce, stalks, raspberries and roasted beets on both the nose and the palate. The mouthfeel is granular, smudged by spicy tannins and a lick of toasty oak—a powerful but charming wine for drinking in the short term.

This opens with delicate aromas of pressed blue flower and a woodland berry. The vibrant, easygoing palate offers candied cherry, juicy orange slice and a star anise note set against supple tannins and bright acidity. While it doesn't posses the complexity one expects from a Riserva, it is bright in savory. Drink through 2022.
Reflecting the structure and fruit of the 2010 vintage, the wine has dry tannins that are balanced by juicy black fruits and fine acidity. Drink from 2017.

appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: This is labeled medium-sweet, and it hits that mark with sugary flavors that push it past off-dry. Powdered sugar and cotton candy highlights come up around clean fruit flavors of simple grape and apple. There's nothing fancy here, but it's a good everyday Riesling for lovers of sweet wines.

wine: Dal Maso 2016 Pas Dosé Riserva Metodo Classico  (Lessini Durello)
review: Crisp and pristine, this vibrant, focused sparkler has delicate aromas of hawthorn, white stone fruit and citrus. Racy and bone-dry, the savory, gleaming palate delivers juicy Meyer lemon, Anjou pear, saline and a hint of bread dough. Tiny, persistent bubbles provide the elegant backdrop.

wine: Chappellet 2016 Mountain Cuvée Proprietor's Red (Napa Valley)
review: This rounded, approachable blend is well-made, blending 51% Cabernet Sauvignon with smaller percentages of Merlot, Malbec, Petit Verdot and Cabernet Franc. Concentrated in big, burly black fruit, it offers accents of tobacco and mocha around a thick midpalate and finishing touch of char.

Light coffee and tea-like aromas emerge from the nose of this sharp and crisp Barbera d'Asti Superiore. The wine is compact, firm and the mouthfeel is characterized by fresh berry notes and crisp fruit on the close.

wine: Quinta do Casal Monteiro 2014 Terra de Touros Arinto (Tejo)
review: A gentle light wine that seems diluted. It has only hints of fruit and acidity, all very easy and ripe to drink. The wine is ready.

wine: Domaine Drouhin Oregon 2014 Dundee Hills Pinot Noir (Dundee Hills)
appellation: Dundee Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: Rich and textural, this gloriously mixes raspberries, cherries, baking spices, cola, cocoa and coconut components, all woven together seamlessly. It's forward and juicy, yet built for medium-term aging. Drink now through 2026.

wine: Château Bourbon 2010 Clos Bourbon  (Cadillac Côtes de Bordeaux)
appellation: Cadillac Côtes de Bordeaux, Bordeaux, France
review: Heavy toast aromas follow through to a wine that is packed with new wood and some fruit. It has a biting burnt edge that may soften.

wine: Chateau St. Jean 2010 Signature Red Blend Red (California)
review: Rugged and ripe, with raspberry candy and green mint flavors. Made from six varieties, it's okay for drinking with burgers and such.

wine: Barão de Vilar 2014 Vinha das Margaridas Reserva Red (Douro)
review: Named after the daisies that grow in the Douro, this reserve wine is firm and structured. It has density as well as plenty of black fruits to sustain its concentration. Drink now.

wine: Casanova di Neri 2005 Tenuta Nuova  (Brunello di Montalcino)
review: Beyond the plump notes of cherry and blackberry there's an added touch of clove, cardamom and rosemary sprig that sets this wine apart. The mouthfeel is rich and textured and because the tannins still need to soften, we recommend you put this bottle down in your cellar for a few more years.

appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: Rochioli's Sauvignon Blanc declined in quality in the 2006 vintage, and 2007 continues that downward trend. It may be the chilly vintage, but this release is thin and minty, with green, gooseberry flavors that barely manage to veer into citrus fruits.

Fragrant green notes inform the nose of this wine: there are moss and sage, citrus foliage and fern scents. That herbal richness also plays on the slender, fresh and streamlined palate. Citrus freshness emanates from the textured flavors, softened slightly by salty yeast notes. An impressive, concentrated wine with lots of potential. Drink 2018–2028.

Crisp and fruity, this wine is fresh and flavorful. Its acidity and bright texture are attractive and accessible. The finish with hints of juicy white currants continues the theme. Drink the wine now.

wine: Zenaida Cellars 2015 Wanderlust Red (Templeton Gap District)
appellation: Templeton Gap District, Central Coast, California, US
review: Tangy plum skins and mulberry sauce meet with salt and pepper and roasted duck aromas on the nose of this blend of 50% Grenache, 35% Syrah and 15% Mourvèdre. The palate is full of brambly fruit, lifted by smoke and sagebrush.

Another wine from the label with the smiling shark I've come to call Jovial Jaws. Simple, generic Chardonnay, with a bit-too-sweet-perfumy profile, though the palate is actually drier than the nose or close. This can pass muster at a large party or gallery opening.

Jammy berry aromas are ripe and slightly candied, with only a hint of Carmenère's patented green. A full, round palate ranks as dense, while this tastes of ripe black fruits and toast prior to a peppery finish where dry tannins take over.

wine: Maryhill 2016 Proprietor's Reserve Cabernet Franc (Columbia Valley (WA))
appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: With almost all of the fruit coming from Tudor Hills Vineyard, this is 100% varietal, though the variety seems hard to find. The aromas bring unusual, somewhat off-putting notes of soil, espresso bean, dried orange rind and cherry. The coffee flavors start out full and then taper toward the finish.

wine: Château Cheval Blanc 2013 Le Petit Cheval Barrel Sample  (Saint-Émilion)
review: 90–92. Barrel Sample. This is a serious, dark wine, with ripe and concentrated Merlot-based character. It has ample density, although there is a light touch that brings out black currant fruitiness as well as bright acidity.

wine: Herdade da Comporta 2009 Branco White (Península de Setúbal)
review: Ripe pear fruit flavors go with green plums in the wine that has acidity, but does seem just too hot and heavy.
This opens with tilled soil, Mediterranean brush and black-skinned berry aromas. The round palate offers black cherry, raspberry jam and a white pepper note alongside smooth tannins. Enjoy soon.

wine: Bründlmayer NV Brut Reserve Sparkling (Österreichischer Sekt)
review: Baked apple and the mellow ripeness of Golden Pearmain apple perfume the nose. The palate adds the creaminess of very fine fizz and the vivid freshness of lemon to this slender, elegant and very expressive Sekt. The finish is totally clean, brisk and utterly moreish. Just made for a classy apero.

This is a distinctive and unique Barolo with an edgy, brambly quality that comes forth aromatically as wild berry, forest floor, chopped herb, furniture wax for antiques and root beer. The wine leaves your palate with a dry, dusty impression thanks to the fine nature of its tannins.

wine: MacRostie 2018 Charles Heintz Vineyard Chardonnay (Green Valley)
review: From the great coastal site, this white sings in fruitful intensity and complex layers of flavor, a burst of Meyer lemon and grapefruit crispness complemented by richer undertones of Meyer lemon meringue and toasted pineapple.

Tascante combines “Tasca” and “Etna” spelled backwards. This wine represents the estate's first vintage of Nerello Mascalese from the fiery Sicilian volcano. It's a tight, tonic expression with small berry fruit and a long finish highlighted by crushed clove and nutmeg.

wine: Armanino Family Cellars 2007 The Ringneck La Encantada Pinot Noir (Sta. Rita Hills)
appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
review: Marked by acidity and grapeskin bitterness, this is a Pinot Noir to stash in the cellar, in order to let everything resolve. It shows fresh, vibrant flavors of cherries, raspberries and red currants, and is very dry. Should hit its window of opportunity between 2010–2012.

wine: Domaine Schoffit 2013 Clos Saint-Théobald Grand Cru Rangen Riesling (Alsace)
review: This wine clearly needs to breathe. It is only after a few minutes of airtime that it shows its true colors: then very tart and aromatic apples appear, alongside a hint of smoke and a sheer touch of lemon freshness. The palate continues on that lemony streak and is absolutely dry. The body is lithe and slender and shows great freshness and intensity. Apple and stone flavors linger. Drink 2020–2030.

The wine is closed up and tough. That's no bad thing because the fruit weight is all there. The tannins are dense at the moment, showing signs of hard extraction, not enough to take away from the potential. Drink from 2017.

wine: Scott Paul 2012 La Paulée Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)
appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: Pretty scents of rosewater, raspberries and cherries introduce this light and pleasing wine. It carries some of the charm of a good strawberry soda, with forward fruit and a delicate frame. That said, it is not just a simple fruity wine, and gains weight and complexity as it breathes. Give it time to show you all it has.

A dense, leathery, richly stylized wine from a great vineyard site, this offers thick layers of dark chocolate, blueberry and plum. Integrated in terms of oak and tannin, it delivers concentration and power, capped off on the finish in a shot of cigar.
A hint of smoked nuts lends a savory tone to flavors of pressed apple and pear. While delicate in concentration, it's dry and approachable, with refreshing lemon-lime acidity. Drink now.
Hints of overripe fruits spoil this otherwise attractive, red-berry-flavored wine. Tannins have already softened and blended with the fruits. It should be ready in 2020.

wine: Lake Sonoma 2002 Saini Farms Old Vine Zinfandel (Dry Creek Valley)
appellation: Dry Creek Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: A tannic wine, and although it's dry, it has overripe, raisiny flavors. Finishes with a rustic roughness and Porty caramel.
On the thin side, and the blackberry and cherry flavors are compromised by some green, minty tannins. But it's not a bad wine for a big party.

wine: Robert Ramsay 2014 McKinley Springs Vineyard Cinsault (Horse Heaven Hills)
appellation: Horse Heaven Hills, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: This is a rare 100% varietal, single vineyard example of this grape. Light in color, it brings aromas of gun smoke, herb and cherry, showing some reduction. The flavors are light and elegant, displaying a lot of delicacy.

Whispers of smoke, bacon and violet lend complexity to ripe black plum and mulberry on this inviting Syrah. Its perfume and lavishly concentrated palate offer a bit more intensity than typically seen in Crozes-Hermitage. This briskly balanced, elegant wine with firm tannins is approachable now but should drink well through 2030.

This big bold wine takes flavor to the limits. Spicy, peppery, beefy aromas and bold smoke, blueberry and clove flavors rely a lot on oak, but have a good concentrated fruit foundation underneath. It is full bodied, mouth-filling and nicely tannic.
The wine has all the potential of ripe fruit and firm tannins. It should become a rich wine with blackberry flavors and a tannic structure. Drink this wine from 2018.

wine: Kana 2005 Cuvée Le Blanc Reserve White (Yakima Valley)
appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: This “Rhône-style white blend” (53% Viognier/37% Roussanne/10% Marsanne) is heavy, hot (14.8%) and dry. The fruit seems attenuated and the flavors thick and simple. Peaches and apricots rule the fruit, with a plastic edge to the finish.

Warm and structured, this has aromas evoking scorched earth, underbrush and mature black-skinned berry. On the firm palate, assertive, close-grained tannins accompany dried black cherry, licorice, sage and tobacco while the warmth of alcohol caps off the finish. Drink 2023–2030.

wine: Juvé y Camps 2008 Brut Nature Gran Reserva Reserva de la Familia Sparkling (Cava)
designation: Brut Nature Gran Reserva Reserva de la Familia
review: Normally I'm a fan of Juvé y Camps. This bottling is bland on the nose, with a cleaning-solution aroma. The palate is foamy in feel and short in flavor, with a strange blend of bitter lettuce, brine and green herbs. Frankly, it's not up to par, a possible reflection of the below-average 2008 vintage.

Earthy aromas of forest floor, tobacco leaf and leather mingle harmoniously with the black-fruit core of this Merlot-based blend, with 20% Cabernet Sauvignon, 13% Syrah and 7% Petit Verdot. The medium-weight palate boasts fruit-skin flavors of plum, cassis and berry, while accents of tobacco, balsamic herbs and pepper unfold on thelingering finish. Drink now–2016.

appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: Quite full of sour candy flavors, with melon and lime accents, this tangy, fruity take on Riesling is not your usual delicate flower. It's big and tart, ready for food.

White-fruit aromas, brine and clam shell notes get this Albariño going. The mouthfeel is full and lemony. Flavors of pickled, briny citrus and nectarine carry onto the finish. This is at its best now; in 2014 it will not be so good.

wine: Heart & Hands 2017 Seneca East Vineyard Riesling (Finger Lakes)
appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
review: A reticent nose gives way to a light-bodied palate of apple, peach and slightly tropical fruit flavors. Integrated acidity gives a delicate frame to this wine, with a mild concentration of fruit flavors.

wine: Riverbench 2009 Mesa Pinot Noir (Santa Maria Valley)
appellation: Santa Maria Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: The Mesa bottling has been a particular success for Riverbench in past vintages, and continues to be today. It's made from a special block in the estate vineyard, and always is unusually concentrated in red fruits, licorice and crushed baking spices, generously coated in sweet oak. It's a beautiful, silky wine of great charm and finesse. Drink now–2015.

appellation: Vin de France, France Other, France
review: Pale ballet-slipper pink in the glass, this wine offers aromas of yellow watermelon, fresh strawberry and Rainier cherry. The palate opens with juicy cherry but turns tart with green apple, lime and grapefruit. Some grassiness steps in on the mouthpuckering finish, with tart citrus lingering endlessly.

wine: Mas Pere NV Selecció Brut Sparkling (Cava)
review: Stalky haystack aromas settle on generic white-fruit scents accented by garlic and mushroom. Despite high acidity, this is notably flat and devoid of bubbles. Honeyed stone fruit flavors finish with a hint of lemon-lime but little more.

Toasty, but backed up by solid black-cherry fruit that fills the mouth with a touch of creaminess. The dark fruit flavors persist well into the finish where they are joined by a hint of mint and smoke.

wine: Gallo Family Vineyards 2005 Sonoma Reserve Syrah (Sonoma County)
review: Gallo's done a fine job at producing this dry, tannic Syrah at an everyday price. It's a little soft, but quite rich in grilled blackberry, cherry, tangerine, licorice and spicy mocha flavors.

Bric Turot is a rich and powerful Barbaresco that shows excellent integrity and intensity of its fruit flavors. Those tones of red cherry and cassis are backed by layers of spice, leather and dried tobacco leaf.

Soft peach and wild berries lead the way on the nose, while the medium weight mouth offers a bit more fleshy stone fruit and watermelon flavors. The finish is dry and accented by hints of peppery spice.

Made with organically grown grapes, this Cabernet Sauvignon opens with inviting aromas of cassis, underbrush and mint. The savory, polished palate features black currant, licorice and tobacco alongside fine-grained tannins. Drink through 2026.

appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: A truly stunning wine of amazing complexity. It has layers of depth rarely found in any Washington wines, beginning with dense black fruits, black licorice, smoke, pepper and charcoal. The trademark Cayuse herbal/green tea elements are there also, more as hints than as layers. The aging in big neutral barriques has buffed it out; as it breathes in the glass the wine opens beautifully, gaining flesh and density. A genuine tour de force, deeply aromatic and fascinating.

wine: Roessler 2006 Griffin's Lair Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)
review: Raw in acidity, this low-production Pinot offers cherry, red currant, cola and dusty spice flavors. Doesn't seem like it has a future, so drink up.

wine: Monticello Vineyards 2012 Estate Grown Chardonnay (Oak Knoll District)
appellation: Oak Knoll District, Napa, California, US
review: Dry, acidic, oaky, it'also a little herbaceous. Orange and mango flavors are enhanced with plenty of oak. While it's elegant, it's not especially rich.

This wine has a distinctly strong element of cured meat and salami on the nose, before it lunges wholeheartedly into chocolate, cedar and tobacco tones. Soft significant tannins wrap around the flavors in an impenetrable way.

appellation: Central Coast, Central Coast, California, US
review: This blend of 80% Syrah and 20% Grenache offers heady and thick violet and plum extract aromas, and smells heavier in alcohol than it is. The palate shows ripe black cherry, but it's eye-wateringly tannic, and needs quite a bit of time in the cellar to evolve.

wine: Glen Fiona 2006 Puncheon Select Syrah (Walla Walla Valley (WA))
appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Much of a piece with its companion releases, this is done in a lighter style, with plum and berry fruit, dried herbs and a short, simple finish.

wine: Gualdo del Re 2007 Eliseo Red (Val di Cornia Suvereto)
appellation: Val di Cornia Suvereto, Tuscany, Italy
review: Easygoing and fresh, this ruby-colored wine offers sweet cherry nuances with lighter aromas of almond and ground cinnamon. It's a cheerful and sunny wine that shows good integrity of fruit and a clean, crisp finish.

Smells sharp and minty, with a green streak of raw oak, and tastes similarly thin and oaky.  It stings with tannins from entry through dusty finish.  Blackberry and plum flavors deep inside are smothered in tannins.
Tart and dry, this brings a dusty note across a range of tangy citrus fruits, particularly lemon and grapefruit. The acids are emphasized somewhat by an astringent, chalky finish.
Aromas of apple cider are a touch acrid, while the palate is wet and easy but low in acidity. Flavors of melon and white fruits show some bitterness and break up in front of a flat finish.

This well-balanced wine is ripe, with dense black fruits shot through with ageworthy tannins. Poised and already offering fruitiness and ripeness built for long-term aging, this wine will be ready from 2026. Organic and biodynamic.

appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
review: Zest and floral notes abound on this refreshingly dry Chardonnay. Satisfyingly juicy and tart, it's penetrating on the palate with flavors of white grapefruit and fresh green apple. Finishes briskly but with a lingering lime-skin astringency.

wine: Domaine Charles Frey 2016 Quintessence Pinot Noir (Alsace)
review: Vanilla and polished mahogany frame the cherry core on the nose of this wine. The slender palate is smooth, with mellow vanilla tones that embrace those tart, bright cherry notes.

wine: Naggiar 2013 Mamma Mia Estate White (Sierra Foothills)
appellation: Sierra Foothills, Sierra Foothills, California, US
review: Full body and savory flavors set this apart from the crowd, bringing a melon and almond aroma and subtle flavors like fig and butter. With a dry feel, creamy texture and lingering finish it tastes more serious than the name suggests.

wine: Cantalici L'Antica Fornace di Ridolfo 2013 Baruffo Riserva  (Chianti Classico)
review: Underbrush, cooking spice and a touch of iris aromas unfold in the glass. The concentrated palate offers ripe black cherry, licorice, tobacco and a hint of mocha alongside fine-grained tannins.

wine: Marine Layer 2018 Gap's Crown Vineyard Chardonnay (Sonoma Coast)
review: Tropical and lushly textured, this wine presents as full and fleshy, with a fruitiness that appeals. Balanced acidity helps counter and complement its more opulent tendencies, pulling it back into a freshness of sea spray and mountain air.

An interesting wine very similar to a classic Napa Cabernet. Has those lush, smooth tannins, gorgeous, velvety texture and long finish, accented with oaky vanillins and smoke. The flavors are distinctive, like a gooey black cherry pie whose rich sweetness lasts for a long time.

wine: Château Julien 2000 Barrel Aged Zinfandel (Monterey County)
appellation: Monterey County, Central Coast, California, US
review: Kicks off with pretty toast and oak notes, followed by hints of blackberry, spice, plum and anise flavors. It's a bit tart on the finish, however.

wine: Clos La Chance 2013 Hadley's Cuvee White (Central Coast)
appellation: Central Coast, Central Coast, California, US
review: It's uncommon to find Grenache Noir in a white blend, but it's a tasty experiment nonetheless. Well rounded and evenly presented, the nose of lemon and honeysuckle is prominent but delicate. The slightly oily palate comes alive with vanilla, pear candy, peach and bubblegum, finishing with a brush of acidity.

wine: Left Bend 2014 Muns Vineyard Pinot Noir (Santa Cruz Mountains)
appellation: Santa Cruz Mountains, Central Coast, California, US
review: Potpourri, ripe strawberries and a touch of cedar show on the nose of this single-vineyard expression. The palate offers baked berries, sandalwood and dried melons, and the texture is a little bit flat.

appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Dark berry, huckleberry, wood spice and cocoa aromas are followed by palate-coating blue and purple-fruit flavors.

wine: Merry Cellars 2014 Seven Hills Vineyard Carmenère (Walla Walla Valley (WA))
appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Raw, sliced banana pepper, ground black-pepper, cinnamon and green-herb aromas lead to plump front-loaded cherry and pepper flavors that don't entirely stay together throughout. Cranberry notes linger on the finish.

wine: Château la Caminade 2015 Mission la Caminade  (Cahors)
review: Ready to drink, this classic combination holds 15% Merlot that tames the 85% Malbec. It's a friendly, black-fruit-flavored wine with integrated tannins and an aftertaste with juicy acidity. Drink now.

Veteran winemaker Wayne Thomas has crafted a prototypical Australian Cabernet, mingling mint and eucalyptus notes with cassis fruit and a touch of chocolaty oak. The texture is creamy enough to suggest early drinkability, yet there are also velvety-dusty tannins that should enable the wine to develop over the next several years.

wine: Réthoré Davy 2018 Chapitre Pinot Gris (Val de Loire)
appellation: Val de Loire, Loire Valley, France
review: This attractive, perfumed wine offers apple flavors that convey both warmth and freshness. Drink this refreshing wine now.

Nero Latino lacks harmony overall because of its rapid succession of unrelated aromas: Red apple is followed by mushroom, beets, strawberry, chocolate and smoke. It also has an extremely strong component of coffee rinds that appears on both the nose and in the mouth. It's not a wine for everyone.

Though there's no denying that Perrin's bouquet is full of dark berries, cherry and plum, tasters also detected a fresh, grassy-peach note. The palate is less sunny, and fraught with tart red fruit and tangy oak. It's a little hard now, and will probably improve after a year or two in the cellar; we still wish that it had a little more complexity. Finishes dry, with toast and crisp tannins.
A darkly fruity aroma leads to sweet flavors like brown sugar, milk chocolate and blueberry jam in this medium-bodied, soft-textured wine.

appellation: Edna Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: Sagebrush aromas lead off this bottling from the newish Fossil Point label, which is connected to the higher end Center of Effort brand. On the palate, spice, tar and pomegranate accompany some fairly weighty tannins, meaning that this will probably emerge as a better wine by 2016.

wine: Mission Hill 2012 Lone Pine Chardonnay (Okanagan Valley)
review: At first this is a spicy, forward wine, with generous flavors of candied fruits, orange peel and baked pear. It offers cinnamon highlights along with moderate toast. The downside? The wine seems to flatten out quickly through the finish, suggesting that it's best to drink up.

appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Here is a good value effort, smoky, chewy and dense, with strong flavors but solid Merlot varietal character. There is unusual smokiness in the wine—presumably from barrel toast—but enough ripe fruit to offset that and the substantial tannins. The spicy finish suggests American oak barrels were used.

A mix of grilled pineapple, citrus oil and sea spray starts off this rich white. Time in oak is apparent yet integrated, offering a delicate brûléed edge to the citrus, pineapple and apricot flavors. Persistent acidity balances it all, leading to a lingering cured lemon finish.

appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: This is all clone 96 Chardonnay. Clarified butter, cream, lemon balm and crayon aromas are followed by creamy candlewax flavors that sail. Toasty notes linger on the finish. Variety and winemaker influence walk hand in hand.

In 2009, it's the Pinot Gris (at 60%) that dominates this two-grape blend; the rest is Viognier. It's always a delicious wine, and here again the two grapes match up beautifully, with the Pinot Gris bringing flesh and rind from a variety of citrus fruits, and the Viognier adding orange blossom and tangerine.

Compared to the less remarkable vintages of the past, San Lorenzo's 2004 Brunello represents a complete about face. This is a gorgeous wine with bold aromas of blackberries, spice, smoke and moist tobacco. The finish is enduring and fresh, and it gives the wine an attractively firm and elongated feel.

wine: Vignerons des Terres Secrètes 2008 Cuvée Delaye les Pierres Grises  (Saint-Véran)
review: Hard-edged wine, with wood flavors dominant over the steely fruit character. It is very structured, perhaps too much.

wine: Sileni 2017 Plateau Reserve Pinot Noir (Hawke's Bay)
review: This starts on the soapy, synthetic side, but these qualities do blow off some with time in glass. There's plenty of cherry fruit here too, along with floral, orange rind, Middle Eastern spice and dusty oak aromas. Gritty in texture and medium in weight, the palate tastes of tangy fruit and oak and finishes a touch bitter. This sturdy wine lacks some of the verve and brightness of the variety.

appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Aromas of pear, stone fruit and lees lead to peach and floral flavors. The concentration is light and elegant.

This is a wood aged wine, full of vanilla flavors as well as fragrant fruitiness. It has great flavor intensity, with bright notes of juicy green plum and grapefruit that are framed by acidity and a tight, mineral texture. It needs some years aging, so drink from 2018.

With the Bandol's very own Mourvèdre dominating the blend of this wine, it has a spicy character, with layers of tannins as well as rich red-currant and berry fruits. It's a complex wine, offering pure fruit but with elegance and a rich aftertaste. Drink from late 2018.

This Chardonnay is barrel fermented, aged on the lees and spends additional time in the barrel, all resulting in a big, honeyed wine. It is tremendously rich, on top of the underlying ripe fruit flavors of mangoes and peaches. Excellent acidity and firm minerality add complexity.

wine: Ropiteau 2019 Les Plants Nobles Pinot Noir (Vin de France)
appellation: Vin de France, France Other, France
review: The aroma brings together cranberry and violet, leading to a light and fruity palate of plum, cranberry and pomegranate. Soft tannins and lazy acidity.

wine: Realm Cellars 2016 Beckstoffer To Kalon Red (Napa Valley)
review: From the famous site, this is a warm, concentrated, impressive wine brimming in tension and fresh acidity. Caramel, baked cherry, cedar and tight-grained tannins are just the beginning of a complex, layered and complicated journey of intense balance and savory character.

An exotic nose lends notes of sandalwood, rosewater and spice. The palate of this wine stays light, translucent and bright, shimmering with freshness and aromatics on the easy, light body. It finishes fresh and dry.
A blend of all five Bordeaux reds, this is a very ripe, soft wine, brimming with cherry, chocolate, pecan pie and oak flavors. It doesn't seem like an ager, but rewards now for its lushness.

This commingles grapes from Lancel Creek, Terra de Promissio and Estines vineyards, all single-vineyard designates in their own right. Together, they offer floral notes of rose and lavender within exotic forested wood, dried herb, cardamom and blood orange. The whole is balanced and silky smooth.

wine: Mercer 2016 Edge of Heaven Blend Red (Horse Heaven Hills)
appellation: Horse Heaven Hills, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Quite dried out-seeming aromas of raspberry, vanilla and cherry are followed by ripe fruit flavors that also seem desiccated. The concentration comes off as quite light.

Aromas of spice, vanilla and wood are stronger than this wine's fruit scents. Pure and lush on the palate, this is showing fine balance. Flavors of baking spices, caramel, vanilla and black fruits finish mildly and subtly, with mocha notes and good length. Drink this ripe Cabernet blend through 2019.

The sense of structure that is so evident in 2010 wines is particularly apparent in this perfumed, rich and firmly tannic selection. It shows the hard edges of granite soil, plus juicy red fruit. Concentrated and complex, it needs several years to mature.

wine: Stolpman 2018 The Great Places Ruben Solorzano Syrah (Ballard Canyon)
appellation: Ballard Canyon, Central Coast, California, US
review: This special bottling in honor of vineyard manager Ruben Solorzano begins with aromas of roasted boysenberry, black pepper and crumpled purple flowers. There's a rustic, almost gritty tannic structure to the sip, which will smooth with time to allow the spicy black-pepper, strong acidity and jammy fruit flavors to better coalesce. Drink 2023–2038.

appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: This barrel-fermented Chardonnay, from the oldest plantings (1972) in Washington State, displays exceptional concentration and palate weight. Apple pie, pear tart, baking spice, butter and caramel flavors abound. It's rich and packed with fruit, along with the seductive flavors that aging in new French oak can provide.

appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: The aromas aren't fully ready to reveal their charms, with notes of spice, plum and cherry. The flavors are plump, ripe, and show pleasing purity and depth, with the mouthfeel upping the appeal. It's a lot of wine for the money. Give it a short decant.

appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: An unusual style, with light scents of fennel leading into intriguing flavors of caraway, arugula and pear. However, after a promising start, the wine fades quickly into a light, tart finish.

wine: Frescobaldi 2015 Tenuta Perano Rialzi Gran Selezione  (Chianti Classico)
review: Pipe-tobacco, baked plum and blue-flower aromas mingle with camphor and coconut while the austere palate features dried cherry, pomegranate, licorice and a hint of espresso. Close-grained tannins give it a drying finish.

wine: Château du Taillan 2011 La Dame Blanche  (Bordeaux Blanc)
review: This is a bright, fruity, rounded wine with a soft texture. It's full and ripe, with melon and green plum notes, plus a touch of bitterness on the finish.

appellation: San Francisco Bay, Central Coast, California, US
review: Wood smoke, black pepper and clove aromas lead to powerful, grapey, blackberry-like flavors in this firm and tannic wine aged in all new oak barrels. It is concentrated, oaky and mouth-puckering.

wine: Ingrid Groiss 2017 Braitenpuechtorff Gemischter Satz White (Niederösterreich)
review: The hints of sun-dried hay, russet pear and bright lemon that mark the nose of this wine combine into zesty freshness on the palate. It's ripe and concentrated, with a dry, lemony zing that lingers until the very last echo.

wine: Chehalem 2014 Stoller Vineyard Ian's Reserve Chardonnay (Willamette Valley)
appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: Back in fine form, this shows crisp and fresh apple, white peach and green melon fruit. Aged in 41% new and 25% one-year-old oak, it's not especially toasty, but has the concentration and balance to develop well over the next six to eight years.

appellation: Anderson Valley, Mendocino County, California, US
review: This dry (or nearly dry) wine is lively and well-balanced, fresh and appetizing. Rose petal and peach aromas lead to citrus and peach flavors that are charming and nicely concentrated.

wine: Henschke 2002 Lenswood Abbotts Prayer Red (Adelaide Hills)
review: This is an enjoyable wine, one with coffee and caramel accents on the nose, and plum, berry and oak flavors. It's hard not to like, but at this price, shouldn't it be love at first sight? Merlot, with some Cab Sauvignon and Cab Franc. Imported by Negociants USA, Inc.
All tannins and black fruits, this is a powerful wine. It is tough, very structured, firm and closed up. The acidity dominates the red fruits on the finish. It has immense promise for the long term.

wine: The Four Graces 2014 Pinot Blanc (Willamette Valley)
appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: This is a thrilling example of just how good Oregon Pinot Blanc can be. Lush and captivating flavors conjure up fresh-baked apple pie, along with citrus, melon and a streak of creamy vanilla. The depth and persistence are exceptional.

Light maple, grape jelly and meaty aromas are succeeded by berry-basket flavors on the palate. A Shiraz with wide appeal, though it's young right now and not yet singing at full volume. Drink after 2007. Imported by Foster's Wine Estates Americas.

This premier cru, from the 18th generation of the Lamblin family, has produced a crisp, cool wine with some steely acidity from vines on the left bank of the Serein river. Its fresh mien is underlined by the citrus flavors and green-apple aftertaste. Drink from 2021.

This interesting blend boasts aromas of preserved lemons and fresh herbs, then turns a bit plumper in the mouth, with nectarine flavors joining in. Tart and high-acid on the finish, making it a natural with oily seafood dishes like fresh sardines.

appellation: Barossa Valley-Clare Valley, South Australia, Australia
review: This is an ultraripe, full-throttle wine oozing raspberry jam and floral dish soap aromas along with a fair whack of peppery oak. The ripeness and oak influence continues on the palate. It's just barely saved by lifted acidity.

Produced in one of the most spectacular of the Douro's many spectacular vineyards, this wine is a serious structure of ripe black fruits and dark tannins. The fruit is going to yield a smooth, concentrated, juicy and smoky wine. Likely to take its tine, this major wine is impressive in its richness. Drink from 2025.

appellation: Anderson Valley, Mendocino County, California, US
review: This is a very pure, clear Pinot Noir. It doesn't have a lot of alcohol, extract or oak. It's ripe in cherries and blueberries, but not overripe. The acidity is bright and the mouthfeel is silky. In other words, it's super-drinkable.

An attractive floral fragrance of peach blossom, cherry blossom, lychee and broom take shape in the glass. The vibrant palate boasts a core of crunchy apple and juicy nectarine, while mineral and ginger notes add depth.

appellation: Central Coast, Central Coast, California, US
review: A delightful Riesling, crisp in Central Coast acidity and with classic flavors of green apples, citrus fruits, honeysuckle flowers and a pungent note of petrol. It straddles the border between dry and off-dry, and is easy to like with Vietnamese and Cambodian fare.

Shows tons of beautiful red and black berries on the nose, which carry over to the palate in the form of juicy, perfectly ripe flavors tinged with just a hint of graham cracker. Acidity is lively; can be enjoyed now through 2011.

wine: Chimney Rock 2012 Tomahawk Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Stags Leap District)
appellation: Stags Leap District, Napa, California, US
review: From an estate-grown, valley-floor vineyard on the southern edges of the winery property, this wine is complex and nuanced in berry pie and a satchel of dried herb. Sizable tannins—which show promise to be tamed with time—form the integrated structure, supporting a lengthy, mocha-chocolate finish. Cellar through 2020.
An earthy overtone and moderate fruit flavors make a decent combination in this medium-bodied and straightforward wine.

Reilly's Clare Valley location tends to give its wines a little more focus than some of the wines coming out of nearby Barossa, like in this fine example of old vine Grenache. Aromas of brandied cherries sprinkled with star anise add touches of chocolate and earth on the palate. It's full, round and generous, yet finishes firm and focused. Drink now and over the next few years.

This is a pretty lean, tightly focused wine. Grilled pineapple and citrus notes broaden slightly on the midpalate, then come together again on the crisp, lemony finish. Drink now through the end of 2015.

Ferentano is a luscious and rich white wine that shows enough structure and staying power to pair with roast pork or turkey and gravy. It boasts a round, soft and supple texture backed by thick density.

The style of Jacquart's nonvintage Champagne is rich, ripe and full bodied. Along with its generous feel, it features apple-driven acidity, pink grapefruit flavor and a final, attractive bite of crispness. It tastes young, fruity and bright.

Tropical fruit, crushed herb, red bell pepper and fragrant white flower are just some of the aromas you'll find on this expressive white. On the juicy palate, fresh acidity brightens white peach and grapefruit while a note of white pepper lifts the finish.

wine: Napa Cellars 2014 Classic Collection Chardonnay (Napa Valley)
review: A hearty cradling of oak provides a tinge of vanilla sweetness here, before richer notions of apple pie and cinnamon tug at the wine's fuller-bodied core. It'll appeal to fans of this richer, riper style, while still finishing in a measure of acidity.
This is a leathery, thick and robust wine that shows more presence of black tea and tannin than tang of fruit.

wine: Castello di Radda 2006 Poggio Selvale Riserva  (Chianti Classico)
review: There's a nice balance here between red fruit and cherries with spice and tobacco. In the background, you'll pick up subtle shadings of green leaf or dried mint with smoky mineral notes on the close. The mouthfeel is dry and textured. Only 250 cases made.
A blend dominated by Merlot, this wine is all about fruit. Young tannins and juicy black-currant flavors have fresh acidity and a crisp aftertaste. Drink from 2021.

wine: Easton 2010 Monarch Mine Vineyard Sauvignon Blanc (Sierra Foothills)
appellation: Sierra Foothills, Sierra Foothills, California, US
review: This crisp white is inviting and dry, with aromas of citrus, fig and fennel. Reminiscent of a fine Sancerre, it's finely structured, steely and still lushly textured and full enough in the mouth to enjoy with seafood, a creamy goat cheese salad or entirely on its own.

appellation: Dundee Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: A dark streak runs straight through this excellent Pinot. It's a whirl of smoke and chocolate, focused right through the core of rum-soaked cherries. Tannic and deep, big and bold—pull this out for your heartiest meal.

wine: Domaine Alfred 2005 Chamisal Vineyards Chardonnay (Edna Valley)
appellation: Edna Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: Lots of acidity in this crunchy wine; this is so tart it's almost like fresh-squeezed lime juice. Fortunately, creamy lees and plenty of new oak add softer, sweeter notes of buttered toast and vanilla.

This vintage of Barbaresco from the excellent Pajé cru is very focused on wild strawberries, red currant and cassis but behind the fruit you will find white mineral, ash and smoke. The mouthfeel is compact and firm but much of the pulpy fruit here has since evolved. The wine is ready to drink and would pair with risotto and white truffles.

Candied cherry, strawberry and a bright minerality highlight this wine, with additional accents of herb and earth. Simultaneously fresh and bold, it features a creamy texture that's near velvety but denser, leading up to a powerful finish.
Apple and white fruit aromas set up a balanced, reasonably full palate, with banana, creamy oak, vanilla and apple flavors. It feels solid and round, with a clean finish.

wine: Barrister 2009 Klipsun Vineyard Sauvignon Blanc (Red Mountain)
appellation: Red Mountain, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: A tasty, round, nicely-balanced, fruity style. Flavors are fruit driven, with lots of melon, apple and pear dominating. The acids are just right, and the wine is as clean and fresh as it can possibly be.

wine: Last Light 2019 Derbyshire Vineyard Pinot Noir (San Luis Obispo County)
appellation: San Luis Obispo County, Central Coast, California, US
review: Dark berries, purple flowers and toasty spices make for a smoothly integrated nose on this bottling from a vineyard along the San Simeon coast that gets the “last light” of each day. There's a solid tension to the sip, which frames the ripe and accessible yet tart red fruits, with aromatic lavender touches lifting the entire  experience.

appellation: Snipes Mountain, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Ripe and spicy, this is a very rich and fruity Gewürz, with moderate sweetness (1.6% residual sugar). Melon, mango, candied orange peel dominate, it's round and tasty, without the soapy or oily quality of the variety.

wine: Silver Lake 2008 Roza Hills Vineyard Reserve Chardonnay (Rattlesnake Hills)
appellation: Rattlesnake Hills, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: An exceptional value, this is buttery and round, loaded with peaches and creamy vanilla flavors. Solidly mainstream and quite delicious in a full-on, barrel-fermented, 100% malolactic style.

wine: Red Stitch 2013 Soberanes Vineyard Pinot Noir (Santa Lucia Highlands)
appellation: Santa Lucia Highlands, Central Coast, California, US
review: This wine from an ownership team of former pro baseballers Rich Aurilia and Dave Roberts is plush on the nose with dried strawberry, gingerbread and baking spices. The palate offers pomegranate-cherry juice along with graphite and coffee notes.

wine: Villa del Lago 2008 Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
review: This starts out a bit coarse, with strong tannins that have a rough-edged feeling. It's very rich in blackberries and black currants, but showing more power than elegance. Time in the glass certainly opens it up, revealing a rich, heady cassis note. While the alcohol is high, it may easily develop bottle complexity over the next 10–15 years.

wine: Grey Wolf Cellars 2015 Instinctual Grenache (Paso Robles)
appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: Slightly stewed aromas of red-cherry syrup meet with gravel and wet earth on the nose of this bottling. Baked cherry flavors are paired with vanilla and gingersnaps on the palate, where the acidity steadily rises.

wine: Joyce 2018 James Joyce Cabernet Sauvignon (San Benito)
appellation: San Benito, Central Coast, California, US
review: Blackberry and slightly funky leather aromas meet with lanolin tones on the nose of this bottling. It's bone dry on the palate, where leathery flavors of dried blackberry and smoke arise.

Floral streaks of orange blossom open this wine, followed by vibrant bursts of lemon. Estate grown, produced and bottled, this fresh, balanced wine picks up weight on the finish, ending with a ripeness of voluptuous apple and oak.

wine: Château de Marsan 2011  Cadillac Côtes de Bordeaux
appellation: Cadillac Côtes de Bordeaux, Bordeaux, France
review: A fragrant, fruity wine, with fruit tannins, just a hint of wood and tight black-currant fruit. This is a dry wine, firm at the center and needing a year to round out.

wine: Garage Wine Co. 2014 Lot #58 Portezuelo Vineyard Carignan (Itata Valley)
review: Earthy berry aromas are a touch heavy and raisiny, with horse and leather notes. A full chunky palate is more dense than expansive, while this tastes of baked plum and prune. Hard tannins are drawing on a full-size finish. Drink the ripest and heaviest of Garage's 2014 Carignans through 2021.

wine: Fournier Père et Fils 2016 Côtes de Morogues  (Menetou-Salon)
review: This is a delicious wine— a soft generous style of Sauvignon Blanc. With ripe apples that are balanced by crisp acidity, the wine is deliciously fruity. There is a light dusting of pepper at the end. Drink from late 2017.

wine: Bellante 2016 The Dark Side Cuvee Pinot Noir (Sta. Rita Hills)
appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
review: Deep and dark aromas of blackberry, elderberry, black plum and clove show on the nose of this bottling. The palate is rather thick and somewhat sweet with blackberry jelly, roasted meat and brown-sugar flavors.

appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: Ripe and candied strawberry aromas meet with nutmeg on the delicious nose of this bottling. There is a strong acidic tang to the palate, where macerated strawberry flavors feel quite fresh and young. It goes down easy.

wine: Yalumba 2004 Hand Picked t/g/v Tempranillo-Grenache-Viog Red (Barossa)
review: This is a new addition to Yalumba's Hand Picked range. Blackberry, black cherry and raspberry aromas and flavors dominate, from nose to tail. This is an enjoyable wine, but it's not quite as complex as the line's other offerings. Imported by Negociants USA, Inc.

wine: Dona Maria-Júlio Bastos 2014 Júlio B. Bastos Grande Reserva Alicante Bouschet (Alentejo)
review: Pure Alicante Bouschet, now mature, reveals the depths of flavor of this grape variety. The wine has a smoky character and tannins that are fully integrated into the fruit and acidity. Its structure has softened while leaving a fresh kick and touches of licorice. Drink this fine wine now.

wine: Grey Stack 2008 Rosemary's Block Dry Stack Vineyard Sauvignon Blanc (Bennett Valley)
review: Nice and crisp, with a bite of acidity brightening the lemon, lime, pineapple, honeysuckle, vanilla and pepper spice flavors. Could be a touch drier, but it's a sound Sauvignon Blanc.

appellation: South Eastern Australia, Australia Other, Australia
review: Aromas are of dusty tropical fruits. It's a soft-bodied wine, easy to drink, with fresh tropical fruit flavors on the palate. Enjoy on the patio.

wine: Le Vieux Pin 2012 Ava White (Okanagan Valley)
review: A brilliant blend of 61% Viognier, 21% Roussanne and 18% Marsanne, this impresses with its proportion, tension and balance. Scents and flavors meld citrus oil and rind, fruit flavors of pineapple, grapefruit and Meyer lemon, and a lovely finish with highlights of English breakfast tea. Long and elegant, this is a landmark effort.

wine: Castello di Gabbiano 2016 Cavaliere d'Oro  (Chianti Classico)
review: Aromas of violet, dark berry and underbrush lead the nose on this 90% Sangiovese, 5% Merlot and 5% Colorino blend. The juicy palate offers black cherry, star anise and white pepper alongside pliant tannins.

wine: Lemelson 2006 Jerome Reserve Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)
appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: This complex wine lists no fewer than eight different clones in the blend, harvested at an average of just 1.8 tons/acre. The winery suggests that it is their most ageworthy Pinot Noir, and the structure of this young wine would support that assertion. It's tight, hard, compact with black fruits, smoke and chewy tannins. It's a wine that needs time to stretch its considerable muscles. The roughly 50/50 mix of new and once-used barrels adds baking chocolate, licorice and charred toast to the finish; well-integrated and buttressed with crisp acids. But the lingering flavor is of raspberry jam; so good you want to spread it directly on your tongue.

Quite round and chewy, but zesty enough to stay on balance. There's lemon custard and pineapple on the fresh nose, and apple, banana and vanilla flavors. Finishes slightly toasty; nicely oaked. Imported by Billington Imports.

wine: Hudson Vineyards 2014 Pick Up Sticks Red (Carneros)
review: This is an estate-grown blend of 80% Grenache, 15% Syrah and 5% Viognier from the great vineyard site, savory in spicy white pepper, blueberry and a persistence of cinnamon and clove. Floral aromas and a delicate texture provide a memorable experience on the palate, finishing in a tease of tobacco.

Give this wine some time to blow off reduced aromas and you'll be rewarded with a simple but charming collection of mixed black and red fruit. A few dry tannins emerge on the cherry-spiked finish. Drink up.

wine: Chronic Cellars 2009 Mr. Nibbles Red (Paso Robles)
appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: Mainly Petite Sirah, this robust, fruity wine shakes up the mouth with the sheer force of its fruit. It's dry, but rich in blackberry jam and dark chocolate. Verging on sweet, it's a nice partner to rich, spicy barbecue.

wine: Michel Torino 2009 Don David Reserve Malbec (Calchaquí Valley)
review: A disjointed, out-of-the-box Malbec that starts out peanutty and earthy on the nose. Things round out aromatically, but in the mouth it's angular and edgy, with stunted blackberry flavors offset by tartness. Has its positives but overall it doesn't fully click.

appellation: Arroyo Seco, Central Coast, California, US
review: Key lime, wet stone and a steely minerality show on the crisp nose of this bottling. Rounded flavors of lemon and orange balm meet with orange blossom and jasmine on the palate, which shows the slightest hint of sweet.

appellation: Ramona Valley, South Coast, California, US
review: Extremely tangy aromas of plum skin meet with lilac and acai on the nose of this bottling. Purple-flower flavors are strong on the palate, but the tangy black-plum-skin and tart boysenberry-balsamic elements dominate.

appellation: Umpqua Valley, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
review: Showing just a hint of sweetness, this well-rounded effort offers a ripe and tangy mix of lime, grapefruit, pineapple and white peach fruit flavors. There's a touch of honey running alongside and trickling out through the finish. It's drinking at or near its peak.

wine: Double Canyon 2012 Cabernet Sauvignon (Horse Heaven Hills)
appellation: Horse Heaven Hills, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: A new offering from the winery, this includes Syrah (13%) and Malbec (3%) in the mix. It's direct and appealing in notes of blueberry, cherry and well-placed vanilla accents. The flavors are supple and polished, with the oak (30% new French) pleasantly dialed back, the tannins providing a gentle squeeze and the acids drawing things out nicely.
This wine is starting to show its age, disclosing hints of truffles and earth in addition to savory raspberries and cherries. The texture is silky, with an edge of acidity for balance.

Big and bold, like the excellent '04 version. If anything, it emphasizes the fruit even a bit more, with less spicy complexity, but it's a black hole of plum and blackberry fruit that explodes in the mouth, staining the palate with fruity intensity. The alcohol level must be elevated, but it's well concealed by supple tannins. Drink now–2015.

wine: Laurenz V. 2004 Laurenz and Sophie Singing Grüner Veltliner (Austria)
review: This well-priced wine boasts ripe aromas of nectarine and lime, then delivers more stone fruit on the palate. With its fresh, citrusy finish, this isn't a particularly peppery or complex Grüner, but one that provides a tasty introduction to the genre.

Pear and yellow apple aromas include hints of wet stone and vanilla. A tight palate with lemony acidity delivers mineral notes along with dry citrus flavors reflective of lemon and tangerine. A clean, crisp finish wraps up this pure Albariño.

wine: Tempus Cellars 2012 Sagemoor Vineyards Cabernet Sauvignon (Columbia Valley (WA))
appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: This 100% varietal wine displays aromas of herb, leaf, cocoa, barrel spice and currant. The flavors are light and fresh, showing restraint and a pleasing mouthfeel. The finish lingers.

In a forward, fruity style, a wine that is full of ripe fruits, juicy ready to drink. Blueberries, sweet black berries are pressed into a sold structure that certainly has tannins. There is a final taste of spice and fresh acidity.

wine: Adega Cooperativa do Cartaxo 2015 Bridão Classico Branco White (Tejo)
review: A soft, fruity wine made from Fernão Pires and Arinto grapes. It has the lightest fruit, gently crisp acidity and a final burst of citrus. Drink now.

This is a Barolo you could probably enjoy tonight with dinner. Its leathery aromas mixed with a mature touch of forest and roasted fruit say “I'm ready.” Medium-bodied and not too tannic, it has a full and ripe cherry flavor, an attribute for an early-drinker such as this.

wine: Legado del Moncayo 2016 Garnacha Blanca (Campo de Borja)
appellation: Campo de Borja, Northern Spain, Spain
review: Aromas of clover and yeasty vanilla lack concentration. This feels a bit oily, while nonspecific citrus flavors finish with a note of grape skins and brine. It's acidic and medium to light in body.

wine: Luigi Bosca 2014 Single Vineyard A.O.C. Malbec (Luján de Cuyo)
appellation: Luján de Cuyo, Mendoza Province, Argentina
review: Rustic, gritty berry aromas come with notes of plastic, oak grain and grass. This is raw, chewy and tannic in feel, with roasted, spicy berry flavors that run low on ripeness. A salt-and-pepper finish includes herbal berry flavors and sticky tannins.

wine: Scar of the Sea 2018 Rancho Tepusquet Chardonnay (Santa Maria Valley)
appellation: Santa Maria Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: From own-rooted vines planted in 1973, this bottling offers aromas of Asian pear, strong chalk, jicama and soft butter. The palate is incredibly crisp, clean chalky and tense, with tightly wound flavors of lime pith, talc, more jicama and loads of white-fleshed fruits.

appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
review: Toast and spice notes add warmth to crisp blackberry and cassis on this elegantly composed Meritage. Richly concentrated on the palate, it's bold and mouthfilling, with big, brawny tannins that should meld beautifully over the next 3–5 years.

wine: Le Bèrne 2014  Vino Nobile di Montepulciano
appellation: Vino Nobile di Montepulciano, Tuscany, Italy
review: Aromas of moist soil, underbrush, leather and a whiff of eucalyptus take shape on this. Taut and racy, the linear palate offers sour cherry, cranberry, powdered sage and a hint of clove set against vibrant acidity. Tight, rather grainy tannins grip the close.

wine: Macchia 2012 Lodi Native Noma Ranch Zinfandel (Mokelumne River)
appellation: Mokelumne River, Central Valley, California, US
review: Very full-bodied it carries a gorgeous ripe blackberry character from the first whiff to the long, lingering finish. Deep, dark ruby in color, it discloses aromas of berries with hints of cedar. The pure fruit essence in the flavor makes it delicious, compelling and memorable.

wine: Palliser Estate 2008 The Great Walter Pinot Noir (Martinborough)
review: This is a solid, well made Pinot Noir, just one that shows more oak than fruit at this stage of its evolution. Vanilla and coffee flavors overshadow pleasant cherry and herb notes in this medium-bodied, slightly chewy wine.
This wine has a rustic, unclean quality. At a high alcohol level it also tastes disjointed, all about heat without fruit.

wine: Tasca d'Almerita 2015 Rosso del Conte Red (Contea di Sclafani)
appellation: Contea di Sclafani, Sicily & Sardinia, Italy
review: Scorched soil, leather, mature black-skinned fruit and Mediterranean scrub are just some of the aromas you'll find on this blend of Nero d'Avola and Perricone. The enveloping, full-bodied palate delivers ripe blackberry, black cherry, black spice and dried herb alongside firm, fine-grained tannins. Drink 2020–2030.

This opens with aromas of black-skinned berry, underbrush and leather. Made with organically cultivated grapes, the savory palate delivers Marasca cherry, black pepper and cinnamon alongside lithe tannins and bright acidity. Enjoy through 2025.

appellation: Santa Maria Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: Simple and direct in oaky, fruity pineapple and lemon jam flavors, this Chardonnay tastes a little sweet. It's made in the modern style, appealing if not particularly complex. Drink now.
Earthy black tea and toasted oak accent a delicate opening bouquet in this widely appealing wine that is light and bright in wild strawberry and spice.

wine: Quinta do Pôpa 2012 Pôpa Tinta Roriz (Douro)
review: An unusual 100% Tinta Roriz, this wine is ripe with well-integrated tannins and good acidity. Blackberry fruits give crispness and a full body. This attractive wine is ready to drink.

What a delicious Sauvignon Blanc, and look at that everyday price. It's so easy to like the creamy, yet tart flavors of peaches, with a slight touch of sour lees for complexity. From Mason Cellars, with a case production of 48,000.
Jammy and sweet on the nose, like a jar of strawberry preserves. The palate, however, is light and tart, with burnt berry flavors. Finishes peppery and short, with little to latch onto.

This light- to medium-bodied red boasts bright scents of cherries with a dusting of cinnamon, backed by silky tannins and delicate minerality. It's rather Burgundian in style and feel, without any overripe notes.

wine: Raymond 2012 Small Lot Collection Barrel-Fermented Chardonnay (Napa Valley)
review: Way too oaky, with buttered toast, honey and caramel flavors dominating. The underlying wine, which is crisp in acidity and suggests limes, peaches and apricots, just isn't strong enough to handle all that oak.

wine: Kanonkop 2014 Black Label Estate Wine Pinotage (Simonsberg-Stellenbosch)
review: There's a lifted, vibrant impression to the nose of this impressive, well-crafted wine. It's a pleasant surprise, as it lends levity and definition to the notes of black cherry, crushed purple flowers, licorice root and earth. The mouthfeel is plush and mouthfilling, yet not oppressively so, with ample acidity and structured but velvety tannins. The rich, ripe and robust palate leads into a long finish. It promises a long life of beautiful evolution ahead, maturing to reveal greater nuance and elegance, so cellar through 2030.

wine: Viszlay Vineyards 2010 Estate Bottled Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)
appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: Lots of classy Russian River character is found in this Pinot. It's dry, full bodied and filled with rich black-cherry, cola and spice flavors. The tannins are fine, and the acidity is brisk, making the wine feel balanced. Might even gain traction over the next 2-3 years.

wine: Château de Rayne Vigneau 2012 Barrel Sample  (Sauternes)
review: 92–94. Barrel Sample. This wine feels concentrated and densely structured with a great texture of spice, botrytis and acidity. It's a success for the vintage—full and richly structured—with fruit and dry botrytis well in balance.
Though labeled American White Table Wine, this is a pink blend of Riesling, Muscat, Pinot Gris and Pinot Noir. It's on the sweet side of off dry, with flavors of strawberry and marshmallow cream.

wine: Foley 2016 Barrel Select Chardonnay (Sta. Rita Hills)
appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
review: Strong aromas of jasmine and honeysuckle meet with creamy white-peach and sweet sandalwood aromas on the nose of this bottling. The palate is classic California Chardonnay: oak, lemon and pineapple flavors riding solid acidity.

appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
review: The nose on this widely available bottling is vivacious and juicy, with strawberry, strawberry blossoms and raspberries laid across a pencil-lead frame. It tightens on the palate, with lots of graphite and pencil shavings, showing just a bit of pomegranate fruit.

wine: Villa Sandi NV Cuvée Oris Dry  (Valdobbiadene Prosecco Superiore)
review: Delicately scented, this inviting sparkler offers light aromas of white and yellow stone fruit along with a whiff of bread crust. The creamy, slightly sweet palate tastes of white peach, candied citrus peel and ripe apple set against a soft, frothy mousse. Bright acidity refreshes the rich flavors while a glazed-almond note graces the close.

wine: Domaine Jean Grivot 2004 Les Beaux Monts Premier Cru  (Vosne-Romanée)
review: Starts with firm fruits, showing more tannin than fruitiness. Then those fruits begin to shine and glow through the structure, although on the finish the dryness returns along with some new wood flavors.

This is a delicate Rosso di Montalcino with aromas of red berry, almond and cola. It's short and compact in the mouth but offers good freshness that could match simple chicken or pork dishes. Drink now.

With its bright acidity, Cimicky's 2005 Autograph stands out a bit from the pack of Barossa Shiraz. Blueberry-blackberry fruit and peppery spice is underlined by vibrant acids, which give this wine a more reined-in feel than many of its counterparts. Despite supple tannins, it comes across as firm on the finish, where it picks up hints of caramel or maple syrup.

wine: Chateau Ste. Michelle 2017 Mimi Cabernet Sauvignon (Horse Heaven Hills)
appellation: Horse Heaven Hills, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: The aromas are unusual, with notes of scorched earth and soil, showing reduction that distracts. Over time, bittersweet chocolate, cherry and herb notes emerge. The palate shows a reserved sense of styling, exhibiting polish and balance. A light grip of tannins pulls it all together. It's in an awkward spot at present.

wine: Domaine Serene 2008 Etoile Vineyard Dijon Clones Chardonnay (Dundee Hills)
appellation: Dundee Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: Estate-grown, fermented in small, neutral oak and given extended lees stirring in the Burgundian style, this concentrated, textural, sensuous offering brings intensity on all fronts. The deep flavors of lemon, orange, apple and pear are wrapped in bright acids and lightly toasty tannins. Excellent concentration and length.

Favorable exchange rates have lowered the price of this gem to nearly everyday status, making it a terrific value. Ripe melon and red berry flavors are supported by a firm bed of crushed stone, then garnished by subtle spice notes. Typical of Tavel, it's on the full-bodied side for a rosé, but doesn't seem heavy at all. Drink now–2018.

wine: Star Lane Vineyard 2014 Cabernet Sauvignon (Happy Canyon of Santa Barbara)
appellation: Happy Canyon of Santa Barbara, Central Coast, California, US
review: This vintage is the first that was under complete control of winemaker Tyler Thomas, and his studious touch shows magically. There's a powerful density of ripe but not sweet black fruit on the nose of this bottling, along with hints of violets, turned earth and leather. The structure is firm, dense and chalky but with a vivid acidity, offering ethereal, supple flavors of black currant and cocoa on the finish. Drink 2018–2034.

A brisk spray of lemon perfumes the concentrated peach and flower flavors on this bright, racy Riesling. It's full of sweet-tasting fruitiness, but zippy acidity keeps the palate brisk and easy- drinking.

wine: Keller 2015 El Coro Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)
review: Earthy in mushroom and pine, this Petaluma Gap-made wine is generous in tannin, with a substantial underlying weight that supports cherry and blueberry flavors. The earthiness takes on a stemmy quality that is wild and complex.

This opens with subdued aromas reminiscent of acacia flower, toasted nut and citrus drop while the lean, zesty palate suggests lemon rind, yellow apple skin and bitter almond. Bracing acidity provides a brisk framework.

wine: Arrogant Frog 2016 Ribet Red Cabernet Sauvignon-Merlot (Pays d'Oc)
review: A friendly, easy-drinking red blend, this offers pleasant notes of cassis and black plum throughout, hit by decadent accents of cocoa, woodspice and licorice root. It's direct and straightforward in feel, but well balanced and clean.

appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: This off-dry (11.5% alcohol) Riesling is a fruit-driven wine, with a tangy sweet/tart mouthfeel reminiscent of Vouvray. Meyer lemon, apricot, lime and candied pineapple flavors pile on. There's plenty of natural acid to cut through the sweetness.
This rosé is almost as rich as a red wine, the difference being a fresher, red-fruit character. It has vanilla flavors, a dry texture and a touch of pepper.

wine: Two Paddocks 2016 The Last Chance Pinot Noir (Central Otago)
review: Actor Sam Neill is behind this highly regarded Otago label. While it sits firmly in premium territory—and could easily age for the next 10 years—this Pinot is undeniably approachable now. The nose offers heady aromas of red and black berries, beets, vanilla, hot chocolate, Middle Eastern spices and stalky cinnamon. The palate is elegant and tightly wound, with an earthy core and a savory finish.

wine: Lafage 2017 La Grande Cuvée Blanc White (Côtes du Roussillon)
review: A blend of old-vine Grenache Blanc, Grenache Gris and Macabeu planted on schist soils, this wine opens with stunningly beautiful bouquet, offering pronounced aromas of musk melon, peach, nectarine and pressed yellow flowers as well as hints of peony and orange blossom. The lush palate is slightly round and full, but pleasantly so, and balanced by ample acidity and a subtle woody texture to lift the fruity weight and lend structure. Drink now–2023.

wine: Fielding Hills 2010 Tribute RiverBend Vineyard Red (Wahluke Slope)
appellation: Wahluke Slope, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: A blend of Cabernet Franc, Syrah, Merlot, and Cabernet Sauvignon, it's ripe and succulent with notes of cherry, vanilla and sweet spices supported by tart acids and tightly wound tannins.

wine: Bodegas Vínícola Real 2014 Cueva del Monge Fermentado en Barrica White (Rioja)
designation: Cueva del Monge Fermentado en Barrica
review: Mild fruit aromas are crowded by peanut and burnt-wood notes. This Viura-led blend is full and round on the palate, with forceful flavors of nutty stone fruits, sea brine and wood resin. A lean, acidic palate is better in feel than weak flavors.

wine: Château de Valflaunès 1999 Espérance Pic Saint-Loup Syrah (Coteaux du Languedoc)
review: Under a veil of skunk cabbage, there's a wine waiting to emerge—but when it does, there's not much to it. Bland, earthy and tart, with dull red fruit. Pass.

Pretty aromas of cassis, cherry and sweet cream are inviting. Feels good, with zesty acidity and nice overall balance. Flavors of black currant, Bing cherry and plum cover the bases, while the finish is easygoing. The epitome of everyday Cabernet.

wine: Novy 2006 Parsons' Vineyard Syrah (Russian River Valley)
appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: Very ripe and extracted, just oozing the flavors of melted blackberry jam, black raspberry purée and milk chocolate. A bit sweet, but saved by firm tannins.

wine: Naches Heights 2010 Naches Heights Vineyard Syrah (Naches Heights)
appellation: Naches Heights, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: An aromatically interesting wine with notes of cherry, cedar and nori. The palate is flavorful with dry, rustic tannins.

From the “King of Beaujolais,” this wine's sweet cherry and grapey fruit epitomizes the best of that region's wines. Forward and juicy, there's enough spice to add a touch of complexity, plus a dash more depth than most Beaujolais.

wine: Longoria 2013 Rita's Crown Vineyard Chardonnay (Sta. Rita Hills)
appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
review: A bright and sour combination strikes the nose on this wine, with aromas of lime sorbet, kumquat and salted green apple rinds. The lean, focused and racy palate is led by crushed limestone grip, with the slight warmth of tart crab apples, proving quite palate cleansing. It's perfect for halibut or other delicate fish.

Leather, tobacco, mature plum and clove aromas unfold in the glass. The robust palate doles out fleshy blackberry, cherries marinated in spirits, licorice and nutmeg while assertive tannins offer support. The heat of alcohol shows on the finish. Drink through 2019.

Like most O. Fournier signature reds, this is dark, extracted and modern in style. The bouquet is full of rubber, marzipan, exotic spice and lemon-like aromas. It shows a rawness on the palate along with toasty dark-berry and lemon flavors. The finish is oaky, with tangy acids and a spot of heat. This is a blend of 80% Cabernet Franc, 10% Cabernet Sauvignon and 10% Carignan. Drink now–2015.

wine: Leeuwin Estate 2015 Prelude Vineyards Chardonnay (Margaret River)
review: From one of Margaret River's leading Chardonnay producers, the 2015 Prelude doesn't disappoint. It's a nutty, smokey, toasty, melony beauty. Perfectly in balance, with a chalky texture and medium to light body, it wears its heart on its sleeve and is drinking perfectly now, but will gain more even more complexity with a few years in bottle. Drink now–2022.

Aromas of underbrush, leather, dried plum, a whiff of French oak and a balsamic note lead the nose. The firm palate offers dried cherry, cranberry, licorice and espresso set against close-grained that leave a firm, rather drying finish.

wine: Domaine Luc et Lise Pavelot 2011 Sous Frétille Premier Cru  (Pernand-Vergelesses)
review: This is already a delicious wine. Young, fragrant fruits bring acidity and a dense sense of structure. The aftertaste shows the spice from wood aging.

appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: Rough and earthy, with some apple and peach flavors and a touch of oak, but also vegetal and mushroom elements. Very dry, with crisp acidity.

wine: Seven Hills 2015 McClellan Estate Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Walla Walla Valley (WA))
appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: The aromas deliver notes of green pepper, parsley, barrel spice, cherry cordial, fresh herb and anise. The palate brings an assortment of plush red and black-fruit flavors, with slightly dry tannins on the finish. It's quite well made but it comes off as a little green and astringent at present.

wine: Matias Riccitelli 2013 The Apple Doesn't Fall Far From The Tree Malbec (Mendoza)
designation: The Apple Doesn't Fall Far From The Tree
review: Concentrated, ripe blackberry and cassis aromas come with peppery spice and cedary oak notes. This is big and generous on the palate, with roasted, well-oaked blackberry flavors. A touch of heat lends sizzle to the finish. Drink through 2020.

wine: Hirsch Vineyards 2007 San Andreas Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)
review: Young and tart in cool-climate acidity, this Pinot needs time in the cellar. It's an exotic wine, spicy and peppery, almost briary, like a Zinfandel, except with flavors of wild forest raspberries, cherries, orange zest and a hint of pine cone. It's as cellarable a Pinot Noir as exists in California. Best after 2015.

wine: Joseph Drouhin 2010 Clos des Mouches Premier Cru  (Beaune)
review: Round and soft initially, this rich, intense Chardonnay then shows its firm side. In addition to the ripe yellow-fruit flavors, there is a minerally, tight structure that promises that this wine will age. Keep it for at least five years.

This Alvarinho comes from vines grown outside the classic Vinho Verde appellation in the larger Minhao region of northern Portugal, but you'd never know it. It has all the intensity and richness of the grape, with a rich texture and apricot and pineapple flavors. It's a fine wine that could age, so drink from 2016.

appellation: Applegate Valley, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
review: Pure varietal and estate grown, this opens with pretty fruit flavors of cherry and red plum. Aging in one-quarter new French oak adds a pleasing toasty note, along with a hint of dark chocolate.

Mocha, coffee, mint and spice in the nose and on the palate make this unique offering from South Africa a true expression of the country's diverse terroir. It has a friendly character, with its minerality and soft tannins, making it great for a meal of lighter dishes.

Trescone (Sangiovese, Ciliegiolo and Merlot) has a more musky and earthy personality with dark fruits, plums, prunes, red beets and a touch of crushed white peppercorn. It has very nice depth and concentration with bright blueberry and blackberry flavors and a thick, brooding quality.

Borgonero demonstrates a very clean and polished quality of winemaking that is reflected in its aromas of ripe cherry, tobacco and spice. It sits beautifully in the mouth and glides clean over the palate with lingering notes of black fruit and cola. Very nice.

wine: Georges Duboeuf 2016 Domaine de Javernière Côte du Py  (Morgon)
designation: Domaine de Javernière Côte du Py
review: The top wine from this estate comes from the famed Côte du Py vineyard. This wine is densely structured, full of tannins and with great potential. Black fruit is still developing under the dry texture but will surely be there in a few months. Drink from late 2018.

This ripe, wood-aged wine is both full of fruit and layered with toast and a rich, smooth texture. A stylish wine, it hints at herbal flavors and also fresh acidity and green plums. Drink from late 2016.

This is a spicy, lusciously fruity wine. Rich blackberry flavors are sustained by the tannins and the succulent acidity and texture. Aged for 18 months in wood, the wine was selected from what the producer considered a fine harvest. Drink this generous wine from 2022.

appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: This Zin comes in a half-bottle, and the alcohol is a Port-like 18.5%. It's a sweet wine, with sugary flavors of cherry pie filling, raspberry tart, chocolate and cassis-infused crème brûlée, finished with a crisp dose of acidity. Likeable for its balance, it makes a nice after-dinner or late night conclusion to a long, hard day.

wine: SignoSeis 2012 The Angel Oak Reserva Malbec (Uco Valley)
review: Blackberry and spice aromas form a harmonious bouquet that's subtle and potent. In the mouth, this is tight, fresh and alert, with raspberry, plum and baking-spice flavors. Freshness rules from front to finish, which offers cinnamon notes mixed with bright berry flavors. Drink through 2020.

Almost black in color, an infantile wine whose aromas are just beginning to emerge. Cassis and blackberry jam are joined to smoky, oaky scents. Huge, young and tannic, with high acidity and a treasure chest of buried fruit. Badly in need of at least three years in the cellar.
