wine: Francis Coppola 2014 Bevil-Wolcott Vineyard Reserve Petite Sirah (Dry Creek Valley)
appellation: Dry Creek Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: This is a well-made vineyard-designate, showing a full embrace of integrated oak and full-bodied richness. Red fruit, leather, meat and black licorice all figure into the mix, as the thickness in the glass suggests decanting or time to air.

appellation: Livermore Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: This is a good substantial wine that offers robust fruit and oak-spice aromas, a pretty big mouthfeel and full body. Sunbaked, cedary flavors fill the midpalate and continue on the finish.

wine: Buena Vista 2014 Karoly's Selection Petite Sirah (Sonoma County)
review: This wine pushes the envelope on ripeness, not unusual for the variety. Toasted oak and black-cherry jam make up the majority of the experience, riding a supple wave of soft tannin and concentrated power.

wine: Smith Devereux 2016 Ibex Proprietary Red (Napa Valley)
review: Blending 85% Merlot with 15% Syrah, this wine is creamy rich and grippy in sizable tannin, with subtle elements of ash, cedar and oak.

wine: Mongarda 2019 Metodo Classico Extra Brut  (Valdobbiadene Prosecco Superiore)
review: Aromas of white stone fruit, botanical herbs and hazelnut lift out of the glass. A metodo classico and undergoing the second fermentation in bottle as opposed to a steel tank like most Proseccos, the bone-dry, savory palate offers ripe pear, Meyer lemon and a hint of bread crust alongside vibrant acidity and a refined, continuous perlage. It shows energy and class.
This fresh Riesling offers crisp apple and spice on the nose and palate, as well as honeysuckle and citrus. Delicate and mild, it's not terribly intellectual, but an easygoing summer sip.

wine: Domaine LeSeurre 2015 Unoaked Cuvée Classique Chardonnay (Finger Lakes)
appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
review: This unoaked Chardonnay has a mild intensity of underripe peach and citrus on the nose, with a muddling of white flowers. The palate lags a bit with soft acidity, yet ripe peach chugs along to the finish.

appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
review: Very light in the glass, this bottling offers aromas of apple blossom and smoked pear. The smoke and pome-fruit character shows on the sip as well, where citrus and baked apple flavors are quite rich.

This full-bodied wine opens with earthy aromas of underbrush, truffle, leather and game. The juicy palate delivers ripe wild cherry and raspberry, accented by white pepper and cinnamon alongside firm  tannins. Drink 2015–2021.

wine: Volker Eisele Family Estate 2006 Family Estate Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
review: While this isn't in the same league as the winery's stunning Alexander reserve-style bottling of Cabernet, it's an approximation of it and, at about one-third the price, a pretty good value. The wine is rich in blackberry, currant and cedar flavors, and balanced with gorgeous tannins, showing true Napa elegance. Drink now–2012.

wine: Bisceglia 2011 Terra di Vulcano Dry Moscato (Basilicata)
review: This dry white wine opens with aromas of acacia flower, honey and stone fruit. The lack of sweetness holds back some of the aromatic intensity, and the wine is easy, fresh and zesty on the finish. Pair it with fried cocktail shrimp.

wine: Schramsberg 2011 Blanc de Blancs Brut Sparkling (North Coast)
appellation: North Coast, North Coast, California, US
review: Bracing and bright, this shows definite Chardonnay characteristics, such as a buttery, apple pie aroma and vivid crisp apple and lemon flavors. Nothing is overblown, though, so it retains finesse. This will be great as an apéritif and even better with seafood after sitting down at the table.

wine: Domaine des Tilleuls 2019 Essentielle Sur Lie  (Muscadet Sèvre et Maine)
appellation: Muscadet Sèvre et Maine, Loire Valley, France
review: This wine is fresh, textured while also packed with ripeness. Bright acidity shines through the mineral edge and touch of salinity. Green and citrus fruits are right there in the aftertaste. Drink now.

wine: Kilikanoon 2018 Mort's Block Watervale Riesling (Clare Valley)
review: An austere and classical Clare Riesling gently humming a medley of petrol, flower blossoms, ginger, white spice, orange peel, lemon and chalk dust. Bone-dry, the palate slices with laser-sharp acidity amid a powdery texture and a long, citrusy finish. This should really shine with another few years in the bottle, and what a bargain, too. Drink now–2027.
Aged in wood for 18 months, this wine offers toast and spice flavors that enhance red-cherry fruits. The wine is elegant, structured and should age well. For it to be at its best, wait until 2021.

Boasts a slightly lifted character to the aromas, but also shadings of Asian spice and espresso. This is supple on the palate and dark-fruited, with bold flavors of prune-plum and coffee and a long, firm finish that demands cellaring. Drink 2008–2020.

appellation: Eola-Amity Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: Made in a lighter style emphasizing elegance and precision, this young wine spent 14 months in 50% new oak. At the moment, oak intensity overrides the pretty apple butter-like fruit flavors, but the overall balance suggests it will iron itself out with more time in bottle.

wine: Winter's Hill 2017 Reserve Pinot Noir (Dundee Hills)
appellation: Dundee Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: This eight-barrel selection handles the challenges of a lighter vintage well, delivering a balanced palate with red currants, raspberries and sweet spice. All components are well-integrated, and the lingering finish suggests aging potential through the rest of the decade.

wine: Cantina Produttori Cortaccia 2013 Pinot Nero (Alto Adige)
review: Pretty varietal aromas include raspberry and rose petal. The sleek, easy-drinking palate offers crushed strawberry, green tomato and a hint of mineral alongside polished tannins.

wine: Foxen 2003 Ernesto Wickenden Vineyard Old Vines Chenin Blanc (Santa Maria Valley)
appellation: Santa Maria Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: This is the best California Chenin Blanc I've ever tasted. Bill Wathan gave the wine full Burgundian treatment, which accounts for the rich creaminess, while the grape itself lends high acidity and a sweet-sour lemon flavor with notes of camphor and tumeric. With the vines dating to 1966, this is an extraordinarily complex, bone-dry wine.

wine: Las Positas 2011 Estate Reserve Cabernet Sauvignon (Livermore Valley)
appellation: Livermore Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: This tastes and feels mellow and approachable, with gentle aromas of plums, dried herbs and tomato, and medium body with moderate tannins. It is supple and easy to drink.

wine: K Vintners 2012 River Rock Syrah (Walla Walla Valley (WA))
appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Brooding aromas of cranberry and mulberry lead to rich fruit and mineral flavors that show exquisite balance and a lengthy finish. It's rare to find a Rocks District wine so fruit filled—a real treat. Best before 2020.

Light in color, marked by strawberry jam flavors, this is fruity but certainly not weighty. There is pleasant acidity and freshness, with an easy, soft texture. Drink now. Imported by Wilson Daniels Ltd.

wine: DFJ Vinhos 2013 Casa do Lago Branco White (Lisboa)
review: Lightly spicy, this is a soft, off-dry wine. Fresh citrus and apple fruit flavors are perfumed and fruity in the mouth. Not for any aging, it's already a rounded, soft, still fruity wine.

Fresh and lively, combining peach, apple and citrus flavors in a fruit cocktail of a wine that's just complex enough to stand up sip after sip. It's medium-bodied, with a juicy, mouthwatering finish. Pair it with grilled chicken or fish and a fruit-based salsa.
Kind of sweet, with simple but pretty flavors of strawberries, vanilla and cinnamon, this clean wine is about as good as white Zin gets.

wine: Fort Ross Winery 2010 Fort Ross Vineyard Chardonnay (Sonoma Coast)
review: Showing the brisk acidity and minerality of this fine Chardonnay vineyard, Fort Ross's 2010 also shows rich, rewarding pineapple, orange, butterscotch and vanilla flavors. Feels opulent, a worthy followup to past vintages.

wine: Armida 2001 Maple Vineyard Zinfandel (Dry Creek Valley)
appellation: Dry Creek Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: Tea and herb qualities mark this wine, which also features blackberry and cassis notes that are couched in moderate tannins. Fairly smooth yet bright.

wine: Provenance Vineyards 2014 Barrel Select Cabernet Sauvignon (Rutherford)
review: This is a tightly wound, extracted barrel selection made entirely varietal. Full-bodied dense layers of dark chocolate complement brighter notions of black cherry and cassis.
This wine has an austere character that comes from the tight structure. There are only hints of possible fruit. It is likely to remain severe even as it matures.

appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
review: Aromas of blistered orange, light butter and clean oak show on the nose of this bottling. There's a bright zest to the sip, where citrus-peel and citrus-juice flavors meet with roasted apple flavors and a lightly grippy texture.

wine: Quinta Santa Eufemia 2010 Late Bottled Vintage  (Port)
review: This is a light and fruity wine that has some attractive red berry flavors and lively acidity. There is a tannic background that gives the a sense of structure, although the dry core lacks some fruit tones.

wine: Germano Ettore 2013 del Comune di Serralunga d'Alba  (Barolo)
review: Woodland berry, dark spice, rose and balsamic notes waft from the glass. Vibrant, elegant and focused, it delivers crushed strawberry, red cherry and licorice flavors on the palate, with firm, refined tannins and bright acidity. Drink 2023–2033.

This Syrah reveals bright aromas of cherry and blackberry, backed by touches of cured meat and crushed white pepper. It has a unique personality, and the finish offers savory hints of earth and porcini mushroom.

wine: Fritz Haag 2013 Brauneberger Juffer Sonnenuhr Auslese Goldkapsel Riesling (Mosel)
review: Dusty, smoky earth tones fade to reveal a rich, fruity palate of sweet white peaches and tangerine. Despite its light-footed nature, there's a lusciousness in mouthfeel, cut with spine-tingling acidity on the midpalate. Enjoy from 2018 to allow its honeyed mineral notes to develop.

wine: Vignoble des 2 Lunes 2009 Sélénite Pinot Gris (Alsace)
review: Rich and perfumed, this is a rotund and smooth wine. It has light spice, followed by ripe flavors of tropical fruit and almond, with a crisp layer of acidity. The finish has a full mouthfeel, with a spice note.

Grassy aromas along with capsicum, nettle and green fruit aromas are pungent and exciting. The palate is spritzy and lively, while the flavor profile balances sweet, candied green fruit flavors with more driving, intense tastes of lime and green melon. Forward, fun and elevated; drink now for ultimate freshness.

appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
review: Ripe, meaty aromas of black fruit and oak announce a well-made wine with nice balance between ripeness and structure. Its creamy and a bit thick on the palate, offset by hard tannins. It finishes with chocolaty oak and savory berry flavors. Drink this serious red through 2026.

wine: Quinta de Gomariz 2011 Padeiro Rosé (Vinho Verde)
review: Very fruity and smooth, this has a ripe strawberry flavor and balancing acidity. It shows some richness while remaining crisp and fragrant.

This almost white rosé is produced from selected parcels of the estate. Citrus and pepper dominate, supported by ripe red fruits and delicate acidity. It is a beautiful wine, elegant and with a fine balance between the fruit and the crisp texture. Drink now.

wine: La Cave des Vignerons de Pfaffenheim 2017 Special White (Alsace)
winery: La Cave des Vignerons de Pfaffenheim
review: Juicy, ripe pear notes are evoked on the nose. The palate is slender but toned, showing some concentration and more pear helped along by zesty, lemony freshness. It's a light-bodied wine with a dry finish.

Barolo Essenze is a blend of Nebbiolo fruit sourced from multiple vineyard spots. The results are super concentration, a brooding, masculine feel and dark notes of black fruit and exotic spice. This chewy, textured wine delivers a big, powerful style that will benefit from more years of cellar aging.
From the warm 2015 vintage, this is a soft and fruity wine. It's open with broad white fruit flavors, the acidity lighter than usual for Chablis, giving it a particularly ripe character. Drink now.

wine: Charles de Fère NV Reserve Blanc de Blancs Brut  (France)
review: A disappointment compared with the other bubblies in this value line. Despite the reserve designation, the wine fails to offer the richness and complexity of its siblings. A beery front end runs into a hollow middle, and there is a hint of sugar at the finish line.

More savory and spicy than fruity, with bramble and leather aromas dominating any sweetness that might want to escape. A touch aggressive in the mouth, with lively but hard raspberry and other red-fruit flavors. Finishes dry and salty, with heat. Includes 17% Carignan.

Enticing aromas of herb, peach and pear lead this delicious SB from centuries-old winery Warwick, whose vineyards are situated on the slopes of Stellenbosh-Simonsberg. The flavors are zesty, with more peach, pear and citrus on the palate, but the overall feel is one of poise and integration. This is a very good example of a wine in which flirty and focused elements marry successfully.

wine: Kracher 2008 Zwischen den Seen Nummer 1 Trockenbeerenauslese Scheurebe (Burgenland)
review: This, the first of 12 grades of richness in the Kracher range in 2008, is already an intense wine, with concentrated orange marmalade and honey flavors. What gives it just the right fresh lift is the lemon acidity on the refreshing finish.

wine: Pedroncelli 2006 Mother Clone Zinfandel (Dry Creek Valley)
appellation: Dry Creek Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: Break out the barbecue, relax and enjoy this savory wine. It's classic Dry Creek Zin in a drink-me-now way. Dry, medium-bodied and gentle in tannins, it features lip-smacking flavors of pepper, red currants, tobacco and anise.

wine: Iris Vineyards 2014 Aroha Vineyard Syrah (Umpqua Valley)
appellation: Umpqua Valley, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
review: Spice, leather, pepper and plum mingle in this medium-weight effort. Purple fruits and intimations of ginger cookie are in play, with pretty baking spices on the finish.

Under the same ownership as Château Haut-Guiraud, this estate has produced a wood-aged wine that's rich in dark spicy fruit and ripe tannins. Dense structure shows the wine's potential as well as its concentration. Drink from 2022.
Air freshener and tropical aromas lead to a juice-like palate with green tannins. Lime, nettle and nopal flavors finish heavy.
Barrel aging and contact with lees give this wine a rich creaminess, and there's also plenty of acidity. Hints of unripe grapes lend mint and ammonia notes that dominate citrus flavors.

appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: Though this is near the bottom end of the Rex Hill Pinot pole, it does not suffer from a lack of flavor. Big fruit, organically grown, runs right through the core, a mix of berries, cherries and plums; woven into the fruit is a lightly leafy vein, a whiff of tobacco, and a suggestion of earthy, organic compost. Thoroughly delicious.

wine: Tarara 2008 Charval White Table Wine White (Virginia)
review: Apples and pears dominate the nose and palate of this blend of Chardonnay, Sauvignon Blanc and Pinot Gris. Full bodied and fermented in stainless steel, this slightly off-dry wine is rich in texture, but stays fresh with a vibrant lemon-lime acidity.

The label does not bear the name Angela Vineyard, but the fruit is estate grown. This is a tight, focused, young red wine, with tangy raspberry fruit that touches on black cherry. Vivid and penetrating, it needs plenty of time to breathe, and as it does it reveals subtle layers of mocha and caramel. This has the bones to age. Drink now through 2030.

Aromas of ripe pineapple, apricot and dried flowers carry the nose. This medium-bodied white is slick and juicy in feel, with full stone and tropical fruit flavors that are honed by accents of lemon verbena and blanched almond. Despite the lushness, there's good grip and tension to the overall feel.

wine: Les Vignerons du Pallet 2015 Château des Templiers  (Muscadet Sèvre et Maine)
appellation: Muscadet Sèvre et Maine, Loire Valley, France
review: This is a crisp and tangy wine. Its citrus fruit and mineral texture give it a bright tight character. It is packed with acidity and with refreshing juicy lime. Drink now.
This is a solid and textured wine, bringing out structure and black fruit flavors. The wine has acidity and a fresher background giving shape to the ripe fruits. Drink now.

appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: This is a blend of 53% Merlot, 45% Cabernet Sauvignon and 2% Malbec. Somewhat lighter in color, the aromas show notes of wet penny, raspberry, wheat, herb stalk, cherry and spice. The flavors are light but juicy, tapering on the finish.

This blends 60% Merlot with 40% Syrah—a successful marriage that is well structured and modest in ripeness. Cedar, wooded tannin and pencil shavings provide an Old-World character set against a backdrop of juicy tart red fruit and black pepper.

wine: Marqués de Gelida 2009 Brut Reserva Made with Organic Grapes Sparkling (Cava)
designation: Brut Reserva Made with Organic Grapes
review: Applesauce, lime and mineral aromas comprise the shy bouquet on this Cava. It feels round yet alive, with crisp apple and peach flavors. Citrus-driven acidity comes out on the finish.
Rich and with good fruit, this is a structured wine that has the density to age well. The dark-chocolate flavors mingle with the black-plum fruits, finishing with just a light lift of acidity.

wine: Palladino 2013 del Comune di Serralunga d'Alba  (Barolo)
review: This wine's new leather, pressed violet and orange zest aromas unfold in the glass. The vibrant, medium-bodied palate offers red berry, baking spice and crushed herb flavors framed by bright acidity and firm, refined tannins.

wine: Tenuta Farneta di Collato 2003 Tenuta Farneta  (Chianti Colli Senesi)
review: A bit reduced, with meaty black-fruit aromas accompanied by hints of grass and hay. The palate is spicy and full of plum and cherry, while the rest of the mouth and finish are carried by short acidity. Hits hard toward the back while scoring points along the way.

wine: Viña Casas Patronales 2010 Reserva Cabernet Sauvignon (Maule Valley)
review: Bashful, mild aromas of herbal berry fruits and mint are followed by a full, round and solid feeling palate. Flavors of blackberry, cassis and blueberry register as fairly ripe and dark, while the finish displays toasty notes, spice flavors and mild heat. This is a step up from good and basic.

wine: Bee Hunter 2017 Filligreen Farms Pinot Gris (Anderson Valley)
appellation: Anderson Valley, Mendocino County, California, US
review: A light buttery, nutty quality gives this wine a serious, mature edge that is fascinating to taste. Almond, vanilla and a hint of honey dominate very dry fruit flavors.

wine: Kay Brothers 2019 Basket Pressed Amery Vineyard Shiraz (McLaren Vale)
review: This bottling from the historic Amery Vineyard opens with notes of fleshy plum, cracked pepper, dried violets and a streak of something more medicinal. In the mouth the powerful tannins are chiseled and chalky, adding textural interest and room in the mix for juicy fruit, with a welcome lift of acidity. Drink now with protein and decanter at hand, or until 2031.

appellation: Columbia Gorge (OR), Oregon Other, Oregon, US
review: This is extremely pale in color with an orange tinge at the rim. The aromas offer notes of citrus peel, BBQ smoke, cinnamon and cranberry. Quite smoky flavors follow. The smoke influence is significant.

wine: Dr. H. Thanisch (Erben Thanisch) 2010 Bernkasteler Badstube Spätlese Riesling (Mosel)
review: A note of dried citrus peel adds a touch of spice to the whiff of petrol on this delicate, minerally Riesling. The palate is zippy and brisk, with loads of fresh stone-fruit flavor and a long, steely finish that reverberates.

appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Aromas of white pepper and raspberry lead to plump, full-bodied red fruit flavors. It brings a pleasant tang.

wine: Ökonomierat Rebholz 2007 Von Rotliegenden Spätlese Riesling (Pfalz)
review: This is a somewhat soft and friendly wine, filled with ripe peaches and pears, and with a backbone of lime-like citrus. It even boasts a subtle dose of minerality. Yet it lacks the power and precision of some of the other Rebholz wines, instead settling for being soft and cuddly rather than profound.

This smells like fresh pavement at first, with gritty black-fruit and burnt leaf notes. The palate feels edgy, with a spotty red-fruit flavor that's matched with notes of resiny oak and vanilla. It finishes in a similar fashion. Novo Imports and Aidil Wines & Liquors.

Weinert holds its wines back longer than almost any other Argentine winery, hence when you get a blend like this it's mature and ready. This is maderized, with aromas of earth, citrus, tobacco and mushroom. The palate is tight and houses tobacco, mocha, citrus and dried raspberry flavors. If you like aged Rioja, this is for you. The blend is Malbec, Cabernet and Merlot.

wine: Alain Jaume et Fils 2018 Domain Grand Veneur Le Miocène Red (Châteauneuf-du-Pape)
review: Tangs of granite and firm, gripping tannins lend angularity to concentrated black cherry and plum in this wine. A blend of Grenache (70%), Syrah (20%) and Mourvédre (10%), it's weighty on the palate but sharply cut by zingy red-cassis acidity. At peak now through 2028, the wine should hold further still.

wine: Farnese 2007 Casale Vecchio Pecorino (Terre di Chieti)
appellation: Terre di Chieti, Central Italy, Italy
review: This fresh and buoyant Pecorino from Central Italy delivers immediate and simple aromas of stone fruit with some papaya and pineapple. It tastes crisp and vibrant and has the natural structure to pair with ham or cold cuts.

Green pear and lemon zest characterize the nose of this concentrated, salty wine. Zesty citrus notes give both texture and direction on the taut palate, which shimmers with savory, yeasty, miso-like saltiness. A very delicious, impactful little package that is sure to unfold beautifully. Drink 2020–2030.

Fresh citrus and pear flavors are highlighted by racy streaks of lime and tart pineapple in this unusually zippy Grauburgunder, or Pinot Gris. It's light in body yet creamy in texture, with a long, lingering finish marked by crushed stones and salty minerality.

wine: Lionel Osmin & Cie 2018 La Dune Domaine de Bachen Rosé (Landes)
review: From vineyards in the forested region towards the Atlantic coast, this fresh and red-fruit-flavored blend of Merlot and Cabernet Franc is bright and lively. A touch of caramel from the Merlot in the blend doesn't detract from the fresh aftertaste. Drink now.

This is still young and closed, but pretty aromas of rose, perfumed berry, baking spice and menthol eventually emerge. The palate delivers crunchy red cherry, raspberry, white pepper, anise and a balsamic note alongside austere but fine-grained tannins and vibrant acidity. Give it time to open up and develop complexity. Drink 2018–2028.

wine: Iron Horse 2013 Wedding Cuvée Sparkling (Green Valley)
review: Exuberant in mousse, this wine is luxurious and rich, the perfect quaff for any occasion. Made from 75% Pinot Noir and 25% Chardonnay, and aged for three years, it's bright in bolts of green apple and strawberry.

wine: Mahana 2016 Carbonique Pinot Noir Upper Moutere Hills Rosé (Nelson)
designation: Carbonique Pinot Noir Upper Moutere Hills
review: As the name suggests, this is fermented using carbonic fermentation. While it should be applauded for trying something new, the experiment, in this case, doesn't really work. Reductive and stinky at first, this eventually blows off to reveal ripe melon and red fruit notes, with florals and (thanks to the carbonic) a distinctly bubble gum quality. The palate, at 14% alcohol, is on the hot side, with a medium to full body and a heaviness of fruit that lacks brightness and freshness.

wine: Castello Banfi 2004 San Angelo Pinot Grigio (Toscana)
review: Floral and a bit different, with a meaty, almost spicy character. Flavors of pear and citrus are modest, while the balance is good and the body light to medium in weight. Fresh and easy; borders on stylish.

This is the entry-level wine at Vallado, one of the Douro's top quintas. Full of berry fruits, it also has layers of tannins and acidity, but is rich and soft enough now not to need much aging. Although it could be drunk now, it will be better from 2016.

wine: Foley 2014 Barrel Select Pinot Noir (Sta. Rita Hills)
appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
review: This well-balanced Pinot Noir shows red-cherry fruit, with complex hints of anise, star anise, thyme and even tarragon on the nose. Both the acidity and tannic structure are lively but not aggressive, carrying tart cherry flavors deep into the finish.
Lean, initially bitter, this is a firmly tannic wine. The berry fruits show freshness, but the dry tannins dominate. Of course, it's young, but the texture is too light for much development.
Acceptable aromas but all acid in the mouth. A sour, bitter, red fruit dominant wine with very little going for it. Offers nothing but sourness on the palate and finish.

wine: Obelisco Estate 2010 Estate Grown Merlot (Red Mountain)
appellation: Red Mountain, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: This soft, supple and seductive Merlot (with 25% Cabernet Sauvignon in the blend) is both earthy and sensuous. The mouthfeel is like smooth felt. Black cherry, blackberry and a dash of cola fill the mouth, with lush tannins and a long finish. There's just a hint of brown sugar as it wraps up.
Spritzy freshness, lemony hints and a slender body combine to make an uncomplicated but rewarding summer wine.

This wine starts with aromas of toasted oak, coffee, mature blackberries and hints of bell pepper. The palate offers overripe plum, black currants, toasted oak, chocolate, and espresso alongside astringent and drying wood tannins that give this an abrupt finish.

wine: The Joy Fantastic 2018 Chardonnay (Sta. Rita Hills)
appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
review: This is a fascinating bottling that holds interest for repeat sips and is likely to age very well. Yuzu-peel, underripe apricot, honeysuckle and light toast aromas frame the nose. The palate zings with racy sharp laser-focused acidity, delivering flavors of bright grapefruit, crisp melon rind and tart apples.

Green apple, peardrop and Conference pear shine on the nose of this wine. The streamlined palate clebrates those fresh flavors, highlighting them with extra lemon spritz, a salty, yeasty fringe adding complexity. The finish is lip-smacking, moreish and dry.
The smoky, peppery aromas and smoky, pomegranate flavors may be atypical, but the wine is well-balanced and enjoyable to drink.

wine: Herdade das Servas 2013 Monte das Servas Escolha Red (Alentejano)
review: This big, bold wine blends local grapes with Cabernet Sauvignon and Touriga Nacional. It has red fruits and rounded tannins that are well integrated with the fruitiness. Full in the mouth and with delicious acidity, it is ready to drink.

Mature black-skinned fruit, new leather, Mediterranean herb and dark spice are some of the aromas you'll find on this big, bold red. The brawny monolithic palate doles out ripe plum, black cherry marinated in spirits and cake spice alongside chewy tannins and the warmth of evident alcohol. Drink 2018–2025.

wine: Château Cambon la Pelousse 2016 Barrel Sample  (Haut-Médoc)
review: 90–92. Barrel Sample. This is a delicious, juicy wine, with black fruit tones backed by firm tannins. The structure and the concentration don't take away from the exuberant fruits.

wine: Rios de Chile 2011 Limited Edition Sauvignon Blanc (Casablanca Valley)
review: The nose on this wine is fresh but nothing unusual or exciting. In the mouth, it's racy, with acidity and flavors of green veggies, citrus fruits and pith. Things turn more pithy and mildly bitter on the finish, where tarragon and rosemary accents take over.

This is a successful, small-production white that's bright, textured and memorable in swathes of well-heeled grapefruit and Meyer lemon. A grassy undertone of pea shoots plays well against the crisp fruit.

wine: Rodney Strong 1999 Reserve Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)
appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: Wears a toasty mantle of smoke, meat and burnt marshmallow. Yet we found the dark cherry and tart plum fruit core to be strong enough to weather its oak. The wine's polished rusticity has great appeal, with earthy, dusty tannins, pepper and cola accents. Drink now through 2007. Editors' Choice.
Entirely made in stainless steel, this is a fresh tasting, vibrant young wine. It has zingy acids, and forward flavors of citrus fruits, melons and white pepper. This dry wine is nice as an apéritif.

wine: Villa Maria 1999 Private Bin Cabernet Sauvignon-Merlot (Hawke's Bay)
review: Spice notes play heavily on the brambly, herbal nose.  This a full-bodied, chunky mix of 53% Cabernet, 24% Merlot, 13% Pinotage and 10% Syrah.  No grape type in particular sticks out on the palate, which is heavy with oregano and basil notes in addition to red-plum fruit.  Best for casual drinking; anything left will help out a red sauce.

wine: Domaine Albin Jacumin 2018 La Bégude des Papes White (Châteauneuf-du-Pape)
review: Earthen notes of smoke and crushed minerals linger from nose to palate in this juicy, moderately full-bodied white. A blend of 60% Grenache Blanc, 30% Clairette and 10% Bourboulenc vinified and aged in 20% new French oak, it puts a spotlight on pristine tangerine and grapefruit flavors edged by a touch of bitter nut skin. Ready to drink now but should maintain through 2028.

wine: Chanson Père et Fils 2009 Les Vergelesses Premier Cru  (Pernand-Vergelesses)
review: This has ripe red fruits and soft, integrated tannins, with concentration and a voluptuous exterior. This will be ready to drink soon.

wine: Domaine la Goujonne 2019 Gamali Rosé (Côtes de Provence)
review: This rich wine is smoothly textured, full of fruit balanced with acidity. Its blend that includes Mourvèdre gives the wine texture as well as concentration. This rosé ready to drink from late 2020.

In need of bottle aging, Cogno's '99 Ravera blends molasses with dates and figs to give the impression of a spiced fruitcake impregnated with tannins instead of rum. Give it until 2010, when it should begin to open up.
This opens with aromas of white and yellow wild flower and yellow stone fruit. The bright palate doles out juicy yellow peach, nectarine and a hint of Mediterranean herb alongside fresh acidity.

wine: Roederer Estate NV Brut Rosé  (Anderson Valley)
appellation: Anderson Valley, Mendocino County, California, US
review: It's complex and inviting, with bread dough, rasberry and vanilla, and atouch of smoky honey.  The flavors are similar, with white peaches making an appearance.  Medium-weight with a slightly creamy mouthful, it closes with creamy-toast flavors on the long finish.  This sparkling wine will have wide appeal: It's big, open and enjoyable.

wine: Pashey 2017 Ribbon Ridge Estate Extra Brut Blanc de Blancs Sparkling (Ribbon Ridge)
designation: Ribbon Ridge Estate Extra Brut Blanc de Blancs
appellation: Ribbon Ridge, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: The fourth vintage of this 100% Chardonnay, méthode Champenoise sparkler opens with a whiff of toast and fresh flavors of lemon pith, apple, white peach and pineapple. The clarity and rather suppressed power are apparent despite its being very recently disgorged. Tuck it away and drink after 2024.

Poggio Antico is one of the best estates in Montalcino but the 2008 vintage doesn't reach the impressive heights of 2006 or 2007 that showed much fuller and more generous results. This edition offers plum, wild berry and leather aromas with a lean mouthfeel and sharp acidity that will soften with a few more years of bottle aging.

wine: Babcock 2018 Born Ready Peake Vineyard Grenache (Sta. Rita Hills)
appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
review: Dark boysenberry and toasty oak aromas lead into hints of caramel on the nose of this riper expression. Candied flavors of violet and dark-purple fruit are wrapped in rustic tannins on the palate.

Utterly dry and crisp, the wine carries a flinty minerality and lime, peach and green-apple flavors. It was largely barrel-fermented, but the oak never feels heavy or tastes sweet. Instead, it provides a subtle perfume throughout. Don't drink this wine too cold, or you'll miss the nuances.

A rosé of 100% Mourvèdre, this bears mild flavors of red cherry, candied strawberry and tropical fruit, which are enlivened by fresh acidity. It's a simple rosé that would be an enjoyable accompaniment to a picnic lunch.

wine: Cave de Tain 2017 Première Note Rosé de Syrah (Collines Rhôdaniennes)
review: While the nose of this light-bodied rosé is quite peachy and perfumed, the palate is demure, suggesting mild pear and underripe apricot. Dry and full bodied, it's balanced by fresh acidity and a salty, mineral finish. Drink now.

appellation: Central Coast, Central Coast, California, US
review: Singed lemon and baked apple converge for a very perfumed aromatic entry to this bottling. The palate is very familiar with flavors of toast, lemon and apple, with an acidity that cuts through the sip.

wine: Spanish Vines 2008 Sauvignon Blanc-Macabeo White (Vino de la Tierra de Castilla)
appellation: Vino de la Tierra de Castilla, Central Spain, Spain
review: Same score as the prior year, and pretty much the same wine. It's dusty and slightly burnt in aromas and flavors, with banana, peach and pithy bitterness extending onto the finish. Mouthfeel is the best part; otherwise it struggles to make the cut.

For a basic Chardonnay, this fits the bill. Citrus and peach aromas are standard and clean. The palate is tight and juicy, with no overt oak feel. Flavors of melon and pear have light spice and vanilla accents, while the finish is crisp.

appellation: Shenandoah Valley (CA), Sierra Foothills, California, US
review: Enticing, with velvety texture but firmness, nonetheless, on the palate. A sleek and subtle blend of apricot, peach, spice, herb and citrus flavors, all couched elegantly with finesse.

wine: Burnt Bridge 2013 Pont Brûlé Red (Walla Walla Valley (WA))
appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Grenache (38%) takes the lead followed by Mourvèdre (34%) and Syrah, with the fruit coming from Seven Hills and Les Collines vineyards. Blueberry pie, herb and spice aromas are followed by extracted blue and black-fruit flavors that bring some warmth along with them.

Soft and rich, with loads of ripe fruit flavors, this Cabernet Sauvignon-Syrah--Merlot blend offers a crisp dash of freshness that keeps the palate clean. It's a balanced wine, with a sophisticated twist of spice and dark fruit on the close.

appellation: South Eastern Australia, Australia Other, Australia
review: Neither supple nor complicated; its tropical yellow fruit and light-to-medium weight made it a candidate for a summer picnic or other such casual circumstance. But it has a faux-sugar note on the finish (think Nutrasweet) that made me like it less than I wanted to.
This offers aromas reminiscent of cedar, black-skinned fruit and a subtle whiff of oak. The firm palate doles out dried black cherry, vanilla and a mocha note set against taut assertive tannins.

This has to rank as one of the world's best wines for the money. The depth is impeccable and the balance and pop are commendable. All hail Argentina, or at least Barons de Rothschild and Nicolas Catena for coming up with this affordable blend of Malbec and Cabernet that pulses with berry fruit, waves of chocolate and so much toasty persistence that it almost requires brakes. For under $20 this is faultless stuff. Imported by Pasternak Wine Imports.

92–94. Barrel Sample. The oak is currently quite forward and powerful in this young wine, which needs time for the fruit to come through. But the fruit is there, with black currant acidity and freshness showing in the background. Let the wine soften and don't drink before 2024.

There's something rugged and rough about this wine that makes it so compelling. Aromas of beach sand and drying kelp recall the seashore, yet there's Anaheim chili, too. The palate combines that seaweed with jalapeño, making for a visceral, slightly funky experience.

wine: Château Valandraud 2017 Valandraud Blanc Barrel Sample  (Saint-Émilion)
review: 88–90. Barrel Sample. Crisp fruit with a strong herbal edge gives this small production wine a lively, citrus character. Ample acidity lingers through a vibrant finish layered in notes of mineral and zest.

appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: Lynmar's basic Russian River is lighter than its more expensive designation bottlings, but it's right up there, which makes it a relative value. Shows the same dry, crisp varietal richness and finesse, with cherry, cola and oak flavors. Balanced, and entirely ready now.

Aromas evoking scorched earth, blue flowers, camphor and tobacco mingle together. The full-bodied palate features dried black cherry, blood orange, licorice and a hint of espresso alongside firm, fine-grained tannins. Drink 2021–2027.

wine: Soquel Vineyards 2015 Partners' Reserve Nelson Vineyard Chardonnay (Santa Cruz Mountains)
appellation: Santa Cruz Mountains, Central Coast, California, US
review: Dried apple and salted almond aromas show on the nose of this bottling from a winery started in 1987. There is a flinty character to the sip, alongside squeezed lime and baked apple, with a light smokiness noticeable throughout.

Big and ripe, with cola, root beer and berry aromas along with rich oak. The palate is a high-wire act of bright red fruit combined with thick milk chocolate and malt. The tannins and acidity allow the wine to be aggressive, maybe too much so given that the fruit is somewhat tart and prickly.

wine: Wines & Winemakers 2014 Andreza Touriga Nacional-Touriga Franca Red (Douro)
review: Ripe and bold, this is a rich wine whose dense fruit is balanced by its equally dense tannins. It has spice, juicy black fruits and a structure that emphasizes minerality and oak aging. It's not quite ready, so drink from 2017.
Orchard-fruit and honeysuckle aromas lift out of the glass. The simple palate offers ripe yellow apple and a confectionery note alongside firm acidity.

wine: Pearmund 2018 South River Vineyard Petit Manseng (Virginia)
review: A deep golden orange in color, this wine has an aroma that delivers warm spiced orange and lemon peel with accents of honey and blossoms. The palate offers ripe orange flavor blended with marigold, hot honey and white tea. Orange and lemon pith tones emerge on the dry, tugging finish.

wine: Ballast Stone Estate Wines 2004 Cabernet Sauvignon (South Eastern Australia)
appellation: South Eastern Australia, Australia Other, Australia
review: A blend of estate-grown fruit from Currency Creek and McLaren Vale, the flagship label of the Ballast Stone line represents a solid value. Cassis fruit is showcased admirably by hints of eucalyptus and wood-derived accents of toasted coconut and vanilla, while the texture is surprisingly lush and the finish velvety.

wine: W.T. Vintners 2014 Boushey Vineyard Mourvèdre (Yakima Valley)
appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: The aromas pop, with notes of freshly ground white pepper, orange zest and raw meat. The savory flavors are silky and elegant in style, with the oak influence dialed way back. It shows a pleasing sense of purity and balance. Put it on the dinner table to see it shine.

wine: Brick & Mortar 2016 Vin Rubis Pinot-Chardonnay (Napa Valley)
review: This light, ethereal wine combines 53% Pinot Noir with 47% Chardonnay, the color dark as a light-bodied red. A thick, dense mouthfeel and gritty texture complements the brightness of cherry and raspberry.

There can be few Pinot Blancs that come in such a heavy bottle. Once the wine is poured, it's a fresh apple and cream wine, with attractive acidity and a soft aftertaste. Some toast shows through at the end.
Caramel wood aromas, with smooth fruit. The wine is rich, warm, with the pure white and yellow fruit flavors showing well. It is crisp, but also rich.

wine: Château du Père Antoine 2018 Olivia  (Blaye Côtes de Bordeaux)
appellation: Blaye Côtes de Bordeaux, Bordeaux, France
review: A classic blend dominated by Merlot, this wine has, unfortunately, been swamped by wood aging. That gives a dry character to the wine, masking hints of black-currant flavors. Drink from 2022.

A blend of six Rhône grapes. It's lush and plush. A lot of sun-baked black fruit here and virtually no edge to speak of. In fact, it's almost too friendly. Aromas of graham crackers and a clear flavor of chocolate make for an interesting drink.

A gorgeous Pinot Noir for drinking over the next few years. It's dry and silky, with ripe raspberry, cherry and cola flavors finished with plenty of clove, cinnamon and white pepper spice. There's an earthy, mushroomy note that grounds it.

wine: Domaine Charles Frey 2016 Harmonie Pinot Noir (Alsace)
review: A lick of vanilla precedes red berries on the nose. On the palate, the berries are expressed as red currant and lovely tart cranberry. This is fresh and light, easy and totally fruit-driven. It would work well as a chilled red with its refreshing backbone and light body.
Aromas of violet, scorched earth and leather lead the way. The savory palate offers dried black cherry, clove and tobacco alongside firm, polished tannins. Drink 2023–2028.

wine: AuburnJames 2009 Bella Vista Vineyard Block 2 Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
review: Hugely oaky, this wine also features a dustiness on the nose and palate, alongside woody tannin. Black olive and dried herb give it an herbaceous quality that belies its full-bodied richness and ripe core.

wine: Ca' Del Grevino 2014 Estate Vineyards White Riesling (Santa Maria Valley)
appellation: Santa Maria Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: There's a classic touch of petrol on the nose of this bottling, as well as richer notes of candied lemon, marmalade, preserved lime and dried citrus. On the palate, it's oily and viscous, but honey, lemon syrup and tangerine zest flavors lighten it considerably. A great all-around experience.

wine: Livio Felluga 2001 Pinot Grigio (Friuli Venezia Giulia)
appellation: Friuli Venezia Giulia, Northeastern Italy, Italy
review: There's a slight coppery tinge to this wine's color, which sets it apart from the vast majority of other Grigios on the market. And maybe it's just the suggestion of the hue, but it seems to taste "pink" as well, showcasing ripe berries and appples backed by tangy acids and great length. Classy stuff.
Bottled after 10 years on its lees, this Champagne has great richness, with mature flavors mingling with the acidity and kiwi fruit flavors. The wine is in perfect condition, ready to drink now.

appellation: Sierra Foothills, Sierra Foothills, California, US
review: An intensely big-shouldered Syrah from high-elevation vineyards in the Foothills, with a swirl of black tea and very ripe black cherry and chocolate.
A really pretty and elegant rendition of Pinot Noir, with supple tannins and soft dustings of herbs and spice atop ripe cherry fruit. Imported by Allied Domecq Wines USA.

wine: Ebner-Ebenauer 2007 Blanc de Blancs Chardonnay (Österreichischer Sekt)
review: Lovely red apple and biscuit notes emanate here to create the perfect balance between fruit and yeasty autolysis. Acidity streamlines the generous, full-fruited body while soft mousse amplifies all the rich, layered apple flavors. The midpalate texture and finish are impressive. This is the full, delicious package and will make a classy apéritif with enough character to accompany delicate, fine cuisine. The length speaks for itself: pure class. Zero dosage.

wine: Barton & Guestier 2018 Bistro Rue La Fayette Pinot Noir (Vin de France)
appellation: Vin de France, France Other, France
review: Blackberry and plum aromas are balanced by anise and black pepper on the nose. The palate is built by grippy tannins, housing flavors of juicy black cherry and pomegranate blended with bay leaf and oak tones. White pepper and plum mark the finish.

Made with organically farmed 80% Sangiovese and 20% Cabernet and Merlot, this has subtle aromas of wild berries and ground brown spices. It's juicy, savory and easy drinking, doling out ripe black cherry, cassis and clove set against polished tannins. Enjoy through 2020.

wine: Château Maison Neuve 2018 Clotilde  (Blaye Côtes de Bordeaux)
appellation: Blaye Côtes de Bordeaux, Bordeaux, France
review: A blend of mainly Merlot with a touch of Malbec, this is bold and full bodied while also balanced. The structure of the cherry and blackberry-flavored wine gives it aging potential. It will be ready from 2022.

wine: Serge Mathieu NV Tête de Cuvée Select Brut  (Champagne)
review: A selection from Serge Mathieu's best parcels, this wine has full, ripe fruit, layers of green grapefruit flavors and white currants. It has good depth, finishing with fine toast and acidity at the end, just missing a higher mark because of its unbalanced dosage.

wine: Domaine Vico 2015 Les Parcellaires A Mina Vermentino (Corse)
review: A limited-production wine from a small parcel of old vines, this is ripe and beautifully rich. A touch of oxidation gives an extra dimension of ripeness and brings out a beautiful texture. Drink from 2019.

wine: Domaine Terlato & Chapoutier 2006 lieu dit Malakoff Shiraz (Pyrenees)
review: Seems more elegant than the brawny 2005, with pretty aromas of violets and cracked pepper that glide easily into flavors of mixed berries and vanilla. It's lighter in weight than many Australian Shiraz, fresher and higher in acidity, which gives it a bit of Old World sensibility. Drink now–2016.

Despite some tempered oak aging, this one will whet your whistle and then some. Talk about cutting acidity and being fit and trim; it's like a hard-bodied personal trainer. It doesn't have an ounce of fat on it, so the aromas are tight and minerally and the flavors lean and crisp. Will plow through grilled vegetables and chicken or tuna salad with ease. Made primarily from Garnacha, with some Viura and Tempranillo.

Starts off with fairly soft aromas of honeydew, petrol and steely minerality. More fruit is showcased on the palate with green apple, lime and pineapple core. Medium weight and appropriately balanced, the finish is fresh and crisp.

appellation: Malvasia delle Lipari, Sicily & Sardinia, Italy
review: This has aromas evoking mature orange peel, dried fruit and butterscotch. The palate shows a combination of sweet and bitter: offering chestnut honey, candied orange drop and maple syrup before a bitter walnut close.
87—89 Barrel sample. Soft fruit, followed by high acids, and a layer of dry tannins. This is a tense, dark wine, very dry, dominated by blackcurrant and bitter cherry flavors.

wine: Donum 2009 Estate Grown Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)
appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: Donum is at the top of it's Pinot Noir game. This is simply wonderful, offering a wealth of red fruit, cola, spice, mineral and earth flavors. The tannins are negotiable, the acidity brisk and clean, the finish dry and long. You may even want to cellar it for 5–6 years, although it's fully enjoyable now.

wine: River's Edge 2015 Elkton Cuvée Pinot Noir (Elkton Oregon)
appellation: Elkton Oregon, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
review: This is a delicious and beautifully-proportioned wine that delivers exceptional value. Concentrated cranberry and blueberry fruit takes the middle ground, and the raw-wood aromas suggest that further bottle age will soften the flavors on the finish.
Clean, fresh Riesling which has light fruit, flavors of ripe pears and a lively, racy aftertaste. This is a delicious aperitif wine with good crispness, acidity and a soft, easy aftertaste.

wine: Apolloni 2007 Conti di Val Seriana Soleggio Red (Columbia Valley (OR))
appellation: Columbia Valley (OR), Oregon Other, Oregon, US
review: This blend of Sangiovese, Cabernet Sauvignon and Merlot is an Oregon winery's take on a super Tuscan red. Aromas are volatile and those high tones carry into the flavors. Light raspberry fruit, high acidity, and a sharp astringency characterize the wine.
88–90. Barrel Sample. This is a producer that needs to watch its wood. This is hugely toasty, and the oak suppresses the fruit.

This wine starts with a spicy nose of tobacco and mocha tinged with a green character. The wine's dry style offers flavors of wooded spice, red berry, tobacco and a slightly lean spin. Spicy and food friendly, but a touch rustic.

wine: Tortoise Creek 2013 Le Charmel Sur Lie  (Muscadet Sèvre et Maine)
appellation: Muscadet Sèvre et Maine, Loire Valley, France
review: This light and fruity wine is fresh with lemon and light minerality. It is ready to drink, with its bright acidity and pear and apple aftertaste.

Broad but imprecise berry aromas are a touch green and topped with creamy oak that lends a milk chocolate character to the nose. A plump, grabby palate deals minty green berry flavors and plenty of oak, while this never sheds its oaky, highly herbal identity. Vintage 2016 saw a lot of rain and this Malbec shows it.

Sulfur shrouds this wine at first, but it dissipates with time to reveal mild notes of honeyed nut, kiwi, white flower and golden apple. The palate has balanced acidity and a slight oiliness, and the flavors seem a bit muted at the moment.

wine: Bindella 2009 I Quadri  (Vino Nobile di Montepulciano)
appellation: Vino Nobile di Montepulciano, Tuscany, Italy
review: I Quadri offers violet and iris aromas accented by vanilla and toasted oak sensations. The palate shows a black pepper streak wrapped around a core of plum and ripe cherry, finishing on a roasted coffee bean note. It's forward and ready to enjoy soon.

Rich and extracted aromas of black cherry, caramel and creamy fudge show on the nose of this bottling from the hills above Camarillo, which includes 5% Syrah. The palate is viscous, showing strong flavors of loamy soil, black-plum pudding and fig, wrapped in creamy tannins and toasty wood touches.

Roccolo Grassi takes Valpolicella Superiore to the next level. While Valpolicella Superiore is mostly recognized as an easy-drinking red to wash down with pizza or pasta, this has touches of ripe fruit and exotic spice that lend extra sophistication, elegance and texture.

wine: Tandem 2003 Van der Kamp Vineyard Pinot Noir (Sonoma Mountain)
review: This is a very soft, sensuous Pinot, low in tannins, with a smooth, creamy mouthfeel. The flavors are rich and exuberant in smoky red cherries, raspberries and cola. The softness suggests against extended cellaring, but why wouldn't you want this silky, complex wine now?

wine: Joseph Jewell 2015 Ryan Vineyard Pinot Noir (Humboldt County)
appellation: Humboldt County, North Coast, California, US
review: This extraordinary wine sets a high standard for California's Humboldt County. An intriguing tension between ripeness and tartness gives this wine great balance, while red and black cherries, rhubarb and subtle oak spices provide plenty of complexity. The wine is medium bodied, has firm tannins to stiffen the mouthfeel just enough and is quite concentrated without being heavy.

A single-vineyard wine from one of the highest points in Sancerre, this is concentrated and dense, full of taut fruit and rich acidity. Apple flavors are cut with tangy, spicy citrus lifted by the taut aftertaste. Drink from 2020.

appellation: Fiano di Avellino, Southern Italy, Italy
review: Flinty mineral, smoke, yellow pear, toasted hazelnut and acacia aromas follow over to the elegant medium-bodied palate along with Meyer lemon, mature yellow apple and saline. A note of chestnut honey wraps around the finish while fresh acidity keeps it balanced.

This medium-weight wine smells rather nice, with plum and black cherry notes accented by cinnamon and chocolate, but then the flavors pick up some green, herbaceous notes that turn bitter on the finish. Imported by Vin Divino.

appellation: Wahluke Slope, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Stemmy, green and harsh, with flavors of earth, stem and pip. The watery, dilute flavors barely suggest fruit.

wine: Wayfarer 2016 Wayfarer Vineyard Pinot Noir (Fort Ross-Seaview)
review: This estate-grown beauty is succulent and supple, with a tense body of bright wild strawberry, crushed rock, dried lavender and Asian spice. Robustly rich and deeply layered in flavor and texture, it finishes in a gorgeous dabble of white pepper.

wine: Villa San Juliette 2014 Petite Sirah (Paso Robles)
appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: Very extracted aromas of cassis and burnt caramel show on the nose of this bottling, which is already revealing its age. Plum-pudding flavors meet with a curiously zippy acidity on the palate.
Apple and pear flavors give this wine freshness and spice. It is bright, fruity and ready to drink.

Oaky aromas of bacon rest atop blackberry, fig and raisiny scents. This is a full and grabby Malbec with some chop to the palate. Roasted, woody flavors of black fruits and barbecue sauce finish with subtlety.

wine: Cooper-Garrod 2013 Finley Vineyard Syrah (Santa Cruz Mountains)
appellation: Santa Cruz Mountains, Central Coast, California, US
review: Savory black pepper and cooked blueberry show on the nose of this bottling. Cracked pepper also gives a savory touch to the sip, adding depth to the blackberry and plum flavors. The tannins are fairly sticky into the finish.

wine: Midsummer Cellars 2013 Tomasson Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (St. Helena)
review: There's a nice aspect of polished tannin behind this vineyard-designate that gives it a refined sensibility, and a roundness of ripeness that becomes almost overwhelming. An aroma of crayon plays with sturdier elements of baked bread and blackberry jam for a concentrated, full-bodied finish.

wine: Ram's Gate 2015 Ulises Valdez Silver Eagle Vineyard Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)
appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: From a site high above Green Valley, typically above the fog and in view of the ocean, this is a spicy, forested and savory wine, textured like nobody's business. Rhubarb, cranberry and wild strawberry attempt to intrude, and do quietly, but it's the cardamom and white pepper that persist most emphatically.

wine: Pine Ridge 2009 Fortis Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
review: This is a blend of the winery's vineyard sources in Rutherford and Stags Leap. It's very delicious and complex in blackberry and blueberry jam, cola, mocha and smoky oak flavors, but is surprisingly soft. It's almost as if the tannins and acids were taken out. Drink up.

appellation: South Eastern Australia, Australia Other, Australia
review: This now-multiregional Chardonnay blend from wine giant Penfolds is a pretty, fruity number with both the polish associated with this brand and upfront appeal. Waxed apple, peach and lime aromas kick things off. There's a fringe of salt, like the rim of a margarita glass. Laser-like acidity slices through the highly textural palate, leading once again to a long, salty finish. Drink now–2028.

wine: Rusack 2013 Santa Catalina Island Vineyards Pinot Noir (California)
review: One of the most ambitious wine projects on the planet, this bottling from Catalina Island shows rich complexity on the nose, with aromas of red cherries, smoked pork, tight graphite, a hint of maple and then violets, lilacs and other purple flowers. The flavors are soft with red and purple fruit, but solidly seasoned with anise, black pepper and spicy herbs, with all elements extremely well integrated.

Sly and expressive, with traditional aromas of wood, earth and leather along with telltale dried fruit. The palate is racy and reduced, a combination of apple skins, cherry and red plum. Finishes tight and concentrated before giving way to mature chocolaty notes. Drink or continue to hold.

wine: Jacquesson et Fils NV Cuvée No 737 Brut  (Champagne)
review: The latest numbered bottling in the Non Vintage series from Jacquesson, this has a beautiful balance between the lightest dosage, making it very dry, and intense structure and texture. It's still young and fruity and worth some bottle age.

wine: Rusack 2009 Reserve Pinot Noir (Sta. Rita Hills)
appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
review: Who wouldn't love this Pinot Noir? It's zippy in acidity and ripe in briary raspberry and cherry fruit, with spicy, smoky oak complexity. Really defines the luxurious silkiness of the appellation. The grapes are mostly from the Fiddlestix Vineyard, with the balance hailing from Rio Vista Vineyard. Drink now-2015.

The first Pinot in Undurraga's Terroir Hunter series is lean, tart and zesty, but also clean and pleasing in its own right. Tea and dried cherry aromas yield to a spunky, lean palate of sharp raspberry and orange peel flavors. Finishes light but clean, with tartness.

wine: Fratelli Muratori 2002 Villa Crespia Iacono Riserva Dosaggio Zero  (Franciacorta)
designation: Villa Crespia Iacono Riserva Dosaggio Zero
review: There's a caramel candy or custard-like quality to this wine that is backed by pear, apricot and mature fruit. It's a complex, layered sparkler with creamy vanilla mousse and golden saturation.

appellation: Mendocino County, Mendocino County, California, US
review: A weird and disturbing aroma suggesting a chemical flaw ruins this wine's otherwise decent flavors and texture.

wine: Abiqua Wind 2011 Chloe's Breeze Müller-Thurgau (Willamette Valley)
appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: This simple and sweet wine has a light peach flavor with a sugary—not syrupy—finish. It might be a good wine to soak fruit in for a light dessert.

Lots of bang for your buck with this rich, full-bodied young Merlot. It's dry and fruity, with black cherry, black currant, licorice and cedar flavors, wrapped into fine, firm tannins. Shows real Napa class.

Notes of crushed earth and flint open to brighter lemon and tart tangerine on the palate of this feather-light dry Riesling. It's a lip-smacking, zesty wine with piercing minerality and a sprightly finish. Drink now through 2024.

A gentle lift of crushed black cherry rises from the glass. There also is an edge of medicinal herb. The body is light and juicy, fresh and highly aromatic. There is concentration without weight, luxuriant fruit without plumpness. This is fresh and pure, lifted and profound. An utterly honest and uplifting rendition of Pinot Noir.

wine: Mureda 2011 Oak Aged Tempranillo (Vino de la Tierra de Castilla)
appellation: Vino de la Tierra de Castilla, Central Spain, Spain
review: Leathery aromas of raisin and horse hide are shaky. This is thick, grabby and a touch cloying, with baked, medicinal flavors of black fruits and blueberry. A minty, herbal finish feels sticky.

wine: Herdade de São Miguel 2011 Ciconia The Reserva Red (Alentejano)
review: A black-hued blend of Aragonez, Touriga Nacional and Trincadeira, this is powerful, rich and firmly packed with tannins as well as dense plum and wood flavors. Accents of spice and mint add complexity. The wine will benefit from 2–3 years of aging to soften and round out, but it's drinkable now.

wine: Château la Varière 2009 La Grande Chevalerie Cabernet Sauvignon (Anjou Villages Brissac)
appellation: Anjou Villages Brissac, Loire Valley, France
review: It is rare to find pure Cabernet Sauvignon in the Loire, but 2009 was the year when it worked with ripe black currant and berry fruits. The wine has a dark, dense concentration while retaining elegance and a light touch. Age for several years.
This is a structured wine, dry and firm, It seems to have lost some fruit along the way, showing extraction as well as acidity. Drink the wine when it may have softened, from 2024.

wine: Schrader 2006 Beckstoffer Vineyard Georges III Cabernet Sauvignon (Rutherford)
review: Smells Porty, like chocolate-covered raisins, and turns rather heavy in the mouth, although very dry. Tastes roasted, with grilled blackberry and cedar flavors. This style is characteristic of the winery and often of this vineyard, on the east side of the Rutherford flatlands.

wine: Soos Creek 1998 Champoux Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Columbia Valley (WA))
appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Look closely or you will miss the vineyard designation, hidden in a tiny black banner in the upper left corner of the label. It's important, because Champoux is one of the state's oldest and best Cabernet vineyards. Ripe, satiny black cherry/red berry fruit is on display here, with firm acids, moderate tannins, and just enough oak to add a dash of toast at the end.

wine: Normans 2002 Chais Clarendon Cabernet Sauvignon (South Australia)
review: This is one good Cabernet with all its pieces in place: fruit-sweet and nutty on the nose, with a juicy blackberry and black cherry core and a gravelly, minerally texture. It's not as mouthfilling and plush as it has been in recent vintages, but it's still an enjoyable wine. Imported by Xanadu Normans Wine Group.

wine: Iron Horse 2007 Ocean Reserve Sparkling (Green Valley)
review: A beautiful sparkling wine that shows the Iron Horse signature of balanced elegance. The lime, raspberry, vanilla and brioche flavors are rich and intricate, but particularly lovely is the texture, which is soft and silky.

wine: Domaine Michel Fonne NV Sparkling (Crémant d'Alsace)
review: A very subdued nose leads to a fresh, lively and light palate that displays subtle red-currant fruit. Freshness makes this appetizing while the finish is dry and refreshing.

appellation: Adelaida District, Central Coast, California, US
review: Ripe red-cherry aromas meet with light mint and cigar box on the nose of this bottling. The fresh, acid-washed palate is quite broad with red currant and tangy red plum, lifted with hints of bay leaf and finishing on a caramel streak.

wine: Viñedos de Canata 2004 Chardonnay (Bío Bío Valley)
review: A touch waxy and oily, with flower blossom and butterscotch scents but no overt, identifiable fruit. Lively and acidic, a trait of the chilly, emerging southern Bío Bío area. Finishes spry but short on flavor. Imported by Corkscrew Imports.

wine: Vignamaggio 2016 Monna Lisa Gran Selezione  (Chianti Classico)
review: Balsamic scents of camphor mix with leather, underbrush and French oak aromas. On the palate, notes of roasted coffee bean, salt and star anise accent a core of dried cherry. Assertive, drying tannins leave a lean, astringent finish.

wine: Stolpman 2011 La Cuadrilla Red (Santa Ynez Valley)
appellation: Santa Ynez Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: This bottling is a blend of various varieties from the winery's estate Ballard Canyon vineyard. The profits go the the winery's vineyard crew. The '11 Caudrilla is a rich, spicy wine, with lots of sweet, ripe berry-cherry fruits. It's fine for drinking now.

wine: Efeste 2013 Eleni Red Willow Vineyard Syrah (Yakima Valley)
appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: The aromas of embers, black pepper, dark fruit, herbs, smoke and spice are brooding and locked up on first pour, showing more on each swirl. The blue and black-fruit flavors are ripe, sweet and full, with savory notes fleshing out the crazy long finish.

wine: Ledger David 2010 Orion's Nebula Red (Rogue Valley)
appellation: Rogue Valley, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
review: A blend of Cab Franc, Malbec, Petit Verdot and Syrah, this was aged for 18 months in 30% new American oak. Perhaps the barrel aging accounts for the over-riding vanilla flavor. That, and some herbal highlights, seem to mask the fruit.
Here's a round Sauvignon with subdued aromas of ripe tropical fruit, peach and cut grass. The mellow palate delivers papaya and pineapple accented with a note of paprika alongside fresh acidity.

wine: Adega Mãe 2020 Pinta Negra Branco White (Lisboa)
review: The fruitiness of Arinto and Fernão Pires in combination is displayed well in this fresh, crisp wine. Its bright character is refreshing, tangy and ready to drink.

appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Aromas of dark plum, blue fruit and spice lead to full fruit flavors that show intensity, with vanilla flavors on the finish. The tannins show a slight grittiness that softens over time.

wine: Domaines Astruc 2010 dA Reserve Chardonnay (Pays d'Oc)
review: Fresh and vibrant with strong pineapple acidity flavors cutting through the ripe stone fruit core. Lush and melony in the mouth with a clean finish.

Right now this is not typically soft and lush like a cult Cab, but hard in tannins, with minerality like little particles of granite. Buried deep down is a pirate's treasure of ripe, intense blackberry fruit. New oak, to the tune of 94%, doesn't cloud the wine, suggesting this blend's its intensity and concentration. The wine is comprised of all five classic Bordeaux varieties, sourced throughout Sonoma County. Clearly this is one for the cellar; drink after 2018.

Runs up and down the hill with firmness, acidity and zest. There's clear cherry on the nose and some Zin-like flavor that tells you it's something different (Petit Verdot). Not weak but sort of limited in content. There's also holding potential based on how it quickly improves with airing. A treat for everyday meats, stews, pastas and grills.

Swathes of violet, lilac and bramble perfume this profoundly juicy, succulent red sourced from young, organically farmed Syrah. Unoaked and medium-bodied in style, it's an irresistibly fruit-forward but elegant wine framed by soft, chalky tannins. At peak now but should hold well through 2025.

Pure Sauvignon, this is a tropical fruit flavored wine. It's bright and fruity while also showing a dense texture of grapefruit and steely minerality. The combination makes for an intense wine that's likely to need time, so drink from 2017.

Subdued aromas of dried black fruit and baking spice set the tone in this wine. Its easygoing, straightforward palate offers mature Morello cherry and vanilla flavors alongside round tannins. Drink soon.

Corrina Wright and her team have showed the viability of a variety rarely seen outside its native northern Spain home. The nose is dense and earthy but quickly opens with time in glass to reveal bushels of dried herbs, spices, cherries and flowers. Silky, brambly fruit is wound by firm, textured tannins on the medium-bodied palate. It's a charming, restrained wine that balances New World sunshine with Old World charm.

wine: Monticello Vineyards 1997 Corley Reserve Chardonnay (Napa Valley)
review: Pear aromas and smoky notes mark the nose. The flavors are deep, with apple, earth, and nuts predominating. Finishes medium-long, with just a tang of oak on the end. Well balanced and elegant.

Pristine but intensely ripe blueberry and cassis are shaded by granite and menthol. It's a luscious, sultry Syrah balanced by brisk acidity that penetrates long on the palate. Fine, chalky tannins make it ready to enjoy now, but it should drink well through 2027.

wine: Cave de Tain 2007 Esprit de Granit  (Saint-Joseph)
review: Deep, dense, purple color. Pronounced aromas of toasty vanilla, clove, sweet spice dominate the backdrop of ultra-ripe black fruit. Modern, forward style with lots of vanilla cream, coffee and spicy blackberry pie flavors. Full-bodied, plush, extracted with supple tannins. Sort of 'Shiraz' with a more savory finish.

appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: As usual, this was sourced entirely from a small block in the Dineen vineyard. Fragrant with a mélange of lemony aromas, the flavors carry the same theme—lemon gelato, lemon pie, limoncello, all buoyed with perfect acidity. It's a vivid, clean, long-lasting wine.

Cooling, mossy chalkiness plays on this wine's nose, despite the heat of 2018. The palate then displays juicy roundness in the form of ripe, yellow pear pervading chalky depth. Rich lemon-peel notes create contour and add mouthwatering brightness to this concentrated, understated wine that comes with subdued but distinct power. Drink 2025–2045.

wine: Château la Vivonne 2020 Brin de Rosé (Coteaux d'Aix-en-Provence)
review: Based in Bandol, the producer also makes this wine from Coteaux d'Aix-en-Provence. It is soft, easy, lightly fruity and lightly textured. Acidity and a crisp aftertaste complete this ready-to-drink wine.

wine: Sanguinhal 2014 Quinta das Cerejeiras Grande Reserva Red (Obidos)
review: A finely mature wine, rich with dusty tannins and black fruit flavors that are changing and bringing in secondary flavors. The wine is rich while also balanced between the ripe fruits and the generous, mature texture. Drink now.

Sourced from the Black Sage Bench, this spent more than 50 days on the skins and was fermented with wild yeasts. It's smoky in the nose and smooth in the mouth, with wild strawberry fruit. The tannins have a pleasantly charred character, with streaks of licorice and dark chocolate.

wine: Chanson Père et Fils 2005 Clos des Mouches Premier Cru  (Beaune)
review: This wine is rich, sweet, extravagant and, finally, elegant. Its ripe fruit flavors, red plums, sweet strawberries and smoky acidity all work together. The wine shows considerable concentration, but never loses sight of freshness. Age for another five years at least.

You'll enjoy the harmony and buoyancy Melini offers thanks to its well-integrated notes of cherry, spice and almond. The wine is a bit thin and acidic in the mouth and has a fresh trail of cherry flavors that lasts until the very end.

Nicely dry and well balanced, this is an appetizing medium-bodied wine that offers no-nonsense cherry and berry flavors and a lightly tannic, almost crisp, texture that will be a good palate cleanser.

appellation: Malibu Coast, South Coast, California, US
review: Jammy fruit aromas of strawberry and plum are cut by toasted wood aromas on the nose of this bottling. The palate offers purple-flower flavors and hints of mint and pine, with red and black plums providing the slight tart core.

wine: The Infinite Monkey Theorem 2012 Cabernet Franc (Grand Valley)
review: Spicy green notes accent the crème de cassis and peppercorn aromas. The palate is concentrated and fluid, with refined tannins and a medium-long finish.

This is a hearty, robust red wine that showcases the appellation well, offering smooth, rounded and rich opulence on the palate. Flavors are etched in cherry, cola and a hint of plum, with a sweetness of oak being met by dried herb and cedar undertones that work well within the wine's weight.

This is a tight, textured and fruity wine. With a great mineral texture and steely structure, it is a wine for some aging. Lemon and pink grapefruit flavors sheer through the texture, still waiting to balance. From 2017 it will be a fine wine.

wine: Wildewood 2013 Hirschy Vineyard Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)
appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: Diffuse and herbal, this has a slightly rustic bent, with overall herbaceousness. It smoothes out through the finish, though generally it just seems thin and under-ripe.

wine: R & B Cellars 2006 Counterpoint Cabernet Franc (El Dorado)
appellation: El Dorado, Sierra Foothills, California, US
review: A very nice Cab Franc that shows how well this variety can do in the Sierra Foothills. It's quite soft and light in body, making it a wine for early drinking. But it offers waves of cherries, anisettte liqueur, cocoa, pepper and mint flavors that are delicious.

Fresh and juicy, this is a wine where the fruit is already well in balance with the tannic core. It is structured and firm while allowing plenty of room for the red fruits and acidity. Drink from 2018.

wine: B Cellars 2004 Blend 25 Cabernet Sauvignon-Syrah Red (Napa Valley)
review: Only the second vintage for this wine, but it joins the top ranks of Cabernet-Syrah blends. Dry, rich, smooth and frankly delicious, it has incredibly complex flavors, of blackberries, violets, coffee, pomegranates, cola, cloves and oak, and a long finish. A terrific wine to drink now and over the next four years.

Superextracted, with jammy cherry, cola, raspberry pie filling, chocolate and spicy gingerbread flavors. Almost sweet in fruity concentration, but it's pretty dry. Ripeness was no problem in this warm vintage. Elegance is the challenge.

wine: Giacomo Ascheri 1998 Podere di Sorano Barolo  (Barolo)
review: The long wood aging in large Slavonian oak barrels has given this a dryness and austerity. The fruit is there, with red fruit flavors and ripeness, but it is the dryness and tarry black flavors that dominate. It is very young, and should develop over the next 10 years.

wine: Domaine de Tara 2009 Hautes Pierres Red (Ventoux)
review: Powerfully built, with masses of cherry fruit backed by firm tannins. A bit unusual for the region, with 80% Syrah and only 20% Grenache, but it workss, yielding a tough, dense wine that should age well for 5–6 years.
This offers faint honeydew, chamomile and elderflower tones on the nose. The palate is similar, boasting more floral and melon flavors.

appellation: Columbia Gorge (WA), Washington Other, Washington, US
review: Red and black raspberry aromas are at the fore, followed by notes of freshly peeled orange, blueberry and herb. Medium-bodied, somewhat tangy fruit flavors follow.
This opens with subtle aromas of wild flower and a whiff of exotic fruit. The bright fruity palate offers white peach, apple and a hint of honeydew melon. It's straightforward and refreshing.

wine: Suacci Carciere Wines 2009 Heintz Vineyard Chardonnay (Russian River Valley)
appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: Strong and eccentric, this tastes like the grapes from this fine vineyard had a hit of botrytis. But it's not sweet; the end result is dry, with apricot and honey flavors.

wine: Usiglian del Vescovo NV Il Bruvè Metodo Classico Sangiovese (Vino Spumante)
review: Aromas of crushed stone, pressed rose and wild berry delicately lift out of the glass along with an earthy forest floor note and a whiff of bread crust. Reflecting the nose, the dry, vibrant palate offers strawberry, wild cherry, citrus and a mineral note of oyster shell alongside racy acidity and a refined perlage.

wine: Perrier Jouët NV Blanc de Blancs Brut Chardonnay (Champagne)
review: Chardonnay has always been the signature grape of this producer and this finely proportioned wine has both the house style and a mineral character from the grape. It is crisp, moving towards the dry end of Brut and with lively fruitiness. Drink now.

wine: Boekenhoutskloof 2008 The Chocolate Block Red (Western Cape)
review: This Syrah-dominant blend with 12% Grenache, 10% Cabernet Sauvignon, 7% Cinsault and 2% Viognier offers a delicious, fruit-driven core matched with complex spice notes of sweet smoke, cured meat and fresh tobacco leaf. The mouth is silky and smooth with fine-grain tannins and a white pepper-flecked finish. Drink now–2012.
Dry and soft, with upfront cherry-berry fruit and a smooth finish. Perfect match for lasagna or hamburgers.

wine: Trinchero 2002 Chicken Ranch Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Rutherford)
review: This lovely Cabernet shows well-defined black currant, olive and spice flavors, and has a good balance of acidity and grippy tannins. It's rich, dry and complex. The oak is pronounced, but perfectly balanced with the fruit. Really displays class and pedigree.

wine: Domaine de Terra Vecchia 2016 Tentation by Renucci Rosé (Ile de Beauté)
review: With its designer white bottle, this is obviously a statement wine. Yet, it's also deliciously fruity and crisp. With bright red fruit and a citrusy tang, it's lively and perfumed.
Nutty aromas, and a slight mustiness mark the nose. Almond, spice and earth flavors on the palate, medium mouthfeel and finish, but overall it seems a bit tired.

wine: Messina Hof 2010 Sophia Marie Sweet Beginnings Rosé (Texas)
review: Unabashedly bold, this Texas rosé hits the nose with a dose of lilac and rose perfume that lingers a bit obtrusively onto the palate. Off-dry in style, it's chunky on the palate, but finishes nicely, with a hint of tart red-plum flavors. Drink now.

wine: Blue Farm 2014 King Ridge Vineyard Hirsch Selection Pinot Noir (Fort Ross-Seaview)
review: Powerful tannin meets subdued fruit in this layered, youthful wine. Concentrated and focused, with rose petal, sage and wild strawberry notes, it holds back teasingly before slowly unraveling to reveal velvety texture and corpulent weight.

wine: Steorra NV Brut Sparkling (Russian River Valley)
appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: Joe Wagner's latest addition to his Copper Cane Wine & Provisions offerings is this dry brut, made from 55% Chardonnay and 45% Pinot Noir. Touched by lemon and grapefruit, it starts with a nuance of flowers before launching into satisfying creaminess that lingers pleasantly on the palate.

A plump, amply concentrated Riesling, with plenty of pineapple fruit to balance the hints of kerosene, slate and lime. Finishes crisp and clean, with a dry quality that invites another sip. Drink now.

This family-owned estate has produced a structured and dark wine with great concentration balanced by acidity and pure, creamy fruit. It is a wine with a good future. The aftertaste leaves juicy acidity and firm tannins. Drink from 2025.

wine: Fattoria Torre a Cona 2016  Chianti Colli Fiorentini
review: This blend of 90% Sangiovese and 10% Colorino opens with dark berry, tilled soil and thyme hints. The round palate offers dried black cherry, clove and licorice notes alongside smooth tannins. Drink soon.

One of the smallest crus, Saint-Amour produces firm and structured wines. This Sélection shows both rich black fruit and solid tannins that are typical. Over the next six months, it's likely the fruitiness will become more dominant.

wine: Gloria Ferrer NV Blanc de Blancs Sparkling (Carneros)
review: Based on Chardonnay, this sparking wine is dry, crisp and yeasty, with orange, mango and lime flavors and a dry finish. The main criticism is that the bubbles are scoury and fierce, lacking the finesse of a fine sparkling wine.
A full-bodied yet crisp Chardonnay, balanced with just a tiny hint of lingering ripeness. Fine for mid-week meals.

wine: Emmerich Knoll 2018 Selection Ried Pfaffenberg Riesling (Niederösterreich)
review: The nose is shy but a tangerine peel zestiness rises from the glass, almost with an ethereal edge. The palate, right now, is open and bold.
