Ripe Mirabelle fruit almost bounces with juiciness, framed by more of that zesty tangerine peel. The palate is concentrated and energetic, generous but racy and certainly brimming with fruity, vivid freshness. Drink 2025–2045.

wine: Hall 2005 Kathryn Hall Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
review: Firmly tannic and dry, this Cabernet, which was blended with a little Merlot, Malbec and Petit Verdot, is one for the cellar. The tannins are tough and astringent, but when they melt away over the next decade or so, they'll leave behind sweet currants, cedar and violets.

A clean and easy style of Chardonnay with peach and melon aromas followed by a melony palate with nectarine and a touch of sweetness. It flattens out and loses intensity on the finish, but overall it's totally drinkable and solid.

wine: Château le Grand Verdus 2018 Grande Réserve  (Bordeaux Blanc)
review: Made from 70-year-old vines and fermented and aged in Burgundy barrels, this wine retains a touch of wood to amplify the richness and smoothness. With a hint of honey as well as plenty of crisp white fruits, the wine is still maturing. It will be at its best from 2021.

wine: Merry Edwards 2014 Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)
appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: A blend from several of the producer's finest vineyards, including Georganne, Flax, Olivet Lane and Klopp, this offers complex notes of smoky lavender and licorice. Velvety texture underlies mouth-coating flavors of blackberry jam, pomegranate and cardamom, finishing tartly in acidity.

With a nose of black currant and aniseed, this dark, garnet-colored wine is opulent in the mouth, with plush tannins and flavors of fruits of the wood, anise, dried herbs, caramel and coffee that lead to an espresso-bean finish.
Made entirely with Sangiovese, this light-bodied wine has aromas of red berry and orchard fruit. Reflecting the nose, the fresh, simple palate suggests wild raspberry and a hint of white peach.

wine: Claiborne & Churchill 2018 Spanish Springs Vineyard Grenache (San Luis Obispo County)
appellation: San Luis Obispo County, Central Coast, California, US
review: This vineyard just miles from the sands of Pismo Beach makes for very firm Rhône wines, even presenting Grenache as a perfect candidate for the cellar. Clean aromas of black raspberry, turned loam, dewy sage and a touch of game lead into a minty, dark-berry palate that's heavily structured yet still playful. Drink 2021–2028.

Heavy aromas and flavors of oak and smoke accompany ripe black cherry and boysenberry for a rich mixture. This wine is deeply colored, full bodied and pumped up with the flavors of heavily toasted oak. A firm but not harsh texture accompanies the almost sweet taste of all that oak.

wine: Torres 2018 Pazo das Bruxas Albariño (Rías Baixas)
review: Stony lime aromas come with a touch of white-flower perfume. Bright acidity creates a juicy palate with lemon-lime and pineapple flavors, while this displays a note of green apple on the finish. Drink now.

appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: This wine is a blend of fruit from Oasis, Gamache and Olsen vineyards and was aged half in stainless steel with the rest in neutral barrels. It's a bit reduced out of the gate, opening up to reveal kiwi, citrus, pineapple and herb aromas. The bountiful tropical fruit flavors delight.

appellation: Nuragus di Cagliari, Sicily & Sardinia, Italy
review: Aromas of white wild flower, white stone fruit, lemon zest and Mediterranean herb lead the nose on this vibrant white. The juicy palate offers succulent peach, pear and nectarine while crisp acidity gives it a clean, refreshing finish. It closes on an almond note.

wine: Castello di Tassarolo 2018 del Comune di Gavi  (Gavi)
review: Made with organically grown grapes and without added sulfites, this unusual but intriguing white has aromas of bread crust, peanut, honey and citrus rind. The aromas carry over to the tangy palate along with mature yellow apple and a candied lemon slice note.

wine: François Lurton 2008 Hacienda Araucano Cabernet Sauvignon (Colchagua Valley)
review: Pleasant red-fruit aromas kick it off, followed by regular-weight cherry and cassis flavors that come with a hint of herbal essence. The finish is racy and almost rough, but there's enough body and weight to the wine to push it across the finish line.

appellation: Amador County, Sierra Foothills, California, US
review: Aromas of fresh black fruit and toasted oak meet dashes of black pepper, vanilla and woodsmoke in this sturdy, full-bodied but lightly tannic wine.

appellation: Cienega Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: Dry and smooth, and a bit coarse, this wine shows berry, oak and leather flavors. Short finish.

wine: Baldacci 2006 Brenda's Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Stags Leap District)
appellation: Stags Leap District, Napa, California, US
review: Easily earns its high score for the sheer power and mass, equal to anything out of Napa. Erupts in the most complex blackberries, black currants, licorice and 100% new smoky oak flavors, with a spicy finish that goes on and on. The tannins are strong and fine and impressive. Not for the faint-hearted, and not a wine to drink now, as it will swamp food. Should begin to emerge after 2012.
Apple flavors and a light texture give this wine an open character. Acidity, bright fruitiness and zesty orange peel enhance the wine's freshness. It is ready to drink.
Although a bit vegetal, there are worthwhile notes of plum, cherry and caramel. The palate is lightweight, with salad greens, tomato and basil flavors. Finishes peppery. —K.F.

Tight and dense, this is a full-flavored, smoky and rich version of Syrah, with flavors that seem a bit cooked. The fruit is smooth, mature and showing a mix of berry, currant and plum flavors. Forward and softer than the reserve, it's a wine for near-term drinking.

So ripe and sweet in raspberry jam, cherry pie and plum sauce flavor, it makes it hard to appreciate the other qualities of this Syrah. It also has lovely, soft tannins and a long, spicy finish. Doesn't leave much to the imagination, but it sure is a tasty wine.

wine: Gran Dominio 1999 San Cayetano Vineyards Gran Reserva Cabernet Franc (Maule Valley)
review: Opens with aromas suggesting cured French olives, white  chocolate, and cherry, with a tropical fruit note of banana. Flavors of black  cherry aren't bad, and the wine has a nice, gentle but firm mouthfeel.

Oak on top of more oak is the calling card here, while underneath you'll find blackberry fruit. There's a juicy part to the wine, but only after digging through a layer of dill-scented wood. Tannic, full-bodied and lengthy, it needs three years at least to show its true self. Now it's just an oaked-up baby.

This long-established vineyard has produced a wood-aged wine, ripe with red fruits and still structured with a core of dry tannins. With a high percentage of Merlot in the blend, it is succulent, full bodied and shows its alcohol. It will be ready to drink from 2022.

wine: Fleur Du Cap 2012 Bergkelder Selection Pinotage (Stellenbosch)
review: This value-minded wine from an iconic producer offers attractive initial scents of brambly berry and cherry, with additional touches of marzipan and vanilla that lend decadence. The medium-weight palate shows great balance, with ample acidity and firm yet fine tannins that frame the bright red-fruit flavors. Drink now–2018.

An aromatic tinge of yarrow and crushed citrus leaf adds heady allure to the lemony flavors on the nose. The palate, still slightly spritzy, presents a riper note, a rounder aspect despite all its lemon freshness. There is something gentle, mild, juicy and harmonious about this. The finish is dry and zesty.

wine: Roche 2013 Barrel Select French Oak Reserve Chardonnay (Carneros)
review: Thick, dense tropical fruit is balanced by acidity and a tartness of green apple and lemon pith in this wine, aged in French oak. Structured and medium bodied, it'll work well at the table.

wine: Le Vigne 2013 Cuore della Vigne Red (Paso Robles)
appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: Cedar, cherry, black olive, wet earth, green olive and freshly plucked plum pop on the nose of this bottling. The palate shows lots of ripe black cherry down the middle, but is surrounded by a tangy green olive and an underripe-berry character, whose tartness enlivens the mouth.

wine: Newsome-Harlow 2009 Herbert Vineyard, Old Vine Zinfandel (El Dorado County)
appellation: El Dorado County, Sierra Foothills, California, US
review: A new vineyard source for Newsome-Harlow and arguably its best single-vineyard designated Zin out of a lineup of superbly delicious Zins. With a heady raspberry and blackberry nose, this Zin is classically lush and intense yet silky smooth in the mouth, tinged by hints of black pepper and licorice. Altogether so, so good.
Earthy and mildly lactic on the nose, with tight, lean, herbal flavors. Doesn't rise above mediocre.

wine: Gloria Ferrer 2013 Royal Cuvée Brut Sparkling (Carneros)
review: Blending 67% Pinot Noir and 33% Chardonnay, this sparkler is viscous and rich in vanilla cream, nutmeg and biscuit, with a layering of thick peach. Robust in style, it offers moderate acidity and structure.

wine: Carmen 2016 Wave Series Left Wave Sauvignon Blanc (Leyda Valley)
review: Tropical fruit and hay aromas open this plump but basic SB that's low on acidity. Low-energy green-melon flavors are a bit briny, while a lack of punchy acidity leaves a short finish.

Made from dried Sagrantino grapes, this opens with blueberry, vanilla and nutmeg scents that carry over to the palate, along with coffee notes. Chewy tannins provide support while a cinnamon flavor closes the finish.

wine: Cave de Lugny 2015 La Côte Blanche  (Mâcon-Villages)
review: This is a soft, gently fruity wine. It comes from a single vineyard creating a wine that has rounded yellow and pear fruits and balanced acidity. It is a smooth wine, made to be drink young.
This luminous Prosecco offers simple aromas of stone fruit, cut grass and honey. The wine is fresh and easygoing with a clean and crisp finish and a watery mouthfeel.

Firm and a bit toasty, with some rubber and dark fruit on the nose. Offers sweet berry fruit and kirsch flavors and manages to stay on form through the finish. Likable and on the money. Imported by Cabernet Corporation.

wine: Newsome-Harlow 2011 The Donner Party The Dalton Ranch Zinfandel (Calaveras County)
designation: The Donner Party The Dalton Ranch
appellation: Calaveras County, Sierra Foothills, California, US
review: A consistent standout among Newsome-Harlow's stellar lineup of single-vineyard Zins, The Donner Party is rich in blackberry liqueur and licorice, finely structured and soft in tannins, with a dusty, mocha-lined finish and just the right seasoning of leather. Blended with 12% Petite Sirah.

Has the lean and tight structure of a mountain wine, with crisp acids framing citrus and peach flavors, but it's also notable for its creamy, lush texture and rich finish. This wine changes constantly in the glass and should improve with age through 2005.

Still young despite some bottle age, this elegant Pinot takes time to open. When it does, it presents an array of attractive notes, from plump, brambly red berries and dried roses to mushrooms and hoisin sauce. A backbone of vanillin oak is present but well placed. Medium bodied, it's broad in shape but tucked in neatly by warm, spicy tannins. With lovely length and texture, this is a classy wine with flesh on its bones. It could be drunk now with decanter or cellared until 2031.

appellation: North Coast, North Coast, California, US
review: This dry wine made from Syrah, Zinfandel and Petite Sirah is smooth and gentle, nicely fruity but also spiced with touches of black pepper and clove. The mouthfeel is especially silky so it's easy to sip and enjoy.
Full of red-fruit aromas, particularly plum and cherry. Feels raw, with wild berry, ample oak and a lot of acid-based tang to the palate. Lightly toasty, with a mild cherry flavor to the finish.

Juicy in fresh cherry, strawberry and rhubarb, this delightful wine sourced from two of owner and winemaker Katy Wilson's single-vineyard designates (Rice-Spivak and Thorn Ridge) intrigues in unexpected nuances of nutmeg and white pepper. Fresh, lively and earthy, it is incredibly good.

Pinot Blanc may be the most underrated grape in Oregon; it straddles the line between Pinot Gris and Chardonnay—at least the good ones do. This is a good one. It's full, loaded with pear-flavored fruit, ripe and round yet retaining its acids and focus. Spicy highlights creep into the finish, and there are even some noticeable tannins, a bit unusual in a white wine, that add definition to the expansive finish.

Explosive aromas of roasted coffee, cocoa, pepper, blackberry and smoke. Has tremendous finesse, not powerfully fruity but exceptionally balanced and harmonious. Dry, elegant, and tannic, and will certainly improve with age. One of the few single-vineyard wines Penfolds produces.

Attractive spicy oak accents and classic fruit flavors come together nicely in this full-bodied, firm-textured wine. A cedary, sun-baked aroma leads to red- and black-cherry flavors and baking-spice accents like vanilla and nutmeg.

wine: Wente 2011 The Nth Degree Merlot (Livermore Valley)
appellation: Livermore Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: Among Wente's highest-priced offerings, this is an elegant Merlot, velvety textured and succulent in herbal cassis and luxurious red plum and cherry. With a gorgeous mouthfeel and some weight to the body, it'll stand up to equally elegant meals.

As one would expect from the sunny, Mediterranean climes of McLaren Vale, this isn't a shy Shiraz. But its robustness and concentration—with notes of plump plum, cassis, mint, ground pepper and chocolaty oak—is neatly balanced by beautifully textured tannins. Well-balanced with surprising finesse for its price point, it never veers into syrupy or cooked territory. Drink now–2028.

wine: Switchback Ridge 2000 Peterson Family Vineyard Merlot (Napa Valley)
review: A thick, dark Merlot, cloaked in smooth, fat tannins and redolent of cherry, licorice, blackberry, plum, spice, coffee, sage, thyme and hints of orange peel. Long and sleek, with toasty oak on the finish. Just a hint of tartness at the end, but still a terrific wine.
Bacon aromas lead to a wine that is spicy, dry and meaty in character. There is a stalky element at first, yet turns to fresh, ripe fruit balanced by lively acidity. Drink from 2017.

wine: Marchesi Ginori Lisci 2005 Macchion del Lupo Cabernet Sauvignon (Toscana)
review: This Cabernet's penetrating green notes are very much in character with the variety: tomato leaf, leafy greens, medicinal notes, exotic spice and cherry cola. Its meaty consistency is topped by a blast of sour cherry.

wine: De Venoge NV Princes Blanc de Noirs Brut Pinot Noir (Champagne)
review: Bottled in a replica of a 19th-century crystal carafe, this wine is a blend of crus from the Montagne de Reims. On the dry side of brut, it has a lively sliced apple and citrus character as well as refreshing, lively acidity. The wine is ready to drink.

Stocky, dark and pure, with inky aromas of shoe polish, black fruits and charcoal. The palate is brawny and tannic, with saturated blackberry, espresso and bitter chocolate flavors. It's rowdy but also attractive and full of everything good including chocolate, spice and pepper on the finish. Drink from 2011 through 2015.

A blend of Douro white grapes produces a wine that is ripe and fruity. It has apricot and warm yellow plum flavors that are lifted by acidity and a tight texture. It is ready to drink but will be better from the end of 2016.

wine: Château Magnol 2011 Les Charmes de Magnol  (Médoc)
review: The second wine of Château Magnol, this is a ripe, smoke and wood flavored wine. It has spice, attractive black currant fruits and some—not too many—firm tannins. With its inherent fruitiness it will be ready to drink this year.
This wine has a sweet nose of chocolate and vanilla oak and this richness continues on the palate. Basically built and structured, it has a simple approachability.
Since this is 100% Sauvignon Blanc, it is intensely crisp, with grapefruit flavors and bright acidity that lead into a lemongrass aftertaste. It's clean and fresh, and is likely to mature quickly.

wine: Kahn 2002 Susich Vineyard Syrah (Santa Ynez Valley)
appellation: Santa Ynez Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: Cedary and toasty, with big, mouthfilling flavors of roasted fruit that pick up hints of pepper and dried spices. But we also found hints of nail polish and dry, woody tannins on the finish.

Showing both the crispness necessary for Savennières, and the ripeness of 2005, this is a finely balanced wine. It is full, open and generous, but still has a center of green, crisp acidity and minerality. Age for 10 years. Screwcap.

wine: MacPhail 2013 Dutton Ranch Pinot Noir (Green Valley)
review: This is a robustly reduced, tightly wound and still quite youthful wine, showing both the vintage and the appellation in warmer years, with an intensity of black tea, tar and black cherry. Full bodied, it's powerfully weighted and structured.

wine: Weingut Albert Gessinger 2017 Zeltinger Sonnenuhr Josefberg Old Vines Spätlese Riesling (Mosel)
designation: Zeltinger Sonnenuhr Josefberg Old Vines Spätlese
review: Succulent lemon, yellow pear and grapefruit extend from nose to finish in this forward yet elegantly mineral Spätlese. It's medium-sweet in style and ringed by a touch of caramelized sugar but finishes refreshingly dry. Enjoy now–2022.

wine: Forstreiter 2011 Tabor Reserve Die Räritat Grüner Veltliner (Kremstal)
review: From one of the oldest vineyards in Austria, this is a hugely ripe and intense wine. It has obvious power and concentration balanced with flavorful acidity and creamy pear. Rich, full bodied and dense, it is still young and should not be drunk before 2015.

wine: Guilbaud Frères 2018 Grand Or Sur Lie  (Muscadet Sèvre et Maine)
appellation: Muscadet Sèvre et Maine, Loire Valley, France
review: A ripe wine with red-apple and apricot flavors, this is gently textured while also having a tight bite of acidity. It's all about fruitiness and freshness. Drink this attractive wine now.

Mulchy aromas lack fruit and freshness. In the mouth, this shrieks of high acidity and hard tannins. Oaky flavors of vanilla and cream blend with spicy herbal green-leaning berry notes, while this shows an earthy essence on a muddled finish.

wine: San Pedro 2002 San Andrés Cabernet Sauvignon (Lontué Valley)
review: Earth and berry aromas, and then thin, woody cherry flavors. The finish is buttery and rather bland, and the palate feel is lean and overwooded, especially given the basic pedigree of the wine. –M.S.

wine: Pride Mountain 2007 Vintner Select Merlot (Sonoma County)
review: Smells and tastes super-oaky, with dominating notes of vanilla, clove, dill and caramel. Although there's a ton of cherry, chocolate and raspberry fruit, sweet vanilla and toast still is the main element. Maybe it's going through a dumb phase and simply needs time. Try again after 2011.

Full bodied and nicely dry, this well-built wine starts with smoky black-pepper aromas that lead to mouthfilling blackberry and black-cherry flavors supported by firm tannins. It's the kind of wine that will pair beautifully with a meaty or cheesy meal, because it has the texture to match that kind of richness.

This sparkling blend (50-50 Chardonnay and Pinot Nero) represents one of only a handful of barrel aged metodo classico wines from Friuli in northeast Italy. The wine's perlage is firm and steely and there are soft layers of toasted bread, stone fruit and honey at the back.
A ripe wine offering pineapple as well as apricot flavors, this is full bodied and rich. Its fruitiness is already delicious. Drink this wine now.

Pipe-tobacco, blue-flower and menthol aromas escape the glass along with an earthy hint of cured meats. It's linearly structured and racy, offering crushed raspberry, strawberry compote and licorice along with an earthy hint of game on the salty finish. Fine-grained tannins provide support.

Disgorged in November 2018, this intense wine has now had plenty of time to develop some maturity. Richness as well as a touch of toast come through the tight texture and citrus fruits. It is ready to drink.

wine: Galleano NV Mary Margaret Sherry (Cucamonga Valley)
appellation: Cucamonga Valley, South Coast, California, US
review: There's a chocolate side to the brandy- like prune aromas on the nose of this Sherry-style dessert wine. The palate is thick yet spiked with acidity, as prune and raisin flavors meet with clove and caramel.

Strawberry tea and rose-petal aromas open this wine with nuance and elegance, a nice entry to a velvety texture that's both spicy and sublime. Forest floor and clove contribute complexity as a touch of smoky oak rises on the finish.

This is 100% Roussanne, from one of the highest vineyards in the Luberon. It's fruity and direct, a well-made medium-bodied white, boasting a panopoly of fruit flavors ranging from pear to pineapple, and hints of melon as well. Drink it over the next several months.

wine: Domaine Costa Lazaridi 2008 Château Julia Assyrtiko Assyrtico (Drama)
review: A snappy nose of citrus and grapefruit is followed by a very pretty balance of fresh apples and citrus and spice. Aromatic but dry, it will pair well with spicy cuisine or grilled seafood.

wine: Quinta Vale do Armo 2010 Vila Jardim Red (Tejo)
review: This wine shows juicy, ripe fruit without much structure. Full of red fruit, smoke tones and considerable acidity, this is a drink-now sipper.

wine: Pine Ridge 2009 Cabernet Sauvignon (Stags Leap District)
appellation: Stags Leap District, Napa, California, US
review: Tastes like sweet, spicy blackberry jam, with an overripe note of prune lurking in the background, which will limit the wine's age-­worthiness. It's fine in tannins and acids, with plenty of elegance, but it seems too sweet for true classic Stags Leap character.

The “vineyard of five oaks” yielded a rich, dark, earthy wine in '96, with sweet notes of molasses, brown sugar and soy sauce. Full-bodied and low in acidity, with plenty of tannin to lose, the question is whether the tannins will ever soften enough to come into balance.

On the nose, there's caramel, wheat and pine aromas; fruit on the palate is juicy and fat, and doesn't pick up oak flavors until the finish. A very good, tasty wine, though straightforward. 1,500 cases produced.
Full of berry fruits, this wine blends Touriga Nacional, Alfrocheiro and Merlot. It is ripe, juicy, perfumed and has good balance between acidity and fruitiness. Drink now.

appellation: Luján de Cuyo, Mendoza Province, Argentina
review: Rusty in color, this is gritty, murky and stewy on the nose. Stewy, mulchy, sweet berry flavors finish bitter and leafy.

wine: Grassini 2017 Reserve Sauvignon Blanc (Happy Canyon of Santa Barbara)
appellation: Happy Canyon of Santa Barbara, Central Coast, California, US
review: Mineral-flecked aromas of wet stone and fresh cement kick off the nose of this bottling, which then leads into exotic citrus, lime-blossom and white-flower touches. There is a great grip to the sip right away, and then more rounded flavors of apple and Key lime pie emerge, yet that stony quality never wavers.

Aromas of blackberry, leather and graphite lead to a palate that is driven by plum, tarragon and chai-spice flavors. This full-bodied wine offers parching tannins and racy acidity. The finish is long and dry, filled with sweet oak spices.

wine: La Rochelle 2005 Paraiso Vineyard Pinot Noir (Santa Lucia Highlands)
appellation: Santa Lucia Highlands, Central Coast, California, US
review: The vineyard has been a consistent source of good to great Pinot Noirs for Paraiso winery. Now La Rochelle dips into it, with successful results. It's a dry, elegantly silky but complex wine, with an array of cherry, raspberry, rose flower, cinnamon spice and smoky vanilla flavors, heightened with crisp acidity. Drink now.

wine: Henriet-Bazin NV Hypolite Premier Cru Fût de Chêne Brut Chardonnay (Champagne)
designation: Hypolite Premier Cru Fût de Chêne Brut
review: Local forests on the Montagne de Reims provided the wood for aging this Champagne. The Chardonnay is rich as much as textured with fine maturity and ripe apple flavors that have been broadened by the toastiness. This is a great wine, textured and now mature.

wine: Uptick Vineyards 2014 Hilda's Rosé (Russian River Valley)
appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: Made from a 50-50 split of Pinot Noir and Syrah, this pinkish wine is medium bodied and intensely electric in acidity, a taste of wild strawberry and waxy apple at its core. Lemony, it remains dry on the palate throughout, with some girth on the finish.

wine: Renwood 2015 Indian Creek Vineyard Zinfandel (Amador County)
appellation: Amador County, Sierra Foothills, California, US
review: Big and bold, this wine gives most people what they want in a Zinfandel—mouth-filling, luscious, palate-drenching berry flavors and good structure, too. Firm tannins and supportive fruit acidity keep the fruit notes from being cloying and help the wine linger nicely on the finish.

Interestingly, Sidewood's 2008 Reserve Shiraz comes in considerably lower in alcohol than the regular bottling. It features a complex interplay of herb, spice and olive that gives it a stylistic resemblance resemblance to northern Rhône Syrahs. The tannins are silky, the finish long and balanced. Drink now–2018.

Rich and full bodied, this is delicious to drink now for its array of blackberries, currants, dark chocolate and toast flavors. The tannins are just a bit jagged, so give it a few hours in the decanter.

With two years of barrel and bottle aging, this wine is maturing attractively. The tannins remain firm, but the taste is broad, rich, a fine combination of solid black plums and wood spice, with a tight edge of acidity. Big, with bold brush strokes of flavor, but worth aging another two years.
This is an intense, rich wine with solid tannins and firm black fruit. Its plum and blackberry flavors are sustained by a structure that promises some medium-term aging. Drink from late 2018.

wine: Banrock Station 2006 Cabernet Sauvignon (South Eastern Australia)
appellation: South Eastern Australia, Australia Other, Australia
review: A bit chunky and lacking in elegance, but offers an assertive mouthful of cassis and vanilla flavors that would capably partner weeknight steaks or burgers. Imported by Pacific Wine Partners.

Aromas of peach and pineapple give way to tropical fruit flavors with just a trace of passion fruit. A bit fat and soft on the palate, then picks up a slightly bitter note on the finish. Imported by Select Fine Wine.

wine: Cloninger 2000 Estate Grown Chardonnay (Santa Lucia Highlands)
appellation: Santa Lucia Highlands, Central Coast, California, US
review: Here's a good, rich Chardonnay, distinctive for its ripe array of tropical fruits, pears, peaches and oriental spices. It feels crisp and clean in the mouth, and finishes rich and spicy.

If you catch this wine soon, meaning before it goes belly up, you may like its peachy simplicity and ample palate weight. Lychee, melon and spiced-meat flavors are interesting up to a point, and the finish is generic, soft and clean. Drink immediately.

wine: Bisceglia 2006 Terra di Vulcano  (Aglianico del Vulture)
appellation: Aglianico del Vulture, Southern Italy, Italy
review: Terra di Vulcano is a base line of wine from Bisceglia. The Agliancio del Vulture offers aromas of raspberry, strawberry, Indian spice and although the wine is big on ripe fruit flavors, it doesn't taste jammy or cooked.

wine: Odette 2012 Estate Cabernet Sauvignon (Stags Leap District)
appellation: Stags Leap District, Napa, California, US
review: Chocolate-cherry and mocha fill the air and palate in this densely delicious inaugural offering from a new estate, set in the heart of the appellation. At this sister property of the PlumpJack and Cade wineries, with the same owners, there's no skimping on quality. The wine is medium in weight and lengthy, subtle in oak and integrated tannin, with a lovely finish.
86-88 Barrel sample. A modern style of wine, blackly fruity and polished with spice and herbs, while surprisingly advanced with rich tobacco and chocolate flavors.

appellation: North Coast, North Coast, California, US
review: Vanilla aromas and sweet butter and baked apple flavors make this medium-bodied wine appealing and easy to enjoy. The acidity is very light, and the texture soft.

wine: Markus Molitor 2012 Ürziger Würzgarten Spätlese Riesling (Mosel)
review: Dramatically ripe, this delicately framed spätlese is a showcase of pristine, sunny peach and Meyer lemon flavors accented by caramel and crystallized honey. It's nuanced as well, darting with acidity and touches of sea salt and slate that persist.

wine: Flora Springs 1999 Rutherford Hillside Reserve Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
review: Ripe and fruity, with intense and penetrating black-currant flavors and a spicing from toasty oak. Quite dry, and a bit acidic, leading to a tart finish. A bit austere now, sort of a Johnny-one-note, but could gain in complexity down the road. —S.H.

A much-loved, easy-drinking wine from near the Italian capital, Fontana Candida is one of Rome's most popular dinner companions. The wine is fresh and easy with simple aromas of stone fruit, citrus and a lean mouthfeel.

appellation: Red Mountain, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Aromas of coffee, cocoa and dried herbs lead to reserved fruit flavors. It's straight down the fairway.

This wood-aged wine, made from the local Bical grape, is reminiscent of an Australian Sémillon, packed with oily, citrus fruit, with toast and rich flavors. Who says Portugal can't produce white wines which are ageworthy?

This opens with gritty aromas of mineral, char, mushroom, leather and berry fruits. It feels cutting and juicy, but it has the body to handle it. The flavors of berry and cherry are bright and tight, while chocolate and earthy notes reside in the background. Toasty, dark and tough on the finish, drink this Syrah-Cariginan blend now through 2014.

appellation: Central Coast, Central Coast, California, US
review: There's lots of zesty acidity in this ripe, forward Chardonnay. It features fruity flavors of oranges and apricots, with a touch of oak that lends a buttered toast note.
This opens with aromas of black plum, roasted coffee bean and a whiff of toasted oak. The chewy palate offers prune, espresso and star anise alongside tightly knit tannins. Drink 2021–2025.

Earthy, savory aromas subside to reveal fresh lemon and lime on this elegant, steely wine. Off-dry in style, it balances ripe pear and apple flavors with a sturdy backbone of acidity. Finishes moderately long.

Has good acidity and lovely tannins, which are soft and plush in the mouth, with good acidity. Feels great, but loses a few points because of green, unripe flavors that ride side by side with riper blackberry ones. That sharpness really kicks in on the finish. —S.H.

appellation: Calaveras County, Sierra Foothills, California, US
review: Nice Zin, balanced and dry, with an easy, sillky mouth feel. Shows upfront spice, berry, cherry and coffee flavors. Notable for its harmony.

wine: Canalicchio di Sopra 2010 Riserva  (Brunello di Montalcino)
review: Underbrush, truffle, pressed violet, tilled soil, eucalyptus and mature berry aromas unfold on this structured, elegant red. It is still young and primary, offering red cherry, black raspberry, menthol, licorice and dried herb alongside youthfully austere tannins that need to unwind. This will benefit from another decade of cellaring.

Slightly muddied lemon and pear notes on the nose lead to a fresh easy light palate. They are joined by that characteristic whiff of white pepper and a savory edge of sage. The finish is totally refreshing.
This wine also contains small percentages of Petite Sirah and Grenache to good effect, providing a soft and approachable entry of well-balanced black fruit and leather.

wine: Di Costanzo 2017 Montecillo Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Moon Mountain District Sonoma County)
appellation: Moon Mountain District Sonoma County, Sonoma, California, US
review: A new offering from the producer, from the famous high-elevation site above the Sonoma Valley, this wine is robust in red fruit, cassis and earthy on the nose. Seamless in youthful tannin and dusty crushed rock-like minerality, it is an outstanding debut from a tough but tremendously rewarding vintage when in the right hands. This will do well with more time in the bottle; enjoy best from 2022–2027.

wine: D'Arenberg 2015 The Ironstone Pressings G-S-M (McLaren Vale)
review: When compared to the 2014, this vintage feels primary and even a little simple. Chances are it just needs a few more years in bottle, but for now this almost 50-50 blend of Grenache and Shiraz (with 5% Mourvèdre) oozes plums, raspberry, cola, ground pepper and warm earthy mineral characters, the Shiraz more prominent than the previous vintage. The palate is full figured, balancing plump fruit with spicy oak and chalky drying tannins that add that signature d'Arenberg texture. Drink 2021–2031.
From a fine vintage for sweet wines in Bordeaux, this is fruity and ready to drink. Good acidity is the key here, balancing the apricot and bitter orange sweetness. Drink now.

wine: Château Moulin de Clotte 2009  Castillon Côtes de Bordeaux
appellation: Castillon Côtes de Bordeaux, Bordeaux, France
review: Soft, warm and smoky wine, this has a finely layered wood flavor to go with the black currant and red berry fruits. It's dry, yet warm and ripe, finishing with freshness.
A half dozen unrelated red grapes are tossed into the mix here, making a serviceable blend with no distinctive flavor or focus. It's a stewpot red, fine for everyday enjoyment.

wine: Alexander the Grape 2011 The Conqueror Klipsun Vineyards Red (Red Mountain)
appellation: Red Mountain, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: This blend of Merlot, Cabernet Sauvignon and Syrah brings aromas of Mounds Bar, spice and cherry. The flavors are tightly wound, showing a mixture of fruit and barrel with a persistent finish. The oak rides heavy but there are good things going on.

wine: Mumm Cuvée Napa NV Cuvee M  (Napa Valley)
review: A tiny bit sweet, with lemon and peach flavors and a bit of a rough scour of acidity. Yet the creamy texture and clean yeasty finish make it a good sip of bubbly.

Tasted in late summer of 2009, this Cab tasted fresh out of the barrel, with jammy cherry, black raspberry, blackberry and plum flavors, generously accented with smoky oak. Delicious now, but with the inherent balance to age for six years or so.

This stylish and distinctive wine starts with aromas of lemon blossom and slate, followed by flavors of exotic white fruits and citrus. A crisp mineral backbone gives the wine focus and flair. A delicious white at an affordable price.

wine: Fess Parker 2007 Ashley's Pinot Noir (Sta. Rita Hills)
appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
review: Tasted in March, 2009, this Pinot was dark, rich and tannic. Clearly too young to really show its best now. But it's an ager. Give it three or four years to let all the parts come together, when the cherries, blackberries, spices and oak should begin to become silky and sweet. Will improve through 2015.

wine: Albert Bichot 2003 Domaine du Clos Frantin  (Clos de Vougeot)
review: This fine wine combines the new wood and modern fruit style of Bichot with the classic power of Clos de Vougeot. Toast and black fruits combine to make a wine which will develop slowly, giving ripe and powerful flavors along the way.

Ripe, floral aromas of blackberry and minerals filter into a grapy, grabby palate. Flavors of iodine, licorice, black plum and cassis finish salty and leathery tasting, with a firm tannic grip and rubbery notes. This is short on refinement but generous in terms of body and fruit content.

This is mostly Syrah, with small amounts of Cinsault, Mourvèdre and Grenache included. The Snake River Valley AVA crosses from Idaho into eastern Oregon; these are Idaho grapes as far as can be ascertained. The wine is tannic and well-made, with deeply-flavored, meaty fruit character. Wild berries and plums are suggested, with much darker streaks of coffee, licorice, smoke and earth. The alcohol (almost 15%) shows through in some residual heat.

wine: Domaine de la Sauveuse 2009 Cuvée Carolle Rosé (Côtes de Provence)
review: Fresh strawberry and caramel aromas start the wine well, but the palate has a bitter edge of almonds, lifed by some juicy acidity and a light apple skin aftertaste.
Aromas of tropical fruit, yellow flower and a hint of nut lead the nose. On the informal palate, brisk acidity brightens banana, white peach and pear.

Pressed rose petal, truffle, crushed mint and cocoa shape the nose along with a whiff of camphor. The vibrant, chiseled palate features strawberry, sour cherry and licorice framed in taut fine-grained tannins and vibrant acidity. It closes on a note of exotic incense. Drink 2024–2034.

Prune, leather, oak and balsamic aromas lead the nose of this wine. The palate shows oak, vanilla, coconut and fig flavors alongside close-grained tannins. The fruit is already starting to dry out so drink soon.

Here's a Bordeaux blend that aims high and largely succeeds. It's soft and intricate despite the thick tannins, with a mouthfeel like wool. Turns flavorful in blackberries and black currants, with more feminine hints of violets and lavender, then shuts down again on a tannic finish. Better after 2012.

A solid effort, dry, tannic and rich in fruit. It's succulent in blackberries, black currants, crême de cassis, dark chocolate and plums, with an overlay of toasty oak. It shows the modern, fruit-forward Napa style.
Furry berry, cotton candy and herbal aromas are less than fresh. This Malbec is clampy, narrow and highly acidic. Minty flavors of plum skins are raw and a bit green, as is an edgy finish.

wine: Spann Vineyards NV Betsy's Backacher Red (Russian River Valley)
appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: Simple, sweet and sour, with apricot and orange marmalade flavors. A blend of Merlot, Carignan, Syrah, Cab and Petite Sirah.

Martummè is an austere Taurasi-style Aglianico (from the Sannio region, however) that places emphasis on richness, elegance and sophistication. Deep and penetrating in the mouth, it delivers a long succession of spice, leather, tobacco and black fruit aromas. Very nice.

wine: Chateau Lafayette Reneau 2013 Semi-Dry Riesling (Finger Lakes)
appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
review: Ripe, pristine pineapple, mango and honeydew burst from this luscious semi-dry Riesling. It's juicy and lush, boasting a tropical fruit flavor, but also structured and sprightly, with a surprising mineral finish.

This vintage of Cigale's GSM showcases more Grenache (63%) than in the past, which perhaps accounts for its slightly one-dimensional cherry fruitiness. Very supple, verging on syrupy in texture, it also shows a bit of warmth on the finish. Drink now–2012.

Hints of sultana and cooked quince reach the nose suggesting richness. The palate, however, responds with streamlined freshness, ripe fruit and depth and gives us concentration rather than richness. Tangy citrus zest frames notions of ripe apple and quince while shadows of dried fruit still haunt aromatically. The finish is clean, totally satisfying and dry. This is soaring but hearty stuff.

wine: Buty 2015 Conner Lee Vineyard Chardonnay (Columbia Valley (WA))
appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: This wine is a bit reductive out of the gate, opening to reveal aromas of pear, peach, melon, lees and spice. The palate is creamy and textured in feel. If the aromas come together, it could move up a notch.

Dried rose petals, black cherries, cedar and a sense of darkness pervade the nose on this wine from a relatively unknown appellation about 25 miles from the Monterey Bay. Flavors of minty chocolate, plums and cherry blossoms show on the lithe palate.
This medium-bodied wine is good in quality and serviceable for casual occasions. It shows earthy herbal aromas and sour cherry and rhubarb flavors.
This is soft and simple, with mild cherry, spice and cedar flavors. It's not very rich, but it's nice and dry.
Aromas of smoke, scorched earth and toasted hazelnut lead the nose. The aromas carry on to the rather lean palate along with sour cherry, lively acidity and dusty, drying tannins.

95–97. Barrel sample. Promoted to Saint-Emilion's elite Premier Grand Cru Classé category, Valandraud's 2012 shows both a mineral character and intense acidity to go with the smooth and beautiful black currant fruits. Power and elegance.

Plummy and brooding in dark cherry, this wine offers substantial up-front tannin and oak that mellows in the glass while presenting rich concentration. High-toned background acidity and jolts of baking spice counter the richer aspects well.

This is a big, powerhouse Cabernet that should develop bottle complexity over time. Right now, it's very dry and tannic, and the blackberry and black currant flavors are unintegrated with the oak. Better after 2010.

An initial hint of crushed ivy and citrus leaf peeks through on the nose. The palate then shows green-tinged ripeness, as if a juicy Mirabelle were spritzed with lime. All is bedded on a light-footed yet profound palate. It offers a gorgeous combination of smoothness and freshness. Drink by 2040.

wine: Quintas de Melgaço 2015 Torre de Menagem Escolha White (Vinho Verde)
review: This is a blend of Alvarinho and Trajadura, a lively, fruity wine that has just a hint of a prickle on the tongue. It has apple and grapefruit flavors that are fresh and deliciously crisp. The wine is ready to drink.

With grapefruit and orange aromas, this is on the ripe side, but the feel is fresh and flavors of citrus, white pepper, arugula and briny melon get the job done. Drink this quaffer soon and it will satisfy; hold it too long and it will lose its fresh character.

wine: IL Gioiello 2005 Estate Petite Sirah (Amador County)
appellation: Amador County, Sierra Foothills, California, US
review: A nice example of Petite Sirah from up in the Sierra Foothills. The wine is full-bodied and tannic, with briary, brambly flavors of sweet black cherries, chocolate, thyme, pepper and charcoal. Immature and jammy now, and should develop slowly over the next decade.

There is dense, ripe fruit here, although with an austere, serious edge. The wine has firm yet juicy blackberry fruits along with concentrated tannins. It is firm, dark, with the potential for good red berry fruits.

wine: N. Kendall Wines 2013 Pinot Noir (Finger Lakes)
appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
review: While ethereal in structure, there's a seductively penetrating appeal to this light-footed Pinot Noir. Initially pronounced notes of smoke, dried herb and cedar fade into a dusty rose and cherry perfume. Blossom and sage aromas extend into the palate, lending a sultry flair to brisk Maraschino cherry and raspberry flavors. The finish extends on a pleasant bite of bitter almond.

wine: F X Pichler 2006 Smaragd Sauvignon Blanc (Wachau)
review: The vines, rare in the Wachau, were planted because the family liked to drink Sauvignon Blanc, a simple explanation for a wine that is fresh, green and balanced between herbaceousness and tropical fruit flavors.
Pretty rustic, with sweet-and-sour cherry-candy flavors and a sharp, acidic mouth-feel. But with the right meats and cheeses, it will do fine.

wine: La Casa Dell'Orco 2010  Greco di Tufo
appellation: Greco di Tufo, Southern Italy, Italy
review: This is a rich, creamy Greco di Tufo that would pair with green olive tapenade or tomato bruschetta. Aromas of crushed white stone, melon and pear drive the fresh finish.

This warm-vintage blend of 90% Tinta de Toro and 10% Garnacha is superripe, such that it smells raisiny, with notes of licorice and pastry thrown in. A heavy, sticky, tannic palate feeds raisin, prune and chocolate flavors, while the finish is flat in texture and raisiny in flavor. Drink now.

Aromas of lychee fruit, pineapple, nectarine and baby powder are fairly typical and welcoming. The palate offers bright but somewhat nondescript flavors that ultimately tilt toward melon. The finish hangs in there, showing moderate grace and length. All in all this is decent Torrontes from La Rioja, a province to the north of Mendoza.

wine: Abadía de Acón 2010 Crianza  (Ribera del Duero)
appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
review: Aromas of tree bark, cherry and cassis are rooty. This feels ripe, dense and generally well balanced. Rich flavors of coffee, dark chocolate, blackberry and black tea finish with creamy oak notes, herbal overtones and tobacco flavors. Drink through 2022.
A clumsy wine that aims for white Bordeaux in style and falls far short. There's plenty of oak and lees, but the underlying wine is thin and disappointing in citrus flavor.

appellation: El Dorado, Sierra Foothills, California, US
review: A peppery, herbaceous aroma and savory spicy flavors make this full-bodied wine, grown at high elevation, a bit edgy but full of personality. The flavors, at first, resemble grilled fruit and beef juices, then ripe black plums flow in, complementing a texture that is firm and moderately tannic.

wine: Birichino 2020 Petulant Naturel Malvasia Bianca Sparkling (Monterey)
review: From 31-year-old vines, this bubbly is all kinds of wild, starting with a very cloudy appearance then leading into aromas of grapefruit soda, apple sauce and banana. That unique combination shows strongly on the palate as well, where tropical hints of mango and makrut lime add to the attention-grabbing format.

This strengthens the argument that there's a place for different kinds of white wines to be made in the Napa Valley, emphasizing fruit freshness and acidity without sacrificing flavor or soul. Juicy apricot and green apple ride a wave of unoaked refreshment and refinement, all within a crisp framework of deliciousness. Lavender and honeysuckle seduce quietly.
Like a home-baked apple pie without the sweetness, this light-bodied wine smells of sliced apples, nutmeg and cinnamon and tastes fruity and lightly spicy. The texture is very smooth and gentle, too.

An interesting nose of fruit and something a little wild; animal and funky. Not for everybody, and perhaps the funkiness was a little over the top, but an enjoyable wine for those who enjoy old-fashioned Dolcettos.
This light, tank-aged wine goes for the fruit. Red-currant flavors give freshness to the soft tannins. The acidity and smoky edge add to the attraction. Drink now.

Golden in color and heavy on the apricot and peach aromas, this seems just past its prime. Citrusy acidity keeps the palate jumpy, while apple and spiced pear flavors lose steam on the unsculpted finish.

wine: Desert Wind 2006 Desert Wind Vineyard Sémillon (Wahluke Slope)
appellation: Wahluke Slope, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Given a moderate 10 weeks of aging time in American oak barrels, this lightweight Sémillon acquires a bit more impact than the winery's Bare Naked (all-stainless) bottling. The fruit is still thin and generic, but the barrel time adds some much-needed heft to the finish, and takes the edge off the phenolics.

Quite good and honest, with full raspberry, cherry and tea aromas along with a hint of grassiness. The palate is dark and full-bodied, with toasty cherry and herbal tea flavors. Finishes long, full and several steps ahead of most of the competition. Drink now.

A rich, mouthcoating, viscous style, with 24% Sémillon blended in and kept on the lees for nine months prior to bottling. Honeyed stone fruits (plum and peach) and its round, supple nature make it easy to drink.

Aromas of leather, camphor and underbrush follow over to the palate together with notes of salted game and dried cherry. Firm acidity and tight close-grained tannins leave an austere, rather astringent finish.

wine: Testarossa 2013 Sanford & Benedict Vineyard Pinot Noir (Sta. Rita Hills)
appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
review: From a historic vineyard planted in 1971, this bottling show savory and dark notes of strawberry, raspberry, licorice, slate, sage and a touch of oak smoke. The palate boasts earthy structure and vibrant acidity, with flavors of slightly bitter cherry fruit, beet juice and bay leaf.

wine: Glenora 2014 Oak Free Cabernet Franc (Finger Lakes)
appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
review: Fermentation and maturation without oak casts a spotlight onto this unadorned Cabernet Franc. Sweet-tart black cherry and berry notes on the nose and palate are accented by streaks of green leaf and violet. It's not a deeply concentrated wine but refreshing, fringed by fine soft tannins and a touch of granite minerality on the finish.

On the nose and the palate of this black beauty, dried spice and mulchy-cedar flavors envelope a caramel-cherry backbone. Has decent balance, and finishes with dry wood, minerals, hot spices and plenty of black pepper.

wine: Panther Creek 2000 Arcus Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)
appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: A sniff reveals smoked meats, bacon, coffee and leather. The flavors are clean and pure—there's an abundance of inky black cherry and plum. The balance between juicy flavorful fruit and firm mouthcoating tannins is just right. Muscular but not overbuilt.
Sweet and insipid, with a heavy, gluey texture and flavors of stewed tree fruits.

Mocha, coffee and other oak-based aromas are front and center on the nose. The palate is quite sweet and rich, with cola and dark fruit flavors. Generally speaking this wine has the right qualifications to make a positive impression; it is, however, oaky and on the stewy side. Imported by Kysela Pere et Fils, Ltd.

This 100% Tuscan Cabernet has struggled for ripeness in the past couple of vintages, and the 1998 is fairly green at the core. Beyond that it has a nice feel and racy tannins. But the murky, somewhat underripe flavor profile is a hurdle that it just can't clear. This type of wine makes one wonder about Cabernet's performance in central Tuscany. —M.S.

Smooth and savory, this polished red has an enticing nose showing black-skinned berry, wild mint, blue flower and culinary spice. The juicy palate delivers ripe Marasca cherry, red currant, star anise and white pepper set against taut, refined tannins. Enjoy through 2025.

Liversan makes a serious style of wine from its 125-acre vineyard, situated in the north of the Haut-Médoc. Dense, this is balanced between the black plum fruits and dry tannins. It's a wine for long-term aging, so drink from 2018.
Menthol and thyme are restrained on the nose, with tart red cherry arising on the light-bodied palate. The delicate tannins show a polished nature, with the acidity driving everything along.

wine: Bryn Mawr Vineyards 2019 Rosé of Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)
appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: Picked early and barrel fermented, this is a bright and fresh rosé with a tasty fruit mix of watermelon, strawberry and raspberry. It doesn't move much past that, but most rosés are not expected to delivers depth and complexity. Fresh fruit is the goal here, and quite successfully met.

Made from young vines, this is the second wine of Suduiraut. It has young, honeyed character, with a ripe, opulent texture that lays bitter orange fruits over drier noble rot flavors. It is so delicious now, but will be better from 2017.

wine: Mount Fishtail 2014 Single Vineyard Sauvignon Blanc (Marlborough)
review: This is on the more herbal side of the Sauvignon Blanc spectrum, showing obvious notes of tomato leaf and boxwood, but there's ample white grapefruit to back up those green elements. This medium-bodied wine finishes long and crisp.

Smoky, rich and dramatic. Opens with peppery, new oaky aromas leading to deep, lush flavors of ripe blackberries, blueberries and chocolate. Almost perilously sweet, but saved by a tannic finish. Drink now and for a few years.

wine: Left Coast Cellars 2014 Suzanne's Estate Reserve Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)
appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: A chocolaty frame wraps around the tightly wound cherry-fruit core. There are delicious seams of coffee, vanilla and caramel, along with notes of tea and tobacco. It's fully accessible and intriguingly complex.

A dark and richly dense wine, this is packed with black fruit notes and concentrated tannins. Aged in French and American oak, it has a strongly spicy character, with bright acid and a solid tannic structure. Drink after 2015.

wine: Sable Ridge 1999 Hensley-Lauchland Vineyard Old Vine Zinfandel (Lodi)
review: Opens with the prettiest wildberry and brambly, peppery aromas, and gorgeous, sumptuously fruity flavors.  It's round and supple, with some nice weight; a sheer joy to drink.  Of course, it's soft, but that's warm country old-vine Zin for you.

wine: Billsboro 2019 Sawmill Creek Vineyards Albariño (Finger Lakes)
appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
review: Lemon and peach aromas are covered in a savory blanket of yeast on the nose. The palate is streamlined in feel, driven by racy acidity that leads to a lingering lemon-juice tone.

wine: Domaine Jean-Luc Mader 2012 Rosacker Grand Cru Riesling (Alsace)
review: The chalk soil of the Rosacker vineyard has produced a rich, intensely fruity wine that is shot through with steely minerality and a wonderful perfumed character. It's so crisp and fresh while also being densely textured and complex. The wine has a long future, drink from 2017.

wine: Claar 2018 Estate Grown & Bottled White Bluffs Merlot (Columbia Valley (WA))
appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: The aromas offer notes of black currant and dried herbs. The fruit flavors are plush in feel with the concentration dialed back a bit. Orange peel flavors linger on the finish.

wine: Harvest Moon 2005 Estate Dry Gewürztraminer (Russian River Valley)
appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: Spicy and fruity and, as the label says, dry. It shows crisp acids and a bright, delicately clean mouthfeel. Kind of like a Sauvignon Blanc except for the exotic tropical fruit and Asian spice flavors.
Earthy in character, this is a rustic wine. It does have attractive red fruits, and balancing acidity but these elements come up against a barnyard character and firm tannins.
Tropical aromas revolve around lemon-lime. This is acidic without much body. Flavors of lemon, melon, mango and green apple are lean and finish with tangy, pithy citrus flavors.

wine: Tenute Orestiadi 2016 Molino a Vento Rosato (Terre Siciliane)
review: Fruity and fresh, this has aromas of red berry and pomegranate. The scents flow through to the easygoing palate along with raspberry and bright acidity.

wine: Casa de Vila Verde 2015 Tiroliro White (Vinho Verde)
review: The wine is off dry, fruity and refreshing. It has lively citrus acidity as well as sliced apple crispness. The wine has the lightest prickle on the tongue, leaving a bright aftertaste. Drink now.

Initially wood dominates, but this is a stage after bottling. Because then the ripe, smooth fruit comes in, pouring through with black fruits, very ripe and juicy. As this wine develops, this rich fruit will be its main character.

wine: Chatter Creek 2003 Jack Jones Vineyard Syrah (Columbia Valley (WA))
appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Despite its youth it's ready to rock, with appealing varietal fruit, sparked by a nose that says this is what Syrah should be, very pretty and forward. It's a bright and snappy wine, spiced up with plenty of pepper.

wine: Lowden Hills 2003 Win Chester Merlot (Walla Walla Valley (WA))
appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: This is the estate vineyard, located in the flat, dry western end of the Walla Walla Valley. It's 95% Merlot with a splash of Syrah and Cab Franc, and it is dark, tannic and straightforward. What's missing is the extra detail and complexity that would add interest to the roasty-toasty tannins.

wine: Chehalem 2012 Ridegcrest Vineyards Wind Ridge Block Riesling (Ribbon Ridge)
appellation: Ribbon Ridge, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: This block selection shows a delicate, elegant touch in this vintage, opening with pretty floral accents and continuing with light but compelling flavors of citrus and honeysuckle. There is a well-tuned bitter streak, presumably from some skin contact, and a refreshing minerality throughout.

Reduction still dominates the nose of this wine with its sulfide haze. The palate is brighter and shows some gentle red fruit on a light, slightly dilute palate. However, the reduction clings on, so this wine really should be decanted.

wine: Gérard Bertrand 2014 Gris Blanc Rosé (Pays d'Oc)
review: This pale salmon rosé is fresh and clean. It opens with bright aromas of strawberry hull, watermelon rind and citrus peel that carry through to the linear yet vibrant palate. The palate boasts excellent verve and refreshment, making this a perfect choice for warm-weather enjoyment. Drink now.
This is a blend of Trebbiano, Malvasia and Grechetto. The mildness of its fruity bouquet and the leanness of its mouthfeel suggest that it should be paired with tuna salads or steamed dumplings.

This must have been one tannic wine for Parducci to sit on it for six years. Those tannins have resolved, and the wine is soft and drinkable, but still with a firm enough backbone to stand up to the sweet blackberry and cherry flavors.

wine: The Withers Winery 2016 Claire's Vineyard Pinot Noir (Mendocino County)
appellation: Mendocino County, Mendocino County, California, US
review: This wine has a wild side, bringing out the savory smoky singed-rosemary and cooked-cherry elements of the varietal, with great balance aided by firm acidity and tannins. With its spicy aromas and layered concentrated flavors, this should improve with some age. Best after 2021.
Sweaty aromas of gym bag, nettle and grapefruit come in front of a citric, astringent palate with grapefruit-like acidity. Heavy, pithy citrus flavors finish similarly.

wine: Emilio Moro 2007 Drink & Dream D+D Red (Douro)
review: Made by a Spanish bodega with grapes from the Portuguese Douro, this is a sophisticated Douro wine that has a smooth, ripe texture underpinned with dry tannins. Now mature, it's very elegant. Drink now.

Smells full but reduced, with a foxy, candied leaning and aromas of vitamins and minerals. Feels big, bulky, grabby and thick, with baked blackberry and plum flavors. Full on the finish, with some heat.

Hints of caramelized honey and crisp nectarine collide in this delightfully sunny yet deeply mineral dry Riesling. Medium bodied and spry on its feet, it fills the palate with a crush of zesty citrus and stone fruit flavors. The finish lingers on strikes of steel and earth. An exceptional value wine with elegance.

wine: Alexander Valley Vineyards 2004 Estate Syrah (Alexander Valley)
review: Nice, easy-drinking Syrah, soft in acids and tannins and dry, with pleasant marmalade flavors of cherries, rhubarbs and blackberries, with a rich edge of peppery, nutmeg spices and vanilla-accented oak. Drink now.
This is a silky and soft Nebbiolo with bright berry aromas and simple spice nuances. There's an elegant, feminine quality to this red wine, but it also shows power and determination.

wine: Balletto 2017 Estate Grown Chardonnay (Russian River Valley)
appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: With a generosity of oak and textured viscosity, this appellation wine offers great value and quality, with rich, rewarding layers of Gravenstein apple, pear and nutmeg.

While earthen and smoky initially, this bold Viognier reveals zesty tangerine and white-floral perfume with time and aeration. It's a hefty wine that collapses in waves of peach and apricot on the palate. This classic representation of Condrieu should hold well through 2027.

wine: Cave de Ribeauvillé NV Giersberger Cacher Sparkling (Crémant d'Alsace)
review: A high-toned nose makes earthy yeast notes seem more heady than they are. The palate is frothy and almost austere, with a slightly bitter edge softened by dosage.

appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Spicy and completely dry, this fresh and fruity rosé is a pretty strawberry and salmon shade, with persistent flavors of cherry candy, lemon oil and nougat. There's a nice citrus snap to the finish.
Luscious and rich, this wine has a mineral edge that will allow it to age. Tropical fruits combine with fresh citrus to add fruitiness to the structure. Drink from 2019.

wine: Vega Moragona 2008 Viñas Viejas Tempranillo (Ribera del Júcar)
appellation: Ribera del Júcar, Central Spain, Spain
review: Creamy oak, mocha and ripe berry and plum aromas make for a sweet-smelling bouquet. In the mouth, this mature Tempranillo is lively enough, with cocoa, spice, raw oak and modest berry flavors. A creamy, slightly resiny feel defines the finish.

wine: Viña Chocalan 2018 Gran Reserva Origen Chardonnay (San Antonio)
review: Nectarine and an unusual hint of passion fruit set up an oily palate that's full in weight. Oddly tropical flavors are salty and suggest passion fruit, while this feels lively and tastes briny on the finish.

wine: Domaine Saint Gayan 2001 Red (Côtes du Rhône)
appellation: Côtes du Rhône, Rhône Valley, France
review: This is very superior Côtes-du-Rhône, since the vines are actually in Côtes-du-Rhône-Villages. But winemaker Jean-Pierre Meffre prefers to keep the name simple and the wine uncomplicated. Sweet, ripe fruit, solid tannins and red fruit flavors make this very attractive.

The wine is packed with super-ripe fruit that gives density and concentration. It is rich with dark plum flavors and integrated acidity. The alcohol does give a burning sensation on the tongue which is a shame. The aftertaste however is full of acidity and fruitiness. Drink this opulent wine from late 2016.

Combining 84% Cab with Malbec, Merlot and Syrah, this is a savory, thick and robust wine, ripe in black cherry and plum. Generous oak and tannin add weight and length, with a lurking hint of dried herb and cedar on the finish.

Earth and bacon aromas meld into darker and fuller berry notes, while the medium-bodied palate shows solid but generic strawberry and raspberry flavors. There's nothing unusual or wrong with this wine; it's ripe, moderately textured and even shows some light milk chocolate throughout.

wine: Van Zellers 2015 Rufo do Vale D. Maria Branco White (Douro)
designation: Rufo do Vale D. Maria Branco
review: Produced from high-altitude (1,800 feet) vines, this wine is ripe while also crisply fresh. Its lime and lemon flavors are balanced by the mineral texture and intense final acidity. Drink now.

wine: Moulin de la Roque 2020 Les Hauts du Vallon Rosé (Bandol)
review: A rich wine, full of ripe red berry and red currant fruits, this is full-bodied and ready to drink. With a mineral edge, the wine has a fine texture as well as a smoky, perfumed character. Drink now.

A blend of Negroamaro and 15% Malvasia Nera, this opens with aromas of dark berry and toast. The palate offers ripe blackberry, black cherry, mocha and allspice alongside firm tannins. It ends on a note of bitter almond.

wine: Goldschmidt 2006 Plus Game Ranch Single Vineyard Selection Cabernet Sauvignon (Oakville)
designation: Plus Game Ranch Single Vineyard Selection
review: The 2006 vintage was erratic, but Nick Goldschmidt has pulled a rabbit out of a hat with this fabulously complex and rewarding 100% Cabernet. It's classic Oakville, dry, tannic and elegant, and the way the blackberry and black currant flavors marry the new oak is simply wonderful. The Game Ranch Vineyard has been source to some of Goldschmidt's greatest Cabernets over the past decade. This is one of those wines that's compelling to drink now, but should evolve over the next 10–15 years.

Big, tannic and very fine. Shows the classic black currant and cedar flavors of Oakville, with an astringent mouthfeel that strongly suggests aging. Made from 100% Cab, it's beautiful now for its lush softness, and should develop for an additional six years, at least.
Citrus blossom and yellow stone fruit aromas form the nose. The crisp, straightforward palate offers yellow apple skin, saline and a note of dried apricot alongside fresh acidity.

appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: This is a creamy, voluptuous and richly layered white wine, smooth and overdelivering on its price point in appealing flavors of peach and vanilla.

appellation: Mendocino County, Mendocino County, California, US
review: Medium-bodied and well-priced for the quality, this Merlot is herbal in cassis and red cherry flavors, on the elegant side of the spectrum, and relatively low in alcohol. The tannins are firm and mellowed, the finish just fine.

wine: Freixenet NV Carta Nevada Brut Sparkling (Cava)
review: Neutral for the most part, with fresh acidity, light bubbles and basic apple and peach flavors. A little sweet and confected but perfectly good. Solid for simple sipping and mimosas.

wine: Intercoastal 2018 Estate Grown Musqué Clone Sauvignon Blanc (California)
review: This medium-bodied wine is well balanced, fresh and fruity in flavor, and should be a crowd-pleaser. It's named for a varietal clone that often shows a floral character.

There is a lightness about this vintage of Mouton Rothschild. It doesn't take away from its quality but does give the wine poise and an attractive lift. The wine is based on solid tannins, then the ripe fruit builds layers of fruitiness and freshness. It is not likely to be one of the longest-aging Moutons, but it will be delicious. Drink from 2020.

wine: Barton & Guestier 2000 French Tom Private Collection Merlot (Vin de Pays d'Oc)
appellation: Vin de Pays d'Oc, Languedoc-Roussillon, France
review: Not as rich as B&G's Cabernet, which was co-released at the same time. This wine is dark, with earthy aromas, and turns tough and tannic in the mouth, with watered down flavors.

wine: Domaine Valéry Renaudat 2018 Les Lignis Sauvignon Blanc (Reuilly)
review: Grassy and herbal, this classic Sauvignon Blanc is also fruity and fresh with lime-juice flavors. It is tangy, bright and ready to drink.
This medium-bodied wine is fruity and friendly, topping pineapple and mint flavors with hints of butter and vanilla, and wrapping them in a soft texture.

wine: Hard Row To Hoe 2009 Burning Desire Cabernet Franc (Lake Chelan)
appellation: Lake Chelan, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: A firm and focused Cabernet Franc, with just 5% Merlot in the blend, this spent 18 months in 50% new American oak. It's a straight-ahead style, with a red berry flavor and polished, proportionate tannins.

appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: A stylish wine from the French team at this winery. Green apples and herbs on the nose. Apple and almond flavors on the palate. Crisp but not sharp acidity and a long, clean finish.

wine: DFJ Vinhos 2008 Pedras do Monte Cabernet Sauvignon and Tinta Roriz (Lisboa)
review: An elegant wine, the tannins a core element in the firm structure. Acidity and black currant flavors go together with spice. It is a young wine, ready to drink, but will develop.
Aromas of apricot, citrus peel and honeydew melon lead the nose. The dense, almost syrupy palate offers yellow peach and candied orange before a short, flat finish.

The Dardis cuvée is taut and citric and shows wild berry fruit. Barreled for 10 months in 30% new French oak, it shows little impact of barrel flavors at this point in time; just the slightest hint of caramel streaking through the finish.

wine: Beauregard 2017 Oeuf en Beton Bald Mountain Vineyard Chardonnay (Ben Lomond Mountain)
designation: Oeuf en Beton Bald Mountain Vineyard
appellation: Ben Lomond Mountain, Central Coast, California, US
review: Aged in a concrete egg, this bright bottling offers aromas of kumquat, lemongrass and light almond on the nose. There is tremendous grip to the sip, where bright and brilliant flavors of crisp lime and fresh lemon blossom extract meet with grapefruit zest. Very lively and tactile.

wine: Tenuta Rocca 2014 del Comune di Serralunga d'Alba  (Barolo)
review: Aromas of dark-skinned berry, leather and underbrush form the nose. The savory palate offers black cherry, tobacco and star anise alongside firm refined tannins and bright acidity. Drink 2021–2028.

wine: Columbia Crest 2009 Two Vines Cabernet Sauvignon (Washington)
review: There is a surprising amount of fruit showing here; youthful, grapey, sweet and clean. The middle is a bit hollow, but the tannins kick back in for a smooth finish, with some charcoal and smoke filtering through.

appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Cabernet Franc often shows more stem and herb than either Merlot or Cabernet Sauvignon, but here there is little else to hang your hat on. Hard, chewy and tannic, it might best be drunk with a grilled steak, so those tough tannins are put to work.

wine: Hartley-Ostini 2010 Hitching Post Perfect Set Pinot Noir (Sta. Rita Hills)
appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
review: Some inherent imbalances, such as green notes and irregular tannins, limit this wine's ageability. But that doesn't mean you can't enjoy it now, especially with hearty barbecue and grilled beef. Dry and crisp in acidity, it has flavors of red currants, heirloom tomatoes and smoky oak.

Bigi offers a well-priced blend of Grechetto and Chardonnay that does a nice job of playing up the qualities of both grapes. The Grechetto, a native variety from central Italy, offers freshness and aromas of herbs and citrus. The Chardonnay offers body and density.

Grapes from southern Beaujolais, the land of the gold-colored stone buildings, are the main source of this wine. It's a typical, bubbly banana- and red-berry-flavored wine with a good streak of tannin and acidity. Of course, drink now.

wine: Owen Roe 2010 Ex Umbris Syrah (Columbia Valley (WA))
appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: A sweet scent of violet greets you first, along with a primary purple-fruit note. It's made in a forward, fruity style, and it offers finishing notes of anise and coffee liqueur.

wine: Emerson Brown 2012 III Michaels Estate Cabernet Sauvignon (Oakville)
review: Smoky oak and huge, dry tannins inform the personality of this full-bodied wine, a filling mix of black plum, cassis and blackberry. Sharper elements of cedar and dried herb are balanced by noteworthy drops of chocolate on the finish.

This three-generation family estate's latest release is ripe and structured, with solid tannins and rich black fruits. The edge of pepper from the alcohol does give the wine a bite and spoils the mature while still fruity wine. Drink now.
92-94 Barrel sample. Big, ripe, juicy wine, the tannins very solid and dark. It has layers of new wood, power and considerable density.

wine: Penfolds 2002 Cellar Reserve Pinot Noir (Adelaide Hills)
review: One of Penfolds' few Adelaide Hills-designated wines, and the only one available in the States at the moment. This Pinot is very good, with lifted, tangy cherry and plum fruit at the fore, and admirable intensity and length. But it's not as good as I've seen it in past vintages; this one has a pervading pickling-spice or barrel note that was a detraction for me. Imported by Southcorp Wines.

wine: Stemilt Creek NV Earthen Red (Columbia Valley (WA))
appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Cocoa, green pepper and baking spice aromas are followed by broad, seamless flavors of green pepper, cherry and a bit of smoke. Pleasing acidity enlivens it.

wine: Stags' Leap Winery 2009 Ne Cede Malis Petite Sirah (Stags Leap District)
appellation: Stags Leap District, Napa, California, US
review: This huge Petite Sirah shows such powerful blackberry, raspberry and Kahlua flavors. It's deliriously rich, so don't look for subtlety.

Charming overtones of citrus herald the freshness of the 2014 vintage, while the palate shows richer fruit: golden Mirabelle plums and baked apricot with occasional swirls of rose blossom. The dry finish beautifully accentuates the freshness and is rather moreish.
Spice and cola scents mix with smoky berry aromas. Tight and juicy in the mouth, with crisp red cherry and plum flavors and a medicinal edge. Solid and racy throughout.

This wine has a strong new-oak signature easy to detect in the vanilla and cinnamon aromas and the ginger-spice flavors that layer over good red-cherry notes underneath. It is medium to full bodied and highly stylized.

Mild aromas are clean and simple, as is the rest of this rosé of Pinot Noir. A medium-intensity palate is easygoing, with standard acidity. Generic, well-accepted rosé flavors finish clean and lightly citric.

wine: Jäger 2016 Vorder Seiber Federspiel Grüner Veltliner (Wachau)
review: Conference pear and ripe lemon scents unfurl on the nose of this wine. The palate reinforces those aromas with juiciness and ease. A zesty, refreshing edge keeps it lively and taut, feeling citrus-centered, refreshing and clean.

A bit crisper and lighter in weight than top vintages of this wine, but pleasing nevertheless, with cedar, herb and cherry flavors that merge harmoniously on the finish. Imported by W.J. Deutsch & Sons.

wine: Adega Ponte da Barca 2020 Grande Escolha White (Vinho Verde)
review: There is a light prickle on the tongue with this young, fruity wine. Fresh, off-dry and with a bright acidity, the wine has crisp grapefruit and a light spiciness. Drink now.

wine: Claudia Springs 1998 Clone 115 - Vidmar Vineyard Pinot Noir (Mendocino)
review: Tannic and firm, yet fleshy, with cherries and cherry tomatoes mixing it up. Some pleasing smoke and toast notes come from aging in oak barrels. Overall, it's elegantly styled but still on the young and tight side.

wine: Pursued by Bear 2014 Baby Bear Syrah (Columbia Valley (WA))
appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Barrel aromas are at the fore, with notes of vanilla, coconut shavings and baking spice in front of cherry. The flavors bring a sense of richness, with barrel notes speckled throughout. Coconut flavors linger on the finish. It's a very stylistic interpretation of the variety.

This full-bodied red offers aromas of new leather, rose, camphor and forest berry. Firmly structured, the tight, focused palate offers dried black cherry, orange zest, licorice and tobacco set against a backbone of assertive tannins and bright acidity. Give it time to unwind and fully develop. Drink 2026–2036.
This is a delicious, ripe wine inspired by its Sémillon and Viognier. The lemon and grapefruit acidity is contrasted with the rich white stone fruits and warmth of this region. Drink from 2018.

Earthy tobacco, smoke and spice on the nose and a fruit-forward palate make this expressive Shiraz an attractive cohort to smoked meat dishes and cheese assortments. The wine has a backbone of toasted oak and a smooth character.

wine: Tablas Creek 2015 Patelin de Tablas Rosé (Paso Robles)
appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: This is an extremely textural pink wine, with delicate touches of raspberry, strawberry, watermelon and the slightest twist of lime on the nose. The blend of 68% Grenache, 13% Counoise, 11% Mourvèdre and 8% Syrah shows grip and acidity on the sip, where lime-soaked nectarine and red apple flavors reign.

wine: L'Ecole No. 41 2013 Estate Grown Perigee Seven Hills Vineyard Red (Walla Walla Valley (WA))
designation: Estate Grown Perigee Seven Hills Vineyard
appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: This wine is half Cabernet Sauvignon with the balance Merlot, Cabernet Franc, Malbec and Petit Verdot. High-toned aromas of dried herb, barrel spice and red and black fruit are followed by well concentrated fruit flavors. The tannins show considerably more grip than is often seen from this site. Give it some time in the cellar to unwind. Best after 2021.
This wine has great fruit with soft tannins and accessible soft black currant fruitiness. A slight earthiness at the end needs to become better integrated. Drink from 2017.

wine: Hendry 2014 Hendry Vineyard Pinot Gris (Napa Valley)
review: High-toned and 100% varietal, this ephemeral Pinot Gris was aged in stainless steel and is dry and waxy on the palate. Crisp green apple and lemon flavors are complemented by a mineral underbelly that makes this a food-friendly wine.

Grgich's recent vintages of Zinfandel haven't been as good as they should be, and this one doesn't correct that impression. It's soft and more than a little sweet in cherry and blackberry flavors, with a tomato and beet edge that suggests uneven ripening.

wine: Domaine Schoffit 2007 Clos Saint-Théobald Grand Cru Rangen Sélection de Grains Nobles Larme de Lave Pinot Gris (Alsace)
designation: Clos Saint-Théobald Grand Cru Rangen Sélection de Grains Nobles Larme de Lave
review: The nose is still shy but already tells of tender sweetness. The palate has a rounded earthy smoky element that grounds the luscious generous fruit of dried pear and supersweet Reine Claude and mirabelle plums. The sweetness of this SGN is balanced and almost fresh, but the intriguing thing is a kind of smoky, dark and mysterious core of stone.

wine: Keller 2008 La Cruz Vineyard Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)
review: An elegant Pinot with a silky texture framing delicious flavors of ripe raspberries and cherries, elaborated with sweet spices and smoky sandalwood. A lovely wine to drink now.
This leads with aromas of white flower, toast and beeswax. The rather lean palate delivers yellow apple skin, citrus zest, a hint of roasted almond and a touch of vanilla alongside brisk acidity.

This wine is on the edge, complex in white pepper and cool-climate characteristics of dried herb and leather. Brawny and full-bodied, it's also bright in underlying acidity, with plenty of elusive power.

appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Fruit for this wine comes from the winery's recently planted estate vineyard in the SeVein project. Aromas of cherry and spice lead to a highly structured palate, with slightly gritty tannins. The middle seems a bit missing. Tasted twice with consistent notes.

wine: Rivera 2006 Violante Nero di Troia (Castel del Monte)
appellation: Castel del Monte, Southern Italy, Italy
review: Nero di Troia, a native grape of Southern Italy, shows its potential thanks to its aromas of berry fruit, Spanish cedar and drying minerals. The wine tastes simple and easy but manages to be elegant and penetrating nonetheless.
Heavily earthy and rubbery smelling, then big and bulky but out of whack on the palate. Tastes buttery and gummy, with generic berry fruit flavors that finish oaky.
