appellation: Lake County, Lake County, California, US
review: There are some decent fruity flavors in this wine, and it's dry and clean. But it wants more concentration on the palate.

Camphor, crushed herb, espresso and pipe tobacco aromas slowly take shape on this wine. Linear and austere, the racy palate offers cranberry, sage and a hint of roasted coffee bean alongside bracing tannins that leave an astringent finish.

wine: Louis M. Martini 2000 Monte Rosso Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Sonoma Valley)
review: Despite the difficulty of the vintage, this is a very good effort. It's bigger, fuller and more-extracted than the '99, with muscular cedar, cassis and graphite aromas and flavors. Drink 2008–2012.

Miguel Torres is aiming high with this heavyweight single-vineyard Cabernet that was bottled back in 2000. The bouquet is classy and deep, with sweet rubber, licorice and berry notes. Cassis, blackberry and chocolate compete on the palate, while the finish is much like flourless chocolate cake and a cup of espresso rolled into one. Clearly the class of the Torres Cabernets.

appellation: Lake County, Lake County, California, US
review: A perfectly simple, stainless-steel fermented Lake County SB with tangy lemon and lime notes, subtle at first. The finish falls off fast.

appellation: Monterey County, Central Coast, California, US
review: Ripe and sweet in apricot, pear, coconut macaroon, vanilla and Asian spice flavors, this Chard benefits from crisp acidity. It's not really dry, but has many interesting tastes.

wine: Gallo Signature Series 2017 Pinot Noir (Santa Lucia Highlands)
appellation: Santa Lucia Highlands, Central Coast, California, US
review: Primarily from the Gallo family's Olson Ranch, with 8% of the fruit sourced from Sleepy Hollow Vineyard, this voluptuous expression starts with inviting aromas of red cherry and vanilla that are cut by slate, soil and forest herbs. The hedonistic palate is oak-driven, offering vanilla, caramel and smoke flavors that wrap around the black cherry and cola core.

wine: Côte Bonneville 2016 Estate Bottled DuBrul Vineyard Riesling (Yakima Valley)
appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Single vineyard Rieslings are a relative rarity in the state. This one brings aromas of lime zest, citrus, white peach and apricot. It drinks off dry, leaning a bit sweeter but with well-balanced acidity along with plentiful peach and orange flavors. Apple notes persist on the finish. The sense of balance is impressive.

wine: Doña Paula 2003 Los Cardos Chardonnay (Luján de Cuyo)
appellation: Luján de Cuyo, Mendoza Province, Argentina
review: Smooth and round on the nose, with aromas of melon and honey. A bit soft but not flaccid, with a sweet, creamy flavor profile that blends apple and pear. Finishes light and clean, with a hint of vanilla.

wine: Cantine Benedetti 2008 Corte Antica  (Valpolicella Classico Superiore)
review: This Valpolicella blend opens with an aged, browning color and etched aromas of dried fruit and almond. The wine seems past its prime already.

appellation: Edna Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: Struck stone and dried and fresh lemon peels make for a pinpoint nose on the focused entry to this bottling. There is compelling grip to the sip, where wet gravel and lanolin touches meet with lemon-cream flavors.

This Aglianico opens with aromas of underbrush, black-skinned fruit and baking spice. The dense palate delivers prune, dried black cherry and vanilla, while dusty, fine-grained tannins provide the framework. Drink through 2022.

From a small Livermore Valley producer; this wine might be difficult to find. But it'll be worth the effort for the blueberries, blackberries and cassis that leap from the glass. The mouthfeel is soft and silky; the structure is tight enough for long-term storing. Should be fine until 2009.

This is a wonderful value and an attractively oaky wine with a good, grippy texture and lip-smacking fruit flavors. Full body and firm tannins give it a lot of muscle, and there's enough flavor concentration to last on the finish.

Sunny tangerine acidity highlights the rounded, slightly creamy mouthfeel of this light-bodied dry Riesling. Bright grapefruit and quince flavors are forward and fresh, offset by stony mineral tones that linger on the finish. It's a delicate yet richly balanced wine to enjoy now though 2025.

wine: Matias Wines 2014 Pinot Noir (Santa Lucia Highlands)
appellation: Santa Lucia Highlands, Central Coast, California, US
review: Dark and concentrated pomegranate and rosebud aromas meet with juniper and sweet pine needle on the nose of this bottling. The attack is a clean and flavorful, mixing dried cranberry and tangy cherry with thyme, marjoram and peppercorn, culminating in a camphor-like finish.

This aromatic young wine opens with sniffs of blackberry and cola, and follows with plush flavors of the same, along with black cherry and a dusting of coffee. The palate offers a tangle of berries, a streak of cola, and textured tannins. Give it plenty of breathing time to open up through the finish.
Here's an Aglianico from Campania with bright cherry flavors, almond nut nuances and lasting shadings of mineral and earth. It offers bright fruit in the mouth and a crisp but firm close.

wine: Bodegas Orusco 2009 Viña Main Rosado Tempranillo Rosé (Vinos de Madrid)
appellation: Vinos de Madrid, Central Spain, Spain
review: Smells lightly burnt and acrid, with stemmy berry aromas, apricot and match stick. The palate has a flat, creamy feel and stemmy, dry flavors of generic berry and bitterness. Too flat and devoid of fruit to rate higher.

appellation: Central Coast, Central Coast, California, US
review: Harsh in texture, though there's some good cherry-berry fruit. The wine feels rustic and clumsy.

This blend of Monastrell, Syrah and Garnacha Tintorera feels lively, its dark plum and berry aromas laced with chocolate. Smacking tannins create a dry sensation, framing ripe black plum and prune flavors. Complex notes of spice and tomato emerge on the firm finish.

This violet-colored wine has a bouquet of black currant and yellow bell pepper. It offers a nice balance of mellow tannins and integrated acidity, with flavors of blackberry, black cherry, pomegranate, violet and licorice that culminate on a surprisingly bright finish.

From a parcel of old vines around the quinta chapel, this is a stunning wine. It has all the opulence we expect from Vesuvio, along with a density that is rare in this vintage. The tannins are there, but are equalled by the toffee, ripe fruit, figs, sweet chocolate. The whole wine is lightened by acidity, but will obviously age.

wine: Starfield 2012 The Starbeam Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
review: Soft in classic layers of cinnamon and clove, this wine is almost entirely Cabernet Sauvignon, with a wealth of black plum and blackberry constituting its inner soul. The finish lingers in black pepper and more of that opening spice.
This is a decent-quality, medium-bodied wine that offers plum and strawberry aromas, almost-sweet fruit flavors and touches of herbs and oak.

wine: Fattoria di Grignano 2012 Poggio Gualtieri Riserva  (Chianti Rufina)
review: This blend of 90% Sangiovese and 10% Merlot boasts ripe black-skinned fruit and cedar aromas. The concentrated palate delivers smoke-laced black plum and tobacco flavors held together by firm, fine-grained tannins. Drink through 2022.

wine: Vincent Vineyards 2018 Family Reserve Malbec (Los Olivos District)
appellation: Los Olivos District, Central Coast, California, US
review: The nose on this bottling exhibits a pure streak of black currant and blackberry, with purple-flower aromas as well as black soil and rock minerality. There is a solid and chalky tannic tension on the palate, where blackberry-jam flavors are lifted by anise.

appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: The Aix is two thirds Syrah and one third Cabernet Sauvignon, scented with mint and herb, with tart red fruit. The Syrah tastes of mineral and graphite rather than earth or cured meat, and the wine remains quite hard and tightly wound.

Raspberry and plum aromas smell a bit powdery, like Kool-Aid. This feels wide, jammy, grabby and tannic, while flavors of currant, red plum and herbs end fresh and juicy, but also a bit scouring and rough. Drink through 2018.
Aromas of French oak, vanilla, toast and white orchard fruit waft out of the glass. On the elegant palate, fresh acidity lifts ripe yellow apple, peach and butterscotch before a café au lait finish.

Old vines planted in the 1950s by a neighbor named Ovide form this complex wine. Aged for eight months on lees, it is a concentrated wine, tight with acidity and with nutty flavors that add complexity and give the wine depth. This beautiful wine needs to age. Drink from 2018.

wine: Tenuta Alzatura 2001 Uno di Quattro  (Sagrantino di Montefalco)
appellation: Sagrantino di Montefalco, Central Italy, Italy
review: From the Umbrian holding of Tuscany's Cecchi family, this wine opens with charred meat, leather, earth,  beets and an interesting mineral dimension. Aged 16 months in barrique, its aggressive tannins will need a few years of cellar aging to soften up. Drink after 2007. Imported by Banfi Vintners.

Cheval des Andes brings together Cheval Blanc from St.-Emilion with Terrazas de los Andes, and for the past few years it has been the leader in Bordeaux-style wines from Argentina. The 2004 shows serious barrel notes framing classic aromas of aged gouda, saddle leather, mushroom and concentrated berries. The palate is structured, mildly tannic and layered with blackberry, cassis, raisin and licorice flavors. It's good now or will age nicely for another four to six years.

wine: Lucia 2004 Garys' Vineyard Pinot Noir (Santa Lucia Highlands)
appellation: Santa Lucia Highlands, Central Coast, California, US
review: Drinks young, crisp in acids and a little impertinent now, but with great charm; this wine is alive with vibrant cherry, mint and oak flavors that finish in a swirl of chocolate raspberry mousse. That makes it sound sweet, but it's bone dry, just enormously ripe in fruit. It's Santa Lucia Pinot in all its flamboyant glory. Drink soon.

91-93 Barrel sample. On the dry, structured side, a wine with huge fruit tannins that roll over the fruit. The concentration is palpable, all dense fruit. The berry flavors get a look-in right at the end. For long aging, as long as the tannins finally soften.

wine: Terra Andina 2002 Reserve Cabernet Sauvignon (Maipo Valley)
review: Brilliant violet in color, with a lush nose featuring meaty black fruit and plenty of smooth French oak. Flavors of cassis and blackberry are true to form and rock solid, while firm tannins and proper acidity bolster the mouthfeel. A fine, tightly wound Cab at a great price.

wine: Quinta da Lagoalva de Cima 2006 Syrah-Touriga Nacional Red (Ribatejano)
review: Perfumed wine, deliciously aromatic but also structured. This is balanced, intently tannic. The fruit is equally important, the black currant juice and refreshing acidity a counterbalance to the tannins.

wine: G. H. Mumm NV Cordon Rouge Brut  (Champagne)
review: The aromas are fresh and floral; combined with undertones of toast, they get this wine off to fast start.  The bead is fine and the mouthfeel creamy, but the solid flavors of tart citrus and green apple lack drama.

This earthy Taurasi opens with aromas of ripe black fruit, blue flower, wet soil and leather. The ripe, structured palate doles out fleshy black cherry accented by cracked black pepper and balsamic herbs. With bracing tannins, give this time to fully develop depth and complexity; drink after 2019. Oliver McCrum, Polaner.

wine: Kellerei Kaltern Caldaro 2011 Rosa Moscato (Delle Venezie)
review: Light pink in color, with sweet overtones of honey and candied peach, this would pair with poppyseed cake or apple tart. The finish is thick and opulent.

wine: Vinícola Miolo 2005 Lote 43 Cabernet Sauvignon-Merlot (Vale dos Vinhedos)
review: Taut, dense and ripe, this 50/50 blend of Cabernet Sauvignon and Merlot opens with aromas of chocolate-covered cherries and cherry cordial. The palate is dry and concentrated with medium acidity and a tannin structure that calls for a knife and fork. Give it a few years.

wine: John Anthony 2007 Church Vineyard Syrah (Napa Valley)
review: The vineyard is in the Carneros, and the grapes from this great vintage must have been just about perfect, to judge by the wine. It's beautiful, rich and delicious, yet so finely balanced. Explodes in blackberry jam, cocoa puff and leather flavors, dusted with black pepper and finished with a swirl of toasted cedar wood. Drink now.

A tropical hint of mango flashes up on the nose before russet pear and tangerine take over. The palate brings a textured element to the rounded citrus fruit, like russet pear peel, that adds backbone. Tangerine freshness pervades a juicy, ripe but very refreshing palate. The finish is dry and mouthwatering.

wine: Fattoria di Basciano 2016 I Pini Red (Colli della Toscana Centrale)
appellation: Colli della Toscana Centrale, Tuscany, Italy
review: This opens with aromas of tilled soil, cedar and a hint of dark-skinned fruit. The straightforward palate offers black-currant jam, clove and bitter almond alongside smooth tannins. Drink soon.

wine: Domaine du Cellier Aux Moines 2018 Beauregard Premier Cru  (Santenay)
review: This wine comes from a 0.6-acre parcel of one of the top Santenay vineyards. With its generous, warm character, the wine is rich, the vanilla a reminder that it was wood aged. Baked apples and a mineral texture combine in a wine that will age further. Drink from 2022.

Fragrant blue flower, plum and a whiff of mocha slowly emanate from the glass. The taut, savory palate presents Morello cherry, black raspberry, licorice and clove, while polished tannins and fresh acidity provide balance and structure. Drink through 2022.

The firm tannins of rich Malbec shine in this wine, which conveys a sense of power as well as great concentration. With its density, layers of black plum and impressive structure, this is a wine to age. Drink from 2023.

Some Russian oak was used on this wine, which is 80% Tempranillo, and it has a nose of bell pepper and dill that could stem from that. The body, however, is good as is the acidity, but the flavor profile comes up midland. From the older school and Bodegas LAN, and in essence lost in space.

wine: Vignobles Pelvillain 2016 Château de Cénac Grande Réserve  (Cahors)
review: A selection in the vineyard is the basis of this powerful wine. Rich in tannins as well as fruit, it has a dense texture, the weight and concentration showing the wine needs aging. It has a rich future; drink from 2023.

wine: Bodega Volcanes de Chile 2018 Reserva Sauvignon Blanc (Leyda Valley)
review: A light color and vegetal aromas akin to canned peas open this lean SB. Saucy, savory flavors of lime and white-wine vinegar finish short and hollow.

wine: Dante Irurtia 2000 Reserva del Virrey Tannat (Uruguay)
review: The rubber and tree bark are common for Uruguayan Tannat. Flavors of dark cherry, cola and coffee are the best part of yet another tough, rugged power pack that's neither plush nor all that pleasant to drink. Hard as heck in the mouth; rough stuff on the whole.

Quite possibly this has the largest production of any single Oregon Pinot Noir, which makes the quality even more impressive. A bit in the vein of a Beaujolais, this offers Gamay-like flavors of red berry and wild cherry. It's broadly fruity and forward on the palate, with zippy acidity that punches through the finish.

wine: Chanson Père et Fils 2013 Clos de Marconnets Premier Cru  (Beaune)
review: Ripe, jammy fruitiness gives this wine a generous feel. Packed with opulent berry flavor, it will develop well. It is rich and rounded, nicely supported by the tannins that are in the background. Drink from 2019.

From an eight-acre vineyard, this is produced by the same team as Château Paloumey. Powerful and concentrated, it is also elegant, balancing its structure with good berry fruits and acidity. The tannins are still considerable, so drink from 2017.

Chewy tannin and oak with a smoky toasty component lead the way to a robust and softly rich wine that includes 21% Syrah, the whole aged in French, Eastern European and American oak. Straightforward and savory, it finishes in earthy black currant.

wine: Grgich Hills 2017 Estate Grown Chardonnay (Napa Valley)
review: Nutty, floral and earthy, this white has a crisp entry of wet stone and earthy white flower. Exotic and well integrated, it shows a lovely mix of pear, mango and peach that finds vibrancy through a backbone of balanced acidity.

appellation: Santa Ynez Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: Good and dry, with very soft, refined tannins and complex flavors. Suffers a bit from arch acidity, but a nice steak should balance it. The delicious flavors include blackberry and cherry jam, licorice, charred meat and a hefty dose of freshly crushed black pepper.

appellation: Columbia Gorge (WA), Washington Other, Washington, US
review: The winery's first release of this variety offers aromas of apple, chamomile, spice and lees. On the palate, the green-apple acids are tart and bracing, needing some food to tame them.

wine: Ryan Patrick 2001 Rock Island Red Red (Columbia Valley (WA))
appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: A blend of 56% Merlot, 42% Cabernet Sauvignon and 2% Cab Franc, nicely crafted and eminently quaffable. Light spice, hints of pepper and herb, and very pretty fruit tell the story.

wine: Montemar Wines 2012 Watch Hill Vineyard EBA Syrah (Santa Barbara County)
appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
review: Fresh aromas of dark violets, sweet lavender, elderberry and a light teriyaki glaze show on the nose of this extra barrel-aged bottling. It's medium bodied on the palate, where dark fruits meet with elderflower and more purple flowers. It's still a bit reserved.
86–88. Barrel Sample. This is green and herbal in character, with an overwhelming acidic intensity. The background brings out dry tannins and a high level of wood spice.

wine: Paradise Ridge 2002 Rockpile Vineyard Merlot (Sonoma County)
review: I have not been a great fan of this winery's Bordeaux reds, and this one also has a countrified thing going on, despite some very ripe and lip-smacking cherry flavors. Half the oak barrels it was aged in were new.
A new brand from Campolargo, this is firmly tannic, and it shows off the Baga grape. It needs several years of aging.

wine: Whitcraft 2017 Pence Ranch Chardonnay (Sta. Rita Hills)
appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
review: Lemon preserves on toast, wet stone and early spring flowers show on the nose of this bottling. There is a toasty quality to the sip, which is clean and linear in structure, without anything flashy.

The merest touch of peach and Golden Delicious apple plays on the nose. The palate features lively lemon notes on a very slender, brisk and fresh palate, along with a tiny bit of spritz. It shows a depth of fruit: a wine for lovers of subtlety. The crisp apple-peel finish is totally moreish.

wine: On Point 2014 Christina's Cuvée Pinot Noir (North Coast)
appellation: North Coast, North Coast, California, US
review: Full bodied and definitely fruity without being sweet, this wine from Fulcrum comes straight at the taste buds with opulent black cherry and tart raspberry flavors on a vivid texture. Having spent 15 months in French oak before bottling, it tastes a bit dense and muted at this point, and should be best after 2018.

Jurosa is a beautifully rich and creamy expression of Chardonnay that shows the yellow flower and drying mineral characteristics that are unique to the Friuli winemaking area in northeast Italy. Pair this wine with vegetable or fish risotto.

Snappy and nice, with a touch of mineral. Otherwise it's all about ripe apple and pear up front and citrus on the back palate and finish. Zesty and clean, with the mildest amount of honeyed sweetness. Imported by Palm Bay Imports.

wine: Joseph Swan Vineyards 2013 Kent the Younger Chardonnay (Russian River Valley)
appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: High in acidity and well-defined minerality, this wine is also soft and velvety, with a sensibility of crushed rocks and preserved lemon. From a younger block of the famed Ritchie Vineyard, it celebrates youthful playfulness on the palate, with a long-lasting, voluptuous finish.

wine: Amizetta 2009 Terraced Hillside Estate Merlot (Napa Valley)
review: Rugged in the mouth, with edgy tannins, this Merlot also features ripe berry-cherry fruit that seems a little sweet. Ready to drink now.
This opens with aromas of French oak, coconut and dark berry. The dense palate offers black plum, mocha and tobacco alongside close-grained tannins.

The producer owns just over three acres of scattered parcels of this 123-acre vineyard, one of the iconic sites in Burgundy. Rich tannins and a huge structure are backed by powerful black damson fruit flavors. The wine is still very young and will not be ready to drink before 2025.

wine: Hogue 1999 Vineyard Selection Cabernet Sauvignon (Columbia Valley (WA))
appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Hogue's mid-level Cab is very well-made, with firm cassis fruit set against a backdrop of slightly chalky tannins. Showing a nice mix of cherry, cranberry, sandalwood and earth, it gives more complexity than usual at this price.

wine: Fallet Dart NV Anthocyane Rosé Brut  (Champagne)
review: This freshly vibrant wine has a soft edge that contrasts with bright cherry flavors and acidity. It has a touch of spice, and the Champagne's essential dryness comes through at the end. Drink now.

wine: Ferraton Père et Fils 1999 Samorëns Red (Côtes du Rhône)
appellation: Côtes du Rhône, Rhône Valley, France
review: Perfumed aromas carry some light cherry and a hint of charcoal. The smooth palate features a solid base of black cherry and some meaty notes that add character. The finish, while short, is clean and dry. Nice and easy, just what you want from this type of wine. Best Buy. —M.S.

wine: Adega Cooperativa Ponte de Barca 2010 Grand Escolha Loureiro (Vinho Verde)
review: Smooth wine, with green plums and citrus flavors balancing the edge of yeastiness. The wine finishes crisp and tangy.

wine: Elevation Cellars 2009 Jammin' Red Red (Columbia Valley (WA))
appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Consulting winemaker Matthew Loso knows his way around a blend, and this fine Cabernet-Merlot mix shines with focused, dark fruit flavors. It's threaded with streaks of clove, black olive and anise, with real muscle and tannic heft.

appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: Former L.A. Laker Sasha Vujacic presents aromas of cooked black plums, mission figs, black currants, uncrushed peppercorns and leather on this reserve bottling. It spent 30 months in the barrel, six more than the estate bottling. The palate offers more plums and tarter plum skin along with bay leaf, oregano and thyme.

Very strong white peach and lemon blossom aromas meet with roasted chicken, honeysuckle and chamomile on the nose of this bottling. Apple, pear and nectarine show on the palate, as does fresh cherimoya, graphite and more white peach toward the finish.

wine: I Veroni 2004  Vin Santo del Chianti Rufina
appellation: Vin Santo del Chianti Rufina, Tuscany, Italy
review: A fabulous dessert blend of Malvasia, Trebbiano and Sangiovese, this Vin Santo from the Chianti Rufina area is aged seven years in caratelli (made with mixed woods spanning from chestnut to cherry). It shows a bright golden color and intense aromas of resin, butterscotch and candied fruit. Very nice.

Yes, 1997 is the current vintage. Reviewers gave this wine's bouquet two thumbs up—it has lovely aromas of wheat biscuit, mint and cassis. Our biggest gripe here was the wine's weight—which, for a Cabernet from a good vintage, was pretty light. Still, it had some pleasant cherry, red plum and earth flavors.

appellation: Redwood Valley, Mendocino County, California, US
review: This appellation has some of the older Zin vines left, and those half-century specimens produced this baby. It has telltale briar and pepper flavors and is very dry, but is overly soft, with a medicinal, cough-mediciney finish. —S.H.

A yeasty touch still clings to the nose and gives a creamy aspect to the stone fruit scents on the nose. The palate continues this creamy-fruity theme but adds a wonderful green citrus zestiness that also provides a pithy, pleasantly bitter texture as a counterpoint to the generous, rounded fruit. The finish is dry and zesty and wonderfully aromatic.

Made with Merlot, Cabernet Sauvignon and Montepulciano, this opens with aromas of sunbaked earth, cassis and dark spice. The aromas carry over to the juicy, straightforward palate along with a hint of crushed sage and powdered tannins.

appellation: Dundee Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: Made from Pommard clone vines planted in 1973 and 1984, this subtle and yet commanding wine fills the palate with lush strawberry jam flavors. It's smooth and textural, and time in barrel has imbued it with just the right touch of mocha.
The Mazzei brothers produce a Vermentino of depth, brightness and persistency. It delivers long-lasting flavors of citrus, peach and orange skin.

wine: Jax 2014 Dutton Ranch Chardonnay (Russian River Valley)
appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: Winemaker Kirk Venge coaxes orange blossom perfume from this otherwise velvety, concentrated and youthful white, toasty in caramelized oak. The concentration makes way for a taste of baked apple and pear within a cradle of nuanced acidity.

wine: Jean-Luc Colombo 2019 La Belle de Mai White (Saint-Péray)
review: Fresh yellow apples and pears are dusted with hints of tangerine zest, allspice and honey in this plump, tea-tinged blend of 60% Roussanne and 40% Marsanne. Fermented and matured in oak barrels (10% new) it's a cream-textured white edged by twists of bitter walnut skin and orange-peel spice as well as lingering oak tannins. While heady in youth, it should meld nicely through 2029.

appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
review: Smoky, elegant and soft aromas of leather, pepper and berry lead into flavors of cherry and cigarbox spice on the palate of this approachable Cabernet. The wine is not terribly complex, but good structure and acidity give it cellaring potential, and paired with duck, lamb or beef dishes, it will make a very nice addition to the table.

wine: Penfolds 2003 Bin 28 Kalimna Shiraz (South Eastern Australia)
appellation: South Eastern Australia, Australia Other, Australia
review: This is a throwback to the Penfolds style of the past, with plenty of stuffing and tannin packed into a dark red wine. Chocolate and plum flavors pick up hints of eucalyptus and leathery notes on the firm finish. Drink 2008–2015.

wine: Weibel Family 2019 Archgate Rose Pinot Noir Sparkling (California)
review: A finely beaded texture and rich mouthfeel are filled in with light cherry and plum notes in this well-balanced, polished wine. Freshness and softness are its hallmarks.
Good, creamy, caramel-and yellow fruit-flavored wine, finely balanced. The elements are all there, knit together, leaving honey and baked apple flavors to finish.

wine: Francis Ford Coppola 2011 Votre Santé Chardonnay (California)
review: A little thin, but it's nice and creamy, with buttered toast, pineapple, lime and vanilla flavors. There's a fine cut of acidity.

wine: Frei Brothers 2009 Reserve Sauvignon Blanc (Russian River Valley)
appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: Racy and bright, with high acidity framing dry flavors of lemons, limes and grapefruits. There's a green streak of gooseberry that signals some unripeness.

wine: Martin Ranch 2003 Cabernet Sauvignon (Santa Clara Valley)
appellation: Santa Clara Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: This valley is known as Silicon Valley, but before the suburbs overran the vineyards, it was one of the most famous sources of Cabernet in California. Although this wine is a little overripe, it shows the lost promise of the valley, in the beautiful tannins and overall balance.

Some of the basic Merlots from Hawke's Bay—like this one—impress for their combination of quality and value. Cherries and dried spices pick up enough hints of earth and olive to be interesting sip after sip in this medium-bodied red that ends on a crisp, mouthwatering note.

wine: Botalcura 2003 La Porfia Grand Reserve Carmenère (Curicó Valley)
review: From what may be Chile's trickiest grape to get just right, this is an admirable offering. Some of the variety's tomato leaf and herb notes are evident, but there's also plenty of plum and blackberry fruit to provide balance. Medium-bodied, framed by slightly rustic tannins on the finish.

Blended from too many varieties to list, including Cabernet Sauvignon and Viognier, this red wine is acidic and dry. It has ripe cherry, currant and oak flavors that are very tannic, but the wine is not an ager. Drink up.

wine: Most Wanted Winery 2008 Garcia Family Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (California)
review: This Cab opens with soy and molasses and then moves seamlessly into a mouthful of blackberry jam. Dense, it's still young but should develop well.
This Merlot-dominated blend is very soft and lush, with upfront chocolate fudge and black cherry flavors. It's an almost sweet wine, although it's basically dry and has good acids.

wine: Qupé 2008 Nielson Vineyard Syrah (Santa Maria Valley)
appellation: Santa Maria Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: Very dry, fairly tannic and acidic, with a tart bite that makes the flavors even more austere than they are. But it's a complicated, interesting wine, obviously pedigreed. Shows discrete, elusive black cherry, crushed pepper, mineral and sandalwood flavors that linger. Should develop over the next 3–4 years.

wine: Fess Parker 2011 Ashley's Chardonnay (Sta. Rita Hills)
appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
review: Despite the rich, buttery, toasty oak notes, this wine stands up to the barrel influence with its strong tropical fruit and pear flavors, as well as its brisk acidity and stony minerality. It's ready to drink now with rich fare like lobsters or scallops.

The nose on this soft red smacks of black cherry and spice, and the like flavors are smooth. Tannins are firm but the wine has a light touch overall. The finish has a spicy spin. Pair with lighter poultry dishes.

appellation: Capay Valley, Central Valley, California, US
review: There's a strong peach-fuzz aroma enveloping this wine. It's unoaked, tasting overly rich and oily.

wine: Tre Monti 2011 Campo di Mezzo  (Sangiovese di Romagna Superiore)
appellation: Sangiovese di Romagna Superiore, Central Italy, Italy
review: Campo di Mezzo (Sangiovese from Central Italy) opens with a dark garnet color and bold aromas of black cherry, prune, plum and blackberry. It's definitely a very ripe expression of the variety with a touch of soft sweetness in the mouth.

wine: Comtesse Thérèse 2003 Traditional Merlot (North Fork of Long Island)
appellation: North Fork of Long Island, Long Island, New York, US
review: Light-medium bodied, and smooth in the mouth, this wine would be fine if not for a strong brett presence, manifesting itself with strong horsey/metallic flavors and aromas. Underneath there is some decent red fruit, but it's too far under to rate higher.
Round and ripe, this opens with fruity aromas of ripe apple and yellow stone fruit. The soft juicy palate delivers peach, pineapple and banana while a hint of mineral signals the finish.

The headiness of roasted hazelnuts, Bourbon vanilla and blossom honey have an immense seductive power. The palate follows up with precision, concentration and long length. This oak-aged TBA is a mature, full package that will easily charm anyone—now or in years to come.

Tropical fruit flavors form the base of this wine, but over the ripe mango flavor rides a heavy layer of toasty oak, and it's questionable whether it will integrate before the fruit starts to fade. Drink now for its lusty obviousness.

Oak, roasted coffee bean and star anise aromas lead the nose. On the palate, notes of fennel, licorice, mocha and espresso lend depth to a core of dried cherry while firmly delineated tannins provide the framework. Drink after 2020.

wine: Chilensis 2014 Reserva Estate Bottled Chardonnay (Maule Valley)
review: Straightforward apple and peach aromas announce your basic everyday quaffing Chardonnay: this is low on minerality and acidity, and thus it tastes of banana, melon and vanilla. A flat, melony finish lacks acidic framework.

This ripe, wood-aged wine is full of rich tannins and generous black fruits. Its structure is young and firm, although the weight and opulence of the fruit will soon show through to give a generous wine that will still age. Drink from 2021.

Mild rooty notes come side by side with plum, berry and cola aromas. This is deep, pure and elegant in the mouth, with ripe berry, spice and vanilla flavors doled out in proper amounts. A loamy finish with just enough acidic kick confirms the excellence of this gran reserva from a classic vintage. Drink through 2018.

appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
review: Very light in color, this wine has a brisk nose that shows Key lime peel, lemongrass, grapefruit blossom and a wet-concrete minerality. There is tremendous energy and zest on the palate, which is steely and stony with flavors of red grapefruit and a great textural grip.

For a white Bordeaux, this is hugely rich and ripe. With its spice and toast, the wood-aging of the Muscadelle has added extra complexity. The alcohol gives the wine a peppery character that is less attractive while also removing freshness. Consider this wine a curiosity.

wine: Etude 2012 Temblor Vineyard Grace Benoist Ranch Estate Grown Pinot Noir (Carneros)
designation: Temblor Vineyard Grace Benoist Ranch Estate Grown
review: Estate owned, Temblor is a sloped vineyard influenced by the Petaluma Gap and its early-morning fog, planted to two types of Dijon clones. Oaky and round, this wine offers a flavor of steeped red-berry cobbler, with rich layers of managed tannin and a smoky finish.

wine: Bouchard Père & Fils 2006 Les Cailles Premier Cru  (Nuits-St.-Georges)
review: With smoky aromas, this starts out as an enticing wine. On the palate, the fruit is surprisingly soft for a Nuits-St-Georges, with the wine's evident structure showing an open character, edged with wood and red plum and currant flavors. The dry tannins give shape, but do not dominate this big wine.

wine: Migration 2014 Drum Canyon Pinot Noir (Sta. Rita Hills)
appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
review: Quite reserved in aroma, this bottling from Duckhorn made with fruit from a Dierberg-owned site shows light cranberry and chaparral scents on the nose. The palate is straight-forward with tangy cranberry and cedar flavors.

appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Made from 90% Cabernet Sauvignon with Merlot, Cabernet Franc and Malbec sprinkled in, this wine starts out quite reticent, with notes of scorched earth, mocha, herbs, woodspice and cherry. It's full bodied and very tightly wound at present, with firm, chalky tannins that need significant time in the cellar to stretch their legs. Best after 2018.

wine: Quinta de la Rosa 2019 La Rosa Branco White (Douro)
review: A blend of four typical white Douro grapes, this wine is cool and collected with fine apple acidity and a bright texture. There is a hint of yellow fruits to add richness to the aftertaste. Drink now.

Fun and refreshing, this delightful sparkler has delicate aromas suggesting red berries and white spring flowers. The dry, tangy palate offers pomegranate, citrus zest and white peach alongside bright acidity.

wine: Château Kalon Nodoz 2014  Côtes de Bourg
review: The wine has layers of acidity that come from the underripe fruit. It has bell pepper and spice along with red currant fruitiness.

Under the same ownership as Château la Dominique in Saint-Émilion, this estate has produced a ripe, Merlot-dominated wine. Although the fruit is intense, this wine has poise and clarity, giving some lightness. It will be worth waiting for this wine until 2024.

wine: Gérard Bertrand 2015 Château La Sauvageonne Volcanic Rosé (Coteaux du Languedoc)
review: A blend of 50% Grenache, 30% Cinsault and 20% Syrah, this is a refreshing and well-balanced rosé. Though young and still somewhat tight right now, it offers bright notes of red cherry, strawberry hull and plum skin that are framed by hints of orange blossom, citrus peel and sweet spice. Silky in texture, with a mineral streak and ample acidity that results in a bright finish.

appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: At more than four years of age, this Cabernet is as good as it will ever be. It's sharp in acids and a little green, but offers satisfying berry, cherry and oak flavors.
This medium-bodied wine shows good red- and black-cherry flavors under a veneer of maple and vanilla-scented oak. It's well made in a popular style that many people like.
93–95. Barrel Sample. The wine already has a delicious side that is both refreshing and tangy. Its tight texture is bright, shining with herbs and crisp fruitiness. It exudes freshness on the finish.

appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: Sharp and aggressive in acidity and unripe tannins, with a green mint edge to the cherries and raspberries, which actually are quite sweet. It's an unbalanced, rustic wine with excessively high alcohol.

Candied orange peel, lychee and rose petals perfume this classically aromatic but dry-style Gewürztraminer. It's a refreshing, easy-drinking white with a lingering bitter marmalade finish. Drink now through 2022.

New Zealand's oldest winery (founded in 1851) has turned out a lightweight but wonderfully fragrant Syrah. Violets and cracked pepper notes are head-turning, followed by modest cherry fruit and a slightly lacking midpalate. Ready to drink now.

This is a well-made, small-production wine from the producer's home estate. Inviting in perfumed oak, pencil and cedar, it has brawny power that remains elegant in the glass, with persistent acidity and layers of cassis and cinnamon.

wine: Pinord 2000 Pi del Nord Cabernet Sauvignon (Penedès)
review: A mature wine with its own set of proprietary virtues. Opens with cedar, cigar box and almost citric red-fruit aromas. The palate, however, is elegant, with herbal tobacco, raspberry and dry plum flavors. Finishes long and classy, with hints of the Old World and plenty of savoir faire. Drink now.

Leather and cassis aromas greet you, but airing turns them toward leafy and green. Flavors of cherry, raspberry and red currants are also a touch lean and green, but for the most part the wine shows verve and a good mouthfeel even if the flavors aren't perfect.

appellation: Mendocino County, Mendocino County, California, US
review: Bright cherry and mellow menthol flavors dance on a smooth but firm texture of light tannins in this full-bodied wine. A cedary, minty character lasts into the finish.

wine: Craggy Range 2006 Les Beaux Cailloux Gimblett Gravels Chardonnay (Hawke's Bay)
review: A warm, lush style of Chardonnay, with ripe fruit notes of peach and melon framed by roasted nuts. It's on the full-bodied side of the spectrum, with acids that almost seem to fall away on the finish. Drink now.

wine: Domaine Chanson 2019 Clos des Mouches Premier Cru  (Beaune)
review: Whiffs of fresh-churned butter and honey introduce this powerfully ripe, sun-drenched Chardonnay. The fleshy, voluminous wine shows the heat of the 2019 vintage through concentrated flavors of Meyer lemon and Mirabelle plum. Matured in oak casks for 14 to 18 months (with some new oak), the opulent, spicy sip should drink at peak from 2024 to 2035.

Mirabelle plum, yellow pear and ripe apple combine into ripe fruitiness on the nose. A medium-sweet palate then puts all its cards on ripe, vivid apple flavors that are both rounded and fresh. The gentle sweetness is met with freshness and presents a slender, entirely apple- and citrus-scented wine that is not quite sweet enough for dessert. Cheese or chili-spiced dishes might be a better option.

appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: This is an enormously ripe, extracted red wine. It shows California's heat in the jammy raspberries, cherries and chocolate, as sweet and thick as the filling in a pie. Shows the strength of Paso Robles, which is ripeness, and its weaknesses, excessive alcohol, sweetness and a flabby structure.

Consistency is always a virtue, and once again this wine is creamy, fully oaked and more European in style than most Chilean Chardonnays. The nose is like popcorn, with apple and peach in the background. Flavors of banana, coconut, melon and apple carry the rich palate, while the finish is smooth and oaky. This is very good Chardonnay even if it lacks the extra elements required of a great wine. Drink now for its freshness.

Very intense aromas of cocoa powder, milk chocolate and vanilla are thick on the nose, with chocolate-covered cherries and raspberries riding underneath. The full-bodied palate echoes the nose, with bold oak tones riding ahead of the lush fruit. Woody tannins rise up on the finish.

93-95 Barrel sample. Huge black currant flavors, very ripe fruit, but also a great sense of balance, of proportion that give this wine both charm and impressiveness. It's going to age seriously, and well.

A little rough around the edges, but otherwise a soft, juicy wine for drinking now. It has pleasant cherry pie and ripe red-currant fruit flavors. Air it in a decanter or in the glass for an hour before drinking.

A small portion of the wine went through malolactic fermentation, so it offers a lovely roundness. Features floral aromas backed by pure tangerine and nectarine flavors. Registers more fruity and smooth than mineral, with a perfect finish.

Lush and full in texture, this wine has more spicy flavors than fruity ones, as a blend of vanilla, hazelnut and cream coat the palate. It has the rich feel of barrel fermentation and will win friends with the layering of subtleties on such a decadent mouthfeel.

Aromas suggest underbrush, oak, coconut, prune and dill. The concentrated palate offers steeped plum, dried blackberry, tobacco, cracked blackberry and licorice alongside firm, velvety tannins. It closes on a note of bitter prune.

Smells buttery and caramelly, then shows clean apple, pear and citrus fruit on the palate. Medium-weight, with a finish that turns more tropical, developing hints of pineapple, melon and citrus. Vilana is the grape variety.

wine: DFJ Vinhos 2018 Aluado Reserva Alicante Bouschet (Lisboa)
review: The deep color of Alicante Bouschet is very evident in this wine. Full tannins and powerful black-cherry and plum fruits are enhanced by touches of wood aging. The wine is still a little young and will be at its best from 2022.
Structured and, very firm, hinting at the black fruit potential. This solid, foursquare wine, is chunky but not without some elegance. The dry tannins come through strongly on the dense finish.

appellation: Monterey County, Central Coast, California, US
review: This is a sound Pinot Noir, rich in raspberry jam, toast and vanilla flavors, with lots of zingy coastal acidity.

Creamy peach and vanilla aromas are perfectly attractive, as is the palate. There's plenty of peach, mango and citrus pith flavors to make it worthy, and the finish is long and citrusy. Surprisingly good given the paltry price and Argentina's dearth of success with Viognier.

appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: Dark strawberry, black plum, fennel pollen, tarragon and a hint of caramel show on the nose of the solid second vintage for this memorably labeled bottle. Ripe purple fruit meets with minty spices on the palate, where the richness is cut by directed acidity.

wine: Domaine Bellegarde 2016 La Pierre Blanche  (Jurançon Sec)
review: Although it is dry, this wine is effectively a late harvest, with the grapes picked in early November. That gives the wine richness and concentration, offering ripe yellow fruits, rich acidity and spiciness. The wine is gently honeyed and lightly structured. Drink from 2019.

wine: Cavatappi 2012 San Pietro Tuscan Style Red (Columbia Valley (WA))
appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: A blend of Sangiovese (38%), Merlot (31%) and Cabernet Sauvignon, this wine displays each in turn with aromas and flavors of dried herbs, coffee, tobacco and cherry. The style is reserved, with plenty of fruit and acid but subtle oak—perfect for the dinner table.

appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: Aromas of lime blossom and Key lime pie meet with a chalky restraint on the nose of this bottling, whose label invites customers to write their names on the front. Flavors of wet stone and lime zest make for a delicate palate, where sharp acidity cuts into the finish.

This is a great wine, rounded and rich despite its power and weight. Its many elements—the ripe black fruits, the balanced acidity—are smoothed with wood aging. It also shows an elegance, giving the wine good aging potential. Drink from 2018.

wine: Domaine Divio 2019 Clos Gallia Estate Pinot Noir (Ribbon Ridge)
appellation: Ribbon Ridge, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: This is fruit-forward, fresh and open. Instantly appealing, it offers plenty of pretty blueberry, cherry and orange backed by ample tannins. Given 11 months in one-quarter new oak, it's the most open and accessible of the 2019s from Divio, and should be enjoyed through 2025.

appellation: Umpqua Valley, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
review: Abacela does best with its Tempranillo, Dolcetto and Syrah. This is distinctive, spicy and loaded with powerful flavors. Licorice, blackberry, pepper and coffee tumble together, the sweet powerful fruit held within a tight focus. Ripe, forward, appealing and yet built for aging.

appellation: Umpqua Valley, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
review: Fruity and forward, this opens with pomegranate fruit and ample but bitter phenolic flavors. The stemmy character frames the finish as the high-toned fruit fades.

wine: Carabella 2010 Dijon 667 Clone Pinot Noir (Chehalem Mountains)
appellation: Chehalem Mountains, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: This is a fine effort from first-year fruit that was cropped way down for extra concentration. It's a vibrant wine with a bright raspberry flavor that has a pretty, lightly candied quality.
This solid Sauvignon is lean and focused, yet manages to show some ripe melon (specifically cantaloupe) flavors to go with its core of tart limes.

appellation: Valpolicella Classico Superiore Ripasso, Veneto, Italy
review: Tightly layered and opulent, this has loads of fruit intensity, with notes of spice and moist earth. The palate shows firm density and supple smoothness.

This is a superb blend of aged tawny Ports, blended to celebrate the company's 325th anniversary. Filled with rich fruit, it has great depth and spicy richness although it is also impressively fresh. Dried fruits and red plums are lifted with a hint of smoky wood and good acidity. Like any tawny Port, it is ready to drink.
Named after the monks of the Lóios monastery (now a pousada), this is a very accessible wine: ripe and soft. It has fresh red fruits, a generous texture and a real drink-me-now character.

wine: Domaines Barons de Rothschild (Lafite) 2015 Los Vascos Chardonnay (Colchagua Valley)
review: Crisp aromas of citrus are feline and snappy. This smells more like Sauvignon Blanc than Chardonnay, and the palate is racy and citric as well. Lime, nettle and tangerine flavors finish green, tart and long, with acidic push.

wine: Peachy Canyon 2011 Mustang Springs Zinfandel (Paso Robles)
appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: Made in the Peachy Canyon style of great power and ripeness, this is one of the more assertive Zinfandels out there. Blended with some Petite Sirah, which gives it even greater heft, it's basically a nuclear blast of wild, briary summer berries and spices.

wine: Gabriel Meffre 2015 La Châsse Merlot (Vin de France)
appellation: Vin de France, France Other, France
review: The is a soft, gentle wine with ripe berry fruit. Minimal tannins are embedded in its fruitiness and rounded texture. Drink now.

Aromas of thick-skinned black cherry and graphite show depth and complexity on the nose. The palate is rounded by a ripe red-plum flavor, with well-honed black-currant acidity cutting through spice tones. Soft well-knit tannins frame it all, giving this a easy, likable personality.

appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: The aromas jump up, with mesmerizing notes of fresh herbs, green olive, violets, orange peel, smoked meat and huckleberry. The palate shows a light but pillowy texture alongside flavors that carry on the finish. It's all about subtlety.
From a Lebanese winemaker, a jammy Pinot tasting of cherries, blueberries, black raspberries and dusty oriental spices, especially clove. It is dry, with lively acids and silky tannins.

wine: Evesham Wood 2017 Sojeau Vineyard Pinot Noir (Eola-Amity Hills)
appellation: Eola-Amity Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: Formerly named Sojourner, this site delivers lightly peppery, brambly berry fruit, sprinkled with green herbs and displaying lovely texture and detail. A whiff of cannabis adds to the herbal impression, but all the flavors are beautifully intertwined, proportionate and graceful.

Named after the dovecote in the family's vineyards, this wine has structure and the aging ability typical of this appellation. Tannins and dark fruits come together in a rich wine with juicy acidity and layers of black-cherry flavors.

Whiffs of orange blossoms add delicate floral flair to sweet marmalade and honey tones on this penetrating dessert Riesling. While creamy and sweet on the tongue, earthy mineral tones and piercing acidity add balance and structure. It's delicious now, but certainly an age-worthy wine that will develop gorgeously over the next two decades at least.

This has sweet-tasting, juicy fruit that is immediately appealing. Its firm structure of tannins appear underneath the ripe red-berry and black currant flavors. It's developing well into an accessible and delicious wine.

appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
review: Bold, forward and extracted red wine, with raspberry, earth, compost and a light leafiness to the nose. Tannic and tight, with plum and heavy, ripe berry flavors. Toasty and dark on the finish too, with power and freshness.

Stony perfume welcomes one into this full, fleshy white adorned with peach and green apple fruit. Succulent on the midpalate, it delivers flavor and body with balance, finishing on a tart, lingering spark of key lime.

wine: Taylor Fladgate 2015 Quinta da Vargellas Vintage  (Port)
review: This wine is ripe with tannins and powerful with ripe fruit. A solid character gives it density. The tannins and the richness of the wine are ripe and concentrated with fruit. Drink from 2026.

Powdery and sweet smelling, with an acidic palate propelling pedestrian green apple, lime and orange flavors. Fruity but not very refined, with a tenuous balance that indicates that it should be drunk as soon as possible.

This bracing, precisely crafted wine emphasizes crispness and attractively lean fruit flavors over richness, and it will be great with appetizers and seafood, even raw oysters. It's fresh, clean and inviting.

From one of the properties owned by the Laplace family, this blend of Tannat and Cabernet Franc is juicy, ripe and all about black fruits. Soft tannins support a juicy, generous wine that will be ready to drink by late 2018.

wine: Williams Selyem 2011 Ferrington Vineyard Pinot Noir (Anderson Valley)
appellation: Anderson Valley, Mendocino County, California, US
review: With ample power under its engine, this Ferrington Vineyard Pinot is rich in cranberry and red cherry, soft and lilting in texture yet nuanced in toasty oak. Big on the finish, it'll beautifully withstand a few more years on its own before opening, the acidity lively enough to keep flavors vibrant yet mellowed.

From Telmo Rodriguez, this Toro is full of eraser, violet and other candied, floral aromas. The palate, meanwhile, is hard and rubbery, with tannins that are bullish and flavors that run dark to almost bitter. A big wine in need of some manners.
This ripe, concentrated wine has a strong texture with a tangy, perfumed character. The bite of spice is a strong element in a wine that needs some aging. Drink from 2020.

wine: Borgogno F.lli Serio e Battista 2010 Cannubi  (Barolo)
review: Hailing from the heart of the historic Cannubi vineyard, this polished wine opens with notes of black fruit, violet, leather and baking spices. The palate offers black raspberry, crushed cherry, clove and vanilla alongside brisk acidity and firm tannins. It's already accessible but will improve over the next four to five years and then evolve gracefully for decades. Drink 2018–2038.

wine: En Garde 2013 Olivet Court Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)
appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: This wine is made entirely from the Martini clone of the variety, a heritage clone that imparts a lovely perfume of raspberry and rose that's hard to resist. Moderately spicy cola seasons a voluptuous midpalate that fills with length as the wine develops, never letting go of its unshakeable prettiness.

A camphor-like aroma mingles with forest floor, blue flowers and botanical herbs. Elegantly structured, the full-bodied palate features ripe Morello cherry, strawberry compote, star anise and tobacco framed in firm, fine-grained tannins. Drink 2027–2032.

wine: Château Bréhat 2012  Castillon Côtes de Bordeaux
appellation: Castillon Côtes de Bordeaux, Bordeaux, France
review: While there are plenty of tannins, this Merlot/Cabernet Franc/Cabernet Sauvignon blend also has a delicious, fruity character. The fresh acidity of the vintage is right there, balanced by black currant fruits and a dry core. It is developing well, and will be drinkable from 2016.

wine: Pali 2007 Boer Family Vineyard Pinot Noir (Chalone)
review: Beautifully rich and ripe in cherries, raspberries and sweet smoky cedar, this Pinot is fully drinkable now, although decanting will help. But it's also an ager. Shows a mushroomy dryness and herbal grounding that suggest improvement through 2013.
Perfumed with its new wood, not excessively as in the past but obviously. That gives the tannins an extra polish, smoothing the wine, leaving black currant fruit to shine through. Age for 4–8 years.

wine: Enrique Foster 2009 Raleo Estate Bottled Malbec (Mendoza)
review: Stalky in scent, this is underwhelming on the nose. It feels adequate and solid, with basic raspberry, strawberry and spice flavors. Scratchy on the finish, with mild red-fruit flavors.

wine: Foris 2010 Siskiyou Terrace Cabernet Sauvignon (Rogue Valley)
appellation: Rogue Valley, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
review: A moderately aromatic wine that brings notes of cherry, plum and baking spices. It's densely packed with sweet cherry, coffee and powdered cinnamon flavors with dry, grainy tannins that distract.

appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: A blend of 42% Cabernet Sauvignon, 42% Syrah and 16% Merlot, the 2008 Trutina has elevated itself beyond any previous vintage. Firm, chewy, tight and spicy, it's a fully integrated and complex wine. Cassis, earth, lead pencil, coffee grounds and a streak of iron keep the flavors piling on. This bottle tastes way more expensive than it actually is.

wine: Monte dos Cabaços 2009 Margarida Alicante Bouschet (Alentejano)
review: Often unsung, Alicante Bouschet forms the base for some of the Alentejo's top wines. With this mature and ripe wine, named after one of the owners, Cabaços has shown again the grape's quality. The wine is big, powerful with perfumed tannins, a celebration of the warmth of the region. It's not for further aging, drink now.

Rich pomegranate, blackberry and plum aromas are sprinkled with spicy pepper and tobacco. Lip-smacking acidity adds energy to velvety tannins. Tart cranberry and raspberry flavors meld with savory spice and peppercorn, leading to a tangy finish that's laced with raw oak tones.

Forest-berry, rose-petal and wild herb aromas delicately shape the nose. On the bright polished palate, sleek tannins seamlessly support juicy Marasca cherry, raspberry compote and star anise. Thanks to the high-altitude vineyards, this has energizing freshness for the hot vintage.

wine: Furthermore 2014 Rosella's Vineyard Pinot Noir (Santa Lucia Highlands)
appellation: Santa Lucia Highlands, Central Coast, California, US
review: Very pretty and precise on the nose, this bottling, which is quite delicate for the rich-leaning region, shows candied pomegranate, cinnamon spice, hibiscus and wet gravel on the nose. Wild strawberry and rhubarb flavors pop on the sip, alongside watermelon rind and a very rocky and tense minerality. There is tons of tannic and acidic depth.

wine: Château Haut Dina 2015  Castillon Côtes de Bordeaux
appellation: Castillon Côtes de Bordeaux, Bordeaux, France
review: While this dense wine has plenty of firm tannins, it also has fine, ripe fruit. Rich blackberry flavors and smoky aromas dominate. Drink from 2020.

wine: Il Macchione 2014  Vino Nobile di Montepulciano
appellation: Vino Nobile di Montepulciano, Tuscany, Italy
review: Balsamic aromas of camphor mingle with underbrush, leather and prune. The linear palate is rather evolved, suggesting dried cherry, game and a salty note accompanied by dusty, drying tannins and bright acidity.

wine: Viña Pérez Cruz 2010 Reserva Cabernet Sauvignon (Maipo Valley)
review: This is a good but generic Chilean Cabernet, meaning it's a bit herbal and fiery, with eucalyptus on the nose. In the mouth, this is medium in intensity and modest in character. Flavors of herbal red berry, carob and dried leaves end with a touch of heat.

Made from the Nebbiolo grape, a ruby-colored agreeable wine with opening aromas of black cherries, chocolate and tar. In the mouth it's bone dry and delicate, with soft tannins, although the acidity is high enough to burn on the finish.

wine: Vignerons de Bel Air 2011 Grande QV  (Coteaux Bourguignons)
review: Soft and lightly smoky, round and ripe, this wine has flavors of black currant and blueberry, plus a touch of wood and gentle acidity. Coteaux Bourguignons is the new appellation that replaces the rather derogatory-sounding Bourgogne Grand Ordinaire.

wine: Viña Los Boldos 2015 Reserva Sanama Carmenère (Cachapoal Valley)
review: This wine's unripe, stalky berry aromas smell of latex. It's tight, pulling and drying on the palate, with weedy, peppery plum flavors that finish green.

appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: With fruit coming from Double D Vineyards just outside of the Lake Chelan appellation, the aromas are light and hard to tease out, with whiffs of herb. The palate is more giving, with medium-bodied, almost thick-feeling lemony flavors. It's hard to see exactly where it's all going, but there is promise.

appellation: Arroyo Seco, Central Coast, California, US
review: The acidity and fruit are the stars of this well-made Riesling. The wine is rich in citrus, honeysuckle, apricot and honey flavors that finish dry and clean.

wine: Enkidu 2014 Tina Marie Vineyard Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)
appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: This small-production, vineyard-designate is impressive in dried cherry and raspberry layers of flavor, supported by integrated oak. Juicy and explosive on the palate, it offers a spicy forest-floor note that complements the fruit.

appellation: Livermore Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: A blend of Cabernet Sauvignon and Syrah, this red is soft and appealing in red and black currant, mocha, anise, cedar and smoky oak flavors. It's dry, direct and elegantly structured. Drink now.

wine: Kenneth Volk 2009 Enz Vineyard Zinfandel (Lime Kiln Valley)
appellation: Lime Kiln Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: A big, bold Zin, with a kick of peppery spices. Really front-loaded with wild berry, currant, cherry pie and sweet tobacco flavors. Nothing subtle about this barbecue-friendly powerhouse.

wine: Chateau Ste. Michelle 2016 Cold Creek Vineyard Chardonnay (Columbia Valley (WA))
appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Aromas and flavors of vanilla, candlewax, custard and clarified butter are out front. Abundant peach notes follow. It seems a bit stylized but still has balance and appeal.

This pure expression of Cabernet Sauvignon from sunny Tuscany has done a good job of holding up to the heat of the vintage. The wine shows ripe aromas of blackberry, chocolate and spice but does not taste jammy or cooked. In fact, it strikes a very good balance between fruit and firmness.

wine: Patz & Hall 2017 Jenkins Ranch Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)
review: A perennial standout in the producer's line-up of vineyard-designates, this wine is lovely, complex and textured. Black tea, forest floor, clove and rhubarb keep it savory and earthy in the glass, while robust and refined tannin, a length of white pepper are there at its finish.
Pepper—both black and green—dominate this wine from the aromatics through the palate and finish. It's ultimately a basic, herbaceous red, with some brambly fruit and plums mixed in with soft oak.

wine: Hannah Nicole Vineyards 2010 Limited Release Row 91 Malbec (Contra Costa County)
appellation: Contra Costa County, Central Coast, California, US
review: Juicy in red raspberry and cherry, this soft Malbec is satisfying on many fronts, with a touch of savory sourness on the finish.

wine: Ledson 2013 Century Vine Reserve Zinfandel (Russian River Valley)
appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: Blended with 10% Alicante Bouschet and aged for 20 months in French oak, this wine shows bright baked strawberry fruit that becomes brooding in the glass, layered with black licorice and peppered leather. Densely built, it finishes seductively smooth.

Something floral and stony appears on the nose, along with a hint of smoke and something uncompromising and hard. The palate then packs a real punch: the wine hits you like a bullet of concentrated freshness and citric verve. This is bundled and effective, delivering a hit of ripened freshness with its lemon-zest dominated, dry tanginess. The finish has something juicy and luscious and is absolutely dry and clean. Totally lip-smacking. Drink now through 2027.
Peach, melon and other slightly sweet tropical aromas lead into green melon and citrus flavors. Medium-bodied and a bit chewy, with a light, uneven finish that pushes grapefruit and soda cracker.

This wine is finding its style, namely, ripe in tropical fruit, peach, pear and apple flavors, soft acids, lavish oak, plenty of lees and a full malolactic fermentation that helps make the texture buttery and creamy smooth. This year's fine effort is not as big as the magnificent '99, but is opulent and delicious.

wine: Beringer 1998 Hayne Vineyard Petite Sirah (St. Helena)
review: A major disappointment from this fine producer and famous vineyard. Aims for Cabernet-style wine, with ripely extracted blackberry flavors, but struck tasters as too big and clumsy for balance. The oak is also overpowering, with huge charry wood tannins.

This family-owned estate in the southern Médoc close to Bordeaux has made a classic wine. Black currants, some firm tannins and a sense of the freshness reflective of the vintage all come together in a structured wine that will be ready from 2022.

wine: Cantina di Montalcino 2000 Villa di Corsano Red (Toscana)
review: A super Tuscan that's not, dare we say, super. The nose is fine but the palate is overly acidic and heavily slanted toward tart. Has the color and nose going for it, however the palate is discordantly sharp. Not pleasant on the tongue.

wine: Boas Quintas 2018 Fonte do Ouro Dão Nobre White (Dão)
review: A limited edition wine, now mature and with great acidity and white fruit balance. Six months in wood has added complexity and smoothed the vibrant fruit. Drink now. Suitable for vegans.

wine: Stéphane Aladame 2016 Les Maroques Premier Cru  (Montagny)
review: Close to the small village of Montagny-lès-Buxy, this vineyard has produced a crisp wine with a texture that's still tight. It will be delicious, showing its delicate wood-aging flavors alongside the ripe yellow fruits. Balancing acidity is refreshing. Drink the wine from 2021.

wine: Château des Tourtes 2015 Duo Blanc  (Bordeaux Blanc)
review: The wine has mango aromas that set the scene for a tropical, richly fruity wine. Spice gives an extra frisson to this ripe wine. It has an exotic character that is unusual in this style of wine although it doesn't seem out of place or context. Drink now.

wine: Le Solive 2006 Innovazione  (Vernaccia di San Gimignano)
appellation: Vernaccia di San Gimignano, Tuscany, Italy
review: This brilliant Vernaccia (with 10% Viognier) has a sweet, candy-like nose that recalls caramel and butterscotch but that also has fresh aromas of stone fruit and pear to give it dimension. It's fresh and thin in the mouth and would do a good job of cleansing your palate.

wine: Finca la Celia 2016 Pioneer Cabernet Sauvignon (Uco Valley)
review: Gamy, foresty berry aromas lack purity but are not bad. A full, soupy mouthfeel is missing definition, while this tastes of roasted, herbal plum. Saucy, minty, green flavors control the finish.

appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: This is the least expensive of Belle Vallée's current Pinot Noirs, and far and away the best value. It's bright and spicy, fragrant with sweet-smelling berries, cherries and grapes. Forward and fruity, it is a fine choice for sipping on the deck.

wine: Frey-Sohler NV Blanc de Blancs Brut Pinot Blanc (Crémant d'Alsace)
review: Crisp and apple centered wine, full of fruitiness and lively acidity. With a fresh, creamy mousse and citrus tang it's deliciously forward and bright. Drink anytime.

wine: Tandem 2007 van der Kamp Vineyard Pinot Noir (Sonoma Mountain)
review: Very ripe and jammy in raspberry and cherry fruit flavors, this Pinot is accented with crisp acidity. Oak barrel aging adds notes of caramel and buttered toast. It's a deliciously dry wine, although a bit direct and obvious. Seems at its best now and for 3–4 years.

With its spicy, wild berry and pine notes, this Pinot bears Failla's distinctive mark. It's a dry, complex and exotic young wine, brisk in acidity and wonderfully silky and elegant in the mouth. If you're into flavor identifiers, they're wild raspberries and cherries. Good price for a fine Failla wine. Best now and for the next six years.

wine: Lachini 2012 Lachini Family Estate Pinot Noir (Chehalem Mountains)
appellation: Chehalem Mountains, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: A deep rose color, this pretty wine seduces with sweet cherry and red plum fruit, rounded out with a dollop of cinnamon spice and buoyed with moderate acidity. Full, forward, flavorful and built for medium-term aging, this should be enjoyed now through 2020.

appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: A bit soft and dull, with oak-infused flavors of citrus fruits and peaches that show some bitterness on the finish.
A fruity, apple-driven wine, this has a creamy texture. It is soft, lightly spicy and with delicious acidity. The wine is fruity, fragrant and refreshing. Drink now, reveling in the fruit.

Despite its silky mouthfeel, there's a toughness to this wine. It's extracted, with jammy stone-fruit flavors, and an earthy edge of coffee and dried herbs. Offers a robust contrast to Castle's regular '01 Pinot.

wine: Viña Vilano 2014 Legón Crianza  (Ribera del Duero)
appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
review: Spicy berry aromas come with a bell-pepper note. In the mouth, this wine is raw and somewhat abrasive. Plum and raspberry flavors are lightly herbal, while this is distinctly tannic, raw and tough on the finish. This quality wine begs for food.

wine: Domaine de la Taille aux Loups NV Brut Tradition Chenin Blanc (Touraine)
winery: Domaine de la Taille aux Loups
review: The honeyed flavors of Chenin Blanc sing in this attractive wine with its lemon acidity and pure, clean texture. This bottling is ready to drink.

wine: Seven Hills 1999 Klipsun Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Columbia Valley (WA))
appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Another fine Klipsun-designated wine, medium weight, tightly wound and hinting at depth. It's balanced and inviting, yet shows less of the terroir-driven mineral flavors than the Klipsun Merlot from this producer.

wine: Gallo Family Vineyards NV Hearty Burgundy Red (California)
review: This year marks the 50th birthday of Hearty Burgundy, one of the most famous wines in American history. It has always offered solid pleasure in a red, and still does. A blend of Zinfandel and Petite Sirah, it's dry, full-bodied and rich in cherry jam, licorice and black pepper flavors, subtly touched with smoky wood.

A strongly spicy, rich wine, this has great concentration and an intense, dense texture.There is weight with plenty of ripe tropical fruits to contrast pronounced black pepper and bitter almond character. It's still young, so don't drink before 2015. Screwcap.
A crisp and taut wine, this is nervy and lively with attractive fruitiness. It is still young, with acidity very much to the fore. Drink from late 2017.

Dusty, leesy aromas of vanilla bean, banana and saline set up a snappy palate with flavors of citrus, papaya and nut skins. On the finish, this blend of Chardonnay and Viura offers easy flavors of papaya, melon and almond. Despite being barrel fermented, this is decidedly not oaky.
93–95. Barrel Sample. This wine shines with ripe blackberry flavors and richly textured Merlot. There is a core of perfumes and acidity that retains the essential freshness of the vintage. Organic.

wine: Nisia 2017 Las Suertes Old Vines Verdejo (Rueda)
review: Peach and nectarine aromas show a hint of barrel influence but not too much. A high-acid palate keeps this oak-aged Verdejo on the citric and tangy side, while flavors of lemon, underripe nectarine, vanilla and wood grain finish full, oily and salty, with leftover zesty acidity.

This offers aromas of just-crushed grapes, a note of chopped thyme and a whiff of moist soil. The palate is simple and soft, offering wild strawberry and a hint of fennel seed alongside round tannins.

appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: This is the second release this year from Maison Louis Jadot's Oregon project—both wines are labeled Résonance, but this is the Willamette Valley cuvée, not the Résonance vineyard bottling. Some estate fruit is included, and it is a subtle and detailed wine, with pretty mulberry and pie-cherry fruit. Thirteen months in 20% new French oak adds light mocha highlights, and it is as smooth and refined as one might expect from master winemaker Jacques Lardière.

wine: Sauvion 2019 Domaine du Cléray Chardonnay (Val de Loire)
appellation: Val de Loire, Loire Valley, France
review: This particularly crisp Chardonnay is bright and fruity. Fresh apple and strong lemon flavors show strongly. Drink now.

With its aromas of aftershave and its flavor of lychee, this is hardly a typical Sauvignon Blanc. It does have some green highlights, but the main flavors here are sweet and rich, finishing with red currant acidity.

wine: Manuel Carvalho Martins 2016 Golpe Reserva White (Douro)
review: The high-altitude vineyards in the Vale do Olmo give this wine a cool edge that lifts the generous creamy texture and the mango and spice flavors. There is a mineral edge to this fine dense wine with its rich backdrop. Drink this wine now.

Here's a taut, steady Barbaresco Riserva with a meaty, fleshy quality to the texture that is backed by ripe aromas of cherry and dried blackberry. Leather, spice and cola come in at the end and the wine delivers a long, flavorful finish.

wine: Angove's 2005 Nine Vines Rosé Grenache-Syrah (South Australia)
review: Slightly soft, this really needs to be well chilled to give it additional refreshment value. Raspberry and mulberry flavors are simple and fruity, finishing a bit short. The blend is 70% Grenache, 30% Shiraz.

wine: Januik 2019 Sagemoor Vineyards Sauvignon Blanc (Columbia Valley (WA))
appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Ask Mike Januik what makes Washington Sauvignon Blanc so good and he gives a simple answer: the Sémillon. That's the case here, with the variety making up 20% of the wine and showing itself. Aromas of fig and spice are followed by textured flavors and a lingering finish.

There's no shortage of ripeness in this single-vineyard, somewhat hot and wild Toro. The nose is all spice, heat and simmering black fruit, and that's backed by a brooding, heaviy concentrated palate. Teetering on the precipice of overripe, this wine needs all the air and patience you can give it to muster elegance to match its power.

wine: Laudun Chusclan 2019 Les Petites Parcelles de Dolia Red (Laudun)
review: This is a plummy, concentrated blend of Grenache, Syrah and Carignan. Full bodied and framed by fine-grained, chalky tannins, it balances ripe flavors of black-cherry compote and plums against an earthen, stony undertow. At peak now–2025.

wine: Sobon Estate 2004 Rocky Top Zinfandel (Amador County)
appellation: Amador County, Sierra Foothills, California, US
review: Tastes overripe and raisiny, with a Porty finish. It's not quite sweet and not quite dry, but falls awkwardly in the middle.

appellation: Umpqua Valley, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
review: Dark and aromatic, this is a svelte mix of plum, mocha, briary blackberry and cut tobacco. Extra bottle age has softened but not tamed its feral wildness. This is a potent and expressive wine that sets a new standard for Southern Oregon Dolcetto.
Aromas of pressed white flower and a hint of stone fruit lead the nose. The simple palate offers subtle green apple and unripe yellow peach alongside bright acidity.

This blend of Merlot, Cabernet Sauvignon and Cabernet Franc boasts aromas of underbrush, ripe dark berry and tobacco. The concentrated, full-bodied palate delivers blackberry jam, cedar and espresso alongside chewy, fine-grained tannins. Drink now–2025.

wine: Lynskeys Wairau Peaks 2003 Single Vineyard Gewürztraminer (Marlborough)
review: Varietally correct, but also somewhat subdued, with muted lychee and rose-petal aromas and flavors backed by pear-like fruit. Finishes a little short and without much spice.

wine: Santa Barbara Winery 2011 Reserve Chardonnay (Sta. Rita Hills)
appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
review: Oaky flavors of buttered toast and butterscotch dominate this simple Chardonnay. It has ripe flavors of pineapples, mangoes and peaches.

Made predominantly with Sangiovese and small amounts of Cabernet Sauvignon and Merlot, this offers pretty aromas of blue flower, red berry, menthol and dark spice. The bright straightforward palate offers dried red cherry, clove and a hint of espresso alongside lithe tannins.

From the Circeo appellation in Lazio (Central Italy), this blend of Trebbiano (50%), Malvasia and Chardonnay opens with sticky aromas of honey, ripe peach and candied apricot. The wine feels heavy and waxy in the mouth and could use an extra boost of acidity.

Ripe, rich and rubbery, and seemingly just hitting its stride. The nose offers earth, tar and lots of magnetic black fruit. Flavors of plum, blackberry and sugar beet are sweet yet not candied, while the finish deals espresso, mocha and wood dust. A very good Chilean Syrah, but one that should be judged among its Chilean brethren.

A beautifully fragrant but not overpowering oak aroma wafts up from the glass. The same sort of sophisticated spicy element joins in the flavors along with vivid black cherry notes supported by firm acidity, moderate tannins and medium body. It's built like a classic, but it costs much less.
An attractive, smoky wine, with soft fruits and some firm tannins. It has some of the right charm for a Margaux, with fresh red fruits and light acidity.

A subsidiary label from Coriole, the Toa Shiraz is a sturdy, seemingly ageable red filled with plum and cassis fruit and garnished by a hint of vanilla. It's earthy and solid, with a layered finish. Drink 2008–2012.

The panel agreed that Affinity is an excellent wine, but had very different reads on the wine's flavors and bouquet. Notes on the aromas range from fresh hay and cherry to grapes and watermelon rind; comments on palate flavors run the gamut from cherry liqueur and vanilla to fresh herb and blackberries. One to try for yourself, to be sure. 2,500 cases made; age 5–7 years.

wine: Germano Ettore 2011 del Comune di Serralunga d'Alba  (Barolo)
review: Aromas of mature berry, menthol, licorice, cooking spice and a balsamic note lead the nose. The firm palate is still tightly wound but already offers wild cherry, white pepper, grilled herb, tobacco and anise. It's balanced and fresh, with ripe but youthfully bracing tannins. Drink after 2019.

appellation: Applegate Valley, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
review: A vibrantly aromatic wine with notes of apricot, toast, nutty spices and cream displaying both detail and complexity. The palate is full-bodied yet still shows restraint with fruit and smoky flavors that keep the interest level high through the lingering finish.

wine: Domäne Wachau 2018 Terrassen Smaragd Grüner Veltliner (Wachau)
review: A hint of beeswax and fir honey plays on the rather subtle nose. The concentrated palate then completes the vivid, intense picture with ripe lemon zestiness, crushed yarrow fragrance and a salty, yeasty core. A pithy, zesty texture is a fitting backdrop. Snappy freshness adds welcome tone.

appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
review: Smells inviting, with a lush, drink-me cherry, blackberry and spice richness, but then turns harsh in the mouth, with high acidity and a dry herbal quality. Cheese, olive oil and beef will soften and sweeten it.

wine: Lynch 2002 Lynch Knoll Vineyard Syrah (Spring Mountain District)
appellation: Spring Mountain District, Napa, California, US
review: This Syrah aims high. It's dry, rich and full-bodied, with rich tannins and oak, and is fruity enough for the core of cassis to develop for several years. On the other hand, it has a sharp finish that may crack this wine up before the tannins fall out.

wine: Chic Barcelona NV Brut Métode Tradicional Sparkling (Cava)
