review: Bready white-fruit aromas are slightly briny, while this feels basic and quaffable. Lime and yellow-apple flavors are calm and pleasant on a mild finish.

wine: Brian Carter 2006 Abracadabra Red Red (Columbia Valley (WA))
appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Sappy, tannic and loaded with plum and blueberry, some cassis and chocolate. A good follow-up to the previous vintage, with very dark fruit, polished tannins and a lengthy, tasty finish of chocolate-covered cherries.

appellation: Dundee Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: Made in the classic Champagne method, this young, racy bubbly is a 50/50 blend of Pinot Blanc and Pinot Noir. It's tart and tangy, with flavors principally of grapefruit and lemon.

appellation: Edna Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: The underlying wine here is so good in fruity flavor and zesty acidity, you have to wonder why the winery piled so much new oak on top. The Chard is dominated by caramel, vanilla cream and butterscotch.
This wine is soft, with ripe white fruits that give it weight while keeping enough freshness. A touch of spice adds interest to the gentle fruitiness of this ready-to-drink wine.

appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
review: Winemaker Larry Schaffer proudly explores lesser-used varieties such as Cinsault, and makes compelling arguments in their favor. This bottling from Camp 4 Vineyard shows fresh and dried strawberry and slightly sour plum on the nose with a touch clove and dried ginger. The palate offers cranberry and hibiscus with red licorice spice, presented with lively acidity.

wine: Quinta Vale D. Maria NV Lote No 17 Reserva  (Port)
review: While this is categorized as a somewhat lowly Reserva Port, it has much more to it. From its rich field-blend old vine origins, it proclaims richness, spice, dried fruits and the ability to age. Drink now, but it will be even better from 2021.

wine: Robert Weil 2014 Kiedrick Turmburg Spätlese Riesling (Rheingau)
review: Sweet and savory go hand-in-hand in this intensely smoky, yet penetratingly fruity wine. It's a deeply mineral Spätlese, marked by dark, dusty streaks of slate, yet brimming with vibrant tangerine and peach flavors. A spike of electric acidity leads a long, long finish.

wine: Santa Carolina 2011 Reserva de Familia Carmenère (Rapel Valley)
review: Foresty aromas of olive, black fruit and cardamom are brusque but solid. The palate is compact, narrow and firm, with grabby tannins that are soluble. Flavors of forest floor, herbal berry and a slight bitterness end with an aftershock of herb, black olive and mint.

wine: Pastoral 2013 The Woodlark Dineen Vineyard Riesling (Yakima Valley)
appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: A first release from this new winery from long-time winemaker Rob Owen, this brings an appealing aroma profile of lime, slate and white peach. It drinks off dry (20g/L residual sugar) with abundant stone-fruit flavors that show good depth and intensity.
Firm and solid, this has a new-wood smoothness underneath the dark tannins. It is concentrated and dense, and the blackberry and plum skin flavors provide a fruity, juicy aftertaste.

A year's maturation and wood aging have produced this smooth, rich wine. The tannins are integrated into the red fruits that burst out of the glass. Aromatic and spicy, the wine is still full of young fruitiness and will be better from late 2017.

Lust is one of the seven deadly sins, and this tiny-production wine from Michael David is a fitting adjunct to the winery's Seven Deadly Zins offering. Spicy, perfumed oak aromas and equally spicy oak flavors accompany deep tones of black cherry and dark chocolate. The wine has a thick coating of tannins that helps support all the richness and elevated body.

Like all of winemaker Kevin Mitchell's Shirazes, this is full-bodied and lushly textured. The point of difference here is the fruit character, which leans toward black olives and espresso, with just enough stewed fruit to provide cushioning. Finishes long and velvety, hinting at vanilla. Drink now–2012.

appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: Aromas of underripe elderberry, black currant, sweet smoke and chocolate cake make for an intriguing (if unfamiliar) nose on this bottling from a new producer in Atascadero. Ripe flavors of prune ice cream, figs and raisins show on the sip, which shows decent acid and texture.

Smoke, burnt toast and vanilla aromas are all indicative of a full-fledged barrel regimen, but that's O.K., because the raspberry fruit can handle it. This wine has near-perfect structure: The acidity is bracing but stops short of being sharp, while the tannins are firm but friendly. By the time winter rolls around, this should be just about ready.

Cortes de Cima was one of the earliest producers of Syrah in Alentejo. The style is full of ripe fruit, structure and a fine juiciness. Touches of spice are a reminder of the natural flavors of the grape. With its tannins, it will age and can be drunk now– 2018.

appellation: Central Coast, Central Coast, California, US
review: Here's a Rhône blend that's full of life and zest. It's a clean, muscular sipper that completely satisfies with tannicly inspired flavors of blackberries, black currants, dark chocolate and pepper. A fine country-style wine with elements of elegance.

appellation: Applegate Valley, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
review: This small, family-owned, biodynamically farmed vineyard and winery is quickly becoming a southern Oregon cult producer. Certainly one of the finest Viogniers produced anywhere in the Northwest, this extraordinarily aromatic wine showers the palate with luscious and tangy lemon, pineapple, Satsuma orange and pear fruit flavors. Then the spices pile on, lending an exotic twist to a lengthy midpalate, and leading into a lightly toasty finish.

wine: Bonny Doon 2015 De Propio Gravitas White (North Coast)
appellation: North Coast, North Coast, California, US
review: Clean and crisp aromas of Asian pear, lemongrass, honeysuckle, passion fruit and green plum show on the nose of this blend of 64% Sémillon and 36% Sauvignon Blanc. The palate would go down very easy on a hot day, with just a touch of acid-carrying flavors of gardenia, guava, mango and kaffir lime leaf.

wine: Schröder & Schÿler 2017 Chartron la Fleur  (Bordeaux Blanc)
review: Aged for a few months in tank before bottling, this wine captures the herbal and ripe green-fruit character of Bordeaux Sauvignon Blanc. Its light acidity, fruitiness and crisp aftertaste all come together well. Drink now.

With a majority of Chardonnay from Grand Cru vineyards, this finely sculpted Champagne has crisp apple fruit and a steely, tight texture that suggests the need for bottle age. A light softness at the end rounds out this elegant wine.

wine: Undurraga 2019 Aliwen Sacred Tree Reserva Sauvignon Blanc (San Antonio-Maipo Valley)
review: Aromas of bell pepper, spring pea and green bean lead to a tight, snappy palate. That same fresh green quality translates to the flavor profile, while this is unwavering on a finish with pole bean and green pepper notes.

This blend of 80% Sangiovese, 10% Canaiolo and 10% Ciliegiolo opens with bright aromas of red berry, violet and a whiff of Mediterranean scrub. The vibrant, easygoing palate brings juicy black cherry, raspberry and a note of clove alongside bright acidity and supple tannins. Enjoy through 2016.

A blend of 55% Sangiovese, 30% Foglia Tonda, 10% Barsaglina and 5% Colorino, all organically farmed, this has aromas of black-skinned berries, leather and underbrush. The savory palate offers blackberry jam, tobacco and licorice alongside polished tannins. Drink through 2026.
A sweet-smelling Soave with simple aromas of peach, pear and honey presented in a very direct and immediate manner. It's thick and compact on the finish with loads of pineapple-like flavors.

This is a tannic, thick and deeply concentrated wine, robust in dried herb, jammy black cherry and cocoa powder. It packs a memorable punch, the savory earthiness providing contrast with subdued complexity.

Robert Mondavi winemaker Genevieve Janssens makes this wine, a small-production solo project that's worth seeking. The 83% Cabernet Sauvignon is sourced from Hendry Ranch and the 17% Cabernet Franc from Detert East Vineyard, a stone's throw from To Kalon. Impressively concentrated and lengthy, within a wealth of power, it is nuanced in black cherry, leather saddle and crushed rock, with the scent of violet never far behind.

wine: Le Petit Panier 2012 Chardonnay (Vin de France)
appellation: Vin de France, France Other, France
review: Soft and ripe, this is Chardonnay at its simplest. It has melon and pear flavors, light acidity and a rounded texture. Drink this easy wine now.

wine: McCall 2016 Marjorie's Corchaug Estate Rosé (North Fork of Long Island)
appellation: North Fork of Long Island, Long Island, New York, US
review: This blend of Merlot and Syrah is a plush sip full of bright black-cherry and berry flavors. It's soft on the midpalate with a ripe yielding fullness in mouthfeel.

This partner of the red Loios is a finely crafted wine, smooth, ripe, with just the right amount of freshness. There are flavors of peaches, almonds, a touch of lime juice, coming together well into a wine to drink this summer.

Iris, wild berry and a whiff of camphor aromas lead the nose. The tightly wound but straightforward palate offers raw sour cherry, cranberry, crushed herb and dark spice notes alongside bright acidity and assertive, rather grainy tannins. Drink after 2023.

wine: Brophy Clark 2004 Sauvignon Blanc (Santa Ynez Valley)
appellation: Santa Ynez Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: Here's another great Sauvignon that displays Santa Ynez's ripe flavors, crisp acidity and polished mouthfeel. Bursts with citrus, melon, fig and spearmint flavors, with a fancy veneer of new French oak. Finishes clean and a little sweet.

wine: Domaine Costa Lazaridi 2004 Amethystos Fumé Sauvignon Blanc (Drama)
review: Oak leads off the nose, then does most of the talking for this wine, with vanilla and toast notes throughout. Borders on too much oak, but some ripe white fruit shows through the toasty veneer, while time in the bottle has lent the wine an appealing creaminess.

wine: 00 Wines 2018 Richard Hermann Cuvée Chardonnay (Eola-Amity Hills)
appellation: Eola-Amity Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: A single new French oak barrel was given the distinction of producing this reserve-level wine. It's very much in the style of the previous vintage: incredibly rich, palate-coating and creamily delicious. Details of apple cobbler, Key lime pie and cantaloupe come through, and despite the overall power of the components, they all remain in focus and in proportion. The lengthy finish adds toasted hazelnuts and a hint of butter brickle.

A wonderfully aromatic touch of cinnamon perfumes the black plum and ripe blueberry notes in this wine. The palate is light and crunchy. With its cinnamon and intense fruit notes and residual sweetness, it's charmingly reminiscent of blueberry pie.

wine: Croix 2019 Floodgate Starscape Vineyard Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)
appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: A great depth of rich red cherry and plum lead to a brooding midpalate of full-bodied intensity and concentration, the wine well-integrated in terms of tannin and oak. Vanilla, baking spice and a note of cola close out the finish.

wine: Domìni Veneti 2000  Amarone della Valpolicella Classico
appellation: Amarone della Valpolicella Classico, Veneto, Italy
review: Beautiful density and color characterize this wine as do its layered notes of exotic spice, cardamom, curry and roasted nut. Plush, full red fruit and cherry build in intensity, especially on the palate, creating a rich wine with a firm backbone, smooth texture and dusty notes on the finish.

The nose beguiles, with scents of vanilla, freshly baked bread and wet stones that give way to tones of lemon and apricot on the tongue. This wine is light-bodied and crisp, a good summer sipper. Drink up over the next year, perhaps with a piece of grilled fish.

wine: Willowglen 2003 De Bortoli Wines Shiraz-Cabernet Sauvignon (South Eastern Australia)
appellation: South Eastern Australia, Australia Other, Australia
review: Plum and oak flavors and aromas, from top to bottom. Good red wine, built for the masses. Three-quarters Shiraz, with Cab making up the remainder.

wine: Left Coast 2016 Brut Rosé of Pinot Meunier Sparkling (Van Duzer Corridor)
appellation: Van Duzer Corridor, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: This exceptional sparkler weaves together complex, nutty flavors in a snappy, sexy, delicious and irresistible style. Apples are the core (forgive the pun) fruit, but that's just the beginning. Buttered popcorn, toasted hazelnuts, lemon oil and citrus-rind components can be sniffed and savored. This is the sort of wine that should be bottled in a one liter size—a standard 750 disappears way too soon.

wine: Nathalie Falmet NV Parcellaire ZH 302 Extra Brut Pinot Meunier (Champagne)
review: Pinot Meunier fermented in wood has produced a very dry wine, but one that almost has sweetness from the wood. That gives a marvelous balance of freshness with ripeness. This single-parcel wine with its baked-apple flavor is ready to drink.

appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: Easy to drink, this has enough sophistication to pair with rich scallop, tuna and lobster dishes. It's dry, although there's a lot of sweetly ripe orange, apricot and buttercream flavors, as well as caramelized oak. Brisk acidity fortunately brings a crisp, balanced edge.

wine: Davenport Cellars 2012 Snowflake Sauvignon Blanc-Semillon (Columbia Valley (WA))
appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Three quarters Sauvignon Blanc and the remaining Sémillon, this young and fresh wine has vivid citrus and grapefruit flavors leaning toward a hint of fresh cut pear. This is clean, crisp and leesy, with bracing acidity.

wine: Bodegas Valdemar 2004 Esencia Valdemar Rosé Garnacha (Rioja)
review: Heavy aromas with soft, dense flavors of apple skin and black plum. Slightly reduced on the finish, but surprisingly sharp and scouring on the tongue. There's a lot of zest and acid for a wine with a meatier flavor profile.

wine: Wild Diamond 2016 Dumb Luck Grenache (Lake County)
appellation: Lake County, Lake County, California, US
review: Smooth and rich, this full-bodied, warm and generous wine blends very ripe plum and raisin flavors on a gentle, broad texture. The flavors are deep and lingering, so it's quite a mouthful.

appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
review: Well-crafted, showing good ripeness for chilly upstate New York. Flavors run to cherry pie filling and fresh strawberries, turning to rhubarb on the crisp finish. Drink before 2012.
This wine is dry and firm, showing developing fruit under dark tannins. Big plum and berry flavors are ripe, juicy and fresh on the finish. Drink from 2019.

wine: Chateau St. Jean 2002 Cinq Cepages Cabernet Sauvignon (Sonoma County)
review: Aloof and tannic now. It's very dry, and those tannins lock in and cry out for something to melt them. It's best to decant this wine many hours in advance of drinking it, but it should develop well over the next eight to ten years.

wine: Podere Guado al Melo 2007 Jassarte Red (Toscana)
review: Made with a blend of Mediterranean and Caucasian grape varieties, Jassarte shows a green note of medicinal herb with forest berry and bramble. The wine is tight, bright and nicely acidic on the close.

wine: The Girls in the Vineyard 2012 Cabernet Sauvignon (Red Hills)
appellation: Red Hills, Lake County, California, US
review: This is a full-bodied and moderately tannic wine, smelling smoky, minty and fruity. It tastes concentrated and feels firm and nicely tannic on the tongue. Not overly ripe, it doesn't scream for attention but will make a really nice bottle for dinner.

Underbrush, violet, wild berry, menthol and sweet pipe tobacco aromas lead the way on this vibrant wine. The sleek palate doles out juicy wild cherries, baking spices and crushed herbs, while fresh acidity and a network of polished tannins provide backup. Drink 2016–2025.

This Muscat offers luscious honey, lemon and tropical fruit on the nose, with viscous waves of lemon, pineapple and warming spice on the palate. Not overly complex but certainly appealing. Pair with creamy cheeses and fruit.
Light in body, with flavors of cherries, cola, mint and peppery spices, this Pinot is dry and silky. It has a sharpness through the finish that suggests a bit of unripeness or stemminess.

appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: Shows the ripeness and oakiness that have characterized previous vintages, but considerably greater structure. The jammy pears and pineapples are there, but the wine isn't as sweet as last year, and is firmer in acidity. Good value for the price.

wine: Tenuta Argentiera 2013 Poggio ai Ginepri Red (Bolgheri)
review: A blend of Cabernet Sauvignon and Syrah, this easygoing rosato doles out bright red cherry and pomegranate flavors alongside bright acidity. It's simple but well made.

appellation: Rosé de Loire, Loire Valley, France
review: With Cabernet Franc in the blend, this dry rosé is structured and peppery, lifted by a youthful burst of acidity. Red fruits and freshness show at the end. Drink now.

wine: Louis Bouillot NV Perle d'Aurore Rosé Brut  (Crémant de Bourgogne)
review: With its strawberry flavor and tight acidity, this is an attractive, clean sparkling wine. It has just the right balance between acidity and bright fruit, leaving a textured aftertaste.

wine: Ferraton Père et Fils 2009 La Source  (Saint-Joseph)
review: Ripe black cherries with a hint of garrigue mark the nose of this attractively plump red from Ferraton. The fruit dominates, but there's just enough savory complexity to make it interesting, with a firm yet silky finish. Drink now–2017.

wine: Adelsheim 2015 Nicholas Vineyard Pinot Noir (Chehalem Mountains)
appellation: Chehalem Mountains, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: This light wine does not reflect the ripeness of the vintage. The fruit flavors are thin, and what is most dominant are autumnal hints of bark, dried leaf and clean earth. Though aged 10 months in one-third new French oak, little barrel influence is evident in the flavors.

wine: Beaulieu Vineyard 1997 Signet Collection Sangiovese (Napa Valley)
review: Soft, generous, and fruity, with seductive sweet fruit flavors and silky tannins. A very typical North Coast style: smooth, light-bodied, with just a touch of oak in the background. Ripe, sweet, fruity and simple.

It's labeled Cabernet-Merlot, but the reality is that the Merlot content is less than 10%. Still, it must bring something positive to the blend, as this is more richly textured and lush than Balnaves' straight Cabernet Sauvignon. Dark aromas and flavors sing gracefully, offering hints of chocolate, anise, cassis, coffee and spice. Finishes long, with velvety tannins; drink now–2015, possibly longer.

wine: Pelvillain Frères 2014 Zee Original Rosé (Côtes du Lot)
appellation: Côtes du Lot, Southwest France, France
review: Bright pink in color, this is a soft, ripe and fruity wine. It has a light texture that supports the raspberry flavors. A delicate cut of acidity comes through at the end. Drink now.

A touch of reduction still clings to the nose but underneath, ripe pear notes peek through. The palate of this wine is mellow, with a lovely edge of baking spice and a rounded mouthfeel and texture. Concentration becomes apparent on the dry, bright finish.

appellation: Umpqua Valley, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
review: The very limited reserve bottling sees two years of barrel age in 100% new French oak. In this vintage, there isn't quite enough fruit ripeness to match that treatment. The light elegant fruit flavors of pomegranate and wild berry are a bit overpowered by the darker smoky oak flavors. A stiff streak of espresso runs through the finish. Best to drink this now through 2020.

Inviting aromas of black-skinned berries, forest floor and leather lead the way. The polished, full-bodied palate offers blackberry jam, licorice and tobacco alongside fine-grained tannins. Drink 2023–2029.

wine: Te Awanga 2019 Wildsong Wildflower Vineyard Sauvignon Blanc (Hawke's Bay)
review: This is a vibrant, aromatic Sauvignon from Hawkes Bay that leads with notes of bright passionfruit, grapefruit, lime blossom, flint and grass. It's tight and focused, with a crisp acidity, a chalky yet slippery texture and zingy, juicy fruit right to the finish.

A spice driven wine, full of ripe flavors, wild flower honey and intense acidity. This is a beautiful wine, its richness totally balanced by a fresher side. Age this wine for a long time. Drink from 2018.

This blend of Pinots from Aloxe-Corton, Chorey, Savigny and Marsannay is slightly lean and herbal. Has some nice black cherry fruit, then finishes on a teal-like note with some drying tannins. Try with rare beef or lamb.

appellation: Vino Nobile di Montepulciano, Tuscany, Italy
review: Mature black-skinned fruit, fragrant purple flower and French oak aromas waft out of the glass along with balsamic notes of eucalyptus. Firmly structured, the rather lean, austere palate features dried cherry, pomegranate, oak-driven spice and roasted coffee bean alongside assertive, fine-grained tannins that leave a drying finish.

wine: Dr. Pauly Bergweiler 2014 Bernkasteler alte Badstube am Doctorberg Spätlese Riesling (Mosel)
designation: Bernkasteler alte Badstube am Doctorberg Spätlese
review: Jolts of honey, lemon and lime introduce this animated Spätlese. It's forward and approachable with sunny tangerine and peach flavors, but maintains a nervous tension of acidity. The finish is brisk and tight.

wine: Domaine du Père Caboche 2017 Vieilles Vignes Elizabeth Chambellan Red (Châteauneuf-du-Pape)
review: Plump but pure in fruit, this blend of 88% Grenache, 10% Syrah and 2% Mourvèdre highlights intensely ripe boysenberry jam and raspberry flavors. Matured in a combination of large-format oak, concrete and stainless steel, it's luminous primary fruit is appealing in youth but rigid, drying tannins should meld nicely over the next few years. At peak now–2030.
The aromas offer notes of pear, lime, diesel and lime leaf, showing a bit of evolution. Just off-dry-drinking Nestea Lemon Iced tea flavors follow. The acid balances them out well.

wine: Moshin 2012 Rosalina Vineyard Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)
appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: Cherry and clove star in this vineyard-designate from a good vintage, in which the producer again aims low in terms of ripeness. It makes for a somewhat one-dimensional experience once the initial aromas and bite of flavor dissipate on the palate.
A heavy, almost sweet and artificially spicy character makes this wine polarizing. It tastes extremely oaky, and thick and sticky on the palate.

Whiffs of sandalwood and violet lend a sultry perfume to ripe, ruddy black plums and cherries on this voluptuous red. In this mouthwatering blend of Grenache (75%), Cinsault (5%) and Syrah (20%), the palate is unctuously fruity but freshly balanced by streaks of red cassis acidity and a lingering granitic finish. Lovely already but should drink well through 2028.

Pale gold in color, this wine leads with notes of fresh apples, blossoms and honeycomb. The palate is prickly and refreshing, with a good lick of acidity and some texture and weight to prop it up. Drink now.

This well-sourced red is sweetly rounded and rich in tobacco, cedar and sage, with secondary notes of dark cherry and dried herb. Robust and powerfully built, it has rounded tannins and nicely integrated oak.

From one of Australia's most treasured historic estates, located in the cool, remote Grampians region of western Victoria, this light, bright Pinot is the color of raspberry juice. Gorgeously perfumed, and seemingly fermented with a fair amount of whole-bunch fruit, it's like squeezing the juice from a fistful of wild, freshly picked strawberries and raspberries; stalks, stems, cinnamon and minerals along for the stroll. The palate is equally vibrant, like biting into those same fresh berries; the texture silky, strung with beads of stalky, spicy tannins.

wine: Derby 2014 Sparkling Pinot Noir (San Luis Obispo County)
appellation: San Luis Obispo County, Central Coast, California, US
review: There's a powerful effervescence on the nose of this bottling, starting with aromas of pink lemon, red plum and rose petal. The palate is tangy, with tight nectarine, tart red plum and a searing acidity.

Crushed floral aromas, berry-infused tea and cherry candy aromas give this wine a sweet profile. The palate, however, is anything but. It pounds with toasty black fruit, licorice and fiery menthol. The feel is a bit tannic but not terribly harsh, so maybe another three to five years will serve it well.

appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: This 100% varietal wine hails from Canyon Vineyard Ranch and Oasis vineyards. It's tart and puckering with notes of cocoa, raspberries and licorice and a firm squeeze of tannins. Barrel notes of vanilla and dill linger on the finish.

Apple, melon and citrus aromas. Offers pretty citrus and apple flavors, and a spicy finish. Tastes like it has some small percentage of a fruity lesser varietal blended in. Still, it's about as good as California Chardonnay gets at this price. Best Buy.

appellation: El Dorado, Sierra Foothills, California, US
review: Intricately woven, complex flavors are braced by firm tannins and bright acidity in this Rhône-style red blend. It is full in body without being fat, blending earthy, meaty flavors with black pepper, blackberry and roasted plum for a subtle but compelling outcome.

wine: Château La Joya 2000 Reserva Malbec (Colchagua Valley)
review: This is the winery's first-ever crack at Malbec, and the wine shows the grape's telltale blueberry and graham-cracker sweetness. But there's also some peanut and heavy earth in there, too, neither of which does much for what otherwise is a commendable wine.

wine: Henri de Villamont 2009 Clos St-Jean Premier Cru  (Chassagne-Montrachet)
review: This is aromatic, with ripeness that balances the bright green and white fruits. Wood and spice notes are followed by a touch of lemon jelly and minerally acidity. It's a wine that is still developing, waiting for the ripe fruit of the vintage to surface.

wine: Global Wines 2013 Casa de Santar Reserva Red (Dão)
review: This is a strong statement of ripe, powerful fruit and dense tannins. So although the wine is now five-years-old, it still seems young. Its structure, from the rich Touriga Nacional that dominates the blend, is firm and a solid base for the black-currant fruits. Drink from 2019.

A simple but by no means unattractive Pinot, dry and silky, with pleasant cola, cranberry and sandalwood flavors. Shows the sophistication of the winery's single-vineyard bottlings, minus the concentration.
Fresh and with attractive perfumed fruit, this wine has a lift to it. Fresh citrus and white-apple flavors are enhanced by the wine's spiciness and crisp aftertaste. Drink from late 2021.

wine: Rutz 2002 Burnside Vineyard Reserve Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)
appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: There's lots of ripe berry flavor in this Pinot, whose mouthfeel has a certain rustic character. It's a heavy wine, dark, thick and jammy, with a chocolaty feel to the cherries and rhubarb pie flavors, although it's completely dry.

appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
review: Weighty yet crisp, with a bit more density than many of its neighbors, this Cabernet Franc offers up green pepper and spice flavors that rest on a carpet of soft tannins and a short, cherry-flavored finish. Try with roast pork in a fruit sauce. Drink now.

Passion fruit freshness fills the nose on this wine alongside honeysuckle notes. The palate comes in with rounded but balanced sweetness that emphasizes peachy fruit at the core, along with a pleasant, pithy texture. It is is medium dry and aromatic on the finish.

wine: River Ford 1999 Saint Clair Estate Sauvignon Blanc (Marlborough)
review: A very herbaceous nose and lean grapefruit and gooseberry flavor profile make this a fairly textbook rendition of this certain style of Sauvignon Blanc. The texture is quite crisp and the finish dry, with a pronounced lime quality. Very alive, and not a wine people will be ambivalent about.

Crimson red in the glass, this Swiss Pinot Noir has delightful aromas of ripe red cherries and farm-fresh raspberries. It is well balanced and has delicate flavors of raspberry, saddle leather, black cherry and baking spice. It is velvety smooth, with persistent touches of nutmeg and cinnamon on the finish.

Solid and intense, the first vintage of this wine to hit U.S. shores is an auspicious start. It's lush and juicy, with a nose- and palate-caressing black cherry, mocha cream and chocolate profile. This Colorino-Merlot blend successfully pushes all the pleasure buttons while maintaining structure and showing substance. With a long, dry finish sporting soft ripe tannins, this is tempting now, but will be best from 2004–2010. Cellar Selection.

wine: Case Paolin NV Brut  (Asolo Prosecco Superiore)
review: Made with organic grapes, this gentle sparkler opens with aromas of hay and white stone fruit. The dry, creamy palate offers green apple, pear and fennel before a saline close. Bright acidity lifts the fruity flavors.

wine: Domaine de Rosiers 2018 Coeur de Rose  (Côte Rôtie)
review: Sourced from the clay and iron-rich soils of the Côte Brune, there's a gorgeous mineral sheen that extends from nose to finish in this rich, penetrating Syrah (accented by 2% Viognier). Matured in 50% new oak, it's delicate in mouthfeel but sumptuous and concentrated in black plum and mulberry flavors. While seductive now for its vibrant, plummy flavors, it's a wine that should gain saltier, smokier nuances well through 2035.

appellation: Malvasia delle Lipari, Sicily & Sardinia, Italy
review: Here's a savory nectar made with late-harvested grapes—95% Malvasia delle Lipari and 5% Corinto Nero—that opens with aromas of dried stone fruit, nut and sweet spice. The palate doles out apricot, fig, hazelnut and a dollop of acacia honey while fresh acidity brightens the rich flavors and prevents it from being overly sweet.

SerraMonte is a blockbuster expression from Southern Italy with inky, dark concentration and beautifully intense aromas of black fruit, cherry liqueur, dried prunes and Indian spice. The wine is pulsing with sweet fruit flavors and boasts thick, muscular density and high, but well integrated, alcohol.

appellation: Santa Ynez Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: There's a funky streak to the nose of this bottling, starting with aromas of pomegranate, baked soil and smoked wood. That wild funk comes through on the palate as well, with smoky red fruits, gamy lamb and damp earth flavors.

Big boned and fruit forward, this is a sizable wine in style and weight, with waves of cherry and strawberry greeting the palate. It shows its coastal provenance in its savory seasonings of clove, black tea and sage.

This robust blend of 85% Aglianico and 15% Pallagrello Nero has aromas of toasted oak, stewed prune and baked plum. The palate offers bracing tannins and a blackberry core alongside notes of black pepper, vanilla and graphite.

appellation: Mokelumne River, Central Valley, California, US
review: This bold and full-bodied wine has ripe jammy Port-like aromas, plump blackberry flavors and a rich, almost-sweet, palate impression. It's certainly mouth coating and tooth staining.
Pulpy aromas of applesauce are a bit flat. This feels chunky on the palate, with low acidity. White-fruit flavors suggest canned peach and pear, and it tastes sweet on the finish.
This lacks much in the way of fruit, but what's there is green. That said, there's something in the nose that seems past ripeness also, and the bitter phenolic finish does nothing to help.

wine: La Mannella 2006 I Poggiarelli  (Brunello di Montalcino)
review: Earthy overtones of wild mushroom and moist soil add pretty dimension to this classy Brunello. At the core of I Poggiarelli, however, are black fruit, sweet spice, toasted nut and long-lasting black cherry flavors.
Aged in stainless steel, this faint SB is herb-y and slightly grassy. Sweetness on the midpalate sticks around before the quick finish.

appellation: Santa Lucia Highlands, Central Coast, California, US
review: Bright cherry and spice flavors dominate, followed by racy cinnamon, tea and pepper notes.  Moderate body and silky texture.

wine: Bisol NV Cartizze  (Prosecco Superiore di Cartizze)
appellation: Prosecco Superiore di Cartizze, Veneto, Italy
review: An emphasis on yellow fruit, pear and measured banana almost makes you think Bisol employs a different yeast selection on their Cartizze Cru. The wine is thick and creamy, with excellent opulence and just the right measure of sweetness.

appellation: Lake County, Lake County, California, US
review: Spice and anise notes pepper stewed fruit on the nose. The palate delivers straightforward, soft red fruit couched in a dusty blanket. Soft and supple; an easy drinker.

A strong showing, with tones of blueberry and iodine interwoven with animal and barnyard scents on the nose. The palate shows red fruit flavors with flowers at the back and ends on a leather note. Refined tannins allow for immediate consumption.

wine: Adega Cooperativa do Cartaxo 2011 Xairel Red (Tejo)
review: A wine with a strange mix of fruitiness and lean, green flavors. There's some black currant coming through the stalky character. The finish is juicy, but it's hard to find pleasure here.

appellation: Central Coast, Central Coast, California, US
review: Nice and dry, and although it's a little sharp and tart in green mint, this inexpensive wine offers plenty of black cherry and cocoa flavors wrapped into smooth tannins.

wine: Rui Roboredo Madeira 2015 Castello d'Alba Colheita Red (Douro)
review: The wine is soft, and full of fruit with attractive spicy black currant flavors. Dominated by the rounded Tinta Roriz, it is an easy wine to drink young.

wine: González Byass NV Apostoles Palo Cortado Viejo Sherry (Jerez)
review: A unique and individual style of Sherry, even among palo cortados. It's dark amber in color, with a pungent mix of aromas that include molasses, raw brown sugar, chocolate and campfire. Feels fresh on the tongue, with coffee, dark chocolate and core peach and citrus flavors.

wine: Viña Casablanca 2010 Cefiro Reserva Chardonnay (Casablanca Valley)
review: Opens with toast and vanilla aromas along with baked apple and oak. The mouthfeel is solid, while the flavors blend barrel resin, pear, banana and macadamia nut. Finishes healthy and clean.

wine: Fernwood 2007 Estate Grown Redwood Retreat Vineyards Cabernet Sauvignon (Santa Cruz Mountains)
appellation: Santa Cruz Mountains, Central Coast, California, US
review: You'll find thick tannins and soft acidity in this wine, which offers direct, jammy blackberry and cassis flavors. It's quite a rich wine that seems best now and for the next few years.

An 100% estate-driven wine, this features intense notes of spicy raspberry and strawberry, full and inviting in aromatics, while maintaining a subdued nature. Earthy tannins rise up midway through the wine, providing strength and structure before finishing long and lean.
Pfister's Riesling is classic, simple and fruity. With its light mineral texture, tight acidity and delicate lemon and grapefruit flavors, it's totally ready to drink.

wine: Ardiri 2012 Estate Grown Vineyard Select Pinot Noir (Chehalem Mountains)
appellation: Chehalem Mountains, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: Toasty and broad at first sip, the oak flavors outrun the fruit. Thin cranberry and tart raspberry notes are carried into a quick, chocolaty finish.

wine: Albert Morot 2015 Les Teurons Premier Cru  (Beaune)
review: This structured firm wine is full of tannins as well as ripe fruit. It is concentrated, showing smoky wood flavors as well as plenty of red berries. The wine will develop slowly, with the rich fruits coming through to give a generous wine. Drink from 2024.

wine: Jerusalem Wineries 2013 3400 Premium Cabernet Sauvignon (Judean Hills)
review: Deep ruby in color, this wine has a nose of black cherry and green bell pepper. The well-balanced flavor profile features notes of cherry, strawberry, smoked meat, Mediterranean herbs and eucalyptus. A network of generous tannins supports a persistent sensation of brightness on the side palate and smoky notes across the center of the tongue.
This very ripe interpretation of Touriga Nacional brings out a dark black-plum flavor, which hides the grape's natural tannins. It is chunky, with powerful, forward fruit.

appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: A stony, wet cement-like aromas meets Anjou lime and jasmine touches on the nose of this bottling from a winery recently acquired by O'Neill Vintners. The palate leads with a dollop of acidity and slowly releases lemongrass, Asian pear and ripe nectarine flavors, cut with a tense streak of lime.

wine: The Winemaker's Loft 2007 Chardonnay-Pinot Gris White (Yakima Valley)
appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: A fresh, vibrant white wine that shows the touch and talent of winemaker Michael Haddox. It's a fine match of grapes, with bright (and co-fermented) flavors of cut pear and apple, a leesy, textural body, and a lingering finish that refreshes the palate without being tiring.

Floral scents of peach blossom, broom and a whiff of pear mingle in the glass. On the bright palate, toasted almond and aromatic herb give interest to the core of Golden Delicious apple and citrus. It's refreshing and balanced with vibrant acidity.

Pungent and nettle-like upfront, but those leafy elements are balanced by bright grapefruity flavors on the palate. It's medium in body and fresh, clean and appealing on the finish. Hard to do better at the price.

Hard spice, licorice, raisin and pastry aromas come with just a spot of green. The palate is lush, smooth and dark, with black plum, herbal berry, black olive and bell pepper flavors. Smooth on the finish, with tobacco and herbal length.

This is a rich, smoky red-fruit-flavored wine. One of three wines produced by the estate that was created by the late Anne-Claude Leflaive of Domaine Leflaive in Burgundy, it is made from biodynamically grown grapes. Wood aged, it shows spice as well as the cool fruitiness that gives the wine both its crispness and aging potential. Drink from 2018.

A kosher Bonarda with hard, spicy aromas but not a whole lot of fruit. Lean and peppery in the mouth, with toasty, bitter finishing flavors. Deep diggers will find some black cherry in the center. Imported by Abarbanel Wine Company.

A Cab lover's Merlot, this wine is massively constructed, a behemoth of tobacco-laced blue fruit and smoke, nearing pie-like proportion. With time and/or a decant, it'll reveal pretty violet on the nose, and take on a sultry juiciness to overcome its weight. Lay this baby down through 2022.

wine: Lamoreaux Landing 2011 Estate Bottled Gewürztraminer (Finger Lakes)
appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
review: Delicate aromas of apple blossoms and fresh pears belie a surprisingly textured, mouthfilling Gewürztraminer, with concentrated stone-fruit flavors and a bristling minerality. Drink now.
This straw-colored Traminer has aromas of honeysuckle, lime zest and lemon blossom. Flavors of cantaloupe, honeydew melon and kiwi unfold on the palate and carry through to the fruity finish.

wine: Schug 2001 Heritage Reserve Cabernet Sauvignon (Sonoma Valley)
review: This is a balanced and elegant Cab. It's almost muted in the quiet interplay of cassis fruit, smoky oak and rich tannins. It's the sort of wine you reach for with real food, as opposed to tasting competitions, and it's likely to age well through the decade.

wine: Fess Parker 2017 Fiddlestix Vineyard Pinot Noir (Sta. Rita Hills)
appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
review: Soft yet dark aromas of black raspberry sorbet are lifted by star anise and wild mint aromas on the nose of this bottling. There is a rich boysenberry depth to the palate, alongside fennel pollen, rounded baking spice and a plum-skin tang.

wine: Telmo Rodríguez 2001 Molino Real Mountain Wine Moscatel (Málaga)
review: There's not a region or grape type that Telmo Rodríguez won't tackle, and here he's on to Moscatel in the deep south. This wine exhibits lilac aromas with hints of smoked ham and hard cheese. It's not a perfect bouquet, but it is intriguing. In addition, look for a bulky but rewarding palate featuring chewy sweet fruit and moderate acidity.

What a roll Peju has been on with Bordeaux wines. This is the first Petit Verdot I've had from them, and it's very good, given the variety's inherent limitations. It's dark, very dry, full-bodied and intensely tannic, with currant flavors. You could try stashing it away for a decade, or drink it now with a well-marbled steak.

This single-vineyard designate is labeled simply Oregon, but is actually Dundee Hills. Somewhat dilute fruit flavors suggest pomegranate and tart strawberries. Despite 18 months in half new French oak, the wood does not overwhelm the fruit, and the wine actually improves overnight. Give it a good decanting for optimum drinking.

appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: This wine has a bright, spicy attack in the aroma that is unmistakably Gewurztraminer. The fruit is ripe, almost fat, with a strong, spicy flavor in the mid-palate and a heaviness in the finish. There is also a little bit of heat, and a slight impression of sweetness from the fruit.

wine: Muscardini 2010 Monte Rosso Vineyard Sangiovese (Sonoma Valley)
review: This wine is hot, soft and simple, with blackberry jam, chocolate and anise flavors. The fruit is enormously concentrated. Inelegant, but it will partner well with barbecue.

appellation: Lambrusco di Sorbara, Central Italy, Italy
review: One of the best Lambruscos out there, this delicious, vibrant wine opens with enticing scents of wild red berry, yellow stone fruit, citrus blossom and a yeasty, comforting whiff of pastry dough. Made by carrying out the secondary fermentation in the bottle, the dry, delicious palate delivers pink grapefruit, crushed strawberry and tangerine alongside crisp acidity and a saline note.

wine: Feudo di Santa Tresa 2006 Rina Ianca White (Sicilia)
review: Creamy and smooth with soft oak shadings, this balanced 70-30 blend of full-bodied Grillo and fragrant Viognier is redolent of honey and bee's wax with softer tones of apricot and pear in the background. The wine has good density and structure but ends on a bright, crisp note.

wine: Albert Morot 2016 Les Bressandes Premier Cru  (Beaune)
review: A concentrated, ripe wine with the potential for great fruit as well as structure, this already offers bold fruits. With its tannins and juicy red-berry flavors, it will be a fine wine from 2023.

Made with 85% Merlot and 15% Syrah, this polished red has inviting aromas of mature black-skinned berry, purple flower, Mediterranean brush and a whiff of sea breeze. Taut and juicy, the elegantly structured palate doles out ripe Marasca cherry, blackberry, ground pepper and a salty mineral note framed in firm fine-grained tannins. A hint of toasted hazelnut marks the finish.

A dark berry aroma comes with a distinct whiff of green. On the palate, the wine feels crisp and clampy, while the flavors of spicy, herbal plum and berry teeter on the edge of being green. It tastes briary and like tomato sauce on the finish.
A bouquet of jasmine, honeysuckle and green apple entice you in to sip of this refined Traminer. There are balanced flavors of ginger, passion fruit and apricot and a clean, acidic finish.
Spicy cherry aromas lead to similar flavors on the palate—cherries, spice and plums. Finishes a little thick and portlike. Very enjoyable overall. How often do you find a very good Aussie Zin?
Wayward aromas are earthy and not terribly fresh. This has a dark tint and a clunky mouthfeel. Dry peppery flavors of stale citrus are briny.

Krug's releases have always shown a wonderful balance between fruit and maturity. This rosé, the 23rd blending, is no exception. The nutty character of a mature Champagne is there along with red fruits, intense acidity from Pinot Noir and impeccable balance at the end. The wine is ready to drink.

wine: Château des Jacques 2012 Clos du Grand Carquelin  (Moulin-à-Vent)
review: This powerful, single-vineyard wine is both fruity and structured. Dense tannins and dark cherry fruits are beautifully balanced with the wood aging. Wait to drink this wine until 2017.

wine: J. Christopher 2013 Lia's Vineyard Pinot Noir (Chehalem Mountains)
appellation: Chehalem Mountains, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: This begins with compelling aromas of rose petals and breakfast tea. Those tea-like tannins underscore an elegant wine with subtle fruit flavors. A delicate dance partners the fresh cherry fruit, the baking spices and other barrel-influenced accents, soft but penetrating tannins and the lightly chalky minerality. Lovely already, it should continue to drink well through 2025.

A semisweet wine, all currants and ripe fruit. The sweetness comes from superripe fruit, giving a delicious balance with the acidity. Flavors of yellow apples, tarragon and all-spice come together in an exciting finish.

wine: Hungry Hawk 2018 Elliot Ranch Reserve Albariño (San Diego County)
appellation: San Diego County, South Coast, California, US
review: Clean aromas of chalk, Asian pear and melon are crisp and pure on the nose, which ends on a slight hint of almond. Sliced green pear, tight nectarine and a tiny touch of toast flavors show on the pleasantly crisp palate.

wine: Domaine Louis Moreau 2012 Vaillons Premier Cru  (Chablis)
review: Yellow fruit aromas promise richness. That's delivered with the apricot and mango flavors, balanced acidity and a ripe while crisp aftertaste. The wine is ripe, full in the mouth. It's still young, and will be better drunk from 2017.

wine: Colin 2001 Grand Cru Blanc de Blancs Brut Chardonnay (Champagne)
designation: Grand Cru Blanc de Blancs Brut
review: Mainly from grand cru vineyards in Cramant, this is a ripe, smooth, creamy wine whose minerality is subordinated to rich white fruits and a pure, dense structure. Despite its relative youth, the richness means this wine is ready to drink now.

wine: Viticultori Associati Canicatti 2008 Aynat Nero d'Avola (Sicilia)
review: Aynat is a ripe and chewy expression of Nero d'Avola with aromas of milk chocolate, moist tobacco and chewy ripe cherry. It is a rich, dense wine that is also pleasingly simple and genuine at the same time.

wine: Catherine & Pierre Breton 2017 Trinch! Cabernet Franc (Bourgueil)
review: Rabelais, the lover of all things good in life, used the word “trinch” like “cheers.” This welcoming wine comes from a blend of gravel and clay soils. Made to drink young, it is packed with red fruits from biodynamically grown grapes. Fresh acidity and just a modicum of tannins have produced a wine to drink now.

wine: Daou 2017 Solomon Hills Vineyard Pinot Noir (Santa Maria Valley)
appellation: Santa Maria Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: Black raspberry aromas are lifted by herbal touches of bay leaf and wild thyme on the nose of this bottling—one of the first Pinot Noirs for the Daou brothers. It's medium bodied on the palate with bright raspberry fruit, herbal touches of marjoram and pencil shavings and a strong acid that carries into the finish.

This is a delicate spicy wine despite its robust ripeness and brawny underside. Compost and brambly brush combine with blackberry and an undeniably delicious streak of white pepper, making for a complex, complete wine that's enjoyable from start to finish.

wine: Tamarack Cellars 2009 Seven Hills Vineyard Reserve Red (Walla Walla Valley (OR))
appellation: Walla Walla Valley (OR), Oregon Other, Oregon, US
review: This is principally Cabernet, with just small amounts of Merlot and Petit Verdot in the blend. Still remarkably young and tightly-wound, it's showing tart cherries, violets and blueberries, along with bracing acidity and minerality. The finish is both elegant and intense, lingering long after the last sip.

wine: Dusted Valley 2006 BFM Red Red (Columbia Valley (WA))
appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Blow your Freaking Mind is what BFM stands for. It's a Bordeaux blend, mostly Merlot, with sharply-defined berry-flavored fruit, bright acidity and a fine focus. The mix of Wisconsin and French oak (60% new) gives it a pleasing, chocolaty finish.

If peach aromatherapy exists—that is, the purest, most concentrated smell of peach in a bottle—this nose is it. After a while, though, an acrylic-like aroma starts emerging, and the palate shows evidence of both acrylic and peach. Still, it's a worthwhile wine, but would have been better with the focus on the fruit. Imported by Australian Wine Connection.

Attractive gold color. Intense aromas of ripe stone fruit fruit. Strong earthy minerality and a hint of honeysuckle adding complexity. Broad persistent flavors across the palate with focused minerality and an earthy savoriness that is beautifully balanced with the ripe fruit. Crisp and taut with a long, layered finish.

Clumsy as an ox at first, but better with airing. This is your classic slightly herbal Carmenère, and in the folds you'll find soft berry fruit, copious oak and a certain creaminess that makes the mouthfeel plush. It's good if you like a fat, soft-tannin wine. But if tobacco and green notes turn you off, then it might be better to steer clear.

This Syrah has aromas recalling mature black-skinned berry, underbrush and a hint of smoke. The juicy palate offers black currant, clove and black pepper alongside polished tannins. Drink through 2027.

wine: De Loach 2010 Cool Coastal Vineyards Chardonnay (Russian River Valley)
appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: Great acidity and minerality in this elegant young wine. Doesn't show the rich concentration of De Loach's single-vineyard Chards, but then again, it costs far less. It's actually a good value for a dry, minerally and complex Russian River Chardonnay. Don't drink it too cold.

Delicate scents suggesting dark berry, moist soil and a whiff ground clove waft out of the glass. The fresh, light-bodied palate offers sour cherry and star anise alongside bright acidity and rather loose knit tannins. Drink through 2019.
Brisk acidity makes this white wine almost tingly. It's also exhibits light vanilla bean, white peach and pineapple flavors.

wine: Quanta Terra 2013 Grande Reserva Branco White (Douro)
review: This is a seriously wood-aged wine, sumptuous in its smooth and creamy texture. It has citrus, lime and really fresh acidity to balance the toast and rich fruitiness. Elegant and worth aging further. Drink from 2016.

Wood aging and low yields have given this rich wine its density and glossy, ripe potential. Two tannic grapes, Malbec and Tannat, together have given a striking structure while also bringing out swathes of black fruit. Drink this powerful wine from 2022.

wine: Santa Ema 2006 60/40 Reserve Barrel Select Cabernet Sauvignon-Merlot (Maipo Valley)
review: Syrupy on the nose, but also green at the core. This Cab-Merlot blend is a little disconnected in that it pushes both rich, syrupy characteristics as well as more snappy, red-fruit notes and herbal hints. In the end it finds a relatively happy place, but the pieces don't seem to fit perfectly together.

wine: Ingrid Groiss 2015 Pankraz Reserve Grüner Veltliner (Niederösterreich)
review: There is something that makes me think about a summer forest: Is it the fresh moss, the fresh green foliage, the implied ease and freshness of light green foliage on a warm day? The palate stuns with white pepper and purity and combines fruit ripeness with ballerina-like poise. Wonderful texture. Prepare to be moved.

There's already some petrol character to this attractive wine, which also has great acidity and a fine, bone- dry feel. On the palate, there are some intense currant flavors. A great food wine with good concentration. Imported by Kermit Lynch.

wine: Château Puyanché 2018  Francs Côtes de Bordeaux
appellation: Francs Côtes de Bordeaux, Bordeaux, France
review: Baked-apple and wood aromas show strongly in this ripe wine. Balancing the toastiness, the ripe fruits are complex, peach and apple flavors going along with the spice. Drink now.

wine: Hirsch Vineyards 2012 West Ridge Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)
review: In this wine, a mellow, aged character comes from subtle aromas that are part fruit, part earth and herb, and from the satiny smooth texture and almost overripe plum flavors. Neither tannic nor tart, the mouthfeel is soft and plush.

wine: André Tixier et Fils 2012 Millésimé Premier Cru Brut  (Champagne)
review: Based in Chigny-lès-Roses on the Montagne de Reims, this organic producer has made a well-structured vintage. Still young and showing a citrus and mineral texture from the 50% Chardonnay in the blend, the wine will develop well. Wait till 2022.

A fruitball of a Malbec, with bright, friendly aromas of berry, cola and cherry cough drop. It feels full, round and well balanced, with a black cherry flavor bearing a mild herbal underbelly. The finish is fruity without being heavy.

From densely planted vines, this is a ripe, very fruity wine, with low acidity, emphasizing the cream and pepper character of the grape. It is not the style of Grüner that can be drunk too young—give it another year to be at its optimum.

wine: Lapostolle 2009 Cuvée Alexandre Las Kuras Vineyard Made with Organic Grapes Syrah (Cachapoal Valley)
designation: Cuvée Alexandre Las Kuras Vineyard Made with Organic Grapes
review: Exotic, attractive aromas of blueberry, cardamom and sandalwood get this Syrah off on the right foot. It feels concentrated and jacked up, with fully ripe, creamy flavors of blackberry, cassis and pastry. This is a chewy, layered, dense and jammy New World Syrah ready to drink now–2014.

wine: Raats Family 2005 Original Chenin Blanc (South Africa)
review: One of South Africa's best with Chenin, Bruwer Raats has hit another home run with this unwooded wine. It kicks off with perfumed citrus aromas, then lets fly with lively almond-tinged flavors of orange and peach. Vibrant in the mouth with beautifully matching acidity, this is a wine that calls for food, but can certainly be enjoyed alone.
Fresh, crisp and fruity, this is a raspberry- and red currant-flavored wine that is featherlight and refreshing. It's a great summer wine.

wine: K Vintners 2013 Cattle King Upland Vineyard Syrah (Snipes Mountain)
appellation: Snipes Mountain, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: This wine is all about power and hedonism. Brooding dark fruit aromas meld with black licorice and lead to a seamless full-bodied blackberry and black-cherry flavors. It demands another sip.
Now owned by the Sancerre producer, Joseph Mellot, this estate is a standard bearer in Quincy. This wine's floral character and generous currant fruitiness is balanced by a tangy acidity and texture.

wine: Golan Heights Winery 2017 Yarden Cabernet Sauvignon (Galilee)
review: Violet red to the eye, this wine has aromas of black currant and clove. It offers a panoply of bright fruit overlaid with baking spice notes set within silky tannins. Flavors of strawberry, black cherry, clove, cinnamon and mace taper off to a menthol-laced finish.
Bone dry and tartly crisp in acidity, this wine's lemongrass and grapefruit flavors are showing their age. It's just beginning to break up. Pretty good, but drink this year.

Typically earthy in style, this is an elegant version of one of the Douro's lesser grapes. It has a red plum flavor and sweet tannins, with a soft, rounded structure. It should be consumed soon while it's still fruity.
Another good Cabernet from this winery. It's a very grapey Cabernet, with fresh, jammy blackberry fruit that tastes like it just came from the fermenter. But it's dry and balanced and likeable.

From the Napa side of Carneros comes this crisp, fruity young Chardonnay. It's tart in savory acidity and bone dry, with pleasantly nuanced flavors of lemons, limes and tangerines, accented with a touch of sweet oak. An elegant wine to drink now.

wine: Stephen Ross 2010 Bien Nacido Vineyard Pinot Noir (Santa Maria Valley)
appellation: Santa Maria Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: Tight, acidic and a little green, this lacks the generosity and opulence you expect of a Pinot Noir from this famous vineyard. The cherry fruit is laced with mint and tobacco leaf notes. Drink now.

appellation: Amarone della Valpolicella Classico, Veneto, Italy
review: This opens with aromas of forest floor, mature dark-skinned fruit and leather. The hearty palate offers raisin, dried black currant, clove and tobacco alongside tightly wound tannins that leave a firm finish.

wine: Weingut Georg Albrecht Schneider 2017 Trocken Sauvignon Blanc (Rheinhessen)
review: This is an easy-drinking but punchy Sauvignon Blanc boasting zesty lemon and lime flavors marked by hints of freshly cut grass and herbs. It's dry, medium-bodied style and margarita-like salted finish lend refreshment. Enjoy now–2021.

wine: Vinum Cellars 2010 The Scrapper Cabernet Franc (El Dorado County)
appellation: El Dorado County, Sierra Foothills, California, US
review: The Scrapper is aptly named, packing plenty of flavorful punches into a structured but softly tannic wine. Peppery, especially in aroma, it offers full-bodied leathery black cherry fruit and concentrated layers of savory chocolate. It's delicious and would make a fine pairing with any steak.

Solid, tart-sweet fruit shines in this flavorful Western Cape Shiraz. Winemaker Linley Schultz's confident hand shows in the judicious use of oak, balanced mouthfeel and tasty, lingering close. Shows some complexity and the structure to evolve. Enjoy through 2007, maybe longer.

About as fancy as Petite Sirah gets. Has the bones and authority of a great Cab. Lush, smooth tannins and full-bodied, with powerful, intense flavors of blackberries, plums, espresso, peppery spices and subtle notes from oak barrels.

wine: Galil Mountain 2011 Yiron Vineyard Viognier (Upper Galilee)
review: Fresh, vibrant and attractive, this Viognier boasts forward aromas of ripe melon, lychee, honeysuckle florals and soft sweet spice. Medium weight, but clean and balanced, with medium acidity and a hint of clementine, which lifts the rich fruit flavors. The floral accents shine through on the finish.

wine: Belisario 2012 Vigneti del Cerro  (Verdicchio di Matelica)
appellation: Verdicchio di Matelica, Central Italy, Italy
review: This textbook Verdicchio from Matelica opens with enticing aromas of yellow spring flowers, stone fruit and citrus. The delicious palate offers peach, tropical fruit and mineral flavors, with a hint of sea salt.

wine: Claudio Quarta 2017 Sud del Sud Red (Puglia)
review: This blend is dominated by Primitivo and Negroamaro, with smaller portions of Cabernet Sauvignon, Petit Verdot and Shiraz. Aromas of tar, potpourri and ripe blackberry carry to the plush, full palate. Warm spice and frankincense tones push through, with bright acidity and soft tannins holding it all together.

appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: This wine is filled with robust Zinny flavors, ranging from wild raspberries and red currants to tobacco, mocha and crushed black pepper. It's just beginning to pick up aged notes, making it sweeter and more mellow than it would have been two or three years ago. Kudos to Balletto for holding it back before  release. Drink now–2016.

wine: El Enemigo 2010 Gran Enemigo Agrelo Single Vineyard Cabernet Franc (Mendoza)
review: For Cab Franc, this is super ripe, with floral, perfumed, earthy aromas of cassis and wild berries blended with pastry and vanilla. In the mouth, it's big but balanced, with loamy, slightly salty flavors of baked black fruits. A lasting ripe-fruit character carries onto the finish.

92–94. Barrel Sample. Owned by the Barton family of Léoville Barton, this wine shows the elegance and ripe style of Moulis, gathered into a structure that is firm and dry. It has fine acidity, and is balanced, perfumed and bright.

wine: Mosquito Fleet 2010 Plyley Reserve Cabernet Sauvignon (Walla Walla Valley (WA))
appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Despite a good effort at balancing this wine, the Pepper Bridge fruit was just at the green edge of ripeness in this vintage. The wine remains tart, sharp and herbal, with some chalkiness in the tannins.

Candy pink in color, this wine made from the local Espadeiro and Padeiro grapes, is dry with a touch of caramel, as well as red-currant fruitiness. The crisp aftertaste is bright and the wine is ready to drink.

Heady aromas of botanical herbs, fragrant purple flowers and eucalyptus are front and center. On the full-bodied palate, notes of licorice, blood orange and tangy mineral accent a core of dried cherry. Close-grained tannins offer taut support. Drink 2022–2029.

appellation: Dry Creek Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: Harsh and burnt, with medicinal, slightly sweet cherry flavors, this disagreeable wine also has rough tannins.

wine: Nittnaus Hans und Christine 2003 Nit'ana Red (Burgenland)
review: An open, generous, ripe wine, with fresh red plum fruit flavors, layered with acidity. The barrique aging is still apparent, leaving high toast. Despite the addition of Cabernet Sauvignon and Syrah, this still tastes very Austrian and spicy, the Zweigelt and Blaufränkisch dominating.
A full, rich, concentrated wine, with fat, ripe fruit and a touch of acidity. Big and powerful, it has a fresh, clean aftertaste.

Yeasty but generic white-fruit aromas come with a hint of vanilla cookie. This feels angular and acidic, not full and complete. Citrus flavors are both briny and sour, while this tastes salty on the finish.

appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: Winemaker Alison Crowe does it again, managing to provide delicious and interesting wine at a tremendous value. Deep red strawberry, black pepper, graphite, black plum, chocolate, licorice and dried chiles show on the nose. The sip brings rounded black cherry fruit lifted by anise, dark chocolate and a touch of olive flavors.

This wine's very shy nose gives next to nothing away, showing a slight sense of lemon and a touch of dried corn husk. The palate is just as tightly coiled and does not yet reveal its full flavors. The structure, however, is already on full display, showing a gentle, smooth texture without an ounce of fat. Drink 2025–2040.

wine: Dashe Cellars 2009 Louvau Vineyard Old Vines Zinfandel (Dry Creek Valley)
appellation: Dry Creek Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: Dashe always produces dependably good Zinfandels from this vineyard. The 2009 shows real complexity, with an earthy, mushroomy richness alongside the raspberry, red currant and spice flavors. It's very dry, with a fine structure of acid and tannins. Marked by the rusticity that characterizes Dry Creek Zinfandels. It calls for pairing with rich stews, braised meats and barbecue.

appellation: Applegate Valley, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
review: Soft and soapy, suggesting high pH, this wine is light in style, with easygoing citrus flavors. The palate is soft and lacking in an acidic lift.

Round and grassy smelling, but turning more pungent and pointed with airing. Shows good grip and a slight spritz on the palate in front of grassy, green flavors of lime, bell pepper and tarragon. Pithy on the finish, where jalapeño and white-pepper notes rise up and take over.

wine: Amity 2009 Crannell Single Vineyard Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)
appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: Dark in color and flavor, the Crannell brings ripe fruit flavors of black cherry and prune. Smooth and full-bodied, with an easy-drinking roundness to the mouthfeel, it finishes softly with all components well integrated.

appellation: Southern Oregon, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
review: Screw-capped and lightly fizzy, this Muscat, Riesling and Müller-Thurgau blend is aromatic and fruity, with soda pop flavors. Consistent from vintage to vintage in both style and flavor, it's a good candidate for a mixer or punch wine.

wine: Provam 2013 Portal do Fidalgo Alvarinho (Vinho Verde)
review: This is a great Alvarinho, full of ripe and creamy fruit that is so pure and crisp while bringing out a tight, mineral character. From the north of Vinho Verde, across the river from Spain, this shows the texture of the granite soil combined with the exceptional ripeness of the fruit. Age for a year, drink from the end of 2015.

An appetizing hickory-smoke aroma and bold fruit flavors make this one stand out, yet it doesn't go too far with the woody character. A hint of bacon blends well with the ripe blackberry flavors, and the rich texture and firm tannins make it a great wine to pair with big portions of protein.

Typical Albariño aromas of white peach, white pepper and citrus fruits are about average. Bright citric acidity makes this racy, while salty tangerine, apricot and nectarine flavors end with pithy grit.

A touch stewy and bulky, but still a positive wine from a good if now old vintage. Plum and cherry fruit on the palate seems ripe, and the finish is properly dry. A bit high in acidity, but still good in terms of mouthfeel.

wine: LangeTwins 2012 Estate Grown Musqué Clone Sauvignon Blanc (Lodi)
review: Offering aromas of sweet peach, this is a round, full Sauvignon Blanc with a pleasant texture. Light in alcohol but rich on the finish, it just begs for shellfish or melted goat cheese salad.

Raspberry aromas are jammy, reedy and leafy, while on the palate this is hard and sappy, with weight. Jamminess is a recurring theme on this high-priced Garnacha. Flavors of cherry and rhubarb wrap up on an edgy, scrubbing finish.
This is a light wine, just juicy red cherries and bright acidity. The structure is also light, leaving fruitiness and immediate drinkability as the wine's main characteristics. Drink now.

wine: Ironstone 2013 Rous Vineyard Reserve Ancient Vines Zinfandel (Lodi)
review: So easy to enjoy, this mild-tasting but full-bodied wine is fruity in flavor and soft in texture. It has an earthy, savory aroma, generous plum and berry flavors, a mineral influence, light tannins and a lingering finish.

Fine complex nose mixes spice, briar, pie cherry, coffee and barnyard. Flavors are pleasant, with plummy fruit, but overall the wine doesn't have much depth or power. Finishes tannic and a little bitter.
A dull gold tint and steamrolling barrel aromas announce an oak-heavy wine that's tight, resiny and high in acid. Woody flavors of salted apricot echo on the finish.

This wine is soft, juicy and light. It has only the slightest texture, leaving its flavors entirely with blackberry fruitiness. That makes it an attractive, open wine with a fresh aftertaste. Drink now.

wine: Chamarré 2005 Selection Grenache-Shiraz (Vin de Pays de l'Ile de Beauté)
appellation: Vin de Pays de l'Ile de Beauté, France
review: From the island of Corsica, this was our pick of the Chamarré wines,  combining stony, smoky aromas with flavors of strawberries and herbs. It's a  copper-colored rosé that finishes fresh, with a hint of anise.
Cedar, berries and tobacco on the nose of this elegant red give it a moody appeal. On the palate, cherry, mocha and smoke prevail. This wine has dimension and class.

wine: Borsao 2008 Tres Picos Garnacha (Campo de Borja)
appellation: Campo de Borja, Northern Spain, Spain
review: Tres Picos, or Three Peaks, ranks as a go-to wine for fans of round, smooth, slightly oaky reds. The bouquet is all mocha and smoky/oaky richness, while the sticky, rich palate deals blackberry and chewy, rooty medicinality. Oaky and spicy late, with licorice and warmth. The best thing is that it's not heavy or overextracted despite being youthful and modern in style.

Leather, mint and wet-dog aromas along with an overriding burn drive the nose toward a resiny, raw palate with snappy acidity and lots of oak. Buttery as well as briny red-fruit flavors are salty and taste mostly of wood resin.

wine: Château de Corneilla 2009 Pur Sang Red (Côtes du Roussillon)
review: Boysenberry, blueberry and black cherry aromas lead on the nose of this wine, with a touch of warmth and chocolaty sensation following behind. The palate veers more towards red-fruit flavors, with a thin midpalate and an astringent close.

wine: Wairau River 2004 Home Block Pinot Noir (Marlborough)
review: Light ruby in color, this wine doesn't appear to be terribly rich or concentrated. But it's a charming, soft little Pinot, intended to caress the palate rather than stun it. Sous bois and cherries are framed by barrel-derived notes of caramel, cedar and vanilla. Ends slightly woody, but should smooth out in another few months.

Light, clean, peachy aromas provide for a nice opening. The palate on this Pinot Noir Cava is crisp, linear and citric, while flavors of tangerine, cherry pie and plum finish tight, citrusy and long. If you want zero funk and no faults in your bubbly, try this.
This wine's stewy, herbal berry aromas are not very ripe or compelling. Its rough palate offers minty, herbal berry and carob flavors, finishing slightly hot and abrasive, with green notes.

wine: Rockpile Winery 2019 Rockpile Ridge Vineyard Zinfandel (Rockpile)
review: Spicy and herbal, this high-elevation grown wine includes 6% Petite Sirah and is earthy and dusty in dark fruit. Firm yet substantial tannins provide concentrated weight and breadth, with brooding highlights of tobacco, black pepper, dark chocolate and coffee.

This wine is the result of a new project from old vines. The wine has great richness while also having the dense concentration to be expected from a field blend. The wine is set for aging, with its firm core of tannins to offset the black fruits. Drink from 2023.

appellation: Arroyo Seco, Central Coast, California, US
review: Yellow peach-flesh, lemon-balm and light almond aromas show on the nose of this appellation blend. Dried lemons, baked apple and a hint of salt arise as flavors on the smooth and easy palate.

This medium-weight wine starts off with wonderfully pure, expressive aromas of ripe passion fruit. On the palate, it's a bit prickly and leafy at first, like tomato stalks or nettle leaves. It then settles back down into tropical fruit on the long, mouthwatering finish. Drink now.
Peach and nectarine aromas are simple and yeasty. Standard melony flavors rank as quiet, while on the finish this basic Viura is vapid and showing signs of fading.

This is an old-style wine: it's the kind of Cabernet that made Cabernet famous in California. It's a dry, ruggedly tannic wine, filled with rewarding blackberry, coffee, herb and spice flavors, and finishes with balance and a certain polish.

wine: Basel Cellars 2011 Estate Cabernet Sauvignon (Columbia Valley (WA))
appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: 100% varietal, this wine exhibits aromas of dried herb, cigar box, and cherry. The flavors are tart, light and elegant, harmonizing on the finish.

appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
review: Grassy green underdeveloped aromas are not what Emilio Moro wines are known for, but given that this is a 2013, these scents are not without foundation. The palate follows the nose with raw pulling tannins and green-leaning flavors of basil, plum and boysenberry. A tight scouring finish is consistent with what came before it.

appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Always a favorite from this Walla Walla producer, the 2005 Merlot includes about 6% Cabernet Franc. Firm and muscular, with a dense core of blackberry, black cherry and cassis, it sprinkles in ground coffee and a streak of licorice. The style is deep, dark, laced with graphite, and definitely built for long -term cellaring.

wine: Dow's 2010 Quinta Senhora da Ribeira Vintage  (Port)
review: This is a perfumed wine with fine acidity. The tannins are soft, accompanied by black cherry and ripe berry notes, making this a sweet, rich style. The Quinta Senhora de Ribeira is on the north bank of the Douro, facing Quinta do Vesúvio on the south bank.

This Champagne exhibits both the freshness of the vintage and a sense of toasty maturity. Baked apple aromas are touched with notes of almonds and cookies. The palate is substantially weighty with a density of flavors and a rich, full aftertaste. Ready to drink now.

It seems smooth and opulent initially, but then shows a structured side that brings out wood flavors, intense acidity and great depth. It's a powerful wine, very rich while keeping the freshness of the year and promising long-term aging. Drink from 2018.

wine: Von Hövel 2007 Oberemmeler Hütte Spätlese Riesling (Mosel-Saar-Ruwer)
Bodegas Fuentespina 2012 First Label  (Ribera del Duero)
appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
review: Creamy oak aromas shout “vanilla” and “wood resin” in full voice. This is a rough wine with stampeding tannins. Toasty boysenberry flavors are more pounding than elegant, while this tastes of bitter chocolate on an aggressive finish. Give this five years and it may show better but now it's massive and unsettled.

wine: Schug 2000 Brut Rouge de Noirs Sparkling (Carneros)
review: Pretty dark for a bubbly, with dough, strawberry, smoke and vanilla aromas and delicate flavors of strawberries and cream. A bit rough in texture, but clean and dry. Might soften with a few years in the cellar.

This brawny wine opens with subdued aromas that recall leafy underbrush, roasted coffee bean and a whiff of stewed plum. The warm, monolithic palate offers prune steeped in spirits, toasted nut, dark spice and a green note of powdered sage alongside raspy tannins that leave an astringent finish. The heat of evident alcohol on the close throws it further off-balance.

Blended with 10% Grenache Blanc, this elegant white shows a whiff of petrol on the nose, following through on the palate with an oily, viscous varietal character. Lemon, green apple and a note of oak round it out, adorned in honeysuckle aromas.
Rich and robust with berry and currant fruit, this wine is rounded and full-bodied, with tannic weight and spicy layers of toasted oak.

appellation: Umpqua Valley, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
review: Aromatic and inviting, this pushes strawberry preserves, cola and a dash of non-carbonated seltzer into the midpalate. It spent 14 months in one-quarter new French oak, and the color along with the already maturing fruit flavors suggest drinking this now through 2020.

wine: Feudi di San Gregorio 1998 Falanghina White (Campania)
review: One of southern Italy's oldest white grapes comes bursting to life in this nutty, lemony, honey-tinged winner that's a little like Tocai Friulano at its best. It goes like your hand in a glove when served with grilled octopus over braised radicchio.

Ripe berry and cassis aromas feature more than enough charred wood and licorice scents. A palate with raw tannins is tough to penetrate. Flavors of burnt oak, clove, chocolate and stewed berry fruits finish similarly but drier. This is 70% Monastrell and 30% Syrah.

wine: The Great Oregon Wine Company 2016 Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)
appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: This mixes light flavors of black cherry, cola and a touch of tanned leather. The tannins are soft and supple, and the mouthfeel has been rounded off for immediate drinkability.

There is a touch of yellow mirabelle plum on the nose. The palate comes in with a more tart note of pith and zest. The slender body unites full fruit and lively freshness in a compact package, boosted by a little residual sweetness that nonetheless lets the wine finish dry.

wine: Dutton-Goldfield 2017 Van Der Kamp Vineyard Pinot Noir (Sonoma Mountain)
review: Stemmy and earthy, this is a wildly exotic red wine, tense in sage and clove. Mountain strawberry, black cherry and rhubarb meet a wall of black tea, with compelling streaks of white pepper and firm tannin, combining for a forceful, balanced finish.

Much more famous for its Tavel rosé, this estate also turns out an attractive, easy to drink red from Lirac. The 2003 shows plenty of bright, fresh fruit married to complex briar and herb notes. Supple tannins make it approachable now.

wine: Viña Bisquertt 2014 La Joya Gran Reserva Sauvignon Blanc (Colchagua Valley)
review: Citrus aromas lead the nose, followed by feline notes, yeasty vanilla and green pepper scents. This wine has a citric, tangy, hard-driving palate. Flavors of orange, tangerine and grapefruit finish with zesty acidity.

appellation: Edna Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: This second, affordably minded label from the Center of Effort team shows caramelized cherries and chipped slate on the nose. Candied red fruits arise on the palate, along with bitter orange peels and a nice acidity, though there's a slightly odd film left on the tongue in the finish.

wine: Castelli del Grevepesa 2007 Clemente VII Settimo Red (Toscana)
review: A blend of Sangiovese, Merlot and Syrah, this opens with plush layers of black fruit, tobacco, chocolate and crushed black pepper. Full, ripe and modern, this has lingering notes of exotic spice and toasted nut on the finish.

appellation: Templeton Gap District, Central Coast, California, US
review: Aromas of leather, game, coffee, cracked pepper and roasted black cherry show on the nose of this blend of 55% Syrah, 15% Petite Sirah, 10% Tempranillo, 10% Grenache and 10% Zinfandel. The mouthwatering palate is loaded with rich flavors of soy and grilled meats alongside roasted plum and mulberry.
A bit tight. The wine harbors dark berry, licorice and herb flavors. On the finish, it's bright and tangy, smoky and with a touch of bitterness.

wine: McCray Ridge 2000 Two Moon Vineyard Merlot (Dry Creek Valley)
appellation: Dry Creek Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: There are some gritty tannins to this wine that make it chewy, almost like a food. It has pretty cherry and blackberry flavors and good acidity that balance the tannins out. Has extra layers of complexity that add interest.

Early Middle Eastern aromas of cumin and the like yield to burnt toast and charred hamburger. The palate is perfectly juicy and for the most part balanced, with berry and plum flavors. With pop and ripping acidity, this is a lively number that should go well with burgers, pizza and similar finger foods.

Tight and edgy but ultimately oaky and generous on the nose, with earth, vanilla, dried cheese and blackberry notes.
