Feels cushioned and complete, with depth of feel and flavor; tastes of deep berry, mild herbs and finally a toasty wave of coffee and chocolate takes over. Impressive for a 2008; drink now through 2014.

The wine has the right weight and power. It comes from a blend of different parcels, bringing out the complexity of the vineyards. Black fruits are soft and generous, supported by tannins as well as licorice and wood flavors. At the end, fresher red fruits show.

wine: Maison Bertrand Ravache 2016 Léo de la Gaffelière Sélection d'Excellence  (Bordeaux)
designation: Léo de la Gaffelière Sélection d'Excellence
review: A ripe, dense wine with opulent black fruits, this broad wine is dominated by generous Merlot. It is made to be drunk young, even with the backing of tannins, and will be ready from 2020.

wine: Howard Park 2014 Scotsdale Cabernet Sauvignon (Great Southern)
review: Give this Great Southern Cab some time in glass or decanter to open up, but once it does it reveals notes of cherry cola, cranberry, florals, black pepper and an earthy core. The palate is rich and riding a line between full and medium bodied. It's currently tightly wound, with savory oak tannins that should mellow out with time. Drink now–2027.

Although this wine starts off a bit stern in texture, by the long finish those tannins have turned velvety and plush, nicely framing intense black olive, espresso, cherry and plum flavors. Drink now–2018.

appellation: Eola-Amity Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: Chewy tannins pretty much define this young wine at this point. Bark and skin flavors cover black cherry fruit, and then give way to more astringent, black tea flavors as it finishes. Time may smooth it out a bit, but it's tough to see it really regaining its balance.

Alpine notes of wet earth and pine needles lend complexity to luscious black plum and cherry in this silky, medium-bodied wine. Equal parts savory and fruity, it offers sun-kissed cherry flavor calibrated against piquant hits of anise and black pepper spices. Fresh acidity and fine, feathery tannins linger on the finish.

Ample blueberry and black cherry fruit is toned by fresh acidity and held in a concentrated body. Little by little the Zweigelt pepperiness creeps in and makes for a punchy, focused red with just the right amount of still perceptible tannins. Great clean finish.

wine: Kessler-Haak 2013 Lafond Vineyard Riesling (Sta. Rita Hills)
appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
review: Typical hints of gasoline on the nose of this wine are bolstered by beeswax, orange blossom water and a steely minerality. The palate is a little flat, with lime pith, lemon juice and very little petrol element.

Here's a lofty, noble Cab that boasts great power and intensity. The nose is redolent of black plum, spice, green leaf, molasses and a touch of cinnamon. Firm tannins and thick density back its penetrating effect.
Soft and fruity, a ripe, medium-bodied wine that has an open structure and good fruitiness. The wine has a background of tannins along with the blackberry fruits and juicy acidity. Drink from 2015.

A soft and approachable, rather than bracing, Riesling—we probably have the vintage to thank for that. Smells of yellow stone fruit, flowers and white chocolate, and tastes of green grass and stone fruit. Finishes minerally. Imported by Pacific Wine Partners.

wine: Livio Felluga 2000 Pinot Grigio (Friuli Venezia Giulia)
appellation: Friuli Venezia Giulia, Northeastern Italy, Italy
review: This full and tangy Pinot Grigio opens with a subdued orange, mineral and tropical fruit nose. There's a good citrus-herb tension to the palate, and darker and spicier flavors here than usually encountered in Italian versions of the grape. Nicely balanced, the wine has a long, citrus-spice finish.

wine: Scharffenberger NV Brut Excellence Méthode Traditionnelle Sparkling (Mendocino County)
appellation: Mendocino County, Mendocino County, California, US
review: This enticing and supple wine starts with aromas of bread dough and toasted almonds. The palate brings flavors of both fresh and baked apple on a plush, softly sparkling texture.

appellation: Red Hills, Lake County, California, US
review: Very dark, very focused, and very pure, this full-bodied wine polishes the notorious tannins of the varietal just slightly, while pouring on dark chocolate, blackberry jam, white pepper and a touch of floral flavor. It's a great wine to buy and stash in a cool place for a few years to see how interesting Petite Sirah can get. Best after 2024.

wine: Alain Jaume et Fils 2006 Domaine Grand Veneur Les Origines Red (Châteauneuf-du-Pape)
review: A luxury cuvée at this price is becoming a rarity in Châteauneuf, but Les Origines delivers the goods. Subtle cinnamon and nutmeg shadings frame densely packed black cherry flavors. It's creamy in texture, with a long, velvety finish that lingers elegantly. Drink now–2020.

wine: Rideau 2004 Sanford & Benedict Vineyard Pinot Noir (Sta. Rita Hills)
appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
review: A thick, young, closed wine with a soft, cloying texture, and jammy fruit and sugared coffee flavors. It's also hot. Might age.

Crisp black cherry and mint aromas burst from the glass, then carry over onto the chunky, authoritative palate before finishing slightly dusty and astringent. This medium-bodied Cabernet features plenty of intensity, it just needs a little time to settle down into a more refined package.
The wine is tight, green and herbal. It has some fruitiness, but that is suppressed by general underripeness. The tannins are hard at the end.

appellation: Central Coast, Central Coast, California, US
review: Tastes unripe, with a disagreeably green, minty streak, and although the wine is fully dry, it's just too tough and lean to recommend.

wine: Château Calon Ségur 2015 Le Marquis de Calon Ségur Barrel Sample  (Saint-Estèphe)
designation: Le Marquis de Calon Ségur Barrel Sample
review: 92–94. Barrel Sample. This wine is lightly perfumed from the Cabernet Franc in the blend, which gives it a juicy, fragrant, exotic character. Red fruits and great swathes of acidity sweep through.

At 46 acres, this is a large property for Pomerol, adjacent to Château Pétrus. This wine has great richness and acidity, conveying power, density and a hint of spice and perfume from the Cabernet Franc in the blend. Drink this wine from 2023.

wine: Symington Family Estates 2011 Altano Quinta do Ataíde Reserva Red (Douro)
review: Still quite closed up, this is going to be a rich wine with great structure. For now, polished wood and stalky red fruits are filled out with fine tannins and a dry, tough core. It's a wine for aging, needing to soften. Drink from 2017.

A blend of Merlot, Cabernet Sauvignon and Cabernet Franc, this opens with aromas of black-skinned berry, underbrush and a hint of green olive. The straightforward palate offers vanilla, black-currant jam and a touch of caramel alongside smooth tannins.

Made entirely with Sangiovese, this opens with aromas of underbrush, cedar and black-skinned berry. The chewy palate delivers blackberry jam, licorice, black pepper and coffee alongside fine-grained tannins. Enjoy now through 2024.

This wine's spicy aromas indicate the considerable wood aging that shows strongly. However, the good news is that there is also plenty of ripe blackberry fruit that will develop well as the wine ages. Give this well-structured wine until 2022 before drinking.

wine: Quivira 2005 Wine Creek Ranch Grenache (Dry Creek Valley)
appellation: Dry Creek Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: Quivira produces interesting, often compelling red wines year after year. A Rhône pioneer, their '05 Grenache is far more subtle and elegant than most California bottlings. The powerful red cherry fruit has a spicy edge, while the tannic structure is ripe and layered. A polished wine.

wine: Au Bon Climat 2010 Historic Vineyards Collection Bien Nacido Vineyard Pinot Noir (Santa Maria Valley)
designation: Historic Vineyards Collection Bien Nacido Vineyard
appellation: Santa Maria Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: This Pinot Noir is insanely delicious. The wine is dry, tart and moderate in alcohol, giving it the smooth silkiness you want in a fine Pinot. The flavors are something else, striking the perfect balance between ripe raspberries, earthy cola, red licorice and mushrooms, with all kinds of spicy complexities. The acid-tannin balance is impeccable. It's drinking beautifully now and should hold and change in the bottle over the next eight years.

wine: Château la Fon du Berger 2015 Cru Bourgeois  (Haut-Médoc)
review: Dark chocolate and rich tannins are strong elements in this mature wine. Dark fruits have softened into the structure, hinting at blackberries but more focused on secondary flavors. Drink now.
Firmly tannic, this is still a young wine. It has a dry structure with a black currant-skin stalkiness. Acidity and structure are still developing, so wait until 2016.
Quater is a rich red blend that opens with blackberry, rum cake, Indian spice, cola and ground clove. It combines intensity and complexity with a bold, opulent mouthfeel.

appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: This blend offers beguiling, complex aromas of violets, scorched earth, cassis, black licorice and graphite. The flavors are tightly wound, showing poise and presence. It drinks well out of the gate but cellaring will be particularly rewarded. Best from 2022 through 2030.

wine: Villa Spinosa 2001  Amarone della Valpolicella Classico
appellation: Amarone della Valpolicella Classico, Veneto, Italy
review: This 2001 vintage Amarone shows elegant signs of age with aromas of old spice, dried fruit, dried porcini mushroom and pressed rose petal. It's a bit tired and flat in the mouth at this point, so if you have a bottle drink it soon.

appellation: Hunter Valley, New South Wales, Australia
review: Faux-creaminess pervades nose and palate flavors, though I'm not convinced that what's underneath is necessarily worth fighting for. The bouquet offers soil, juicy berry and watermelon aromas; tart black fruit peeks out from under the palate's creamy cloak.

This wine exhibits the generosity from the ripe 2009 vintage. It has rich, full and round fruits, with a pleasing black currant flavor and tannic edge. Juicy, with a dust-textured aftertaste, this will age for 4–5 years.
A dreary, simple wine, as thin as water with a few drops of blackberry syrup. It's also soft and bitter on the finish.

wine: Golan Heights Winery 2008 Yarden Heights Wine Kosher - 375 ml Gewürztraminer (Galilee)
review: Rich and alluring with notes of ripe stone fruit, baked apple and a drizzle of chestnut honey throughout. Full and viscous in the mouth but lifted by crisp acidity that follows through to the clean but long finish.

Pale in color, this watery Shiraz initially offers some bright cherry fruit but quickly slides into synthetic territory with a dish soap and oak spice quality. The palate is thin and astringent, and the fruit falls rapidly flat, finishing on the sour side.

wine: Lieubeau 2017 Domaine de la Fruitière Gneiss de Bel Abord Sur Lie  (Muscadet Sèvre et Maine)
designation: Domaine de la Fruitière Gneiss de Bel Abord Sur Lie
appellation: Muscadet Sèvre et Maine, Loire Valley, France
review: The schist and granite soil of this vineyard yields a wine that is strongly mineral. Its acidity and fruitiness are restrained by a tense texture and steely character. This fine wine needs to age a few more months, so drink from early 2019.
A little earthy, with creamy apple sauce flavors dusted with cinnamon and nutmeg, but dry. There's a rough texture through the finish.

wine: Coelho 2016 Coelho Estates Pinot Gris (Willamette Valley)
appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: This is the most expensive of Coelho's three Pinot Gris offerings and also the least ripe. Bone-dry, sour and thin, it seems to improve when paired with fresh oysters.

wine: Romantic 2014 Authentic & Chic Cabernet Sauvignon (Vin de France)
appellation: Vin de France, France Other, France
review: The medium-intense nose of this solid and easy-to-like Cab offers scents of blackberry, cassis and plum, all laced by hints of cocoa and cigar box. The medium-weight mouth offers a pleasant texture, thanks to moderate tannins and ample acidity, with solid black-fruit flavors at the core.

appellation: Monterey County, Central Coast, California, US
review: This blend of Syrah and Grenache is hard and tough, with stringy, dry tannins and flavors of vegetables and cherry cough syrup. Lots of new French oak does little to make it more palatable.

wine: Barth René 2003 Vignoble de Bennwihr Pinot Gris (Alsace)
review: Ginger and tonic water on the nose, with pear, apple and sweet melon flavors. Seems a touch off-dry, with licorice and candy on the finish. Spunky but feminine in style. Imported by Atlanta Improvement Co.

wine: Tin Barn 2016 Pickberry Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Sonoma Valley)
review: This is an herbaceous and thickly dense wine from the famous site, a study in mountain forest, sage and savory tobacco. The fruit is red and tart, integrating well within the wine's balance of power and grace.

This wine opens with an intense bouquet of white roses with accents of baking spices. The flowery sensation carries over to the palate along with ripe banana, pear and clove, plus the heat of alcohol. It concludes with a slightly sweet finish.

wine: Lomas del Valle 2012 Coast Cool Climate Pinot Noir (Casablanca Valley)
review: Piercing sour raspberry aromas introduce an edgy, scratchy feeling wine with a combo of minty, herbal pie cherry and red plum flavors. This dries out and finishes modestly, but always with true Pinot Noir character.

wine: Laird 2013 Mast Ranch Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
review: This vineyard designate from Yountville is packed with compact tannin and rich oak yet nicely balanced by crisp ranberry, cherry and clove flavors. Light black-pepper notes add seasoning.

Delicate but perfumed, this deft, sprightly Riesling offers rich, concentrated pink grapefruit and white peach flavors etched by lime and steel. It's a juicy, thirst-quenching wine that's gobs of fun to drink young but should continue to drink beautifully through 2029.

wine: Pierre Gimonnet et Fils NV Oger Grand Cru Blanc de Blancs Brut Chardonnay (Champagne)
designation: Oger Grand Cru Blanc de Blancs Brut
review: In keeping with Gimonnet's dry style, this is almost bone dry and as sharp as a knife. Behind the steely texture, it is fruity as well, with tight apple and strong citrus flavors. It's a tense and nervy style with depth of flavor and concentration. This is 100% Chardonnay harvested in 2011 from Oger grand cru vineyards in the Côte des Blancs. Drink now, although it will age and round out in bottle through 2015 at least.

This well-priced white wine is simple and clean with fruit-driven aromas of peach, melon and honey. You can taste sweet notes from the strong sunshine and the wine has good density and firmness throughout.

wine: Labouré-Roi 2010 Les Sangliers Pinot Noir (Pays d'Oc)
review: The fruit isn't the star of this wine; instead, intense notes of forest floor and cola spice dominate the nose and palate. Sure, the red berry and cherry flavors are there, but they're just hanging in the background of this bright yet herbaceous selection.

wine: Merry Edwards 2014 Olivet Lane Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)
appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: This is from one of the oldest Pinot Noir vineyards in the area, owned and farmed by Bob Pellegrini, and a place that has provided grapes Edwards since the 1980s. Spicy pine and cardamom greet the nose and palate, as silky smooth layers of rose and wild strawberry meet cardamon and vanilla. Medium-bodied, it remains complex and balanced as it develops additional nuance in the glass.

wine: Mansfield-Dunne 2017 Peterson Vineyard Pinot Noir (Santa Lucia Highlands)
appellation: Santa Lucia Highlands, Central Coast, California, US
review: Full and pleasantly rustic aromas of cherry, cranberry, sagebrush, roasted game and crushed gravel show on the nose of this single-vineyard bottling. The palate is also savory and full of intriguing flavors, showing roasted pork in mulberry and cranberry sauce with a pinch of oregano.

Has the usual mid-Napa aromas of cassis, smoke and oak. Flavors are similar, ripe and fruity, verging on jammy. But the tannins are ultrasoft and creamy, yet complex and lacy. Provides sheer pleasure now or you can age it. From consulting winemaker Heidi Barrett.

Dramatically rich and full-bodied in blackberry, cassis, dark chocolate and oak flavors. With thick, fine tannins giving it a youthful astringency, this Bordeaux blend needs to be cellared. Should develop bottle notes over the next ten years.

wine: Bedell 2014 Cabernet Franc (North Fork of Long Island)
appellation: North Fork of Long Island, Long Island, New York, US
review: Plummy blackberry and cherry flavors abound in this Cabernet Franc, anchored by a taut frame of fine, firm tannins and cranberry acidity. It seems lavishly oaked, but pronounced aromas of cedar and toast integrate smoothly on the palate. The long finish is marked by an enticing pencil-shaving edge.

appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Excellent varietal character and definition. This is the most firm and tannic of Townshend's lineup, an earthy, slightly chalky wine. The fruit is clean and well-delineated, with grace notes of coffee and coconut; just not quite as lingering as its siblings.

Dark fruit and soft, supple texture define this estate wine, silky and complete with the appellation's signature funk. Rose-petal aromatics, black-tea and forest notes provide varietal beauty and complexity.

Shows full cherry, licorice, leather and barnyardy notes on the nose. Some sour cherry and raspberry flavors, with sly oak and chocolate accents; a slightly creamy mouthfeel and a medium-long mineral and herb finish. Again, good elements, but the total effect is curiously less than the sum of the parts.

wine: Il Marroneto 2013 Madonna delle Grazie  (Brunello di Montalcino)
review: Earthy aromas of underbrush, truffle, game and new leather meld with ripe berry and a whiff of blue flower. Reflecting the nose, the savory palate is loaded with personality, delivering crushed raspberry, black cherry, clove, aromatic herb and a distinct but intriguing gamy note alongside a backbone of assertive, fine-grained tannins. Vibrant acidity lends balance. Open this way in advance to give it time to breathe. Drink 2023–2038.

Here's a rich, densely layered Cab. It's showing complex flavors of black currants, dark chocolate and cedar. The tannins are a little edgy, giving the wine an astringent bite that could mellow out with mid-term aging.

wine: Waters 2006 Loess Vineyard Syrah (Walla Walla Valley (WA))
appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: This Loess is definitely more—more concentration, more ripeness, more Côte Rôtie character than the 2005, but already showing dramatic flavor development. Cofermented with 3% Viognier, it's a silky wine with flavors of blood, meat and earth dominating. Tannins are ripe, and it was barreled in second-fill oak, preserving the natural flavors of the vineyard. Clearly the best so far from Waters.

wine: Château Langrange Monbadon 2010  Castillon Côtes de Bordeaux
appellation: Castillon Côtes de Bordeaux, Bordeaux, France
review: A softly juicy wine, this is missing structure while it has plenty of fruit. It's ripe, rich and juicy; a pleasure to drink in 2–3 years.

wine: Foxen 7200 2012 7200 Vogelzang Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Happy Canyon of Santa Barbara)
appellation: Happy Canyon of Santa Barbara, Central Coast, California, US
review: Winemaker Billy Wathen is steadily perfecting this appellation, and this wine shows blackberry, black pepper and roast beef crust on the nose. A very savory and interesting palate mixes Bing cherries and dried berries with peppered beef jerky, oregano and even roasted garlic, making for an elegant and delicious wine.

appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
review: Shy aromas of citrus and apple blend with a light plastic tone. This is slick in feel, with green apple and pear holding court, ending on a crunchy apple peel tone.

wine: Joseph Cellars 2015 Ramazzotti Vineyard Petite Sirah (Dry Creek Valley)
appellation: Dry Creek Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: Dusty tannins are at the center of this boldly ripe, brawny wine, which offers soft plush texture and a depth of rich plum. Dark chocolate waves are complemented by a savory twist of cigar box and pepper.

appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: This is the reserve label for Abbey Road Farm. It's a two-barrel selection from the same sources as the regular Pinot Noir; one barrel was new. Supple dark fruits, along with a slightly bitter streak of barrel toast, give the cherry flavors a sort of charred character. The wine is in good shape for near-term drinking, with medium length and balance. Decanting first is recommended to soften the barrel impact.
If you are staging an informal outdoor barbecue with franks and burgers, this value wine will meet all your pairing needs. It's soft, plush and round, with exotic spice, ripe fruit and black pepper.

Everything about this wine is designed to flatter the palate, from the cherry and black raspberry fruit, dusted with dry crushed spices, to the overlay of richly toasted oak, to the soft, yielding tannins. What's not to like? It ain't grand cru Burgundy, but it sure is nice drinking. —S.H.

A disappointing Port from a firm that is better known for its Sherries and brandies. The fruit is highly perfumed, with aromas of geraniums, but is not at all structured. Instead, it is much more in a light, fresh style.

wine: Morandé 2001 Grand Reserve Vitisterra Cabernet Sauvignon (Maipo Valley)
review: Quite condensed and woody, with brier and sawdust aromas and some vivacious berry fruit. The palate is deep and pure, with cherry and cassis along with hints of coffee and earth. Yes, it's a bit hard due to firm tannins, but it's also a complete wine with a long, overt finish. Best Buy.

wine: The Walls 2014 Wonderful Nightmare Stoney Vine Vineyard Tempranillo (Walla Walla Valley (WA))
appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Light in color, intriguing aromas of cedar, mushroom, orange peel, smoke and cigar box are followed by somewhat faint elegantly styled red-fruit and spice flavors. It falls a bit flat on the palate.

Aromas of steeped plum and baking spice and a whiff of rose lift out of the glass. Round and concentrated, the full-bodied, enveloping palate doles out fleshy black cherry, blackberry jam and cinnamon alongside close-grained, dusty tannins. Drink through 2026.

wine: Château Julien 2001 Barrel Aged Pinot Grigio (Monterey County)
appellation: Monterey County, Central Coast, California, US
review: Fruity and simple, a wine that will give pleasure if you're not looking for complexities. Peaches, melons and figs, a little sweet, a bit soft.

Henschke is best known for its red wines, but the 2005 Louis Sémillon shows they know a thing or two about whites as well. It combines some toasty, smoky characters with herbal notes on the nose, then develops flavors of wax, spice and citrus, lingering elegantly on the finish. Tasty now, but might develop even more interesting complexities with additional age.

wine: Quinta do Vale Meão 2017 Monte Meão Vinha da Cantina Baga (Douro)
review: It is unusual to find the Bairrada grape, Baga, in the Douro. This single-vineyard wine shows the grape's natural tannic character along with black currant acidity. The wine is in need of some aging. Drink from 2023.

wine: Collovray et Terrier 2012 Les Vignes de Joanny  (Mâcon-Davayé)
review: A tight, mineral-driven wine, it has both great fruit and acidity. It is tangy, pushing forward crisp lemon and apple skin flavors and a touch of peach. Drink now.

wine: Black Kite 2010 Stony Terrace Pinot Noir (Anderson Valley)
appellation: Anderson Valley, Mendocino County, California, US
review: More subtle at first than the 2010 River Turn, Stony Terrace, another of Black Kite's yearly single-block designates, is earthy, savory and dense. Mouth filling in its juicy red and blue fruit flavor, it's silky and entirely seductive. Well integrated and structured, it's another fine choice for the table and for cellaring another 5–7 years.

Ripe black-skinned berry and black plum aromas take center stage in this wine, along with a whiff of toast. The dense palate shows black cherry, licorice and mocha touches framed by firm tannins. Drink through 2020.

wine: Decugnano dei Barbi 2013 Villa Barbi  (Orvieto Classico)
review: Aromas of stone fruit, wildflower and Bartlett pear come together in the glass. The savory palate doles out juicy green apple, creamy white peach and aromatic herb, while fresh acidity and a light mineral vein give it a clean, crisp finish.
Badabing shoots forward simple fruit tones of cherry, raspberry and cranberry that wash clean over the palate. Pair this wine with simple pasta or pizza; it's an easy-drinking, no-fuss red.

As good as the 2001 Napanook is, this wine is more intense. The fruit is lusher, the oak newer, the control more complete, but the kicker is the tannins. They're powerful and dusty, and conceal the flamboyance, for now. Needs time; hold until 2010 and beyond.

A relatively rare varietal that is believed to originate in the Krems region. This example shows the varietal's high acidity that needs an off-dry flavor to compensate. It has a nice caramel layer which helps in the balance.

Made entirely with Sangiovese, this opens with aromas of scorched soil, used leather and game. The aromas follow over to the funky palate along with mature plum and black pepper. It's already accessible, with evolved tannins. Enjoy soon.

This is a well-balanced and attractive pour, with scents of orange blossom, lemon verbena, quinine and lime that frame the just-ripe peach and melon fruit core. A pithy astringency provides a subtle texture to the palate and lends some lingering grip to the finish, coupled with a vibrant acidity that leaves you read for more. Drink now–2022.

Very familiar Rioja aromas of cherry, plum and prune scream Tempranillo. This is wiry in feel, with tight, hammering acidity. Berry and black-cherry flavors finish on a subtle note of chocolate along with a final shot of juicy, sharp acidity.

This blush wine is a blend of Cabernet Franc and Merlot. As you'd expect, it's a big wine for a rosé, a little heavy, but there's a nice cut of acidity that helps. Is it dry? Sort of, with a jammy finish of black raspberries. Try this easy-drinking wine with grilled tuna or a hamburger.

Intense underbrush aromas, black berries and baking spices lead the nose on this wine. The dense palate offers up juicy wild cherry, black pepper and cinnamon-spice alongside solid but velvety tannins. It's well balanced and already shows depth but hold for complexity. Drink 2016–2021.

wine: Jeff Cohn 2016 Broken Compass Saitone Vineyard Old Vine Carignane (Russian River Valley)
designation: Broken Compass Saitone Vineyard Old Vine
appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: From a well-known old-vine site for Zinfandel, this wine shows the prowess of other varieties within its ground. Thick, leathery and tart, it retains plenty of acidity within a core of full-powered earth and stems. The richness is complemented by seasonings of white and black pepper.

wine: Vigne di Mezzo 2004 Efesto  (Aglianico del Vulture)
appellation: Aglianico del Vulture, Southern Italy, Italy
review: Here is a very likable Aglianico del Vulture with bright spice flavors, big concentration and black fruit. The wine is dark and impenetrable with thick tannins and chewy succulence.

This is a fine, beautifully controlled wine. Its dark black currant fruits and firm dense texture are restrained, stylish and delicious. At the same time, the fruits offer a smooth, juicy aftertaste. Keep for 6–7 years.

A small portion of Château Peyrabon lies in the Pauillac appellation and is vinified separately. This is a surprisingly light wine for its appellation, fresh with fruitiness rather than structured. It has attractive black-currant acidity and a core of smoky tannins. Drink from 2018.

The shy nose on this wine keeps its secrets for now, showing only a hint of ripe pear. The palate comes in with the subtle richness of baked pear, freshness and gentle spice. A mellow fruit balance gives roundness and texture. The finish is off dry and bright.

wine: Cave de Kientzheim-Kaysersberg 2013 Furstentum Grand Cru Gewurztraminer (Alsace)
review: This wine is ripe, full while also fresh. A rounded character gains texture from the dry spiciness of nutmeg and pepper. Acidity holds this wine together and gives it fine potential. Drink from 2017.

Muga has crafted a steely, no-fat Viura (with 10% Malvasia), despite the wine being fermented in barrel. The nose is clean and passive, while the palate is crisp and tight but largely neutral in its delivery of apple and lemon flavors. From a cool vintage, this wine is like kissing the razor's edge. Good stuff but limited in what it has in store.

wine: Il Nuraghe 2000 San Bernardino  (Monica di Sardegna)
appellation: Monica di Sardegna, Sicily & Sardinia, Italy
review: Very cheesy in the nose, and that scent of English cheddar just won't go away. Otherwise, the wine has some starchy tannins propping up stewy plum and blackberry flavors. The finish of bitter chocolate and molasses is heavy and lacking in purity.

wine: Blue Farm 2017 Laceroni Vineyard Estate Farmed Chardonnay (Russian River Valley)
appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: This is a profusely complex, floral and mineral-driven white wine, gorgeously crafted to exhibit deft layers of Bosc pear, Gravenstein apple and lemon peel. Pronounced oak and tannin speak to its youth more than its style, leaving a weighty imprint of barrel and clove on the finish.

wine: Shannon Ridge 2016 High Elevation Collection Chardonnay (Lake County)
appellation: Lake County, Lake County, California, US
review: This full-bodied wine smells quite fruity and buttery, and tastes lush and ripe. It has plenty of vanilla, butterscotch, ripe pear and cream notes along with a texture so broad that it's almost sweet on the tongue.

appellation: Central Coast, Central Coast, California, US
review: Dark, bone dry and tannic, a full-bodied wine whose tartness and astringency call for rich fare, like beef stew. Shows deeply ripe flavors of blackberries, cassis, bitter dark chocolate and black pepper that are enlivened with brisk acidity.

appellation: Edna Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: Very rich in oak and ripe fruit, with kiwi, lime, pineapple and fig flavors that finish crisp and dry. The oak really stands out with its blast of buttered toast, caramel and woodspice.
Seems a trifle raisiny, with dark, plummy notes that come across as sun-baked rather than fresh. Still, it offers a mouthful of fruit and a nice, plump texture.

Shows everything that's noble about Oakville, from the wonderful, dusty tannins to the dryness and overall balance. Lovely, with flavors of blackberries, black currants and cedar. Could have more depth, though.

The best Oregon bottling ever from this exceptional producer. Spectacular, ripe, plush aromatics open into plummy, jammy, purely varietal fruit. But there is more, a textural complexity that incorporates light herb, leaf and vanilla notes. This has it all, and offers every bit as much pleasure as any of the single-vineyard bottlings.
This exciting wine is crisp and tangy, full of vivid fruit flavors like kiwi, lime and green apple. Good acidity gives it a lively, appetizing mouthfeel.

Already bottled, this wine isn't scheduled to be released until March 2005. If you like your Cabs big, rich and chewy (and who doesn't?) it's never to early to start badgering your retailer or wholesaler to try to get you some of the 613 cases produced. Toasty notes accent dark chocolate and plum scents, while intense cassis flavors fill the mouth. Sturdy; try after 2006.

Bottled without added sulfur, this wine is a blend made primarily with Merlot and Cabernet Franc. This mix gives a perfumed character to the juicy fruits. The tannins need to soften before the wine is ready to drink so wait until 2021.

Aromas of green pear, lime peel and lawn clippings show on the zesty nose of this bottling. There's a fresh and easy energy to the palate, where green apple peel, red apple and guava flavors slide into the finish.

wine: Cascina Luisin 2010 del Comune di Serralunga d'Alba Leon  (Barolo)
designation: del Comune di Serralunga d'Alba Leon
review: Black plum, fleshy wild cherry, crushed raspberry, white pepper, leather, sage, cinnamon and balsamic sensations are all woven together. It's nicely balanced with firm but fine tannins and brisk acidity, closing on a licorice note. Best after 2020.

wine: Pessagno 2006 Lucia Highlands Vineyard Pinot Noir (Santa Lucia Highlands)
appellation: Santa Lucia Highlands, Central Coast, California, US
review: Here's a savory, delicious and varietally true Pinor Noir that drinks well right away, but has the structural integrity for the cellar. With crisp, dry flavors of cherries, pomegranates, cola, tobacco and Chinese five-spice, it appeals for its exotic immediacy, but has the density to evolve for 5 or 6 years.

wine: Tero Estates 2007 Windrow Vineyards Reserve Cabernet Sauvignon (Walla Walla Valley (OR))
appellation: Walla Walla Valley (OR), Oregon Other, Oregon, US
review: This is superstrong Cabernet Sauvignon, with precise, concentrated flavors of brambly old-vine fruit taking center stage. The wine spent 33 months in barrel and has the density and power to prove it.

wine: Bennett Lane 2007 Reserve Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
review: Tons of fresh, succulent cherry and raspberry fruit flavors in this savory wine, elaborated with sweet, smoky oak. Made in a drink-me-now style, it's soft and lush, with beautifully ripe, smooth tannins.

wine: Carmel 2004 Kayoumi Single Vineyard Kosher Cabernet Sauvignon (Upper Galilee)
review: The acidity is strong and quite forward in this wine, both in the mouth and on the nose. Red berry preserves and a faint cocoa dusting flesh out the medium-weight mouth, with grainy tannins lingering through the finish.

While this smells directly from the Old World, it's appealing and unique in style for Argentina. For starters, it's mature, bordering on old. Because of vital acidity, it's in good shape, with stewed berry, tobacco, spice and chocolate flavors. On the finish, pepper and bitter coffee notes enter the picture. Drink this one-of-a-kind Merlot now.

wine: Elk Cove 2006 Five Mountain Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)
appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: Five Mountain is the newest addition to Elk Cove's single-vineyard portfolio, and it stands apart with sharp, spicy, pine resin highlights dotted with cranberry fruit. Tomato leaf and savory spices pile on through the finish; this is distinctive and well-crafted, though a bit off the mainstream Oregon style.

This richly fruity wine comes from the southern part of the Haut-Médoc, close to the city of Bordeaux. Its density and concentration give it the ability to age. With its black fruits and ripe tannins, it will likely be ready to drink from 2022.

wine: Château Tour des Gendres 2015 Les Anciens Francs Parcelle A252 Cabernet Franc (Côtes de Bergerac)
appellation: Côtes de Bergerac, Southwest France, France
review: A smoky perfume marks this young wine immediately as Cabernet Franc. Its ripe blackberry and juicy black currant flavors give it richness, while tannins come through strongly. It's a powerful, solid wine, with great potential. Drink from 2020.

Round, chunky aromas of grapefruit and passion fruit settle on friendly and varietally correct. This is snappy and solid in feel, with lime, orange and nectarine flavors. An acid-driven finish holds the line and doesn't taste bitter or green.

wine: Estampa 2004 Reserve Assemblage Syrah Red (Colchagua Valley)
review: Dark and just a touch herbal and green on the nose, but overall it's a pretty, beefy blend of Syrah (60%), Cabernet and Merlot that should win over even the most discerning of critics. The palate is balanced and features a rich, comfortable feel. And the finish is crisp but also long and rewarding. For $12 there's not much you can gripe about.

wine: Wines of Carmel 2001 Carmel Chardonnay Chardonnay (Monterey County)
appellation: Monterey County, Central Coast, California, US
review: From the warmer Carmel Valley, a wine with flavors of fruit pie, especially apples and peaches, including the sweet, buttery crust. Creamy, with an almond-skin bitterness on the finish.
Playful aromas of sweet fruit and watermelon candy open the nose of this bright Piedirosso wine. It's smooth and easygoing in the mouth and would pair with grilled sausage or lamb chops.

appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Stainless steel fermented, this pure varietal is bursting with a tasty fruit bowl mix of apple, pineapple, and Meyer lemon. A hint of mint sneaks in, and the acidity brings bracing minerality to the finish.

wine: Cinnabar 2008 Sleepy Hollow Vineyard Pinot Noir (Santa Lucia Highlands)
appellation: Santa Lucia Highlands, Central Coast, California, US
review: Opens with an ashy smell that mostly blows off if you give it a few moments to breathe. Afterwards, it's tough in acids and tannins, lacking generosity, although there's a good core of black cherry fruit.

wine: Vinícola Miolo 2005 Family Vineyards Merlot (Vale dos Vinhedos)
review: If you're ready to jump head-first into the emerging but sketchy realm of Brazilian table wine, then Merlot is a good place to start. This one has baked, earthy aromas of clay, spice and leather. The palate is fruity and saturated, with deep cherry, berry, coffee and prune flavors. Good in its class. Imported by GM Miolo, USA.

Waxy aromas of dried stone fruits and potent oak open this classy barrel-fermented Viura. A refined palate with cutting acidity energizes woody pear and apple flavors. On the finish, resiny oak and a wave of oxidized Sherry notes are highly complex but maybe not for everyone.

wine: Château La Rose du Pin 2011  Bordeaux
review: The wine is rounded and soft with attractive berry fruits and wood aging. It's fruity with juicy acidity, black currant freshness and a dry core that will allow it to age 2017–2018.

wine: Beauregard 2013 Beaureagard Ranch Chardonnay (Ben Lomond Mountain)
appellation: Ben Lomond Mountain, Central Coast, California, US
review: There's a warm peach ripeness on the nose of this wine from a tiny appellation north of Santa Cruz near Bonny Doon, along with aromas of kumquat, vanilla bean and sea salt. The palate shows more peach, caramelized apples and saffron, cut with a lime-juice acidity and finishing with a dollop of vanilla-butter.

wine: Elena Walch 2011 Beyond the Clouds White (Alto Adige)
review: Oak extract dominates the nose on this wine together with aromas of Golden Delicous apple and lemon zest. The palate offers lemon, oak, vanilla and clove, but it lacks the fruit richness needed to support the oak.

wine: Sevtap 2013 Shark Bait Petit Verdot (Happy Canyon of Santa Barbara)
appellation: Happy Canyon of Santa Barbara, Central Coast, California, US
review: This wine's aromas primary are very primary, evoking Concord grape and black plum, but hints of star anise and clove take it deeper. The flavors are jammy with superripe purple fruit, lifted by brown spice and black pepper.

wine: Domaine Claude Branger 2013 Terroir les Gras Moutons Sur Lie  (Muscadet Sèvre et Maine)
designation: Terroir les Gras Moutons Sur Lie
appellation: Muscadet Sèvre et Maine, Loire Valley, France
review: Les Gras Moutons is regarded as one of the top vineyards of Sèvre et Maine. Here it has produced a richly fragrant, aromatic wine that is structured and tightly textured. It's full of acidity, freshly squeezed lemon and some minerality. Drink from 2016.

wine: Iron Horse 2006 Brut X Sparkling (Green Valley)
review: This is one of Iron Horse's drier wines, with a low dosage, but it's still fairly sweet. There's a coating of sugar on the raspberries, oranges and limes. The bubbles are a bit scoury now, but this Pinot Noir and Chardonnay blend could develop nuances in the cellar after, say, 2013.

An intriguing combination of almost equal parts Malbec, Mourvèdre and Petit Verdot, Rock Wall's Romancer hails from Clarksburg's small Heringer Vineyard, and is bright, fruity and juicy with blackberry and strawberry flavors. Aromatic lavender and jasmine notes against a backdrop of meaty tobacco make the presence of Mourvedre apparent.

Starts out with plum, cherry and red cabbage aromas, which lead to a palate of light red fruit and mild vegetal flavors. Broad and starchy on the finish, with some thickness. Has its moments but doesn't really strike up the band.

wine: Spade Oak 2007 Heart of Gold Chardonnay (Gisborne)
review: Rather pulpy in texture, but the flavors are fresh and fruity, with bold notes of pineapple, lime and fruit salad. Crisp and clean on the finish.

wine: Turnbull 2010 Leopoldina Estate Grown Cabernet Franc (Oakville)
review: There's a raisin skin bitterness and some raisiny, Port-like flavors to this Cabernet Franc, suggesting some of the grapes were roasted on the vine. Other than that, it's softly tannic and savory, with cherry pie and oak notes.
Jammy, baked black cherry gives this wine a richness of flavor and texture, while cola and clove stand idly by in support. Lively acidity preserves a freshness on the palate.

appellation: El Dorado, Sierra Foothills, California, US
review: Tempting mint and cinnamon aromas meet ripe, almost roasted fruit flavors generously accented with oak notes like vanilla, cedar and woodsmoke. A full body and moderate tannins give it nice heft on the palate.

wine: Concha y Toro 2003 Marqués de Casa Concha Merlot (Peumo)
review: A wine the band Deep Purple could get into, because it's just that color and it rocks. The bouquet is dusty and loaded with dark chocolate and ripe blackberry. In the mouth, there's nothing miserly about it: lush plum, blackberry and licorice flavors are full and forward. Highly enjoyable, especially at this price.

Raspberry and pomegranate rise above aromas of white pepper and herbs. Tart cranberry, cedar and vanilla flavors are supported by chalky tannins and a vibrant vein of acidity, finishing on notes of cedar and raspberry.

wine: Château de Ribebon 2015 Cabernet Franc  (Bordeaux Supérieur)
review: Although the wine is labeled Cabernet Franc, it also has 15% Merlot in the blend. Nevertheless the ripe tannins and spicy perfumed character of the wine sing of rich Cabernet Franc. With its dense structure and tannins, the wine needs to age, so wait until 2021.

Opens with a sweet opulent nose driven by aromas of plump cherry, moist pipe tobacco, chocolate fudge, vanilla bean and ground espresso. But the wine is not modern or overtly international in terms of its style. It shows deep roots in Montalcino tradition and a bold, overt personality. Earth, leather and dried tobacco drive the finish.
Here's a wine that needs time to show its stuff, but it's very good in its youth. Dark and thick, with strong dusty tannins, but a core of blackberry fruit. Cellar it until 2005 and try again.

This big-shouldered blend of 60% Cabernet Sauvignon, 25% Petit Verdot, 10% Cabernet Franc and 5% Merlot offers soft waves of black fruit and smoky oak. It's accented with meatier elements of brick and tobacco.

This great value turns the neat trick of boasting an almost molasses-like density of fruit without seeming overly heavy. It's full-bodied, with hints of smoke, vanilla and herbs that add complexity to the cherry fruit, while on the finish, the tannins are soft and the flavors linger elegantly. Drink now through 2012.

wine: Acorn 2007 Allegria Vineyards Heritage Vines Zinfandel (Russian River Valley)
appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: This is a big, spicy, powerful Zinfandel that brims with berry, cherry, currant, chocolate and cedar flavors. It's not particularly subtle, but slams into the palate like an asteroid from space. Calls for barbecue, pure and simple.

wine: Louis Latour 2003 Chambertin les Heritiers Latour  (Chambertin)
review: A wine that explodes with powerful, ripe flavors. It offers complex black fruit flavors, and tons of spice plus ample acidity. This great wine should develop over many years. Imported by Louis Latour.

appellation: Temecula Valley, South Coast, California, US
review: Snappy lime, lemon-flesh and citrus-blossom aromas indicate an acid-driven expression on the nose of this bottling. The palate begins with a fresh splash of that citrus, then widens toward riper honeydew and mango flavors.

appellation: Horse Heaven Hills, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Varietally designated Pinot Noirs are an extreme rarity from this warm region. This one brings notes of cranberry, copper penny and herb, although the aromas not in sync. The flavors are plump and sweet, showing a sense of elegance.

wine: Les Vignerons de Cases de Péne 2003 Château de Peña Réserve C Red (Côtes du Roussillon Villages)
winery: Les Vignerons de Cases de Péne
appellation: Côtes du Roussillon Villages, Languedoc-Roussillon, France
review: Based on old Carignan vines, this ripe, fruity wine is full of great barbecue-wine flavors. It's bold and juicy, with some dusty tannins and fresh red fruits on the finish.

appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
review: There's intriguing precision to the nose of this bottling from Chad Melville and family. A laser-sharp line of tart elderberry, black-plum skins and black-cherry skins cut through the dark earth, tar and purple-flower elements. The palate blends approachable black raspberry, dark strawberry and muddled mulberry fruit with touches of coffee and dark cocoa.

The flint soil behind this wine gives it a stony, smoky character that is allied to the mineral texture. It's a ripe wine, still young with pure fruit and an intense acidity. The wine needs to age, so drink from 2018.

Rubber and savory berry aromas lead it off. The palate shows good texture and overall smoothness, with round cassis and plum flavors. Very competent and solid on the finish, with toasty, warming afternotes and only a slight tannic grab. Textbook Malbec given the price range.

wine: Walter Scott 2017 Cuvée Ruth Pinot Noir (Eola-Amity Hills)
appellation: Eola-Amity Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: Strawberry and cherry fruit, wrapped in sweet spices, gives this a warm, open, drink-me character. A lovely streak of cherry tobacco informs the finish.

Silken in texture and redolent of kirsch, leather and dried earth, this full-bodied blend of Syrah (50%), Grenache (40%) and Mourvèdre (10%) is a powerful expression of ripeness calibrated by the zest of limestone soils and high-altitude vineyard sites. Fermented and matured in oak, it has black-cherry and cassis flavors accented by smoke, vanilla and clove along with a fine, feathery rim of tannins. Delicious already, the wine should improve through 2028.

wine: Valdivieso 2018 Single Vineyard Piedra Hermosa Vineyard Pinot Noir (Cauquenes Valley)
review: Jumpy red fruit aromas suggest hot rocks and iron. A fresh, lean palate is agile, while raspberry, currant and herbal green flavors reflect the wine's cool coastal origins. Zesty acidity and red fruit leftovers drive a lean finish.

wine: Miscreant Project 2017 Boldfaced Lie Miscreant Affirmation #03 Red (Columbia Valley (WA))
appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Cabernet Sauvignon accounts for 60% of this wine, with the rest Merlot. The aromas are bright, with notes of rose hips, raspberry gummy, dried herb and spice. Fairly smoky cherry flavors follow, creating some distraction.

wine: Clos du Bois 2001 Pinot Noir (Sonoma County)
review: A simple, soft, fruity and one-dimensional Pinot that offers up slight flavors of raspberries, pepper and tobacco. Fully dry, with silky tannins and bracing acids, but it's hard to get over the anorexic profile.

The little-known wine region of Tumbarumba, on the foothills of the Snowy Mountains in New South Wales, often producers fascinating cool-climate high-altitude wines. This Pinot is no exception. The nose is a fragrant combo of fresh tarragon and other wild scrubby herbs, red berries, florals and white-peppery spice. Light to medium bodied, the palate is fresh and bright, with juicy fruit and savory spicy undertones. It's slippery in texture, with a soft grip of herb-flecked tannins. Drink slightly chilled with springtime cuisine.

Very aromatic, showing a complex nose of cherry, spice, smoked and raw meat, and tobacco. The flavors are copious, too, with strong black cherry, licorice and tobacco elements. Balance and structure are beautiful here, and the coffee-chocolate finish has very good length, showing spice and blueberry accents. Lovely already, it will be better in four years and will drink well to 2010.

Olive, raisin, cassis, clove and wood grain aromas constitute an interesting nose. A full palate with resiny oak and noticeable tannins sets up a flavor profile based mostly on clove, oak and berry fruit. While this remains oaky across the finish, there's enough dark fruit here to make this well worth a go. Drink through 2022.
93-95 A fine wine, the juicy fruits overlaying the firm structure. It has all the right weight, perfumes, new wood element. A great success.

wine: Ledda 2014 Tenuta Monte Santu Ruiu Red (Isola dei Nuraghi)
appellation: Isola dei Nuraghi, Sicily & Sardinia, Italy
review: Made with native grapes Cannonau and Muristellu, this opens with aromas of underbrush, tilled soil, leather and tobacco leaf. Smooth and full bodied, the rounded palate offers dried black cherry, licorice and pipe tobacco alongside fine-grained tannins. It closes on a graphite note and the warmth of alcohol that throws it slightly off balance.

wine: Stemmler 2013 Anderson Valley Pinot Noir (Anderson Valley)
appellation: Anderson Valley, Mendocino County, California, US
review: Gorgeous fruit aromas and flavors fill out this plush-textured and softly balanced wine. It offers ripe black cherry and raspberry tones and a full body, but has a delightful, light touch on the palate. The finish lingers nicely, too.

wine: J. Portugal Ramos 2004 Antão Vaz White (Alentejano)
review: Delicious, fresh, fruity and clean; great acidity, creamy flavors and aromas of summer hedgerow flowers. Imported by Aidil Wines & Liquor Inc.

wine: Tiger Lily 2018 Reserve Estate Zinfandel (El Dorado)
appellation: El Dorado, Sierra Foothills, California, US
review: This plummy, chocolaty wine is soft and flavorful, low in tannins and high in ripeness and ease of sipping.

wine: Songs 2020 Young Forever Karayannis Vineyard Cabernet Franc (Paso Robles)
appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: Plenty of purple-flower aromas waft across the white-pepper and black-raspberry elements on the nose of this bottling. The floral qualities sing on the sip as well, where lilac and rosewater provide an elegant foil to the grape Jolly Rancher flavor.

appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: Sweet and simple, with vanilla, butterscotch and Lifesaver candy flavors.

appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Sobra is Brazilian Portuguese for leftovers. It's a Bordeaux blend, but the recipe changes every year. This is very nice and drinking well, smooth with a nicely resolved mix of black fruits, smoky wood, pepper and a bit of bacon fat.
The lemon note on the nose is tender yet focused and pure. The concentrated palate comes off as crystalline in nature, almost fragile. The mentholated freshness lingers on the palate. Drink by 2050.

wine: La Honda Winery 2013 Lonehawk Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Santa Cruz Mountains)
appellation: Santa Cruz Mountains, Central Coast, California, US
review: Rich blackberry and candied black-cherry aromas meet with strong cedar, roast beef, smoke, olive, soy and a tarry quality on the nose of this bottling. It's very dry and sticky with tannins on the sip, which relegate the flavors of red cherry and roasting herbs to the background. The 100% American oak treatment remains prominent, so this may evolve more favorably with time.

wine: Chakana 2016 Inkarri Made With Organic Grapes Estate Bottled Bonarda (Mendoza)
designation: Inkarri Made With Organic Grapes Estate Bottled
review: Feral aromas of rubbery berry fruits mixed with animal scents make for a woolly opening. This Bonarda has a narrow clamping mouthfeel and sour-meets-savory flavors of red plum and tomato. A screechy finish is high in acidity.

Blended with 9% Cabernet Sauvignon, 8% Malbec and 3% Petit Verdot, this is a thick and concentrated showing of the variety, plush and lushly spicy in clove and cinnamon. The fruit is plummy and rich in dark cherry, toasted oak and vanilla tea.

wine: Loring Wine Company 2013 Sierra Mar Vineyard Chardonnay (Santa Lucia Highlands)
appellation: Santa Lucia Highlands, Central Coast, California, US
review: Charred vanilla beans and lemon custard greet the nose on this single-vineyard bottling by Buellton-based Brian Loring. The flavors are quite subdued at first, and then unleash green pears and red apples, with lime pith bitterness and a wet slate minerality that arises toward the finish.

wine: Domaine Combe Blanche 2009 La Chandelière Red (Minervois La Liviniere)
review: The nose has subtle notes of game, iodine, lavender and blackberry, which follow through oto the palate. Suave and supple tannins pair with medium acidity and evident glycerol, making this an easy-drinking red. It has integrated yet high alcohol, and the short finish points to a drinking window of two years.

appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: Feels hot and prickly, with simple cherry, cola and spice flavors, as well as thick, astringent tannins. And the acidity tastes unnatural.

wine: Artisan Wines DI Franz Scheider 2017 Pure Welschriesling (Burgenland)
review: The freshness of green and yellow apple dominates the nose. The palate has an earthy inflection but is light, bright, vivid and dry. This is refreshing and easy with a very clean finish.

wine: Hill Wine Company 2012 Chardonnay (Russian River Valley)
appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: Dry and flinty, it delivers an ultra-clean mouthfeel that's brightened by crisp acidity. The flavors are of lemons and limes, with a hint of golden mango and honey. Drink fare like with shrimp in cream sauce or grilled scallops with buttery polenta.

wine: Bernardus 2003 Rosella's Vineyard Pinot Noir (Santa Lucia Highlands)
appellation: Santa Lucia Highlands, Central Coast, California, US
review: I love the silky texture of this Pinot, with its crisp acids and fine, smooth tannins. The fruit is enormous, bursting with cherry and mocha flavors. It seems rather sweet now, but that may be its youth. Give it until mid-2006 to come together.

wine: Raphael 2012 Chardeaux White (North Fork of Long Island)
appellation: North Fork of Long Island, Long Island, New York, US
review: This cheeky blend of Chardonnay and Bordeaux-inspired Sauvignon Blanc is delicately framed. Fresh and fruity, it discloses apple and lemon notes accented with hints of smoke and savory nuts.

wine: Seven Hills 2014 Seven Hills Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Walla Walla Valley (WA))
appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: This wine comes from this vineyard's original Cabernet blocks planted in 1980. Wound-up aromas of woodspice, herb, pencil lead and dark fruit are followed by concentrated but still supple black-fruit flavors. It's high up on the hedonistic scale, accentuated by a lengthy finish. Decant to let it open up.

appellation: Lake Chelan, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: This brings an intriguing assortment of dried fruit including pear, spiced apple and apricot. It drinks off dry, with abundant stone fruit flavors that linger on the finish.

wine: Clos du Lac 2012 Estate Rosé (Sierra Foothills)
appellation: Sierra Foothills, Sierra Foothills, California, US
review: Made from a blend of 60% Grenache and 40% Syrah, this Best Buy is a heady combo of sweet raspberry and plum, dry and straightforward, ready to open and enjoy now as a very good quaff.

Very rich and concentrated, this is a blockbuster wine. Its sweet fruit is packed with a high amount of toast flavors. Acidity seems to be missing, giving the wine opulence without the final sense of age worthiness.

Delicate but enticing scents of wild red berries, sun-warmed hay and stone fruit waft out of the glass. Tangy and bright, the savory palate delivers ripe pear, pomegranate and a hint of honeydew before closing on a saline mineral note. It's a fantastic rosato.

wine: Sandro de Bruno 2010 60 Mesi Extra Brut  (Lessini Durello)
review: Heady aromas of yellow spring flower, ripe white stone fruit, botanical herb and honey shape the nose. The aromas follow over to the dry, silky palate along with mature yellow apple, hazelnut and a sprinkling of baking spice before a slate finish. Crisp acidity and a light perlage accompany the rich flavors.

This food-friendly wine is most remarkable for its structure and gracefulness on the palate. Herbal on the entry, it offers grip and elegance within sturdy elongated tannins, a note of brushy cedar and sage and integrated French oak.
Apple-cider and earth aromas open to a simple apple-toast palate. The mouthfeel is even, the finish dry and rather woody. Then again, there are few drinkable California Chardonnays of this age.

Full, serious and ripe, with leather, animal and an underside of savory oak and bacon. Typical of the house style, the wine is lush and jammy, with syrupy black-fruit flavors setting up a composed, rich finish. Best for fans of hefty, New World reds.

This is solid, journeyman Riesling offering a full grapey bouquet with diesel and earth accents. Grape and mild citrus flavors play on the easy mouthfeel and the decently long, slightly mineral finish.

This has a shy nose that eventually reveals mocha, tilled soil and cedar, while the firm palate offers dried black cherry, tobacco and sage. Assertive, grippy tannins leave an astringent finish. Drink after 2021.

wine: Stags' Leap Winery 2013 The Investor Red (Napa Valley)
review: This new blend features 38% Merlot, 32% Petite Sirah, 18% Cabernet Sauvignon and 12% Malbec, combining brawn with beauty. Red fruit and a light grip of oak wrap around a softly textured body, making for an approachable, easygoing experience.

wine: Domaine Jérome Marcadet 2020 Pinot Noir Gamay Pinot Noir-Gamay (Cheverny)
review: The dense texture of this wine promises well. It supports the black fruits and acidity in a combination that has weight and plenty of richness. The wine will be at its best from 2022.

wine: Willamette Valley Vineyards 2012 AVA Series Pinot Noir (Chehalem Mountains)
appellation: Chehalem Mountains, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: The grapes for this limited-production wine come from the outstanding Alloro vineyard. The texture and complexity are immediately apparent. Mouthcoating plum and cherry fruit combines with lively citrus, toasty oak and a rich chocolate note. Drink now or put some away for a few years, but don't miss this one.

From a trio of vineyards, this white is grassy and fruity in equal measure, with flavors of pineapple, maraschino cherry and kiwi. Lively acidity keeps it fresh in the glass, leading to a mineral-laden finish.

wine: Ram's Gate 2018 Gap's Crown Vineyard Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)
review: Demure in dense red fruit, this wine comes to life in lively acidity and a crispy texture that defines its cool-climate provenance. Black tea, nutmeg and a note of dried herb provide savory earthiness and length.

A ripe, perfumed, relatively soft wine, which is going to give great pleasure with its juicy fruit, ripe jelly flavors and balancing acidity. You could enjoy this wine within a year, but it should age well over the next five or six.
A little ungainly now, with stiff tannins and lots of fresh, jammy raspberry and cherry fruit colliding with unintegrated oak notes. All the parts are there, but they need until 2019–2020 to meld.
90-92 Perfumed, juicy wine, fresh, with delicious acidity and blackberry fruits. A fruit bomb of a wine.

wine: Peter Lehmann 1999 The Mentor Red (Barossa Valley)
review: Though it's named after Peter Lehmann, this is not an imposing, masculine wine. It has plum and cassis fruit at its core and fresh cream on the nose, with a moderate, appropriate-for-food weight. A blend of Cabernet Sauvignon, Merlot, Shiraz and Malbec.

wine: Willamette Valley Vineyards 2003 Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)
appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: This is a good effort for the price, showing spicy cherry and raspberry fruit, light hints of herb, beet root and moist earth. It seems to get a bit earthier as it weaves into the finish, but it's well balanced and certainly well matched to salmon, swordfish or poultry dishes.
This is a steely wine wrapped with white and green fruit flavors. It is clean, bright and full of pear and crisp apple notes. The tangy after taste is floral. Ready to drink in six months.

wine: Jefferson Vineyards 2014 Estate Reserve Petit Verdot (Monticello)
review: This Petit Verdot feels almost sinful, bursting with aromas of dark chocolate, followed by notes of violets, prune and coffee. Balanced by bright acidity and well integrated tannins, this feels velvety on the palate, with a smooth, plush finish.

This Barossa Shiraz veers on the lighter brighter side of the road than most, although it's still a fairly full-figured wine. A medley of red berry fruit, mint, mocha and cloves make up the nose, while the palate is satiny in texture and wound by soft but structured tannins amidst prickly savory brambly tones. There's an appealing fruity and spice finish.

Ripe, and densely textured, this wine shows an impressive, rich balance between fruit and tannins, with a dry core and broad black fruits that have great intensity. This wine, with 12 months in wood, conveys spice, concentration and excellent potential. Drink from 2024.

wine: Umani Ronchi 2003 Casal di Serra Vecchie Vigne  (Verdicchio dei Castelli di Jesi Classico Superiore)
appellation: Verdicchio dei Castelli di Jesi Classico Superiore, Central Italy, Italy
review: Aromas of honey, spring flowers, grapefruit and almond skin are intact and beautifully presented thanks to stainless steel fermentation. This is a late harvest wine from 30-year-old vines that earns points for its natural ability to pair with food.
A powerful, chocolate- and berry fruit-flavored wine, powered by ripe tannins and juicy acidity. It has a solid foundation of tannins, on which is built a rich edifice of fruit.

wine: Chateau Capion 2009 Le Colombier White (Coteaux du Languedoc)
review: This is a rich and round white that needs a bit more cut to its overall character. Honeyed peach, buttered toast and heavy cream all abound, screaming for more acidity to liven up the party.

appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US

review: 92-94 Barrel sample. Very sweet new wood, caramel aromas that give the wine an initial softness. Then acidity and sweet blackberry flavors move in, suggesting that this will be a finely balanced wine once it is bottled.

With just 4% Viognier, for better or worse it doesn't have that  lifted-aroma quality that Viognier usually lends these kinds of blends. Feel is rough at first but smoothes out; there's a fair dose of wood here. With air, blueberry flavors come to the fore. Still this is not a deep wine. Imported by Wilson Daniels Ltd.

Merlot in the Barossa can be a tricky proposition, but this bottling successfully juxtaposes superripe, chocolate fudge notes with surprisingly tart acids. Hints of licorice, vanilla and black cherries impart complexity, while creamy tannins and crisp acids mark the finish. Drink now–2012.

wine: Be Good or Be Gone 2015 BG 2 The French Revolution Lot 3 Red (Vin de France)
appellation: Vin de France, France Other, France
review: A blend of 50% Cabernet Sauvignon from Cévennes, 30% Grenache and 20% Syrah from Southern Rhône, this opens with a gamy, rustic bouquet of iron, leather, black plum and boysenberry. It's gripping and tight on the palate, with a lingering cured-meat character through the close.

wine: Darcie Kent Vineyards 2009 Crown Block Merlot (Livermore Valley)
appellation: Livermore Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: A dark, plummy Livermore Valley Merlot that reminds one of herb-encrusted roasted meats, and would be a good wine to pair with such a feast. Full-bodied and lush, with a smoky, oaky finish and cedar lurking throughout.

Intense in the nose, with sharp leathery notes. Pure and clear cherry fruit forms the basis of what is a splendidly clean palate. The finish is tannic and tight, but it provides excellent support for the wine and indicates that it will age well. This is a leaner, traditional wine. Fanatics of fat, rich fruit bombs may not be impressed. —M.S.

wine: Aljibes 2011 Petit Verdot (Vino de la Tierra de Castilla)
appellation: Vino de la Tierra de Castilla, Central Spain, Spain
review: Grapy, horsey berry aromas are herbal, jumbled and suggestive of untamed brush. A full but flabby palate offers funky, lightly herbal flavors of cherry and berry. A sticky, sweet-tasting, finish lacks cut but is far from out of whack.

wine: Patricia Green Cellars 2017 Notorious Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)
appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: This is the only wine among the winery's vast portfolio that is aged in 100% new French oak. Its green label also sets it apart from the rest, and it's priced as a reserve (from a winery whose every bottle could be called a reserve without a quibble). It's a stunning wine, vibrant with rich red and black berry fruit, cherry, orange peel, root beer, toast, chocolate and on it goes. Just a splendid bottle in every possible way.

Aromas of white peach and dusty minerals lead to a chunky palate that struggles to maintain its shape and cut. Pithy, lightly bitter peach and citrus flavors end with the sensation of licking a peach pit.

wine: Wakefield 2015 Jaraman Coonawarra & Clare Valley Cabernet Sauvignon (South Australia)
review: This vintage is a strong offering. The fruit is from two top South Aussie Cabernet regions: Clare Valley and Coonawarra, and both regions shine through. The nose leads with plums, currants, pencil lead, black olives and oak spice. The palate follows, with lifted tangy and juicy fruit that acts as a counterweight to the fine chalky tannins and oak spice. This is a relatively straightforward but varietally expressive drop with a long, brambly finish.

wine: José Maria da Fonseca 2019 Periquita Rosé (Península de Setúbal)
review: The wine is all fruit, dominated by Castelão at its ripest and crispest. It is lightly textured, with red currant fruits and perfumed acidity. Drink now.

wine: Bloomer Creek 2013 Tanzen Dame Auten Vineyard 2nd Clone 10 Dry Riesling (Finger Lakes)
designation: Tanzen Dame Auten Vineyard 2nd Clone 10 Dry
appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
review: Waxy lanolin, lime zest and savory nuts waft solemnly from this distinctly earthy dry Riesling. It's a showcase of minerality—shades of clay, dust, smoke and rock—but fascinatingly so, bolstered by a shock of lemon-lime acidity.

wine: Sparkling Pointe 2006 Brut Séduction  (North Fork of Long Island)
appellation: North Fork of Long Island, Long Island, New York, US
review: Complexities of mushroom, caramel and brioche lend a haze of maturity over delicate strawberry and cherry notes in this Champagne-style sparkling,which was aged for eight years over lees. Tiny, persistent bubbles spread seamlessly on the palate, accentuated by streaks of racy acidity.

wine: Left Bend 2013 Muns Vineyard Pinot Noir (Santa Cruz Mountains)
appellation: Santa Cruz Mountains, Central Coast, California, US
review: Featuring a unique and intriguingly fresh and floral nose, this shows bright strawberry, fresh-pressed hibiscus flowers, exotic vanilla-cinnamon notes and hints of slate and chaparral. The palate is just a hair less exciting, with raspberry, cranberry, white pepper, white sage and dried mint, all wrapped with tart acidity and tannins.

wine: Columbia Crest 2016 Reserve Late Harvest Muscat Canelli (Columbia Valley (WA))
appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: The aromas leap out of the glass, with notes of freshly peeled tangerine, white flowers, jasmine and honeysuckle. It drinks quite sweet but manages to stay in balance. It's a delicious example of this variety. Enjoy it for dessert.

Restrained creaminess on the nose promises subtle refreshment. The palate follows with a harmonious rounded notion of red apple, ripe lemon and citrus-spiked shortbread that unites seamlessly. The fizz is fine and creamy giving sustained freshness, real pleasure and utter honesty. It's very charming and very lovely.

wine: Siduri 2016 Ewald Vineyard Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)
appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: Tart in complex acidity and subtle flavors of strawberry, pomegranate and orange, this is a light-bodied, lightly ripe wine, that's angular and elegant.

wine: Nickel & Nickel 1999 Stelling Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Oakville)
Raphael 2014 First Label Chardonnay (North Fork of Long Island)
appellation: North Fork of Long Island, Long Island, New York, US
review: Notes of pressed apple and pear mingle into complexities of vanilla, clove and toast in this barrel-aged Chardonnay. Full bodied in style, it's a ripe richly textured wine but balanced briskly. The finish lingers long.
Soft, overripe and simple, with chocolate-covered raisin, cassis and caramelized oak flavors. It's delicious, in the modern style of ripe extraction, but lacks structure and dryness.

wine: Lieubeau 2016 Domaine de la Fruitière Gneiss de Bel Abord Sur Lie  (Muscadet Sèvre et Maine)
designation: Domaine de la Fruitière Gneiss de Bel Abord Sur Lie
appellation: Muscadet Sèvre et Maine, Loire Valley, France
review: From gneiss base rock that is similar to granite, this tight, taut and mineral wine is intensely crisp, dominated by acidity and by bright citrus flavors. It comes from a vineyard that is being converted to organic farming. The wine is young and will be ready to drink from 2018.

wine: Eberle 2013 Mill Road Vineyard Viognier (Paso Robles)
appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: The grape's usual peachy aromas show on this wine from regional pioneer Gary Eberle, along with lemon juice, honey and a touch of minerality. There is a nice mineral-driven tension on the palate, with flavors of apple and pear cider. It's a solid, down-the-middle take on the grape—not too ripe, not too thin.

The freshness and concentration of the fruit flavors in this full-bodied wine is exceptional. It smells like Concord juice and tastes dark and grapy, forming a simple but appealing personality that's hard to resist.

wine: Fondazione Edmund Mach 2010 Istituto Agrario San Michele all'Adige Sauvignon (Trentino)
review: From the vineyards of Italy's most important school of enology, this bright Sauvignon delivers clean aromas of passion fruit, citrus, peach and tomato leaf. It's fresh, with balanced acidity.

appellation: Adelaida District, Central Coast, California, US
review: Ripe aromas of red cherry and baking spice show on the nose of this bottling of Pinot Noir from a relatively warm area. The flavors are quite extracted on the palate, with blackberry, boysenberry and dried mint.

From San Rafael in southern Mendoza, this Cab Sauvignon picks up a little more steam and complexity every time you go back to it. The nose is your basic cassis and raspberry, while the medium-weight palate features ripe fruit finishing in a sweet cascade of milk chocolate and burnt brown sugar. Satisfying, especially if you like a hint of sweetness to your Cab.

wine: Davis Family 2016 Rosé de Noir Dutton Ranch Sparkling (Russian River Valley)
appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: Made by the Méthode Champenoise from Pinot Noir grapes grown at the Green Valley ranch, this tastes of watermelon, grapefruit and cherry. Meaty in texture with moderate weight, it is lively and fresh, with lasting acidity.

wine: Tarara 2010 Whitie's D9 A Big Bold Red (Virginia)
review: As the name suggests, this blend of Merlot and Cabernet Sauvignon does taste big and bold, but it also tastes hot and lopsided. It has a Port-like consistency, with notes of charred sesame seed, chocolate and dark cherry that lack precision.

wine: Maryhill 2010 Proprietor's Reserve Cabernet Sauvignon (Columbia Valley (WA))
appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: This simple Cabernet Sauvignon is lightly fruity and forward, with berry flavors that seem to fade on the midpalate. It resolves in a wash of drying, herbal tannins.

wine: One Hope 2009 Two Pisces Vineyard Reserve Blanc de Noir Sparkling (Sonoma Coast)
designation: Two Pisces Vineyard Reserve Blanc de Noir
review: It's easy to like this smooth, clean sparkling wine, which hails from the Petaluma Gap, an increasingly important area in the cool, foggy south of the Russian River Valley. It's very rich in raspberries and strawberries, with notes of sweet vanilla and yeast. The mouthfeel is smooth and elegant.

appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
review: More like an Italian Pinot Grigio than an Alsatian Pinot Gris, this wine is light and lively on the palate, with a peachy-floral nose, a slightly creamy mouthfeel, and zesty lemon-lime flavors. Finishes with a touch of bitter almond.

wine: J. Bookwalter 2015 Protagonist Conner-Lee Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Columbia Valley (WA))
appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: This brings roasted coffee bean, char, leafy green herb, spice and cherry aromas, and the oak (75% new French) plays a prominent part in the show. The palate is rich, textured and supple, with plentiful black cherry and barrel flavors that linger on the finish. It hits the gong hard, feeling totally hedonistic.

wine: Gorman 2014 The Bully Cabernet Sauvignon (Red Mountain)
appellation: Red Mountain, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: The aromas are wound up at present, with notes of generous barrel spices, dried herb, dark fruit and pencil lead. The dark-cherry flavors are smooth and supple, backed by fine-grained tannins.

appellation: Yorkville Highlands, North Coast, California, US
review: With layers of nutty, toasty oak flavors lingering in the background, this is a Sauvignon Blanc with lushness to its core of melon, guava and grass notes.

wine: Steiner Family Vineyards 2012 Cabernet Franc (El Dorado)
appellation: El Dorado, Sierra Foothills, California, US
review: A smoky, peppery aroma and equally spicy flavor set this medium-bodied wine apart from the pack. Dry in style, it has a firm, tannic texture. Bring out the lamb or beef to enjoy with this one.

wine: Acumen 2019 Mountainside Sauvignon Blanc (Dry Creek Valley)
appellation: Dry Creek Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: Stony mineral gives way to a tangy tropical midpalate of sweet peach and melon in this creamy full-figured wine.

wine: François Lurton 2008 El Albar Lurton Tempranillo (Vino de la Tierra de Castilla y León)
appellation: Vino de la Tierra de Castilla y León, Northern Spain, Spain
review: Dark and baked on the nose, with rubbery aromas. Strong, strapping and tannic Tempranillo with roasted black fruit flavors and herbal shadings. A rough, tough style with heat and black coffee on the finish.

appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: This bottling spent 20 months in French oak (30% new), and incorporates fruit from Ponzi's Aurora, Abetina and Madrona vineyards. Superripe aromas and flavors conjure up a rich and riveting mix of black cherry with amaro-like botanical nuances. This profound wine is already irresistible, but stash a few bottles in your cellar, to drink now through 2030.

The nose is quiet here suggesting trace hints of toast and smoky mineral, but the palate of this spry, fresh-footed Pinot Noir offers bold strokes of zippy black cherry and raspberry. Freshly concentrated and edged by fine-grained, silky tannins, it's a wine that's ready now but should drink beautifully through at least 2028.

It's easy to appreciate the buttery aromas, vivid and tangy fruit like crisp apples and Bosc pears, and lively texture with appetizing acidity, elegance and raciness. It's not a big wine but a finely detailed one.

appellation: South Eastern Australia, Australia Other, Australia
review: A wine that's been under development at Rosemount for three years, this is the variety's debut under the Rosemount label. It's plump and round in the mouth, featuring honey and peach notes that turn crisper on the finish.

wine: Closerie du Bailli 2012  Blaye Côtes de Bordeaux
appellation: Blaye Côtes de Bordeaux, Bordeaux, France
review: Powerfully structured, this is a dense wine, with layers of ripe fruit as well as tannins. It is concentrated, firm and showing its structure. The black plum fruit flavors from the 70% Merlot and 30% Cabernet Sauvignon blend give weight and a broad character to the aftertaste. Drink from 2017. Produced by Alliance Bourg.

wine: Joseph Swan Vineyards 2004 Trenton Estate Vineyard Syrah (Russian River Valley)
appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: Tons of jammy fruit in this softly tannic, easy-to-drink wine. Explodes with the essence of blackberries, cherries, raspberries, mulberries and chocolate, with plenty of pepper and other Asian spices.

wine: Sartori 2004 I Saltari Le Vigne di Turano  (Valpolicella Superiore)
designation: I Saltari Le Vigne di Turano
review: Compared to the 2003 vintage, the fruit is slightly more vibrant and polished here. There's also a slightly green note of herb or dill that we didn't notice in the past. The mouthfeel is, however, bright, crisp and refreshingly informal.

Highly aromatic, this explodes with bright passion fruit scents and herbal pungency. Lots of pink grapefruit flavor and a zesty, crisp finish make this eminently drinkable. Drink now, as an apéritif or with light appetizers.

appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: Aromas of dark berry, mint and fudge kick off the nose of this bottling. Firm tannins frame the ripe berry, herb, mint and cocoa flavors, with fresh acidity driving it all.

A 50-50 blend of Sangiovese and Cabernet, this wine is rich and opulent, without being at all heavy or exaggerated. The mouthfeel is smooth, soft but structured and there is a long fruit and spice flavored finish.
