Aromas of red-skinned berry, leather and underbrush lead the nose on this Sangiovese. The straightforward, juicy palate offers raspberry, cinnamon and white pepper alongside smooth tannins. Drink soon.

appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Though 100% Merlot, it seems more reminiscent of a Syrah with notes of blue fruit and ash. The flavors are light with chalky, mouthcoating tannins.

wine: Leacock's NV Rainwater Tinta Negra Mole (Madeira)
review: On the lighter, fresher side of Madeira, with candied citrus flavors edging out honey and nut notes. Ends with a smoky, citrusy tang.

Rather stocky, with beef bouillon, blackberry and rubber on the nose. The feel is solid while the plum, berry and leathery flavors display some of the heat of the year. Not a refined wine but good in an easy, drink-me-now way. Could use cheese or some roasted meat.

Very nicely composed with toasty oak over apple/pear fruit and crème brûlée aromas. It has a full but not heavy mouthfeel, with rich apple and butterscotch flavors. The finish is tangy and toasty, with good length.

wine: T2 2016 Reserve Red Willow Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Yakima Valley)
appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Aromas of bittersweet chocolate and maraschino cherry are followed by lighter-styled fruit flavors. The concentration doesn't all seem to be there.

wine: Bodegas Dios Baco S.L. NV Imperial Amontillado VOS Sherry (Jerez)
review: A turbid brownish-gold color is cloudy but nothing else about this amontillado is unclear. Concentrated aromas of nut oil, pecan pie, molasses and sweat are rugged and raw. Blasting acidity creates pinch on the palate, while this tastes salty and like almonds, pecan pie and white pepper. A long finish with bracing acidity will not be swayed.

wine: Simonsig 2007 Cape Winemakers Guild Cuvée Chêne Blanc de Blancs Chardonnay (Stellenbosch)
designation: Cape Winemakers Guild Cuvée Chêne Blanc de Blancs
review: Winemaker: Johan Malan. This mature beauty still has plenty of life left in it, as vibrant notes of orange peel, apple skin and wood-grilled peach are met with complementary tones of honeycomb, candied ginger and toasted challah. The palate is full and creamy, but very bright, with mouthwatering acidity that cuts through the rich baked apple, pear butter and toasted sweet spice flavors. Drink now–2020.

appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
review: Clean and fresh with hints of underripe mango, fresh apples and lemon, this dry, medium-bodied Chardonnay is pleasantly brisk but hindered by a slightly soapy floral note in the midpalate and bitterness on the finish.

A nice Cab from a great vintage. Ripe and juicy in currant, cherry, cocoa and oak flavors, with lush, complex tannins that make for a creamy mouth feel. From veteran Bob Pepi, mostly Cab, with a splash of Merlot.

appellation: Santa Ynez Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: This wine is mostly Syrah, which gives juicy blackberry, plum and chocolate-covered raisin flavors. The slight percent of Viognier brings acidity and an uplifted floral note to this easy-drinking wine.

wine: Tenuta di Fessina 2008 Ero Nero d'Avola (Sicilia)
review: Ero is packed tight with bright berry, cassis and white almond. That all-Sicilian jamminess you sometimes find in this variety is absent here.

Generic berry aromas combined with oak and bath soap scents set up a jammy, soft, chunky palate with baked berry, plum, loam and savory flavors. Licorice, baked berry and an overriding ripeness carry the finish on this ready-to-drink Malbec.

A delicate nose of cola, cocoa powder and white pepper leads this food-friendly red from Greece. Balanced minerality and a delicate fruit character offer a lighter touch than many Greek reds. Cocoa, plum and spice dominate. Pair with grilled lamb, sausages.

This well-balanced, medium-bodied wine is an ideal choice for those who prefer a lively texture over pure richness. There are plenty of tasty cherry and berry flavors, all nicely supported by tangy acidity.

On the right bank of Bordeaux, close to Lussac Saint-Emilion, this property has produced a ripe, Merlot-dominant wine. With juicy black fruits and richness, this wine is warm, generous. and will be ready from late 2020.

wine: Château Castel des Maures 2012 Cuvée Jeanne Rosé (Côtes de Provence)
review: fruits touched with caramel and soft tannin. It's well balanced, with fruit and acidity integrating richly on the finish. It's a fine summer wine but also good for Thanksgiving turkey.

wine: Copain Wines 2017 Maggy Hawk Pinot Noir (Anderson Valley)
appellation: Anderson Valley, Mendocino County, California, US
review: This relatively light-bodied wine is broad and delicious, layering baking spices like cinnamon, vanilla and clove over considerable black-cherry flavors. It highlights the Anderson Valley's fresh fruitiness and supple texture.
With tight acidity and intense black currant fruits, this wine has a raw edge. It presents a full, fresh, crisp texture that's bright, with layers of acidity at the end.

wine: Boscoe 2015 Lizette Rancho Boa Vista Vineyard Grenache Blanc (Ballard Canyon)
appellation: Ballard Canyon, Central Coast, California, US
review: There's a compelling stony streak to the nose of this bottling, which shows crushed rock and the faintest hints of guava. The sip is extremely well textured, with acidity that rips through the rounded cherimoya-flesh and citrus-peel flavors into the finish.

This is a thick, rich and layered white from Oak Knoll District-grown estate fruit. It's inviting, with lemon chiffon, baked pineapple and anise. Medium bodied and not afraid to be robust, wet-stone minerality brings it together.

appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
review: Scents of smoke, forest floor and leather lend rustic elegance to this bright briskly concentrated wine. Blackberry and cherry flavors are pleasantly crisp, framed by soft ripe tannins and an earthy lingering finish.

appellation: Amarone della Valpolicella Valpantena, Veneto, Italy
review: Notes of clove, toasted nut and spicy, juniper-infused bresaola open the bouquet of this hearty effort. It sports a bright, polished, savory mouthfeel, with a distant touch of sweetness.

wine: El Enemigo 2017 El Barranco Single Vineyard Bonarda (Mendoza)
review: Black currant, dark plum and berry aromas are lightly floral and hint at herbs, giving this Bonarda an elegant nose. A juicy, lifted palate is pulpy but finessed. Raspberry, cherry and currant flavors are a touch reedy, while this tastes slightly of red licorice candy accented by herbs on the finish. Drink through 2025.
White peach and a bit of sweat accent the expiring bouquet, while the flavors are of dull, heavy apples dotted with sauerkraut and pickle accents. Imported by Kysela Pere et Fils, Ltd.

This opens with aromas of stewed prune, charred earth, orange peel and exotic spice. The palate is evolved, offering raisin, oak, espresso and an unusual note reminiscent of maple syrup but the fruit richness has already dried up.

wine: Lynmar 2014 Old Vines Chardonnay (Russian River Valley)
appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: This is a decidedly beautiful wine, a carefully crafted offering of Tahitian vanilla bean, caramelized apple and juicy peach that is integrated and buoyant in acidity. It continues to open and shine in the glass, getting better as it travels along the palate, with a lush finish of preserved lemon that just sings.

93–95. Barrel Sample. This is a rich wine, with notes of pineapple and peach that are balanced by a tight texture and attractive minerality. The wood aging just shows through, lending a spicy accent to the vibrant finish.

All juicy fruit, this is a bright, dry wine with delicious acidity that gives freshness. It also has a mineral edge, giving the red berry fruits a firm texture. The wine is ready to drink, although it will be better from 2016.

Starts out kind of murky and pasty, with gummy black fruit and compost aromas. Airing helps it escape that shell, and in the mouth there's rubbery blueberry flavors mixed with mildly tart rhubarb and bramble. Good enough, but doesn't do much to push the envelope that is Chilean Syrah.

wine: Novelty Hill 2016 Stillwater Creek Vineyard Syrah (Columbia Valley (WA))
appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Vanilla, barrel spice, raspberry and anise aromas lead to a mixture of blue and black fruit flavors with abundant barrel accents, with vanilla and nougat out front. Fruit and barrel seem to tussle, with the latter winning out.

wine: Bacigalupi 2014 Estate Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)
appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
review: Plum, sassafras and dark cherry form a contingency of flavor in this brooding, velvety smooth wine with a sizable finish. Cinnamon and clove are peppered throughout this full-bodied, well-made effort from the famous vineyard site.

wine: Lombard et Cie NV Brut Nature Grand Cru Blanc de Blancs Chardonnay (Champagne)
designation: Brut Nature Grand Cru Blanc de Blancs
review: This is an impressive wine. From the floral aromas to the crisp mineral-driven texture, the wine is tense, structured and very stylish. The apple, green plum and nervy texture are of a piece with the Chardonnay fruit from some of the finest villages in the Côte des Blancs. Drink this wine now.

wine: J. & P. Matheus 2017 Piesporter Michelsberg QBA Riesling (Mosel)
review: Dusty, spicy mineral notes lend an earthen tone to pressed apple and grapefruit juice here. It's a juicy but unpolished off-dry wine. Drink now.

A generous blend of Alicante Bouschet, Touriga Nacional, Aragonez and Syrah, this is firm with tannins and packed with ripe blackberry fruits. Six months in wood added a toasty character enhancing the complexity and depth of the wine. Drink from 2019.

wine: Langlois-Chateau NV Brut Rosé Sparkling (Crémant de Loire)
appellation: Crémant de Loire, Loire Valley, France
review: With some tannins, this is a full-bodied and ripe sparkling rosé. It has strong wild strawberry flavors that give the wine a very fruity character. A sense of structure enhances the naturally rich nature of the wine.

wine: Falua 2019 Conde Vimioso Colheita Seleccionada Red (Tejo)
review: This is a ripe, juicy wine, full of berry flavors and attractive acidity. Lightly textured, the wine has freshness that comes through at the end, contrasting with the black fruits. Drink now.

wine: Camille Giroud 2003 Beaune Premier Cru Les Avaux  (Beaune)
review: A ripe, juicy wine, one that has a good balance between new wood, acidity and fresh red fruit flavors. Its dry tannins suggest aging potential. It's a good, solid wine, already delicious but will develop well. Imported by Veritas Wines.

appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
review: Five clones are blended in this barrel-fermented wine. It's young, sharp and toasty (from just 10% new oak). Fruits are light and recall yellow apples and a touch of citrus.

wine: Four Degrees of Riesling 2009 1st Degree Riesling (Seneca Lake)
appellation: Seneca Lake, Finger Lakes, New York, US
review: The second in Three Brothers' series of four Rieslings, this wine would be more accurately described as semisweet. There's a familiar hint of fennel and petroleum on the nose here, contrasted by a bright lemon-honey sweetness and hints of grapefruit.

wine: Hawkstone 2010 Barney's Heritage Cuvee Chardonnay (Napa Valley)
review: Strikes a nice balance between opulence and subtlety, offering pleasant orange, pear and subtle oak flavors that are balanced with a dry minerality. Feels fine and balanced, an elegant Chardonnay to drink with roast salmon, pork, butternut squash risotto.

wine: Albert Bichot 2014 Lavaux Saint-Jacques Premier Cru  (Gevrey-Chambertin)
review: This rich wine is dense with dark tannins and concentrated structure. The vineyard, with cool winds from the valley behind, gives wines that demand aging with their tannins and fragrant fruit. The aftertaste is full of promise. Drink after 2022.

Partially wood aged, this perfumed wine is full of rich fruits and generous tannins. It also has the structure to age well for several years. There is a strong texture of minerality as well as the bite of tight acidity. Drink the wine from 2022.

appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
review: Spicy ginger and smoke tones meld with ripe grapefruit on this unusually refreshing Gewürztraminer. The palate is juicy with characteristic lychee and rose-petal flavors, but brisk and bright, with a shower of lemony acidity.

appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
review: Earthy aromas of pinched sage, turned soil and mace meet with smashed red plum on the nose of this bottling. The palate is packed with sage, thyme and orange rind flavors that play against the cranberry backbone.

wine: Dr. Pauly Bergweiler 2016 Wehlener Sonnenuhr Kabinett Riesling (Mosel)
review: Ripe, sweet yellow peach and tangerine flavors are shaded by darker tones of smoke and sea water in this slightly rustic, savory kabinett. It's well balanced by acidity and the finish is refreshing and crisp.

appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Pale in color, a delicate wine, with tea, cola, and smoky aromas. Turns fruity in the mouth, with light flavors suggesting black raspberries and red cherries. Nicely dry, with crisp acidity. Clean and vibrant, if not very complex.

wine: Uggiano 2015 La Casa di Dante Alighieri  (Chianti Colli Fiorentini)
review: This laid-back blend of 90% Sangiovese and 10% Cabernet Sauvignon opens with iris and underbrush aromas. The bright, simple palate evokes red cherry and green tea, blanketed in soft tannins. Enjoy soon.

Crisp, green and steely, this is classic Chablis, all about pure green fruits and minerality, only lightly layered with wood. It is vibrant and fresh, with the acidity adding a mouthwatering lightness.

appellation: Templeton Gap District, Central Coast, California, US
review: A dark, fuschia-like shade of pink, this rosé blend of Syrah, Grenache and Viognier smells like rust, cherries and earthy raspberry on the nose. The palate combines an array of red fruit with hints of herb and mint, proving quite bold.

This entry level cuvée is finished with a screw cap, and pulled from a mix of barrels and clones from across the estate. It's forward, fruity and big, like an especially bold Beaujolais. Along with primary berry fruit there are light touches of pine needle and chocolate. It's full bodied and ready to go with your winter meal's roasted fowl.
This wine's light, sugary, red cherry and watermelon aromas lead to similar flavors and a light, lean texture. It has a bright coral color that's eye-catching.

wine: Freiherr Heyl zu Herrnsheim 2003 Baron Heyl Nierstein Kabinett Riesling (Rheinhessen)
review: Herrnsheim tends toward a drier style of wine without labeling it as such, so this kabinett is crisp and almost dry-tasting. Apple blossoms and limes on the nose are complemented by hints of diesel and a tart, steely finish.

Dark, tight and masculine smelling, San Román is once again one of the two or three best wines from Toro. This vintage is black, extracted and super ripe, but it maintains a fine level of balance and more than adequate freshness. Flavors of coconut, vanilla and chocolate announce generous new oak, as does mocha and espresso on the finish. Heady but ready; ageable for another 5–8 years.

wine: La Selva 2015 Colli dell'Uccellina Riserva  (Morellino di Scansano)
review: A blend of 85% Sangiovese and 15% Merlot, this has aromas of baked plum, leather and a balsamic whiff of eucalyptus. Soft, juicy and full bodied, the palate offers black cherry, prune and licorice alongside velvety tannins. It's already hit its ideal drinking window so enjoy sooner rather than later.

Produced from vines on the plain of Saint-Émilion near the Dordogne river, this is a Merlot-dominated wine. It has big tannins, bold ripe fruit and a dark core of dryness. As with so many wines in this vintage, the fruitiness makes it work so well, ripe and bold black fruits that are finished off with acidity. Drink from 2018.

wine: Stonehouse Cellars 2016 Bonaria, Barrel 3 Cabernet Sauvignon (Lake County)
appellation: Lake County, Lake County, California, US
review: This wine is sturdily built, supporting good ripe fruit flavors with firm tannins and acidity that give a very textural mouthfeel. Aromas of cedar, cloves and baking spices complement black cherry and vanilla flavors—a good wine for people who appreciate some tannin.

appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Coming from fruit from Yakima Valley and Red Mountain, Grenache and Syrah (37%) play equal parts, with the rest Mourvèdre (26%). The aromas intrigue, with notes of flower, orange peel, freshly ground black pepper, blackberry jam and green herbs. The palate shows a lovely sense of deftness, balance and detail to the fruit and herb flavors that keep the interest up.

Tasted from a half bottle, the rich and complex flavors of Brut La Française show just that extra touch of maturity. The wine has peach and almond flavors that contrast well with the taut, nervy edge. It's full in the mouth and ripe, and works well both as an apéritif and a food Champagne.

A lovely and light aroma of faint honeysuckle rises enticingly from the glass. The spiciness and florality of that same blossom also appear on the palate where they are joined by pear and wet earth notes. This is light and just a little fruity but with ample freshness—an easy but subtle and refreshing classic Alsace blend.

Savory whiffs of clay and smoked nuts belie the pristine white peach and grapefruit flavors that flood the palate of this semidry Riesling. It's juicy and primary, but irresistibly so, finishing on a lingering note of spice and saffron.

appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: Slightly simple but pleasurable aromas of pomegranate, black raspberry, light cocoa and caramel candy show on the nose of this bottling. The structure is also airy, but it's easy to enjoy with ripe strawberry and boysenberry flavors.

wine: JM Cellars 2013 Margaret's Vineyard Estate Red (Walla Walla Valley (WA))
appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Cabernet Sauvignon (45%) takes the lead on this blend, followed by Merlot (30%), Cabernet Franc (20%) and Petit Verdot. The aromas are all high toned, with notes of vanilla, herb and dark fruit. The black-fruit flavors are tightly wound, needing time in the cellar to stretch their legs. Best after 2020.

wine: Telmo Rodríguez 2003 MR Mountain Wine Moscatel (Málaga)
review: Even if this Moscatel begins with waxy aromas and whiffs of hard cheese, it is one excellent elixir. The palate will please with its honey, sweet melon and guava flavors, while the additional notes of white pepper and green melon add foundation. Excellent for the price, and it won't require a Master's degree in wine to enjoy. Imported by Jorge Ordoñez/Fine Estates from Spain.

There's a traditional, Gevrey-meat note to the nose of this dark-fruited wine. It's creamy and mouthfilling, with black cherry flavors that pick up hints of anise on the finish. A blend of villages fruit with bits from two premier crus.

wine: San Pedro 2014 1865 Single Vineyard Carmenère (Maule Valley)
review: Woody berry aromas come with more than enough olive, green spice and eucalyptus notes. On the palate, this is good but lacks tension and specificity. Flavors of creamy oak, blueberry and boysenberry are herbal and finish without much definition.

wine: Page Mill Winery 2018 Chandler Vineyard Chardonnay (Livermore Valley)
appellation: Livermore Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: Bold butter and toasted-oak flavors give this full-bodied wine an assertive personality, while a rich, smooth texture pulls the big flavors together nicely.

wine: Alain Jaume et Fils 2010 Grande Garrigue Red (Vacqueyras)
review: A perennial winner, Grande Garrigue is a medium- to full-bodied wine with supple tannins and ample cherry fruit. This vintage shows a hint of asphalt upfront, then dark tones of earth and chocolate on the velvety finish. Drink now–2022.

By sourcing French Colombard and force carbonating like beer, David Potter made this fun and tasty wine as an antidote to the high prices that sparkling wine traditionally require. Aromas of apple cider, crisp Granny Smith apples, key lime, yellow melon and chalk lead into a palate laced with fatter bubbles and flavors of more apple and pear.

This wine's crusty, minerally aromas of black fruit are lightly toasted and earthy. On the palate, it feels tannic and high in acidity, with roasted, earthy flavors of plum and raspberry. Concentrated and grabby on the finish, it has a touch of lemony oak and astringency.

This wine, sourced from organically grown grapes and made by German ex-pats, shows plenty of waxy lemon, pineapple rind and green bean characters, with white pepper and mint aromas adding complexity. The palate is downright opulent—textural weight is balanced by tingly acidity with a salty finish.

appellation: Anderson Valley, Mendocino County, California, US
review: This emphasizes freshness and a light touch, rather than the assertive flavors that this varietal can produce. It smells like rose petals, has a soft texture, rose petal and pear flavors, and delivers a light spritzy feeling on the tongue.

Peachy aromas are friendly, while the palate has a good feel to it along with green flavors of melon, lime and fresh veggies. Finishes with fruit, dryness and a touch of bitterness, yet in the end it fails to deliver on the promise of the bouquet.

wine: Lucy 2006 Rosé of Pinot Noir Pinot Noir (Santa Lucia Highlands)
appellation: Santa Lucia Highlands, Central Coast, California, US
review: I love this wine. It's more like a Provençal rosé than almost anything out there, even though it's made from Pinot Noir. Dry, crisp and silky, it has interesting waves of cherryskin, rosehip tea, tobacco, vanilla and peppery spice flavors, and finishes impressively long.

Pure, deep berry aromas are accented by quality oak and a hint of earthy prune. Chewy, dense and concentrated on the palate, this tastes ripe, chocolaty and earthy, with blackberry and pepper flavors that stay the course and finish peppery and dark, with a mild note of rubber. Drink through 2019.
87-89 Soft wine, its acidity light. Pineapple and green apple flavors, with hints of wood.

wine: Cielo e Terra NV Deor Raboso Rosé Spago Raboso (Delle Venezie)
review: This pale-pink sparkler, with large, chunky bubbles, offers aromas of mature berry, violet and rose. It's an easy wine that should be a good apéritif.

Plum, cherry and berry aromas are standard but clean and fresh. Following the nose, this everyday Tempranillo from the Valdelana family feels spunky and bouncy, with rubbery tannins. Generic plum and berry flavors finish snappy and bright.

wine: Betz Family 2018 La Côte Rousse Syrah (Red Mountain)
appellation: Red Mountain, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Cofermented with 6% Viognier, the aromas are lifted, with notes of boysenberry pie, fresh flower and orange peel. It's a mouthful of blue- and purple-fruit flavors, showing impressive freshness and deftness for this warm appellation.
Rustic, with sharp, green flavors of blackberries and chocolate-covered mints.

A blend of Cabernet Sauvignon, Merlot and Syrah. Has reserved aromas of black cherry and plum, and a solid core of black-cherry and berry fruit and spice. Dry and well balanced, not fat. Has a lot of white-tablecloth elegance. Intense, with powerful acids, but maybe just a little muddled on the midpalate.

wine: Camins 2 Dreams 2018 Spear Vineyards Grüner Veltliner (Sta. Rita Hills)
appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
review: Tightly woven aromas of lime skin, chalk and honeydew rind show on the nose of this rare Grüner Veltliner from Santa Barbara County, made by married couple Tara Gomez and Mireia Taribó. There is tremendous tension to the sip, offering lime skin and intriguing white-pepper flavors.

wine: Foxen 7200 2012 Range 30 West Red (Happy Canyon of Santa Barbara)
appellation: Happy Canyon of Santa Barbara, Central Coast, California, US
review: Winemaker Billy Wathen blends 60% Merlot and 40% Cabernet Franc into this blend that's named after the U.S. Geologic Survey's name for Happy Canyon. A nose of dried oregano and thyme has a Bing cherry backdrop, with a palate of green peppers, blackberries and tomato leaf.
With its layers of wood, the wine has weight. Herbaceous characters are mixed with ripe pear flavors. There is a good, tight final texture.

wine: Clos Solène 2013 Hommage A Nois Pairs Reserve Red (Paso Robles)
appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: An extremely dark wine, with purple bubbles, this blend of 94% Syrah, 4% Grenache and 2% Roussanne expresses the essence of dark, extracted fruit all around. The nose shows blackberry puree, fresh lilacs, lava rocks and background pepper and vanilla. The palate is rich with espresso bean, violets, lavender and dried blueberries, lifted by minty herbs and peppery spice.

wine: Vini 2013 Veni Vidi Vici Merlot (Thracian Valley)
review: Ruby red with garnet hues in color, this easy-drinking Merlot brings aromas of cherry, black berry and black raspberry on the nose. Tones of black plum and black cherry are ripe and persistent on the finish.

appellation: Vin de France, France Other, France
review: Made from Grenache, this fresh and deliciously fruity wine has a soft side from its ripe berry fruits and warm acidity. Produced in Languedoc, the wine has a sunny character, full of life and lightness.

Here is an expressive Chardonnay from the far north of Italy that delivers beauty and harmony in the form of mature peach, honey roasted almond, butterscotch and sweet lemon zest. The wine boasts thick, creamy density and lively fruit flavors on the long finish.

This is an impressive bottling primarily from grapes, including 4% Merlot, grown in the Santa Rosa Valley near the Ventura County city of Camarillo. Dried and bloody beef, black currant and cracked black pepper show on the nose, while the palate offers an intriguing array of charred bacon fat, violet, cassis and more pepper.

wine: Steven Kent 2007 Ghielmetti Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Livermore Valley)
appellation: Livermore Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: Give this Cabernet some time in the cellar. Right now, it's a little tough in acids and tannins, although the blackberry, cherry, black currant and smoky oak flavors are rich and fine and enjoyable now. But it should soften and be even more approachable after 2013.

wine: Saarloos & Sons 2008 194Five The Union Red (Santa Ynez Valley)
appellation: Santa Ynez Valley, Central Coast, California, US
review: Simple and jammy, with black cherry, black raspberry and chocolate chip cupcake flavors. Saved by smooth, polished tannins.

appellation: El Dorado, Sierra Foothills, California, US
review: Excellent fruit concentration and tasty, judicious oak spices are ably supported by moderate tannins in this full-bodied, well-structured wine. Blackberries and black cherries are dusted with cocoa and nutmeg accents. This makes two out of two stand-out wines Wine Enthusiast has reviewed from newcomer Kehret, where Steve Leveque is master winemaker. Best from 2024.
Sweet new oak brings a jacket of buttered cinnamon toast to this soft, ripe Cabernet. The fruit flavors range from blackberries and cherries to currants and mocha. Easy to drink this wine now.

While ebulliently floral and fruity with notes of orange blossom and white peach, a bracing hit of lemon balm and lime zest make this bright, brisk Grüner Veltliner especially refreshing. It lingers long on the palate with a bristling minerality.

appellation: Mendocino County, Mendocino County, California, US
review: Ripe and bold in flavor, this polished, focused wine is full bodied and firmly tannic. It has effusive blackberry aromas and wonderfully dry, concentrated flavors.

wine: Val di Suga 2010  Brunello di Montalcino
review: Spiced plum, mocha, leather and Mediterranean herb are some of the aromas that jump from the glass. The one-dimensional palate delivers oak, anisette, stewed plum, vanilla, menthol and a confectionary note alongside drying tannins.

appellation: Central Coast, Central Coast, California, US
review: This is quite a good Cab for the ripe currant and black cherry flavors, firm tannins and smooth mouthfeel. It has that fancy complexity you want from a good red wine, and is priced fairly for the quality.

This wine was whole-cluster pressed and puncheon fermented, with native malolactic fermentation. It's intriguing, with aromas of corn on the cob, lees, almond butter and chamomile that are followed by a dense flavorful palate. The balance is exquisite.

appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
review: There's a lot of raw power on this jumbled red that starts with rubber and spice before settling on maple. The mouth is a cacaphony of loud flavors, while the finish is stark. Needs finesse to match the aggressiveness.

Starts out “smoky” but quickly degenerates toward murky and stemmy smelling. The palate has a bland feel along with roasted, leafy, dried-out flavors of raspberry and earthy plum. Not a prime-time wine.

Bright in aromas of pineapple, lemon and green apple, but also boasting sweet cream and yeastiness, this wine is layered on the nose. Zippy and fresh, with ample acidity and flavors of subdued lemon and pineapple, it's an easy wine to pair with dishes from halibut to a more robust pork chop.

wine: Korta Katarina 2010 Plavac Mali and Zinfandel Rosé (Peljesac)
review: The lavors of candied red cherry and flower are pleasant, but dusty herb notes distract on the nose and palate. It's a big wine at 13.9% abv, but zesty acidity keeps it relatively balanced.

wine: Adegas Gran Vinum 2015 Selección Especial Albariño (Rías Baixas)
review: Citrus, mineral and honey aromas are good but not all that complex. This feels full and weighty, with nectarine and orange flavors. On the finish, dry citrus flavors are round and lasting but low on elegance. Drink now.

wine: Lava Cap 2017 Estate Bottled Cabernet Franc (El Dorado)
appellation: El Dorado, Sierra Foothills, California, US
review: This is a serious, age-worthy wine that's big in structure yet refined in texture and generous in black-fruit flavors while staying firm, dry and a touch restrained. It's easy to appreciate its layers of dark chocolate, black fig, dark cherry, mint and tobacco that are framed by fine-grained tannins. Best from 2026.

wine: Zanoli 2016 Glenrose Vineyard Rows RR & SS Syrah (Adelaida District)
appellation: Adelaida District, Central Coast, California, US
review: Deep black-plum and blackberry aromas make for a hearty nose on this bottling, which comes from two specific rows. The mouthfeel is thick and the palate is framed by a strong acidity, carrying flavors of ripe boysenberry.
Subdued aromas of acacia, honey and toasted almond with a whiff of yellow stone fruit follow over to the palate along with fennel and dried apricot. Fresh acidity lifts the rather rich flavors.

wine: Cortes de Cima 2013 Homenagem a Hans Christian Andersen Syrah (Alentejano)
review: Drawing on his Danish heritage, owner Hans Jorgensen pays homage to the writer of fairy tales in this wine. It is dense with big tannins but also with fine spice, rich black-fruit flavors and great concentration. It is a powerful wine that, with its tannins, should age further. Drink from late 2019.

appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
review: Firm, tart berry fruit, annotated with dried herb and leaf. The tannins are nicely smoothed out, though the wine finishes with a slightly chalky aftertaste.

Barolo Ciabot Manzoni is a tremendous wine with rich notes of cherry, vanilla and chocolate. Yes, it's a bold, modern wine but there's no denying the quality and beauty here. Give it more time in the cellar to allow those oak notes to integrate and give more prominence to the sophisticated aromas of wild berries, mineral, cola and licorice that are generously present. A Marc de Grazia selection; various American importers.

wine: Midnight 2014 Mare Nectaris Reserve Red (Paso Robles)
appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
review: Candied violets, black currant candy, lilac and even a hint of jasmine show on the floral nose of this blend of 35% Cabernet Sauvignon, 35% Merlot, 17% Petit Verdot, 8% Malbec and 5% Cabernet Franc. Bright flavors of dark-purple fruit are leveled by a chalky mouthfeel, solid structure and ample acid.

appellation: Central Coast, Central Coast, California, US
review: This pale pink to slightly orange rosé shows tangerine, cantaloupe, cherry and sand aromas on the somewhat muddled nose. It's light in texture and a little flat on the palate but presents enjoyable squeezed lemon and watermelon flavors.

The big tannins indicate a wine with powerful potential. It has weight, richness, generous red fruits and a strong sense of structure. The freshness of the vintage comes through in the acidity at the end. Drink from 2018.
Aromas of smoke and rubber dominate on the nose of this rich and full-bodied wine. It has an earthy streak on the palate, too, but it has a fruit core that makes it enjoyable nonetheless.
